description:
I stopped into anchor & hope this week for a quick business lunch and much to my surprise, I loved everything about my experience. I was able to snag a bar seat (my fav) and get in/out in a fashionable amount of time. The bartender was super prompt,  very attentive and recommended the burger. 

The burger was really good, cooked perfectly mid rare and had a nice set of fries on the side. In fact, the fries might have stolen the show if it weren't for the fried onions atop the cheeseburger. The jalapeños on the burger were also a nice touch. 

I'll definitely be back for another lunch and have my eye on the little neck clams on the half shell. I was a bit too full but, next time...muahahhahaha.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Anchor + Hope serves very good seafood, but they also throw lots of fried food in your path and, although it's my will power that is at issue there really, I do wish they would make a bigger effort to offer more healthy snacks, sides and choices on the menu. 

I love the decor and setting at A+H. It's a loft-like dock-style room with ropes dangling from the rafters.  The seats are metal chairs and the tables are bare hardwood. It can get a little loud but that's part of the fun. Think boisterous send-off party vs romantic or business lunch. 

Fresh seafood here is first rate. The ceviche at A+H is one of the highlights, in my opinion: shrimp, fish, squid in a citrusy vinegrette served with house-made chips. It's delish. Their salmon, sand dabs, Louis salads are all made with fresh local creatures and prepared to showcase the seafood's flavor. Just avoid anything that says "battered" as it'll come in dough thicker than a kitchen mitt and drenched in oil. 

Their sandos -- lobster roll, burgers -- are served on brioche-type bread, and pretty much most folks I've eaten with there say it's just too much bread. They wind up taking half the bread off. I'd say skip the sandwiches and go for fresh fish. 

There's a decent wine list and beer selection here.
author: Lanny B.

description:
Happy hour was yummy with reasonable priced drinks and apps. We ordered about 2 dozen oysters, mussels, fries & some Pinot Grigio to wash it all down.

Overall, good happy hour but extremely hot & stuffy. And we were basically told as we were sitting down that we had to leave by a certain time because a large party was coming in which didn't make us feel very welcomed...
author: My N.

description:
I was walking down the area and was thinking of getting oysters for HH and by chance saw their sign outside for their $1 oyster deal. To my surprise, Anchor & Hope was also one of the places I read about on an article of SF restaurants serving lobster rolls. 

Anchor & Hope has a pretty upscale decor and I enjoyed looking at the art work they had on their walls. Seems like dinner service here can get busy so I would recommend making a reservation ahead of time or getting here early enough to grab spots at the bar where they don't have a time limit. 

TIP: HH is 4PM-6PM

+ $1 oysters for HH - The oysters are on the smaller side of things but for $1 I'll take them. They pair them with their own mignonette sauce & cocktail sauce on the side. 

+ Lobster Roll ($31) - I'm a sucker for lobster rolls and this one was a roll I had to try. Was it worth $31? In my opinion not really, but I am glad I tried it. The lobster wasn't overcooked but there was few pieces of it. However, the bread they paired it was nice and fluffy/buttery that it just melted in your mouth. I wish they had some extra melted butter on the side for dipping as well, but you can only get it dressed in butter or aioli. The lobster roll is also paired with 5 of their tater tots and coleslaw. The tater tots was perfectly crispy while the coleslaw offered a nice bite/change in texture from the rest of the dish. 

We also grabbed some of their $5 HH drinks. They have a stout, hefe, and from what I remember two wine options. 

Service at the bar was also pretty hands off. If you want to see the full dinner menu you'll need to ask your server.  

Overall, Anchor & Hope was a nice place to try in SF, but I gotta admit, New England Lobster still has my lobster roll loving heart. Their happy hour menu wins you over with their $1 oysters, but the rest of the menu doesn't have other unique options that would entice me to come back as I could go to other places for a cheaper price.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
Came for a work lunch a few months ago. If you have a hard stop don't do it, took about 50 minutes for our food; service was pretty bad. It was one of those "ask the waiter a million things because you only see them once every 20 minutes" deal. 

The decor was pretty neat- big open space with seashore/modern vibes, but quite loud due to the tall ceilings. The food playing was gorgeous, but flavor fell short :( Calamari was under seasoned and too greasy from the breading. My fish tacos were oily, too fishy for my liking (though gorgeous). A friend complained that the fried chicken burger was just all batter and bread. 

Overall sadly a forgettable/mediocre experience; hell it did take me three months to review, probably won't return.
author: Tash B.

description:
Paula J. chose this restaurant and I'm so glad she did!

Reservations were made on the fly just an hour earlier and we luckily got a seating for 5 on a Saturday night.

Other than our Uber driver not knowing where to drop us off, my first impression was that Anchor & Hope felt like SF.

Modern soft lighting, the tinkling of cutlery and glasses, and the loud buzz of many conversations all at once. The noise level actually got louder throughout the night but I couldn't be sure if that was because our party of 5 or the incoming patrons.

The food was well prepared, well seasoned and delicious in its simplicity. Let the fresh ingredients shine I always like to think. Here, they do just that.

Only small glitch was the overly long wait for my friend's daughters' meal. It seemed the wait staff forgot about it despite several reminders. 

I'd like to come back and sample more of the intriguing menu!
author: Sharon H.

description: This place was recommended to us by the concierge at the Four Seasons Hotel. The place is beautiful. The food is disappointing. I ordered grilled oysters and for $16 I got 2 of the world's smallest most tasteless shriveled "oysters". My friend ordered the grilled little gem app and it's was less than average. The chowder was outstanding, no argument there. Wine by the glass @ $17 - no thanks. The total bill for 2 apps and 2 bowls of soup, 2 glasses of wine and a desert was $190. Sorry, not worth it. If you want good honest seafood, go to Woodhouse Fish Co. on Fillmore or Market. The photo attached is how you do grilled oysters right
author: Katie B.

description: This is a $31 lobster grinder. The most expensive I've ever seen and I've had hundreds in my lifetime. I would never have eaten at such a pricey place but my hotel sent me and said it was the best. But it was the worst!  The lobster was TOUGH!  The cole slaw was rotten. I sent it back and left. I am eating at my Hotel restaurant (Courtyard by Marriott) which is way better.
author: Paula H.

description: Damn fine establishment to rediscover what the meaning of American hamburger means.  I will be back.  And I will bring friends.
author: Michael V.

description: This use to be one of my favorite restaurants, the food is great But the quality of customer service was very very poor. From no smiles at the door while sitting us down, from only taking orders for drinks and appetizers, coming back later after 20 minutes and then taking our entrée orders, to expecting us to move all of the dishes around the table to make room for our actual meals, To hardly filling up our glasses of water, From letting our empty glasses and empty beer bottles on the table leaving no room to really eat our actual meals. Our waiter didn't even ask if our food was good or if there was anything else we needed, my friends had to get up and find him. It was just really upsetting and to make matters worse, I bragged about this restaurant. All six of us were very disappointed and it was shown in their tip. This restaurant is not cheap, I expected much higher quality customer service especially after how much we spent.
author: Mari B.

description:
Went to Anchor and Hope on a Saturday night. We were one of the first people there and were greeted by a very unfriendly hostess. She sat us at the table right next to the only other table with people seated, which was strange because they had just opened and every other table was available. When we asked if we could move she seemed frustrated, but allowed us to move a couple tables down. 
Aside from the strange entrance we had a lovely time and the rest of the staff was very friendly. The small seafood platter was amazing and tasted very fresh. I ordered the halibut with my entree and it was delicious. I would definitely recommend giving anchor and hope a shot, but maybe make a reservation to avoid having to deal with the hostess.
author: Teresa M.

description:
The Good

Nice atmosphere. Interesting menu. My entree (sole) was great and properly priced. The bacon-wrapped scallops appetizer was also great.

They serve homemade chips with a spiced mayo that was also popular.

Ryan did a great job setting up our reservation and communicating.

The Bad.

Service was iffy. I asked for a cocktail menu and my waitress said they did not have cocktails, just wine and beer. I think she meant they didn't have a specific menu for cocktails because I later saw a list of cocktails at the top of the drink menu. So I ordered a beer. Wa. :-(

Screwed up on how to split the check after I was clear about how we wanted it.

The seafood plateau was not worth the $60.

Dessert was meh. A peach crisp that was equivalent to a frozen Marie Callender's dish.

Also, no points off for this, but their website has been borked for like 6 weeks now.

Overall, we had a good night, but will not return.
author: Wolf H.

description:
Came here on a whim to try to find a decent place with seafood.  When we first arrived they gave us some chips and dip.  Oh boy just this alone was so satisfying and filling.  I don't know what is in the dip but it is so good! 

The lobster roll and salmon were so fresh! Highly recommend each of them.
author: Michelle T.

description: Cool space that has a warehouse feel. Seafood is their focus. The food I had was wanting sadly. The salmon tartare was a little fishy, the butter squash soup was OK but bland. I liked the panna cotta.
author: Sunil R.

description:
I've never thought it was fair to judge a restaurant based on a large event. Have you tried to serve 100 people all at once? I've tried 20-30 and let me tell you it's not my best work

However when someone pulls it off as elegantly as Anchor & Hope, you can only imagine what their normal day to day is like.

I was there for a private event and it started with a cheese station and passed apps. The shrimp fritters and crab cake balls with perfectly crispy and    The sauces paired with each complimented them.  The duck mushroom whatever was to die for! Here I am thinking I could sit here drinking beers off their amazing beer menu eating these little bites of heaven all night when they announced dinner was up.

As I look over at the buffet style serving my first thoughts are bland over cooked food. This was anything but that. They salmon had the perfect crispy skin that most chefs can't get on their best day and was cooked a perfect medium well. (I like medium rare but again we are at a large event where preferences vary so medium well was a safe bet) the lentils they rested on were a perfect pair. Next was handmade gnocchi that were soft pillows of yummy goodness. I think the next item was pork belly or the most tender pork rib I've ever had. Either way amazing!

This is definitely a place I'm bookmarking so I am return!
author: Michelle S.

description:
As recent-ish returnees to the area, we found in the five years we were away living in another great food town we missed some major restaurant goings-on back home in the Bay Area, and yes, that includes beloved Townhall and it's sibling, Anchor and Hope.  Walking down a downtown alley into a modern, light wood and high ceiling space, didn't disappoint. The space has a Pacific Northwest feel. We came for drinks and tastes before a reservation elsewhere, but we hoped the feeling and food would inspire a return visit.  All around us large seafood towers were being placed on adjacent tables, leading us to conclude we had to try one. Our baby seafood tower (we got the smallest one) came quickly, as did the fresh ceviche and house potato chips and drinks.

The space was beautiful overall and the fish impeccably fresh, but service was a little bumpy, despite trying to communicate a limited time window. Overall a nice place for the fresh and raw, but not for the hurried.
author: Rachel H.

description:
I work nearby and love seafood.  Inevitably I had to eat here...

Had the Beer battered Flounder w/ Fries and Tartar sauce.  The fish was tasty; It was happily in b/t crunch and juicy!  It was on a bed of hardened, bland fries unfortunately, and I love fries, but I couldn't eat them, sadly.  The fries had speckles of black rotten parts too.

I had the Clam Chowder bowl.  It was served only lukewarm, and the seafood inside was tenderly fresh.  I don't prefer chunky carrots in my Clam Chowder, and I think it needs more leeks to balance out the soup flavor although it wasn't too milky nor creamy.  

I also had the Dungeoness Crab Roll w/ Giant Tots and Coleslaw.  The crab was delicious but overly salted, and the toast it was in was the proper vessel to transport this "dungoodness."  The tots needed another round of deep frying as they were a bit mushy, but I commend the attempt of even creating such a labor intensive food.  The coleslaw could have been any ol' coleslaw; nothing special.  

Unfortunately, it's Anchor & Nope for me.
author: John M.

description:
Happy hour is great ($1 oysters, and yummy fries)

Have since returned for a lunch! Still retains its 4 star rating.
Attentive, yet relaxed service even through the busy lunch hour.

Food was splendid - no complains, and servings were all very fair for the price and location!

Chips - free app! Fresh fried potato chip.. the mayo (?) it came with complemented it perfectly.
Calamari - again, fair portion. Fried nicely, not too much batter and just enough salt.
Brussel sprouts - $7 - fair portion. Roasted - soft and cooked through, seasoned perfectly. I prefer a more crisp and fried brussel sprout. As long as a brussel sprout is cooked and seasoned, I'm not going to complain!
Crab louie salad - $29 but HEAPING!!! I was only able to finish half. Very generous with the crab and greens. Dressing on point.
author: Emily C.

description: Anchor and hope has one of the best happy hours in soma. $1 oysters, who can beat that? Affordable wine and beer options as well. The ambiance is fantastic, high ceilings and great decor. The bar gets to be a bit crowded because of the awesome happy hour, so get there early if you want a seat. The other happy hour food options are also delicious and affordable.
author: Mollie H.

description:
One of my best friends is in town visiting and we decided to come here for happy hour dollar oysters. I reserved a table for 5:45 PM.

Upon arriving, the hostess asked me if we were here for dinner service. I said yes, but we'd also like to order off the happy hour menu before happy hour ended at 6 PM. She said that if we reserved a dinner table we weren't allowed to order off the happy hour menu as happy hour was "walk-ins only," and then said that if we did want to order off the happy hour menu and still sit at the table we reserved, she could make an exception but we would have to give up our table at 6:30 PM and leave. I was unsure if I actually heard her correctly as this sounded like an absolutely absurd policy, so I responded for confirmation, "So you're telling me that I'm not allowed to order off the happy hour menu because it's 'walk-in' only? And that you can make an exception but that we would get kicked out of the restaurant at 6:30 PM and have to give up our table?" She looked at me, completely serious, and responded "That is correct as we are booked for the rest of the evening."

I didn't want to be hassled with finding another place to go, so I told her fine, we'll do dinner service only. As soon as I sat down at our table, I saw people getting up from the bar and leaving, and more people walking into the restaurant and heading straight for the bar to sit down without even stopping by the hostess stand. At that point, I went up and asked one of bartenders if the bar was open seating. I was told that it was, that we could stay as long as we wanted and could order off BOTH the dinner and the happy hour menu there as the bar was FULL SERVICE. *Insert Facepalm Emoji* Why didn't the hostess just SAY so then?! A simple "Reservations are for dinner service only, but the bar is full service and first-come-first-served" would have saved me so much time and prevented confusion. What a waste of time and a convoluted answer to such a simple problem!

In any case, once my friend and I got situated, we ordered two dozen dollar oysters, a seafood platter (with clams, shrimp, remoulade, ceviche, etc.), and finally a plate of mussels along with some wine. The food was average at best, and some of the oysters were very grimy and had chunks of mud/seaweed/sea gunk on them. But no matter. We were there to catch up and have a good time so we just ate our food and kept to ourselves!

While we reminisced about our life back in the Midwest, we asked the bartender out of curiosity if they carried Malort, a type of alcohol popular in the Midwest but seemingly nowhere else. The bartender responded, "No...what is that?" As my friend began explaining to her what it was, the bartender turned her back and walked away from us while my friend was MID-SENTENCE. Mind you, the tab was ~$198 and we tipped the bartender ~$40. Guess the bartender figured since we already gave her a good chunk of money, she was no longer required to give a sh*t.

Bottom line - rude, unprofessional staff. Mediocre, forgettable food. Go somewhere else!
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Decent seafood-oriented restaurant with the main advantages being its business-friendly location, plus ambience and price points that aren't too formal or fancy. Smaller items like the oysters and the shrimp cocktail are decent and aren't unreasonably priced, while entrée-sized ones like the lobster roll - which approaches $30 - are rather unmemorable.

Indeed, it's very much a casual business lunch or post-work dinner sort of place with reasonable food that you'd rather not pay out of your own pocket, but isn't so expensive as to max out your expense account.
author: Vincent L.

description:
I always end up having weird ass dinners here but I do want to applaud them for the way they accommodated my friend who is in a wheel chair when I made dinner reservations here to celebrate my graduation. I made reservations for two via opentable and made a note that my friend was in a wheelchair and they had reserved us a pretty large table in a corner to accommodate him which I thought was very thoughtful. I always get a little worried when I make these opentable notes because I am not sure if the staff really pay attention to the requests but I am very happy they went out of their way to. 

I am dying to go to their shrimp boil next week but its literally only shrimp and beer which sounds like I might vomit. I was hoping it would be like other ones I've seen that are more like shrimp with corn, potatoes, garlic noodles, sausage, aka anything other than just shrimp!!!  I love shrimp more than anything but I can't even think about all you can eat shrimp with nothing else. I mean corn and potatoes are way cheaper and just fillers and would offer some variety.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
Anchor & Hope is a nice spot for seafood in the area. I've been there twice for lunch and it is definitely on the pricier side. Make a reservation as it can get a bit crowded after 12pm.

The complimentary chips are addicting. I tried to stay away from them but couldn't control myself.

I had the Petrale Sole that is prepared medium rare. It had a nice crust to it that I enjoyed. My dining companion had the massive Fish & Chips. It looked very good as well.
author: Yi Z.

description: Loses major points for snotty entitled waitstaff. Incompetent hostess and bartender who walked away from me mid sentence after I had tipped her generously on a large bill. Ruined the experience. Also the seafood platter is overpriced. Meh.
author: Amy S.

description:
Ceviche was a little foul when I ate it, flavors were incredible but every once in a while it'd be the taste of 3 day old fish.  Not bad but certainly worse than I expected at $16.  Lobster roll was wayyy too much bread, also added too much celery for my tastes (live in DC frequent NE).  For $31 in SF it was about how much you'd expect for meat.  However the quality must have been super low as the bartender assured me it's flown in every morning from Maine and it tasted frozen. 

Second star because the bartender was very nice and polite, answering my questions and knew the menu well.  The food was just not good.
author: Mike P.

description: I've come here for lunch 3 or 4 times now and I've gotta say they make the best fish & chips in the area.    Actually, let me be more precise:  they make the best beer battered fish in the area.   Their chips are just so-so.   That's why they don't get that 5th star...   Well, that and they're definitely on the pricier side.    But yeah, that beer-battered flounder is absolutely amazing!   The fish isn't dry.  It's juicy and tender and simply delectable.    I've also tried "angels on a horseback", which is essentially bacon wrapped oysters.   They were tasty but nothing special.   Naaahhh.... This place is all about that beer-battered flounder.   Yumminess!
author: David O.

description:
Great ambience and great food. Our waiter was very knowledgeable and Sid not try to over sell the menu
Very happy to have had dinner here
Had steak and then saw the fish dishes coming out of the kitchen. Should have got fish instead. But the steak was excellent- no
Highly recommended
author: Cecil W.

description:
Only been here for happy hour and it's lovely.  $1 oysters are yum! Plus they have clams for $1.5 NICE!  Their bubbles selection is rather limited which isn't nice for me since I love bubbles but I have heard that their beer selection is good.

Service is always nice and efficient which I imagine can be a challenge because the restaurant is often overrun by loads of office ppl in the area so kudos to the staff for still making it welcoming and fun.  Place is clean.
author: Lev E.

description:
OK Food, server with attitude.

Hate to write these kind of reviews but....

Kids met me in the city after work and they had already eaten.  Stumbled upon this place around  6pm and explained very clearly to Maitre D that we were only looking for a couple of apps and a drink and didn't want to take a table if it didn't suit.  She said no probs, they just needed the table back by 7pm.

Server dude comes out and I explain we're just having a couple of apps yadda yadda and he says "yeah, I heard".  Strike one.

So we order drinks and the guy comes to take our food order.  I'd picked out a few apps, mostly just for me, but started by ordering a cup of chowder for my son and server boy butts in with "A cup of chowder?  For the whole table"?   And this in a snarky tone you just don't use with customers.   Strike two.... but I kept my cool, mostly because my kids all got that look of fear when they know Dad is about to go ballistic on someone.

So I say "No" as nicely as I can and start to repeat the order,  starting with the offending chowder at which point server boy breaks in again with "A cup of chowder?  For the whole table"?  Strike three.

At this point I don't know if he's stupid, bored, hates his life, or is just unsuited for customer service.  And honestly I don't care.  I got the rest of the food ordered without snapping, the food was OK, we were out of there in short order.  I mean I get it, we weren't going to be a big ticket for this guy.  But I explained that very clearly when we went in and we were out before dinner hour really started.  If you get a table like that, a professional handles it with grace and class and treats the customer the same as he would a big ticket table.  If you can't do that you shouldn't be in the business.
author: Gilford S.

description:
2 of our party of 9 had the seafood tower: shrimp clearly had been on ice for a while - limp, tasteless. Had 9 on our table. 2 people shared the seafood tower. Waiter strongly suggested we have that before our main course.....which meant all 7 of the rest of our party waited until that 'appetizer' was finished before all our main courses arrived. Thoughtless.
They did top up the chips on the table, but surely that was a sign that those other 7 diners were about chewing their arms off with the hour wait.

So, rest of the food was OK. The 'angels' on horseback were absolutely awful. The fresh oysters in the seafood tower were fine. Maybe the fried oysters were off. I have never had such a rank taste from fried oysters. We almost had to spit them out. 

Go for the cool space, but on this occasion, the food and mis-call on the sequencing of service was a real let-down.
author: Cameron D.

description: Had lunch here.  The bun on the Lobster Roll was over-toasted; it was crunchy and on the dry side; the bread should be just lightly toasted with the inside of the bun still soft.  I also didn't care for the dressing.  The Beer Battered Flounder was extremely oily, as if the fry oil wasn't hot enough.  The calamari just okay.  The "tater tots" were good, as were the home fried chips.  I ate at this restaurant several times many years ago and I was disappointed to find it wasn't nearly as good.
author: J W.

description:
Staying at the W and needed a casual place that could accommodate a party of 8 on a Monday when there's a gaming convention in town. I wasn't a part of the convention, although they took over my hotel. Luckily we got to escape the hoards of game developers/players and had a decent meal just a few blocks away. 

The Anchor & Hope is really a 3.5 star restaurant. I would describe it as moderate with some shining points. Our server made some good recommendations--Sancerre, check; salmon, check; oyster appetizer, check; lobster roll, not so much.  

To be honest, I know better than to order a lobster roll--we're too far from the choice lobster haven of New England, but my colleagues were convinced based on our server's recommendation. So, judging by their disappointment is their choice, was the lobster from Florida or the Caribbean where the lobster isn't as sweet? Or had the miles of shipping taken their toll? It's hard to know for sure, but when the high point of the dish is the side, you know you've ordered the wrong thing. 

That said, my salmon was delicious. I was super happy with it, just wished there was a vegetable on the plate. Perhaps they should focus on seafood dishes that are closer to home.
author: Pam W.

description: They have great lobster rolls! It they could have a bigger lobster roll compared to the potato bites or salad they served on the side, that would be even better. They have a pretty decent drink menu, too, if you happen to want to have a sip on a Friday afternoon.
author: Isabelle L.

description: Fantastic seafood, inventive, yet grounded and refined.  Great service.  One of San Francisco's most consistently outstanding restaurants.
author: John S.

description:
We searched for a seafood restaurant in the city on a Sunday night and this was one of the only places that could seat our party. I'm so glad we found it! 

We started by trying a few wines before purchasing a bottle of delicious Chardonnay. 

Next up, we ordered the seafood platter. The large fed 6 people perfectly with clams, oysters, shrimp, ceviche and (my favorite) crab salad. The oysters and clams were incredibly fresh. But the shrimp had too much shell left on. And the cocktail sauce was perfectly spicy with the amount of horseradish. 

As for entrees, I highly, highly recommended the clam chowder. It was loaded with fresh clams. Skip the table bread and asked for the grilled bread that comes with the fish stew. Excellent stuff. 

The fish stew also got rave reviews - especially the fish - though, I found the the tomato broth to have a strong vinegar flavor. Other friends had the salmon and another grilled fish - both great. 

The only downside was finding this place. When we finally found the entrance on a side alley, two tractors were outside, which didn't give the best impression. The restaurant didn't disappoint once we went inside, though.
author: Danielle D.

description:
Anchor & Hope is situated in a warehouse with exposed pipes and vents giving it an industrial vibe.  Went there for lunch with coworkers and loved the atmosphere, ambience, crowd, service and food presentation.

Probably its good for HH but definitely not a place for lunch or dinner. Butternut squash soup was good and so was the Brussels sprouts. Other than these two items rest of the dishes were sub-par.

This is a good place for business lunches and HH and not for a date night.
author: Sujeesha V.

description: This was a great lunch spot! Delicious calamari and fresh ceviche to start, both were perfectly seasoned. I had the Sole with quinoa and veggies that was perfectly cooked and paired well with the light garlic purée. Definitely will come back!
author: Brigid M.

description: Excellent food and atmosphere, but their menu did not do them justice.  They need a better writer to make the dishes sound more appetizing.
author: Melissa H.

description: Delicious.  Great fresh seafood.  The lobster roll was great as was the shrimp louie.  Would definitely recommend
author: nicole c.

description: Super disappointing.  The muscles were crunchy after the 2 types of oysters were great.  Wasn't expecting them to charge for water so communication is not there.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Service (3/5 Stars)
- Boyfriend wanted to take me out on a date for my birthday and had chosen this hidden restaurant in the city. The hostess was nice and welcoming. Everyone else after her was meh okay. The bar was a little slow.. which sucked cause we ordered simple things like... Beer and champagne. No mixology needed lol. The staff seemed a bit disorganized because a few always look frustrated or lost. One was dropping glasses on the floor... standing there in disbelief and annoyance with a fellow coworker. We felt the tension in the room for sure but it was also entertaining for the time we are not talking to each other and just people watching. Anyways. On to the important stuff. 

F O O D 

Raw Oysters (5/5 Stars) 
- No happy hour or discounted price on the oysters sadly. But... that didn't stop us to keeping our tummies happy and satisfied. I forgot which oyster we got but we always ask for the smaller sized oysters. Had two dozens of it lol. 

Mussels (4/5 Stars)
- When it was first brought out it had such a funky smell. I did not like it at all but luckily it tasted better than it smelled. The table to my right had clam chowder and the smell of it smelled like.. the taste of the mussels after a while, which was good I Guess. In the end, I still devoured the whole plate of mussels. 

Iron Skillet Steak (3/5 Stars)
- Whenever I see iron skillet on the menu, I'm getting it ! This was rather disappointing. The steak was overcooked and the taste was just meh. It wasn't GREAT but it wasn't THAT good either. It was chewy. I only had a slice and was done with it. The boyfriend ate the rest of that.
author: Jenny N.

description:
I came for the last bit of happy hour and dinner with a couple of friends. I arrived a bit earlier than my friends so I decided to get some fries (to share with them) and an oyster. I didnt want to fill up before dinner with my friends so I just wanted to try a few things. 

I ended up getting the lobster roll (one of my friends and I got them and one was warm and one was cold) I think I preferred the warm buttery one. Regardless, we also shared the calamari - delicious. 

Service was wonderful and the food was great. Definitely will be back to try other dishes. 

Protip: lobster roll
author: Nina Y.

description:
Good location, hip if sparse decor, strong quality food, and good service.  A great place for a normal (i.e., not fancy) business lunch.  Service was attentive but not too much so.  The lobster roll was very good (and appropriately sized).  The oysters were great.  My guests all enjoyed their meals though I can't remember exactly what they had.  (My vegan guest was happy which doesn't always work out at a seafood place.)

Overall, a solid business lunch, and when I need to lunch in the area, I'll be back.
author: Dave K.

description: Unfortunately, like another reviewer wrote, this place was Anchor & Nope for me as well. I had the $27 Shrimp Salad for lunch - described as shrimp salad, little gems, cucumber, red onions, tomatoes, roasted jalapeño avocado dressing. It was just 5 or 6 shrimp on top of a chopped green salad. To make matters worse - the salad was not very fresh and seemed almost pre-made (like a salad from a takeout place). For $27 at lunch I expect a really amazing salad, not wilted, browning greens with a couple of shrimp thrown on top. Plenty of other great places in SF, I won't be back.
author: Allie H.

description:
This is one of my favorite lunch spots near my office. The dinning room is beautiful with high ceilings and exposed beams - I've never had a bad meal. 

In the past I've brought large work groups for lunch and everyone has found something on the menu to enjoy. Lobster roll, oysters, clam chowder, shrimp salad plus those addicting potato chips always hit the spot. They also have non-seafood dishes if that's what you prefer. 

Sometimes the service can get a little slow during the lunch rush but they never drop the ball when it comes to refilling a wine glass. My kind of place!
author: Alison C.

description: The food was amazing! It was beautifully presented. The seafood feels fresh. It's a little pricey but worth it. I love the homemade chips they serve. It goes with the beer that they serve.
author: Michael A.

description:
Anchor and Hope is a delicious standout from the normal fare of the financial district. Perhaps I just haven't tried enough places, but I don't think there are a lot of places in the city you can get such a good lobster roll with a coastal vibe. The decor is nice and I just love how much natural light this place gets. 

We went with the express intent of trying the lobster roll. Even for a lobster roll, it's pretty pricey at $30 - I'd note average somewhere closer to 25. It's not the best I've ever had, but it's a strong contender. The amount of lobster is good, and the dressing it tasty but not overpowering. The tots the roll comes with are HUGE and remind me absurdly of the Giants' Causeway. Since they're so big they're a bit doughier than your average tot, but still tasty. We also had the mussels with green curry which was delish. They provide complimentary chips and dip that are quite tasty and a nice change from the usual bread. 

Overall great place albeit a bit on the pricey side - but it's seafood so that's to be expected. Definitely looking forward to coming back one day.
author: Kim B.

description:
I hate rating a place down, but I have my reasons. This restaurant was recommended to me by a friend because I wanted seafood. I think I would have been better off eating seafood at one of the restaurants near the Pier. 
We got to the restaurant 5 minutes before they opened, and we didn't realize how early we were. A lady with a short boy hair cut, dark hair, came to us and asked us if we needed help. We told her we had a dinner reservation, and she said "We are not opened yet. We will be opened in a few minutes. Please come back then." No offer to just wait near at the hostess area with a drink or so...I mean it's just 5 minutes.. anyway, we decided to leave and grab a cocktail at the neighboring bar. (minus a star for that
When we got to the restaurant, we were seated with the friendly hostess and waitress (+1 star for that). 
My date was bummed out that they did not have a full bar (minus a star for that). 
I ordered the Sole and he ordered the clam chowder and crab cakes (as his dinner). They came out with the clam chowder first. I told the server to make sure to bring out the crab cakes out with my dinner, because my date ordered the two appetizers as his "dinner". The clam chowder was amazing. He ordered a cup, which looked like a bowl. Makes me wonder how big a bowl of clam chowder would be. (+1 star)
My sole was super SALTYYYYYYYYYYYY and the couscous had no flavor at all. I guess the chef decided to just pour salt all over my sole and leave the couscous bland.??? I did not enjoy my dish at all. (minus 1 star)
Now on to the douchiness of the wait staff: 1. When the waiter delivered our food he said, "Here is your dinner" and to my date, "here is your appetizer". Like does he really have to clarify what it is? FYI, My date ordered two appetizers as his dinner.... 2. The waiter sat a couple behind us. He was trying to upsell water "would you like sparkling water or regular?" The couple said regular water is fine . He made it clear , that he didn't get the upsell, that regular was just tap water.. He repeated "Okay tap water." Really? You have to say tap, when he didn't mention that before? The waiter left, in which I said, "tap water taste just as fine. It seems to be filtered." 3. Service seemed really slow and the restaurant was not even full (minus 2 stars).
In fairness the women hostess and woman waitress were very friendly and nice. I don't think I'll be back though because the food was not as good as I thought it would be, there is no full bar (my mistake for not looking at the information on yelp), and because of how "douchy" the male staff seem to be.
author: Ivy R.

description:
I like A&H because the service is very - very attentive. The food is very well thought out; for example the fish tacos, despite being one of the cheapest items on the menu arrived perfectly plated and served on tortillas that were toasted just enough.  Also had their lobster roll which was less memorable but a good choice for when you just gotta get lobster.  If you like bacon I highly recommend the angels on horseback.

Pro tip: get reservations - they get busy at lunch
author: Oleg H.

description:
Anchor & Hope is a great place to come for happy hour specials.  If you love oysters, they are $1 for the chef's selection. I have tried their Summerset and Hammersley, which are both west coast oysters.  They were on the small side and up to two inches in length. Both were creamy in taste and their juices were clear.  I also tried the beer steamed PEI mussels.  There were seven of them served during HH.  Not only were the mussels delicious, but made a great dipping sauce for the bread.

Service is lacking here. It wasn't busy and the servers were wondering around aimlessly and chatting amongst themselves.  The recent times that I have come, the manager, Curtis, was taking care of me.  I don't mind being waitered on by the manager, but the other servers need to step up their game.  This would have been a three star review, but Curtis made it up.  Thanks Curtis for giving me a great dining experience!
author: Peter C.

description:
Pros:  food was fine, nothing special
Cons:
-When we first walked in, on a Sunday early evening, there were only two tables occupied. We told the maitre d, a young man with long curly dark hair, that we had six people instead of the five in our reservation.  He snapped irritably, "I wish you had told us that before."  First time an empty restaurant has complained about an extra diner!
- I ordered the petrale sole for $26.  Was served with a tiny piece...when I sent it back, instead of offering to provide a larger piece, they told me that this was the standard size. Even worse news for future diners!
- another in our table ordered the steak rare...it came well done, had to be sent back.
- pricey for the value received, even apart from the service issues.

Decided not to linger for dessert given the attitude and quality, went elsewhere instead. Will not be back.
author: Jay S.

description:
First time here.  Can't really complain about $1 oysters during happy hour.  Well...

Ordered 2 beers HH fries and a dozen oysters to start while waiting for other people.  

Place was warm which made it a bit uncomfortable.  

1st dozen oysters we great.  Ordered 2 more dozen wasn't as great as the first.  Look like they did a rush job.  Shells everywhere, mangled oysters and milky too.  Made the 2nd order very unpleasant.  

Better places in SF for $1 oysters. 

Also doesn't have a full bar.
author: jason v.

description: Great chowder! Limited menu but eclectic and fresh. Relaxing ambience; good wine and beer selection. Waitstaff was excellent. Very impressed.
author: Rhonda K.

description:
I've had dinner at Anchor & Hope twice and both times were disappointing! 

The menu focuses on seafood but none of the dishes stand out.

I would NOT recommend the lobster roll, especially if you enjoy tasty, meaty lobster rolls with good lobster to roll ratio. The lobster was slightly too tough. The massive bun was burnt. It comes with a side of wet, soggy coleslaw, and a couple of homemade tater tots. 

It was a pretty sad meal! 

Ambience is good.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Fantastic food and service. Brought my husband and a couple friends here Saturday for H's birthday dinner. In the middle of the holiday season they were firing on all cylinders. Food, service, wine. A great table. I will definitely come back next time I am in SF, everything was superb.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
I'd give Anchor & Hope 4.5 stars for ambiance/decor/service, but 3 stars for the food. Our servers were incredibly nice and attentive so I really, really appreciate that :) 

Ambiance = fantastic. Anchor & Hope is in a warehouse - lights are dim which makes this place perfect for a date, or for business meetings. HH ends at 6 pm and the restaurant was pretty empty around 6 and filled up at 7 pm. So I'd recommend for you to come around 6. 

I've been here for HH and came today for HH because it "seems" like a great deal. $1 oysters, $6 drinks, $6 fries, $8 mussels, $3.5 angels on horselback (aka fried oyster wrapped in bacon), $8 salmon cake. Sure, each individual piece seems fine, but added together, yikes! Gets pretty expensive.....

I came here today for HH with a friend, the two of us ordered: 
- 20 oysters (DELICIOUS, I really like the oysters here). $20. 
- 4 Angels on Horseback (aka fried oyster wrapped in bacon) EH, not amazing. Pretty dried and def way too expensive. I wouldn't get this again. $14. 
- 1 salmon cake. Very small, literally two bites and you're done, pretty dry. Not amazing, but decent. It looked delicious but imo pretty over priced. $8 for one. 
- 1 order of fries. DELICIOUS! Fries are always amazing. $6. 
- 1 order of beer steamer PEI mussels  - there were about 8 mussels total. $8. Decent, but again, portion was very small. 
- Drinks - we ordered 2 A&H royale ($7 each), which is pretty much champagne. 2 Savignon Blanc (red wine blend $6 each), which was better than the champagne. 

Overall our bill for two came out to be $95 (including tax and a 5% SF mandate........). We weren't that full after this $95..... We could have had a more filling meal.......eh......

Our server was great, I really appreciate that. Oysters were delicious so I would come back only for oysters. Everything else was way too overpriced for the portion. But again, keep in mind that this is downtown SF and most people come here for business, not on their own dime!
author: Dana Z.

description:
Perfect spot for the FiDi Happy Hour crowd - busy restaurant bar with a great beer selection and sweet HH seafood deals. Oyster lovers go here for the $1 oyster list, others like me indulge more in their extensive beer list, featuring local beers only.

Try the 8% German Altbier called FORT POINT 'Westfalia' and it'll turn your shitty workday into a splendid one within 15 minutes.

Highlights from the menu include:

Roasted corn soup, heirloom tomato relish ($10)
Summer salad, grilled corn, mizuna, cucumber, jicama, cotija cheese, roasted jalapeño vinaigrette ($14)
Salmon cakes, radish, fennel, parsley, muhammara sauce ($15)
New York strip steak, vadouvan roasted potatoes, summer beans, red wine demi-glace ($36)
author: Sebastian F.

description:
I seem to have forgotten how fantastic the happy hour deal is at Anchor & Hope. I've been expanding my $1 oyster list and it wouldn't be complete without this lively, nautical themed spot. 

Happy hour is from 4:30pm - 6pm and I got here shortly after 5 and the bar was full sans for 3 middle seats. Do these people work?! ;-)

I would sneak out of work early too to slurp down a dozen oysters all by myself! Pair that with a Cristalino cava ($6 at HH), have a bite of dungeness crab croquette and stuff my mouth with crispy fries. 

 LIFE IS PERFECT.
author: Janice C.

description:
I was soo excited to come back after an incredible meal 2 years ago. Sadly the food was not on point this time around. 

The ceviche lacked flavor and only came with 6 chips. On the plus side the server gladly brought us more. The calamari was lackluster and the sauce overly vinegared. 

The lobster rolls were both bland and the sides didn't help make the dish as the tater tots were mushy and the coleslaw was watery. 

The rockfish and curry sadly came with a very runny curry which resulted in it also having very little flavor. 

I hope this was a fluke as we came excited and left disappointed.
author: Karen J.

description: Came here on Valentine's day. Cool building that doesn't seem to fit with all the other high rise buildings in the area. We were promptly sat at our reservation time at 8:30. We ordered oysters and littlenecks to start. Being from New England I was impressed with the waiters knowledge of Cape Cod Oysters. We had a couple more apps and then entrees. We were very pleased with everything. We saved room for dessert - bread pudding with ice cream. Really good! This place has one of those liquor licenses where alcohol proof isn't that high. Still a good selection of beer, wine and some aperitif type cocktails. I'd give this place a go. We luckily got best table in the place too. Request table in the back by itself if available.
author: Tyler M.

description:
Just dined here tonight 3/22/18.
Great food, god AWFUL service (other than the busboys, who were kind and prompt). I came here with 2 friends at 5:45, before happy hour was over at 6.

-the host, an older gentleman with a beard repeated twice when he sat us that he needed the table by 8 pm. 
-we asked our waitress about happy hour, she gave us the options (she didn't know the menu well) and we ordered some drinks, only to be scolded by  said host that happy hour was only for the bar (no one told us any different when we ordered). The host then asked if we were doing happy hour or dinner - when we just ordered food from the main menu. 
-our waitress proceeded to never check in on us during our meal so we had to ask another waiter to take our order and he said our waitress assumed we didn't want anything else because we ordered happy hour...all in our bill was 160 dollars.

The whole experience was overall very uncomfortable. They made us feel like our money wasn't good enough. Mind you, happy hour is advertised on all of their receipts as being an everyday occurrence ending at 6 pm...

I suggest management reassessing their staff and investing in hires with a higher level of professional acumen if they hope to maintain a consistent clientele.
author: Laura H.

description:
I was craving some oysters and decided to give this place a try. They usually have a HH during the weekdays, but I came on a weekend so no HH for me. Atmosphere is pretty nice, dim lights and ocean feel, good for groups and date night.  Each table gets a bowl of chips with mayo. Meh, the chips were stale...not feeling it at all.

We ordered the small seafood platter. It came with prawns, oysters, clams, ceviche and crab. The best was the clams. They were big and juicy! SO fresh and good. Prawns and crab with decent. Oysters were whatever, I hate oysters that aren't juicy or full, like it shrunk or something, not worth it. Ceviche had no taste, I felt I was eating a cardboard. The total came out to be $58 for the platter, I personally didn't think it was worth it for the quality and I have had better. 

Therefore, the trick is to get the clams that are only $1.50 each OR just come for happy hour.
author: Natalie L.

description:
We're all Negan.  

I try to make a point of having seafood whenever travels bring us near the coast.  Anchor and Hope has been in our SF rotation lately and always turns out to be a solid meal.  

They've got a lot of raw bar options and I've always been happy with what I've chosen, so that's where I started.  As we were putting together our plan (collectively planning all aspects of a meal is a thing, right?) a manager sensed our uncertainty and stepped in to assist.  I geeked out for a bit as he was a dead ringer for Negan.  But, instead of bludgeoning me with Lucille he played savior and guided us along with our decisions and got me going with the daily selection of oysters.  My wife wasn't feeling them, therefore I embarked solo on that effort: Miyagi, Pickering Pass, and Cape Cod.  A beet salad to open for the little lady and calamari to share.  As usual I loved the oysters once again here.  They're always fresh, tasty and well presented with various dipping sauces.  The beet salad had a bunch of different beets and greens and my wife loved it.  Calamari was some of the best we've had and was perfectly lightly fried.  

For our mains my wife got the Ling cod and I, once again, opted for the lobster roll.  A&H really excel at what I like to think of as classic seafood fare: fish&chips, raw bar and this delectable lobster roll.  Lump lobster meat piled high on one of those perfect split down the middle rolls accompanied by house made slaw and monstrous tater tots.  No filler at all with it and I love it every time I get it.  Kris really liked her fish too.  We also got a side of spicy broccoli rabe that had a nice kick to it.  We enjoyed everything we had.  

Service was attentive and we appreciated the insight to the menu and help with our selections, which we ended up very pleased with.  Another solid dinner at A&H.  And they've got Pliny!  Pee pee pants time.
author: Dan G.

description: The staff here was blatantly rude to us. Tried to rush us out the door when there were plenty of open tables for other guests and no line. Will not be returning.
author: Theresa H.

description:
If you're craving for Oysters- you won't find a better deal than here.  $1 Oysters from 4:30pm-6pm at the bar, Monday through Friday.  I love coming here for Oysters, Little Neck Clams- all so fresh, & wine during their happy hour.  The Angels on Horseback which is a bacon wrapped oyster is tasty but pricey at $3.50 a pop.  Some other items I got to try were:

Beer Steamed Mussels were ok.  Nothing special.
Grilled Spanish Octopus with Salsa Verde was tender with great flavors!
Grilled Fig Salad with Proscuitto & Goat Cheese was refreshing and delicious.

Nice ambience and and friendly service, I will be back!  I wish they would extend their happy until 6:30 or 7pm so that way I don't have to rush over after work.
author: Melanie N.

description: The place had a nice interior, with really neat decor. The seafood was well done, and had no complaints, although it was slightly expensive.  The service however wasn't great.  They couldn't care less if we were there or not, no asking how our food was, water bottles were empty the whole time, dishes were never cleaned up, wouldn't split up the bills (there was only 3 couples), had to ask for cutlery for our mains several times and the restaurant was not even busy. All of this would have been fine but then he dropped the bill with a hand written gratuity of 20% added to it, with no notice or heads up that was expected. Normally 18% is fair for a group of 8 or more. The 6 of us all received poor service and were expected to pay 20% for it which was not disclosed on the menu or website. It's too bad that the good food was overshadowed by poor and expensive service.  I would perhaps recommend this place to a smaller group where you're allowed to pick your tip amount, but 20% for poor service seems a bit entitled and arrogant to me.
author: Steve G.

description: Very nice place to go have a meal with a group or friend.  Very good service and they have nice proseccos.  Their lobster roll, calamari, and Miyagi oysters are great.
author: Thomas P. L.

description:
There isn't anything unlikable about this quaint place tucked away in the corner of the alley. The venue is a blend of modern and rustic: metal beams and rope overhead, and the classiest glassware, beverages, food, and staff. Everyone is also very attentive, kind, and they check in with the table without seeming as if they're swooping in or hovering. Great ambiance. 

This place operates very modestly and with little ego--what I mean by that is the prices are very affordable, even outside the happy hour. You can get smaller samplings of both wine and beer, so you don't have to commit to a huge serving at a high price. Example, you can sample beers in 6oz tulips for $6-$8, wines you can sample at a few ounces for similar pricing. 

The happy hour is phenomenal. Nothing better than $1 oysters served on ice, $6 cava, and $5 beers. Want a combo? A half dozen oysters and a Dry Dublin Stout for $11. They also have Acme pull-apart bread--need I say more?
author: Alison A.

description:
Yet another restaurant I am well behind the times on!  Clearly, bookmarking Anchor & Hope years ago did little to get me through the door any faster.  However, now that I have?  The wish that I had someone (other than myself) to blame for me being so late to the party comes to mind.  That, and whether coming here twice in a relatively short time makes up for taking so long to begin with!  Yes, I'm a fan.

From the same folks as Town Hall and Salt House, Anchor & Hope is fit for an array of occasions - from post-work happy hours and business lunches to casual get togethers and dinner dates alike.  Beyond just the look of the place though (modern, casual), their seafood-centric menu is pretty terrific, in addition to a great selection of beers that also includes a cask variety.

-- "ANGELS ON HORSEBACK" - Smoked Bacon Wrapped Oysters, Remoulade...$15
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-and-hope-san-francisco?select=LjXOcUm1y__2-foBUrsg_g)
I'm generally cool on cooked oysters, but these are the angelic exceptions.  The oysters were meaty and juicy enough (read: not dried out) and those long cuts of bacon added a nice salty, smokiness.  Admittedly though, the (slight) downside to the latter was that the bacon was a bit overpowering.

-- ANCHOR & HOPE LOBSTER ROLL - Pain de Mie Bun, Tater Tots, Stevie's Coleslaw...$29
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-and-hope-san-francisco?select=IntQcWqsFdBoziAAm3tvTg)
Woodhouse's is still my favorite, but this one is up there.  The chunks of lobster were sizable, fresh, and had a tinge of sweetness that was complemented nicely by the dressing.  The only thing holding it back was the bun, which dried out every bite.  As for the sides, the slaw was okay, but the tots didn't disappoint - huge, crispy, and tasty!

-- GRILLED BABY OCTOPUS with Butter Beans, Squid Ink, Shaved Mango, Chimichurri...$16
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-and-hope-san-francisco?select=sRMqi_DV9x-DKgEKVtKZyg)
The portion felt modest, but only because the dish was so good!  The octopus was tender, charred well, and tasted great with the chimichurri and squid ink.  Plus, I liked the sweet acidity from the mango.  I was mixed on the butter beans though; good earthiness, but bland and starchy.

-- SMITHWICK'S BEER BATTERED LOUISIANA FLOUNDER with Tartar Sauce and House Cut Fries...$26
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-and-hope-san-francisco?select=TY6JTOhZHdSrsnN2aTRDLQ)
Comparatively, the "worst" dish I've had here, but fine, really.  Both were crispy, but the batter on the fish was a little thick and light on seasoning.  Still, plus points for using a decent cut of flounder, as opposed to the usual cod.  Also, while I did enjoy the generous portion of fries, part of me wanted their tots instead (fish & tots!).

Somewhat like with my entree, I didn't find the service to be quite as sharp the second time around.  While our first server was very friendly and attentive, our second seemed fairly indifferent in both demeanor and helpfulness.  Plus, our table never received the complimentary chips and dip that we got the first time around, which I note more out of principle than for the sake of the chips themselves.

Still, despite their flaws, Anchor & Hope is an awesome spot in my book.  Perhaps they've lost a bit of their shine over the years (like with Town Hall), but the fact that they're still a solid four shows just how high they set the bar for themselves.  At the least, the silver lining is that it's that much easier to get a table here these days!
author: Mike L.

description:
This is the only place I'm coming now for oysters. They were cool and briny, came with mignonette and cocktail sauce, and at $1 a pop during HH, you can't go wrong. 

We stayed for dinner too and everything was excellent. Fish was moist with a perfectly crispy batter, Brussels sprouts were delicious and broccoli was decent too. Overall a great place for hanging out with good friends, enjoying great food.
author: Linda Y.

description: We came in late one night but they still decided to serve us. That was awesome because the food was fresh and amazing some of the best oysters we've had in a very long time and the drinks were phenomenal! We will definitely come back here again!
author: Thalia O.

description: Such a an awesome experience. I loved the clams and clam chowder with Ace Perry Craft Cider! The best seafood in SanFrancisco. I love the rustic mix of old and new.. definitely a first class atmosphere.
author: Nina I.

description:
I want to start out by saying I've been to this restaurant 4 times. Each time (except for tonight), I've gone with a reservation before 6pm, gotten oysters and fries on happy hour, then ordered salad and other stuff from the dinner menu to share with friends. 

When my friend and I arrived and were seated at 5:45, I asked for some oysters. The server asked, "are you here for happy hour or for dinner?" I replied "both!" She just stared at me. I said, but if you're making me choose...I guess happy hour?" 

She took our menus and the hostess brought me new ones just for happy hour. The rude hostess said, "just so you know, we don't take reservations for happy hour." Um, what? Who does that? Your restaurant opens at 5(ISH) for dinner and happy hour is over at 6. Why let your website take reservations for that time, then? Plus, no one has ever said that to me the 3 previous times I've eaten here (and have spent at least $50 per person, so I'm not being cheap).

I won't be back. Plenty of other places in the city have $1 oysters without the snobbish attitude.
author: Ashley M.

description:
The food was nice, specifically the seafood platter but then, how can you mess that up?  My friends had fantastic fish and chips which was delicious, my lobster roll was nice, and my last friend had the salmon, again very tasty.  

My problem was the service.  Our waiter almost ignored us quite a few times...  He wasn't great.  It's kind of shame because the place is pretty and the dishes are good-ish.
author: Alyse S.

description: Best fish and chips I've ever had. Their fries are orgasmic. Casual, indulgent seafood realness. No-frills while being super tasty. Staff is attentive and efficient. Went for dinner and will be coming back for lunch soon.
author: David W.

description:
Delicious but busy.

Came for a birthday lunch with my team at work and booked on the early side to avoid the rush.

The menu isn't extensive, but the food is delicious. I had the clam chowder soup and the Louis Shrimp and both were so tasty. The shrimp were huge and even though it didn't look much it was very filling.

I would highly recommend the Brussels sprouts if you like them generally - these were done a way I had never tried before and tasted so good I may come back just to get more of those.

It was really loud in there, which made conversation difficult at times, and the food took longer to come out than we expected but the location was very trendy and it seems very popular.
author: Jemma B.

description:
Really popular spot for business lunches in FiDi. Whenever we take a new hire out to lunch, this is one of the go to restaurants. Fancy but not too fancy, and the food is always on point. 

Free chips come with every meal, and they are definitely addicting. Lobster roll is delicious and comes with huuuge tater tots. Mussels are good too-the sauce is a little thicker than I thought it'd be, but I still ate the whole plate of that tells you anything. If you're going to get an appetizer, definitely go with the bacon wrapped oysters. The fried greasy flavor pairs so well with the ocean, saltwater flavor. 

I would definitely suggest making a reservation, which is easy even for same day. It is fidi so parking is either slim or expensive.
author: Steph D.

description:
AWESOME NEIGHBORHOOD PLACE - delicious amazing food - loved the entire experience.

One down side - no full bar :(
author: Phillip S.

description:
Its down a short alleyway. Very eclectic ambience inside.  We really loved it.  

Excellent food.   We had a variety of appetizers:  calamari - Excellent!  Very delicate batter.  Not oily at all.  String beans:  Again excellent.  Very light batter with a hint of heat.  Mussels:  Done to perfection.  The sauce was so good we ordered bread to soak it all up!


Their fish and chips was fantastic.  It arrived piping hot. Very large portion of fish with excellent fries!

Don't miss it!
author: Steve H.

description:
This place is a gem in Financial District. We were up for SuperBowl week (easy walk from the Marriott Marquis), made reservations in advance, and had dinner for 2 at 6:30.  Down an alley off of Mission, a very charming brick building that was a converted barn.  

Good for a romantic dinner, or a team dinner of 6-8 folks.  Noise level is good for conversation.   

This place is all about great seafood.  They have a terrific selection of (8!) east and west coast oysters (we tried the west coast).  Mignonette was basic, oysters were mostly well prepped (two had grit, all were cleaned from the shell)
We rated:
  1. Kusshi
  2. Miyagi
  3. Fisher island
  4. Chelsea Gem (these bad boys are very fleshy)

Clam chowder was nothing to write home about (too creamy and overwhelming bacon flavor)
Mt Lassen trout was a nice, large portion with crispy skin, the Skuna Bay Salmon with clams and mussels had a delightful combination of ocean fresh flavors.

Quintessa Sauv Blanc was a great pairing with both dishes.
Wait staff was delightful and attentive.

We will be back!
author: Bill H.

description: Fantastic food and service was great! I had the salmon and wasn't even ready for how amazing it was! Calamari was also great! Highly recommend!
author: Jeremy R.

description: We arrived to find two girls french kissing in the doorway.Lucky I did not have my grandchildren with me.Went to the hostess who was very off as she was busy on the phone hmmmm.We had a booking but they were half empty.We waited asked for a particular table and was told we could have it for 30 minutes as someone else wanted it.They never showed up hmmmm.We sat at the bar very cold service.The place had a very strange vibe.No one seemed very happy.We told them we are glutton free and not by choice.Our meal came with couscous.I asked if it was G.F. she said yes but I asked her again and she checked,it was not.The food is nothing remarkable.Service mechanical.We were the last 2 people on a very long bar.They decide to count there money and receipts right in front of us.We moved down and they did not even look up.There are so many better places in the City.Do not waste your money here.
author: mark B.

description:
I absolutely love the space.  It's so bright and airy inside I was more excited about the place after I walked in.  The service was good, knew the menu well, and kept the flow moving during lunch on a weekday.  Once it got crowded it was a little loud most likely because of the acoustics.

I had the lobster roll which came with five large homemade tater tots.  The tots were great, the lobster roll was average but $29 is just a bit much for lunch.  They could have used more spice  in the lobster roll and maybe some celery for texture too.

I'd really like to give them 3.5 stars based on the other items on the menu I didn't get a chance to try and the style of the place.
author: Scott M.

description:
I came here based on recommendations from a friend to try the Lobster roll with tater tots. It was DELICIOUS.

Ambiance: Very cute, upscale type place. Everyone was wearing businessy clothes and look very professional. I came from the airport and they had a bag check to hold my suitcase, which was really nice.

Drinks: Didn't get any

Food: Lobster roll with tater tots!!! SO good. I made sure to ask for the homemade chips and aoili, and dipped the tater tots into the aioli sauce. They are massive, crispy on the outside and mashed potato like on the inside. The lobster was very fresh and whatever it was mixed with was delicious.

Rating: 4.5/5. 

Overall: Would love to come back and try other things here! They had $1 oysters for happy hour....
author: Jenna G.

description: Best food! Fish and chips and Crab/Shrimp Louie was incredible! Plus most awesome service. Can't wait to come back again!!
author: Lindsie J.

description:
Wednesday, August 5th: National oyster day & International beer day

Two things I love to consume! I had to celebrate. Easily made a reservation for 2 through OpenTable (www.opentable.com) for dinner at 9:45pm.

Food:
*Complimentary chips and dip
*Seafood plateaux: half dozen oysters, six shrimp, five little neck clams, crab remoulade, ceviche ($58 small)
*New England clam chowder, smoked bacon, oyster crackers ($8 cup)
*Gulf prawn scampi, savory clams, aleppo, white wine sauce, grilled levain ($18)
*Anchor & hope lobster roll, pain de mie bun, tater tots, stevie's coleslaw ($28)
*Blackberry panna cotta: macerated blackberries, cardamom ($7)
*Strawberry shortcake: pound cake, macerated strawberries, creme fraiche whipped cream ($7)

The seafood plateaux was my favorite. The oysters, shrimp and clams were fresh with a wonderful sea flavor. The crab remoulade was okay, but I felt we needed a carb to eat with it. Maybe I should have used the complimentary chips? I didn't care for the ceviche as it was too sour for my taste. The scampi and lobster were both good. The clams and prawns were nicely cooked and the white wine sauce very flavorful. The lobster roll buttery and tender. I loved the tots! I didn't care for the clam chowder at all as it had carrots so it had a sweetness I didn't care for. Desserts were pretty good. I liked the panna cotta. The strawberry shortcake was a little dry.

Beer:
*Headlands 'pt bonita' bohemian pilsner: san francisco, california, 5.3% abv ($7)
*North coast 'old 38' dublin dry stout: fort bragg, california, 5.4% abv ($8)
*Allagash 'curieux' barrel aged tripel: portland, maine, 11% abv ($8 for 6oz)
*Pinkus mueller: 'pinkus' pils, munster, germany, 5% abv ($10 for 500ml)

Lots of beer between the two of us! My favorite was the Allagash curieux. It was my first beer. Strong and smooth. I'm still at a loss when looking at beer menus, but I enjoyed all the beers we ordered.

We came close to closing, but our waitress was awesome! She never made us feel rushed. And she was very attentive. Kept the beer flowing.

Fun place to celebrate a day dedicated to oysters and beer. Would definitely come back for that seafood plate. Yum!
author: Elena N.

description: I am surprised at some of the low reviews.  I thought this place was quite excellent.  I had the sole and it was great.  Indeed, a little salty, which I actually liked but could be overpowering for a lot of people.  I also had the clam chowder which I thought was excellent.   Of course, I would have loved the place even more if it was a little less expensive.
author: Yohannes S.

description: I'm a fan of Anchor & Hope! I've only been here twice and it's not a disappointment. I'm really surprised of the ratings it has on yelp..it should definitely be higher. They also do happy hour too from M-F from 4:30 to 6PM. Just to note their dinner is only from Saturday - Thursday 5:30 to 10PM. The service was phenomenal! He helped described whats the best thing on the menu and what he recommended as well. Everything I ordered was on point and I'll be coming back!! Can't wait.
author: Jenn L.

description:
This was my third time over at least five years that I've eaten here. It's changed and not for the better. The service people seemed almost angry.

We stepped up to the bar while waiting for a reserved table and the bartender walks up and just stares at us. No "hello" or "what can I do for you". Just standing there looking into our eyes... in silence. It was pretty strange. After about 10 seconds of looking at us we said "hello" to her and she gave us one of those cynical smiles that says "fuck you" in a passive aggressive sitcom manner.

Our waitress seemed like she was trying to leave asap and actually looked pissed that we didn't order more wine.

We paid $150 for some fish n chips, broccoli, a salad, and a pretty good sole. I'm talking bar level fish and chips.

I forgot that we ordered the civiché. That was pretty good.
author: Selino V.

description: I think they were having a bad day but almost every plate we ordered was really salty.
author: Charlie L.

description:
Awesome place for happy hour! If it weren't for my friend, I'd have never found this little place with it hiding away in the little alley like Minna street.

Once you step inside you are immediately greeted with a surprisingly open and well lit cafeteria-like seating area with the bar sprawled out over on the left side. A waitress promptly seated us and very kindly informed us that HH was only going on for about another 15-20 min so we should order quickly, lol. Ended up each getting a glass of bubbly, an assorted dozen of oysters, and a pair of BACON WRAPPED OYSTERS (say what?!?!?!)

All super delicious, very fresh, and not bad at all for HH in the city. Usually any place with $1 oysters gets super crowded, really fast...but maybe people just haven't caught wind of this spot fully yet.  The bacon gems were a lil pricey, but definitely worth trying at least once. I mean.... Bacon. Do you really need another reason?
author: Yen D.

description: We came to Anchor & Hope for my friends birthday dinner. The food was very good. We really enjoyed the oysters and the lobster macaroni & cheese is a must! The service was excellent!
author: Christina S.

description: Came here for dinner a few weeks back, service was great and the (west coast/miyagi) oysters and clam chowder were both delicious.
author: Debra D.

description:
This review is for their happy hour. $1 fresh oysters!!!  Should just end the review right there.  If you're an oyster fan then you really can't beat this.  The oysters are fresh and nicely presented on a bed of ice.  The waiters were attentive.  Only thing to be aware of is over indulging. Even though it's only $1 you can still rack up a pretty good bill.

Just remember:

"Consuming raw or undercooked meats, poultry, seafood, shellfish, or eggs may increase your risk of foodborne illness."
author: G M.

description:
I came here for my 30th birthday, and returned for my 31st (which was yesterday), and this place delivers the goods when it comes to seafood dining. There is an assorted variety of oysters to choose from, local and further, and eating coming with their own dipping sauce. For a wonderful appetizer, I recommend the Angels on Horseback, bacon wrapped oysters. The food is always fresh, as if they plucked it from the water, and cooked it there for you. The staff is helpful, and knowledgeable about their menu, and are always ready to refill your drink.
The two downsizes would be the price, being why I choose to go there only once a year on my birthday because someone else gets to take care of the bill. Not a lot of room for parking, but it is the financial district so that is expected.
Besides all that, if you want to feel fancy, and eat some great seafood, look no further.
author: Joel G.

description:
This restaurant stands out from all the other eateries I've visited in the Financial District. My friend took me here for lunch on a weekday. I thought we would need a reservation, but apparently we didn't. When we first walked in, I felt like I was transported to another world... the restaurant feel nautical with its high ceilings and "fishy" décor. Great place for any occasion, from a business meeting to a date. My friend and I were seated immediately. 

I was excited to order the bucatini pasta with Dungeness crab which I saw on their website earlier that morning before coming to the restaurant, but they didn't have it on their actual menu. Kinda disappointed, but I ended up ordering a salmon dish which was amazing. Cooked perfectly (not dry) and complemented by the quinoa and vegetables. Service was excellent, very professional and prompt. It was a seamless culinary experience, one that I would recommend if you're dining out in this neighborhood!
author: Stefanie C.

description: GREAT SPOT!!! Their lobster roll is delicious!!!! This spot is great for a date night or a work lunch. The vibe and decor of the restaurant is really fun. I think all the meals I have had or tried here have been really good. Definitely worth checking out.
author: Makenzi B.

description: This place is a hidden treasure. You wouldn't know it was there unless you were looking for it, but it is well worth going to. The service was great and the atmosphere is awesome. They have a farm to table meets pier dining feel. The food was all amazing and none of the group had a complaint.
author: Micah W.

description: Great choice for date night. Good local craft beer list & I had a wonderful sancerre. Fresh seafood that is delicious. If you are looking for Oysters this is the spot. The lobster roll was fantastic and we loved the service. Very cool space in an old garage with nice design elements.
author: Flavia C.

description: Located in a short alleyway, this place is easy to miss, but so glad we didn't! Complimentary house made chips with an aioli dip was a good way to start, and then we ordered an amazing arugula salad which my husband and I split. Figs, goat cheese cream and crispy prosciutto made this salad one of my favorite dishes. We then ordered the salmon and the fish & chips. The salmon was prepared wonderfully, and was tender and tasty, but the beer/battered flounder my husband ordered was off the charts! Ordering fish & chips at an upscale seafood restaurant is not normally my thing, but I probably would have ordered this had I known how amazing it was. Batter was thin and crisp, and the fish was buttery and flaky! So good. Our server was wonderful and brought us a complimentary drink to end our dinner. Highly recommend and we will return!
author: Andrea S.

description: Great experience overall. Chowder, west oysters, and stuffed dorade were all fantastic. But what really made the experience was Curtis, one of the managers. My server was clearly very busy and Curtis stepped in to help and went out of his way to make sure I had an amazing experience. Made me feel like a guest in his home. Looking forward to returning here next time I'm in SF.
author: Brandon T.

description:
Simply put: It is pricey AND there is excellent food and service. 

They have a very attentive staff and an efficient system of servers, bussers, and runners. Great ambience too. 

Everything we ordered from food to beer and wine was great. Ceviche, grilled shrimp, chowder, and calamari were great. Thanks.
author: Ben J.

description:
wow - such a huge disappointment.  stunned this place is so popular.

DO NOT ORDER THE LOBSTER ROLE - it's an embarrassment to new england.  it's bland, flavorless and a bit overcooked served on a huge, dry texas toast type of bread - awful.  the 'tater tots' were seriously under seasoned - the only good thing on the $31 plate was the cole slaw.   also the calamari appetizer was tough and gritty.  the tuna appetizer was fine.  

service was mediocre at best.  the waiter does spend time up selling the bubbly water as other reviews have mentioned.  but once the food is served he was no where to be found.  i had to borrow some lemon from my dinner mates plate to try to make the lobster roll taste like something.

no idea what this place does with all the cash it's raking in but i think it's safe to say we can rule out spending on quality ingredients or talented chefs.  or on heat.  the place is so cold and drafty - i was counting the minutes until our business dinner was finished so i could put on my down jacket and go outside to warm up.
author: claudia t.

description:
So, I normally don't eat out alone.  Wait, I take that back.
So, I normally don't splurge on meals.  Wait, I take that back.
So, I normally don't celebrate big milestones.  Wait, I take that back.

Ok, today was probably just an excuse to eat out just cuz but little did people know, I was having a little party in my pants and no one knows why.  Yesterday, I came home, checked my email, and received the most awesome news ever.  I am officially a Yelp Elite.  My jaw drops.  Celebration time.

-Angels on horseback (bacon wrapped oysters) - This app comes with four pieces but since I was dining alone, they were able to prepare half the amount.  The bacon was nice and crispy wrapped around the perfectly cooked, but not too cooked, oyster.  Not gonna lie, I should've ordered four.
-Anchor & Hope lobster roll, pan de mie bun, tater tots, Stevie's coleslaw- The roll was perfect.  The bottom was toasted just right creating a sturdy foundation. Lobster was good but perhaps a hint of lemon would've given it more flavor.  Tots were nice and big and crispy.  I don't use ketchup when I eat fries/tots but this was an exception.  The slaw was a little bland.  Not sure if the lobster roll is worth the price but it wasn't bad.

Service was great.  I was content with my meal but the celebration will not end here.  

Look Ma, I did it!  #YelpEliteSquad #Squadgoals
author: Linda N.
