description: We had 18 people in our party and one didn't like the two tables so the staff changed it up. Amazing service and food the whole evening. Everyone loved it. Thank you xx
author: Sarah G.

description:
Had Mother's day dinner here.  It was simply an AWESOME experience in every respect.

The decor is great.  A modern rustic look and feel.   

We had the ceviche and Angels on horseback for appetizers.  The latter was really really good.  For entree we had grilled rock cod, crab and pasta, grilled salmon and fish and chips.  All were delicious and the portions were pretty generous. Seafood was fresh and well prepared.  

They also have a large and diverse beer selection.  I had the cask beer which our server advised is served at room temperature.  Personally, I like that and it did not disappoint.

For dessert we ordered the bread pudding and chocolate cake.   Both were delicious and not too heavy.  

Service was excellent with impecvable timing.  

Return visits are in the works.
author: P.Y. H.

description:
Great french/new American lunch spot in Soma.

Ordered the house made chips with some sort of sweet aioli sauce and it was great. I could eat that sauce forever. Mayo something, but oh so good. 

Ordered 3 of the fancy ($3.50) #kusshi oysters from British Columbia are the best with a naturally sweet flavor. The #rappahannock ($3 I think) oysters are solid and more tender, but skippable.

Mussels (French style) are done well, with white wine sauce and you get plenty in a bowl, along with pomme frites (thin fries), yum.

Would definitely come back for lunch.
author: Chuck N.

description:
I wasn't fond of Anchor & Hope following my first few visits but have seen a sliver of how decent they can be. It was a frequent suggestion for post work drinks. I know larger groups at happy hour can be a pain in the ass but folks behind the bar here don't make much attempt to hide it. Much disdain from behind the bar when you split the tabs when closing out. 

Then once we got seated in the dining room when the bar was too full and that's when we finally experienced some cheery hospitality. Service was friendly and attentive - a total step up from 10 steps away. Service issues aside, $1 oysters at happy hour are great especially when paired with some happy hour kolsch or bubbly. The shrimp tacos are quite tasty with a nice balance of sweet and spice. Crispy calamari is always a crowd-pleaser. Also angels on horseback - bacon wrapped baked oysters? Yes, please.   

A great spot for dollar oysters at happy hour but probably best with a group size of under four. Even then I have other spots close by that I prefer for post-work drinks but wouldn't mind coming back to Anchor & Hope for dinner - the dining room experience way surpasses the bar.
author: Jon L.

description:
Anchor & Hope is a restaurant hidden in a valley. It is quite hard to find if you don't pay attention. 
Came here for lunch on a workday. I ordered a lobster roll ($29) and requested to switch the tater tots to french fries, and it was easily accommodated. The lobster's taste is just right! It has a strong lemony flavor to it, which I really liked. The bread is nicely toasted and buttered.
They also gave out some chips with aioli in the beginning, but it does not taste any special. It is definitely a nice place to enjoy your seafood cravings.
author: Maylene F.

description:
I love the amazing selection of oysters at Anchor and Hope. My husband and I are oyster snobs. Loved the selection. We had 4 different kinds. All from the West Coast. Our favorite last night was the Grassy Bar. The mignonette was definitely a compliment to the oyster. They had 4 East Coast oysters on the menu, but while we are on the West Coast, we will stick with those. As they say, "When in Rome..."

As a side, I had the crispy Brussels. So tasty. I love Brussels, and these were very delightful. They were fried, spicy and crispy. I would love to go back tonight and get them again. 

The service was great. Not a second went by where we were in need of anything. We chose a bottle of wine. Our server made sure there was wine in our glasses until the bottle was gone. 

The restaurant was very lively. Lots of people enjoying the ambience and delicious food.
author: Tracy F.

description:
$1 oysters for HH! 
Great happy hour and a super friendly staff. I like it! 
The oysters tho ... the mignonette and horseradish cocktail sauce was yummy and fresh. Ordered the mussels too. I wanted to pick up the bowl and slurp up all the broth. Very tasty.
author: A L.

description: Very bad service. The staffs give your group an attitude if you're not willing to order lobsters or a seafood feast. They are unhelpful and cannot manage a shared dinner order. It was our first time here and we were not that hungry, so we tried to order fewer entrees to share and get a taste of the place. Guess we are not a familiar customer but still the service here is unacceptable.
author: Evelyn N.

description:
Great food, bad service (attitude)
Dined on a monday night - place was busy enough and we were seated quickly. Our waiter (didnt catch his name, dark curly hair and beard) arrived and immediately appeared irritated and impatient as we made a drinks order. After 'snapping' that they do not carry spirits when I asked for a cocktail, he went on to virtually grab the menus from our hands to point out the wines and beers. This snippy attitude continued throughout the service, so much so that we felt we were putting him out by asking for any sort of service, until he was virtually non-existent when we were ready for the check - ended up asking another server who took care of us. Shame, because the food was decent, and everyone else on the staff was pleasant enough. If you don't like 'interacting' with your paying customers, head back to the kitchen.
author: Phil S.

description: Great staff, nice ambiance. Delicious food. Clam chowder is a must! Calamari was fair, fresh but not the best I ever had. Lobster roll left a lot to be desired and definitely over priced. Tater tots delicious. Friends I dined with enjoyed the salmon and sea urchin as well. Would return and try something else as my entree.
author: Sha. R.

description:
Came here after work with a coworker for a beer and some oysters. We sat at the bar and was impressed by how not packed it was. We ordered a half dozen of oysters and some beers. I had the kolsch (yum!). 

Oysters were amazing. Fresh and all kinds of great. Wish it was happy hour so they weren't so expensive. 

The service was okay but a little off. We asked for suggestions for oysters and she didn't really help us at all. If you work at an oyster restaurant- you better know your oysters. 

All in all, I would come here again for oysters and a nice meal... Hopefully with a better server. :)

---------------UPDATED REVIEW----------------

Came back 12/3 at 5:30 during happy hour with my boyfriend. He wanted to grab a beer. We were on our way to a work function and had some time to kill before we arrived. 

He had the green bullet beer- really great choice!
We shared a dozen oysters ($1 during happy hour). We sat at the bar and were the only customers there. 

What a difference service makes when you're the only customer compared to my last visit. We had three servers helping us and asking us if we needed anything. 

Definitely come during happy hour to take advantage of their great deals!!
author: Amanda M.

description:
Went here for a planned dinner date, but ended up underwhelmed and unimpressed. The impression I received from the vibe was that the oysters would be great, and the food decent. However the oysters were just okay, and the food was pretty lousy and bland. 
I'd come again perhaps if pressed by colleagues who want to have a few oysters and not a real meal, but I would not stop by for dinner.
author: Mima G.

description:
I had been craving oysters since moving to SF so my friend and I decided to come here. The inside was really pretty and to me was quite fancy shmancy. Our server was EXCELLENT and provided us with a lot of options when we kept asking him what he recommended. I'm only giving it 3 stars because other than the great service, the food was just okay and ended up being REALLY PRICEY. Our bill came out to $146! We ordered a small seafood plateaux ($58), calamari ($16), lobster roll ($29) and 2 drinks ( not sure). 

The seafood plateaux was really good. It came with clams, oysters, cocktail shrimp, ceviche, coleslaw, and sauces. The oysters were definitely our favorite and were sooooo good! We preferred that over the clams which were slightly bitter. The ceviche was great also but the amount was what could fit in a shot glass. And you can't really go wrong with shrimp cocktail. 

The waiter said that the calamari was the most popular appetizer so we went with that. The calamari itself was average but the thai dipping sauce is what made it really good. If it wasn't for the sauce I wouldn't get it again.  

The lobster roll entree was the biggest disappointment for me. The roll itself was delicious. It was quite fluffy and buttery. Sadly the star of the dish, the lobster, wasn't amazing. It lacked flavor and was a bit chewy. The tater tots it came with were extremely bland and had a weird consistency. Even after salting the tots up it didn't help so we didn't finish them. 

My friend had a red win and I had a prosecco. Not much to say about them other than they were our drinks.  

I would return to this place because of the customer service and the oysters but that's it.
author: Andrea R.

description:
Dropped by for happy hour on Tuesday evening, which turned into a mini eat-fest.

My friend has been having some hard times lately: from his apartment being robbed, dropping a pair of Ray Bans, and asking a group of fellows who almost turned it into a brawl, it seemed like someone needed to shine a light of compassion on him. So we snagged a little corner spot at A&H and chatted about life and limb. 

We both had the Penfolds Riesling ($5) from the happy hour menu and then ordered up some apps. I wanted oysters real bad, so we got a dozen of the Chef's Selection (at $1 each who could say no?). We also ordered the Anchor & Hope Fries with Malt Vinegar Aioli ($6) and the Shishito Peppers with Sea Salt ($6). Thick potato chips come out before your food, which were tasty with a drizzling of lemon juice and dipped into aioli.

Everything was good, but the oysters had a milky, kind of chalkiness under some of them that made me feel a little uneasy. I ate four and left the rest for my friend, or the garbage, whichever, as getting sick from oysters is not my gameplan (I didn't get sick, mind you, but I also drank a Fernet next door at Eddie Ricknebacher's just to be safe).

The Shishito peppers were good, but could have used some jamon, like the ones from Coquetta on Pier 5. Good, just lacking a dimension of flavor from lack of fat. The fries were crisp and light. He had a Cali Craft and I had another wine as we decided to finish the mini meal with the Angels on Horseback ($3.50 each), which were bacon-wrapped oysters, flash fried and drizzled with a sauce of sorts. These were deeeelish and I recommend them to anyone who is open to bacon / oysters /  anything that tastes like heaven. Salty, light, creamy, a winner all around.

Surely I'll be back, as I've been in several times. I hope to get the Lobster Roll next time, people seem to be enthralled by it.
author: Crystal C.

description:
My family was on vacation. We meet our local friends here. Our group was 9. The atmosphere was romantic.    
I order the lobster roll. The portion was small but the meat and roll did taste very good. Mom ordered the fried flounder the portion was much bigger and was fresh. Fancy place however the high cost of the food for small portions.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Wait, wait and wait some more. Thankfully a busser brought us these chips and aoli. The bus staff was good actually. For such a good looking restaurant, cool build out near location they could have hired more waiters. We counted two. And when we were on the cusp of just ordering from the bar, our gal came. 
Great beer, but you'll pay for it. The food wasn't memorable, mushy sprouts, water thin clam chowder. The west coast oysters were fine. Two people 170 bucks without tip. We were robbed.


Anchor & hope your server comes.
author: Adam K.

description:
I happened upon this restaurant while roaming San Francisco looking for something good to eat. I passed so many restaurants I just couldn't decide. I saw this one, walked in and immediately loved the ambiance. It has an open layout and lively atmosphere. 

Since j wasn't too hungry I went straight to the main course. They did bring complimentary homemade potatoes chips and a dipping sauce. For my main course I ordered the Grilled Tai Snapper which was served with what I believe was broccoli rabe, spinach farro and a butternut squash purée. I'm not sure I have the details right but what I do know is that the flavor combination created a celebration of flavors in my palate! There was a hint of orange in the dish and the citrus flavor complimented the dish perfectly. 

I was trying to behave so skipped dessert but there was a Chocolate Tres Leches on the menu I really REALLY wanted to try. Hopefully next time!
author: Rosa R.

description: We came here on a Friday night with a small group of friends. The restaurant was half empty. There were more servers, bar tenders, and bust boys in the restaurant, yet it took them 15 minutes to come to our table to ask us what we wanted to drink. Not even a glass of water. I asked if they had garlic fries. They said they did. They brought regular fries. When I said I asked for garlic fries, they said they didn't have garlic fries. They didn't comp the fries at the end of the meal. The food took forever to come out, and at the end of it, it wasn't that good. They didn't have any specialty cocktails and the staff looked like they hated their life. The energy in the room was extremely rude and negative. What an awful way to end my Friday night.
author: Greta K.

description:
TL;DR - I will not be returning and I do not recommend this restaurant for anyone considering the expensive mediocre food with extremely poor service.

I made a large group reservation with business guests scheduled during happy hour. When we arrived, we had to wait to be seated for some time even though we had a reservation and there were only 2-3 other parties in the restaurant. We patiently waited. We were just happy to drink soon.

Even though we were well within the happy hour timeframe, we were only given regular menus until we inquired. The happy hour menu items are cheaper, but minuscule in portion, so it didn't seem like a happy hour deal at all. It felt more expensive in a way. We ordered lots of appetizers to share (all of which came hot and fresh), but we also ordered two vegetarian-friendly entrees that never came at all.

When we realized our dishes were forgotten, we tried to flag a waiter, but no one was available to tend to us for some time (by now there were only about 10 parties in the restaurant). With some urgency, we began to wave our hands in the air like children. Our associates were hungry.

We found out that the original waiter never put our entree orders in. At this point, we also found out we had a new waiter. We didn't know she was our new waiter, but we came to realize she was because when we inquired about our missing dishes, her response was, "You didn't place those orders with me." ... Of course not. We placed them with our original waiter!

They switched waiters on us, and the new waiter was entirely and utterly unapologetic about our wait, our missed orders, and our hungry clients. In fact, the sharpness of her attitude (tone of voice, choice of words, and body language) all spoke as if we had accused her of some heinous crime when all we did was politely ask about our missing dishes. (For the record, our original waiter was kind and jolly; this waiter clearly did not want to serve us.)

When we received our bill, we reviewed it and noticed that they charged us for an extra count of a dish we ordered. We flagged our waiter down. 

Waiter: "Is there a problem?"
Me: "I think there's a mistake. We only ordered 2 of these."
Waiter: "No, there's no mistake. You definitely ordered 3."

Disgruntled, she was insisting I did what I did not do. At this point, none of us really wanted to deal with her sour attitude any longer--especially over $12--so we just paid for it. For our own sanity, we asked around the table in case they really did serve us the extra dish, but everyone confirmed that there were only 2 orders of that dish.

As I write this review, I'm starting to have an epiphany: Maybe the restaurant is empty because waiters like her keep customers from returning.

There are some positives notes, e.g. A&H has a great beer selection and some fresh seafood. Sure, the portions are small and quite expensive, but that's many San Francisco establishments. It's just unfortunate that the service left such a bad taste in my mouth.
author: Basile K.

description:
Mediocre food and horrible service. 
Went for dinner on a Friday night. Not fully booked but reasonably busy. Took about 30 minutes to flag down the waiter. Ordered appetizers and main courses for 3 of us. Waited forever for drinks and then immediately after drinks came all the food. Some main courses first and then rest of main courses with appetizers. Now we didn't come to a fast food and but came to hang out and socialize as well as eat. 
We asked the waiter if he thought this was appropriate? Answer: " I have no idea"
Wow. Nice ah!!
15 min later came back and offered a half hearted apology and said he would get me a free beer. Beer came another 30 minutes later. But not the one I was drinking instead a heavy dark ale. Why? No idea. At this point we just wanted to leave to so left it at that. 
If the food was great maybe it would make up for it but it was very very mediocre. Octopus was tough and the fish we ordered was fairly bland. 
Will never come back.
author: Marc V.

description:
Happy hour with friends. Went inside and hostess says there isn't any available seats at the moment (place had about 4 other parties there and was EMPTY). She said we can have a seat but we'd have to get up in an hour and a half (who says that??). I went to check OpenTable and sure enough they were on there and reserved a table at the exact time we arrived. I then told her I had a reservation and she then proceeded to seat us...

I guess we were there a bit early because the waiters were nowhere to be found. Someone told us after we were sitting with our menus for a good 15 minutes that all the servers were in a meeting in the back.

I ordered a dozen happy hour oysters ($1) and Fish Tacos, Tomatillo Salsa, Cilantro 2 per order ($8). The oysters were good but the fish tacos were not that great. The whole thing was soggy and the fish was not crispy and felt extremely oily. They also only have flour tortillas. 

Throughout our meal, we did have difficulties getting the attention of any waiter. There didn't really seem to be a designated one for our section/table.
author: Lauren K.

description: Great happy hour with $1 oysters and pretty normal drink prices. Friendly service and not too crowded when I was there on a Friday. Will return.
author: Peter W.

description:
I have been coming here for a few years and the food never disappoints.  When I am feeling healthy, I opt for the crab Louie salad with a nice, big lump of crab meat.  When I am feeling indulgent, their fried fish sandwich is pretty darn perfect.  They also have these house-made chips which they serve with aioli that are pretty addictive.

But, one of the best parts is their $1 oyster happy hour.  These guys use some quality oysters, nice and fatty.  Some places give the small, skinny oysters, but Anchor and Hope always serves the freshest, tastiest ones.  I always eat a least a dozen!

Nice spot, always bustling but not overly crowded, and great service.
author: Sandra S.

description:
TIP: Parking Garage is just down the street (looks like an alley but there is a garage on the left past the restaurant.

We arrived right on time for our 7:30pm reservation. If there is one thing that really ticks me off it's getting seated long after your reservation time (people sometimes sit forever and won't clear tables) but tonight we were seating only 5 minutes after our reservation.  Scores a star!   

Our server was great (but see below). She was very friendly, offered recommendations and let us know everything was on the menu.  We were then served with their homemade chips and sauce which is a nice spin away from bread and butter.  The chips were great, highly addictive.

We started out with a dozen oysters (see photo). We did the entire West Coast (3 oysters each of the 4 types).

Kumiai
Miyagi
Kudomo
Kusshi

Miyagi is usually my favorite and again they were here...smaller and the sweetest of all the oysters. I like to chew and taste my oysters unlike other people who say they do oysters and just slurp em down like their eating spaghetti...chew those suckers and taste them!  Oysters were great, nice and fresh and they had a great sauce along with the vinaigrette sauce you always see.  The cocktail sauce had fresh ground horseradish...I mean FRESH, not the stuff out of the jar which I see a lot. 

We then decided to go with several appetizers and one main dish.  We order the Mussles which were good...nothing different than fresh mussels anywhere else...good broth (thick and tomato based with very nice flavor).

Next up was the salmon tartare which we thought was fantastic.  The flavors in the salmon were full of the various ingredients especially the Fresno chiles which were very mild combined with everything else...just a perfect combination.

On to the grilled baby octopus and you have a wonderful plate of octopus, perfectly grilled (you could tasted the grilling) tenticles ( love those suckers!...no pun intended) and a great texture.  Very tender but not mushy, thus very fresh.

Our final course was the Red Spotted Trout which is probably the best trout I have had in a long time. Perfectly seasoned, cooked whole (no head) and deboned (found just a few small bones but that's to be expected with trout) and the best tasting crispy trout skin I have ever had.  Don't skip the skin!

We had a fantastic pumpkin bread pudding for dessert along with a few cappuccino's.
The coffee was not hot which was a bummer but by the time we got the coffee we were ready to just finish and go.  We also were served our desserts 10 minutes before the coffee came which is a negative for me.  Timing also was a bit off toward the end of the meal and we waiting a long time for dessert and then the coffee.   All in all I would recommend you have a meal here.  The food is excellent.

Be prepared for a very noisy dinner as it appears everyone that was there enjoyed yelling at each other.  I almost yelled EF HUTTON....for those of you who remember...and those that's don't...watch YouTube and search for it!

4 stars. (Get the timing and coffee hot and 4.5 stars)
author: Jay G.

description:
We didn't have a great experience here tonight. We wanted to come for happy hour, 4:30 to 6. 

We got in at 4:45, placed our order by 4:50, but didn't get our food til 5:30. They had admitted to forgetting our order and we reminded them around 5:20.

We ordered 18 dollar oysters and a side of fries. They served the first dozen and then forgot to bring the last half dozen. 

Cherry on top of the experience is that my boyfriend found a hair in the fries :( it definitely wasn't my hair color. They replaced the fries then ended up giving them to us for free. 

In the end the oysters were really tasty and fries were good too. They made honest mistakes but unfortunately it wasn't the best overall experience for us. 4-5 stars for food, the waiters were friendly, but service wasn't on top of their A game.
author: Monica B.

description: I love their appetizers like shrimp cocktail, ceviche. Not a fan of Angle Horseback though
author: Vy T.

description:
Went there for a special birthday dinner. Loved it! My friends had grilled oysters for appetizers. Not sure they noticed that I watched them licking the shells! I had the gazpacho and sopped up every drop with a hard roll. Our entrees were fish & chips, salmon with quinoa, and fishermen stew. The calamari in the stew was a bit overdone but everything else was excellent. 
The restaurant is noisy but had a very interesting decor. Would definitely go back.
author: Elan W.

description: Amazing experience. The food was incredible but that's not what sold me. We were the first through the door on a Sunday evening. I quickly realized our server was also the manager as he informed us the restaurant was supposed to be closed that evening but since OpenTable had booked reservations anyway, he called the staff in to serve them. He couldn't have been more friendly, accommodating or classy. The building is beautiful, the staff is amazing and the food is impeccable. This is what separates good restaurants from the great ones. These folks truly care about their craft and it shows. Keep it up!
author: Austen G.

description: Outstanding food, cuisine and atmosphere. I loved the decor; from the mural on the bar wall, to the exposed brick and wood in the ceiling, fab lighting, chunky wood tables. The service was amazing. And the food was perfect. Our best meal of our trip to SF. We had oysters, fishermans stew, prawns, and sea bass. Ended with delish dessert. Highly recommend. Will be back next time.
author: Emily G.

description:
I have to say, being here the first time. It was awesome. You have to make a reservation as it seems that is pretty full. It's a good environment plenty of attention and nice service. 

You have to try the lobster rolls. That it's a must.
author: Abe M.

description:
Great place for seafood - definitely worth the trip!

We always go there when in San Francisco - the seafood is fresh, the oysters are the best and Happy Hour is tremendous - do yourself a favor and check it out!
author: Joe M.

description: If you are a seafood fan this is a must go place. It was an office dinner so we got to try a lot of things. A special call out for the ceviche with rock fish and the grilled octopus. I had a main of salmon with butter beans. Delicious. The wine selection was excellent. I loved the place!
author: Vidya K.

description:
Enjoying bacon wrapped oysters (yes, bacon wrapped ousters!) raw oysters, fish and chips, mixed salad, ceviche and linguine with clams in tomato white wine sauce, my girls and I had a fabulous time here!

Located in an alleyway, Anchor & Hope gets most of their business mainly from people who work in the Financial area and want to dine somewhere close after work - while being guaranteed with some fine dining and above average seafood entrees!

Even though it was busy, the servers and bartenders were accommodating and friendly on getting whatever you want in a jiffy.  Make sure to call in for reservations if you are planning to head here!  It was still a full house with a wait when it was after 9pm on a Thursday night!

I really liked their raw oysters and ceviche!  Their raw oysters tasted very fresh and they offer imports from east and west coast!  Nice!  As for their ceviche, the zesty flavor tingled my taste buds and it was asking for more, more, more!

The atmosphere to this seafood restaurant was hip and contemporary.  I loved it!

Great spot in the alleyway for some seafood and drinks with a group or with two!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I've been here a few times and have enjoyed my meals each time.  The decor and vibe are really cool.  The angels on horseback were very good.  I mean, how can you go wrong when it's wrapped in bacon?  The shrimp roll with avocado on a brioche bun was delicious and very filling during lunchtime.  Their New England Clam Chowder was filled with flavor and had a lot of clams in it.  It was the right consistency and filled with flavor.  The Bucatini, gulf shrimp with lobster carrot sauce was flavorful and the gulf shrimp was cooked perfectly.  

Enjoyed the Calicraft brew and the service has always been good.  I also enjoy their complimentary chips as well.  I'd recommend making a reservation, since it can get really busy.
author: Lon H.

description:
I came on a Friday night after work, and I was told that there would be a one hour wait for a table for 3. However, I left my number and the hostess had a table ready for me in 15 minutes. The servers were patient even though my friends were an hour late.

The food is more on the expensive side as expected, but the quality was fine. We had the medium seafood platter which included a dozen oysters, 8 little neck clams, large prawns, ceviche, and crab salad. The oysters were in different varieties and free of sand. They were good, though not amazing. We also got the clam chowder, which lacked a bit in flavor because it was rather thin and not as creamy as I would've liked. The desserts were great! The Darkstar cocktail was good but a little too sweet. There were many varieties of beer to choose from.

Overall, nice atmosphere and food was reasonably fresh and good.
author: Lily L.

description: My party of three started with the large platter of shrimp, crab, clams and oysters. It was very well done and the crab meat was to die for and the shrimp were very large with good taste. We then had the clam chowder which was perfect - not too thick and not too runny with hearty portions of clams. I had the lobster roll which was good not great, however my wife's sea bass was excellent and our guest's fisherman's stew was also very good. The service was average, which kept his from being a 5 star.
author: Don H.

description:
I've been here now 3 times for dinner and twice for lunch. the menus are different

perhaps a little overpriced for the value, but the food is awesome, the waitstaff is really friendly and congenial and the atmosphere is really nice, although it can be a little noisy. 

although it's primarily a seafood place, the meat dishes are fantastic. don't be afraid to order the steak sandwich at lunch. 

the lobster roll is as good as can be found in New England. oysters are always delicious. so is the baby octopus, bouillabaisse and cod

no mixed drinks, just beer and wine, but the wine prices are pretty good. with the seafood, especially shellfish,  sauvignon blanc is always a safe choice and usually pretty reasonable.
author: Bob U.

description:
We stopped in after work for hh. They have a limited menu, but their options were really good. They have dollar oysters; steal of a deal. They were alright. Three some lemon juice and sriracha on them. Not too bad. They were a little fishy that day, but my friend swears by them and said it was just an off day. 

Their best menu item was he Angels on horseback....aka bacon wrapped oysters. Oh em geeee! Sooo delicious. Crispy bacon, yummy oysters, and a really good dipping sauce to compliment them both. 3.50 each for these...definitely worth it. 

Their hh beer was really good too. A brew from walnut creek. Gotta love local support. 

Oh! And we had popcorn shrimp. They are pretty good. Not anything to rave about, but definitely on he good side. I like the light batter and yummy dipping sauce.

I wish I could give this place 3.5 stars instead of 4. I went with 4 bc of the food. Wanted to give them less because their service blew. Any time anyone in my party asked for something, they said wait. Then they'd come back at least five minutes later to take one order and leave again. It was slow. They can definitely be more friendly as well. I was with seven people and each person was irritated with the servers. It wasn't even busy!
author: Morgan F.

description:
So sad, this place was once our favorite. We were treated so rudely by pretty much everyone (the hostess, then the manager, then the waiter... only the bus staff were nice). 

Even with over $100 spent on happy hour for 3 people they made us feel incredibly unwelcome; so much attitude that we all just sat there a bit shocked. We arrived at opening for a happy hour before the dinner rush and they very reluctantly offered us a table (I guess the new rule is that you're not allowed a table during that time, fair enough). There are a lot of ways to handle a table you need to turn over quickly but passive aggressive, downright snarky comments should not be one of them in the service industry. Just tell us straight up that you need the table by 6:30 and we'd be cool with it. Instead we had a prolonged encounter of rudeness and three forgotten orders. Anchor & Hope, your oysters remain some of the best in the city but come on... being nice to your customers is what keeps your business in business (and the vibes pleasant to be around). Please return to the happy place we kept on the calendar month after month...
author: Marie A.

description: Great experience and staff was super flexible to us adding another person to the reservation.   The food was epic and pay attention to the seasonal themes as in crab is something you need to pay close attention
author: Tim K.

description: We came here for dinner on Saturday.  We arrived 15 minutes early for our 7:15 reservation and there were 6-8 empty tables.  The hostess says she can't seat us because it would be too much for the wait staff. Huh?  How do they ever handle a full restaurant?  An obvious push to get us to buy a drink at the bar and we thought about leaving.  Then we get seated by the front door (again, many empty tables) after the hostess asks us if we had a reservation.  Luckily, our server was friendly and competent and the food was good.  Other odd thing... we asked for bread and were given unbelievably stale, inedible bread. When we told our server, she acknowledged the bread was bad but said that's all they had since too many people had ordered bread that night.  7:30 on a Saturday?  She did bring some chips by to make up for it but it should never have been served.
author: A B.

description:
Anchor & Hope can be summed up like this: excellent food, excellent service

I am a frequent patron and can say that their lunch and dinner service are wonderful. This is the place to go for delicious seafood. Great raw bar and entrees, whether for lunch or dinner, have never been a disappointment. One of my favorites is their fish and chips plate. Thumbs up to their lobster roll, too. Also recommend the moules frites. Drinks are also on point with nicely-crafted cocktails but beer is definitely worth ordering, too.
author: Grayson E.

description:
I came here for HH, specifically their $1 oysters, which is on weekdays from 4:30-6. The restaurant has nice decor and a dim, laid back vibe that's perfect for hanging out after work. Also, it's not crowded at all, so you don't have to worry about fighting to get a waiter's attention to order before HH ends (we all know how painful that can be in the city...). 

They also have an extensive beer menu. I got really excited when I saw Pliny from Russian River on the list but it was less palatable at the price of $15 for a bottle. Excellent beer, but ridiculous price. We also ordered fries to share - $6. Fries weren't very good, so don't get that.

I recommend coming here only for the dollar oysters during HH, the prices for the rest of the food seem pretty insane, even by SF standards. However, their good service, lack of wait, and plenty of space will make me a return customer whenever I'm in the mood for some oysters.
author: Venus L.

description:
Love coming here after work. Check the menu before going. You'll be torn on what to choose.

We always start with oysters. They're always great and fresh. Lots of seafood choices there so we try to order a couple of different things and share.

They have a great craft beer selection with some local options.

I can't speak to dessert as we've never had room. It can get packed quickly so I recommend reservations.
author: Ed G.

description:
Came here for a welcome lunch in my honor. True rating is probably 3 & 3/4, but looking back through my pics is making me hungry, so I'll round up. 

***CATFISH SANDWICH, avocado, southern-style cole slaw, pickled jalapeño mixed greens

Quite a generous slab of catfish served on this toasted bun (methinks baguette). I never know how to describe the taste of catfish flesh besides "slightly dirty", not in a repulsive or overwhelming way--maybe "earthy" is the right word. Not quite creamy & sweet, though. The coleslaw was rather subdued, and there frankly wasn't enough avocado to notice--the sandwich would have been become forgettable as is, but when I unloaded the entire side of pickled jalapeños & carrots directly therein and started dipping the sandwich in the creamy dressing of sorts that was intended for the chips, it instantly gained some character and made a tasty finish. 

The mixed greens with cherry tomato, radish, & cucumber was surprisingly gardeny & fresh, with a light vinaigrette of sorts to carry it through. A plus where most fail. 

ALL IN ALL:

Mind not blown, but after a little tweaking, ya got yerself one pretty satisfying sandwich there. Next time I'll have to try the Angels on Horseback.
author: Elliott D.

description:
This place is literally, AS GOOD AS IT GETS!!!! I was in town from Sunday to Wednesday and found myself coming here, every night!  Let me explain why:

1.  They are slightly off the beaten path which means you are likely to find a spot at the bar without issue and maybe even a nice table.
2.  The food is OUT of this WORLD!  In the few nights that I've been here, I've consumed 6 Duxbury, Mass oysters (they will change your life), the Arugala Salad (thin slices of Granny Smith apples, manchego cheese, candied walnuts, and black pepper vinaigrette), Smithwick's beer battered flounder with fries, and last but certainly not least, the Bucatini pasta which is Gulf shrimp, clams, in a lightly spicy sauce (if you've ever had the shrimp Diablo at bonefish, the sauces are very similar)
3.  THE BEER!  This beer list is ridiculous! Pliny the elder (for you IPA lovers) and many many more options!  I won't give their list justice if I try so if you like beers, GET OVER HERE!
4.  This has got to be my absolute favorite reason to recommend a place...THE STAFF!!!!!  Everyone from the front of the house to Aaron (boss), Tom, Adam, Dustin (hardworking bartender/waiter)...to the rest of the amazing people that make up this team.  In the multiple visits here I've personally witnessed them dealing with difficult customers with finesse all the way to the customer that strolled in absolutely trashed at 9:59 (1minute before close) and obnoxiously orders a whole bottle of wine.  On one side note, I had already paid my bill and was getting ready to leave so don't judge me!    I wouldn't subject my worst enemy to 5 minutes with this complete A-hole, but to watch this team articulately and PROFESSIONALLY work with him was truly mind blowing!  In those moments that I would have already flipped, they represented composure and poise!  My hat is truly off to this team!

Bottom line:  I always look forward to visiting SF!  I have the best time, meet awesome people and see great friends.  The networking here is priceless for me.  Anchor and Hope just gave me another reason to look forward to coming to this awesome city.  If you value Quality, service, and BEER you should look forward to your next trip out here or if you're a local, look forward to your next reason to eat out and treat yourself.  They are an Anchor for sure, holding down this block and the Hope is, that you love yourself enough to realize you deserve an experience that they offer!  You're welcome Yelpers!
author: Brian H.

description:
First of all, I LOVED this place. The first thing I noticed when walking in was the amazing natural lighting that spilled out from overhead. The wood floors add so much charm and actually add a pleasant aroma that can't be ignored. 

The staff were friendly, efficient and attentive to my large party. Excellent service.  

I ordered ordered the Lobster roll, after asking the waiter if I should order the lobster roll or the Sole dish. He told me they only had 9 rolls left, so I jumped on it. I mean, if the dish has the establishments name in it, then they must be proud, and I have to order. I was not disappointed. It came with a creamy coleslaw, beautiful potato tater tots, and a gorgeous lobster roll. There was plenty of lobster in the beautifully toasted roll. The ONLY feedback I have, is I wish that a lemons wedge was served, as it needed a little added brightness. 

Five stars from me!!! Well done!
author: Cat B.

description: For $31.00 the lobster roll was the worst I have ever tasted.  The roll was so over toasted, it crumbled.  Hard to eat with a knife and fork.  The servers where unfriendly and had attitudes.  With so many good restaurants in San Fran, I'd suggest looking elsewhere.
author: Scott S.

description:
I came here for my friend's birthday dinner. It was perfect for the occasion -- lively enough to set a fun mood, but not super loud to the point where you can't hold a conversation. The decor and ambiance of the place are really nice. Sophisticated but not formal, it has a very hip and modern vibe.

The service was excellent. Our server was very patient with us, and gave great recommendations.

I tried some of the oysters and they were absolutely delicious. Served very chilled, and tasted very fresh. I paired my oysters with a beer from their expansive collection.

For my meal, I opted for the Lobster Roll and was happy with my decision. The coleslaw and tater tots were both so delicious.

Overall, a good experience for dinner. Not the cheapest option, but totally reasonable for the Financial District/SOMA area! I'd definitely recommend this place for a casual dinner with friends or co-workers.
author: Greg J.

description:
I went there for lunch on a weekday. It took them a long time to seat the three of us despite having reservations. I would have dinged them a star for the wait, but the host was very cognizant of it and brought us a free dessert to share at the end of our lunch. Things go wrong all the time, but the fact that they had such a great way of handling it shows the professionalism of the establishment. 

Food wise, the table had the some oysters, the grilled sole, fish and chips, and the lobster Po'boy. I split the po'boy and fish and chips 50-50 with one of my companions and it was definitely a smart decision since you get the best of both worlds. I love fish and chips, but there's only so much of it you can eat before getting a little queasy. The fish was well battered, fully cook, and everything stuck together in one solid piece - not the crap where batter and fish separate. The fries were incredibly crunchy, and I originally thought they were double-fried, but it turns out they use rice bran oil, which imparts an extra crunch for some reason. The lobster was perfectly chilled and tender, placed on a well buttered, fluffy bun.

I would definitely go back again, and totally worth the wait!
author: Peter T.

description:
My husband and I enjoyed a lovely dinner here recently on a Saturday evening before seeing 'Cabaret'. We were seated at a quaint romantic table with an L-shape bench seat that was situated away from the other tables. 
The staff is well-trained; friendly, yet professional, and really knows the menu. Everything we ordered was fabulous! 
-The fries were piping hot!
-Could have placed a second order of the crispy calamari with pickled veggies, jelépeno, micro cilantro had a crazy good Thai chili dressing!
-PEI mussels were wonderful!
-Halibut Ceviche was great, although the portion was more appetizer-sized.
-Fabulous clam chowder as well!
The staff here is awesome! They seem to do a 'shared-table' system which I really like. Instead of having to wait for 'our waiter' who may be busy, any waiter who sees a need: water glass/wine glass filled, dirty dishes cleared, food brought out when ready takes care of it! I felt as though we received faster/more attention/service this way.
We will definitely go back and we HOPE anyone reading this will check out Anchor & Hope as well!
author: K D.

description: I like Anchor and Hope a lot.  I've been coming since it opened and with all the choices in SF to come back to a restaurant 3 or 4 times means it's good to me.  It has a great ambiance and even better service. The lobster gnocchi was just absolutely fantastic. The bacon wrapped oyster was tasty. Braised ribs were fall off the bone good. I would eat here twice a week if I could but I can't.  Did I say lobster roll ?
author: Andrew S.

description: the service and vibe was great but honestly the food wasn't good.  i had the lobster roll w/fries instead of the tots.  Tots are huge bc someone else ordered the same as me and they were good.  but the lobster roll wasn't huge and taste wasn't great.  my coworker had the cod and fries and it's a huge piece but stated it didn't taste great either.  went for admin day but for myself i wouldn't pay that much for what we rec'd.
author: Tasha D.

description:
Per an acquaintance's recommendation, our family placed a reservation here to celebrate my parent's 50th wedding anniversary. 

Well ... the overwhelming impression I got from this place is: Come here if you're between ages 20-40. Past that? Don't. And I'm gonna be 50 next year, too! 

Overall Impressions & Anecdotes:
* That chic "unfinished" look from the late 1990s
* Super-cold metallic chairs ... BRRRR!!
* No full bar. Beer & Wine only. They were also out of a few beers when I asked.
* Seafood appetizer platter = meh. Well ... okay ... Meh with a capital "M".
* Complementary homemade potato chips were nice
* The menu seems tired & played out. Don't get me wrong, though: If you're younger and haven't been exposed to this type of offering, this is a GREAT, GREAT PLACE to begin building the foundation of your foodie wisdom!
* For dessert, it was a good thing I was wearing a wine-colored shirt because the port I ordered was spilled over the table as it was handed to me. Funnily enough, the staff immediately blamed the uneven tables placed together. So I'm sitting there, wiping off, thinking, "Hmmm ... these guys immediately came to the correct conclusion as to how this mess occurred. Lemme guess: This shit happens fairly often here, n'cest pas?"

So, in sum, if you're going to celebrate your parents' Golden Anniversary, straight-up *don't* do it here. Find someplace with a dark wood interior (or hyper-modern low-lit one), cushioned seats, and Harris Steakhouse-level service. If you've just moved to The City from fresh-outta-college and want to dive in to a fair representation of continentallly-fusiony-California-y cuisine, this is a great place to start!
author: Greg T.

description: Came here for a quick happy hour before heading to an event with some friends. We were greeted by a not so friendly hostess, which gave us some pretty bad vibes to start off with, but the other staff members were nice so that made up for it. We each got a glass of wine, the fried chicken bites, and fries and malt vinegar. Everything was pretty decent but nothing to brag about. The portions are SO SMALL, even compared to most other happy hour menus. I did really love the decor and the nautical feel throughout, so I'd like to come back and try it again for dinner. Overall, just an okay happy hour, but it was a nice place to start off the night!
author: Jaymie S.

description:
I really liked this place! Great food, amazing service, romantic atmosphere. Orange/Yellow dimly lit, no table cloths, but clean and widely spaced restaurant with many tables and a bar. We came on a Saturday night and there were many tables open, but the host said they were all booked so we sat by the bar.  By the time we left all the tables were booked.  So if you don't want to sit by the bar, make sure to reserve a spot! 

ANGELS ON HORSEBACK aka BACON WRAPPED OYSTERS ($14): [5 stars] Omg, this was amazing! Bacon wrapped oysters...what more do I have to explain?! I saw this on foodspotting and was the reason why I wanted to come to Anchor & Hope. Bacon wasn't too crunchy or too soft, it was just right wrapped around juicy oysters. Dip that in the rémoulade sauce and you have amazingness!!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iy1KBR5hRNcgCaqiUoBSoA?select=cdOV6QeNczwmKJc_K_y0zw#kKpJlyeK77VvDWf0ymj5wQ

SEA URCHIN & DUNGENESS CRAB LEMON BEURRE BLANC ($12): [3.5 stars] I also saw this on food spotting and it looked really delicious.  Sea Urchin and Dungeness crab on a creamy rich soup?  But when we got it, it was VERY sour, too strong of a lemon taste to handle.  The service here actually brought our soup back and fixed it to our liking, so I thought that service deserves 5 stars! It wasn't sour anymore, but this time it was really buttery. The sea urchin and dungeness crab were delicious, and the soup was better too, but if only there was a balance between the lemon and the butter then it would be perfect.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iy1KBR5hRNcgCaqiUoBSoA?select=cdOV6QeNczwmKJc_K_y0zw#MSskSUJg7GndCTiQiDzOZg

LOBSTER ROLL ($24): [4 stars] we split the lobster roll and the dish was great.  The brioche bread was perfectly toasted and yummy with butter.  The lobster was light on the mayo, as well as the cole slaw on the side.  They also service you Old Bay Kettle Chips with tarter sauce. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iy1KBR5hRNcgCaqiUoBSoA?select=cdOV6QeNczwmKJc_K_y0zw#WHrDGlBRAnS-PFsf8dWOnQ

MUSCAT: I love moscato because it's so sweet.  They didn't have moscato but the server said the sweetest would be muscat, pronounced mus-ca-re.  It was basically moscato without the sweet aftertaste, so it wasn't bad, just didn't go down as easily.  I still enjoyed it, and you have to get wine when you wine and dine at a fancy place like this :) 

FOOD: 4 stars 
SERVICE: 5 stars
ATMOSPHERE: 4.5 stars

OVERALL: Anchor & Hope started off a lovely night.  If you like seafood, great service, and a romantic and nice atmosphere, I'd recommend coming here :)
author: Raquel Y.

description:
I've only been here twice on the company dime, so I must disclose that I've never paid for my own meal here, which is nice because it is a pricier restaurant. However, I've enjoyed the food both times I've been. 

Parking is hard so we've always taken a taxi or Uber here. It's located in a small alley so might be easy to miss at first. Inside, the space is very roomy with high ceilings. (One thing my coworker pointed out to me my second time there was that the door was super squeaky...so of course after she pointed it out, I noticed it every time someone opened the door...I really wanted to put some WD-40 on those hinges!)

The first time I came, I had the lobster roll. It was deeee-lish! The bread is toasted oh so perfectly with just the right amount of butter. So crispy and delicious. The lobster was also yummy - it was a great combo with just enough flavor. I've experienced a few lobster rolls where it just tastes too bland for me, but not this one! The lobster roll also comes with these awesome ginormous tater tots. The second time I came, I was torn because I really wanted the lobster roll again but also wanted to try something different. Luckily, I was able to convince my coworker to do halfsies with me. So he ordered the lobster roll and I got the fish sandwich. Yum! It came with a nice light salad and the sandwich was perfect. The fish was cooked perfectly and together with the sauce was delicious. 

Overall, good dining experience with yummy food.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Fun, hip, industrial vibe without the pretentious people. The seafood platter was perfect for a warm night. I'd definitely return to explore the menu.
author: Sarah F.

description:
I went here for a work lunch and the food and service was AMAZING! Not sure why this place is only rated 3.5, this place was stellar.

Made reservation on Open Table for lunch, super easy.

The Food:

Clam Chowder: Flavorful and rich. I've had many clam chowders in my days, and this was  one of the best.

Oysters: We had a dozen of the various oysters they had, all great.

Mussels: Yes, recco too! haha.

All in all, I will definitely come back for my next seafood fix!
author: Kim H.

description: I was not pleased. The food was marginal. The service was flat and unwelcoming. The restaurant was uncomfortably warm and needs more air circulation. Too many stellar restaurants in SF to compete for my food dollars. I will not return.
author: John Y.

description:
Good, but inconsistent. They have an impressive selection of beer on tap and good seafood, but their cooks appear to be inconsistent. 

After about ten visits. Some of their more consistent dishes are Angels on Half shells and their Tatter Tots, but I think their servers understand their cooks either have OFF days or perhaps a high turn over in staffing. 

I do not recommend their lobster roll, but their salmon is usually good, and their muscles are cooked well, though under seasoned. 

They are close to my work so I come here and send back stuff that is too horrible to ingest.
author: Dean N.

description:
$27 a lobster roll with a few tater tots is a bit overpriced.  I didn't order it so I can't comment on the taste but judging from the look, there weren't much lobster meat at all and mixing the meat with mayo and masking the natural lobster flavor definitely a no no for me. 

My order of shrimp carbonara was good except the kitchen added a tad too much chili flakes so it was somewhat spicy for me.  

The fried chicken sandwich looked ok but it only had half chicken fillet.  You can tell they fried a whole pieced but only half was used on the sandwich.

The bacon wrapped oysters was tasty and good appetizer to start with.
author: Shirley H.

description:
It was halloween, it was raining, and the Giants had just celebrated a World Series win. It was a eventful day leading to a grumbly stomach. While in the area I used the trusty yelp app to look this place up. It was still happy hour so I made the trek to Anchor and Hope. It's nicely decorated with ship decor. My husband and I were dressed head to toe in Giants gear because hey, we just won. Granted we weren't super dressy, we just wanted some good food to celebrate.

As soon as we walked in the door I felt out of place. We were awkwardly standing at the front while waiters walked passed, and the place was only about 25% full. We tried to find the hostess, manager, somebody..anybody..to seat us. It took quite a while for the hostess to finally come, and she was not a pocket full of sunshine. I'm not sure if she was just having a bad day, but it instantly brought down our celebratory spirit. Okay, moodiness aside, she gave us the menus. I had read on yelp about their happy hour, so I asked her what was on it. She rolled her eyes and then went to get a separate happy hour menu. I would have missed it completely had I not known. That was the last we saw of her. Thank god.

Now our actual waitress was very friendly and upbeat. The $1 oysters were stellar, and so were the $3.50 fried oysters, I cold have eaten a dozen of them. 

For dinner I had the lobster roll and my husband had the fillet fish. The total for the night was over $75 without drinks. I felt the prices were absurd for the main courses but I guess they are shooting for a upperclass feel, the staff however did not help with that. The 5 star reviews on Yelp for this place surprise me quite a bit, maybe it was just a off night.
author: Bevi K.

description: Service a bit of a problem here. One of my biggest pet peeves, I ask for a side salad instead of fries on a burger and they say no problem, and then the bill shows a $2 surcharge. On a $17 burger that wasn't very good to begin with. It's a pain point for me, and it's a deliberate move by the waitress not to tell me. Frustrating! If the food was better, I'd probably give this place a second chance. For the price, though, it's not worth it.
author: Alex B.

description:
One of my favorites in San Francisco.  Great selection of drinks, especially beer (that includes the hard-to-find Russian River beers). The oysters are a great choice to pair with your happy hour drinks. I have had about half the items on the menu, but my favorites are the angels on horseback and the lobster roll. In fact, this is one of the only places in SF where you can even get a lobster roll.  

In terms of the space, there is plenty of seating - so coming for lunch, happy hour or dinner is great. The atmosphere is also pretty cool - open/exposed ceilings, stainless steel bar and concrete floors.  Being here reminds me of some of the lobster joints I used to go to in New England as a kid (although a tad nicer!). 

If you haven't been, I suggest you give this place a try.
author: Joe M.

description:
Fantastic place! Definitely one of my favorites in SF. Not only is the food delicious, ambiance perfect, the best part is the staff. Starting with Mr Danny Barrious (general manager), the entire staff is accommodating and very friendly.

Our most recent visit was about three weeks ago. We had made a reservation at a different restaurant online, and upon arrival we were told the restaurant was closed (strange since they had accepted our reservation). Understanding it was late (approx. 9:30), and hesitant to make staff stay late at any restaurant, we decided to give Anchor & Hope a chance. Mr Barrious was very welcoming and adamant that it was not too late to have a quick meal, continously coming over to recommend wine and chat.

Kudos to Anchor & Hope! we will definitely return.
author: Gus C.

description: We came in for the happy hour and we were about 15-20 minutes early. They had us wait until happy hour until ordering.  The oysters were great for $1 a piece. The shrimp was yummy. The steamed mussels were delicious as well. It was a toss up between 3-4 stars.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
"Without a reservation the wait will be 2 hours 40 minutes." Be sure to get a reservation. Fortunately we were seated at the bar in 15m.

I'd like to love this place with we were ignored for 15m. And it took a long time to receive our food. Perhaps the wait wouldn't be 2:40 if they were a little faster with the service.

Excellent drink menu. Very creative menu.

My lobster roll was good, but fairly bland.
author: Will D.

description:
The lobster roll was skimpy on the lobster (see my pix). I mean, really? $28 for this? When I complained, the maître 'd kindly offered to bring me some more lobster. I declined, but that was nice of him. 

1 green salad ($12), 1 lobster roll ($28), 1 glass of chardonnay ($15) plus tax

TOTAL: $62 + $10 tip (well, the waiter was good) = $72!!!!

Yeah, this will probably be the last time I come here, unfortunately.
author: Randy M.

description: This place is DELICIOUS! We had the lobster roll, salmon, and potato leek soup - all fantastic! Great location, very "local" vibe, fresh seafood made perfectly, super friendly staff from host to waiter. Definitely check this spot out!
author: SF M.

description: Food was way over priced. We like to eat health and the food was too greasy for us.
author: Marilia H. G.

description:
We were in SoMa and were super hungry and walking past Minna St, I saw Anchor & Hope. Through friends recommendations, we ducked in. It was almost 9pm Friday and didn't need a reservation for a table of 4. 
Ordered a bottle of prosecco which was fabulous (forgot the name). Baby octopus and ceviche appetizers was tasty too.
It is a 'fish' based restaurant so I chose the snapper for the mains and my party ended up with fish and chips + the lobster roll which was all generous servings. 
They catered to my gluten free intolerance and our waiter was lovely. 
The setting is great, with bar seating to eat casually or table settings.
author: Van-Anh N.

description:
made same-day reservations, but it seems like this industrial-chic seafood spot will be a hard reservation to get in the near future. Not a disappointment on the menu. Refreshingly little attitude with the service. and although loud, you can't hear conversations at adjacent tables. which is good because there's a lot of posturing going on. Great beer selection. waitstaff doesn't hurry you. and charming old building soon to be overwhelmed by the new salesforce building, which it sits cheek-to-jowl with. In fact, go now if only to peak through  the fence at the construction of the foundation of what will soon be our tallest building.

Tuna crudo, lobster rolls, oysters all excellent. Calamari, unimaginative and rubbery on so many menus, proved a winner -- I wouldn't have ordered it if it hadn't been so well-described on the menu. portion sizes were small, as some people have mentioned, but not universally so. perfect spot for friends, co-workers, family from out of town.
author: Kate B.

description: Really enjoyed the food. It took awhile to get it, but worth the wait. The atmosphere is loud and dark - probably not a date night fit.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Angel on horseback - 2.5 - not my thing..i now realized that I do not like cooked oysters, although the texture of the bacon was good, just not that great. The sauce was nothing special or memorable just like regular aioli...

Rockfish ceviche - 2.5 - super small and it didn't hit me with any punch of flavor..the rockfish texture was on par with what ceviche should be, but it was late during the day so the fish was not as fresh..

Trout salad - 2.5 - bunch of green/string beans and smoked trout. The trout was good, but everything else was bland. The potato on the side didn't really go together, I felt like it should be more married with the dish..

Lobster roll - 2.5 - I now realized I do not like lobster roll. The bread was toasted with butter like it should, but just not my thing. The potato was cute, but would of loved sweet potato instead

Chocolate bread pudding - 3.5 -  more delightful and was moist and delicious. It would of been great if it was served with ice cream instead of whipped cream. The strawberry accompanied the dish well..

Popcorn panna cotta - 2.5 - the panna cotta was like a regular vanilla one with accents of peanut brittle which my friend said it tasted like cracker jack. It would of been better to see real popcorn..

Overall, not sure if I'd come back..maybe not..or maybe for oysters? I think this place is better for oysters only..

The service could of been more prompt especially with water. The seating was a bit tight. It's really noisy and dark inside so hard to hear. 

I thought highly of this place, but quite disappointed..
author: Minerva L.

description:
Anchor & Hope has been on my must-try list for quite some time. It was the perfect opportunity to come here during their happy hour...

$1 Oysters and $5 glass of wine? Can't top that... In the heart of Soma, this spot offers a really gorgeous, contemporary, high-ceiling ambiance. The bar is great for a casual affair, or grab a table with a date/small group to enjoy a more intimate setting.

I would love to return here for a full sit-down-meal. But as for the Happy Hour.. I can't wait to come back!
author: Veronica S.

description: I had high hopes for this place. It wasn't bad but left me feeling lacking. Atmosphere is nice. Waitress was professional but zero personality, not even a smile. I ordered the "famous" lobster roll but it was very cold and comes with tater tots and cole slaw. Seemed like kiddie food. My party enjoyed their meals but we all agreed no way this place was worth the exorbitant price. Almost $300 for 4 people (1 glass of wine each) is a little beyond a normal family budget when it's middle of the road service and food. Too many other places in San Fran to enjoy for better food at better prices.
author: Mark L.

description: The food here was amazing!  We had a lobster roll, muscles, and fish and chips, yum!  Service is good, no complaints there.  We wanted some good seafood and we found it!  I'm so glad a friend recommended this place.
author: Priscilla M.

description: Unlimited dollar oystbros 4:30-6:00 pm in a coolish setting with nice service. Didn't have to compete for seating coughwaterbarcough. Shopping bag / purse hooks under the bar. Don't be surprised if you run into me at Laurel & Ren & Mork & Cagney & Dumb & Larry & Timon & Anchor & Hardy & Stimpy & Mindy & Lacey & Dumber & Balki & Pumbaa & Hope.
author: Dan B.

description: Rude.  Just absolutely rude.  I am appalled at the level disrespect that came from that building today.  Wow...
author: James L.

description:
I had the experience I was expecting to have. Anchor & Hope is well-situated for the business lunch crowd. Located in the heart of fidi, accepts reservations, and lends itself well to small and large groups. Needless to say, was here for a work lunch. 

Service was a bit on the slow side. Our waiter offered up a few suggestions, one being the trout which I ended up going for. Pretty disappointing dish. The trout was honestly so sorry looking. It was the thinnest piece of fish I've seen in some time, honestly equal ratio of skin to filet. A few others in our group went with the salmon which looked more exciting. Still confused on the waiter's rave trout review. Le sigh.
author: Brianna M.

description:
I went here for dinner with some family members. I tasted the:

-Ceviche: not much flavor. Kind of a lot of money for a small appetizer
-Bacon wrapped Branzino with potatoes and brussels sprouts. This was an entire fish with some stuff inside, wrapped in bacon. They told us the fish had been deboned but I found like 12 bones in my first mouthful (subsequent mouthfulls had few to none, but...). Flavor was ok. Bacon was the best part. Potatoes were undercooked, but the brussels sprouts were good.
-Fried flounder and fries. Tasted good. Nice and crispy. Overpriced though, but so was everything here
-Kale salad: overpriced but awesome
-Lemon cheesecake: overpriced and small but seriously tasty
-Chocolate blackout cake: overpriced but awesome

So the food was ok but really not worth how expensive it was. For the price I expect the food to rock. Meanwhile, the servers were super friendly but the food took forever to arrive, and the servers were kind of aggressive about removing plates, even when we were, like, still forking food off them. Finally, one of my family members clandestinely paid half the bill, and the guy who brought the other half of the bill to the table was kind of shifty about it, which made it seem like they had taken items off the bill or given us a deal, rather than that no, a member of our party had just paid for half. So it was kind of like taking credit for something they didn't do.

So it wasn't horrible, and if three stars wasn't "A-OK" I might have given it 3, but I will definitely never go there again, and I wish I had checked the reviews before going there a first time. 
The space is cool and not loud, which was a plus. I would have been satisfied with the experience if it had cost half as much but for a $$$ restaurant there is a higher bar to meet.
author: Audra N.

description:
One of my FAVORITE happy hour joints! 

First... It is cute. It's tucked away in an alley in soma... Which made it hard to find and kind of had me a little worried at first because I was wandering around in an alleyway looking for it, but it is so cute inside. 

Second... Happy hour. Dollar. Oyster. Happy hour. And decent drink  and other food specials to go along with during happy hour. 

Third... The lobster roll!!! Probably one of my favorite lobster rolls in the city so far. I'm not a big fan of mayo but it also disguises the taste of the meat itself especially when used too heavily, but here they are light on the mayo and generous with the lobster chunks. If you want mayo... I don't know, go buy a jar of mayo and eat that. But if you want lobster in your lobster roll... :)
author: Terra C.

description:
i had the lobster roll, for the 142th time, but it's the first time i've eaten the bun! and its carbyyy and deeelicious. anyhoo, i filled up on the kettle chips beforehand, big mistake. but theyre so crunchy and salty and hard to stop eating....but there was hardly ANY lobster on mine...! so sad face.  and the cole slaw, which is usually my fave thing in the world, was too soup-y..! merrrgghhh. bad.

my colleagues got the fish n chips (huuuugggeee portion of fish) and the rock cod dish with lentil and lobster bisque - both looked good and they liked them.

anyhoo, solid fidi sit down lunch spot. i will probably be back again next month considering its steps from my office building..
author: Christina L.

description:
I found Anchor & Hope to be a great place to stop by for lunch (e.g. that rare weekday afternoon when its beautiful outside and you have the time to use a whole lunch hour). The restaurant itself was very open and airy, which gave it almost a relaxed, vacation-like-atmosphere. Between that and the exceptional seafood, it's not hard to imagine the you're beachside. The service was just okay, though- nothing to write home about. 

Enough about the atmosphere though, because I'm sure you're way more interested in the food. The food was excellent- I had a soft shell crab sandwich that was accompanied with a light, citrus-y coleslaw (deeeelicious), and there is currently a persimmon and quinoa salad on the menu that makes me want to drive straight up to SF. 

I am definitely interested in going back to check out their happy hour and to sample a few more offerings from their menu!
author: Alex S.

description: Really beautiful space and an unlikely location. The food was good, but at this price point should have been better - more flavorful, more memorable. Portions were small. Really liked the host when he addressed our undercooked halibut - he was a nice guy. That said, it was an easy place to go.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Worst service ever! Ever!

I came here for my boyfriends birthday. Our server spoke to us maybe twice. It's an expensive restaurant with the worst service I've ever had. 

Don't go.
author: Tumay A.

description:
Wow I really loved this place!  I wanted to mainly come for their happy hour m-f 4:30-6 because they have 1$ oysters.  I arrives right before 5 and had a seat at the bar with my husband.  We had another friend joining us and put our name down for a table later on.  We started with a dozen of the chef selection oysters.  I was worried "chef selection" was code for some crappy leftover oysters but they were actually rocky point oysters and they were AMAZING!  I am an oyster fanatic and these were some of the freshest tastiest west coast oysters I have had.  PLus for the cost it was amazing.  We also had the angels on horseback which was a cooked oyster wrapped in bacon and it was really good- totally expensive though at 3.50 an oyster, I think I liked the raw better.  They had 4 happy hour drinks for 5$- champagne, pinot grigio, red wine, and a beer selection.  I had the champagne and pinot grigio and they were both really great.  Once we sat down we ordered some more dishes such as the fries, popcorn shrimp, ceviche, and tuna salmon tartar.  Some of these were on the happy hour menu some were not.  The fries were my least favorite they were just okay.  The popcorn shrimp were surprisingly delicious and light.  The ceviche was also really tasty and flavored great.  My favorite dish of the night was the salmon and tuna tartar it had passion fruit and avocado mousse and I think I will probably dream about this dish for a long time.  Its served with plantain chips as well.  
The prices were a little on the high side for items not on happy hour but I thought it was well worth the money.  I also want to mention how attentive everyone there is.  That really brought my experience from 4 stars to 5 we were constantly being checked on and all the servers were so friendly.  I would definitely come back here- especially for those oysters and tartar!
author: Kate F.

description:
Horrible terrible service. Was there with co-workers, who were from from out of town. We were there for 1 hour and 10 minutes, during which we were attended to three times - all three times because we flagged them down! If we did not flag them down, then not sure what would have happened.

In addition...
-One of the people in our party asked for bread for the table. We received a small paper bag with a small personal baguette. When we asked why that is (we didn't want to grope the bread with our hands as part of sharing), we were told that it's the way they do things there. No option to bring us a place of sliced bread was offered. Or no offer was made to bring the rest of us some bread.

-We gave very specific instructions to our manager/server on how we want our oysters brought to us. Instructions were - 2 dozen now, and 2 dozen about 10-15 mins later. We got 1 dozen, then 3 dozen about 30 mins later. Oysters where crap - no flavor and incredibly tiny.  Chef's selection it said on the menu. More like "left-over-blowout-of-oysters-that-noone-orders-otherwise" during happy hour.

When we called for the head manager so we can describe our horrible experience - he copped an attitude. I have no idea why that place is there and still in business. Maybe it's a trendy location, in a trendy space, with a trendy menu (average of $30/plate) for bad food?

Please don't go there. That space needs to be occupied by a better foodery.
author: Andre K.

description:
This was a great place to meet friends on a business trip to San Francisco. It's a little hidden gem (although not secret, people definitely know about this place!). I've been to the original Anchor & Hope in London, which is a rustic gastro pub on the South Bank. This place definitely does the Anchor and Hope name justice. The best part of the meal were the Angels on Horseback, smoked bacon wrapped oysters. I read about them in everyone else's Yelp reviews so I knew I'd have to try them. I love oysters. I love bacon. You can't go wrong.

We all shared a lot of the other dishes instead of anyone ordering a main dish. We ordered some ceviche, which was also delicious, and some of the salads.

The beer selection was also impressive and we all tried some delicious new brews. San Francisco turned out to be a beer trip for me! I loved the decor in here. It was dimly lit with marine decorations all over and really tall ceilings. It felt like being in a fishing dock, albeit a luxury fishing dock. I'd definitely recommend this place!
author: Carolyn L.

description: Food and service were good, with one important exception. Noisy. Loud music. Not conducive to dinner and conversation. I requested the music be turned down and was given a blank look. Asked again, and waiter said he didn't think he could do it. Next time, I will adjust  my tip down, or go elsewhere.
author: Becky B.

description:
Had the seafood platter. So Delicious. The atmosphere was very nice. I must admit that I felt a bit sick afterwards, but that could have been because I was so greedy with shoving so much fish inside my mouth....

I would come here again. They only thing holding me back is that it is on the pricey side for the amount of food you receive.
author: Kimberly N.

description:
Great food. Very tasty fish. Big portions & tasty chips to start... Go easy on these. Enormous beer selection & knowledgeable staff to assist with your selection. 
Only drawback is the temperature..... Avoid this place in super hot / cold days, the building is old (has character) & has no AC / ventilation.
author: Barry O.

description:
Just went for a team holiday lunch and it was so good. 
 
1 .APPS:  Ceviche & Tuna Tartare. both very flavorful and fresh
2. MEAL: Lobster roll.... Every review said to try it and it was delicious! The roll was  very cripsy and buttery , and didnt lose its shape when biting into it and made for a sturdy sandwich with no sogginess! Lobster was delicious and  had perfect amount of sauce. 


Recommend for sure!
author: Sarra E.

description:
We had dinner here recently before seeing a show downtown. The place seems like a popular after-work destination for the downtown crowd. It was busy, but not too crowded. After promptly being seated by the hostess, we were then met with some of the worst service we've ever had. We sat for at least 15 minutes without acknowledgment from any of the wait staff. No drink order, no "I'll be with you in just a moment", nothing. I was beginning to wonder if we were actually there. 

The food was nothing special. We ordered oysters to start. When the oysters arrived, I immediately squeezed a bit of lemon on a few. The waiter then informed us that we received the wrong order of oysters. I told him that I'd already squeezed a bit of lemon. His is response was, "everyone likes lemon on oysters" and he then took our oysters to the table that had actually ordered them. WHAT?!?!?!? I sincerely hope those people actually do like lemon on their oysters! For my  main, I had the salmon, which was good; not great. It was very, very greasy. Not oily (like typical salmon), but GREASY. The hubs had the  moules frites, which were pretty good. Again, nothing special. The potato chips given at the beginning of the meal were delicious! Two people, meh food, shi**y service = $200! They're outta their minds. 

Overall, this place is overpriced for meh food and HORRIBLE service. Skip it.
author: Lisa G.

description:
Anchor & Hope is tucked away in a small alley in a great, off the beaten path location near 2nd & Mission.  I like the location and I love the fresh seafood menu.  The sommelier was very helpful in suggesting a bottle of wine that met our needs at a significantly lower price point than expected.  The service here was fantastic from hostess to sommelier to the wait staff.

We started with the Tombo Crudo and Poblano Tomato soup.  The Tombo was sliced like sashimi with a medley of cucumber and tomatoes in a spicy salsa.  The delicious soup was a mildly spicy tomato soup with a puree of poblano peppers.

The three of us ordered salmon, fish & chips and seafood bucatini.  My wife and son loved the salmon and my son's fish & chips were a big hit.  I had the bucatini in a spicy lobster sauce with clams and shrimp, very tasty.

All around, this was a great spot and I'll visit again.
author: Lance W.

description: I like all of this groups establishments; Salt House, Town Hall, and Anchor and Hope. They do gussied up classics without straying too far from the original. This space is a lot larger than I thought it'd be and the selection is very large compared to Salt House. Clam chowder, rockfish, beer battered flounder and all types of oysters fit the bill. The beer menu was maybe the most surprising to me as they have a ton of good Belgians and other craft selections. You could come here for just those alone.
author: Kim N.

description: We met a colleague here for lunch.  He said the lobster roll was excellent so we all went with it.  Good choice!  The chips were very flavorful and they had a good selection of draft beers.
author: James R.

description: Food is good (not great), service is mediocre at best. Some of the servers were downright lovely, but overall the experience was not great. Recommended for oysters and happy hour, not much more.
author: Mark W.

description: Went here after work with a girlfriend of mine. The space is really cute, high ceilings, kinda like a warehouse.
