We just came for happy hour and it seemed like most were there for dinner. There was a very good selection of beer and wine. During happy house they had dollar oysters so we got a couple and they were delicious! I will have to try to come back here for dinner time and see what the food is like.
author: Eileen H.

description:
Went here for happy hour (Monday - Friday 4:30 PM to 6:00 PM). Good atmosphere, good service, and lots of seating!

We had 2 dozen oysters each for a total of 120 oysters. And we could've had 2 dozen more each but decided to refrain, as we felt bad for the oyster shucker in back. Quality control for the oysters was sub-par, but I guess that should be expected when you order 120 oysters? At least they're just $1 each for happy hour. And they seemed fresh enough.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-and-hope-san-francisco?select=9BlYcswhmPUW89kmfL_kIQ#AGu21pGie6evcTGpMGy4pw

We also ordered the fish tacos and fried shrimp, but they were nothing special and I probably wouldn't get them again.

Cornmeal fried shrimp:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-and-hope-san-francisco?select=9BlYcswhmPUW89kmfL_kIQ#9BlYcswhmPUW89kmfL_kIQ
author: Michael W.

description:
lobster roll rocked, as did the little hash brown cylinders.   
It was crowded, glad my colleague made a rez.
primarily SF tech crowd at lunch enjoying a kinda throwback vibe.
author: Ted H.

description:
This place was a let-down.  After months of seeing this place constantly busy I went for a business lunch and tried the tuna tartare appetizer and chicken sandwich.  

I have never experienced a tartare where there is more fluff than actual ahi.  It tasted like cardboard that had been dusted with cilantro and mayonnaise then a little avocado on top for color.  We didn't even finish 1/2 of the order.  As for the chicken sandwich which both my boss and I ordered; it tasted OK but completely fell apart after my first bite.  The bun was much too soggy and ended up having to eat that sandwich with a fork and knife.  The sweet potato chips served with the sandwich need FLAVOR!  

The iced tea was nice.
author: Joshua G.

description: Overpriced for the food here. I would only recommend coming for oysters during happy hour otherwise there's not too many things going for this place.
author: Bill H.

description: Best fish and chips I've ever had. Just the perfect, light flaky breading on the fish...
author: Erika S.

description:
If you are working late in the financial district this place is open late on weekdays for a post work dinner. Make sure you come in with reservations or you may be waiting for a while (30-45 minutes).

It was my first time every trying lobster and the lobster roll was amazing! Prices are kind of steep for an average dinner but I like the ambiance and decoration there.

The place seems pretty busy and the service is not that great and timely. It took about 30 minutes to bring out the clam chowder.
author: Kunal T.

description: Disappointed. Extremely slow service. We 3 were here 3 hours for marginal food. $245 for a few drinks, fish and chips and sole. Sole was great the rest? should have gone to Joe's Crab Shack in Flint.
author: Joe W.

description:
$1 oysters on Wesnesday from 4:30-6. Shucked right in front of you ( I was at the bar) with a glass of pinot grigio. 

The prices are right, super close to FiDi so I don't even need to walk to Embarcadero, and all around a fun time. Nice bartenders and did I mention AWESOME oysters.

Only drawback are the HH time. Wish it would last longer...say 7? Either way, I'll be back!!!
author: Linda L.

description:
Nestled in the alley full of gems that is Minna, Anchor & Hope is a great spot. I love the warehouse-like decor and the tall ceilings/natural light. The dangling ropes and exposed metal add a great touch.

Note that A&H doesn't have a full bar - beer and wine only. Great selections of those.

The salmon tartare was a fantastic starter - rich, buttery fresh salmon cubes with the creaminess of avocados, balanced perfectly by a tangy acidic jalapeno vinaigrette and the brightness of watermelon.

The lobster roll lived up to all expectations - the warm, toasted and fluffy brioche bun was buttery and a perfect compliment to the generous amount of fresh lobster.

A&H would have gotten an easy 5 stars if they didn't miss the mark on my steak - my medium rare steak arrived well done (and they brought my date salmon instead of the ordered lobster roll) - though both mix-ups were remedied very graciously and efficiently.

The whoopie pie ice cream sandwich was a fitting end - rich chocolate and salted caramel ice cream. YUM.

Like most spots in SOMA/FiDi, a meal with drinks won't come cheap - but A&H is a worthwhile effort amidst much competition.
author: Jocelin L.

description:
If there was a way to give a another half star, I would. 

Visiting from the east coast for work and a friend met me in San Fran. We really wanted some seafood and the review for this place looked great so off we went... And thank god we did. I immediately loved the actual restaurant- from the decoration, to the set up, the bar look, the servers appearances. Fantastic start.

Their beer menu is killer- if not a little overwhelming with so many choices. I had the afflegim and it was wonderful. 

We had the calamari and the shrimp cocktail for appetizers- the calamari was seasoned and cooked to perfection and the shrimp was super fresh. The only downside was that the cocktail sauce was very spicy- but still awesome.

My friend got the New York strip steak and I got the fish and chips. Can only say positive things- fries were perfect, steak was flavorful, flounder was battered just right. 

Next time I'm in the area again... I'm definitely stopping by. The only downside is that it's a bit pricey but quality reflects why!"
author: Jenna T.

description:
After hearing about their recipe for Angels on Horseback, Ashely S and myself went on an odyssey to try them...and, I must say, they didn't disappoint.  The preparation was perfection and the flavors were as amazing as we'd heard.

That said, parking was a major PITA and this place is quite pricey...but food odysseys are my favorite kinds of odysseys...good times.
author: Corey P.

description:
I was rather disappointed in the blandness of the lobster meat in the lobster roll, as it was the primary reason for my visit here.  I did not detect any flavor, even with added salt and eating pieces by themselves, just to see if the flavor was being over powered by the roll and other ingredients. The tater tots were great and the cole slaw was good too. 

The clam chowder, while thinner than I usually encounter, tasted very good, but the clam pieces were not chewable and the gristle lodged in my teeth.

The fish and chips were tasty, but oozing with oil -- more than I expected anyway. 

The banana cream pie was amazing, the best item we had. Service was very good, but considering the prices, I was disappointed overall.
author: J M.

description:
Everything is delicious here!! The mussels are utlra rich - be sure to ask for bread to soak up the sauce. 

My husband got the fish and chips and I got the pasta with clams...we realized that we ordered too much food but we were pleased with everything we ordered. 

The service can be a bit slow on a Friday night but the busboys were all very helpful.
author: Mimi T.

description: Thank you for giving us a great night tonight ! We were on business travel and underestimated the number of our reservation from a party of 8 that grew to 10 and the gentleman at the host stand went above and beyond to accommodate us on a busy night . That set the tone for a luxurious experience of fresh and savory seafood dishes that exited the kitchen . Our grand platter was an absolute treat and our entrees were airy and flavorful all at the same time .  We all left happy and now have a great place to visit on our next trip back to HQ. oh and good wine list. !
author: Wendy N.

description:
Great setting and a decent call if you need to get your seafood fix in SF. Here's the rundown on the grub:
 - Ridiculously good Heirloom salad
 - Average Octopus App & Sardines App; felt like I misordered
 - Exceptional King Salmon

I'd come back to try more of the menu
author: Jeff F.

description: I came here with a friend for dinner the other night and I don't really get the mid-level reviews as we were really impressed, especially me. The atmosphere was awesome with high vaulted ceilings and dark-lighting. I had one of sole fish dish with diced celery root and mashed potatoe "drizzle" side.. perfect portion and perfectly cooked. My friend had the pasta dish with seafood and red sauce and she thought her dish was delicous as well. I recommend coming here for a tasty fish dish for an intimate dinner or group.
author: Aryn C.

description:
The calamari was excellent. The complimentary home- made chips with a sweet but acidic white sauce (vinegar and mayo) was excellent. 

We were a large party and had calamari (totally awesome, Dude) and the large raw bar. Two kinds of oysters, clams, mussels, shrimp, ceviche, crab salad and sauces like mignonette, cocktail, and Cajun remoulade were excellent. But the lobster was tough. 

I had ordered the lobster roll as a main course and was disappointed, but not because it was tough. The lobster was seasoned oddly. There was tarragon, which was fine but a "warm" Christmassy taste like cinnamon or cloves was put of place. The cole slaw and tater tots were excellent, as was the service. 
  
There are no distilled spirits but I'm flexible in the face of adversity. The fine list was large and well-priced. It appeared to me that they  doubled the retail price of the wines I could recognize. Many places triple their costs. 

Service was excellent-fast and attentive without being disruptive.  The space is a brick-walled high ceiling room with exposed beams and skylights. It was comfortable old-school seafood house.
author: SR C.

description:
The service was great. I don't know if they are always packed on a Saturday night but service was attentive, friendly and patient. I ordered the lobster roll and it did not disappoint. It will set you back $25 but it's worth it for the cole slaw and tater tots alone (almost). It can be casual but a button up wouldn't hurt. Will definitely be visiting again soon!
Pro tip: request avocado on the side.
author: Stefuhnee A.

description: My new office is just a block away.  I like the food but really wish they had a full bar.  Great littlenecks but I want to have a martini with them!
author: Bob S.

description: Came here for happy hour. The food was okay but not necessarily anything unique for the area. Oysters were a bit small. I guess if you have a client dinner or someone to impress and cost isn't an issue this is a decent place. Otherwise I would recommend a lot of other places.
author: Charles K.

description: While the food was delicious (we ordered brussels sprouts, cod and ceviche), I was primarily wowed by the service!  Our server was Ros and she was WONDERFUL!!!  Very warm, sincere and courteous.  The entire staff was quite lovely.  We'll definitely be back for more!!!
author: christine l.

description:
Amazing amazing amazing! Time and time again. Immaculate service, and incredible food. We had the Washington and Kusshi oysters. The Washington was definitely more textured, but we loved the Kusshi. They were soft and pillow-y in texture, and definitely a mouthful. They were also extremely buttery and smooth. Delicious! 

Josh was our server and was the best! He was totally helpful and very knowledgable. 
The manager, Danny, was also super friendly and very attentive. 

Overall, wonderful service and great food!
author: Tati C.

description:
The space of this place is very unique with great decor. I came here for lunch during the weekday at the end of the big lunch rush so it cleared out pretty fast by 1pm. 

My friend and I shared 2 appetizers: 
- fried calamari: they did it very well and the batter wasn't too heavy, but also nothing amazing about this dish.

- Tartare: I love me a great tartare and it did not disappoint here =)

We also shared a dozen oysters; 6 different types. It all tasted fresh and delicious!

My entree was the fish and chips which I was very happy with. The fish was still nice and juicy while the batter still light and not overly oily. To rinse down all this yummy food I had a glass of their pinot grigio. 

Although this place is pricey, you get great quality food and a fun atmosphere.
author: Ashley P.

description: We tried the Small seafood plateaux, "Angels on horseback" (bacon wrapped oysters), french fries, and the cod.  Everything was amazing, but the best dish was definitely the bacon wrapped oysters.  I am definitely coming back again, specifically for more of those (and to try more of their food!).
author: Cici A.

description:
Had dinner here while on a trip and was skeptical at first since the entrance is in an alley way but those thoughts melted when I entered the restaurant. I love the feel of it as a whole- dim lighting, stone walls, wood... it was great.

I had the angels on horseback (bacon wrapped oysters) for appetizer and a raw oyster on the half shell. Loved the flavors of the angels on horseback. Had the lobster sandwich for an entree and was only able to finish half of it since it was so rich and flavorful! Buttery, moist (did I seriously just use that in a review?), and stuffed with lobster goodness. Worth my money, for sure. Finished off the night with some strawberry shortcake- which wasn't to my liking.

Would love to stop by here again the next time I'm in town and try some other items on the menu like their salmon dish!
author: Pauline T.

description:
3.5 Stars

It's actually been a while since I last ate here but from what I remember, the lobster roll I had was pretty delicious.  I've been meaning to come back because I've heard so many good things about some of their dishes like the Angels on Horseback and something they make with Uni.
author: Rose A.

description: The service was great. I came in during happy hour but was not any happy hour specials. I ordered the lobster roll but was a little disappointed since it was a little skimpy.  For $28.00 you would expect a little bigger in tater tots or coleslaw.  Plus biting into a shell wasn't very pleasant.   The meat in the roll amount to two claws.  Had more bread than lobster.
author: Eric N.

description: The lobster roll is to die for.  Better than the ones I've had in Maine. And the homemade tatertots are amazing. Had the ceviche for an appetizer and it was light and perfect. The restaurant was very crowded for lunch- you need a reservation.
author: Anastasia J.

description: Awful service and mediocre food. We were waiting for 15 minutes for waiter to place an order. Main dishes were served before appetizers by some reason which waiter was not able to explain. In the end he brought a check which was twice higher than our order and contained items which didn't order.
author: Vilen B.

description:
My wife and I recently visited San Francisco and decided we'd have one "splurge" meal, and this was it! We like oysters and beer so it was an easy decision.

Our mustached waiter was very attentive and gave some nice suggestions for apps, including the Angels on Horseback (bacon-wrapped smoked oysters). For dinner I ordered the Linguine with gulf shrimp and clams. I had a pretty big appetite and the portion was adequate. Stopping to remove the clams from their shells perhaps paced me and allowed me to feel full at the right moment.

For beers I tried both the Urban Peoples and Green Flash, both products of San Diego and otherwise unavailable to me in Texas, that I'm aware. My wife ordered the Pliney the Elder, a can't-miss.

I liked the restaurant's atmosphere, although our table for two was *really* close to the next table for two, so much so as I actually jumped in on their conversation at one point. Prices were a tad on the high side, but given the quality of food and service they were justifiable.
author: Ryan G.

description:
Came for a work lunch with my team. I was able to make reservations easily online through Open Table without any issues.

When we arrived, our table was ready and our server was attentive and friendly. We ordered ceviche and the Angels on Horseback, which everyone loved. The seafood was fresh and seasoned well.

I had the salmon entree and it was cooked perfectly. My coworkers all tried different mains such as fish and chips, bucatini, trout, and even the burger and all were pleased with their meal. Our typically (very) chatty team, went silent when eating because the food was so satisfying. 

I discreetly asked our waitress if she could select a dessert and add a candle or script for my coworkers birthday. She was so sweet and helped me select the bread pudding and ensured that there was a candle for the surprise. I later found that they even removed this dessert from the bill as a complementary item. 

This experience sums up everything I expected -- excellent service, food, convenience, and reasonable prices. Cannot recommend enough!
author: Tina G.

description: Great food and a great place to entertain at. The atmosphere is easy and clean feeling. The dining room is open and inviting. The service was great. Now the food was marvelous. Our crew enjoyed the Flounder Fish and chips, the mussels and the lobster roll. All were most excellent. Business lunch so no drinks but the "coolers" the have were very refreshing.
author: Debey G.

description: I don't know why this restaurant doesn't get better reviews. We ordered the burrata salad, calamari, salmon, and sea bass, and it was all delicious.
author: Jessica P.

description: Another great dining establishment in San Francisco. Sat at the bar and ate a variety of oysters from the west coast. So good I had another dozen after the first. It gets pretty crowded so be prepared for a short wait. The service is friendly and most accommodating. The clam chowder was delicious as well as the dungenous crab appetizer. If u don't like onions, stay away from it. Lol. Overall, great place to go Urself or with a group of people.
author: Jay G.

description: I had the Calamari and Fish and Chips (fried flounder) for lunch.  It's pretty decent food, but a bit on the pricey side for the quality.  Expect to spend about $20 per person just for the entrees.  Also expect Yard House chain quality food. However, the complimentary, freshly made chips were delicious.  As far as atmosphere goes, it's pretty cramped but very bright with high ceilings.  You almost forget that you're in San Francisco when you're inside.  It's not a very comfortable or intimate atmosphere, and can get pretty loud inside, making this place best for a casual lunch or quick dinner.
author: Lj N.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by Anchor and Hope. 

$1 Oysters during happy hour (ends at 6p)
Trout with browned butter was delicious but lots of small bones
Good selection of beer - Pliney the Elder available in a bottle
Cute ambiance - wood beams,  open concept

Very loud and crowded - good for a group of friends but not a date

Lobster roll was over rated and pricey - cold lobster on a warm roll
author: CL S.

description:
This is our second time coming here, the last time being a couple of years ago. They've kept the high prices but the food was very mediocre for San Francisco.

*The grilled peach salad had peach that was very firm--not quite ripe yet.
*The grilled octopus was rubbery.
*The lobster roll itself was OK, but for the price I would have expected to be blown away. The large tater tots that accompanied it were an interesting idea but entirely devoid of taste.

We arrived at happy hour but weren't given a happy hour menu or told about it so we had no idea. Service was otherwise functional, but nothing above and beyond.

5% healthy SF mandate is also higher than standard. Seems especially greedy of management at an already expensive restaurant.
author: O W.

description: Outstanding bouillabaisse with mussels, clams, shrimp and rockfish. Grilled pieces of sourdough with Dungeness crab remoulade accented the bowl. Fresh and delicious, very well prepared.
author: Shayne M.

description: Lunch on a Thursday, insanity!!!!  This place was easily packed by 12.  Thankfully we showed up around 11:30 right when they opened so we got seated pretty quickly.  Must try...Crab Louis!!  What a bundle of deliousness.  Definitely will go back and try the bacon wrapped oysters next time!  Great service, friendly staff, and great location!
author: Kevin C.

description:
I almost gave this place ONE star, but I've been there for lunch on a few occasions and it hasn't been horrible. 

Last Saturday, I went here with a group of 7 people for dinner.  The service was not just poor, but exceptionally awful.  It took nearly 40 minutes for the waiter to even take our order.  Our reservations were at 7:45 and everyone in our party was there and seated by 7:45, yet it still took 40 minutes for someone to take our order.  The appetizers were fine, but we didn't get served our entrees until 9:30pm.  It was ridiculous.  They had taken away our appetizers and plates but we were still sitting there waiting for our entrees.  

NO ONE came by to ask if we wanted more drinks.  We had to flag someone (not even our own waiter) for more drinks.  And no one ever asked if the people who were not drinking alcohol wanted refills.  The service was just awful considering a.) most of the tables cleared out by 9:00pm, and b.) there were at least 10-15 staff running around (a mix of servers and busboys and waiters.  It was hard to tell).  But the place is NOT big, so it seemed over-staffed.  

The fact that they messed up an order and took an additional 15 minutes to bring out the correct entree didn't even factor into my low-star rating because sometimes that just happens so I gave them a pass for that. 

But what put it down to TWO stars after the horrible service was that the meal itself was not great.  It was fine...just fine.  AND SUPER EXPENSIVE.  I mean a $500 bill for 7 people where only 4 of those people had a glass of wine is RIDICULOUS unless the meal is fantastic.  And it just wasn't.  I won't ever return for dinner and I'll even avoid going there for lunch unless I have plenty of time and money to spare.
author: Lisa F.

description: This is the third time we have been to Anchor and Hope for a team lunch (8top) and every time we go the food and service get less and less satisfying. 5 of us had the rock cod entree which said it came with quinoa and it really didn't! There may have been a sprinkling of it, but an hour later we are all hungry. We also asked the server for cappuccinos and she was very rude it taking the order and rushed off. We wanted more water as well but were afraid to ask for it. It's sad to say, as this was one of our favorites, but Anchor and hope is officially off of our team lunch list.
author: Maria X.

description:
I enjoyed our experience eating here this past weekend.  Some dishes were off-the-charts good (best mignonette for oysters ever) and some dishes were just "eh".  The oysters are really fresh, very good, and many to choose from.  Spendy (about $3.25-3.75 each) but if you are looking for great oyster choices and freshness, you can't beat this spot.  Some of the other dishes we ordered were either very small for the cost, or the flavor profile left me scratching my head.  A friend at the table ordered the pork belly and grilled octopus, and I really just didn't get it.  However, the Mt. Lassen smoked trout and potatoes had me banging my fist on the table in delight--awesome.  

One thing I did notice was that the place was too dark to read the menu.   My partner couldn't read it at all, and I noticed that other people around us were taking their phone out to use the flashlight app so they could see.  The vibe of the place is cool and very open, and I would definitely go back.
author: Brad D.

description:
I walk by here all the time, and it's got the hidden gem kind of look.  It's off Minna between 1st and 2nd, which feels more like an alley than a street.  I'd almost stopped in a few times but it's often pretty crowded; finally one Saturday evening it was clear so I went in and sat at the bar.

The vibe is kind of industrial-chic, laid back but with minor elements of a fancy place.  The crowd was a mix of casual and date night, semi-fancy dress.   Not pretentious but it looks nice and clean inside, and since it's a seafood place it has a nautical feel to it.

I first had one each of the 5 west coast oysters they offer.  They were good, not the best ever, but they tasted fresh and the cooks shuck them right behind the bar.  $3.50 each which felt a little above average in price but I haven't been in SF long enough to judge that.  Everything is pricey here so maybe that is normal.  They also carry east coast oysters but I didn't try them.

Next I got the lobster roll with tater tots.   It's hard to screw up a lobster roll, and they certainly did not.  It was tasty, and they have the real rolls like you get in New England, warm and buttered.  I've had stellar lobster rolls in the northeast and this was pretty darn close.  The cole slaw that came with it was nothing special but who likes cole slaw?  The tots were probably homemade, they didn't look like the traditional tots we're all used to, and they were just ok.  Honestly I probably miss the low quality ingredients in the school-lunch tots so that's not a great reason to ding them.

They have a good wine list and offer a handful of cocktails, and appeared to have quite a few draft beers.  I didn't booze it that night but it looked like a good list.

All in all I gave 4 stars because it was good but I wasn't blown away and I thought it was a bit pricey.  There weren't any low-priced entrees, everything was in the mid 20s to mid 30s range.  Dinner for 1 with oysters, an entree, and a dessert ran me about 70 all in.  But I'll definitely be back when I want to take my lady out to a nice place.
author: Heywood J.

description: Might just be my favorite restaurant in SF. Started off with $1 happy hour oysters. Then had beautiful salads (I had kale/quinoa, she had arugula). Then we had the best salmon dish we've ever had. We will be back!
author: Bill S.

description:
Yummmmm seafood! 

Every single dish on this menu is amazingly delicious. I ordered the lobster roll and I could have eaten three of them. The whole crab is delicious as well. I also liked that they seated our somewhat large party of 8 at a round table!

Vibrant atmosphere and good service. However is u go on a slow night the vibe is a bit cold.
author: Shadi N.

description:
Came here on a Friday night for dinner with friends. We made reservations for 6:30 and were seated promptly. I enjoyed their extensive menu of seafood, especially the sea urchin which I have never eaten before. It was very good! We ordered a bunch of oysters from the list and were very satisfied. We also had their fried calamari with Thai chili sauce, bacon wrapped oysters, Anchor & Hope fries (garlic fries) and the seafood paella left us feeling very full in the end. I had their apple cider ale and it was good. The lobster roll wasn't too impressive though, my friend had better in Boston. 

The restaurant got pretty busy around 8pm. The service is great and the waiter was very attentive to our needs and answered all of our questions. It was quite the dining experience!

For desert we shared Maple Whoopie Pies and a Blue Bottle Coffee Milkshake.
author: Tim G.

description: Our friends took us out for dinner as a belated wedding gift and the food and service was wonderful. The one sore point was that the salmon we shared came out VERY rare and my husband is too shy to ever ask for things to be re-fired. As a someone with a lot of industry experience I should have known to specify the temperature when the server did not prompt me for one but I always assume when the server does not ask that it will come out medium. It was barely seared and we didn't eat most of it as a result. It's not fair to leave a poor rating for something so minor, especially when we could have asked to have it cooked a bit more. However, a suggestion to guests; specify a temp. A suggestion to management; have your servers require a temp when taking orders. Aside from that, everything was perfect.
author: Melissa S.

description:
Been coming to Anchor & Hope for over four years now. But Wow today, the food was the best ever. 

At the top of the list was the lobster roll. Frankly it was the best I have ever had, hands down. 

The calamari was also really well done, but man that Lobster roll was the BEST!!!!
author: Marc R.

description:
I think I should just admit it now my yelp crush is seafood. It's been a few years now since I was turned on to shellfish and there is no turning back. 

I'm constantly looking for new places to try and I've wanted to check Anchor and Hope off my list for quite some time. I wanted to try the Dine about Town Lunch Menu and made a reservation for Frieda and I to indulge in our monthly get together and seafood lunch :)

We started with two of the daily appetizers specials, the Crab Remoulade and the Scallop Ceviche. I liked both, but if I had to pick one - it would be the crab. Mmm, crab....

I ordered the Dine about Town Lunch: Angels on Horseback (Bacon wrapped cooked oysters) and the Ahi Tuna Melt. The Angels on Horseback were delicious, but I am a bigger fan of fresh raw oysters. The Ahi Tuna melt was divine. I loved the capers, it was a GREAT tuna sandwich. But at that point, I was pretty full. 

It did take awhile to get out of there in the end, the lunch crowd had just left and we lingered a little longer than we wanted to waiting for our bill and some boxes. 

I'd like to come back, but maybe for Happy Hour. I read that they have $1.00 Oysters and drink specials from 4:30 to 6pm. Champagne and Oysters sound good to me!
author: Rebekah T.

description:
If I'm being completely honest, I would have preferred Salt House (never been their either) since I am not a big seafood fan, but I knew A&H had non- seafood options so I was happily on board.

The space is great, however we kinda had a weird table right up front in the dark corner (by the fire exit?). On the upside I snagged the only seat with a great view of the entire room.  

I loved the touch of instead of bread/butter, you get homemade potato chips and a dipping sauce.  We did request another portion that never arrived ;(
  
Because I was not paying (and sadly my employer does not allow a drop of alcohol during the work day) I had the ($5!) lime rickey - made with ginger syrup - LOVED it!

I ordered the Fried Chicken sandwich (comes with fries in a paper cone). I was hoping the fried chicken would be reminiscent of Town Hall's Fried chicken, but it was not nearly as good. The roll was great (but maybe a bit too big for the chicken). And I would have preferred my fries much more well done (kinda soggy). 

The service was just okay, nothing personal, no check-ins to see if we needed anything.

Town Hall remains the gold standard for the "R brothers"

Here is my suggestion though, The brothers like to sort do "New England style" dishes. I would love the addition of a Cape Cod style fried scallop roll, fried full-belly clam roll, and maybe some clam cakes (a very regional dish that's basically a heavy hushpuppy type thing with bits of clam throughout.)
author: Amy W.

description:
good for dinner/happy hour with coworkers
kitschy nautical decor and good oysters
large beer selection and great service
author: Marie r.

description:
Yes, it can be crowded, but isn't that the case of most things in life that are worth waiting for? Try the Angels on Horseback (AoH) and you will see why it's worth reserving a table in advance. AoH further proves that wrapping food in bacon and deep frying it is always a good decision. Our waitress was highly knowledgable about each item on the menu and drinks list. Overall, it was a solid experience and I will definitely back. 

Tip for those that hate it when they leave for the restroom and their date steals large portions off your plate: make sure your date is facing the wall length mirror.  It forces them to see their face so they'll be shamed with each bite.
author: Justin P.

description:
I've visited Anchor & Hope a few times for business lunches. I think the food is decent but nothing has ever stood out as really good. For the price I always leave thinking I was hoping for more. 

Last week's adventure at Anchor & Hope had us seated near the front door. It was badly in need of oiling and made a hideous squeak each time someone entered or exited. When we asked for a new table, farther away from the front door, the staff knew exactly why. If the staff knows the door needs oiling maybe the next step ought to be actually fixing the problem?
author: Ivan L.

description:
One of my favorite seafood place in SF!
This is a great place for happy hour ($1 oysters until 6pm!) and dinner.

They always have amazing selections of fresh east and west coast oysters...its every oyster-lovers dream!
I love their dungeness crab soup with big chunks of uni added on top...it is rich and delicate all at once! I am completely addicted! Only thing is menu changes seasonally so its not always available.
Their crudo and cerviches are also very fresh and flavored well. Def a must! I've had many of their dishes and they were all excellent, so can't go wrong!
author: Nancy Z.

description: This place is awesome! It has a great vibe and the location is fairly easy to get to. Came here for a company dinner and their happy hour deal is a STEAL! Their fresh oysters and bacon wrapped fried oysters are so delicious. I asked for their most expensive wine and I must say it's something you can't underestimate! lol.. Their service can step it up a little of my personal taste.
author: Pj A.

description:
I've had both lunch and dinner here a few times.  The crowd seems to consist mainly of FIDI lunchers so it gets quite packed.  Reservations are always recommended since we sometimes need to wait a few minutes even with reservations.  

For lunch, I ordered the crab salad and the angels on horseback.  The crab was just OK as it didn't taste very fresh.  I steam live crab all the time and when I make too much, I would take out all the meat so that I can scoop them into salads for the next few days.  I know what crab taste like on day 1, 2, and 3 and after a while, crab will start having strong seafood smell.  I'm not sure how many days old this crab was but it definitely was not day 1 or 2 so let's just leave it at that.  The angels on horseback were quite tasty since the wrapped bacon was still crispy.  My friend ordered their famous lobster roll.  I tried a little bit and thought it was quite bland.  

Lunch for two cost us about $40 pp with tax & tip.  Note:  They also add the mandatory Healthy SF tax to the tab. I really hate it when restaurants do that since we all know that they contribute much less than what they collect.  In addition, it's a tax that they should be paying for and not passed on to the consumers.
author: Wina K.

description:
This place is one of my favorite more up-scaley type places in SF because I love seafood and the area is reasonable to get to.

My dinner date and I had the lobster roll and seared scallop dishes... both were great, we agreed lobster roll was the winner. Homemade potato chips were good too.

+ Original takes on seafood classics
+ Fresh and delicious
+ Great atmosphere
+ Quality service
+ Good alcoholic beverage choices

- Only open for dinner (5:30-ish)
- Not outrageously pricey but remember this is a seafood restaurant

Would definitely come back to try more entrees!
author: Jack T.

description: Ate here while visiting san francisco and really happy we did.  Food was delicious and the atmosphere was great.  We were travelling with a 6 month old and they were accommodating and great with getting us a good table for the stroller.
author: Michelle M.

description: Just OK.  Staff recommended the rockfish and it was pretty bland/tasteless.  Fish was cooked well, but not much on the plate except 5-6oz fish.  Not sure that qualifies as an entree.
author: D M.

description:
Anchor & Hope has the best oysters! This year was the first time I've ever ate an oyster, and I thought it was just okay. I was just afraid of how slimy it can be and the taste. I've actually been here two months ago and I tried one of the oysters and wasn't satisfied till yesterday!!! haha Maybe it was a way they prepared it or an oyster from another state or country? I forgot to mentioned about angels on horseback hehe meaning bacon wrapped oysters! OOOHHH gotta try it!! enough said!

 The restaurant is hidden in an alley, so you would have to actually have to yelp a place for a good oyster bar. The restaurant is pricey for lunch and dinner, but worth it! I think I'm going to try lunch here next.

Happy Hour is from 3-6p They have dollar oysters!! which I think is a sweet deal =) did I mention their fish tacos are off the hook? I haven't tasted a real good fish taco since I was in Costa Rica. Wine is 5.00 a glass, which made me very happy!! lol 

Anchor & Hope is a place where I will definitely come back!
author: Kathy V.

description:
Normally I wouldn't go to a 3.5 stars place with three dollar signs, as the risk of a bad experience isn't worth it to me for this price point. Unfortunately I was with a group for a party and I didn't choose the venue.

- Some of the food was quite good; I had the rockfish, and the sides / garnish, while tiny, was delicious. The fish itself was fried on one side, and was so tough that it was hard to cut with a knife.
- The wait staff was slow as molasses, and didn't do basic things like keep the water full or offer us refills on drinks.

Very B grade food with a D- wait staff.
author: Kris W.

description:
The real (and only) reason for coming to this place was because I had a super important business lunch, otherwise this is sort of out of my jurisdiction of day-to-day lunch places  I had never been, and since I'm not into seafood all the time, I was skeptical but open to trying things.

Most of lunch was spent talking about work and the like, and I had a very unimpressive chopped salad with green goddess dressing and a side of grilled chicken.  I eschewed the potato chips (although they were calling my name) that were brought to the table early on, but the rest of my table seemed to really enjoy them.  The biggest observation I had about here was that the service was absolutely terrible. Coming to take our order was slow, getting drinks out were slow, and getting food out was slow.  And while I acknowledge that this was during the peak of lunch hour, it just seemed like we got NO attention the entire time we were there.  I'm glad my work ended up covering for the downtime in between things, but I would really expect more from a place that's right in the middle of a bustling area with a ton of foot traffic.  I'm not really motivated to come back here unless it's for a work lunch again.
author: Lisa I.

description:
Super place - great oysters for cheap money when there is happy hour.
A good atmosphere and a very professional and friendly service.
Angels on a Horseback - it tastes so fantastic - try it!
I look forward to visiting this restaurant again.
author: Per Skovgaard H.

description: Ordered the rockfish, over priced and does not taste good. Waiter did not refill our drinks.
author: MR R.

description:
I wanted to like this place more but it has several minor deficiencies.

Sloowww service.  Very SF.  

Clueless front of the house.

No hard liquor so no cocktails.

Wine list not bad, but brief.

This is a beer place.  They got growlers here.

Decent crudo.

Excellent oyster selection.

The 'angels on horseback' are cooked oysters wrapped in bacon.  Tasty.

Price high by about 20%.

There are abundant choices for fine dining in SF.  This has fine dining prices but falls slightly short.  Others have grasped this too in other reviews.

It's a shame you can't give 3.5 stars since it is decent just needs some tuning.
author: Dave H.

description:
If you love seafood, this is the place to go.  We ordered 3 dozen orders of oysters and they went fast.  Great selection from both east and west coasts. We ordered:

- NE Clam Chowder - I'm from Boston so I know what good chowdah is :) and this was pretty good despite it being slightly different - they had carrots in it!
- Moules frites (steamed mussels) and it came with side order of fries.  I had this as my main meal. The broth was amazing...my nephew couldnt get enough of it..drank it like it was soup!
- the Fried Flounder: this was perhaps the lightest fried fish I've ever had.  Best dish overall.
- Lobster roll: this was ok...we've had better back east. 

Overall, a must-go place if you are in the mood for seafood. The ambiance of the place was nice...very open with a rustic feel. Will definitely be back.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Had dinner here on a very warm, alright hot for SF, evening. 

The good:
- attentive service. Staff took very good care of our rather large group. 
- quick turnaround on drinks and appetizers. They were quite busy yet the drinks were replenished quickly and early orders were brought out promptly. 

The not-so-good:
- entrees were average. Presentation was unspectacular and the taste did not excite the palate. I was expecting more from my meal. 

The bad:
- not enough ventilation for such a warm day. It was hot and rather uncomfortable. Granted these days are few and far in-between for SFO; yet I expected them to be better prepared for the weather. 

I may return but only if it is convenient - won't go out of my way for this place.
author: Dhaval V.

description: We got the seafood platter and it sucked. The oyster and clams didn't taste fresh.  The mussels were okay.  Overall not going back and certainly not worth the money.
author: Kay P.

description:
Only rating based on the lobster-roll and it was just ok.  I feel like the ratio price/taste wasn't there.
The service was good. The place get packed.
author: Renaud P.

description:
I dined here with a friend on Friday night, and I've struggled with this review all weekend, but I need to say that the rose that I drank with dinner left quite the bitter taste in my mouth.

The restaurant was a suggestion of my friend, and I didn't really have many expectations mainly because the reviews have been so mixed.

Our service was great.  Very friendly, patient and super pleasant.  4 stars.

The food.  Well it was fine.  Not exactly life changing, but it was tasty with a dash of salt and the portions were plenty.  3 stars.

It was the darned rose.  Of the many reviews that I read, most balked about the value perceived for the price paid and I would have to agree.  0 star.

I have to say that I'm a bit surprised that 2 lobster rolls and a bottle of rose with a few oysters thrown in would amount to a $200 (incl. tip)  Heck, 4 days later and I"m still really surprised.  I guess it's our fault for not inquiring on the bottle price when the server highly recommended the rose.  Then again, who in their right mind would expect to pay $70 for a bottle of rose at a fish joint, which amounts to roughly $17 PER GLASS (not incl gratuity).  I think the server could have been transparent about that when she was giving us the Rose Spiel.  I mean 5 star hotel bars don't even charge that much.  Why should Anchor & Hope?

Needless to say, highly unlikely that I would ever return or recommend.  It was just one of those dining experiences where I would have been much better off spending money on high quality ingredients and entertaining at home.
author: Amy Z.

description: My fiancé and I came here last night for a date night and  it was perfect. The oysters were delicious we liked the Wellfleets, Miyagi and Kusshi oysters the most. The staff were all very nice and knew their seafood! Great selection of wine. It is pricey but worth it for a nice quiet date night. Definitely a hidden gem in the city. Micheal was our server at the bar and he was great!
author: Mal L.

description: I didn't think this place was so great. Took them about 30 minutes to seat us even with a reservation at lunch and the food was just okay.
author: Jill T.

description: Food was good.  Had the mussels with Chorizo, very tasty.  Service was very lacking.  Waitress was not engaged and food server put our dish on the table without a comment.  Not welcoming at all.
author: Joni C.

description:
Such a great place for lunch...just make sure your server isn't working the bar and treats you like you have the plague.  We really only saw him for about 10 minutes out of our hour and 15 min lunch.  He was MIA and would ignore such requests like...check please?

Also, if you are expecting this place to pop out and scream at you on the street you will be waiting a while.  This place is tucked away on a small side street but you would NOT guess that walking in.  A huge, very open, lovely Baltimore or Boston feel restaurant.  

The Salt butter was amazing. That made me smile.

I am going to tell you that I got a burger and I already know 75% of responses...at a Seafood joint? Yes, I was on a burger roll...leave me alone.  The burger was so good, the roll was awesome and it was just smothered in melted cheese, so good!
author: Colleen B.

description:
I forgot to yelp this sooner!  here goes:

Food is suuuuperb! Our waitress that night was PERFECT, she was very patient with us. We came here on Jan 11th for my bday dinn, a group of 10 close friends. Since i been here back in December, i knew the food was great. So the original 4stars def remains for the food. Feels like we ordered everything on the menu(the Grand seafood platter, mussels, soup, arugula salad, ceviche, octopus and then all the different entrees)  Huge portion, my palette loved everything. The ambience is top notch!

But this 2 star review is for the rude hostess. A few days prior to the dinner, i made the reservation via Yelp. Then we ended up with more attendees so i had to call in to update the number. She did not sound happy at all, i hear the huffing and puffing over the phone and putting me on hold. She said if i have more people coming, i cannot keep my original reservation time, that she would have to move me to 6pm. Because another group of 10 people are coming that same night and there aren't enough space. i had no choice and said ok to 6pm. She also said, that table is not meant to have that many people so it will be a very tight fit. She ended the call with "Everyone has to be here at 6pm, on the dot".  Ok....calm down! That Saturday, everyone made sure to arrive at least 5min early. We got situated, the round table was perfect, no one was crammed. The food was perfect. The restaurant was busy, there was indeed another larger group seated close to us, they had the long table. We took a long time to finish our dinner, coffee/dessert and bday cake. We were not rushed, didn't see another big group waiting for our table and the bill came out to a little over $100 per person. Sorry, but the rudeness was just not necessary...
author: Vee V.

description: I'm a seafood fanatic, and had always wanted to try Anchor & Hope.  When I did, I enjoyed my experience a lot.  Happy hour oysters were ok, kinda small and not super fresh, but it could have been because I was so spoiled by oysters I had in Seattle recently.  I like the vibe of this restaurant, and how spacious the place is when compared to other tiny restaurants in SF.  Loved the interior and its staff's top notch service.  I would definitely go back again.
author: Henna C.

description:
There is a scene in current hipster TV program du juor, Portlandia, where the two protagonists, seated in a restaurant, ask about the locality of the food they're about to order. Long story short it results in them visiting a farm and hilarity / mockery ensues. 

As our waiter stood before us at Anchor & Hope telling us the whereabouts of the items we were about to order I was momentarily distracted by visions of my dining companions and I whisking ourselves off to the San Francisco surrounding areas to see where our food had originated.

Alas, it didn't quite come to that but tucked away at the end of an alley way this bustling restaurant was a welcome surprise and try some of San Francisco's best seafood.

As we soaked up the dimly-lit atmosphere in this renovated warehouse it seemed like nothing could tarnish our dining experience. Unfortunately there were a few things that soured our dinner that evening but overall the food we did enjoy was simple, flavoursome and delicious. My own steak was cooked to perfection and our entrees arrived swiftly and with plenty for us to all try. My tip: the cured smoked salmon.
author: Lani P.

description:
Decided to check this place out and must say we were somewhat disappointed.

We grabbed seats at the bar, expecting drinks and small bites.  The bartender was friendly but looked very standoffish.  

Anyway, what we had:
glass of rose - $12
glass of Squid Ink beer - $8 
ceviche - $15 - calamari and shrimp w/ avocado, some Asian dressing - not bad, small portion
2 each of Kusshi ($3.50/each), D. Beau Soleil ($3.50/each) and manila clams ($1.5/each).
author: Gloria H.

description:
This review is for if you want to have Anchor & Hope do your company Christmas Lunch (21 People)THEY WERE FANTASTIC!  Easy to arrange the event with.  

Service:
Waitstaff were SUPER on top of their game.  We had a lot of people modifying orders for health reasons, as well as personal preference reasons. For instance, I wanted the butter sauce on my fish on the side.  Not only did they get a almost every order perfect, but they all came out at once.  And hot.  The one order that had a single issue was comped.  We had water at all times in jugs but these jugs were used to fill our glasses and we never had to touch them.  There was more than enough fresh bread on the table to munch as we waited.  The waitress was very knowledgeable about the fresh oyster bar selections which i found impressive.  My boss loved the ones he got.

Atmosphere: 
Spacious enough that we had 21 people not knocking elbows and there was plenty of room for other lunch patrons.  Cute nautical theme and I'm a huge fan of open kitchens to keep cleanliness standards high.

Food:
Grilled Brooke Trout, butternut squash puree, brussel sprouts, in prosciutto-sage brown butter--I had the butter on the side which turned out to be just fine (though it was tasty).  I ate every drop of my food.  Well balanced.  Reasonably healthy.  Fresh.

Shrimp Cocktail--Great cocktail sauce! The shrimp were clean, fresh, and done perfectly.  Presentation on a big plate of ice on a raised platform was a lot of fun as well.


This is exactly what I would expect from such an establishment.
author: Susan C.

description: Interesting ambience.  Actually ate at the bar.  Really enjoyed the Roasted Cauliflower Soup & Moules Frites.  Beer selection was also on point.
author: John W.

description:
I really enjoyed my time here. I came to Anchor & Hope on a quiet Sunday with my friend when we weren't very hungry so we ended up only ordering appetizers. The appetizers were great. I ordered the calamari which hit the spot and I appreciated how they put their own spin on it by adding basil, mint, and chili dressing. 

The complimentary chips they provide are damn good. I usually don't like chips, but theirs got me to change my mind. 

Our waiter was very friendly and made our experience at Anchor & Hope memorable. 

I plan to go back again with a bigger appetite because their lobster looks delicious.
author: Abena O.

description: This place is great. Recommended by our concierge on vacation. Walking up the street it almost looks like a warehouse or garage but keep going! Great atmosphere, loft feel and nicely decorated. Food was amazing, service was great. Our waitress had great recommendations and was very accommodating to our "out of town" lack of knowledge. Positive all around. Definitely check it out.
author: Alison G.

description:
Heads up: make reservations. I don't think we would have gotten a table so quickly if we hadn't.

I'll start off wit the con. Our waiter was a very pretentious hipster (well those two things just go hand in hand I guess) who got under my skin quick. His wine suggestion was very good, but other than that I wasn't completely happy with him. He seems like the kinda guy where he listens to a Radiohead album on repeat for a week and says "Yeah their new album sucked." But the man knows his wine.

Moving on. The food was pretty good, not mind-blowingly amazing, but it was pretty good. Each of us had fish, because what else do you  get at a seafood restaurant? Chicken? Back to the fish, like I said it was alright. The portion wasn't enough to fill me up, but I eat a lot, and they give you homemade chips (which are an easy and fun thing to make yourself btw).

The look of the place was very neat, and it reminded me of a restaurant back home (albeit way more expensive). It was a bit loud, but it was St. Patty's weekend, there's going to be people out, but even then the noise wasn't so bad.

I was a little disappointed when I asked for a cask ale and was told they were out, but what can you do? Also, nobody told us this was only a beer and wine place, so when my girlfriend asked for a mojito, she was met with a very snide "Oh, we only do *wine* and *beer*." from the waiter. As I said though, as much of a prick as he might have been, he knew his wine.


I don't think I'll be going back, for the money we spent I think we could have done better. But the experience was decent enough.
author: John J.

description:
A bit biased fuz I know people who know people here. Also, if you get a chance to watching the shucking magic of one of the chefs you will greater appreciate your oysters. (legit grammar) 

Their angels on horesback should just be called oysters wrapped with bacon. No need to hide the goodness friend. Soooo good. I'm not the biggest fan of fizzy alcohol unless it's in my OJ but the Cava served was quite nice. I also liked that I could have my oysters plain or width toppings, so of course I mixed it up and had all of those options. 

The malt  vinegar aioli is THE TRUTH. So good with th e fries. 

It's a bit hidden and you spass two restodown an ally before you get there, but I thought it was a great HH find
author: Grace K.

description:
We snagged a last minute reservation on New Year's Day for dinner.  The food was ok, not bad but certainly not great.  Our waitress seemed a bit scattered and could not understand me when I ordered a bottle of Chenin Blanc.  I had to point it out for her on the wine list.  It was the only bottle of Chenin Blanc and my pronunciation was flawless.  Check your battery!

The oysters were overpriced though they did have good flavor.  If I wanted to pay $3.75 an oyster I might as well go to Swan's and do it right.

The lobster roll was was a bit of bleh with a side of meh.  The lobster portions were on the small side.  Our waitress told us that the restaurant was known for its Lobster Roll.  Methinks it is known for its mediocre lobster roll.  The colossal tater tots that accompanied the roll tasted like they had been cooked in hash oil.  I'm sure they weren't but they certainly tasted like they were.

The dining room looks like something out of a bad Elvis Presley movie a la Clam Bake.  Random boat lines hanging from the ceiling, a buoy over here, an anchor over there. 

I think Anchor & Hope could be a great place if they refined the menu, redid the interior of the restaurant, and focused on service.  I don't want to be able to look into the kitchen and see the staff congregating around the food window while I wait 10 minutes for the check.
author: Sean D.

description:
Underwhelmed by the food.
Overwhelmed by the bill.

Let me explain... For a restaurant with 1100+ reviews, it was fairly dead on a Friday night.  Albeit our reservation was pretty late in the evening as well.  Also, considering they do not offer hard liquor, I don't see why people would stick around much after their meal.

Our server was as pleasant as they come.  No qualms with her or the helpful water pourers.  Super disappointed by the fact that they ran out of the lobster roll.  As a table of 7 hungry girls we ordered a lot of items off the menu and ate family style.

Most were not too memorable, but here are some that stuck out:

Large Seafood Platter: delicious array of fresh seafood.  No complaints, came out fast and was annihilated rather quickly too.

Angels on Horseback: ate one, it had bacon, how to you go wrong with bacon?

Heirloom tomato salad: I liked this more than the Arugula

Bucatini: way too salty, lid must've came off when they were seasoning it in the kitchen

My favorite part of the meal was the dessert: chocolate chip walnut cookie, vanilla ice cream and bread pudding.

Least favorite part of the meal was the bill  :( 

It's true what they say, food tastes better when it's free.
author: Two P.

description: Great beer list!  The bartender was beer educated and helpful. I had the Calicraft Kolsch, a Thirsty beer cask ale, and finished with North Coast Old #38. On tap. I may pitch a tent here tonight!
author: Jim C.

description: A SOMA gem.  I love their Fish and Chips and frankly try to plan time in the area just so I can swing by to enjoy just that!  Mussels are good, salmon is good, it is all pretty good!
author: Flynn L.

description: The service has room for improvement here. Tried to make a reservation for a large party and the lady who "helped" me, Natalie, was extremely rude.
author: Hillary R.

description:
This place was amazing!  I was originally craving PPQ for some crab, but needed something closer to the financial district.  However, after eating here, I couldn't even remember what PPQ was about...

We had the small seafood plateaux appetizer.  It was pricey, but well worth it.  The oysters were delicious, the littleneck clams were gone before I knew it, and the ceviche and crab...my mouth is watering just thinking about it.

I also had the baby octopus appetizer and I think this just made my week.  This was the one thing I kept thinking about all night long.  It was sooooo good!  I wouldn't have thought Thai basil, yuzu, and beets would make a good combination, but this just blew my mind.

For the entree, I had the sole.  At this point I was already a raving fan and was worried I would be disappointed, but nope, the goodness just kept coming.  The dashi broth was just full of umami and the sole had some nice crispy skin and was soft and delicate in the inside.

To top it all off, I had the Sugar Pie Pumpkin Bread Pudding.  I hope they never take this off the menu!  It wasn't like your normal bread pudding, actually it felt more like a flourless cake, but it was scrumptous.
author: Ray B.

description:
stopped by the first time with a VC friend -- not too much recollection of my first dining experience except that it was delicious.

I bumped into the place again, by accident, and sat at the bar. Great laid back ambience. I ordered new england clam chowder and one from each of the three type of West Coast oysters. Skookum oyster from WA was the best -- close to the hog island oyster which is my favorite -- sweet and not too salty. I am a bit of a purist when it comes to oyster, only using lemon with no other sauce. For some of the salty ones, if you don't put vinaigrette insider, you feel like you are drinking sea water along with the oyster!

New England Clam Chowder was excellent, not too creamy and not too runny. Very fresh clams. Wish that they put a few of those oyster crackers on the side rather than inside the chowder.

I just found out that they have a $1 oyster happy hour deal with Skookum - will have to come back for that!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I found a moving bug in my taco and sent it back to the kitchen. All I got was a quiet apology from the server. I saw him walk into the kitchen to examine the tacos. Not sure if he even told the chef or  the kitchen staff. I called the manager over to tell him that I sent the food back and his response was "No worries" like I made a mistake? Then he continued to say that "Bugs are extra protein in some countries". I'm not sure if that's the right way to respond after a customer has found a bug in their food. All I got was a light apology & the tacos removed off my bill after being asked multiple times if I wanted to order something else.

I'm not ever coming back. It's even scary to think we're eating raw oysters at a place that is not as clean as we would expect it to be. I understand there are some flukes in food prep or service sometime but the response from the manager just shows what the establishment is OK and not OK with. Obviously they are OK with bugs in their food and not OK with compensating for their mistakes.
author: lyds o.

description: Beautiful place and delightful service. Good food - but I did expect better food at the price point. Btw, 3 stars is not bad in my book.
author: Howe L.

description:
Came here on a recommendation for dinner. We had a reservation and got a drink while we waited (they were running about 15 mins behind). 

Overall, I'd give the decor, service, and ambiance a 4 or 5 star rating. Neat space and well designed. Very good energy. 

Sadly, I'd give the food 2 stars. The food (ceviche, mussels with chorizo, lobster roll, chocolate pot something or other dessert) was all fine, but for the price, I didn't find it particularly impressive. I would happily try any number of other restaurants before coming back here. I wanted to like it but nothing about the menu here blew me away. 

Sad to say as I was really looking forward to it.
author: Louie D.

description: Oysters are tasty but service can be a hit or miss.  Not a bad place.  Will give it another try next time.
author: Stephanie I.

description:
I really like this place. I love the ambience and the seating arrangements, but prime lunch hour can get pretty noisy. We came on a Friday at lunch hour and had no reservations, so were asked to seat at the bar section (which we didn't mind).

I got the halibut/trout dish (I don't really remember which, haha. Fish names kind of sound the same) with a sweet glazed sauce (mango?) It was divine, and very filling. My coworker got the lobster rolls with tater tots-- also looked amazing.

I really have to rave about their dessert though: vanilla ice cream with frozen raspberries and chocolate chip cookies and chocolate drizzle. It was SO GOOD. It's just vanilla ice cream, you say? Well, the entire combination was just so satisfying. I don't know. Maybe it was the combination of my entre coupled with this dessert, but I just remember it so well and will be back for more.
author: Jessica Y.

description:
I was very excited to try this place, it's located in a nice small street, sure to keep the tourists out and caters to the work crowd, but I found this place very forgettable and average.  We had a week night dinner here for work and thought it would be a fun place to have a good meal, but the food was just meh and not worth the money.  Places in SOMA seem to get away with charging a lot for very average food.

We had cod and the salmon and while both sounded great on the menu they just didn't live up to our expectations.  The service was also a bit slow and inconsistent, they were slow to take our order and get the food out to us.
author: Inga W.

description:
Arrived at 5:25 to grab a drink before an event at 6:00. We let the hostess know this, and she said another table would need our table at 6:00 so that would be perfect. Server did not come to our table until 5:35, drinks did not arrive until 5:45. A drink that was on their "seasonal specials" was not labeled as beer, and I am not great with gluten. I didn't touch my drink and it still took until 6:05 for someone to check up on us. I didn't even have a chance to order a glass of wine instead. 

If you need a nice place to grab a drink after work, don't bother unless you have a reservation, they'll seat you but they won't serve you.
author: Tommy D.

description: Got the small seafood plateaux last night. $58 for a couple of tiny oysters, rubbery clams, and a few tablespoons of crab salad and ceviche...all very fishy tasting. I expected top freshness. Restaurant food didn't measure up to the prices. However, no problem getting a table, and service was polite and responsive.
author: Bear Z.

description: Really small menu , mediocre food , cool warehouse vibe, only serves beer and wine, stepped over the garbage to get to the door, not impressed
author: Julie D.

description:
Anchor & Hope is good. It's tasty but expensive seafood and first class service. If you're in the area, hungry and holding a corporate card, I see no reason not to go.

The menu has a lot of tasty apps (bacon wrapped oysters) and a decent list of entrees. Great beer list, which includes Pac Brew Labs' Squid Ink. Nice decor (fun posters in the bathroom) and a friendly wait staff. 

It seems to be busy at dinner time on all days, so don't forget to make a reservation.

The clientele is primarily business folks, which is the result of the location. And speaking of the location... keep your eyes peeled. It's on an alley and easily missed from 2nd Street.
author: Nick K.

description: Amazing Place! The Food is Exceptional. My second time visiting here from the Monterey Bay. First visit, we ordered the Seafood tower, OMG that was Delicious! Second visit, Shrimp boil: It was quite the experience. This place has certainly become "Our Place" while visiting San Francisco.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Shame! Where to start.. We came here last night for my friends bday - 8 of us.. Dinner resos were at 6:30 - the last person strolls in at 6:45ish.. It took them 1.5 hours before we got our food. The waitress took FOREVER to take our orders - we weren't planning to make this a 3 hour dinner!

We ordered half a dozen oysters - they were ok

Half our table ordered the Cod - the other half Seabass - Anchor & Hope is a seafood restaurant.. How could they get the one thing they're supposed to be good at soo wrong?! The fish was overcooked.. We told the waitress, she asked if they could bring us new fish but at this point we were STARVED.. 1.5 hours later - STARVED.. so we ate our dry fish.. SHAME.. 

One of the servers came by our table and accidentally dropped some type of app down my friends back.. the manager came out an apologized.. fine.. 

We get the bill - NOTHING is comp'd AND they also ADD TIP.. Come on... 

I will NEVER come back... There are just tooo many great restaurants in the city to ever have to experience Anchor & Hope again..
author: Monica S.

description: i really wanted to like this place...but our dinner was a disaster.    the bartender gave us attitude when we were trying to order drinks before dinner.    the fish stew had a really bad looking mussel in it and when we sent it back they didn't comp the meal.   the waiter basically forget about us until we had to flag him down for the check.   and when the check came it had about $100 worth of charges that weren't right....he clearly did not check the bill before giving it to us.  Now, the food was good, so that's a major plus....but the experience has definitely left a bitter taste in our mouths.
author: Mike J.

description:
Had lunch here today years after my first visit, not too bad considering we were super disappointed that they don't serve the Sea Urchin soup at lunch.

Best thing was the lobster roll, fresh and light, great lunch sandwich.

Calamari with thai green papaya salad: the dipping sauce was delicious. The calamari was on the dry side.

The bacon wrapped oyster: the bacon was overly crisped, yet dipping sauce didn't really go with the heavy fried protein+protein. 

In all... better than my last visit but still not as great as I'd like it to be.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Oysters and champagne!  The most divine indulgent pair ever. If I ever have dogs again,  I will name one Oysters and one Champagne.  

I love/hate the location of this restaurant. Love it because it is literally behind the building in which I work. Hate it because its in an ally, feels dark and dinghy upon entering with people smoking and loitering in front of it.  The inside however, is quite airy and nice.  A little on the cold side, temperature-wise.  

I am a huge fan of seafood, fresh oysters specifically- in case you didn't catch the first sentence of my review.  They offer a great selection at reasonable prices.  This is a fantastic place for appetizers (Angels on Horseback: bacon wrapped oysters) at Happy Hour.  The other items on the menu are also solid, although I wish the accompanying sides were more creative.
author: Ronita J.

description: Fantastic place! The happy hour was great value, the oysters were fresh and tasty, the ambiance was perfect!  We will definitely return.
author: Elvida N.

description: Phenomenal!  Attentive service. Friendly and knowledgeable. Large selection of beer and wine. Lobster roll is to die for.  Definitely order the Angels on Horseback appetizer!!
author: Tina M.

description:
Food, really good
Beer, really good
Service, Excellent

Sea urchin & dungeness crab was very tasty, I enjoyed that.  Wife had the Cioppino, lots of seafood (no skimping), broth was terrific.  Squid Ink beer was very smooth.  Keith, our waiter, an asset to the restaurant.
author: Troy H.

description:
Came here with friends and we all really enjoyed it.
While the service was a tad slow at first, our server helped us select a great bottle of wine and from them on was great (seemed like he got slammed with a bunch of tables all at once when we first sat down).

The oysters were fresh and tasty and everyone enjoyed their entrees. 

The only mishap was that we all refused to "share" our desserts and we all were too full afterwards

Very cool atmosphere and lovely food and drink.
author: Jim D.

description: Great food, great service. We came early when the restaurant just opened for dinner. The oysters were some of the best. Shrimp cocktail as well. Then we had the lobster roll. You need to try the cole slaw. All in all a fine start to our Thanksgiving adventure in San Francisco.
author: Lee B.

description:
I came to Anchor and Hope on a whirlwind with no reservations on a Friday night. Arriving past 9pm meant waiting only about 15 minutes for a table. The restaurant is large with high ceilings and wooden beams. The nautical decor is classy and clean with good lighting.

We ordered the bottle of Honig Sauvignon Blanc and i can certainly see why it's their most popular! We came to have drinks and to nibble on food so it was the perfect compliment to the Sizziling Garlic Shrimp and Grilled Bread. Six large de-shelled shrimps laid in chile de arbor and parsley with nicely charred bread to sop up any remains. We unintentionally had a "garlic" themed night and ordered their Garlic Fries after our neighboring table suggested it.

It was worth the $$.
author: Samantha L.

description: Service is hella slow. Took 30 minutes for them to take our order. But barely more than 15 to get our food after we ordered. Food was very good. The salmon was tasty. Were quite slow about refreshing my drink as well.
author: Dixon M.

description: Drink & appetizers at Anchor & Hope while visiting San Fran for work. Beautiful decor & great by the glass wine selection. Loved the Octopus appetizer & Cauliflower side dish. Sat at the bar with a friend right as the restaurant opened for dinner. Bartender was not overly friendly, but she got our order right & explained dishes true to form.
author: Yvonne D.

description: This place was good, nice friendly staff. The fish and chips was enormous and yummy. Just be ready to pay $$ for the parking garage across the street.  They have an assortment of oysters and they are so good and fresh
author: Tiffany T.

description:
I tried super hard to find really great things about this place.  I know it's a recognized gem, but I think things may be slipping...  The menu seemed a bit inspired, and we were very happy with our service, but the portions seemed really small and the food was literally just "meh."  

The steak I ordered was far too salty, the wine list: just okay, and our appetizer was both bizarre and minuscule in portion.

All told, we paid FAR too much for a sub-par experience.  We had high "Hopes," but I'm not sure we'll be back...
author: Brad D.

description:
THE GM ins amazing... Wine selection awesome - had the Brown Zinfandel and it was an awesome recommendation!  Service by waiter wasn't quality at all... Hope is a good word - hope your waiter comes bye! Atmosphere and atmosphere is excellent!

The ceviche had more jicama than fish; add more fish and you'll have a HIT!!

The GM offered a desert that was complimented by the wine and on the house for the lack of service - have to say the beginning and ending great -
author: Paul A.

description:
Had my birthday dinner party here, well surprise party, and honestly thought that the wonderful company I had could have used some real good food.

Although I have to say, the server was super patient with us, thank you for that!, especially a bunch of people who couldn't decide what they wanted to eat or what kind of wine to drink and then one girl who doesn't even eat seafood!

She helped me pick out the two bottles of wine, great choices. Not sure what everyone else ate, but for me, the Salmon Tartare was a hit and tried one of the bf's Bacon Wrapped Oysters and that was amazing also. 

The lobster roll, fish&chips and other entrees definitely did not seem like they were worth the price we paid. Could have gotten better elsewhere for less (ie. Sam's chowder mobile). 

They were kind enough to bring out my birthday cake and then cut a slice for each of us also. Thank you, but will not be coming back.
author: Anh P.

description: I absolutely hate it when a restaurant is half empty but they will only seat me at the bar because I am by myself. On top of that, I felt like I was risking my life walking here from the Palace Hotel. It feels like it is in a very dodgy part of town. Lots of construction and dark streets and alleys.
author: Chris S.

description:
I came here for my bday dinner with my friends. It was interestingly tucked in a side alley of the financial district easy to miss if you didn't know it was there. Walked in and the decor was great: rustic harbor industrial chic. 

The food took a while so my friends and I devoured 4 bowls of their complementary chips which were yummy. 

Appetizer was curry squid wrapped in crab meat. The sauce was great but the squid was under seasoned and quite rubbery. 

For the main course, I had to have the lobster roll. It was ok. I felt the lobster was a little under seasoned and underwhelming. Also the proportion of lobster meat to bread was too bread heavy. The mustardy slaw side also overpowered the delicate lobster taste.  For good seafood rolls, I'd still recommend the crab roll at Fish in Sausalito. 

My friend on the other hand had the crispy trout in brown butter with apple, I had a taste and it was amazing!!  I wanted more but it was all gone. I will definitely get that next time! 

All in all pretty decent but depends on what you get!!
author: Kenji H.

description:
Hadn't been here for years so wanted to try it out again and a pre-YBCA event early dinner seemed like a plan.

I arrived 30-mins before the appointed time & took a seat at the bar awaiting my companion.  Dollar oysters always grab my attention - I arrived just before the end of their happy hour promotion.  They were ok, fresh, etc., but three of the shells were poorly opened - cracked, two with shell residue swimming with the oyster.

Bartender was outright surly - not just with me but the whole bar.  Has no business working in any customer service capacity whatsoever.  The two gals next to me commented between themselves how atrocious he was.

Once seated the waiter was a nice enough guy.  Wine geek, and that's just fine...
The food was disappointing.  We shared four apps which were all a bit lackluster.
The adjacent tables each had the fruits de mer, or whatever they call it here, and could tell each were underwhelmed.  Presentation was off and frankly looked a bit, I don't know, "old.."

I really like the other restaurants run by the management team, particularly Salt House, and I've been eating these guys food since they were at Postrio back in the day, so I felt a bit let down.  Maybe it was just "one of those nights..?"
author: David P.

description:
After moving to the Bay Area last December, we have come to Anchor and Hope about 4 times, and every time we go there, we have a great experience.  The seafood is always super fresh and the flavors are developed and unique.  The service is always very friendly and laid back in a very lacking the portentous attitude that you get in a lot of these types of restaurants, which I appreciate so much being new to this city.   

The ceviche is amazing, super delicate with refreshing flavors.  The oysters are always a fun adventure.  I had the sea bass the last time I went there, and it was spot on.  Super flavorful, perfectly cooked, and well-balanced.  I still have yet to try the lobster roll, which I was sad to hear they were out of the other day, but every time we go there, the waiters tell us that while the lobster roll is great, there are so many amazing dishes on the menu that are better - so we always end up trying different things.  Oh, their strawberry shortcake is super yummy, but nontraditional (using olive oil shortbread instead of the traditional biscuit).  I appreciated an updated and different take on it.

The food takes a little longer than most places, but I actually like this.  Rather than trying to get you your food so they can turn your table, it really allows you to enjoy your time with your friends, or your hubby...whomever you chose to dine with. Our waiter was very friendly, but allowed us to enjoy our meal, coming back at just the right times to check on us or pour us another glass of wine.

Speaking of wine, they have a great selection, but normally we drink beer here as their list is long and full of some of our favorite craft brews.  Great beer list!

I can't wait to go back again for a 5th time.  :)
author: Jane P.

description:
This place has great happy hour for oysters and bubbly.  $1 oysters that never fail to be very tasty and $5 Cava cannot be beat.  I've also had some of their happy hour bar bites, which are also very good.  They have recently added a couple of items to their happy hour menu, the tuna melt bites I believe...very tasty.  This place can get pretty busy so get there early.

The ambiance is great, the staff is friendly, and location is conveniently in the financial district and near public transportation.

Highly recommended.
author: Ellen B.

description:
Food is great.  A good selection and a good selection if you aren't a typical seafood junkie.  Had the steak and it was cooked perfectly.  Not sure how they do their onion rings but everyone at the table had to keep taking them.
Service has always been good.  More than one server will help you if needed.
author: Alex P.
