description: Went for a team lunch.  I ordered the blackend catfish sandwich.  Was very tasty and good portion.  Sweet potato chips were oversalted but still pretty good.  Also tried dessert and got the Smores.  Wow really good and rich.  Definitely will put you to sleep.
author: Josh L.

description:
Dim-lighting, mellow ambiance, and amazing SEAFOOD. This restaurant yields a cordial, classy atmosphere, without all the uptight formality. 

Unfortunately, with my family history, I already have high LDL (the bad kind) cholesterol. However, I had no qualms of neglecting my health and conscience for the sinful seafood at this restaurant. It was simply delicious, and every guilty mg of cholesterol consumed was entirely worth it for their succulent oyster and uni.

From their seafood bar, we ordered all 6 types of oysters offered. 3 different oysters from the East coast, and 3 different oysters from the West coast. The thumb-sized oysters came out on an elevated ice platter, arranged as listed on the menu. 

Their East coast oysters are definitely more brine-y than their West coast counterparts. I, personally, like the West coast oysters, because their meats offer a fresh aroma, that makes it easily compatible with both their cocktail sauce and their vinegar-herb sauce. However, as an oyster lover, every single one tasted amazing. Even without their beautiful presentation and tasty sauces, their oysters are STILL 5/5!!

Now, the Uni... (I'm already drooling from the thought of it) It's an uni chowder with bits of potatoes, and unlike clam chowder where the clams are chewy (and can even get plastic-y if not fresh), the uni was like tender flesh that melted in your mouth. I practically licked the bowl clean (well, not literally, but used the bread they served to wiped it clean!) Umm...DEFINITE 5/5. 

We ordered monkfish as the main entree. Unfortunately, after the uni appetizer, this dish tasted, well, sub-par. Although the fish was cooked tenderly, the vegetables surrounding the fish tasted a bit bitter! I do NOT recommend ordering this platter, especially after having uni, because you'll be severely disheartened. 2/5. 

Their servers were very attentive, always vigilant to my needs almost to a point where it was intrusive on our conversations. But that may also be because we went on a Wednesday night, when business wasn't as busy, so they may have over-did it on the service. 4/5

As my friend mentioned, the open-kitchen allows one to see not only the culinary finesse of their cooks, but also their sanitary standards. And of course, they have nothing to hide.
author: Rose W.

description:
Came to this place for dinner years ago.  My sister and I had a reservation but we arrived early.  The hostess couldn't seat us and made us wait along time.  We saw that there were tables available, after the long wait, the hostess sat us in one of the available tables that we were looking at when we were waiting.  I remembered the food being just ok.  Not at all what I had read on the reviews.  

Today I stopped in there for lunch.  This time we were seated immediately at the bar.  It took the bartender a long time just to take our drink order because he was too busy flirting with the girl seated next to me. We had to ask for a glass of water twice, twice, just for a glass of water.  The wait for our food took a long time to arrive.  My friend had the burger with fries, which looked delicious.  I had the clam chowder, which I've had better at other places.  When our food arrived, the bartender/waiter didn't even ask us if we needed anything else.  because I would have liked to have had come Tabasco sauce.  Again the bartender/waiter was too busy flirting and talking to pay any attention to real customers.  At the end of the meal, the only thing that came fast was our check. 

 I would never go back to this place ever again because the service was very bad!  Next time the bartender/ waiter should provide better service and flirt with patrons on his own time!  I feel as though giving a one star is too much for this place.  Would love to have given this place a negative star if there was an option.
author: Thand H.

description:
He Said:

She focused nicely on the food and I only have a little to add to that.  The walnut/raisin mixture in the center of the squash soup added a nice texture change to the very delicate broth, though the oil slick that accompanied it was a little odd.  It wasn't over-whelming, but it was an addition I didn't need.  I could smell the curry, but it didn't contribute to the flavor significantly.  No problem there, delicate is the order with a soup like this.

The rockfish ceviche, which I loved if nothing else for the light-handed use of citrus, was a highlight.  Our very helpful server said each ceviche dish is made to order, so the fish is not swimming in citrus all day long.  This was great because some of the pieces were less cooked than others, bringing some rare pieces and some medium-to-well pieces.  I liked this mix of textures and doneness.

Being close to full we should have stopped, but I insisted on one more crudo and opted for the salmon tartare.  Maybe because I was full or maybe it was the dish, but I was not happy here.  There was yet another oil slick, this one resulting in at least a tablespoon of it in the bottom of the dish when I was done.  The cut of fish wasn't great for me either.  I would have liked the fish a bit more manageable, perhaps shredded or more chopped.  The mint and basil added a great compliment, but not enough to make me want it again.

One humorous note for us: we had at least 5 servers through the night.  On the one hand it made sure we were well attended to in this busy place, but on the other it lead to some confusion about who was getting us what.  In the end the hostess/server who seemed to be a manager (excellent arm piece) was my favorite.  There is simply nothing wrong with a server who understands good beer and how to pair it with food.  

She Said:

We arrived just as they opened on a Wednesday night, and the bar was already full. We got a table with no problem despite not having reservations.

First, the beverage selection was good. I opted for beer because their selections on tap were great, but the wine list was pretty amazing too.

While we waited for our ceviche, a waiter delivered some chips and dip, and they were both very good. The ceviche was excellent. Not too citrus-y, and served alongside a plum and basil mixture that complimented it nicely.

Next we shared a bowl of clam chowder, and it was really quite good. There wasn't a heavy flour taste as there often is in chowder, and the chef didn't rely on the heavy cream to carry the day either. I would have liked more clam in it, but it wasn't so lacking that I'll complain. It was also good enough that I might come back just for the chowder.

We also shared a bowl of the butternut squash soup, and it was delicious. Smooth and creamy with a bit of a curry taste. Although He Said felt that it was too oily, I didn't find that to be a problem at all.

After the chips, ceviche, two soups, and two beers, I couldn't even imagine eating anything else; however, He Said is a trooper, so he ordered... something.

Overall, this is a great place. The decor is fun, it's only steps from the hotel where we regularly stay, the food is tasty, and the libation situation is good. It can get pricey, and the rotating server situation was weird, but overall, I'm a fan.

She Said's Potty Points: The bathroom situation was fine. They were clean, and there weren't any lines. Four out of five potty points!
author: He Said She Said ..

description: We were able to sit at the bar as soon as we walked in, and I'm glad we did.  Our server was super fast and attentive.  I started out with a couple oysters, then ordered their lobster roll as my entree.  Everything about this dish was perfect.  The buttery, perfectly toasted bun with tons of lobster meat, the coleslaw, and especially the tater tots that accompanied the sandwich.  My boyfriend had their fried chicken sandwich, and said it's one of the best he's had since VH Sandwich Shop in BK.  That says a lot.
author: Michelle R.

description: Excellent lobster roll and service. I had to take a star away for the noise level. The concierge at my hotel recommended it telling me that President Obama ate here when he was in town. He definitely knows a good place!
author: Michele T.

description: Very mediocre. Very average, the ceviche was downright bland. Trying to understand the more favorable reviews.
author: bruce b.

description: Great place to visit for happy hour! Dollar oysters and other delicious treats and drinks in a trendy environment! $1 oysters were delicious.
author: M. N.

description:
Walked in solo and sat at bar: great server BTW... I over ordered and she let me slide with a cancelled dish.
I did egg arugula salad and bucatini seafood, both super.
Wine list had breadth too
author: Miles S.

description:
Service is slow here. We arrived at 8, got seated at 810 (for an 830 reservation) and didn't get our first drinks until 830. Entrees didn't arrive until 947pm. It wasn't crowded. 

Food overall was very decent at best. Oysters were fresh, salmon tartare was tasty (the watermelon helped), but the avacados which were not ripe and pretty inedible. 

Pumpkin soup had a nice silky texture but was pretty salty. Calamari, I was told, was not good. 

I ordered the lobster roll and was underwhelmed for $25. The bread was more flavorful than the filling. 

Also, my buddy's birthday is tonight and his wife made a cake to bring to the restaurant, but we opted out of having them serve it to us because they wanted to charge $4/head/slice. If the waiters had been more on top of things, I think we would've been more likely to oblige but as I'm writing this it's 1015pm on a Monday night and we have to work tomorrow. 

Overall, for a FiDi restaurant I guess it's okay, but you're definitely paying for rent more than quality of food/service. Worth going to once, maybe.
author: Vamsi T.

description: I aknowledge some of the downsides of crowds, noise, waits and indifferent servers but the food is really good. I really enjoyed the lobster roll which was stuffed with large chunks of lobster in a light mayo sauce. Perfect home made tater tots and coleslaw rounded out a nice plate. My people got the clam pasta which had a nice little kick and seemed to be spooned over home made pasta. I would go again but a reservation and maybe an off-hour would make for a better overall experience.
author: Jeremy R.

description: Some of the best seafood in San Francisco. Great atmosphere, super crisp and clean oysters. The happy hour is fantastic. Very personable manager named Danny walks around the dining room greeting diners. My kind of place.
author: scott o.

description:
First of, I'm a huge lover of fresh oyster & sea urchin. So, here goes my review of this place. 

Get the corner bench table to the right, it's the best date spot for 2. Mention that when you make your reservation.  The BEST HOUR to go on a weekend is 5:30 pm, when they just open & there's not a lot of people (yes, they fill out right away).  They run out of sea urchin usually by 8 pm.

5 stars for the sea urchin! (I always like eating my sea urchin on it's shell. I like it better when I get to crack it myself & scoop the meat out). (1) Great presentation. (2) fresh sea urchin meat, it's so soft, melts in your mouth! As if I can still taste it while I'm writing this review. Only 5 pcs of meat though, not enough for me. (3) nice mix with the crab chowder. 

4 stars for the oysters in bacon. (1) great presentation (again), they put each on top of a half oyster shell. Now I got a great party idea for homemade hors d'oeuvres. (2) salty oysters + salty bacon = interesting mix, I guess that's what the lemon was for. 

2 stars for the fresh oysters, we ordered 4 pcs only. I find it flavorless (even the juice), a little chewy when it's supposed to be soft. But maybe because I know my oysters well, and I know where to get the best ones. If you want the best fresh oysters, plan a 2 hour trip to the Hog Oyster Farm in Marshall, CA. I always go there during the Easter to get my yearly oyster-fix. 

4 stars for the ambiance. 

TIP: before you go there, grab some food 1-2 hours prior at the Crab Station #2 to get some crab & clam chowder overload for only $12/person. By the time you get to Anchor & Hope, you wont be at your hunger state you'll only want some "appetizer" sea urchin & oysters in bacon. Coz just the 3 items I mentioned above (without any drinks) cost $75! 

But it's SWELL trying out their sea urchin. I'm coming back for more.
author: Jën N.

description: The food and service below mediocre. For almost $60 I got a watery clam chowder and something called lobster roll - a small bread roll filled with a creamy paste smelling like rotten fish. If there were any lobster in there, the poor thing surely had passed away a long time ago. Oh, yeah, I also got a beer. The place is just one big open space with a high roof which makes it terribly noisy and it looks very much like a factory canteen from the last century.
author: Ivo K.

description:
Happy Hour Review

- Raw Oysters: fresh and delicious, just how they should have been.

- Angels on Horseback: bacon worked very well with the oyster and overall had a great smoky flavor.

- Red Wine: pretty good for $5.

Service here was decent. My friend ended up with a fly in her glass of wine at the beginning of our happy hour. Not sure where the fly came from but the bartender went ahead and gave her a new glass of wine. I'd love to return for more oysters and perhaps to try their lunch/dinner items.
author: Maya S.

description: The lobster roll did not disappoint! I ended up splitting that and the kale salad with a coworker and the combo was perfect. We also started with a round of Kushii oysters for the table and they were so fresh and good! It's now our favorite lunch spot to celebrate birthdays.
author: Kim O.

description: I was visiting San Francisco for the first time from Texas after yelping and trying to pick a place to eat I chose Anchor & Hope. They did not disappoint the service was great the food was awesome and the best part of all they had what I consider the best beer in the US Russian River's Pliny the Elder. I ended up going back later in the night to sit at the bar and have a couple of more. This place is great!
author: Bobby D.

description:
Called on a Tuesday night to reserve a table for eight the following night, and surprisingly they were able to accommodate us -- which I am grateful after seeing the turn out. I ordered smoked trout with mixed greens coupled with a lengthy tater tot. I don't believe I've ever had fresher veggies. They were scrumptious. The same is true for the potato side; however, the smoked trout was much too salty
If you're looking to fill your stomach, I suggest to stay away from the appetizers. 
Go for the more expensive entrees! 

Also, the waiters seem more familiar with birthday policy than the hostess. When we asked the hostess for a complimentary dessert for our birthday boy, she told us, "We're not THAT type of restaurant" 
Luckily, this miscommunication was resolved once I spoke to the waiters directly.

If you're a fan of rustic decor and willing to pay for a good meal, I certainly recommend Anchor and Hope.
author: John P.

description:
I've eaten at Anchor and Hope a couple times in the last month and have to say, I don't know how I hadn't heard about them before.  

I work in San Francisco and met a friend here for lunch the first time I ate here.  The soft shelled crab sandwich was fantastic.  I don't know how they do it, but it is packed with flavor and overall delicious.  The wait staff here was also very attentive.  It made for a very pleasant experience.

With that said, I returned here recently bringing some out of town co-workers for lunch (my treat).  Again, we encountered wait staff that was very friendly and attentive.  My friends happened to be from Maine, so I thought it would be interesting to see what they thought of the menu.  One ordered the lobster roll with giant tater tots, the other, including me, ordered the shrimp Po'boy.  Now with lobster being a staple in Maine, I really wanted to know how this menu item held up.  It did't disappoint.  They loved it!  Not only did they they fall in love with the lobster roll, but they couldn't stop talking about the awesome giant tater tots!

As for me and the other co-worker, the shrimp Po'boy was fantastic.  Fresh ingredients, perfect seasoning, and just a great meal altogether paired with shoestring french fries.

Great job Anchor & Hope.  I will be back.
author: Charles A.

description:
I went here for a large company dinner. Great location and hip decor. We were seated right away. Our appitizer of raw oysters, shrimp cocktail, raw clams and other cold seafood was amazing! The other cooked appitizers were really great too! The cocktails were great. I loved by Blackberry Champange cocktail. The service could not have been better. The minute I finshed something it was taken away. They were really attentive. 

However my entree was just not good. I ordered a fish entree, the fish had been flown in from Greece! I love Greek food. It's my favorite vacation spot. I was excited.  Nope it wasn't great. It was bascially a tone of minced olive on a bland piece of fried fish.  I would have not eaten any of it had it not been at a work function. My other co-worker's steak wasn't cooked correctly and was just so-so. For such an expensive entree I was hoping for more. 

Luckily the dessert was to die for. I ate all of it and left full and happy.

Come here for the drinks, appitizers, and dessert! Skip the entrees. Not worth it.
author: Christy T.

description:
I have been here about a half a dozen times over the past couple of years -- a convenient lunch spot since it's across the alley from my office. 

Have always had excellent food and service here. The staff is very aware that many are here for a business lunch so service is quick and professional. I've had their shrimp roll several times, grilled fish dishes and several desserts -- all great. Food presentation is clean and bright and flavors are super fresh. I always request they substitute a salad for chips and they are so generous with how much salad they give me which I love. Recently I've been in love with their fresh peas/tendrils/mushroom side dish which is super flavorful but not overdone -- I wish I could replicate it at home, especially how bright green they can get those peas!

Yes, this is a slightly pricey place for lunch but very well worth it.

Thanks A&H!
author: Miki C.

description:
I was craving lobster roll one day after work really bad that I remembered this place had it, and it was on my walk home so we went and still in time for happy hour. 

Pros: good lobster roll, 
- eat at the bar for happy hour special. 
- The host was so sweet that felt like he was our personal waiter. 
- Fun happy hour menu. Good seafood, (but maybe not for the high price tags)
- Great nautical interior feel. Does not feel like I'm in the busy SOMA, rather, somewhere in Cape Cod. 
- Good wine list
- Beautiful & professional atmosphere for business/corporate meals

Cons: expensive seafood. (use your expense account)
author: Yum Y U M.

description: Went with a group of six - my parents, my fiance's parents & I, and all of us loved the food!  My tai snapper was amazingly delicious, tomato soup delectable.  Calamari with thai dipping sauce was really great.  His mom raved about the gravlax - all around a very satisfying meal!
author: Jessica H.

description:
I've been back 3 times since my first visit and I think it's a solid four stars. My favorite dishes have been the steak and the stuffed lobster, least favorite was the mussel and monkfish stew. On the app side I still recommend the sea urchin or if you're not feeling adventurous just go with an assortment of oysters.

Service has been consistently good. Last time I was in the hostess noticed from across the room that our table was rocking, she found a slice of wood and corrected the problem. Mr. Manager please give that girl a high five.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
My first experience at one of SF's more expensive restaurants was mediocre (Town Hall).  I was a bit iffy about Anchor and Hope, but both L and I had this bookmarked for awhile after reading excellent reviews from fellow Yelpers.  OpenTable saved our spot (it was packed, fyi) and we were seated around 6:50 (btw, for some reason, parking in the area is usually pretty easy breezy but tonight it was HOrrendous).

After deciding that we both needed to be "good" since we'd eaten an uncharacteristically large amount of food during the day, we both decided on the gravlox salad each, and we split an order of the Angels on Horseback and the brussel sprouts with bacon, plus a glass of red wine for her, and a pear cider for myself.

Let me tell you something, in case you didn't already know this: bacon makes everything better.

Such was the case when we got the Angels on Horseback, which are smoked oysters wrapped in bacon, served with a tart creamy Thousand Island-like sauce and a squeeze of lemon.  The whole thing was smokey, chewy, savory, and just overall amazing.  The bacon overpowers the oyster, so if you don't like oysters but like bacon, you'd probably still enjoy this.  Bacon also made the brussel sprouts taste absolutely uh-may-zing; how can something so healthy and normally pretty untasty be turned into something so salty, flavorful and overall heavenly?  Oh right, bacon and bacon grease.

Our salads were the perfect size for someone who's trying to be good.  The bottom was diced beets in a mayo-based sauce (I think), and on top of that were some fresh greens, and smoked salmon was the top layer.  There were also crispy pieces of lavash bread sprinkled all around.  So many different flavors and textures made for a very unique salad.

Finally, we decided that we had to get dessert.  We were thinking of splitting one, but then I figured that with it being an uppity expensive restaurant, the dessert would probably be smaller than the palm of my hand.  Plus, L wanted the Blue Bottle Coffee Milkshake, and I wanted the Chocolate Almond Cake, which came with malted ice cream and hot fudge.  The desserts took significantly longer than our food, for some reason.  Maybe they were hand-churning the ice cream?

But oh, it was so worth the wait.  Best coffee milkshake ever.  And best chocolate cake ever, with the ice cream melting into the hot fudge.  And I was right - it was small.  Like I could probably eat 4 servings.  All by myself.  Note to current and future potential boyfriend(s)/significant life partner(s):  If you ever ask to share my dessert, I will cut you.

What a great dining experience - the restaurant was beautifully themed and decorated, and the food was excellent.  This is one of those restaurants that I will be returning to if I'm ever in need of an old favorite or a place to impress my picky parents.
author: Tori S.

description: Food and selection are first rate.only beer and wine,some nice ones to be sure. Service was slow and felt as though we were forgotten. Waitress had a party of 8 but left us hanging so ruined the experience and didn't care. Oh well bless your heart
author: Kristen O.

description:
I wasn't really impressed with my experience at Anchor & Hope. I was there a couple months ago and it was very meh. We had the oysters for appetizers, they were good but expensive (I think it was $3-4/oyster). I had the bouillabaisse for my entrée and I've had better, especially for $29. For dessert, we had cheesecake (I think) and that was $9; from what I recall, it was okay. The quality and taste of the food wasn't worth what we paid.

The space in which the restaurant is setup is nice. The ceilings are really high and there are exposed walls and beams. It has a new-age industrial feel. The service was good; our server was prompt and polite but even with that, I don't plan on going back.
author: Kim T.

description:
There seems to be a lot of hi's and low's in regards to the reviews here... Not sure what is causing the swings up and down in terms of service and quality food.  Leaves me still to question if I should be giving this place a 4-star, but to focus on my FIRST visit, I thought it was quite terrific!  I'm a fan.

I came here for a business meeting and the table set-up was perfect.  Just enough distance so that you could not hear the conversation next door to us. The food is plentiful and very tasty.  They have house made chips which are a BIT salty but really complement their menu list.  I couldn't stop eating them!  I ordered a sandwich but now looking at their menu I don't see it on there anymore.  But, it was very tasty!  My colleague ordered the lobster roll and he said it was well prepared and plentiful of lobster pieces.  He couldn't finish the whole sandwich and took it to-go so for the price, you were getting your money's worth.

My only complaint is that the service is a BIT slow.  Some moments they would be very attentive and then other moments total space cadet.  It wasn't enough to be apparent and ruin our luncheon.  We could have walked out of the restaurant and nobody would have noticed we left.
author: Sandy L.

description: My friends and I were in town for my birthday and had heard this was a great spot to eat. We made reservations ahead of time. When we arrived we were seated. Our waiter greeted us after a few minutes with water then didn't return for 15 minutes. The only reason she did was because we stopped her. She seemed kinda rude and even put her hand up when one of us tried to ask a question. We got more attention from the severs around us that night as they refilled our drinks. The food arrived and was good but our server kinda ruined the nighht for us. The atmosphere is great for groups and a intimate date night. If ever in SF again, I may try this place again.
author: Candy M.

description:
Vicky L says: Bacon makes everything better.

I concur, but may I also add: Blue Bottle makes everything better, too.

It had been a while since we had seen each other and decided to knock this off of our bookmarked lists. We had indeed both decided to be "good" during that dinner since we had both had gluettenous days. (Who does this? Aren't you supposed to be good all day so you can eat what you want during your anticipated dinner? Ass backwards thinking, I tell ya.) 

Our good intentions started off well enough, as we both eyed the beet and salmon salad. But then I remembered that Anchor & Hope is known for their Angels on Horseback, so of course had to suggest this. What's this? Vicky L. loves bacon? Sold her on that. And then... we spotted brussels sprouts with bacon... we LOVE brussels sprouts. And with bacon? Ok, we'll get that too. And then... we were given the dessert menu. I'm not even a huge dessert fan but I wanted everything. Blue Bottle Milkshake? Must. Have. And V got the chocolate almond fudge cake which was also damn good. I think we're both glad we decided not to share dessert.

So what was supposed to be a catch up dinner with both attendees being "good" ended up being a bacon-tastic dinner followed by THE BEST MILKSHAKE EVER. 

Hey we had beets and brussels sprouts. That's healthy enough.
author: Leilani H.

description:
The food: I've been wanting to go to Anchor and Hope for awhile, especially after food network featured the sea urchin appetizer on a show. So my close friends and I made reservations for NYE and it was really quite mediocre with some shining moments. We started with two different oysters- one sweet, one briny, and they were delicious.The sea urchin and crab appetizer was a sauce? a soup? that had amazing flavor- the richness of the sea urchin and lumps of Dungeness were delicious and well herbed. Surprisingly though, our entrees weren't all that amazing- my friend's trout was bland, her boyfriend's scallops were good, my sister's seared tuna was passable and my mahi mahi was something I feel like I could make at home.

The good: We were seated at the best table (probably due to the reservation) and our  servers were very polite and helpful with beer and oyster suggestions. The oysters and sea urchin appetizer were the highlights of the meal. It was also a little fun that the restaurant is down a little alley, and dimly lit in a romantic, quirky kind of way.

The bad: For the money we paid ($25 and upwards for entrees) I expected blow your mind seafood, but then again it's SF and good food comes quite pricier here it seems. I was disappointed with my mahi mahi entree as well.

Overall: worth a visit if you can afford to splurge, but aside from the freshness of the seafood the flavors and skill in cookery wasn't quite there.

Good for: dinner with friends or a date
author: Jackie T.

description: We had a birthday dinner on Saturday night this week.  The food was really prepared well.  The raw oyster were a nice selection from other regions of the states.  The ceviche mixed seafood was well balanced and tasted great.  We split the lobster between the two of us and it had plenty of meat in it.  The restaurant had a good selection of beer.  The service was a little slow at first when the restaurant was packed.  I would eat here again!
author: Dwayne K.

description:
I can only comment in getting a beer here.   The day we went it was one of those Hot days and I guess there was no air-conditioner they had a large fan blowing in.   I grabbed a beer at the bar and I was hot and thirsty and for the $11 dollar beer I got a really thin redbull can-sized drink.   Um ugh.  I drank it and we we're off to the next bar.  

I didn't like it too much.  I "might" go back for the food on a cold day.   I guess they rely too much on the SF weather.
author: Homer S.

description:
what happened to this place??  we came here again saturday night last weekend and the experience was sub par, if not bad.  we noticed a lot less patrons than last time too.

we ordered the seafood plateaux and the six clams on it were BAD.  like rank.  yuck.  we politely tried to tell the server and he told us they got them in that morning.  well then he can eat them.  they replaced them with 6 oysters which then promptly appeard on our bill.  which meant that we had to awkwardly ask him why that was the case. it was a mistake.

we also had the tomato burrata salad.  but who can mess that one up.  for mains we shared the clam pasta and then the steak.  the steak was good.  the clam pasta looked like it had sat out for a while, maybe and most likely through our bad clam debaucle.  they probably should have remade it because it was tasteless but a bit sour and not hot.  ugh.

for dessert we tried the banana cheesecake which was good but the peach crisp was not. it was a bowl of hot mess.  

no sure what happened to this place
author: claudia y.

description: Walk thru a slum to get there. Typical poser restaurant. Horribly inattentive waiter. $32 for a lobster roll? Fuck off!
author: Steven R.

description:
ordered the crab louie, not what i had expected. a scoop of shredded crab bits no chunks at all like most other crab louie salads.  my guest order the tacos, they didn't seem that great either....

although the tater tots were delicious!
author: Mel S.

description:
Came here for Mother's Day! My mom loves the whole brunch thing with free flowers but I knew she also likes to try out the newest thing in the City. We arrive early, 15 min. for our reservations and we were seated after 15 seconds. 

After looking at the menu, we decided to order a bunch of appetizers to share and just two entrees. We were going to go with just the Monk Fish Stew, but because I am allergic to fish, my parents wanted me to get something to eat. 

friendly service, love the atmosphere, decor isn't over the top. airy space in cool colors and gigantic cartoon scary fish on the walls.

LOVE the scallop ceviche, UNI, and white corn chowder. mouthgasmic!  i've never had hot uni before and was kinda skeptical about it, but with mashed potatoes, tomatoes, cream and lobster meat.... DROOOOL! and the chowder, omg! of course they served it steaming hot in the trendy, pour-the-liquid-in-front-of-you-from-a-small-carafe, but one taste and HOLY CRAP THIS IS DELICIOUS! So creamy, so sweet. 

My entire family tells me all the fish dishes were fresh and delishshshshes. 

the lobster salad was good. as my dad said, "my favorite kind of salad. no veggies. just lobster." but i'd say if you get the lobster roll, don't order the lobster salad and coleslaw, bc it comes with it. the bread is perfectly panned friend in butter and the chips are tissue-paper thin crispy savory goodness. the coleslaw was good, but kind of reminded me of kimchi.

I would skip the stone crab claws - maybe its not season? great selection of wines and beers. we were way too full for dessert, but ordered the bread pudding anyways. mmmm! vanilla peach warm goodness...

pros: taste! service! atmosphere. casual. UNI AND CHOWDER
cons: looks like this place is gonna get popular. get here before it gets too hard to get a table!.. street parking is always a bummer unless you get lucky.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Very good food, but very pricey - as expected

Reservations are a must especially if you have a large group. Upon arrival, they promptly filled our waters and brought out delish (looking) chips [since i'm on my no fried food diet.. couldnt partake but i was told they were good]

- lobster roll - been craaaving this forever. the lobster was tasty but the consensus of the table was that the bread overshadowed the lobster. one even commented that she'd rather just eat the bread than that expensive lobster :p

- mussels - this was delish and surprisingly spicy! can't recall what was in it but that was a nice surprise. good thing it comes with a piece of bread that you can realy enjoy the flavors of the broth.

 - drinks - very large menu of wine and beer.. enjoyed a nice white wine with my meal.

the wait staff was very attentive and our waiter was very nice, however, probably due to a busy evening, we really had to flag him down to even order (which took at least 15 - 20 minutes).

would dine here again when my wallet is replenished.
author: Selena H.

description:
Bacon wrapped Oyster for $2 during happy hour!

Met my friends here for happy hour and didn't even know it ends at 6pm. They ordered me the bacon wrapped oysters, since I have been raving about it.  By the time I got there, it was a bit cold,. but so good.  

Didn't get a chance to order drinks or try anything else,.. and we had to leave to the next spot.  I will be back,. just to eat the bacon wrapped oysters HOT and right off the grill!
author: Chanel L.

description:
I love this place!  I've been here 3 times in the past six months and enjoyed the meal all 3 times. The Dungeness crab in particular was incredible!

My only complaint is the noise level - lots of hard surfaces and high ceilings that make voices carry. This is not the place to go if you want to have an intimate conversation!
author: Peter H.

description:
Kudos for the creative beer selection alone! Note to self, come back for happy hour.

Fish & Chips = One piece of fish sitting atop a mountain of fries. Seems portioned wrong for an entree.

Lobster Roll = Good authentic bread and very nice presentation. Wish there was a 'naked' option where they didn't toss my lobster chunks in their 'special' sauce. Couldn't really taste the lobster this way. I'll ask for sauce on the side next time.
author: John H.

description:
The sea urchin is very good but it's really just a fancy potato soup. There is a decent amount of crab but that delicate sea urchin flavor wasn't the focus. That said, I would definitely order this again.

The "Angels on Horseback" are also good. At first all you taste is bacon but then the oyster comes through and is great, but then fades out into more bacon. Highly recommended for bacon lovers. Oyster lovers, maybe just get a half dozen market price.

The catfish was bland and tasted almost, dare I say, not fresh? I love fish but I didn't have more than one bite, it was so unappealing.  It was accompanied by two even blander pieces of fried okra that fell out of their breading atop "jalapeno cornbread." This is not cornbread. This is toast that may or may not have a whiff of jalapeno but it is in no way a cornbread. It only made us reminisce about Dottie's amazing cornbread with jalapeno jelly. 

The parmesan fries were serviceable and came with some kind of dill mayo. Not cheesy enough for my taste, though.

Also, I asked and they no longer have the Blue Bottle Coffee milkshake on the dessert menu :(.

Recommendation: Come here for beer and appetizers only (probably best during happy hour). The decor is nice. Bonus points for the free Acme pain epi.
author: Annie C.

description:
I would say this place is not worth a visit. Though my rockfish dish was quite nice, everything up to it tasted ok to not good.  I am happy to pay a lot for nice food, but this food was not worth the money. The mussels were ok on 1 batch and really awful on the second batch with a different flavoring. The menu offered a limited range of options, I thought.I love seafood and there was not much that I wanted to order and neither of my 2 friends ordered a main dish because they did not like anything on the menu (they just ordered a salad and a chowder). We had plenty of appetizers, a few main meals, and only 2 alcoholic beverages but somehow the bill was still $60/person. Again, happy to pay that if I was provided with more choice and really high quality cuisine. 

It was hard to get service though there were 3 people attending to us and we were in the CENTER of the restaurant. 

The waitress was beyond RUDE - she seemed to be quite pretentious, barely opting to look at us. Though my parents asked some embarrassing questions, she could have at least humored them. They are not originally from this country so yes, they mispronounce things like arugula. She could barely stomach engaging with them - definitely NOT welcoming.

Definitely would not recommend this place.
author: Monica S.

description:
I met up with an old work colleague for lunch here last summer.  The decor and ambiance were wonderful, with the large windows and natural lighting.  However, the food was rather disappointing.  We shared the Angels on Horseback, which were greasy and the bacon was chewy (should be crisp).  The oysters weren't that fresh either.  We also shared the catfish sandwich that was terribly under seasoned.  The highlight of my meal was definitely the lobster roll!  They didn't skimp on the lobster and the buttered brioche is mouthwatering.  Crispy on the outside, fluffy and moist on the inside.  

For the price, I would not go again, but I would say this is the best lobster roll I've ever had.
author: Jen Y.

description:
Service is a bit shaky....  maybe it's just during happy hour and they are setting up for dinner.  Servers were very polite and friendly just slow.

Happy Hour:
$1 oysters - Were great!  couldn't get enough

Great Beer selection.  they got good stuff.
author: Steven F.

description:
I've been to this place a couple of times for dinner, and I really enjoyed it. Decorations go on par with the restaurant name, and they make obvious references to the ocean.  Full menu is server at the bar as well, so that's another option. 
As of food, everything was great - oysters, ceviche (spicy!), and scallops. 
Atmosphere is usually vibrant and somewhat loud, especially on weekends.
If you're into seafood, this is definitely a good place to try.
author: Steve E.

description: I really loved my lunch here today and the service was excellent. The lentil soup was bowl-licking good. The crab Louie was light and delicious. And I think I may have eaten the best Brussels sprouts of my life, seriously, I'd go back for them alone. I plan to return.
author: Vincent C.

description:
Came here with some co-workers for lunch and we had the large shellfish plateaux consisted of east and west coast raw oysers, shrimp, raw clams, and crab and shrimp remoulade. Oysters and clams were quite delicious. Also tried the calamari appetizer, which was mediocre.

I was told their shrimp roll ($21) was their signature dish, so I decided on that one. The brioche bun that the shrimp was on was the best but I wouldn't say the same for shrimp--which was basically the shrimp remoulade from the plateaux. There were a lot of shrimp shells in there and I had to pull them out of my mouth everytime I bit into the sandwich.Tasted like a jar of mayonnaise. The sea salt chips and cole slaw that accompanied it weren't all that great either.

3 stars because I liked the brioche bun and the oysters and clams.
author: Cheri S.

description:
Keep coming back here for many reasons.  Primarily, the service is excellent...sure you can get oysters many places in the city, but the waiters here are interactive and attentive, making dining here an experience.  Even without a reservation we have been able to grab a seat at the bar, and still had a great experience.  They always have excellent wine suggestions.  They always offer a wide range of oysters - I prefer my east coast varieties.  They also have amazing ceviche, pastramied salmon, and other fish dishes...I've never had a bad meal here.

If you are a seafood fan and want an excellent dining experience, I highly suggest coming here.
author: Nic S.

description:
I loved Anchor and Hope. The BF and I hit it up at 10 pm on a Friday night for a quick appetizer and drink before a night out. The place was busy, but we found a comfy spot at the bar. We got a glass of wine and the angels on horseback. 

The angels on horseback were really good - perfectly cooked. The bacon was crispy on the outside, and the oysters were still tender and juicy on the inside. I loved the dish! Just wished there was more to go around.

The vibe and the atmosphere alone in this place make me want to come back for a full dinner. Based just on the app and wine, I had a great time, and would recommend this place to anyone.
author: Amanda D.

description:
Anchor & Hope is a great place to come for a business lunch or if you want to treat yourself.  The seafood here is really fresh and tasty.  I was looking to have a nice lunch by myself away from the office and wanted to try the lobster roll mentioned in 7x7.  $25 is kinda steep for lunch but what the hey, lobster!  The lobster roll came with kettle chips (yummy) and coleslaw.  The roll had large chunks of lobster in it.  At first i thought it wasn't that much compared to the bread, but that's just because the bread is kinda big.  The lobster roll is nicely complemented with one of their fancy beers (if you're going to get a nice lunch you might as well go all out).  It is not big enough to share despite how it looks.

Though it was more than I would normally pay for lunch, and I wouldn't do this very often, I would probably come back if I was looking for good seafood.
author: Jean K.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this place.

As others remarked, service was just a bit off. The bar basically had no bartender for a while during the dinner rush, so it was a long time before anyone helped us. The lighting is dark but not annoying, and the place gets LOUD so be warned.

The server was helpful and understanding when I asked her with obvious embarrassment on my face which dishes were dairy-free. The lobster roll sandwich was great, as were the clams with linguine that I tried. Despite that, somewhat small portions in both apps and entrees for the price. I'd go back but not my favorite. Then again FiDi isn't really my scene.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Such good food, such poor planning! 
If you sit at the bar and choose to eat it's like you are in a wind tunnel!!! The kitchen fan sucks all the air right through the front door.  Directly past the bar seats.  I could literally see my hair moving  then they tell you they have to keep the doors open as the rest of the restraint  is not air conditioned.  Ok so who cars about bar patrons anyway
author: Mary T.

description:
We love to have random staycations in this gorgeous city of ours. This time, we ventured out to this restaurant 2 blocks away from our hotel and had such a fabulous time here last night. 
We shared a small seafood plateaux with 6 different types of oysters, each with it's own distinct flavor. The prawns were fresh and meaty and the cocktail sauce not too tangy or overly sweet. The rockfish ceviche sang with Thai chili and coconut milk flavors and the delicious crab rémoulade demanded we eat it by the forkful. Knowing we would be full from the plateaux, we'd ordered on the light side and decided on the grilled octopus with pork belly. While I was expecting the "octobelly" I was quite unprepared for the fresh cubes of sweet watermelon, pickled canteloupe rind, dollops of balsamic vinegar reduction, grilled beets and crispy pieces of chiccharon! The combination of flavors and textures was perfection on both the plate and palate. We also had the grilled summer squash which was topped with a tasty hazelnut-heavy gremolata. 
We were so full halfway through the squash that we didn't want to look at the dessert menu, but at our server Josh's insistence, we did...and found ourselves lusting after the Nutella bread pudding, but unfortunately lacking the stomach space. His solution? Pack it up, bring it back to the Palace Hotel and have them heat it up for you when your stomachs are good and ready. Um, hello, best suggestion ever!

What really stood out was the wonderful attention given to us by Josh and the rest of his team. Everyone we encountered had a smile to share with us and made us feel very welcome and right at home. At the beginning of the meal, I wondered aloud to Josh if he might have any sour beer suggestions to share with me. Seeing his eyes light up when he told me they actually have a Secret Sour Beer menu made me positively giddy! When our 2 glasses of Bruery's Sour in the Rye were brought to our table by Tom the bartender, he told us they were the very last 2 glasses they had and not a drop was left. Manager Danny also stopped by our table and we had a great conversation regarding Bruery and we're excited to try more of their selections. This team's attention to detail and infectious enthusiasm for the food and beverages they stand 100% behind is refreshing to experience in this sometimes jaded industry.

I can't wait to come back here with my friends, my family and maybe even just myself. Just the thought of sitting at the long bar with the sourest of beers and the octobelly in front of me makes my mouth water. 
As I asked my dining companion last night, "Can we come back tomorrow?!"
author: Veronica C.

description:
I Loved it here! The food was great, im a big sea food fan. I ordered oysters and the crab, super excellent. My girlfriend had the lobster roll it was good but I thought the bread was to thick and not enough lobster. :-/ 
Also the deserts are amazing must have after a great dinner, it completes the whole experience!! I will for sure return!!!
author: Julieta C.

description:
Not sure what's up with the mediocre reviews. 

I am a total east coast seafood snob and loved this place. Fantastic service, wonderful beer and oyster selection and our mains were spot on. The seafood was undeniably fresh and cooked perfectly. 

I will definitely be coming back soon.
author: Robert T.

description: I've been here a few times for their happy hour. Even when they're all booked up, they still squeeze me and my friends in at a table, giving us a good hour to hour and half to chill and eat. Their oysters are always fresh and are easy to pop in your mouth. I get a couple dozen oysters for a group of 2-3 of us. They also give those chips and some dip to go along with it. Pairs well with the fresh oysters. My go to place for happy hour oysters!!
author: Jenn T.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in SF.  It helps that I am a seafood junkie, of course.  I have been here so many times over so many years (it's a family go-to for birthdays, celebrations, big dinners, etc) that the menu has changed, but no matter what it looks like, we always luck out and have something delicious.

Appetizers are, in a weird way, the stars here.  Not that the entrees aren't good, but the appetizers continue to be unreal.  Sardines, angels on horseback, ceviche, etc.  The oysters are on another level.  Beer list is INCREDIBLE for an upscale(ish) seafood place, so many good things to try, and the servers are ridiculously knowledgeable.  

Ambiance is fantastic, everybody has commented about the mural of the fish food chain, and the pirate "limb reimbursement" poster in the men's bathroom, but this is one of my favorite places aesthetically in SF.  Contemporary, understated, and witty/humorous.

Perfect for big dinners, and also for a datenight if you want to get some of the appetizers and a wine/beer at the bar.  No hard alcohol though, even though the wine/beer lists make up for it.

Ultimately, even though I love this place, if you aren't a diehard seafood fan, there are better ways to spend your money.  If you are, this is a real treat.
author: James S.

description: The decor at Anchor & Hope is trendy and clean. I really like the atmosphere and it was buzzing after work around 6pm. I ordered the clam chowder which was fine. I was expecting something amazing since they are such fish specialists, so maybe that was my problem. I paired it with fries and wine from the happy hour ($5! glasses). The service was slow because they were so busy, but our waitress was so sweet and checked in on us as often as possible. The cake we got was a real highlight to the meal!
author: Natalie N.

description:
A friend & I came here particularly for the sea urchin dish but they did not have it. We were disappointed but stayed to try other things. We started off with the dollar happy hour oysters which was fresh & good. 

We also had the "angels on horseback" baked bacon wrapped oysters, which was good too. The dishes I thought were just okay & really, nothing special were the Little Gem salad, sashimi, & lobster bisque. 

Probably would only go back here again to try the sea urchin dish, that's all.
author: Alysha K.

description: Everything I had is good but the portions are really small, especially for what you're paying. Also they don't have hard alcohol but are about as pricey as an actual cocktail. I think this is probably a great place for happy hour oysters but I won't be back for dinner.
author: Dino R.

description:
There are so many things to like about this place:

1. Nautical decor done in a tasteful and beautiful way---ropes, weird ship stuff.
2. Huge platter on ice of oysters, shrimp, and shrimp/crab salads.
3. The best fish and chips I've ever had.
4. Lots of natural light.

It is one of the better places I've gone for a work lunch. A lot of people were on the dressier side but it didn't really matter that much.
author: Julia D.

description:
We had reservations at 7 p.m. there were three of us. A friend and I arrived early and had shrimp cocktail, calamari and a sparkling riesling at the bar. Everything tasted great and the bartender was very efficient.  

Once at our table we waited 15 minutes before the server arrived. My friends shared a bottle of sauvignon blanc. Which took another 10 minutes to arrive.

After yet another 10 minutes or so the server arrived to take our orders. My friend and I ordered petit romaine salads. For an entree I had the lobster roll with potato chips, my friend had lobster remoulade with potato chips and our other friend ordered fish and chips. 

The remoulade was the exact stuffing used in the lobster roll both were just OK, too much mayonnaise. The fish and chips were great except for the tiny bits of french fries, we wish they were whole fries instead of bits. 

The salads were good and fresh but had too much dressing. 

For desert we shared a piece of banana cheese cake. It was out of this world. It tasted like burnt marshmallows with banana. So, so very yummy. The crust is more like a crumble instead of graham cracker crust. We loved it.

We will not be returning. The service was good, the kitchen was way too backed up. One can get a better lobster roll at Sam's Chowder House in Half Moon Bay and Liverpool Lil's by the Presidio has THE BEST fish and chips in San Francisco in my opinion. 

Anchor and Hope charged too much ($265 for three of us) frankly there are better restaurants for the price.
author: Bob H.

description:
- Delicious chips and dipping sauce served before meal
- Server seemed like he was straight out of acting school and claimed the wine list was his religion and the menu was his second religion. He was a little overzealous for our taste, but otherwise provided great service.
- Amazing clam chowder
- I hadn't had a lobster roll before coming here, so I didn't know what to expect. It's a little unusual and very bready but it was good, just not the savory lobster dish that I thought it might be.
- Overall, it was a little pricey for the portion size, but the food was well prepared and really delicious.
author: Joshua K.

description:
Waiter was friendly but service was very slow and they forgot our  side dishes.  Fish was fresh but a bit overpriced. Room was 
Noisy
author: basil p.

description:
Holy crap! Can I just say the food here is justifiably delicious?! I have decided to be one of their regular patrons...@ least for the Happy Hour portion.

Referred to as A&H by regulars, this place seriously rocks.

Oysters for a dollar. Really, who does that?? Expecting tiny withery type oysters, out came 12 Oregon full grown and full of meat type oysters, magnificently displayed may I add, above fresh sea salts and served w/ lemon, vinegarette & red sauce. Ohhh Joy! 

Each oyster bite packed a flavorful punch, and when paired w/ the braised bacon, beets, and cabbage OH MY GAWD did I just die and go to heaven. Sigh, it was that awesome of a pair ohmmmmmm!! Much like the Angels on Horseback (as referred to on the 7x7), however, less the remoulade.

While the chef select oysters & braised bacon did not disappoint, neither did the fish tacos. Tender, succulent, crispy fresh fish meat served w/ savory green cream sauce in a small tortilla wrap. This dish brought pure happiness to my palate. Hi.

Bottom line: a little on the pricy side but definitely well worth it. Seafood- awesome! Service- awesome! Happy Hour- even more awesome! Try it!!!

Happy Hour is from 4-6PM!
author: Joy A.

description: I will start by saying that the staff was very nice and attentive. However the food left a lot to be desired and typically the lifespan of a restaurant in SF is short lived if they can't deliver decent food. The fact that this place is still here amazes me. The oysters were pricey but not terrible. However oysters don't require any cooking on the part of the restaurant so they get no credit for that. My bf ordered the lobster roll. The bread appeared to be nicely toasted but instead of using thick chunks of lobster it was actually minced into small pieces, not seasoned and used tons of celery as a cheap filler. Let's get to the real problem though. The grilled rock cod with lentil arrived cold as if it had been sitting in the pass for a while. The fish was overcooked, unseasoned and rubbery. To make it even worse it sad on a bed of bland lentils soaked in its own dirty lentil water because it wasn't properly drained. The dish was sent back and I did not even want to bother to have something else sent in its place. Total disappointment.
author: Mai C.

description:
West Coast raw oysters. Decadent, fresh, and a luxury. A great way to celebrate anything.

Shrimp cocktail - shrimp are large, plump, sweet and not at all rubbery or frozen whatsoever.

Desserts, especially the carrot cake. Eat it all.

I would just come here to eat the raw offerings and desserts. Their dishes change seasonally, but man...if you can catch that lobster roll, I would hit it up.
author: Genevieve L.

description:
Made reservations through Open Table for lunch on 6/8/2010 to try the Dine About Town 2010 menu.

Food - 2 stars
Waitstaff - 2 stars
Location - 1 star
Overall - 2 stars

Thank goodness I was walking to this restaurant in broad daylight. It's definitely located in an unsafe alley that I would not want to go into at night. The street was so dirty and wet from run off that I don't want to know about. It's located just walking distance from the unsavory backside of the SF bus terminal. 

Once inside, I felt relief. It was bright inside and decorated with a seafaring motif. If I didn't know, from the name of the restaurant, that they serve seafood, the decor gave it away. Not very original.

I ordered the following from the Dine About Town menu:

Appetizers: Angels on Horseback ~ Smoked Bacon Wrapped Oysters, Remoulade Sauce 
- amazing! A must-have when eating here.

Main course: Ahi Tuna Melt with Fontina Cheese, Oven Dried Tomatoes, Lola Rosa Greens
- bread was so greasy that my fingers were dripping the oil as I was trying to hold the sandwich to bite into it. The tuna was dry and I actually opened up the sandwich to see if there was cheese and sundried tomatoes inside....just barely.

Additional: raw oyster from Walker Creek (CA) and Island Creek (MA) for $3.50 each.
- too expensive for the dime size raw oysters that didn't taste as good and half the size of the oyster used in the appetizer.

Service was mediocre and not a smile on the waitress' face the entire time. I'm very disappointed with the overall of this restaurant.

The only redeeming aspect is the Angels on Horseback, but who could resist anything wrapped in bacon!  Otherwise, skip this restaurant completely.
author: Christine T.

description:
I greatly appreciate the General Manager contacting me about my customer service experience. Seeing that one employee may not necessarily represent the good of the whole, I am going to give Anchor & Hope another try when I'm in town next and provide an update!

Didn't return. I was told my check from that evening couldn't be found. Not that many ppl in the restaurant that evening...split check for a party of 2...??? Doesn't really matter though. Hopefully no one else will receive the rude service my friend and I received that day. To top that off, the Mgr had the nerve to contact me and demand I remove my negative review immediately.
author: S K.

description: Doorman at our nearby hotel recommended this place. Wow! Delicious! Massive beer list, and excellent wine. Loved it. Great service.
author: Patrick D.

description:
A warehouse located in a SOMA alley. Exposed brick & exposed beams. Airy. Light & bright. High ceilings. And they serve lobstah rolls. I'm gonna like this place.

After having lunch here, I realized that A&H's appeal comes from their location, the ambiance & the hype. The food gets 3 stars, but they get an extra star for paying attention to details that make them unique (water served in large brown-tinted medicine bottles, beer served in curvaceous glasses, check comes with a fishing weight, etc.) & for their upscale, but lively atmosphere.

Their lobster roll ($24) was my favorite dish, partially because I felt it was the only one to stand up on it's own. The crab remoulade appetizer (from the "specials" menu on the chalk board) & shrimp po' boy relied on the spiciness of the remoulade for it's flavor while the lobster didn't need anything extra to make it delicious. I especially liked the lightness of the mayo & the buttery, toasted bread. A&H's flavors are a little too subtle, too safe. The bf commented that the food was too mild & that the lobster did not taste distinctly "lobster." 

Total for 1 appetizer, 2 sandwiches & a Port of Call drink: $68

Our waitress, although not enthusiastic, was quick, which was helpful because we were parked at a meter. If you don't make reservations for lunch, the hostess will try to seat you at the bar even if there are plenty of open, available tables.

A&H is a trendy, fun spot where the flavors are mellow enough to convert seafood skeptics but good enough to satisfy a seafood fan such as myself.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
I've been wanting to come to Anchor & Hope for sometime because of the Angels on Horseback on the SF Big Eat List.  Came here with the BF after watching the Peter Pan show.  It was kind of scary walking to this place because Minna is pretty deserted and dark.

Angels on Horseback (bacon wrapped oysters) - First time having oyster like this and it was pretty interesting.  Cooked oyster has this distinct taste that I'm not too fond of, but with the bacon, it mellowed it out a little bit and made it more pleasant.  The BF however did not think it was good, said he could not taste the bacon and the whole thing was kind of flavorless.

Fried Green Tomatoes - Not sure why, but they gave us this dish complimentary from the chef. First time also having fried green tomatoes.  I like how it had a nice crunch to it, but the tomatoes were too tangy for me.

Calamari - The BF has to order this at every restaurant we go to if on the menu.  It's nothing special, not too soggy, and came with a pretty good thai chilli dipping sauce.

Ahi Tuna - While the BF has to order calamari at every restaurant, I have to order Ahi Tuna.  It was fresh and had a very good sauce and other things mixed in.  My only complaint is that for $15, I expected a little more.

Soft Shell Crab - I did not like this at all.  I know it's suppose to be "soft shell" but this crab was soft and soggy and tasted as though it was fried in the morning and served to us at 10 at night.  The avocado type mousse tasted kind of sour too.

The restaurant was a cute and intimate restaurant.  Our waitress however seemed kind of unpleasant and the food was definitely not worth the price.  It was fun trying out the Angels on Horseback just to knock another item off the Big Eats List, but I would not come back here again.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Anchor & Hope just doesn't do it for me.  I went here for a work lunch 3 years ago and didn't love it then which is why I haven't been back.  My office is across the street so after all this time I felt like it was time to give it a second chance.  This experience was even worse.  

We were seated in the corner which was fine with me except that we were completely ignored our entire meal.  Our lunch to such a long time because they never came by to clear our apps, bring us bread, which I had to ask for 3 times before we got any, and we waited almost 15 minutes after we finished eating for the check before I asked the hostess to bring it to us since our waitress waited so long to check on us.

As for the food, the prices are fine but the portions are tiny and the food is just not that flavorful.  I got the crab Louie.  It was simple lettuce and a tiny portion of crab with a really heavy not so tasty overly pickley tartar sauce.  No tomatoes, nothing extra to go with the lettuce and crab.  Just not very tasty. The burger was overcooked and didn't fit the size of the bun (was really small).

Lots of good places downtown for a casual or business lunch.  This is definitely not one I would go back to.
author: Julia B.

description:
Friday night - no reservations - but room for the three of us at the bar. Couldn't have been a nicer experience. When ordering drinks, small misstep in that the original bar guy didn't ask 10-year-old daughter what she wanted to drink. However, when our drinks came and were served by the woman who took over, she was on it. My favorite question ever by a server? "Tell me what you're allowed to have." Oh. my. god. All these years in the bay area and not one server has been smart enough to take that angle. Savvy servers often will be kind to kids (and duh - if you haven't figured this out yet servers...listen up) but they do it to the exclusion of the parent. "Want something syrupy and sweet?"  "Would you like dessert?" Right at the kid. Bad move server. You may think the tug factor works in a restaurant - but you'd be wrong. Now you've just pissed me off. 

But back to THIS server who did NONE of those bad things. She engaged her (and us), served her crab appetizer without the spicy stuff that normally comes with it, stopped and had a full-on adult conversation with her without excluding us....on and on. The food continues to be spot-on - daughter thought the crab was the best meal ever....the squash soup that we split was delicious, the trout was yummy (although I do think I'd revert to the lobster roll next time - just can't get enough of a good lobster roll....ever). Husband had some meat thing again - pork belly? I don't know - sorry - but he really really liked it.

Go here. You won't be sorry.
author: Laurie H.

description:
I had high hopes for the A&H. Overall, the decor and atmosphere is great. Menu is solid, food is good, good beer selection. Here is where the place lost me a little bit-

Although the food is above average, you can find better at a lower price nearby.
I ordered a soda and it was 4 bucks!!! WTF?

And they add on the Healthy SF surcharge, which we now know is a transparent scam...

2.5 stars.
author: Jim B.

description: Great service, great food. We had the Clam Chowder and heirloom tomato salad to start, amazing. My husband had the Lobster roll and I had the cod, delicious. We will come back again.
author: Karen G.

description:
What happened, folks that brought us Town Hall and Salt House? Anchor and Hope's website made it seem cool and classy. Reality differed. The interior looked like a semi-creative person's garage, with a lack of temperature control to match. The chairs were that really light aluminum that could fall over in a light breeze. 

There seems to be a disappointing trend in SF restaurants where they are very understaffed yet charge fine dining prices. I take offense when a restaurant charges thirty bucks for an entree but gives the server so many tables that she can't spare a moment to ask if that entree came out all right. Our waitress gave us no warm attention at all, just came by to ask, "More wine?" or "Room for dessert?" basically asking, "Wanna spend?" instead of, "How can I make this dining experience good for you?"

Two people I believe were managers just creeped me out to see them. The guy looked like he had recently been turned into a zombie (the black under his eyes giving him away) while the woman manager appeared seriously cracked out and apparently never learned know how to use a hairbrush.

Awful.
author: Gerard B.

description:
The low 2-star food rating was helped out by friendly service.  I might come back for HH with the good beer selection, but prob not for dinner.

One mistake I made was forgetting to order the mussels for apps, as those looked pretty tasty.

Service was very good, as it took a whiles longer than they'd told us to get us seated, but gave us some comped calamari.  BTW the 5 of us, we ordered 3 different entrees.  Shoulda gone for more variety.  

The Lobster Roll was pretty good, pretty flavorful.  Don't think it would have filled me up though.

The fish n chips (Beer Battered Flounder) looks cool resting atop a bed of fries, but was really mediocre tasting.  I guess it was fresh enough, but the flavor was pretty bland.  Maybe Halibut would have been a better choice of fish for $24 fish n chips.  Also, the batter was sharp & crunchy, the type that tends to cut the roof of your mouth.  Only decent part of this dish is the fries.

The Linguine With Clams...also mediocre, bland sauce and kind of a low clam-to-pasta ratio.

Overall, a mixed experience.  Friendly staff and good customer service, but they need some help with the food.
author: J S.

description: I've been here twice and both times were amazing. The first time I sat at a table and food and service were nice. The second time my boyfriend and I sat at the bar just for appetizers and wine and it was amazing! I don't remember the bartender's name but he was awesome. We had oysters and muscadet. Their wine list is perfect!
author: Marina D.

description: Tasty oysters, good beer, french fries and lobster roll are a must. But they run out so show up early and order quick. Nice service.  Good place for business lunch or post work happy hour. Gets crowded though - reserve a spot.
author: Sarah B.

description: As an out of towner, I can't speak to the quality of this place on a daily..but when I went in, was able to sit at the bar (before the massive influx of the lunch crowd) and had me some great beer (Allagash Curieux) and great eats (Little Neck clams on the half shell and a grilled shrimp and calamari sandwich). The bartender was cool, there was one light skinned gorgeous waitress who looked like a young Vanity (a special reference for all you Prince fans) and just overall a nice atmosphere. Definitely will hit up again when I come back to SF!
author: Osito S.

description: After many business lunches and after work happy hour meet ups, it pains me to banish this place to average-ville. What can I say?  They work hard to earn their rating.  I think A & H needs to either revise their menu or lower their $25-30 entree price points.  A po-boy sandwich for $26?!  Currently the only thing this place is good for is drinks and apps as the entrees are just stupid expensive for what you get.  Some places are just going to fill tables easily due to location and this place is no different.  They're in SoMa and seem to prey upon tourists who think they've stumbled upon a local hot spot or business professionals who can expense the meal.  After my final dinner here last week, I walked away content knowing I'd never waste $200+ dollars for 4 here ever again.
author: Darin E.

description:
11.30am DAT for two.

It took us a while to find this place. When we spotted it, I was leery... it looks ghetto but as I got closer I saw the nicely decorated windows and the fancy interior decor. 
 
Didn't even need reservations. It never got close to being packed the entire time we were there.

The DAT menu was:
New England Clam Chowder, Smoked Bacon, Housemade Sea Salt Crackers 
or 
Angels on Horseback ~ Smoked Bacon Wrapped Oysters, Remoulade Sauce 
 
& 
Shrimp Louis, Heirloom Beans, Olives, Arugula, Remoulade
or 
Ahi Tuna Melt with Fontina Cheese, Oven Dried Tomatoes, Lola Rosa Greens

We each got something different so we could try everything.

You get three bacon wrapped oysters. The oysters are cooked. It was the best thing I had the entire time I was there.

The clam chowder in my opinion was eh. The Ahi Tuna Melt was pretty good and a way better choice than the shrimp thing. The shrimp wasn't good but the salad was but definitely not worth it. I believe the shrimp gave me a stomach-ache. 

The Angels on Horseback was soooo good we ordered another one. It came with four straight out from the oven. Delicious!

Their aesthetics is very different from other restaurants. I liked it. They use brown jars to hold water and they leave it on your table. We never had to pour our own water even though the jar was there. Good service.

Overall it was a good experience but I would probably only come back here for the Angels on Horseback.
author: Sarah C.

description: I have been here four times now. The food is exceptionally excellent and has been very consistent. SO i really don't have anything bad to say about their food. Their service is pretty excellent as well, except the last time I was there and busers was trying to rush everything and my date hasn't even finished his oysters and they were taking his plate away. He wasn't happy but it was super busy that night so I can understand things can get crazy. But overall I am a big fan of this place!
author: Kevin W.

description: No idea why this venue is rated so high: came here after online booking for a lunch, was seated and ignored by waiters afterwards about 10 minutes. Had no choice but to leave it and enjoy a lunch at a restaurant nearby (Rickenbacker's). Seafood menu and beer and wine list are great though at Anchor&Hope (that's why I did not rate this place with 1 star). Finally, it's quite noisy there in the daytime period.
author: Konstantin P.

description: From the food to the atmosphere to the ambience it was all very well done.  I recommend if you're in San Francisco and in the financial district stop in and enjoy a good meal.
author: mark s.

description:
The food was delish! Decided to take a little spin here with my sister for a small dinner. We got the "Angels on Horseback" and the Spice Crusted Sea Scallops. And I love, love, LOVED the angels (aka. oysters), for not being a shellfish fan, this was awesome.

And FYI, the portions were a perfect fit for me, not too much at all, just  enough to drive your senses wild. Hahaha.
author: Catherine N.

description:
The food is pretty good- I think that we had some hits and misses tonight.
Contrary to the others, I am just not a fan of the angels on horseback (Bacon wrapped oysters). I found it rather greasy. 
The calamari was excellent and beautifully seasoned with a great sauce
The sea urchin is a must have (a recommendation from a friend)
The banana cheesecake was sooo yummy
But the highlight was the wait staff- very attentive and super friendly smiles :-)
author: Danica B.

description: This place was great! Super cute ambiance, not too loud when I went for happy hour.  The happy hour prices and selection were great, wait staff was nice! Cant beat $1 oysters! I will definitely be coming back for dinner or lunch one day as well.
author: Lily C.

description: Visiting from Houston and wanted somewhere to get some seafood late last night. Had a reservation for 10pm and was seated immediately. Drinks were good, but the mussels in white wine sauce were absolutely life changing! We even ordered a second round of them. Highly recommend!
author: Amanda H.

description:
Headed to Anchor & Hope as it was one of the few nicer restaurants in SoMA that had reservations available on a Friday night at the last minute.

We were seated about 10 minutes after our reservation time, and things just continued to be slow and delayed from there. Took forever for someone to take our order, a bit longer to get a second drink, even longer to get water refills, and when dinner finally arrived half the restaurant had already come and gone. 

Despite the plodding service, the food was tasty and the ambiance is wonderful. I really appreciate a restaurant in the city that makes use of natural lighting as much as possible - the overhead lights inside didn't actually come on until probably 9 p.m. last night! 

We had a garden salad and asparagus to start, both ok. The salad was kinda plain and the salmon prosciutto with the asparagus was SUPER salty. My date had the white fish special for dinner, and I had the halibut. Both fish meals were really big portions! 

As other reviewers have noted, this is a beer and wine only place, but the selection is pretty good. I also appreciated that they had cupcakes to go for dessert, which I took advantage of given we were full. I think I'd head back to Anchor & Hope for their Happy Hour specials or for a nicer after-work drink place, probably not for dinner. Yay! I'm a fan.
author: Sally R.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Friday wanting one thing: lobster roll. $24.. and very disappointing. I'm not sure if lobster rolls are supposed to be served like a cold salad on a bun? I believe this should be called "Lobster Salad Roll" and NOT Lobster Roll. As it is, it had small pieces of lobster that does not in my mind justify the $24 price. 

Other than that it's an ok place. Make reservations if you go at lunch. Probably won't be back.
author: Vol T.

description:
Mussels. Mussels. Mussels. 

Seriously though, if you love seafood and you want a trendy, pretty sophisticated ambiance - this place is a gem. Service is always above par. Seafood ceviche is great too, if you can tolerate the heat from the jalapeno.

Great beer selection, too. I recommend trois pistoles unibroue.
author: Beeta O.

description:
I came back here yesterday for Happy Hour and a friend's bday.  Given their very limited happy hour menu and their happy hour time, (ends at 6:30pm WTF?), I still had a better time than the last.

We ordered some fries (yum), a dozen oysters (even more yum),  fish tacos (more yumz), and a couple of drinks.  We were sitting at the bar and the one bartender was doing a great job running around helping everyone.

Happy hour bill came up to about $60 for two people, including tip.  There's nothing happy about that...
author: Rosalind S.

description:
I was taken here for business lunch with my colleagues. Right away, I was very impressed by the large, open, and airy atmosphere. The service was very great and attentive. Meal also comes with complimentary house-made seasoned potato chips.

Since they are a seafood restaurant, I order the cioppino - an SF seafood staple. The seafood was very fresh and tasty and the broth was savory and flavorful. Also, comes with toasted bread for you to dip and eat. One compliant is that there is not enough broth since I like to drink the soup.

I learned that you can request black cloth napkins so the napkins won't leave white lint on your black pants.
author: Joanna L.

description: Went with my wife after all day in the Fancy Food Show, Had a great dinner of Beautiful Raw Oysters, Grilled Sardine and Angels on Horseback followed by Flounder Fish & Chips and Lobster Roll. The only thing better than the food was the service. Our server Josh made it a very special dinner offering advise on wine, beer and oyster choices. It was extremely busy but you would never know it by the attention to detail by our server Josh.
author: Mike P.

description:
I made a reservation here at 6:15 the day after Valentine. Due to the streets being closed off at Mission, we called the restaurant and inform the host that we will be a bit late in which the hostess told us that they will hold it for us until 6:30. When we arrived at 6:25, the hostess told us that they will be seating us a tiny table in the corner in which my wife objects to it since we have our 9 year old son with us and it would be quite discomfort for our family. After that, we noticed the 2 hostess exchanged glares with each other in a non friendly tones. One of them took us to another table and she just left the menus on the table without even give us the proper intro. Granted, we realized that the restaurant might be busy and that they might have better things to do than making us feel welcome, but for the prices that we about to spend on this special occasion, I feel the service is even less than a fast food chain. My wife was really unhappy and she wants to leave but I convinced her to at least stay and try the food since I heard great recommendation about this.
I was right, our server was amazing and he made us feel a lot better by recommending the right wine for the our food. We ordered the large seafood plateaux, the angel on horseback, clamchowder for our little one as appetizers. For entrees, we had the steak and the scallops along with white wines. The food was amazing as the plateaux was definitely the best i've had. The steak was tasty and the scallops was perfect. Overall, the food was definitely on point and what I was expected coming here.
