However, the hostess's service was very poor and I don't think I will coming back here again no matter how great the food is. I will tell everyone I know that if you want great food, this would be the spot, but the service definitely does not justify the $300 we spent on dinner. (again our server was excellent, but I just can't get over the treatment we received from the hostess in the beginning)
author: Dooee N.

description: Had some Ahi which should have been more rare, the other food I had was not up to snuff considering the price. They do have an excellent beer list, which gives them 2 stars versus 1 star.
author: Jonah K.

description: Love this place! Beer and oysters selection is always good! Very delicious appetizers, 'Angels on a horseback' is must try thing!
author: Igor S.

description:
YUM YUM YUM. I love seafood, and if you are a seafood lover, you'll LOVE this restaurant. You would normally not be able to find this place if you walked past the area. I never noticed it, until I actually had to look for it. 

Anyway, came here with a colleague. I ordered the fish and chips, but prior to that, they serve the most awesomest bread ever. It's delicious--reminds me of Acme bread. Quality free bread--that's the best.

Anyway, on to the fish and chips. So when you order, you actually get around 3 pieces of fried fish and a lot of fries. Nonetheless, you somehow get full. There are enough fries that you'll have leftovers, unless you're like me and you like (and are actually capable of) eating everything on the plate to the point that it makes it easier for the busser to clean your plates ;) ... In that case, you may have an eating disorder. JK. The crispy fried fish was perfect, though. The fish inside was tender and flaky, as well as flavorful. Loved it!

I hope to try the lobster roll that I hear so much about. Actually, I'd like to try a lot of their menu items, so I'm hoping to go a couple times more. I also love the setting and atmosphere of the restaurant. It makes you think that you're in a fishing type of warehouse by the pier, or something like that. The place gets crowded, so I suggest making reservations.
author: Vera W.

description:
Delicious but expensive!

Calamari was amazing. Crab sandwich was really good (lemon aioli was a bit strong on the lemony side for my taste, but still amazing). 

Satsuma Mandarin Tea Cake for dessert and espresso - amazing.

Lunch bill for 2 came in over $100 - wowza! Great atmosphere too, though.

4.5 stars!
author: Rebecca L.

description:
"Small and unnoticeable in the alley turning into one awesome fancy restaurant" seems to be my style these days....

I can't believe I didn't discover this place since I pass by here all the time until now (but i'm so glad i did!!)

The decor is really cute...very spacious and interesting...serving water in brown glass bottles and hanging ropes in the ceiling....you feel like you're in a fish market!

Angels on horseback (bacon-wrapped oysters) is its signature and #48 on Big Eat SF list. It was delicious (how could it not with bacon?) but little disappointing as the oyster was way too tiny hidden inside, though you can still taste its fresh sweet taste. 

What impressed me more was the warm sea urchin and dungeness crab appetizer. *if you have never tried sea urchin before, this is a great place to start* trust me because i am an uni expert (japanese for sea urchin) i can tell its freshness without tasting just by looking at its color...and what A&H served was definitely Grade A. It went so well with the dungeness crab underneath and the cream sauce complemented the seafood without having an overpowering taste. 

*One more disappointment that dropped one more star was the bread. Coming with a brown paper bag...i was expecting it to be fresh and warm to fill my stomach when i sat down. Sadly, it was not :( 

Still, as a seafood fan, i should be back to taste other dishes (and those tempting desserts) in the future!
author: Shirley H.

description:
Anchor & Hope is a good place to go for a quick business lunch.  Simple seafood sandwiches and entrees, nothing too fancy.  The food is fresh and tasty, but lack in presentation.  I am really big on how the food is presented so didn't really get the "Wow" factor on presentation.  The restaurant is nicely decorated in a nautical theme with a nice spacious bar. 

OVERALL EXPERIENCE:  Good food, good service and a nice comfy atmosphere.
author: Miriam O.

description:
Great Place, good vibe, I like the basic garage-esque decor

I thought the portions were well sized and the fish selection was good.  The dishes were not to crazy in regards to flavors, and that is the way I prefer my seafood.  I like to taste the fish.  I had the CA Rock Cod - it was simple and firm.   

The beer and wine selection is very good and reasonably priced

the service was a little on the average scale, could have been warmer
author: Thomas G.

description: Solid 4 star restaurant. Definitely not cheap but the quality of food is very good.  I usually don't order mussels but since this is mainly a seafood restaurant I wanted something with fries.  They were delicious.  The Lobster roll was just ok. It needs more salt and a bigger portion.  Fat people eat a lot.  I would go back and sit at the bar.
author: Fatty A.

description:
SF is a frequently traveled destination for business and I would regularly find myself at Anchor and Hope - at the bar solo for dinner or with colleagues for lunch. 

What makes it a SF-South of Market go-to for me are the Oysters (nice selection, rotating), the Calamari and the Berkeley Trumer Pilsner on tap, which I first discovered here. Calamari is often a heavy appetizer filler, but here it is something special - mouth-watering Salt and Pepper Calamari with a Thai Chili Dipping Sauce. Mmmmm lip smacking with the right amount of spice. One of those dishes you will not want to split on your next visit! 

I've also had some great dinner specials - but the above are the highlights for me. 

I love the atmosphere - the high ceilings with lots of light - is lovely during the day, and the bartenders / wait service were always welcoming for a solo evening dining at the bar.
author: Kelly H.

description:
Whoever decor-ed this place needs some kind of medal. They nailed the balance between ship's hold, fishing wharf and restaurant. And that's not an easy mix to perfect (as anyone who's tried to apply that sort of interior styling to their bedroom knows full well. What an abortion that project was). 

The seafood is par excellence, but you'll pay a pretty penny for your pescado predilections. So many different oysters to choose from was a delight, somewhat sullied by one bad oyster that sort of ruined the batch for us. 

They're signature appetizer is the Angels on Horseback, a slightly confusing misnomer for oysters wrapped in bacon that were the definite highlight of the meal. 

Our first waiter was righteous and attentive; after a shift change though his replacement went missing, leaving us with a vacuum where previously we felt the love.
author: Benjamin B.

description: I suggest making a reservation if you're planning on having lunch because the entire resto is filled with suits at lunch. Great spacious dining with your typical SF rustic, warehouse type décor. Service is quick, friendly and efficient. They give you chips to start, I ordered the $25 lobster roll which is on the pricy side but expected in the financial district, good buttery bun, lobster was well seasoned and their tatter tots were really good, crunchy on the outside and soft of the inside. Yuuuummm. I didn't try anything else but the lobster was two thumbs up for me!
author: Ennie L.

description: Crowded, but lucked out. The hostess allowed me to take a reserved table if I could be done in an hour. I was just looking to eat and go. I came based on the online menu on yelp looking forward to trying a specific dish, only to discovered it was no longer on their current menu. My entire reason for seeking out this restaurant evaporated. I was pretty hungry, so I decide to stay. I chose the pacific cod with manila clams in a clam broth. The broth flavor was pretty bland along with the cod which was tasteless. The cod was a bit rubbery. The bread crumb crust was nice. Good texture and flavor. The clams were large and meaty, unfortunately very undercooked. It tasted raw. I'm not a fan of raw shell fish. The raw flavor made me gag. I paid $32 for the entree which included tax.
author: Marshall C.

description:
Lunch here on a Tuesday.  The restaurant is loud and packed.  A good place for a social lunch, but don't expect to get business done!

We had the ceviche appetizer.  Great flavor as long as you like jalapeño!    For my entree, I had the coconut stew which had a good amount of mussels, shrimp and calamari.  The mussels and shrimp were cooked perfectly.  The calamari was a but more rubbery than it should have been.  The coconut broth with fennel was sublime ... Just enough spice to be interesting but not overwhelming.

I would come back for the mussels all by themselves!
author: Debby C.

description: I'm not used to seafood being buttery, but at Anchor & Hope I'm fairly certain they have a butter fairy in the back, using butter magic to butter up all the butterables.  By this I mean that my lobster roll was soft and sweet, while my friend's batch of mussels were brothed to savory perfection.  Fishy fish is a big no-no for me, and Anchor & Hope will give you hope that there are still dynamite seafood places out there (Or at the very least, convince you to buy your own butter fairy).
author: Michael D.

description: A fun place. But not much vegetarian food. A fantastic corn soup. Dinner on 08 August.
author: Philip S.

description: Best oysters South of Market.  Also a big fan of the beer selection.  Service is consistently top notch, as well.
author: Michael G.

description: We ordered white corn soup (good, kinda different), oysters (can't go wrong), warm sea urchin (disappointing, sour soup base which is lemon beurre blanc with sea urchin and crab meat, to me, it didn't really go together well. Maybe I'm too used to having sea urchin in sushi, this one just didn't do it....) and lobster remoulade (it could be better, if it's colder) good ambiance!!! Cute place!!
author: Christina T.

description: The roasted tomato & poblano soup was just the right combination of sweet & smoky. Great beer & wine selection. An overall delicious, casual dining experience.
author: Lawrence G.

description:
Came here with work pals in search of some legit SF seafood, and Anchor & Hope delivered.  We'd heard it'd been featured on the food network for the bacon-wrapped oysters - which is a good enough start to get me in the door.

We started with that very dish, in addition to some west coasters served in the original style with shallots and cocktail sauce, as well as some legit black pepper calamari.  I definitely preferred the original chilled oysters to the bacon-wrapped variety, but that might be a personal preference as the rest of the table was pretty enamored with them. Calamari was a hit as well - instead of being served with a mayo-based sauce or tartar, they came with a spicy asian dressing.  

For entrees, I was immediately attracted to the cioppino because it featured so many different types of fish - crab, mussels, clams, and bass in a fiery red sauce.   It was substantial and tasty.  

As an FYI, they don't serve liquor.  Only beer and wine - but they have a pretty extensive list of both. It's hidden on a side street, so it's slightly hard to find.  The space itself is like an old warehouse, with chains and funky things hanging from the ceiling, but they manage to make it very romantic. 

A great place to take clients, family, or friends who love wine & seafood.
author: Emily R.

description: Casual seafood place in SOMA.  Not cheap but not baller expensive.  The seafood selection is solid, raw bar selection is great and the lobster roll was tasty.  Beer selection is legit.  It's close to my work, so I'll definitely be back.  Great place for a date or a dinner with your out of town friend.  It's nice enough to be worthwhile, but not so expensive that you seem like you're just showing off.
author: Arthur Y.

description:
5 stars for their Happy Hour.

A glass of stout and 6 fresh and sweet oysters for $11? How can you not appreciate this place?

It's on Minna street, and get there early for the happy hour. 

Their french fries taste very similar to In-n-Out fries, except they're bigger, and the malt vinegar-mayo dipping is fabulous.

I don't know about you, but I'd go back here in a heart beat. 2 orders of the oysters and stout combo and an order of fries for me.
author: S Y.

description:
Absolutely loved everything about this place. The service was wonderful, the food was amazing, the beer selection was vast and not typical, and the ambiance was spacious and relaxing. Quality of the food made me happy and the portions made my husband happy. We will definitely be back. Highlights were the sea urchin appetizer and the banana creme pie. We loved it so much that I can't wait to try their other two locations, Salt House and Town Hall. 

P.S. Not sure why there are so many reviews that say the service was bad. Our server was AMAZING. Always knew the exact right moment to swing by and check on us. Gave us great recommendations. Was an overall charming sweetheart. The hostess was also super friendly and the food runners and bus staff were smiling and polite.
author: Stomparella J.

description:
Good: Ambience.
Okay: Food.
Management: Terrible.

We went to Anchor and Hope for a friend's birthday dinner.  The restaurant is airy, big, and generally pretty sexy.  The food was expensive-ish ($25 entrees) and not bad (particularly the free potato chips at the beginning of the meal), but our night was ruined by the restaurant's terrible hygeine and even worse management.  To summarize:

(1) My husband found two short black hairs in our raw seafood appetizer.  He brought it up with our server, who then walked away (presumably to consult with his manager).  The server came back and apologized, saying that the restaurant would comp. the appetizer--which was an appropriate response for a well-managed restaurant, we thought at the time.  But, 30 minutes later, AFTER our appetizers had been taken away and our entrees served, our server came back bearing a small plate with 6 shrimp on it.  He leaned in and said that the restaurant was giving us this tiny plate of shrimp INSTEAD of comping the hair-laden appetizer.  We said that we didn't want the shrimp, since it was the shellfish that had the hygeine issue in the first place, and we were already eating our entrees...He then took it away without a word.

(2) The server also brought us the wrong bottle of wine, which neither he nor we noticed until after he had poured the glasses.  The server later came back and said that he accidentally poured a more expensive bottle, but that since we were ordering another bottle of wine, he would just charge us $100 for both bottles.    We thought this was a weird response, but accepted it.

When the bill came, not only were we charged $120 for the wine, but we were charged $55 for the appetizer!  When my husband brought this up with the manager, the manager basically said (1) that the server didn't have the authority to comp. our appetizer, so he didn't want to take it off the bill, and (2) more alarmingly, it was the guests' responsibility to make sure that the right wine was poured!  This is an incredibly shady practice because, under that reasoning, if I order a $70 Malbec, and the server pours a $2000 wine instead, I owe the restaurant $2000 for the restaurant's bait-and-switch.

In the end, the manager relented and took $75 off of our $500+ bill, but the unprofessional way he handled the whole exchange left a bad taste in our mouths.   We will never be going back.
author: Thomas W.

description:
We didn't know how much their largest seafood tower would cost us - it ended up being just shy of $150 - but it was an extravagant feast befitting any price tag. They are not afraid to serve you a healthy dose of raw clams and their prawns were about as good as prawns get. The quality of the lobster let me know they were serious. And some less common components - like pickled mussels and a ceviche that tasted nothing like ceviche - made it more interesting than the usual fresh seafood indulgence. We ordered one side, brussel sprouts, and they were the best I've ever had. 

The beer menu was acceptable, but don't be fooled by their cocktail menu as this establishment does not have a hard liquor license. What kind of backwards city do we live in where check-cashing scammers can stay in business but an outstanding restaurant in a quiet part of SOMA can't serve booze? 

The staff was outstanding and the decor fully appealed to me. I look forward to going again. They also have a happy hour. Five stars.
author: Phil D.

description:
Had dinner with old friends, 8/17/2012 @ 6:30 pm. They are former neighbors and close friends from here in Florida, that transferred to SF.

We weren't impressed.  It was average, at best.  The service was rushed, to the point of hurrying us, like they needed the table turned quickly, yet the main course took way too long to arrive.

The wine is expensive, and the overall "feel" of the restaurant was vibrant on first impression, and soon became annoying, as it is loud. Lots of hard surfaces in the decor make for loud background noise.  Difficult to have a conversation across the table.

Food:  Had rockfish, small portion, light sauce, and that's about it.  My son ordered the lobster roll - I tried it....bread was good, lobster was good...but served with the same "free chips" as were already on the table....Really?  My friends ordered the same things. One lobster roll, one rockfish, their impression was the same.

We're from Florida, I own a fishing boat........ on the menu.....Gulf Shrimp!  Expensive!

Overall we had a nice time with our friends, but we will not return.  I do not think my local friends will return.

With so many great restaurants why go here?  Someone noted that this place has over 900 reviews...strange that it's still busy as it is...maybe I missed something? I don't think so.....
author: Ken K.

description:
What I Ate
- California king salmon

Would I Go Again?
Yes, I would give it another shot.  I didn't really like for my salmon dish.  I thought the salmon was well prepared, but I just didn't care for the flavors in the dish.  I think, however, that my problem was that I simply chose a dish I didn't particularly like, rather than the food being of poor quality or not being prepared properly.  I am going to give Anchor & Hope the benefit of the doubt.  I have since heard that the "angels on horseback" are fantastic, so I am willing to go back to give those "smoked bacon-wrapped oysters" a try.
author: Ben M.

description:
We went here on the suggestion of a guy we met at a conference, and I have to say he did a great job recommending this place.

It's in what I remember to be a back alley, which was kind of cool, and it is a little dark, but the food was great (I had branzino for the first time and they did a fantastic job).

I don't know what else to say, other than this place was enjoyable, a little pricey but for the location, decor, and level of food quality, I say it's worth it.
author: Danielle S.

description:
Cute, casual place in SOMA to satisfy your beer & seafood craving. 

A & H wasn't my first choice, but after a gas leak last week closed my fave seafood restaurant Farallon, we had to quickly go to plan B. A & H serves oysters & seafood...sold! 

We started with a dozen oysters, 6 west cost & 6 east coast. I can never remember which oysters I prefer after I eat them, but I do know that they were all fresh & delicious. Maybe next time I will actually write down the names so I can order them again! 

I was very impressed with their beer list. It was as extensive as some wine lists. I tried the local Linden Street Black Lager, which was a slightly lighter version of a stout. This was probably a bad idea seeing that I had a lot of food coming & stouts are very filling, but it tasted great. Hubby tried a Japanese hefeweizen. Yeah, who knew, right? It was light & refreshing. I liked how they brought the matching glass for each beer. Classy touch. 

As an appetizer I ordered the very creamy, chunky clam chowder. Hubby ordered the calamari. I usually skip over fried calamari as an app cuz it is usually rubbery, greasy, & tasteless. These were lightly fried & came with the most amazing dipping sauce. Hubby was all over it. In fact he almost canceled his main dish just to get another order of calamari. The dipping sauce was a strange combination of fish sauce, lime juice, & thai chilies. But somehow it worked & was a great compliment to the calamari. 

My main dish was the sea bass which was perfectly cooked (of course) & delicious. Hubby got a pile of mussels which was almost more than he could eat. They definitely don't skimp on portions here. 

My only complaint is that some of the tables are realllly close together. When you have guys with booming voices on either side of you, it's kind of hard to concentrate on your own conversation. Whether we liked it or not, we got roped in to conversations with 2 different neighbors. This is a casual place, right? 

I'm glad they spared this place when they tore down all the surrounding buildings to make way for the new Transbay Terminal.
author: Erin S.

description:
We returned on a Tuesday night to Anchor & Hope  - this time, the place was busy and full - we were offered bar seats first over tables.

I had just had some dental work done in the afternoon. My lower left jaw was numb and I had been instructed to eat only soft foods.  The warm uni with dungeness crab, lemon beurre and mashed potatoes seemed a much better alternative than cream of white or jamba juice.

And it was - appearing this time in a large cup rather than its signature spiky uni shell (perhaps not quite the season for  local fresh uni), the dish was as decadently delicious as I had remembered.  I have to admit that it was a tad salty, but the perfect texture for a gal who could only chew on one side of her mouth.

The husband ordered spice-crusted Scallops with fantastic israeli couscous and sauteed mustard greens - a dish that was better balanced in flavours. 

The lobster roll with house potato chips was not a good as I had recalled- the lobster bits seemed like a conglomeration of leftover bits and pieces - the 2nd-string components which did not quite make the premium cut.  The dressing also was less rich and luscious as I had previously remembered.

All in all, still a good restaurant, and I'd return again and sit at the bar (which carries an amazing selection of beers - notably - several sour beers, my current obsession).
author: Claudine C.

description:
Ate here twice in August.  First time, just some appetizers and a bowl of chowder.  Everything excellent.  Second time around, for dinner.  Started with some Kumamoto oysters, prepared and presented to perfection.  Had the whole branzino which was absolutely killer.

Over a couple nights, just absolutely on the mark experience for me all around.  Sat at the bar the first night and at a table the second time.  Excellent service both times.

Worthy of 5 stars from my perspective.
author: Michael F.

description:
If you are looking for a quiet place to have a great glass of wine or an artisan beer with your seafood, this is the place for you. 

5 stars for atmosphere. Even at 7:30 pm on a Sunday, this place was busy but not hectic. The staff was very knowledgeable and  eager to please.

3 stars for menu. This is not based on quality but on quantity. I ordered the lobster roll which was probably a poor choice for dinner and didn't quite hit the stop but I was determined to have my lobster, dang it! The menu was limited to about 5 entrees and I wasn't drawn to anything so I made a quick choice when the server came for our order. My boyfriend ordered the clam linguine and cleared his plate. We both had the clam chowder as an appetizer (when in San Francisco, right?) and it was delicious. In hindsight, I should have stuck to the chowder and maybe a side salad instead of the lobster roll but oh well! 

All in all, we had a nice meal but it wasn't cheap. What it lacked in choices on the menu, it made up for in ambiance.
author: Maura H.

description: My boyfriend and I went here on our vacation to California. We wanted to go to a good seafood restaurant that was not the typical Fisherman's Warf, (I don't eat meat only seafood) It turned out to be a great choice, I ordered two appetizers for myself because I love both Ceviche  and Calamari and wanted them both. They were delicious and had a not-so-typical taste. The wine menu looked great but we were just in Napa and brought our own wine. The ambiance and service were superb as well. Highly suggest!
author: Rachael C.

description: Ate here for the first time today. Cannot wait to go back. Went with a group of 8 and service was excellent. Ginger beer got raves. Tomato and watermelon salad, ceviche and calamari were perfect. My lobster roll was excellent. Tomato soup was creamy. Fish tacos looked good. Pasta primavera had huge shrimp and chicken sandwich was huge.
author: Graciela C.

description: In SF for work and looked for a place near the W Hotel for good seafood and a casual atmosphere. This place was great. We had a dozen oysters which were yummy they had 3 different west and 3 different east coast oysters. Then we had the clam chowder which was not too heavy, very yummy. Last we split the lobster roll and it was as good as a lobser roll from Maine. This place is worth a try.
author: Vanessa B.

description: Overall this place is decent, but for the price I shouldn't find grit in the clams and the shrimp should be deveined better.
author: John C.

description:
Based on its beer list alone Anchor & Hope is a great place. They have a nice bar with people who know what they're talking about when it comes to beer and wine. After work sometimes I'll just cruise down there and have a nice barleywine or porter.

But the food is probably what everyone really wants to know about. It's good stuff. The sea urchin is great, their clams are solid and they do good cooked fish as well. It's definitely not cheap, and it may not rock your world but it's definitely a good place to check out.
author: Paul C.

description: Came to anchor and hope on a Monday night with a party of six, and we all left very satisfied and absolutely in love with this place. The Lobster Bisque I ordered was delicious and my date had some oysters which I'm normally not a fan of but on the particular night I thoroughly enjoyed it. The service was excellent and our waiter was very knowledgable about pairing our wines with our meals accordingly. I'm a typical female so of course the first thing I noticed was the decor, it had a rustic nautical ambience that fit perfectly. I highly recommend this place for larger groups, our semi large group came on a very busy night and we still recieved superb service.
author: Angie M.

description: Wife and I had date night. Limited time. We had 8pm Reservations. Walked out at 8:30 to the restaurant across the street because they had overbooked. Weak. Not going here again.
author: George H.

description:
A partner of my company was hosting a bunch of us for dinner.  It felt kind of weird to walk into a restaurant that is one of those off-the-beaten-path but kind of well known spots with 30+ people.

Again, the service was attentive and the food was fresh.  Since this time, the menu was fixed, I can't comment on much, however, I will say that the calamari was delish.  The steak was done perfectly and so were the scallops for the most part, however a couple of bites were SUPER salty.  Not the best way to finish off the entrée portion.  I did manage to sneak away an extra chocolate cake to go, though...gotta take care of the lady since she can't join business dinners...especially if it's chocolate.  

God forbid that she find out that there was an over abundance of cake and her thoughtless boyfriend didn't think of her :p
author: Dylan T.

description:
Waited over 20 min to place order, waited another 36 min for main entrees. - lunch -

Items ordered:
DAT mussels - first place to serve mediocre mussels without fries or brioche.
Sad looking salad.

Shrimp roll - greasy .. Greasy. Don't remember the taste obviously not great.

Catfish sandwich - meh.

Overall, loooong wait, greasy and priced above average for below average food.

Not coming back.
author: Catalina C.

description:
Went here for a business dinner and enjoyed the overall experience.  The food was good but not phenomenal but the ambiance was great and the service was exceptional, so I will be recommending this place.

I got the cod and found it a please albeit somewhat forgettable dish.  The scallops appetizer I had was the same - a very good dish but not exceptional.  The wine list is good from what I saw (and drank!).

The whole experience though is very nice.  The decor is fun and even though the place was packed I didn't feel like it was too loud, noisy, or crowded. Our server was also helpful, attentive, and seemed like she actually enjoyed her job, which made a big difference.

All in all, a very good restaurant and I would probably go back if I were in the area and wasn't paying.  At the end of the day, I think Anchor & Hope could be great if it just got slightly more adventurous with the menu as everything just sort of seems plain vanilla to me.
author: Dean H.

description:
There was probably a day when Doug Washington woke up in his palatial Mediterranean villa after a long night being curled up in his Egyptian 1500 thread count sheets, rubbed his eyes, and came up with a brilliant plan...

"I'm gonna cover the interior of a warehouse in nautically themed elements, put up an oyster bar, call it an east coast seafood shack, and charge $25 for a lobster roll with a small amount of shredded meat stuffed into an oversized wonder bread-ish roll.  Also, I'm gonna take the cheapest thing on east coast menus, fish n' chips, toss some $7/six pack Smithwick's on it and charge $23...I'm brilliant!"

The problem is that none of it is very good.  The beauty of seafood shacks on the east coast is that a) the food is cheap, b) the food is appropriately tasty, and c) the food is simple.  Anchor & Hope tries to bring a fanciful level of sophistication to what should be simple food in order to justify the number at the bottom of your bill.  I'll gladly pay for freshness, but, depending on the day of your visit, you may as well be doing a yankee swap at your office.

By the way, the 600 thread count sheets at Target feel the same and cost 80% less.

My recommendation?  Go to the Old Port Lobster Shack in Redwood City to taste what Anchor & Hope's marketing tries to sell you.
author: Eric H.

description:
Came here for a company lunch.  Not really a fan of the types of seafood they serve. 

- Food - 
I guess it's fresh since the items they serve can all be found near the Bay Area.

I had a crab louie salad.  It was one of the most expensive items on the lunch menu, yet it was the smallest.  There was barely any salad/veggies.  The crab meat was about the size of a normal scoop of ice cream.  Not impressed by the proportion of the two, but again, seafood lovers may love this. 

The oysters we ordered (not sure which one) were tiny and tasted alright.  I definitely felt better eating that than the ones I had at an oyster farm.  The restaurant must've cleaned it somehow.  

- Service - 
Staff was very friendly.

- Atmosphere - 
Very upbeat and loud, but it's in the financial district so fits it very well. 

Its specific location is a bit strange because it's in a very.. not-busy alley.
author: Emily W.

description:
I have been to Anchor several times and I decided to write something today as my food was just OKAY! I took a friend for lunch who had not been there and she had looked at the menu on the website and was excited about some of the choices but when we got to the restaurant most of them were not on the menu. I understand menu's change but if everything is chanced, that needs to be updated considering the amount of staff they have (sure one person could do this!).

Appetizers: Angels on Horesback is a must appetizer

Shrimp Louis needs to be pulled from the menu. It was noting close to Shrimp Louis.

Desserts: the spin-off Snicker Bar

Service: Standard - okay

Bill: $$$ expensive for lunch
author: Saudat N.

description:
I like this place because I can come here for multiple scenarios.

It's a great place to grab a drink and a few oysters by the bar.  Why snack on gross bar food while drinking when you can get a platter of oysters to snack on?

It's a good place to eat too. Diverse menu though i think the oysters might be the best part about this place. the lobster roll that everyone seems to love was just okay in my opinion.  the rest of the food is good, but not terribly memorable truthfully.  The dessert was okay too.

The service here is pretty good, both at the bar and at the tables. Thumbs up there!
author: Sandy K.

description:
Ehhh.  

Whateva.

I met up with my sea-creature-eating friends for happy hour last Friday.  The first thing I have to mention...Happy hour lasts from 4:30 to 6pm.  Are you kidding me???  I barely have time to get over there by 6!!   Errrrrrgggg.  Good thing I'm going easy on the drinks this summer. 

You're probably thinking, "WTF, Ang...You're a vegetarian so why would you write a review about this place?"  Let me tell you why....

The space is great, industrial-esque.  Much like Salt House but larger.  With that said, I ordered the fabulous green been salad that easily deserves a 4-star rating.  And OMG, those fries:  A five-star "around the world and back" snap!  

Sadly, it all went down the toilet for me when my colseslaw arrived.  EWWW.  I asked if it was fresh and they told me yes.  But I'm convinced it was bought from Costco several days prior.  The salad was sitting in pinkish--yes I said it--pinkish milk!

The nail in the coffin came from my friends.  I naturally assumed they'd be swimming through a sea lovers dream; instead, they were equally disappointed as I.  Consensus?  The main courses were well below par.  And those prices? Waaayyyy over-the-top.

Last thing...I forgot to mention that our waiter was a dick.

Just not feelin' this place.
author: Angella S.

description:
My daughter who turned 30 the other day specified this restaurant as her selection for dinner. Boy; she hit this one spot on as very good.
Anchor is all about fish, beer and wine, no cocktails. 
We started with a roasted beat salad which we shared for $12. In retrospect it was small and we should have ordered two for the table.
Roasted beets, mizuna, watercress, pistachios, goat cheese, sherry vinaigrette
Next we had Catalan style P.E.I. mussels as an appetizer, they were fresh and delicious with a red sauce around a Spanish sausage -- great pick Lo, the mussels were a home run IMHO.
Lo ordered the Lingcod which you don't find on menus all that often. She said it was very good; but, I wasn't paying that much attention - sorry Lo. Don't bother me, I'm eating. 
Pacific ling cod, brussels sprouts, butternut squash polenta, chanterelle mushroom daube $27
Barbie and Bob had the lobster roll, wasn't real impressed, certainly not exactly a to Maine roll. The roll they serve it on was "good." Barbie said; "not too much mayo, which is a good thing."
 Anchor & Hope lobster roll, pain de mie bun, tater tots, Stevie's coleslaw $25
I had the $24 fish & chips; yes, $24 and they kicked ass. The single piece of flounder was huge and the batter crust was crisp and flavorful enough as not to overcome the taste of the fish. Actually, maybe the best F&C I've ever had. The chips - amazing taste, tartar and cocktail sauce need work, nothing special. I will say the sauces are superfluous as the flounder and crust were so good it would be an insult to mask the experience with side sauces.
Smithwick's beer battered Louisiana flounder, tartar sauce with house-cut fries
This was all accompanied with a Hafner 2009 Chard from th Alexander Valleyt, CA for $40 a bottle, actually a pretty good wine for the price and went very well with the fish.
4.5 stars if half stars were allowed on YELP.
author: Gary J.

description:
Dine about town ripoff. 

Extended review: Went there for dine about town for 2. Their menu for dine about town online is inaccurate. The lunch appetizer was a tiny salad.  The main course was either a plate of tiny potato dealies or a plate of 10 mussels. Both sucked. Wasted 45 bucks (total). Came back to work smelling like french fries. Next time I'm getting 9 five dollar footlongs at Subway.
author: Terence E.

description:
I'm generally a badass (minus the generally part) so I sometimes decide to do things like not eat any solid foods for a month because being sensible and thinking logically are two key character traits of wimps. Besides, there's nothing manlier than surviving purely off of water, whey isolate, and some questionable-looking brown powder that apparently required the harvesting (and subsequent destruction) of a 5' x 8' patch of protected Amazon rainforest.

Over the years though, I've learned that not everyone's as much of a hero as me, so when we decided to throw a welcome lunch at A&H for a new co-worker, I acquiesced and decided to have a solid meal. The fact that I was recovering from the previous night where I found myself drinking a spirit that tasted like it was fermented from a potato found in an old Commie boot of Dostoevsky's also likely contributed to this brief moment of weakness.

Given the above circumstances, you'd figure that I would have enjoyed my meal at A&H a lot more than I did (since somewhere deep down inside I do have a soul and can appreciate things like calories that don't start off in powdered form). Besides, a lobster roll is pretty manly and that's apparently this place's signature dish.

Looks like someone needs a new John Hancock. (Hahhhh good one, Leo.)

Overrated with a capital OVERRATED sums things up nicely. Basically they served me a San Francisco-neutered version of what's supposed to be a hearty East Coast comfort food. I want a real lobster roll, people. Layer on that mayo and throw in lobster chunks so large that I question whether or not that's actually lobster in there. Bonus points for throwing everything in a supermarket bun.

This description couldn't be further from what I got at Anchor & Hope. I don't remember much since I probably blacked out in a fit of rage upon seeing my lunch; what I do know is that from hazy recollections I still realized that pretentious French pastry (seriously, f those guys) and tiny little lobster chunks in a light cream sauce does not a lobster roll make.

Will not be coming back here unless someone else is paying or until they start grinding up their whole menu and serving it to me in a Big Gulp.
author: Leo K.

description: fantastic happy hour.  one of the only places in the city that i will always trust their $1 oyster happy hour deals.  plus, they have a ridiculously super tasty crispy shrimp appetizer which is worth a trip alone.
author: Helpful S.

description:
If you love seafood, then Anchor & Hope is THE place to go.  Hidden in the middle of Minna alley, it may be hard to find if you're not familiar with the area.  Just ask my friend who met me for lunch.

The waitress is all too knowledgeable about the draft beer and helped us decide on two.  Mine came in a test tube looking glass, that needed an anchor to hold up because it couldn't stand on its own.  Cute detail.

I ordered the halibut again, and KT ordered the crab louie.  They were both fantastic, fabulous and fresh.

Obviously we left room for dessert.  But KT there was watching his girlish figure, so I had to devour most of it.  Way to start a food coma.

Next time: angels on horseback.  Bacon wrapped oysters, really?!
author: Jenny L.

description:
Underwhelming--you know, when you are told that something is a signature dish, automatically I will have high expectations. I had the lobster roll, which was okay. It was practically stuffed in one thick slide of toast that had been drenched in butter--I think they should rethink this whole bread idea, because it 1) made the roll tiny, and 2) did not add enough texture because the lobster was textureless as well.

All in all, flavors were decent but not up to par with the price / hype. Granted, the theme is very interesting and an extensive wine list.
author: Chrissy H.

description: Really good seafood here, and the fried chicken sando is amazing as well.
author: Mark P.

description:
The dining area is very nice and comfortable and although I like dim lighting this was maybe too dark.  I noticed I wasn't the only one who used his iPhone flashlight to read the menu.  I had the Mahi-mahi with baked yams.  Nice presentation but it lacked flavor.  My wife had a small Plateau and same thing,  Looked nice but was on the bland side.  I felt the menu was very pricy for what you get.

Parking for this place is on the street or valet.  It took me almost 30 minutes riding around to find a spot after 7PM on a Saturday.  Very frustrating.
author: Sam H.

description: This place is a hidden gem. I've been here for lunch and happy hour. Service is grand. My coworkers are huge fans of the $1 oysters during HH. I'm not much of a seafood person but their fries are really good!
author: Jasleen K.

description: We made reservations for a work lunch since we were on a time constraint, but it looked like they overbooked for the lunch rush.  From the hostess to the server, service was not that great.  There was no sense of apathy from the hostess, and our server probably only said two sentences to us (at least he was smiling).  However, the food was good.  I had the pork loin sandwich which was delicious, but I probably won't go back since the service really downplayed the experience.
author: Joanne F.

description:
Awesome beer and drinks selection.

Great place for seafood, though not sure how experienced their chefs are.

I ordered a clam pasta and the whole dish was just contaminated with sand. The response i got was basically : you can only clean it so well. Well, anyone who knows clams knows you have to soak it in water and wait for it to spit out the sand before you actually cook it.

The flavors were great, and the atmosphere was stellar - just dont get the clam pasta ;)
author: Ryan C.

description:
This place has grown too big for its britches.  

I loved my first visit to this place about sixth months ago.  The lobster roll was overflowing, the fries were to die for, and the old bay chips were tasty.  I did have a problem with a $150 lunch for two, which included 2 glasses of wine each, but was okay for the special occasion.

The second time I went back - all hell broke loose.  The lobster roll - which is $25 by the way - was so skimpy.  The waiter apologized and said that they had their 2 year anniversary the night before and they had run out of lobster, so he took it off the bill.   But I was a bit skeptical.

Last night, bad got worse.  I went back and was served an even tinier lobster roll.  It was the smallest lobster roll I had ever seen.  The roll was ginormous compared to the little scoop of lobster meat inside it.   I told the waitress what had happened last time and she admitted it looked dinky.  So she brought it back to the kitchen.  The same roll returned 2 minutes later with just a few chips added to top.  I was told that the chef had given me 3 ounces of lobster meat the first time and that was all I was getting.  20 minutes later, with each staff member just looking at me sitting there pissed off and not touching my food, I finally got the attention of the waitress again and sent it back to the kitchen for the last time.  

The manager finally came over and tried to offer me a normal-sized lobster roll, but the chef had been watching me not eating for the past 20 minutes and I felt like I was on a Seinfeld episode.  

So I got up after a wasted hour and left, starving, and went to Salt House.  I told them about my experience and they treated me like royalty.

I think Anchor and Hope has become too busy, too big for its own good.  The food is overpriced and they don't have enough servers to help.  It has underwhelmed me on two occasions, and at the prices they charge, its not worth it - especially in a city with so many beautiful places to dine.
author: Scott H.

description: I thought this place was awesome. Whether with a date, with friends, or even alone at the bar, you're gonna have a good meal in great atmosphere. Solid local crowd. Crudos, Brussels sprouts, and seafood in general was great. I think Yelp rating average is not fair for this place - it's a solid 4-5 star in my book.
author: Rick R.

description:
Had a fabulous lunch here. Appetizers were tasty (delicious calamari especially), and the fish& chips were on point.

Loved the atmosphere!
author: K. D.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Wednesday with 12:30pm reservations for 3.  We arrived and told that we had to wait another 10 minutes, but when we expressed our disappointment, they immediately sat us at an open table, which happened to be the very first table upon walking in.  On occasion that table got chilly if the front door was left open, but each time an employee would close it to make sure I didn't get too cold.  The interior is extremely airy, filled with light (huge windows and skylights), and decorated with a nautical feel.  The space is larger than it looks from the outside, and it's not too cramped while sitting inside.  Tables can be moved around to accommodate people dining alone to larger groups of 6.  

Water is left on your table in dark tinted bottles that look like they were found at the bottom of the ocean after many years.  I liked it.  Also, the bread is served in brown paper bags....the bread is in full length rolls that you need to break apart.  The bread is good and I found myself munching on it throughout the entire meal.  

Appetizers: 1) Wild Arugula Salad with picked fennel, roasted olives, grana padano (cheese), and lemon vinaigrette. 2) Seared scallops with mustard greens, kohlrabi, and apple miso broth.  Both were really well seasoned 

Entrees: 1) Almond Crusted Shetland Salmon with Israeli Cous Couse, Asparagus preserved lemon, endive, and Citrus Butter.  The salmon was not very flavorful but it was well cooked.  I found myself needing to dip it into the Citrus Butter and mix each bite with the cous cous to give the fish flavor.  This dish was 3 stars.  

2) Brie Burger.  I didn't try this but I was told it's good.  Comes with sauteed sweet onions, smoked bacon, and mushrooms.  Also has rosemary & thyme fries on the side.  However, I have been told that the burger at Spruce is WAY better (review to come).   

 3) Lobster Roll on a Brioche Bun with kettle chips.  The lobster roll looks small when you get it because the lobster stuffing appears to be sitting on top of the toasted bun (which looks like 2 huge pieces of toast).  However, the lobster stuffing is literally stuffed inside of the bun  like a hot pocket and just spills over the top.  The stuffing is very light, well seasoned, and not too heavy of a lobster flavor (yet you can taste the lobster).  

Dessert: Dark chocolate mousse with salted caramel popcorn.  2) Strawberry sorbet with shortbread.  Both were really delicious!  The strawberry sorbet was super fresh and tasted like I was eating a frozen sweet strawberry that had just been mashed up.  

Service was attentive and professional for it being so busy during the lunch hour.  There were many people to seat and serve, and yet our glasses were constantly filled to the brim with our beverages and the food was served promptly.
author: Naomi P.

description:
Rustic, fun atmosphere with good food!

Bacon wrapped oysters are delicious! Recommended as one of 100 things to try on 7x7 SF! - http://www.7x7.com/eat-drink/2010-big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die
author: Eunice M.

description: Disappointed that the Catfish with Fried Green Tomatoes Sandwich was kicked to the curb but the Shrimp and Fried Oyster Po' Boy more than made up for it, another winner from Head Chef Vernon. Fresh and tasty! The Lobster roll is another classic not to be missed...
author: Odlaw P.

description:
Had few oysters, clam chowda' and lobster roll

SO GOOD!

Great Atmosphere and very friendly staff!
author: Amar S.

description:
I've eaten here a number of times since I moved into a new office less than 100 yards away and am finally writing a review just to say:

Get their traditional lobster roll. I don't know why I never ordered their signature dish before, but I was not disappointed at all. The brioche bun it's on is tasty, too. We also started with the calamari, which was simple, but actually one of the tastiest I've had in a while.

Service was also great - we had a very enthusiastic waiter who had some great tips for us.

Cheers
author: Shahrzad K.

description:
Cool warehousey atmosphere - big open room with exposed wood beams overhead, and a few bits of fun nautical stuff spread around - maps, fresnel lamps, etc.  Plus, there's a giant mural of progressively bigger fish preparing to chomp on the next smaller fish behind the bar which is amusing.

The beer list is ginormous - something like 15 taps and probably 50 different beers, and there's a solid wine list as well, with plenty of reasonably priced options both by the glass and bottle.

The focus is clearly seafood.  The appetizers list, comprising perhaps 10 different options, had 2 which weren't seafood.  And only 2 of the entrees weren't seafood as well (yes, one of them is steak).

They focus on sustainability, which is fantastic - for example, they knew not just where my wild king salmon came from (Oregon), but also that it was line-caught.

The warm sea urchin and dungeness crab appetizer was spectacularly ridiculous - it was almost more like a chowder with a rich, buttery sauce and huge chunks of crab meat (including a whole claw) and giant pads of uni.  Really fantastic.
The Thai-sauce ceviche was interesting, and the shellfish was clearly all very fresh, but the sauce really was overpowering at first - it did dissipate as you chewed, giving way to the flavor of the seafood, but even so it seemed too strong.  I'd recommend they put less of it on the plate.

The King Salmon was fabulous - perfectly medium-rare, and the crisp, fresh, buttery veggies beneath it were wonderful.

The Lobster Roll is served inside a large piece of toasted bread, which is really nifty, but the lobster itself is more like a tuna salad, except with lobster instead of tuna.  There was a lot of celery, and its flavor threatened to overwhelm that of the lobster.

The rhubarb, aniseed meringue and almond ice cream dessert was excellent, and the 3 flavors enhanced each other in ways I'd never have guessed; this was great!

I also really recommend the Vermont Ice Cider, which was truly unique - imagine an ice wine made with apples instead of grapes.  Fascinating.

It may not be cheap, but seriously good seafood never is.  And it's worth it.  We'll be back.
author: Don H.

description: Really good business casual place. Great service,  food, and beer! Been here a dozen times and the consistency in the quality of food and service is one of the tops in the City.
author: Ramil I.

description:
I have something nice to say. The beer selection is outstanding. I had the De Glazen Toren jan de liche, a Belge that was delicious.
 
We had the bass with risotto which was BLAH. There was literally no flavor to this dish and the risotto was mushy. The 28 dollar lobster roll was overloaded with fennel which masked the delicate essence of the lobster. 

The kitchen was in view and they were busy. One fellow looked comfortable over the hot oven; every move purposeful and timed. But the other fellow was all arms flailing every pan too hot and he stirred the risotto like it was coming alive and needed to be whipped. The expediter did jump in to help by cooking the bass I counted eight servings and I can attest to the fact he was remiss on seasoning mine.

One hundred bucks later it was not worth the trip. I liked the hostess and waiter but I come for the food.
author: Lhm M.

description:
Sustainable seafood in the Soma area with a nautical theme (maps, ropes, fish murals). An enormous high-ceiling room with concrete floors & exposed wooden beams, & a bar that runs almost the length of the front of the house.

Enormous beer menu & a solid wine list, & bar tenders who are happy to give you a taste or help you decide on a good option to go with your dinner.

We decided to be daring & try the sea urchin & dungeness -- good call. Amazing. A rich, buttery sauce & plenty of urchin & crab. The ceviche was not bad, some of the fish flavors (good ones) were overpowered by the Thai-style sauce.

King Salmon was perfectly cooked & came with tasty, buttery veggies. The lobster roll was not what I expected -- it was more like tuna salad served in toasted bread. It was pretty good, except that there was too much celery, & the flavor was too much for the lobster.

Dessert was rhubarb, aniseed meringue, and almond ice cream. Interesting, unique, & fabulous! The Vermont Ice Cider was fabulous -- like ice wine made with apples.

As SF seafood goes, I'd recommend it! There are still a ton of things on the menu I want to try.
author: Angela B.

description: The general manager contacted me and apologized for the misunderstanding and invited me back to try the restaurant again.  In this day and age, it's rare that somebody takes the time to read my reviews and contacts m.  This is something I feel deserves public  appreciation and acknowledgement.  I am looking forward to going to Anchor and Hope again.
author: Daniel O.

description:
convenient business lunch spot. fast service.

For SF, food is mostly execute well but nothing to write home about.
author: Koh K.

description:
This was really good! I came here for lunch only because i worked nearby. However the quality of food and the atmosphere both exceeded my expectation.

For appetizer, we had the fried calamari. For entree we had mussels cooked with wine and a crab bisque. I don't remember exactly what the food were cooked with and what other tiny little things went with them, however, i do remember how it felt when they touched my taste buds!! The mussels were soooo fresh! They were cooked to a point that they were just done, not over-cooked at all. The crab bisque, on the other hand, had a very strong crab favor. Kind of like a lobster bisque. Absolutely love all of the dishes. 

As for atmosphere, the restaurant is in this abandoned-factory-look place. Very urban.  

Look forward to go back again! XD
author: RB B.

description:
My new obsession right now is seafood - namely crab, lobster and calamari (in no particular order). So when my coworkers wanted to go out for lunch I knew the exactly the right spot!

We ordered the calamari to share (YUM!) the calamari was yummy fried goodness and the dipping sauce was tasty as well. I ordered the lobster roll and OMG heaven. I loved that its served on a brioche bun which I thought ended up looking like texas toast. I devoured my whole sandwich! Even though we were all stuffed we kept nibbling on the fries and the potato chips that were served with our lunches. 

Anchor and Hope has happy hour prices for oysters and a very limited appetizer menu - all found on their site.
author: Julie F.

description:
I had seen this restaurant on the 2010 7x7 Big Eat list, so I had to check it out.

Walked in and loved the open floor plan. The vaulted ceilings with exposed duct work provided for a great restaurant environment. I also loved the art on the walls. I had plenty of time to study everything because it took 15 minutes for our waitress to come by and take our order.

I also really liked the design of the candle holder, salt and pepper shaker and water bottle on our table. I had plenty of time to admire them because it took another 40 minutes for our first appetizer to arrive.

When our first dish did arrive, I found it to be overly salted. And to call it the salmon pastrami dish is a little bit deceiving because there's more potato and egg to the dish than salmon pastrami. I wish I had a drink to wash it down, but our waitress hadn't been around to refill our drinks.

The beer and wine list were excellent. I had plenty of time to study that while waiting for our waitress to come back to our table to take our drink order.

Also tried the Angels on Horseback because that was the Big Eat list item. Found them to be underwhelming. More bacon than oyster.

This place shouldn't be called Anchor & Hope. It should be called Anchor & Hope You Get Good Service. I'd be more forgiving if it was on a busy night. However, I was there on a Tuesday night and the place was hardly at capacity. We spoke to the manager about the wait time, and she showed no remorse. Pretty sad for a manager of an upscale restaurant.

My advice? Ditch this place and walk over to The Salt House. At least there if you complain your food is too salty, they can point to the name of the restaurant and say it's not their fault.
author: Page K.

description: This was a great find by a work colleague of mine for an early dinner. Very new and trendy with a seaside motif. I had the Smithwick battered fish and chips, which was excellent. They have a decent selection of beers, although if like to see a few more IPAs if I come back. The steak entree, ordered by another colleague of mine, was huge and definitely a filler. He had to ask for a box. A box. Come on. It was that much. But if your in SF, around 2nd Street and Minna, venture down the alley and find this place. You'll definitely have a good meal, but be prepared to pay, it's new and a little pricey. Play credit card roulette for the bill. Who knows, you might get lucky!
author: Patrick F.

description: We were seated right away (10min early) even though one person in our group hadn't arrived yet.  The food and drinks were delicious.  We had the lobster roll, mussels, and salmon pastrami salad.  The only downside was the service.  The food was slow to arrive and there weren't really any check-ins.  We would probably all have had one more drink, but the waiter never checked in with us after serving the food.  Overall, the food was good and we would eat here again.
author: Sasha R.

description: Finally made it for happy hour! First off let me tell you that even though it's in an alley and hard to find its a nice find. First we ordered some beers to quench our thirst. Then came the oysters $1 each so we ordered a dozen. Not bad but the size were a bit on the smaller size, a little disappointing. Angels on horseback were next on the hit list and Geee Whizzz these were spot on, baked oysters wrapped in bacon how can u go wrong here. Then an order of fries, another round of beers, an entree consisting of halibut mushrooms and asparagus and finally a sea urchin dish with a cream sauce which all were on par. The service was decent but the only thing that displeased me was the overpricing, small servings and the extra 4% we had to dish out for the employees medical. I would advise happy hour so you can get a little break from the steep pricing.
author: T L.

description: This place is good but the food is just okay. Great ambience and good for big groups . Its a little on the expensive side though. There are 3 of us that had dinner here and our bill came out to $75 per person with one bottle of wine. There are definitely better places in the city.
author: Claudine V.

description: The "small" plateau is ALOT of food.  Great place for seafood!
author: John A.

description: I got dollar oysters (I'm such a sucker for dollar oysters), split the lobster roll and an order of cornmeal shrimp tacos. The food was delicious! I would recommend going early for happy hour and I was quite full. I got the Het Anker beer which was a pleasant surprise. Love the feel of this place!
author: Jennifer P.

description:
I came here to Fancy Lunch with my boss and coworkers. We had reservations and were seated promptly.

First off, our table was right by the door on a windy day and we had to ask four or five times for somebody to close it (they kept forgetting to close it). That aside...

I had the Cioppino, my boss had the lobster roll, my coworker the wild trout and my other coworker the fish & chips.

The trout looked amazing and she ate it all up. It was plated beautifully and served with ramps and other seasonal delights. The lobster roll looked fabulous and my boss enjoyed it. The fish & chips looked pretty standard.

My cioppino was just OK. The broth was forgettable, the seafood scarce. I was given a crab cracker yet there was not a shred of crab to be found in my stew. Just a few clams, mussels and some fish. It tasted fine but was largely disappointing, I had high hopes for a good bowl of cioppino.

They have a decent beer & wine list and the ambiance is very nice. I might come back to try something else, but for now my memory is sullied by that very mediocre cioppino. Maybe they could try adding more seafood, making the broth richer or spicier... just something to make it better.
author: Tala D.

description: Very good! I love the sea urchin with crab - It's buttery. The bass was really good too!
author: Kissy F.

description:
I'm upping my star rating, because the last time I came here for my birthday, the food was amazing. Service at the door still stank of rude. We waited 20 minutes with a reservation when there were tons of empty tables around.

As always, we ordered a half dozen oysters -- so fresh and delicious as per the usu. Then I got the lobster tails and died and went to heaven. I've never eaten that slow but wanted so badly to eat fast. The food here is pricey as expected, but if you ignore the sub-par service, it is an awesome experience. Yay! I'm a fan.
author: Catherine C.

description:
Happy Hour Review

The hour of happiness is from 4-6:30 p.m.  The specials were amazing and the bar side service is great!  We ordered oysters, fries and drinks.  For a $1, the oysters were fresh and quite large.  It was much larger than the ones you get at Hog Island for their happy hour, so that was a bonus for us.  Also, the fries were so well-seasoned that you really didn't need any additional condiments.  Love it!  As for the drinks, they have a daily draught beer for the HH price.  The choice beer that night was Downtown Brown which is solid, but just not what I was seeking.  I went with the Prosecco instead.  However, I have to hand to this place, the beers on tap as well as in bottles were exceptional!
author: Lisa R.

description: Amazing food and amazing atmosphere but horrible service and the longest wait ever for our food. I don't even recall if I had a waiter? Hmm..
author: Amanda M.

description:
A good.... but not the best seafood restaurant. 

Service was so so. Hostess was not pleasant. No smiles at all and our waitress gave our water without greeting us and did not come back I would say after 20 mins to give our bread and to take our order. 

Food: Garlic steamed mussels were small. Lobster roll was great but I loved baked sea urchin. It came in a mug, not in a real sea urchin shell as advertised in website. 

2 stars was for so so service....
author: Kristine P.

description:
High energy in a mechanic warehouse.  Very cool decor.  For lunch, make sure you do have about an hour and a half or more.  This is not really meant to be a quick FiDi lunch place.  In fact, they didn't even honor our reservation time at 1230pm and we were seated about 20 minutes after our booked time...
 
TIP #1: A great date spot is in the wooden bench back right corner, which is perfect for two.  The high noise level during lunch will encourage you to chat too.  Don't take my spot!  
 
We quickly started ordering so as not to linger for too much longer.
- Bacon wrapped oysters: Read my tips and my lips.
- Lobster roll: The lobster roll was light on the lobster, but came with a freshly baked egg bread, which was buttered well.  All accompanied with kettle chips and a cole slaw.  Nice, but it was also difficult to get my mind off the loaded lobster rolls I had in Boston...  This was a lot less hefty.  
- Seafood etoufee: Just the right amount of seasoning and the portion was just right for lunch.  
- German chocolate cake: Just right for a German chocolate cake, but if you want more dense chocolate, then you might want to go for something else. 
- Ginger beer: Great cooler to go with your food. 
 
TIP #2: Order the bacon wrapped oysters.  Mmm...  Very nice presentation of the food too.  Mmm...  Maybe I should return for the happy hour?  
 
TIP #3: This is likely not your everyday lunch place walking out at ~$90 for two people.  I know, I could've skipped dessert!  Nah...  I love my dessert.
author: Bonnie S.

description:
I'm writing this review on really behalf of my Dad. They were visiting from out of town and I brought them here even though I had never been but we like to try new places and I can't think of too bad an experience I've had at a restaurant in the city yet. The menu was small and pretty unimpressive but we managed to find a few things that looked good. Everyone must have agreed that nothing really looked very good because at 7:30pm on a Tuesday they were out of the only items we liked. I probably should have took this as our queue to leave but instead we sat through a mediocre but  expensive meal. 

The real kicker came at the end of the meal when my father--who happens to have lost a limb in a horrific accident--heads into the bathroom only to be assaulted with a poster above the urinal advertising compensation for missing limbs complete with prices posted next to pictures of body parts. Normally he could have brushed this off but at this point felt like not only had his wallet been abused but so had he. When I made a comment to the waiter about whether or not we would actually receive compensation as the poster in the bathroom advertised, he laughed but not even so much as the dessert was on the house.
author: Rachel F.

description: Fantastic experience. Pricey but worth it. Non-alcoholic cocktails are great. Lobster roll is special. It's expensive, but it being SF I get it.
author: Al P.

description: We tried this place for lunch after eating around the corner at JerseySF and were not disappointed!  I was born in Boston and raised in Rhode Island and that was one of the best lobster rolls I've had and felt like I was back East!  Before we left we made reservations to return again in a few weeks!!  We have found our new home away from home.
author: Linda M.

description: Had dinner reservations for 6 on recent trip.  The good,  excellent rockfish ceviche, large oyster and beer selection.  Really open and nice atmosphere.  The bad, sloppy and disengaged service.  Wait stuff constantly rushed and not friendly.  Ordered mix of oysters and they brought out with no explanations and later tried to take from table before we finished.  Head waitresses asked how food was and then walked away from table as we responding, not at all interested in hearing answer.
author: Steve S.

description:
This used to be one of my favorite spots for oysters and seafood (I was there +5 times over past year). Last time I went though I was VERY disappointed. First we had to wait for 45 minutes for our table (with reservation). Hostess suggested upon checkin it would be a 10 minute wait and didn't bother to invite us to bar to wait or to give us any other update. After waiting 30 minutes we went to bar to wait. Manager came buy to apologize and wanted to buy us a drink. He told bartender what we liked who promptly ignored us for the next 15 minutes until he came over and asked "what did you order again, I forgot". So not too happy when we were finally seated. Alas things went from bad to worse. When uni with mashed potato came out the sauce was VERY over-salted (I usually eat very salty - but this was uneatable even for me). We sent this back and when they re-did the dish it unfortunately tasted just about the same - they must have over-salted the sauce and didn't bother to fix it. We also had a fish that tasted really off I. A couple of other dishes we ordered were ok. To top up the evening I woke up in the middle of the night with foof poisoning....

So very sad to say - this dropped from very high on my list of favorites to - bot again anytime soon.
author: Eliette K.

description:
My brother and I took my parents here for their anniversary back in January. Now, when this happens, usually my brother and I will split the bill down the middle. However, my dad thought it would be fun to invite my grandparents as well. It WAS still fun, don't get me wrong (I love my grandparents to death). BUT, it was not fun for our wallets. So, essentially, my dad conned us. Well played, father, well played....

Anyway, I walked into the place not really knowing what to expect. The ambiance of the restaurant was really nice. Dim lighting and a very mellow environment, which is great for nice dinners and quiet conversations.

We ordered the "Angels on Horseback" as our first appetizer. Pure delicious heaven. Bacon-wrapped oysters pairs well with good wine (or an IPA, if you're like me).

For my entree, I ordered the lobster and crab gnocchi. Succulent crab and lobster meat with potato gnocchi in cream sauce. Simply divine. In fact, this dish was SO good that I decided to stop drinking alcohol for the whole meal so I could remember it fully. And I'm glad I did, my friends. I'm very glad I did. 

The service was great. Very friendly waitress and staff.

My only gripe was the price of it all. So come eat here ONLY if you have the moola to dish out on a good seafood meal. It's really quite good.
author: Daniel M.

description: Wonderful find in downtown SF. Amazingly fresh seafood (I tried the shrimp cocktail and a plate of grilled shrimp for my main) and nonalcoholic mixed drink options that made our lunch feel super special (note: lots of fresh ginger was involved). As well, the open floor plan - lots of light, space, etc - lent to a feeling of tremendous collegiality. Cannot wait to go back...though maybe it's time to check out the happy hour.
author: Erin W.

description:
I really like this place. I love the urban vibe in a old warehouse.

Food: They have my favorite Oysters!!! I looove Kusshi. You can't find them everywhere. They are the best you can ever have. Delious~ And Clams! Loooove clams. I ordered a dozen clams and 1/2 dozen oysters. My friend had the lobster roll which I tried that was really good. It's not the typical mayo and abundance of lobster but with i believe and onions and stuff. Still really good. I had the soft shell crab BLT which was amazing. The only thing is they only put 1 crab in there. It needs 2 because you can only taste the body of the crab in a sandwich.

I will definitely come back. Hopefully next week. :)
author: Karen L.

description: I just got back from this restaurant and I can't believe that it's currently rated 3.5 stars -- this place is simply amazing!  If you want a five star kind of feeling, get the heirloom tomato salad (can be split with 2), then get either the salmon or the linguine. The pinot grigio wine pairs awesomely with all the above.  Finish the night with the salted carmel ice cream whoopie pie if you have room!
author: Scott N.

description: Surprisingly fresh seafood hidden away in the financial district. I came for a work happy hour and loved the bacon wrapped oysters, calamari, and seviche appetizers. They have tons of beers on tap and by the glass, as well as wine and cocktails. The warehouse feel of the restaurant is also fun and makes it feel trendy.
author: Jing L.

description: Awesome seafood here! Super fresh and thoughtful presentation. The service was excellent, not overbearing but attentive. The oysters were absolutely super fresh and tasted as if they came right from the ocean to our table! The beers on tap were all local beers and very tasty as well. Highly recommend this place!
author: Dr J.

description: I really, really wanted to love this place.  The space is great.  The location was great.  Decor was great.  The food was amazing.  The service was just so-so.  And I would have given this place more than three stars, but I got super sick after eating here, as did one of the people that I went with.  We shared the large seafood platter and we both thought that the crab and ceviche tasted a bit "off."  Everything else we had was perfect.  But, I got super sick.  I would rate it 1 star because of this, but the food was very good and the ambiance was pretty cool.  I would like to say that I would go here again, but I really don't want to be laid up in bed for two days again.  And that worries me.  :(
author: Jenn S.

description:
I ate here once, during the Fancy Food Show and well, yeah I'm a fan! I wish I discovered this place when I was still living in the bay.
Atmosphere is nice, staff is great, the food pretty freaking awesome. 
We were a party of 5: 2 chefs and 3 peoplethatworkwithfoodallthetime, and we were all very happy. We shared some appetizers: the octopus, the calamari, the sea urchin and something else that now I can't remember but everything was delicious.
The entrees were all also very good, and one person in our party got the steak, which looked and tasted delicious as well. There are no vegetarian items on the menu, which is not a problem personally, but being in SF is probably an issue for some.
I didn't try the deserts, but the wine selection was pretty great, but I wish they had more wine by the glass selection. 
Very good experience.
author: Fra L.

description:
Wow, pretty horrible service today.  I am a frequent patron at this establishment (my 2nd visit for lunch this week) and I've always been satisfied with both food and service. It takes a lot to get me upset, so I find it necessary to spend time writing a BAD review for Anchor & Hope. Today, I was quite disappointed with the service, and as a result, I did not enjoy my meal my food because I had to rush to eat it.

What went wrong:

1) It took 10 minutes before someone came by to take my full order (and I gave a full order of beverages, appetizer, and entree)

2) 20 minutes later before any bread was brought to us AFTER we had to request bread.  

3) The appetizer came out 10 minutes later, only after I had to had help the server bring the appetizer to the right table because she was looking around aimlessly for who ordered the appetizer in her hand. 

4)  Another 15 minutes elapsed and my friend had to ask our server if our entrees were coming out.  

5) When they finally came out, I spent the last 15 minutes to eat my lunch.

6) Let me add that the staff did not know how to process their own gift card... Odd since I used it on 2 days ago.

7) From start to finish, my lunch took 1 hour and 20 minutes.  

Sure, I did go during peak lunch hours... but it's your job to staff accordingly.  I probably would not be upset if:

1) During the whole time, there were 2 occasions where servers were standing around and conversing.

2) My own server was in the kitchen chatting it up with another person in clear view, not giving a sh!t

3) How many times did you stop by to check on me or ask how my food was?  Zero.

4) Why did the Line Cook have to flag you down so that you could bring me my bill?  Wasn't my frustration evident?  Oh, it's because you weren't paying attention to me.

So, I'm not sure if I'll be going back to Anchor & Hope anytime soon... It sucks because I still have a good balance on my gift card.  Rather than throwing it away, I may have to give it to one of the homeless so that he/she can enjoy a good meal... and I hope you show the same courtesy to him/her as this person is a paying customer, even as your patrons get uncomfortable dining with this person next to them... 

Good Luck on your business in the future... even if you have one less patron frequenting your establishment in this tough economy...

Sincerely,

Me.
author: Brian K.

description:
Within my first few moments at Anchor & Hope, I couldn't imagine how they only had a 3.5 star review. It had a cool ambiance, everything on the menu looked too tempting to decide on just a few things, and our selected appetizers were delicious once they arrived.  

But (of course there's a but), there were a few too many other things that tainted the experience.

1. Reservations: My boyfriend called to book a table for 4 and was told the first available was at 9:30 pm.  I looked on Open Table through Yelp and was able to book one 45 minutes earlier.

2. Appetizers: GREAT.  We ordered/split the sea urchin which was delish although a little disappointing that it didn't come in the cool shell like some of the pictures online.  The heirloom tomato, burrata and peach salad was absolutely worth coming back for.  And the mussels (we opted for "bollywood" style) were not bad either, although I've definitely had better.

3. Entrees: Don't bother. Two of us had the rockfish which was a nice piece of fish that was cooked well.  And the dish probably should have ended there.  There were about 5 other things in the dish that just didn't seem to mesh well together: gnocchi, smokey japenese eggplant, thick strips of roasted red pepper.  
Another ordered fish and chips but the fish was barely battered and not that crispy.  And my other friend had linguine with clams which I tried and frankly would have sent back.  It was over spiced and loaded loaded with garlic (lots of full garlic slices throughout the dish).  I also had grit /sand in 2 of the clams I tried. 

4. Waiter: very nice but made a few mistakes/forgot to bring us essentials after we asked. He also cut the bill wrong and it took about a 10 min wait for him to circle back to us when we were ready to leave at 10:30.

Overall, maybe this was just an off night?  It'd be a good spot for a lighter diner of just drinks and a few apps. Next time, I would pass on entrees and try to reserve a table through Yelp/Open Table if tables don't appear available over the phone.
author: Miss W.

description: This has to be one of the worst dining experiences one can find.  The chairs are metal seats and are ICEcold!!  Not a welcoming experience.  The chill remained during the evening with the waiter recommending the most expensive bottle of wine on the menu at $130.00 a bottle to them clearing the table while one person was still eating.  The excuse was " We are not fine dining and this is efficient for the staff"!  The food was on subpar with the experience and this is a place that will not get a second chance.
author: Malin G.

description:
So we went here initially for the Bacon Wrapped Oysters--having seen them on 7x7 mag's Top 100 Food Experiences in SF.  First impressions of this place: hip and very social.  The layout is built for socializing.  Most seats plant you literally a foot or two from your neighbor. Not much private seating--maybe 2 or 3 booths, which we obtained by request.  

Dinner isn't served until 5:30 so we started with some good Sauv Blanc.  Nice wine and beer list.  Excellent Service.
