And then the food came....
The garlic fries are pretty damn incredible and didn't last long.  Nice presentation too.  
Calamari was delectable.
But those bacon wrapped oysters.....damn.....I may not need sex for a while after those.  Seriously....melt in your mouth good.  
Go here with a group for socializing, beer, wine, and oysters.
author: Ethan R.

description:
Anchor and Hope was introduced to me by my friends who live in San Fran.  

First, the wine list has enough variety but not big enough where you feel lost.  Let me also note that the mark-up is not wallet busting and makes it more reasonable to enjoy a bottle of wine or two over dinner.

Moving on to the food, the appetizers are very interesting in a good way.  The Angels on Horseback are delicious and you may have to order 2 (in my opinion).  The Charred Blackened Baby Octopus was another favorite of mine.

Entres are not as exciting (on paper) as much as the appetizers are but nonetheless very tasty.  I had the Lobster Roll and Cioppino, both of which were very tasty.  

For dessert, I had the sorbet with what looked to be a pomegranate reduction.... a great way to end an enjoyable meal.

Please note that the menu is not incredibly large so if you have a picky eater, you may have your work cut out for you.  I would suggest checking the menu online as I would with any other restaurant.  Also, I must note that the menu online vs. actual menu in restaurant varied slightly..... so you may have some pleasant or perhaps not-so-pleasant surprises when you arrive.

Enjoy!
author: Brent K.

description:
Great restaurant concept and building...However, it just barely missed the mark for me.

Since there are so many reviews I'll just provide the bare bones.

Beer selection is fantastic.  A&H knows what's up here...top notch.

Menu is interesting, fun, and can please numerous people in a large party.

Space is done well.  Cavernous but not in a way to make you feel tiny.  However, lots of traffic near the open kitchen...lots.  Get a table by the wall if you can.  Also, a random I-beam is a little odd.

Grub is slightly off mark.  Every dish I've seen and heard of here have all been slightly lacking.  Pretty much a hair above average for the price point.  A little hit and miss.

Service...a little hit and miss too...however, everyone is friendly and knowledgeable.

Bathrooms are fun and worth a look-see.  Props to A&H for recognizing 826 Valencia.

Bottom line is I'm glad I went...Personally, I may be back, but, I would say to any of my friends to give it a shot.  3.5 stars really.
author: Chris D.

description: The food was overpriced and average (not good and not bad). The music they played was good and the waitress was nice.
author: Zach S.

description:
Update: 
I just spoke with the manager about the bill over the phone and it sounds like it should resolve itself in a few days with the bank.  More importantly she acknowledged the poor customer service of her hostess, apologized and offered to comp the next happy hour we do there.  

I am absolutely delighted that this is resolved because I really loved the oysters, and the corn fried shrimp- AND it's right by our office, which makes it perfect for after-work happy hours.  My recommendation to others looking for the same is to try and reserve a table for larger parties since the bar seating is fairly limited.  

* * * 
First review ONE STAR 

I was ready to give this place rave reviews and/or not review it because I had such a nice time I didn't want it to get ruined with crowds. HOWEVER... 

I went there last night for happy hour and as I mentioned had a very nice time. Service was a little spotty, but in general very nice and accommodating.  I paid $20 for my part, which was the delicious oyster/stout special and some fries. This morning when I checked my bank account, I see they charged me for the full bill which came out to be about $75 - still a great deal for what we got.  When I called into the restaurant today to follow up about it and get the charge fixed, the hostess I spoke to was extremely rude. At no point did she apologize for my having been overcharged by $55. Instead she asked for information about the card and was snarky with me when the receipt that I have didn't have any kind of "reference" number or "check" number.  As if I am supposed to know the coded language of your receipt/POS system.  I then asked if it would help if I brought my copy of the receipt, which shows me having paid $20 and she responded that they would have to do some research and wouldn't be able to help me until the afternoon.  She finished our conversation with "Ok?" Not 'Thanks for letting us know of our error' or 'Again I am sorry for the complication.'   Just "Ok?"  

Uh yeah, ok. Good bye and you're welcome for the extra $50 bucks. 

I work as a receptionist so I understand customer service.  I deal with medium to rude people regularly and  I cannot handle when someone is rude to me as a customer, especially when the business in question is at fault.  

To be determined how they will handle this... will follow up.
author: Sarah T.

description:
Had an opportunity to visit the Anchor & Hope.  It's tucked away on Minna street by 2nd.  Easily missed, unless you know it's there.  

This was a business dinner.  The food was good.  A few of the standouts were the ceviche appetizer, and a sweet corn side dish, along with the chocolate toffee cake for dessert.  

It was a bit on the expensive side for my personal dining choices.  However, it's a good choice for a business meal.
author: Xiao B.

description:
4.5? Good food, excellent wine list, great service, lovely ambiance.

It's a great option for an upscale bite or to sit and sip wine. Our table of three ordered appetizers and wine. We were seated immediately, our waitress was great, and our only (very minor) complaint was that it was much too warm in the restaurant. Prices were not outrageous... it's just kind of a fancy place. We liked it, and would return for sure.

The bread they give you is delicious, too!
author: Jacqueline W.

description:
Gee, is "Anchor & Hope" an old expression like "a Wing & a Prayer"? I was just wondering because I wasn't feeling like I was in a desperate situation and relying on hope to see me through. I was actually relying on someone else's expense account.

So I have finally completed the triumvirate of swankily packaged, suit-friendly SoMa eateries from Doug Washington and the Brothers Rosenthal - Town Hall, Salt House and now Anchor & Hope. I have to give them credit for opening restaurants that are neither snooty nor overly creative in concept. They all serve good food - pricey yes but good. Since I now work within the lopsided triangle that connects the three locations, they have become the default go-to spots among my colleagues, past and present, for the after-work cocktail get-together or the catch-up business lunch.

Luckily, I actually like the people who were generous enough to take me to lunch there today. I also like the open warehouse loft decor, as it offers space rather than the cozier warmth of the other two places. Although they offer meat and poultry options, it's really a nice fish house as you could guess from the name. What immediately drew my eye on the menu was the $23 Anchor & Hope Lobster Roll which came simply with kettle chips spiced with old bay and a ramekin of cole slaw.

Oh yeah, it was really tender and buttery, though I couldn't help but remember getting a similar roll at a lobster shack in Cape Cod for less than half the price. But I'm sure not complaining. It was a helluva lot better than the chicken salad on sourdough I get at Lee's. The roll also went own nicely with a Port o'Call, a non-alky concoction with raspberry puree, cranberry juice and club soda. We were seated in a little nook in the back which I recommend you secure if you want a decent-decibel conversation.

FOOD - 4 stars...mmmm, a fresh lobster roll
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...airy and spacious tucked away on Minna, the alleyway with marginally less urine than Natoma
SERVICE - 4 stars...very officious and thorough...she talks a bit fast for my slow ears
TOTAL - 4 stars...great lobster and great company....a nice seafood option in an area in need of one
author: Ed U.

description:
Over-salted food?!

Poor waitstaff?!

Unconcerned manager?!

Come on down!

What a disappointing meal in a such a great space. Beer and wine, yes they have it. Yes, it's good. Hard to mess that up. 

Can't believe their angels on horseback ever made the 7x7 list. Bacon overpowering. Salmon dish with poached egg too salty. Couldn't finish. So over the meal by the time the main course came, we asked for the check and a doggie bag.

Worst part: the service. Waited 45 minutes for first appetizers. Another 20 for our meal. Mind you it was 9:30pm on a Tuesday, and the restaurant had a whopping 12 other guests. Manager was less than concerned when we voiced our wait time, offering no explanation or apology. 

Advice: take your (lots o') dining bucks and head somewhere else. Walk, crawl, swim away from this establishment.
author: Erin B.

description: Prob one of the best dinners we have had in San Francisco! The hostess was courteous and seated us at a nice table even when we arrived earlier than the OpenTable reservations I had made. The ambiance & decor is perfect. I am a beer lover and they had an awesome selection on tap. Salad was fresh and nicely done. My wife enjoyed the fresh fish selection of the day. They made an off-the-menu vegetarian pasta for me which was delicious. A very enjoyable experience. Highly recommended for a date night
author: Manish V.

description:
Anchor & Hope came highly recommended from Bon Appetit, among others, so we decided that it would be a perfect splurge for the last night of our San Francisco honeymoon during which time we ate everything and went everywhere - no seriously, 33 places in 9 days. Unfortunately, it turned out to be the possibly the most disappointing dining experience we had on our trip.

We were seated right away, and after some time with the menu, our server took our order, suggested wine pairings - and then went home sick. Time passed, and no server or wine. Another server arrived with our entrees: seafood risotto for me, and a seared ahi tuna for my husband. No wine.

I should state up front that I'm a tentative seafood eater. I can do most shellfish, and am working my way up through meaty white fish. I had carefully checked the menu before ordering, and so was surprised to have four sizeable chunks of salmon in my risotto. Salmon! My food kryptonite! I ate one piece, then ate around the rest as it quickly went cold - not how you want to be eating when you're paying $25+ per plate. Shane enjoyed his tuna, but liked the accompanying sausage and beans even more. Our wine finally arrived, but only after we'd flagged down another server. Honestly, the highlight of the meal for us was the Blue Bottle milkshake and wee maple macaron that we split for dinner, both of which were sweet and delicious without making us feel guilty about the indulgence.

I've subsequently been told that Anchor & Hope can be hit or miss - and I received a very apologetic email in response to my complaint - but I still can't shake the disappointment of that last special meal.
author: Elizabeth E.

description:
Went in for dinner with an out of town guest. Hostess quoted a 30-40 minute wait for our party of 3, as they were quite busy at the time. After about 50 minutes, went to check in with her, and she mentioned that we were up next. 
As we stood by the hostess stand, we watched her seat 3 tables. We were willing to stick it out a bit longer, but after 90 minutes, we couldn't take it anymore. I asked if we'd be seated soon, and she pointed to a 6-top where they were still waiting on their desserts, and said that it would be ours. 
After 90 minutes, I was in no mood to wait 20 more. She did try to apologize as we left, but a glass of champagne after an hour and a half isn't going to cut it. If I had wanted a drink, I would have gotten one myself. 

At least Osha Thai had no wait.
author: Ashley C.

description:
I've been here a few times for lunch and always hope for the best.  The staff is friendly and the ambiance is inviting and trendy.  So far my lunches have been a bit disappointing. Maybe I haven't been ordering the right things, but everything should be good right...especially since their food isn't on the cheap side.  I've tried a couple sandwiches and entrees. None of them were memorable and lacked in flavor and sauce. 

They do have two amazing appetizers though...
Angels on Horseback: bacon wrapped oysters with remoulade = heaven! The bacon's crispiness with the oyster's juiciness...mmmmm!  I can probably have 3 orders of this for myself!

 Warm Sea Urchin with dungeness crab: I saw this on The Best Thing I Ever Ate and had to try it.  Luckily it lived up to it's hype. They only serve it for dinner though. That puff pastry on top with rich creamy lemon beurre blanc inside...what buttery dreams are made of...

I'll probably go back to this place for happy hour.  Seems like they have some pretty good deals.
author: Monica P.

description:
I left feeling a bit conflicted. I badly wanted to like Anchor & Hope but my overall impression was just meh.

The space was beautiful, gorgeous even in a clean, nautical sort of way. Our waitress was pretty helpful, friendly, and overall the service was generally impeccable. No complaints there.

My first instinct was to go for the clam chowder as an appetizer but I decided at the last instant to be adventurous (but not ambitious enough to try the sea urchin) and went with the Slow Cooked Oxtail Marmalade and Oven Roasted Bone Marrow with toasted Brioche. I could not have been more happy. The dish was unique, perfectly sized, both rich and flavorful with lots of moist tender meat. The bone marrow was almost sinfully decadent. Everything in the dish just seemed to work well and compliment each other.

Since trying dishes I normally wouldn't was paying off, I decided to continue and went with the Oven Roasted Striped Sea Bass with Fava Bean Brandade, Manila Clams, and Chorizo Bouillabaisse. After all, this was a seafood place and I figured if anything was going to be great, it'd be a fish plate. But alas, it didn't live up to what I was hoping for. Don't get me wrong, it wasn't bad, but the bass was just ok and while I love chorizo and clams, the flavors of the sauce didn't really work with the fish. Most of the people I ate with seemed to enjoy their dishes so I'm going to chalk this up as a rare miss for Anchor and hope next time I order a winner.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
Um...A-OK, not super impressed.  I went for lunch during DAT. I love the space, ambiance...gotta say that but the food not that special. I had the gumbo/etoufee and the arugula salad. I didn't care for the salad. A whole salad of arugula is not tasty IMO. The dressing was nice but I forced myself to eat 90% of the salad for the vitamins. The etoufee was good but a little cold, so I guess I'll blame that on service. For a $25 lunch, I expect more. Sooooo, I don't think that I'll be back.

Attractive space but the taste of the food does not justify the price.
author: Kiristen R.

description:
What's it called when a trend is so prevalent and overused and ubiquitous and everyone is doing it?  Whatever it's called, it's here.  It is the fries served in the cone.  Especially when the cone is something trite like a drinking glass.  And the menu advertises "Parmesean something fries."  As a $6 version of some Happy Hour nonsense.  

I'm not impressed.  The aioli was not good.  It tasted like mayo with lemon zest and some salt.  It certainly did not rock my off-kilter world.  I don't care for it.  

The fries were also short.  Indicating that they were not prepared with care.  I like my fries long.  Longer the better.  Size does matter.  Plus, the texture was sandy and mushy and did not hold up well, in it's freaking cone holder.  

The happy hour menu had 1 non-oyster thing, 2-3 cooked oyster things for $3 each, and some snippet told us that "Angels on Horseback" was mashed potatoes mixed with cod.  Someone must have told her that to get her to eat it.  Idiot.  IDIOTS!  I'm surrounded by idiots who have no common sense.  

Where's my freaking herbal tea, I'm tense.
author: Christina C.

description: Wow!  As a pre-Thanksgiving lunch, Anchor & Hope almost spoiled us for the big day.    Anyone who follows me knows that I'm a tuna melt diehard - and Anchor & Hope's was one of the best so far, across the country.  Openfaced, delicious tuna, chopped not too finely, and the caramelized onions were inspirational.  Oh, polenta fries!  Crispy, shareable.   Housed in what appears to be an old warehouse - high ceilings, industrial fixtures, big windows, A & H is a great downtown SF find.  Happy to find "Cali Colsh" from a favorite local brewer, CaliCraft, on the menu too!  My three dining companions quaffed and ate their way through the delicious, attentive lunch - this is a comeback again place!
author: Cheryl N.

description:
The service was so disappointing! Our server never asked us how are food and completely ignored us for no reason.

The food wasn't any better than WHC in the Castro. The ambiance and decor is ok. There is no hard alcohol, and the beer/wine list is waaaay expensive.

I would not go back.
author: Jacqueline Y.

description: I normally live 4-5 hours from either coast so I grabbed the opportunity to have some fresh seafood. The place was recommended by the concierge and after I looked it up on line sounded interesting. My small seafood plateau was excellent and our helpful server was right that the large would be more suitable for two people. It comes with a free tutorial on oysters of the two coasts. The obligatory octopus appetizer was also very good. I would have appreciated more direction in the wine selection. My ocean hating wife had the steak which was very flavorful. Not cheap but worth it.
author: Alain E.

description:
Anchor & Hope is in a really cool space but I was less than impressed by the food. I had been craving a lobster roll for ages, and this really didn't hit the spot. 

I expected my lobster roll to be overstuffed with sweet, fresh-tasting lobster but found a relatively skimpy portion with pretty average  lobster...for nearly $25. The lobster was also shredded, not the big chunks of lobster that I'm used to having in a lobster roll. The side that the lobster roll came with was potato chips which were tasty, but I would've preferred a different side (fries? salad?) than a mound of chips.

Our server was nice and very attentive, but overall, I found the restaurant to be too expensive for what I what it is.
author: Wendy L.

description:
This restaurant is hidden on a side street but has really interesting decor. Has a cool fish painting on the bar wall which I really liked. Staff was pretty friendly and the company I was with really appreciated the extensive beer list ;)

Food: 
Bread in a Bag: For an appetizer they offer a whole loaf of French bag that comes in a paper bag. Be careful as there is a lit candle in the middle of the table which could easily catch fire. ( as a friend quickly made predication come to reality when he he caused our table's bill to catch fire at the end of our meal...lol)
Calamari thai vinegar: I would say of out of all the interesting dishes this was nothing special. It was good for what it is but really not to die for. 

Sea urchin, crab in remoulade and mashed potato: I am a big big fan of uni when I go to the Japanese restaurant and a fan of crab as well. However, this dish was extremely heavy, almost like a thick clam chowder but is a much much saltier. The sea urchin is a bit unsettling because it is luke warm. Not as good as when it is chilled. It was a interesting dish to try and the crab meat was great but I would not order again. 
Trout: Grilled trout was a perfect flaky and buttery consistency. 2 large pieces of filleted skin on trout grilled to perfection. Crispy skin with tender meat. The squash is a nice touch to the fish. If you're a fan of fish I would most definitely give it a try. 

Overall, this place had creative ideas but execution was not entirely up to par. Considering the other million amazing places there are in SF it will be a while until I come back.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Came here for dinner last night (a Tuesday night, 7.30pm) - was really nice.  Clientele is primarily business FiDi people in small groups. We got a lovely table in the corner which was quiet - but I can see it would be a little loud in the middle.  It's a great space - a converted garage.  Not overly decorated - nice and light.

Shared oysters to start, and cheese stuffed squash blossoms. Followed by the trout served on green peas and mixed veg for me, halibut for the Mr.  The trout was really lovely, the red wine reduction on the side was not overpowering - I really enjoyed my meal.  Finished off with a rasberry, peach & rhubarb crumble (yum, yum!)

Wait staff was great - polite, chatty and prompt. We got a nice wine recommendation that matched our meal really well.  The wait between starter and main course was a little long - but luckily they kept our wine on ice and promptly filled those glasses of wine for us as they got low, so we didn't mind!
author: Beekay M.

description: Good place to meet for lunch during the week.  Service and seafood are very good.  Like so many places these days, it has hard finishes on all sides (brick walls and hard floors) so can get really noisy.
author: Arthur M.

description:
Love at first taste in a new restaurant isn't easy to come by, but it's magical when it happens. It all started when a friend emailed me a brief article about Anchor & Hope, a new restaurant in SOMA from the owners of the renowned Town Hall and the more recently acclaimed Salt House. After reading some more promising press coverage, I decided on a whim to check it out on their opening night. 

Located in the Minna Street alley, the restaurant is housed in a renovated warehouse from the turn of the century. According to our very friendly and charming waiter, the Rosenthal brothers (owners) traveled to the seafood hot spots along the East Coast to figure out how to capture the look, feel, and tastes of a traditional fish house by the sea, while still retaining a modern touch. Their research clearly paid off, as reflected in the high ceilings, wood floors, brick walls, lengths of nautical rope dangling from wooden beams, and sea-themed decorations. The resulting space was comfortably roomy and rustic, like an old fish shack, but still urban enough to fit into the city. 

Sarah Schafer (formerly from Frisson) is the head chef at Anchor & Hope, and the menu consists mostly of seafood items, including several kinds of oysters of the day. My friend and I decided to order several appetizers to share, so we could sample more dishes.

Our waiter informed us that the wine and beer list was unavailable that night, due to some shipping issues. But before we could start feeling too bad, the owner came around and offered us complimentary tastes of white wine. We each ended up getting two generous glasses of free wine for our dinner. Now that's great customer service!

The food was phenomenal - fresh seafood, creative approaches, and casually fun presentation. We started off with a half dozen of raw Drake's Bay oysters - one of my favorites for the salty flavor. These bad boys were nice and fresh, served with a slightly spicy cocktail sauce.

I had really wanted to try the Angels on Horseback - smoked bacon wrapped oysters - and I'm glad I did. These were amazing! The combination of crisp, slightly fatty bacon, buttery oysters, salt, and mild spice sent my taste buds to heaven and back, resulting in my signature "zoned out" look as I was happily chewing. Another excellent dish was the basil-stuffed clams, topped with parmesan bread crumbs. The crinkle of the crumbs contrasted well with the softness of the clams, and the basil was a nice highlight. We also ordered a cold maple smoked trout, stacked atop a warm potato salad layered with some greens and a drizzle of balsamic vinaigrette. And we even got complimentary fried smelts! 

Finally, for dessert we settled on a warm rhubarb apple crisp with fresh strawberries and vanilla bean ice cream. A wonderfully sweet way to end the meal.

Overall, I was very impressed with the Rosenthals' latest offering, and I will definitely venture back to Anchor & Hope to try their main fish entrees, along with that warm sea urchin in a shell appetizer. I hope you'll find the time to make a visit as well! 

(See accompanying photos!)
author: Lisa M.

description:
Do you LOVE overpriced and over-hyped food? How about being asked to wait around for 10 minutes for the hostess to seat you when you have a reservation at 1pm, and there are open tables that simply need to be set?? If you're ready to drop a hundo at lunch for 2, then this is the place for you.

Came here for lunch last week as part of Open Table's Dine About Town. Is it sad to say that the best part of the DAT was the salad? Yea...that's sorta sad. The arugula salad was simple and delicious. I just wasn't feeling the crawfish/rock shrimp etouffee. It was spicy...but...off. My bf, however, wasn't as put off as I was.  His lobster roll was good-- and it better be at $24--but it's nothing to get filled up on. We did start with the angels on horseback, since they are highly recommended in all these reviews...a bit to briny for me.Nice, thick, meaty, bacon, wrapped around thick sea-like oysters. Meh. 

Some positives though...the manager (?), who brought me my diet coke after it wasn't brought out by my server, noticed I was cold (I resorted to wearing my bf's fleece), and she offered to turn up the heat AND brought me hot water with lemon. How sweet.

I am intrigued by the happy hour...but it ends at 6pm M-F. Who gets off of work that early?
author: Misha F.

description:
The wine selection was great or else that was my boyfriend who is awesome at selecting fine wine.

Both appetizers that we ordered were fried, which was kind of disappointing as I thought the squash blossoms were not.

The waitress was friendly, but when we asked her what the squash blossoms were, she wasn't able to correctly describe them.

The mussels were divine, best part of the meal for sure!

The paella, which they say they are known for, was nothing special. It was a flat portion of rice that was stuck to the bottom of a cast iron pan and didn't have a lot of shellfish or meat in it which is what a real paella is all about. It was as disappointing dish.

I'd probably go back to see if my experience was better because the ambiance is so awesome and I'd like to see if the other dishes are up to par.
author: caitlin k.

description:
Make it an 83 night.  Head to 83 Proof for drinks, followed by 83 Minna for dinner.*  

Nautical, dude.  Eastern seaboard.  Oceanic.  Angels on Horseback app goes back to my edict that anything tastes good when bacon is wrapped around it.  A&H's version of fish & chips - hearty battered halibut and potato wedges - looked extremely satisfying. The mussels and monkfish stew pot  was nicely spicy & brothy (the little chorizo meatballs were deelish!), and the snapper dish was quite good.  When I've got seafood on the mind, I'm definitely going here.   



*We tried going to Salt House first, but they were packed.  The nice tattooed lady at Salt House suggested we try their sister restaurant, A&H.  With one call, she had A&H hold spots for us at their communal table and we trotted over.  Nice.
author: Peg S.

description:
The problem with coming in to a dining experience with high expectations is that unless the restaurant is exquisitely impressive, you ultimately end up disappointed. 

This is what happened at Anchor & Hope.

I was looking for a casual, yet elegant restaurant serving American seafood, so I chose this restaurant.

The food:

Appetizer/soup: New England Clam Chowder with Canadian Bacon
Yes, "why would i try clam chowder at an establishment like this like this?" you ask. Well b/c i was craving clam chowder! haha. Anyways, the clam chowder was, by far, my favorite dish of the night (which may something about this restaurant, but i'll let you all come to your own conclusions). The clam chowder was not your typical thick, overly creamy potato blend. Rather, the clam chowder here was of thin consistency (which i prefer), had fresh whole clams (as opposed to minced mystery shellfish meat), and was overall packed with clam essence/flavor. You tasted clam, not milk, cream, or potato. The only downside of this dish was that it there was not much soup, especially when you consider the 10 dollar price tag. 

My entree: Prosciutto wrapped brook trout
The dish was a whole trout wrapped with prosciutto wrapped around the body of the fish. It lay on top of a bed of brussel sprouts, almonds, and osyter mushrooms.I had high expectations for this dish, but was slight disappointed. First of all, the prosciutto was wrapped around the skin of the fish. I understand if the purpose of the prosciutto was to provide flavor into the fish of the meat, but i still wouldve preferred to somehow be able to consume the prosciutto without eating the skin of the trout. The meat, while cooked well, was a little bland in my opinion. Despite the fact that it was seasoned with salt and stuffed with dice garlic, i felt there was some missing component or flavor that i badly craved from the trout itself. On a brighter side, the brussel sprouts and oyster mushrooms were well cooked and flavored. 

The service:
Our waitress was decent. She was polite and cordial, but didn't seem like she wanted to be there on a Saturday night and was void of any human energy. She did not check in on us often and relied on the bus boys and other waiters to provide our appetizers/entrees. There was no subsequent explanation of our food when it was laid down on the table (which i needed for the damn trout). 

Overall, this restaurant is exactly as i rated it: a-ok. Some of the food was good, some were just decent. But in the end, the price tag was way too high for the food and service we were given.
author: Nathan T.

description:
Very similar setting and food to Salt House. It's in an alley where unless you know where it is or you are going to the parking lot, you won't pass by it.

Clean, yacht club style deco that has high ceilings with ropes and fish drawings on the walls. The wooden chairs and some tables that are table-clothed while others just painted in gray give an intentional mismatch, a rough look of the restaurant, yet an elegant hint.

Food wise, the creamy scallop ceviche was not with traditional lemon and lime juice but was inventive. Crab salad was fresh and tasty. Sichuan prawns were actually not spicy so it was a bit of surprising. Ribbon fries was good and light, especially on a hot day where this place does not have air-conditioning but a far blowing.
author: T L.

description:
I went here for dinner Saturday night with friends - we were a party of 4.  This was the first time here for all four of us, and we all agreed on the following:

PROS
- Beautiful restaurant, comfortable and stylish interior
- Great service
- Noise level not too loud for conversation, although it did get progressively louder later in the evening.
- Amazing homemade potato chips brought free to the table while you are perusing the menu - we all ignored our better instincts and chowed down on them

CONS
- For a seafood restaurant, we had high expectations for the fish dishes.  Unfortunately, we were disappointed.
- Bland shrimp on the seafood plateau - no seasoning whatsoever.  However the cocktail sauce with fresh horseradish was a welcome addition.
- Rock fish entree was also bland and overcooked, sauces were odd, had to ask for lemon to season it
- Lobster roll (eaten by 2 in our party) was bland and underwhelming.  However the homemade tater tots on this dish were amazing.
- King Salmon was average
- The cocktails (no hard liquor, all wine-based) were very odd.  Just odd.  Not balanced in flavors like a good cocktail should be.  No one enjoyed them.

I would have given this rating 3 stars, except for the costly price.  When the bill came, all of our mediocre disappointments were felt more keenly.  Overall impression was that our favorite items on the menu were potato-based.  Eh?
author: Virginia K.

description:
Fail to plan. Plan to fail.

This perfectly sums up most of our evening. We decided to be spontaneous and drive into the city from Marin with no plan of where to eat. Not a good idea when you have a hungry 3 yo in the car with you. My phone was not working with opentable and either was yelp for some reason so I resorted to the GPS to find a seafood restaurant.

Well Anchor and Hope popped up so I called and made a reservation. When we got there, it was not what I was "hoping" for unfortunately. It looks like a restaurant geared toward large groups, and expense accounts...not a sunday evening dinner with the family. The restaurant was about 25% full when we arrived at 6:30PM. The waitress was very nice and the hostess was accomodating so 1 star for that...though the food did take FOREVER to arrive after the appetizer.

The food was very good. Our tuna tartare was  light and flavorful. My husband had the seared ahi w/ bacon flavored black eye peas, and I had the petrale sole. Now we both wanted to order something iight, but these portions were so tiny...especially for the price at $29 and $27. These looked more like tasting menu portions. I actually ate everything on my plate which I never do.

The total bill for 1 app., 2 entrees, 1 childrens pasta, 1 champange and 1 beer was $124, which to me is very overpriced for what we actually ate.

The night before we had 2X the drinks and 2 apps and 2 desserts at Bungalow 44 in Mill Valley for $15 less, and  much better food and atmosphere,

I doubt I would ever go back here for dinner. Its not good enough for the prices. I might check it out if I was invited and someone else was paying.
author: susan c.

description:
I had a great meal at Anchor and Hope. 
The appetizer, entree and dessert were spot on.  Our server was bubbely, effecient and knowledgeable, even the support staff were great. The wine list was impressive and the room is terrific, it's hard to believe it was once a muffler shop.
Why then only 4 stars?  Because they add 4% to the check for employees health insurance.  It's the employers responsibility to provide health insurance for their employees not mine.  
That nice tip would have been 4% bigger.
author: Richard L. D.

description:
Anchor: What's in the stomach of an East Bay guy when he leaves after enjoying four courses of some of The City's finest seafood in a design-forward atmosphere perfectly paired with a couple of bottles of Napa whites.

Hope: What's in the head of an East Bay guy who is pining for a seafood joint of this caliber on the east side of the tunnel.
author: Tim O.

description:
I've always wanted to try this place out since I saw them get mentioned a few years ago on one of Food Network's "Best Thing I Ever Ate" episodes and they said to try the "Warm Sea Urchin with Dungeness Crab".

I finally came to eat dinner for my birthday here and let me say, the Warm Sea Urchin with Dungeness Crab DID NOT disappoint!  If you have to order one thing from their menu, you have to order this!  My party also ordered a couple of fish entrees and they were cooked perfectly!

Personally, the only reason why I did not give this five stars is that they only serve wine and beer.  I have no problem drinking either, but at that point of the evening, I wanted something a little stronger like Scotch.

Other than that minor thing, great eats!  Enjoy!
author: Jason T.

description:
We took my BFF here a few weeks ago to celebrate her bday and we all loved it. The service was wonderful. The staff was absolutely attentive, knowledgeable, and friendly. The atmosphere is inviting and decor is super cute. 

They have a great selection of wine and beer but unfortunately not a full bar. We shared a bottle of the 2009 Honig Sauvignon Blanc. Her bf also had the Brewdog IPA and Three Philosophers. Our beverages complimented all of the food we ordered very nicely. 

To start, we had the Kumamoto and Pearl Point oysters from the W. Coast and fried calamari. I'm not very familiar with oysters but our server thoroughly explained and walked us through the selection. Both were amazing. 

For the entrees, we ordered the rock cod, battered cod, lobster roll and crab remoulade. I had the rock cod which came with pork belly and clams and thought the combination went really well. The presentation was very nice especially the lobster roll. 

For dessert, we had the lemon cake which tasted a little bitter. This was our least favorite but we really enjoyed the after dinner port and stout. Wish L.A. had an Anchor & Hope!
author: Hanh S.

description: During my visit, this place was difficult to find due to construction in the area.  However, it was worth the search.  This place is pricey.  If the food is good, I don't mind paying.  The dishes here are D-elicious!  The service is fantastic.  Parking is not easy to find.  You drive around searching for a meter.  The Lobster Roll...is to write home about.  Actually, you better tell everyone.
author: Veronica V.

description:
It's hard to get excited about a place whose fish selections are very limited an uninteresting - at least for lunch. 

(Skip the next paragraphs if you don't care about my fish rant)

I will admit that this review is also a rant about politically correct seafood, and I feel most places are missing out on a wonderful selection of fish which is both sustainable and delicious, but is skipped due to lack of market recognition. I was hoping for this kind of experimentation from Anchor and Hope, but I expected too much.

While I was deciding over a tuna sandwich, fish tacos or a salmon sandwich, I asked what type of salmon it was. "Wild Alaskan Salmon". This is a red flag, as it will mean a salmon with very low market value and an off-flavor. I ordered it anyways, and upon tasting it was very clearly a chum salmon. This is a throw-away fish in Alaska, but when you add a sustainable and healthy label on it, we happily pay $16 for it on a sandwich.

(You can start reading again here)

Despite this, my Salmon sandwich was very well prepared, and there were nice comments from around the table about the tuna sandwich and the burger. It's a tasty place to eat, but not worth the price all the time knowing what I know.

The dinner options look slightly more interesting, so I may try it out.
author: Ryan V.

description:
For me, the highlight of Anchor & Hope were their non-alcoholic bevies, and I don't mean that as some sort of backhanded diss. I really really enjoyed their creative selection of non-boozey refreshments, including my personal fave: a high quality ginger beer. 

I also enjoyed the wood, fish, nautical interior. It made me feel like I was at the beach. 

Oh yes, they do have food. I went with the fish tacos, and I had no problem eating up all three. The fish was fried, but tasted fresh. The table also had a shared plate of onion rings, which for me are hard to do wrong, but they were supposed to be an appetizer. Instead, they came out with our meals.

Speaking of which, our service was a little lazy and the food took a long time to hit the table, so if you have somewhere you need to be, this might not be the place for you. A little stronger service, and we would be closer to a 4.
author: Misti Y.

description:
I'm not sure if it's the personal tie I feel to this restaurant or what, but frankly, this might be the best restaurant in the City. That's right. I said it. And I meant it too.... 

On a recent visit back to the city I once called home, we were sure to make reservations here for a late Friday evening meal. I love the atmosphere, and the friendly staff, and the professionalism of this place almost as much as I love their BEER LIST! HOLY COW! This has got to be the most diverse, highest quality, and most awesome beer selection in the city. Stuff on tap, stuff in the bottle, its just mind blowing.....seriously. Mind. Blowing. 

Being near an ocean for the first time in months, I had a hankerin for some oysters and A&H did not disappoint. And when I eat oysters, I drink black beer. That's just what I do. So naturally after perusing their previously mentioned extensive beer list, I opted for a local Oakland brewery Linden Street and their "Burning Oak Black Lager". Wow. This beer is amazing, and while I know its not the restaurant that should receive the credit for this fine lager, they get the credit for having it...and having it on TAP no less. Brilliant. Oysters and Black Beer people, trust me..... 

After several Black Lagers and even more oysters, it was time to move on to the entrees. Everything was prepared well and tasted great. Again, moving down the beer list I found a great German Pils to go with my fish and chips. A few more of those Pils' and the evening was complete. 

The meal was not cheap, but as I've said, I just LOVE this restaurant. Beer geeks and sea-foodies alike should make this a must try and be sure to try the black beers!
author: Matt M.

description:
Came here for lunch. mMm. It's definitely located in a small little alley so I'm sure people keep wandering around looking for it. It looks like a grimey wharf export warehouse from the outside. However, it's definitely nice and elegant inside with a touch of San Francisco IF that makes sense. 

We tried out the angels on horseback and these are DELICIOUS. Bacon wrapped oysters? How could you go wrong? Oh right... when the bacon is super salty and overpowering... but they weren't. They were cooked perfectly and the oyster was piping hot. The bacon was just perfectly crispy. 

I had their famous lobster roll on brioche. DELICIOUS. The lobster was fresh and clean. It was dressed up a bit but it was perfect and not overpowering. The bread was buttered and melt in your mouth. It comes with slaw, which I'm not that big of a fan, and it comes with kettle chips dressed in SOME kinda seasoning. They were completely addicting. 

I'd come back. They have a large selection of beers. On their dessert menu, they have an option for beer and cheese. Yes, you read that right! BEER and cheese. Fancy!
author: Jeannie L.

description: If you do not try this, or if you do not rate them 5 stars, I will fight you to the death. Amazing food and beer selection.  Not ordering the Bollywood Mussels or the Bruery's Mischief (if still on tap) would be a crime against humanity. Wait til I start using hyperbole. Also: Dustin rocks!
author: Justin S.

description:
Most younger diners won't complain about the noise level, but I found it excessive.  You could not hold a normal conversation in this high ceiling, brick wall restaurant, but that is not to say it wasn't attractive. Both the presentation of the food (which arrived hot) and the general ambiance were pluses.  

The monkfish stew is not very special, but their clams with basil was a great appetizer.  Too much sea salt ruined the crusty bread, but the double chocolate beer was fabulous.  It was a restaurant of contrasts and will probably improve weekly because it is so new.
author: Lynn S.

description:
Stopped in on a cold, rainy night, and the place was packed and appeared to have no available seating. The manager (we later learned that his name is Danny) quickly walked over and asked if we'd be OK with seats at the bar. Oh, yes, we were. We sat at the far end, where it was quite roomy and actually sort of intimate. 
The food was fantastic (see below), but the most remarkable thing about our time there was Danny and his attentive, professional wait staff. That old-school, effortless-looking graciousness and attentiveness elude most restaurants today, even the really nice ones. But Anchor & Hope may be an exception, because the manager and staff made us feel like we were guests at a festive dinner party. 
About our food:  We started out with half a dozen oysters and frites (french fries) served with mayonnaise and ketchup as well as a bottle of vinegar to mix into the mayonnaise, which I think the Belgians do and which is DELICIOUS. Danny suggested a glass of champagne with our fries, saying that fried food with the clean taste of champagne are a perfect pairing. He was so right. Oysters were icy cold and weren't attached to their shells, so we could tip them right out of the shells into our mouths. Because I like a strong brine taste, I preferred the Cotuit, Mass., oysters to their western brethren. For the entree, we split a dungeness crab filled with dirty rice, both of which were excellent (rice wasn't overly Cajun-spicy). But if you like a whole lotta garlic, you'll love the butter slathered on the crab. The only misses came at dessert time: The cookies were large but average, and our espressos were cold, which I've since learned has something to do with a mistake during preparation of the "espresso extraction." But the warm pumpkin bread pudding with marshmallow cinnamon sauce were absolutely over-the-top tasty.
author: Felicia S.

description:
Our friends were in town and we tried to get a table at our fav restaurant The Salt House on a Sat night with no reservation. Yes silly us. So it was either a 45min wait or they offered us a table at their sister restaurant Anchor & Hope. We thought we'd give it a try so we went over.

I ordered Cod Fish, Pork Belly, Manilla Clams (that was one dish) and very small portions of each item. The pork belly was perfection. I wish there were more than two bites! The other two items in the dish were okay. Cod Fish was bland and the clams were very fresh but otherwise not much else to report.

My husband got the Trout (also quite small) and it was decent. Nothing mind blowing.

We also started with the Salmon tartar topped with roe. It was fresh but otherwise kind of lacking. Surprising when there was avocado and wasabi in it... it still managed to be kind of bland. 

Our friends go the lobster roll and sea urchin (which they are famous for apparently) and they said it was amazing. 

So my guess is just order those the two items our friends got. Hahaha.

From the food we had I say just get a few drinks at the bar and wait for a table at The Salt House. It is worth it.
author: becca w.

description: The oysters & wine were delicious! Very nice atmosphere! I came here after a happy hour and our group continued to have a fun time while here.
author: Janine D.

description: Quaint seafood restaurant in a small street (Minna) behind Market/Mission. Girl at front desk was extremely pleasant and helpful. Waiter was very pleasant, even when he found out I don't drink alcohol. Service was 5/5 and food was 4/5. A bit noisy, but in a lively manner. A bit pricey for the quality but still worth going there. I'll be back..
author: Bomi J.

description:
Like many others I came here for the happy hour.  With $1 oysters, you really can't go wrong.  $4 pints and $5 glasses of wine and this is an affordable treat in a great location in SOMA/ downtown.  The real delicacy here are the "angels on horseback" which are the oysters meat wrapped in bacon then deep fried....yes it tastes exactly how it sounds.  

The decor of Anchor and Hope fits its menu selection fairly well. I will definitely be back here not only for the happy hour but also to try out what dinner has to offer...
author: Natan O.

description:
Came here for lunch on a whim. Okay not that much of a whim, since I've been planning to go after bookmarking it. We originally wanted to have dinner because after checking out the menu online, I was all excited about the sea urchin. The lunch menu is condensed but still delicious and no sea urchin! 

I like the discreet location. Make sure when you're walking down Minna to look up, other wise you'll miss the Anchor & Hope sign. My bf and I were there around 1pm, not busy at all, so we were seated right away. We were served with water quickly but our actual waitress took a bit long but she was very friendly. We had the Point Reyes oysters (per the suggestion of my bf, he knows oysters, I just know they're deliciously slimey), fried clam (much better than calamari) to start off with. The oysters were excellent! Can't go wrong with food that's gray! For the entree, I had an the maple trout salad with poached quail egg and anchovy dressing. That sure is some salty shit boy howdy! The trout was really good. The salad is $12 and very tiny. My bf had the grilled sardine sandwich, with homeade potato chips, which were also delicious.

They have lots of different beers to choose from, I really liked The Three Philosophers (I think thats what it's called). It has a subtle cherry flavor!

About $78 for 2 peeps. Bring a date here, you'll dazzle him/her. Then go for a drink at Harlot down the street and you'll dazzle them right into your crotch!

I'm definitely coming back for dinner.
author: Tatiana D.

description:
Again, spotty service, but a little bit better than last time. At least we *saw* our server multiple times! He was hard to track down more than once, but our tea glasses were filled within a reasonable amount of time and the check didn't take a gazillion years.

I reeeeally wanted to order the lobster roll, but went with a shrimp poboy instead for variety. The shrimp were delicious fried balls of juiciness, stuffed into a nicely baked brioche roll with some tangy pasta/slaw type of condiment. Whatever it was - I wanted a bowl of it. The butter lettuce and tomato only complemented the already-delicious ingredients.

We also split an order of onion rings with jalapeno aioli. To that I say eff the onion rings - I'll drink the aioli!

Perhaps they're just understaffed at lunch all the time? Either way, our server was obviously working his ass off and simply didn't have the time to babysit each of his tables. I guess I have to accept, move on and enjoy the place for what it's worth.
author: Nikki B.

description: Started off with Oysters and beers. The beer selection at Anchor & Hope is ridiculous! They must have over 50 types of beers. The oysters were awesome, very fresh. The entrees were amazing. I got the Pacific Cod and my friend got the Scallops. I'll admit I was very satisfied and full by the end of the night, only down fall was how slow it was, but I guess I can't complain too much since the restaurant was pretty packed. It was a Monday when I went, can't imagine what the weekends are like....
author: Cody M.

description:
I so wanted to enjoy Anchor and Hope but at the end of the day it just didn't.  I really liked the atmosphere and had high expectations because of good dinners at Town Hall and Salt House but the food just didn't deliver.  

The drink menu was pretty extensive and the beer selection great and the menu looked and sounded great but nothing really stuck out in being fantastic.  The lobster roll hardly had any lobster on it and it was expensive ($25) for that.  I tried one of the bacon wrapped oysters even though I'm not a fan of oysters and wasn't impressed and either were the big oyster fans in our group.  The desserts weren't anything to write home about either.

The service was very good but overall for a pretty expensive meal it wasn't really worth it.
author: Blake B.

description:
Best lobser roll that I have ever eaten.  I had this sandwich nearly three years ago when I was an intern on Howard and Main, but could not remember the freaking name of the place, now I remember, and I am beyond happy.  

BEST LOBSTER ROLL EVER!  You know those stores and restaurants that always say they have "The Best..." or the "The Greatest..." and you are unsure of what the source is or how it's judged, I am going to be as clear as possible:

ANCHOR AND HOPE HAS THE BEST LOBSTER ROLL IN THE WORLD AT ANY POINT IN TIME THE WORLD HAS EXISTED.
author: Min P.

description:
i really wanted to love anchor and hope. it's just so darn close to where i live that i had high hopes this local restaurant would be my go-to spot. unfortunately my overall dining experience was only a solid 3.5 yelp stars. 

5 stars for the outstanding service. our waiter was friendly, helpful and attentive. even the hostess was welcoming and cheerful. sometimes at these types of places you don't get the upfront hello when you walk in. not at anchor and hope, they greet you right away. oh and when the manager (i think) came by to pick up our tab, he asked if we enjoyed our meals and thanked us for stopping by -- again a very nice gesture.

4 stars for the creative and fun decor. loved the nautical theme and exposed brick walls.

3.5 stars for the food overall. our waiter our waiter did a great job of recommending a half of dozen of fresh oysters to try. we liked them but missed the generous portions of freshly grated horseradish from our recent vancouver trip.

the bf liked the urchin dish but thought there was too much (mashed) potatoes vs. uni and crab. the bf ordered the seared ahi tuna and thought it was on the salty side. i had the sea bass and it was decent but maybe alittle too much butter for my liking. i did enjoy the ramps though. i really enjoyed the bread offering. it comes in a paper bag and it's the french epi bread -- one of my favorite baguette rolls.
 
we were too full to try any of the desserts but maybe next time?
author: Helen Y.

description:
Anchor & Hope is a new fav.. They actually have one of the most solid beer selections in the city.  Had a couple of apps and the steak wid my homie Jeff, and we throughly enjoyed our culinary and beverage experience.

Great lunch menu and solid dinner menu.  Try the bourbon beer cocktail at lunch.. whewww... Definitely gives you a great buzz and complements your meal well.

Great service and good food..
author: Carlo M.

description: This place rocks.  My friend and I came here on a late Thursday night around 9 pm, and we were able to get quickly seated.  Although it took awhile for them to get around to serving our table, the food more than made up for it.  I ordered half a dozen of the Skookum oysters, and they were DELICIOUS.  The cocktail sauce on the side is delicious, too.  I also had the clam chowder, which was tasty as well.  This was a great treat, and I really like the quaint alley locale.  I'll hopefully be back soon!
author: Mel G.

description: Really good restaurant, would rate it higher but for the price/value proposition.  Had the traditional mussels (excellent) and the lobster roll (also excellent).  Service was good, not great, but all in all fine.  Nothing wrong but the price.
author: John R.

description:
Upon walking in I was immediately struck by the decor of the restaurant. While nautical it also had a strong hangar/garage vibe but still maintained a strong sense of classiness. Considering how sketchy the street looks on the outside it was a remarkable transition when entering the establishment.

I didn't really order much, had a stout and one of Unibroue's fine brews but as far as beer goes, they've got a nice selection. In addition, they do make some creative cocktails out of the various beers they have on tap which all look pretty good.

The happy hour is definitely work coming for. A half-dozen oysters and a pint of stout for $10? Sounds like a deal to me. The oysters aren't the best you'll have but for the price they are fresh and wash down well with the pint.

The fries are also quite delicious with a hint of garlic and parsley. The aioli also pairs very well with the flavors in the seasoning and they're not too oily. In fact, they have a pretty light and airy taste to them.

I really enjoyed the setting of the restaurant more so than the food as the atmosphere is not overly trendy. It seems like a great place to hit after work to have a few beers with some good friends.

Cheers!
author: Andrew B.

description:
after a day of shopping we headed over to A&H for a happy hour dinner.  

bites:
angels on horseback
2 dozen oysters ($1 a piece)
spicy tuna hand roll

imbibes:
kilt lifter
prohibition

stellar food.  i'll definitely be back again to try out different dishes on the menu!
author: Sheri N.

description: Great place for a business lunch.  Food is well thought out with a lot of options for meat/fish/and veggie lovers.  Great for a business lunch -- Salmon sandwich is a standout, and the fish tacos are really good as well.  They had a soft-shell crab sandwich for a bit as well that was great.  Nice, loud space -- good if you want to have a business chat and don't want to be overheard too much.
author: Trent W.

description: Had dinner here after a show on a Sunday night during the holidays; great decor / space, friendly and knowledgeable staff, and very tasty food.  Sufficient selection of wines, diverse array of beer - certainly enough to satisfy your craving on either side :) My recommendation would be to spend money on the raw bar items and appetizers - the full courses are good, but can't rival the freshness of the oysters (for instance).  A little pricey, but well worth the $!
author: Bradley O.

description:
My husband and I have really been into fish and although they had a small selection the entrees hit the mark. 

The chips in the beginning (the substitute for the Acme bread, which you can still request) was fun and unexpected. 

The appetizer, I had the ceviche, was full of flavor and not fishy smelling. My husband had the grilled shrimp special and it was also full of flavor and a more than decent portion.

My entree was the flounder. It was excellent! My husband had the whole fish and it was really good. I was picking off his plate. 

The beer selection was extensive. The nice part was they grouped them in categories from light to dark and bodiness. I wasn't sure between two and the waitress brought me a taste of each. 

Service was more than good. Our waitress was knowledgeable, didn't rush us (because I was undecided), and when I asked her what she would recommend for appetizer she didn't say "well, what are you in the mood for" or "what kinds of foods do you like?" She gave me her top two. Bus boys were great. 

I didn't give the 5th star because there was just something missing somewhere -- could be that the water came out room temperature, could be when the second waitress brought the food she didn't explain the dish, or could be the tables were really close together and the I was nervous every time the bus boy had to pick up something from our table. 

I will return.
author: Jane K.

description:
Great Stout... Great shrimp cocktail... Great oyster(a little pricy, but that's normal in SF) and wonderful beet salad! Beautiful seasonal ingredients.

We sat at the bar, it was nice and not overcrowded... We will definitely be back!
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
When it comes to Anchor & Hope, the key is to "anchor" yourself to the appetizers and leave little "hope" for the main course. 

We started off with the angels on horseback and calamari, and were pretty impressed. (How can you not be when you fry oysters and then wrap it around with bacon?) Expectations were high well after the appetizers, but that was soon going to fade away into a deep, dark oblivion. 

For my main course, I had the lobster roll. OK, it was fresh, I give them that. But was really nothing special. Here's the recipe: get some lobster tail, pull the meat out, season it well, and jam everything into a toasted brioche bun. BAM! LOBSTER ROLL that will cost you an arm and a leg. It was good, but not worth the price.

I also tried the seafood risotto...which was fresh and pretty decent, but seriously, a little too salty for my liking. I personally have no fondness for constantly reaching for a glass of water as I'm trying to enjoy a $30 plate of food. 

Pricey? Yes. Would I come back again? Yes, but you'll only see me during Happy Hour for those $1 oysters...
author: Blenda L.

description:
This place was extremely disappointing.  I order the bacon wrapped oysters.  They were good.  And then me and my friend got an entrée each.  I got the Cod with Pork Belly, and she got something else.  Both were pretty horrible.  The fish and pork were both very dry.

In summary, dinner for two is $100+ bucks but I've been more satisfied coming out of a Red Lobster.  I am very angry at 7x7 for recommending I go to this restaurant.  It does not belong on the list.  I will never go here again.

One positive, they had a great beer selection.
author: Joseph W.

description:
Great service,great menu,awesome beer selection!

Try the:
Angels on Horseback
Warm Sea Urchin
Salmon Pastrami
Fish & Chips
author: Shelley M.

description:
Had a fantastic meal at this place a few years ago, but went back and have to say that I have no intention of ever returning. When we first entered, we let the staff know before sitting that we would need to solve for a gluten-free diet for one diner. They said this would be no problem, then after sitting only offered 1 entree selection and refused to make changes to the menu to accomodate this diner.

- Going down hill
- Unhelpful staff
- Good sea urchin
author: Kelly K.

description: The reason for the low rating is not for the food, or SOME of the staff... It's for the overall experience we had at the restaurant. This past Friday (Aug 7th) myself and a group of about 6 other ladies went to Anchor and Hope after work for their $1 oyster Happy Hour, and to celebrate or coworker leaving the company. Upon arrival (between 430-5) to a semi empty restaurant, we immediately were told that we needed to vacate by 7 because of a 7pm reservation. Not a huge issue... However, it would have been more customer friendly to KINDLY mention this tidbit, or simply seated us in the area that hadn't been previously reserved... Strike 1. Then a hostess (the short one with curley hair, NOT the one with a geometric nail design.) came over to take our order. When one of the women in our group attempted to order food, she rudely cut her off and said "I am only taking your drink order", and gave her a less than pleasant look... Strike 2. We had 3 more people join our table. Multiple wait staff came to check in with us periodically, which could explain the reason for the issue that occurred when the bill arrived. BUT, it doesn't justify the waitress' reaction. When the bill arrived, we were charged for 5 orders french fries, instead of 3. The oysters, alcohol were fine. When I very politely mentioned this to the waitress (slender, with chemically dyed red hair worn in a bun) she immediately got defensive. She then lied, semi-yelling, and claimed she brought over "all 4 orders of fries" because she "remembers" doing so, and told me I could talk to her manager. We only received 3 fries, and unless she transformed into two Latino gentlemen, she never brought fries to our table. She took off the two orders, but it didn't make up for her and the curley haired hostess' behavior. The women I mentioned pretty much ruined what could have been an otherwise pleasant experience at the Anchor and Hope restaurant. I recognize people can have bad days, but we weren't the cause... All we did was walk in.
author: Shirell B.

description:
Imagine my disappointment when I last visited Town Hall to find my longtime favorite, fish & chips, was no longer on the menu!  So the waiter recommended Anchor & Hope, the sister restaurant devoted to seafood.

I really enjoyed the Anchor & Hope decor.  So much that I swear I felt a clean ocean breeze upon entering.  Our party of three was seated immediately, at a wobbly table that seemed just bad enough to become a minor nuisance.  The waiter noticed our displeasure (no, we weren't snobby about it!  we were showing a "we can adjust" body language) and even shook the table himself to see how bad it was, but rather than move us he disappeared suddenly.  To our surprise he returned with a slice of cork to slide under the faulty leg.  So instantly our hopes were raised for excellent service.  Alas, matey, from there the service level plummeted to the ocean floor.

Our water jug went empty for long stretches of time, and I was never asked if I wanted a refill of my delicious iced tea.  Our waiter seemed to be tending the bar for much of the time, despite nobody being seated at the bar during lunch.  A few staff members were running around clearing tables and filling water jugs.  They would bring out new water jugs for parties who were just seated, then walk past our table, acknowledge that our jug was empty, then do nothing about it.

My fish & chips came out with no ketchup, and the waiter never came back to ask how we were doing.  I used the tasty tartar sauce concoction to dip my fries and it actually worked out quite well so I didn't bother raising a stink over ketchup.  The fries were tasty enough, and the batter around the fish was light the way I like it.  It hit the spot but I'll probably never order it again from here.

I will say that the menu was packed with other options that piqued my interest.  Including the virgin cocktails at the top of the menu, which all sported names consistent with the ocean warehouse theme.

All things considered, Anchor & Hope was better than Salt House and a step below Town Hall.  Town Hall has much better service and better food thus far, but I wonder how my opinion might change on future return visits here.  But Anchor & Hope clearly boasts the nicer venue.

Salt House really props the other two up and shouldn't be mentioned in the same sentence.
author: Gary D.

description: Fantastic food and service.  We ate there last night because we had such  a great meal the night before there.  Yep.  Two nights in a row.  Highly recommend the salmon.  Their oysters were top notch.  Fresh flavorful and a variety to choose from.  We LOVE this place.  Oh, and get a bottle of the Peay wine.  Or is it Paey?  Good stuff.
author: O. O.

description: First off, let me say that I think people tend to overrate lobster rolls purely because they're impressed by chunks of lobster. Sorry my friend, it takes more than that to impress me. Yes, the freshness of lobster is critical but it takes more than that. The lobster sandwich at Anchor and Hope had that extra something! The bread of the sandwich was just right with a nice crunch. The lobster was fresh and it had a nice balance of mayo with it. They also had an amazing coleslaw (I normally hate coleslaw!) and fresh chips to go with it. Yum!
author: Donna W.

description:
I came here for lunch on a Wednesday w/ 2 collegues.  We shared the calamari, which is only OK if it hadn't been the sauce that came with it.  The Asian sauce definitely made it a little more special. 
I ordered the Prix fixe menu for $22.  

For starter, I got the clam chowder.  It is pretty good - good bacon-taste and the soup itself was more "soupy" rather than creamy, which works for me.  It's not as heavy.  One thing I didn't like about the soup was the potatoes. They were very hard, as if they were not cooked thoroughly enough.

For the main course, I ordered the duck leg.  The duck was tender but way too salty.  I wasn't able to finish it because it was so salty. what a shame.  the duck leg came on a bed of vegetable salad, which was excellent. It consisted w/ spring lettuce, peas, string beans, and baby carrots.  That was good.

For dessert, I had the chocolate blackout cake.  This is good.  It's not dry and not too sweet.

My other 2 collegues got the lobster roll, which was supposed to be their signature dish. The sandwich itself is quite small, about 6 inches or so.  I took a bite of the lobster and it's very creamy.  I think to eat it in one sitting is actually quite filling.  

Total meal with 3 ice teas, including tips = $120. Ouch!
author: Jannie Q.

description:
On New Years Eve, we were scrambling to find a dinner reservation due to the constantly changing number of people in our party (planning groups are a pain!). After browsing through some reviews, we decided on this restaurant. I browsed on yelp and I was pretty excited coming in, especially being a seafood hound myself.

With reservations, we were promptly seated. Service is great and the ambiance is very cozy - dimly lit with little lights here and there. We ordered the bacon wrapped oysters and calamari for appetizers. They oysters were beautifully presented and were delicious, although all I could really taste was the bacon. And really, anything tastes good with bacon. I've had bacon on a doughnut and it was delicious. Calamari was very light and crisp - much better than your average calamari. The good appetizers made up for the terrible bread. Maybe it was because I was overly excited when they brought it to the table in a little brown bag and it was beautifully designed, but the bread was cold and chewy as hell! 

At our table, we had people order the swordfish and the lobster roll. My boyfriend and I shared the lobster roll and a tomato lobster soup. Soup was ok, nothing out of ordinary other than the lobster pieces although a little on the salty side. The lobster roll was very disappointing. The bread was drenched in butter and oil which made it soggy near the center. The lobster inside was ok - I felt like I could've bought something just as good on the streets. The chips that came with it were not very crispy and bland! None of my friends were impressed by the swordfish either. Maybe it was because we came on New Years Eve on a Saturday night when they are grudgingly cooking in the back, or maybe it was because I didn't order oysters which was their specialty, but it was overall not a very tasty experience.

Overall, place is more on the pricey side (~$30 per plate) with ok food and small portions (our boys decided to pick up some fast food after we ate....after their swordfish and 3 plates of appetizers between 6 people!).  Corking fee is $20, although if you buy a bottle they will take off the fee. Service and ambiance is great. Maybe I'll give this place another shot on a better day, but probably not.
author: Viv T.

description:
Anchor and Hope is good but really should be a lot better.

For the good, great interior design with a happening crowd. Tall exposed ceilings and rafters which takes the boathouse theme to new levels. Interesting artwork and decor (cool lamps above the bar that look like gigantic fish eyes etc). Excellent beer and wine selection. While there are no spirits, there are literally about 100 different beers to try many from Belgium, Japan, and obscure parts of America. I had 2 great pilsners. The glassware was funky and matched whatever beer we selected. The food menu offered a great array of seafood and it was a challenge to decide what to order.

That said, there were quite a few hiccups that prevented me from going higher than 3-stars. First although we had 8pm reservations (for 3 people so not a huge party), it took 40+ minutes to be seated at our table. I understand waiting 10 min or so, but 40+ is a bit obnoxious especially when you have a reservation. The food was a bit of a let down largely because of my very high-expectations after eating at Anhor & Hope's sister restaurant (Salt House). It wasn't bad by any means, but was just OK. My pepper seared ahi was gorgeously presented but was just blah...not enough flavour. My appetizer (yellow-tail sashimi) was also just OK (see the recurring theme). My friends did polish off their jambalaya though.

3 stars overall---I wouldn't go out of my way to recommend Anchor & Hope but am open to trying it again.
author: Dave S.

description:
I heart Anchor and Hope.  My girlfriends took me here for my bday dinner and I was thoroughly satisfied with every minute of our experience here (except for the fullness we all felt in our tummies)!

Let me start off by saying that our server was exceptional!  It was a busy night, but he was able to make sure we had a pleasurable dinner!  Very personable, funny and full of character!  Thanks!

-I'm not a huge fan of oysters, but when they are fried and wrapped in smoked bacon, I'll make an exception.  The Angels on Horseback were...different...but the bacon made the oyster taste bearable.  I'll try anything with bacon...food that is :)
-The Anchor and Hope fries were yummilicious.  We couldn't get enough of them!  
-I had the Alaskan Halibut and it was pretty good.  The sauce had a hint of truffle in it, which made me sad because I was too full to finish it.  
-The Seared Scallops were good as well.  What made it better was the bed of couscous it was laying on.  
-The Seared Ahi Tuna had great flavor, but I felt it was a bit thick and heavy...

And finally, the birthday dessert-Blue Bottle Coffee Milkshake...Again, I'm a huge sucker for Blue Bottle Coffee, but it was good and the perfect touch of caffiene to get us to our next destination (although the tiny espresso helped as well!)

Overall, great dinner and healthy portions, so go hungry!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
My husband and I came here based on recommendation from a friend. We were visiting San Francisco for a weekend getaway. 

I love that the location was somewhat down an alley, but when you walked in the door the places was buzzing. It had a great feel and good energy. The decor was pretty cool as well. My husband and I kept admiring the different arrangements of lighting.

We both love seafood as well as beer, craft beers to be specific so we were both very excited! 

Service didn't start off on the best foot, but we were talking so we looked passed it. We ordered beers and decided to order about 5 to 6 different things off the menu so we could get a wide variety of what they had to offer, since we were on vacation and may not be back.

We were very impressed with the beers we ordered, however, our food came out in a very random order. They did give us the wrong food, but insisted we keep it and wouldn't be charged (which we weren't) they also forgot one of our orders as well (again they brought it out late and didn't charge us). My husband and I don't feel comfortable doing that so we insisted on leaving extra money, whether that went towards the tip or food, didn't matter. 

The food was delicious, we ordered the catalan mussels which were great, but a little over salty.  The ceviche mixto which was heaven and one of my favorites. We also had oysters (Riocky Port and Kusshi) both wonderful, however, I enjoyed the Kusshi. The calamari was good, but again to me over salted. We also split the lobster roll, which was very good, but not the best I've had. We did order the cream of asparagus soup, but that got lost in the mix.

Overall, we had a very nice time, great beer selection, good food, but only ok service. If we head back to San Francisco we may stop in again for a beer.
author: Kristine L.

description:
We were referred to Anchor and Hope by their sister restaurant since they had an hour wait. We were able to find seats at the bar which was fine for us, but I recommend you make reservations. 

We had the Sea Urchin and BBQ Shrimp appetizers. The urchin was delish. Very friendly staff and good decor.
author: Lidia Z.

description: I was mediocre after my first visit to A&H but this time I really liked it. Got the lobster roll on brioche, asked for salad instead of chips, and enjoyed the close slaw. I don't remember getting bread in the past but we got bread similar to the ones served at Bouchon restaurant (with the leaf design), only better. It was served in a brown bag which I think absorbed the moisture. It was super fresh and the soft butter was SO good. Nice ambiance and decor...spacious and high ceilings.
author: Emm C.

description:
Scents of the salt licked Monterey coast accent this open space. 

Hidden along Minna Street, Anchor and Hope is a venue that actually finds comfort in the San Francisco fogs that wraps itself around the entrance.

A clean interior with high ceilings, the intricacies aren't found on the table tops but more on their plate and the genuine service offered.

**Quick note, no liquor is served here, but they more than make up for it with their vastly deep beer list and handsome wine offerings. **

Sparked by a months long intrigue to their hailed "Angels on Horseback" ( Smoked bacon wrapped Oysters ), an order was delivered to the table with eager anticipation.

Heaven sent, the very image of food delight was beautifully crafted in this dish. Lines of aroma skipped along the table, and visually, the line up of these 'angels' were bound to a culinary fairytale.

The outer crunch of the bacon sealed the richness and texture profile of the oyster masterfully offering a very unique combination of flavor and structure. Rather than reading any more words about this dish, Just. Go.

The Smithwick's Battered Cod with Rosemary and Thyme potato wedges were by far the best fish and chips dish I've had in San Francisco.  

The dish will blow you away in size and taste. Reaching back to the origin of this dish, the cod is fried to golden perfection and piled high. Very High. The accompanying tartar sauce could make you an addict and you'd welcome it.

Anchor and Hope is a successful marriage of the sea and a simple concept. Nothing too elaborate interior wise, and lets the kitchen speak. As all venues should, right?
author: Mike K.

description:
We went here for a date night, and I must say, it's definitely one of the better restaurants in San Francisco.  Yes, I know that's a pretty large claim, but there are two things on this menu that merit the 4 star rating I'm giving.

The first thing I must talk about is the famous "Angels on Horseback".  As angelic as it sounds, they are pretty naughty at the same time.  They describe this dish as "Smoked Bacon Wrapped Oysters with a Remoulade Sauce."  Forget all that...they should just say "orgasm in a bite."  If you're an oyster fan like I am, I'm all about trying new and exciting ways to eat those little slimy, salt-watery, little aphrodisiacs.  As cliche as it sounds "bacon makes everything better."  Real talk.

The second item I must call out is the Sea Urchin.  This isn't your mama's Uni.  They actually take the Sea Urchin and mix in with Dungeness Crab in a Lemon Beurre Blanc sauce.  As you bite into it, the flavors marry with one another and dance on your tongue.  As for the presentation, they serve this in the Sea Urchin's own shell...kinda morbid, but whatever.  It looks pretty damn cool.

Sure I had other things for dinner, and they were good, but those two things are enough to make me come back over and over again.
author: Mark P.

description: This place is amazing, it's not cheep but so worth it. The spicy dipping juice for the calamari was so good, oysters - amazing and as an entree I the battered cod, really good. A friend had the octopus and raved, next time. Highly recommend... Oh and they have many premium 10-12% ales and stouts. Perfect.
author: Frank V.

description:
I really enjoyed Anchor & Hope the first time I visited (~two years ago), and the second time I visited (~six months ago), but this last trip was not so hot. 

The wine was very good (and pricey), ambiance was still phenomenal, wait staff were attentive and pleasant, and appetizers (calamari, Cajun shrimp) were tasty. My entree, however (flounder, I think, served with potatoes and a clam scampi), was really rich (overseasoned, and with a bit too much butter).
