Among my family, everyone ate the appetizers, and nobody (but me) was sick later that night, which I assume had to have been my entree.

Needless to say, I don't think I'll venture back to Anchor & Hope...
author: R. Harrison E.

description: Went for lunch yesterday.  Had the seasonal salad (heirloom tomatoes, frilled peaches, burrta) it was very tasty.  The portion size for the $13 price was pretty small.  Not a bad option for a work lunch, but be warned you will be left hungry.
author: Sheetal P.

description:
The service is quite disappointing.  It all starts with a hostess that doesn't seem to know how to allocate tables or prioritize customers.  I guess not everyone is cut out for a GED.  The waiter started slow, but was so quick with the check.

The food starts with good ingredients.  However the preparation misses some basic things.  If you are going to fillet the bones out of a fish it isn't that hard to check for remnant bones.  For their price point, I expect there to be no bones.  I guess they are too busy with their mediocre, yet trying-too-hard presentation.

Whats up with serving cider in a champagne flute?

Not impressed.
author: H C.

description:
Lovely atmosphere. 
Bartenders were a lil loomy...but sweet.
Great beer and wine selection.
Bacon wrapped oysters!! Need i say more?
Salomon tartare with avocado was great...avocado didnt seem real, more like the paste u buy...buttt that doesnt mean i didnt lick the plate.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Previewed:
oysters + bacon = who was the matchmaking genius responsible for this union?
$1 oyster specials

Indulged:
Sea scallops - nicely seared and melt-in-your-mouth
Lobster Roll - really complimentary flavors between the roll and the lobster but I would say sort of lacking on the lobster filling

Imbibed:
2  glasses of beer on tap for him
2 glasses of Scarpetta Pinot Grigio for her

Total bill came out to a little less than $150. Too steep (for us) for a Monday night especially since we left still hungry. I think the standout for me about this place is the actual space. Really well-done and would consider taking out-of-town guests to this spot or come back and just order a bunch of small plates and of course the oysters.
author: Jane K.

description:
I had heard about Anchor & Hope from a colleague after I couldn't get reservations at Town Hall. So I came here with a small group of people from the office with reservations and we were seated promptly. The place was pretty packed for being on a little hidden street, but I think the fact that they're related to Town Hall and Salt House add to that. I liked the decor of this place: the warehouse style, with lofted ceilings, and nautical flair. 

For a drink, I had a lime rickey which was extremely tart, but I love tartness so it worked out well. It had a huge kick to it which was pretty awesome. I liked that the servers poured water from little water jugs. It definitely went well with the nautical theme. The bread and butter was great, I love it when restaurants have good bread! For the main meal, I had a rock shrimp po' boy, which was pretty delicious, but nothing to rave about. Overall, the meal was very average. I think I'm going to need to try the lobster roll next time.

My only complaint is the time it took to serve our food. It took roughly 45 minutes from the time we ordered to the time the last person received their food. So if you're on a time crunch, avoid this place during the busy meal times.
author: Viola L.

description:
The food here is fresh and delicious.  The service is great!  It does get a bit busy so I would suggest a reservation.  

You MUST order the sea urchin appetizer.  Even  if you have never had sea urchin, or you don't like seafood...whatever.  I don't think there is a person on the planet who would not love this.  

The main dishes are all good but slightly overpriced...so order the sea urchin and treat yourself!
author: Jessica J.

description:
Giving this place 4 stars because of Happy Hour (would have been 5 if the cheap booze and appetizers were extended), which is literally an hour, it starts at 5 - 6PM.  

Had the angels on horseback, and if you love bacon, you'll love these.  I love bacon, I love Oysters put them together and it's an orgasm in my mouth.  DELICIOUS!!  For Happy Hour, they were $2 each, needless to say I had quite a few.  Wine was $5 a glass and other various appetizers were also cheap.

The people are nice, and the bar is a lovely place to hang out and chat.  It was great to stop by here after a visit to SFMOMA.
author: Carol V.

description:
Granted we only had apps here, they just look too goo we just decided to do our own tapas style dinner! We had the shell fish platter, you get one oyster of all the different kinds they have, some clams, crab, lobster, and giant cocktail shrimp! Absolutely delish! Next we had the bacon wrapped oyster and the sea urchin and crab dish (which was amaz-balls!) and I've never had sea urchin before this was definitely the place to try it! 
Atmosphere was really nice! I really like the decoration and the whole atmosphere, the "street" they are located on is more like an alley and you kinda think you walked down the wrong place because it seems like nothing is down there but then you walk in and you are just wow'd by this little gem you feel like you've stumbled upon. 
I would definitely go back and bring friends to try too!!!!
author: S L.

description:
Ever since I heard that Anchor and Hope had this warm uni dish with dungeoness crab over potato puree, I've been dying to come and try this place. Perhaps I hyped this place up WAY too high but I became very uninspired by what was served. 

Service: Was ok. The hostess was nice enough to accommodate for the extra person who came and the wait staff was very nice but our waitress was a bit inattentive.  Nobody came to refill out water jug and it took a "Excuse, we're ready to order" to have someone come over take our order. I'm not a tunneled vision person. I can understand if you're waiting like a 5-6 other tables but the place was not full yet when we were there. 

Food: The major problem for me with the food was the grease and oil factor. And the price we paid for the quality of food, the dining companions and I thought this was definitely not worth it. 

Warm Uni, Dungeoness Crab with potato puree: In theory, this probably deserved a 4 stars. It was creamy, rich, and flavorful. BUT I had to really fish for my uni and when i found it, it was the tiniest piece of uni I've ever had. Smaller than 1/2 the sliver of my pinky. It defeats the purpose that its call an uni dish when it has marginal uni. Nonetheless, it was very tasty and probably the highlight of the meal. 

Angels On Horseback: Everybody is enthusiastic about this.  "it's delicious, decadent." Yea its pretty tasty, but I'm not impressed by it. I think I've had this before a buffet with similar quality. I just wasnt wow'd and don't really get why its on the 7x7 list. 

Lobster Roll: Again, minimal lobster, more roll. I've had an excellent Lobster Roll in Boston for the same price and there was like 2x the lobster, it was succulent lobster. That was not the case at Anchor and Hope. The bioche was crispy but saturated in oil and I just couldn't finish the bread. 

Cod Fish & Chips: Too greasy. It had a very crispy batter and you can taste the beer batter but we had to 'de-flake' the crust to actuall eat it. 
Halibut: This was probably the second most flavorful dish next to the uni dish. It had a combination of tart and sweet, complimented well with the sweet corn. My only issue was that I've had much more juicier and flakier halibut at ISA in Cow Hollow. But overall, this was an above average dish. 

Ahi Tuna Poke: Typical. 

In conclusion: the meal was grease laden and forgettable. I would've like to have opted for something more dependent on flavors than crispy texture. In theory, everything sounded like a good idea but it fell short. I'd come her to try out the warm uni dish during happy hour. Other than that, I don't think I would return.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I'm in the restaurant business, so I was really looking forward to trying another restaurant from the founders of Town Hall...

Sadly after spending over $300 for a party of four last night, I'm on YELP writing a scathing review...

The service was awful... The server, a guy with a beard and shaved head, was someone who should definitely not be in the hospitality business... If he worked in one of my restaurants and a secret shopper had our experience, I would have fired him the next day... This guy had an attitude from the minute he arrived and clearly wasn't interested in helping us or ensuring we would have a great experience... At one point later in the meal, the server disappeared (my guess he was on a break) and another server actually ended up taking our dessert order after we waited for over 10 minutes...

The food was interesting but I'm concerned that the menu design is relying a bit too much on the fryer in the kitchen... More importantly, I'm not sure the BOH is staffed / trained accordingly because we had slow food arrivals the entire evening even thought the restaurant was not full...

The one bright spot was the bar and the beer selection... My compliments to the person selecting the local beers...

Many kinks would have to be worked out before I step foot in this establishment again...
author: Max J.

description:
Okay...so I dined here last weekend.  Here's what we had and some other misc. comments:

Appetizers-
New England Clam Chowder:  nice, thick, creamy, smoky, good flavor
Fried Calamari / Thai Chili Sauce:  they really fried these up nicely.  very crunchy.  sauce was sweet.  had small thai chilis on the side.
Warm Sea Urchin:  Very, very nice. Savory and rich.

Enrtrees:
Spice Crusted Sea Scallops:   scallops were cooked nicely.  kinda of a bland dish though
Smithwick Battered Cod with Rosemary/Thyme Fries:  terrific dish.  the fish was fried to perfection.  fries were a little heavy on the rosemary.
Black Cod with Pork Belly and clams:  disappointment.  dish was very salty and mealy portions.

Dessert:
Pumpkin Icecream / Cake with caramel sauce:  nicely done.  not overly rich.  the caramel sauce was very decadent.  Presentation was cute.

Service:
Adequate.  Our meal was off on the spacing (two of us received entrees 3 minutes before others).  

Ambiance:
Nice casual crowd.  Noise factor was mild.  Didn't have to shout to have a conversation, which is a plus when compared to other restaurants.
author: Derek N.

description:
I've scanned a lot of the reviews over Yelp, and it seems like most of the 3 star reviews and under have 2 critiques in common: underwhelming entrees, and price tags that don't match what you're getting.

I am not of this opinion.

While it's clear that the appetizers (especially the sea urchin) clearly stood out from the rest of the meal, the entrees were certainly not disappointing - large portions, solid execution, good flavor combinations. I would certainly be back.

I've written a more detailed article for examiner, which you can check out by following the Examiner link in my profile.
author: Kelsey E.

description:
You know what I like? Charming service. Tasty food. Lively atmosphere. Anchor & Hope lived up to my expectations and more ... the best restaurant I've been to in SF.

Saturday night. Lively scene. My friend and I had no reservations. The friendly server who happened to be near the door winked at us and helped us score two seats at the bar. From there ... an attentive bartender (NO JOKE-- in San Francisco! Live! No attitude! No joke!) who guided our menu selection. Perfect shrimp ceviche seasoned ever-so-lightly. Perfectly garlic-y broccoli raab. Kampache with avacado slivers. And the sea scallops. Oh where to begin? The sea scallop curry! The perfect amount of couscous! So inventive, so flavorful. 

We ended the meal with the butterscotch creme brulee. Served up with chocolate chocolate chip cookies by the generous dessert chef ... she even snuck me an extra cookie when I rambled on and on to her about my love for them. 

But the night wasn't over. Another one of the bartenders placed our happiness as a priori-- serving up a selection of dessert wines for us to try. The friendliness, the concern for our well-being and ultimately the damn high quality ... you cannot go wrong with Anchor & Hope.
author: Cate P.

description:
Great food - we shared some oysters to start and then I ordered the PEI mussels with frites. Very yummy! Desserts are amazing here - I can't quite recall the name of what I ordered but the Meyer Lemon & Poppyseed cake was wow delicious. 

It's a little staunchey during the lunch hour but if you like your eye candy wearing suits this is the place to come.

The service was decent and the prices were as expected.
author: Leanne S.

description: Given the limited options around the area, there are a lot of business lunches at this place. Food is good mostly but it can get really loud and therefore, not really good for any business conversations. I would come back here for the food though.
author: ZW N.

description:
Beer list gets 4 stars, food 3 stars which gives it a 3 in my book (food before alcohol).

Came here for dinner the other night.  It was hard to get a reservation which was a good sign.  We started with the tuna hand rolls which were fresh and decently flavorful.  For mains, we had the salmon which had a unique preparation but as nothing to write home about.  The other entree was their version of fish n chips, which had a good light batter, but below average fries.  

Service was good.  Did I mention the beer list was great
author: Andrew S.

description: Solid restaurant. Bustling boxy space with a maritime theme serves a great selection of beers, wines, oysters and snacks. To me, the beer list was the most impressive. Servers were flying everywhere; all our dishes arrived quickly and service was remarkably efficient. Despite the oceanic moorings it sometimes felt like we were flying through. The fish was fresh, though in truth it must not have been memorable because I cannot tell you what I ate. Enjoyable.
author: Paul S.

description:
Anchor & Hope has an array of seafood dishes and a raw bar that rotates daily.  I had the pleasure of trying 3 of their delicious appetizers.

First was the Ahi Tuna Poke (sorry for the blurry pic!).  It was prepared in the traditional way, with small cubes of ahi tuna sashimi tossed in a soy-sesame mixture, green onions and sesame seeds.  But it also had cucumber mixed in it, which was a nice cooling contrast to the special hot sauce they served on the side. 

Next up was the acclaimed "Angels on Horseback," smoked bacon wrapped oysters, served with a remoulade sauce.  Need I say more?  This combo screams delicious.  The oysters were tender and the bacon salty and crisp, and the slightly tart sauce complemented the dish well.

Last but not least was the Warm Sea Urchin in the shell, Dungenous Crab, and Pureed Potatoes. Having never had sea urchin before, I was a bit nervous to try it, but I'm really glad I did.  It tasted like butter with a hint of sea salt, and it had a texture similar to pate.  The big chunks of dungenous crab complemented it quite well, and the potato puree balanced it all out.  It was heaven in a bowl, or rather, a shell.
author: Anne A.

description:
Very few occasions in life call for $118 lunches. When your best friend turns 33, you throw caution to the wind, open your wallet and prepare to have a good time at his birthday lunch. Although we entered the restaurant with high expectations, we left Anchor & Hope with anger & disappointment. 

We made reservations for 11:45 in hopes to beat the lunch rush. When we showed up, the place was almost empty. There was a party of 8 enjoying their meal and 2-3 smaller parties. By 12:15, the restaurant was at 100% capacity with people waiting for a table by the door. Why doesn't anyone think of making a reservation for 11:45? 

The restaurant really embraces its nautical theme. I mean, the boat ropes hanging from the rafters and abstract fish paintings are one thing, but starfish paperweight on the hostess' desk and giant red metal canisters are quite another. It's cute, but perhaps they went a bit overboard (pun intended). Well, "if nautical nonsense be something you wish, then drop on the deck and flop like a fish!" 

Our waitress came by and took our drink orders. My friend ordered some kind of a strong Belgian beer served in a wine glass ($10), whereas I opted for my usual: iced tea. My friend also had a few oyster related questions for the server, which she seemed to handle very well. I was sitting there with a blank stare, looking at myself in the mirror. Oysters are not my thing. However, our waitress was as elusive and cold as she was tall and presentable. We could hardly track her down, although it wasn't even her fault. Anchor & hope seemed to have been severely understaffed and slightly unprepared for the lunch rush. 

While my friend was enjoying his single oyster, served with all the accoutrements that one would expect when ordering oysters, I waited for my celery root puree soup. The soup presentation was spectacular: a poached quail egg was placed in the middle of the plate, and then one of the waiter poured the soup from a tiny decanter. If soup were meant to be admired for its aesthetics, this soup would win awards. Sadly, it was as bland and boring as pureed celery root. 

We really wanted to find two different entrees to try, but after rereading the menu for the umpteenth time, we both settled on seared ahi tuna. The standard "our chef prepares tuna rare; is that OK?" question followed, and we both answered that we wanted our tuna as rare as possible. Much to my surprise, the tuna, encrusted with cracked farro, was slightly overcooked. It was medium rare, if you will. It was obvious that they used high quality fish. We also ordered a serving of Anchor & Hope fries, which complemented the fish nicely, despite being over-seasoned. 

To cap off our meal, we decided to share some cobbler-type creation served a la mode. Again, it was an obvious case of form over substance. Beautifully presented in a clay pot, the dessert ($8.50) tasted rather pedestrian and overly sweet. 

As I paid our bill ($101 + tip), I felt a little gypped. I felt as though I had a pretty good $50 lunch, and I was being charged double for it. Perhaps it's different at dinnertime, but I don't see myself coming back here for lunch. $118 lunches should be reserved for special occasions, and Anchor & Hope is just not that special.
author: Yan G.

description:
4 1/2 stars. i was really surprised how good this place is. On the outside, the place seems small, but when u walk in, it has the old wood charm and it's a decent size. 

it's hard to say that u liked everything on the menu, but i realllllly did.

they start you off with a bread in a paper bag, which makes it easy for  you to take home

the "angels on a horseback" (bacon wrapped oysters) were so good. the bacon covered the whole osyster and had a smokey flavor. came with a nice dipping sauce. my friend doesn't eat oysters at all and she ate 2 of them because they are that good

the special was a tuna poke-light and fresh with just enough flavor

the uni with crab was to die for. it came out lookin like a chowder, but the flavors were so good. the uni is a lil cooked, so don't expect a raw uni, but it was just heaven.

the calamari was great too, but i don't like the dipping sauce with it. use the sauce from the bacon wrapped oyster. it's a better match

the fried eggplant, with seafood was a werid combo, but tasted really good with a green spicy sauce.

the cod with porkbelly was just amazing

the brussel sprouts and bacon was great too and the truffle fries with this light mayo sauce was alot but just great

i would come back here anything. a lil on the pricey side, but worth every bite!
author: Karen H.

description:
What a strangely mixed bag (mixed crab pot?) this place is.

FOOD:  Generally (but not uniformly) very good, four-star food.  We focused on small plates -- they have a lot of choices.  Divine clam chowder, sardines, and a side cole slaw that I'll definitely go back for.  But the lobster bisque was too salty for one of my friend's too eat, and I thought the "angels on horseback" (shrimp wrapped in bacon) were surprisingly dry and ho-hum.  Finally, what's with having fish and chips priced at $23?  Guess we really have over-fished cod.

SERVICE: Oy, what to say?  Had a pleasant enough start, but as soon as we'd placed our orders, the server flipped a switch and was a complete ice queen the rest of the evening.  What did we do?  Nothing.  But it was a topic of (hushed) conversation for us.  As others have posted, for these prices, service should be much more professional.  Icy is fine if stately.  But this was the kind of icy you get from a 14-yr-old (I imagine) when you post something nasty about her on facebook.  This is what brings the overall rating down for me.  WTF?  We're still trying to figure it out.

AMBIANCE:  Love the lofted, timbered space, and it was a lovely place to converse.  Lighting left several diners reaching for pocket flashlights, and I truly couldn't see the menu.
author: Brandon B.

description: I had the halibut and the broth it was in was so salty, it made my eyes water.  The salad was arugula, strawberry and goat cheese and for the most part I could count the strawberry pieces on one hand and there were two teeny pieces of goat cheese.  They clearly were busy and the service was like molasses in the winter. I took at least 45 minutes before we placed our order and the wine I ordered at the bar came to our table when we placed our order- ouch.  Sadly, I will not return.
author: Candy T.

description:
Located in an old mechanics warehouse on Minna Street, this restaurant has a lot of charm. Simple metal tables placed strategically in an open space, large ropes hanging from the rafters, and lanterns  hanging in the corners.  

On their website they state that diners can come in a suit or jeans.  True to their word, the vibe was a perfect middle between a happy-go-lucky fish shack and the fine dining expertise of a major seafood restaurant. 

We loved everything about our first encounter- from the bread in a brown paper bag to their selection of Belgium beers.  We wanted to order everything on the menu, but decided on the BBQ shrimp and the Halibut and Tuna entrees.  My boyfriend and I were impressed with the cuts of fish and how perfectly everything was prepared.  The halibut was flaky and white and served with a pea ragout and asparagus.  The tuna was a generous portion over beans and Italian Sausage.  We had to run to a performance and were unable to try dessert.  *sigh* 

Our waiter, Dustin, deserves a special call-out.  In addition to being professional and attentive, his personality and interesting points of conversation made the evening more like dinner at a friends house.  (I had to refuse their wonderful selection of beer and wine because of my allergies, and he encouraged me to start bringing my own flask of whiskey when dining). 

Next time I'm definitely trying the lobster roll.
author: Lisa R.

description: Consistent and delicious EVERY TIME.  I go at least three times per month since it opened.  Thank you A&H team for your outstanding performances in the kitchen and dining room.
author: Denise L. P.

description: Oysters on the half shell were amazing. House made chips. Yum! And the lobster roll with tater tots made me want to  share with my friends it was so good. This was my second time doing here and it was as good as the first time.
author: Michele O.

description:
I dont Yelp often, but just had a great dinner at A&H.  
The seafood platter, great way to start your night.
Beer menu longer than a harry potter novel, check.
Awesome fish with a great little southern twist, but still very light and healthy.
We also had great service and the atmosphere/ music in there is pretty relaxed but still nice.
Fish that good makes me want to eat out more ;-)
author: Cody V.

description:
A solid and reasonably priced restaurant in SoMa/FiDi (at least for lunch).

Pros:
- Oysters were fresh and very flavorful. We got some of the Washington Kumamoto ones (3.50 each I believe)
- Calamari was crispy on the outside and perfectly soft  on the inside. I normally don't like calamari but I really enjoyed this one. The dipping sauce had a good kick to it as well. 
- Fish and chips were perfectly crispy and the fries were seasoned perfectly. The tartar sauce was definitely on a different level than most -- very yummy!
- Salmon tartare was DELICIOUS. The avocado base and seasoned crackers/chips were great accompaniments
- House-made lime rickey (not alcoholic) was yummy. Lots of fresh lime flavor
- Service was great, waters were refilled quickly, and empty plates were cleared within a reasonable amount of time (one of my criteria for good service)

Cons
- Wish they had removed the brown stuff from the salmon in the tartare (you know, the stuff at the bottom of a salmon filet...the fat?)
- There was an awkward gap of time for them to finish bringing out all the entrees for the group. Wish they had just let 4 out of the 5 wait for another 2 minutes and brought them all out together. 

Overall, a great place and reasonably priced (around $40/pp with tax and tip) for lunch.
author: Farhad M.

description:
You may be tempted to visit this place for happy hour. I strongly suggest  you go elsewhere.

I was here tonight celebrating my friend's birthday and we had Happy Hour oysters for $1.00 each and champagne for $5.00/glass. I know, I know.. it sounds like a great deal, but they aren't the first, nor will they be the last restaurant to offer $1.00 oysters. I've frequented other places in the past (like East Side West,who had the same Happy Hour special).  

Needless to say, I know I'm getting a "good" deal on the oysters, however, that does not excuse any restaurant from providing extremely poor and unresponsive service. Special pricing does not equal un-special service.

The oysters were just okay. I mean, I've had better oysters, and Oysters will be Oysters. The mignonette sauce was so-so, but the oysters themselves (though of the tiny variety) were okay, and fresh enough.The broiled oysters, on the other hand, tasted, ummmm... as my friends called it, "Earthy", which I take it, is a euphemism for "Tasted like mud".

Food aside, the poor service really was the nail in the coffin. The place was 98% empty. No one was seated at tables, and there were only two other patrons at the bar. The lady bartender could not be bothered to help, I had to practically flag her down " Excuse me!! EXCUUUUUUUUUUUSE ME!!". I got the feeling we were being deliberately ignored. I even told her nicely that it was my friends' birthday (in an effort to evoke the human side of the ice queen). I got no reaction, no 'happy birthday', no niceties, not even an offer to take my drink order ---- just dull, blank, a combination of Dumb-Snob. .

To make a long story short, it was hard work getting my drink order, and even harder work to get silverware. I got up and got my own napkin, plate and fork, from another table (yes sirree I sure did.). My husband never even got a napkin or silverware.

So will the $1.00 oysters from Anchor and Hope save the day? Um.. No. Not really. Actually, not at all.  In this economy, I am surprised they treat paying patrons like shyte.

I will take my $106.00 bar tab somewhere else. If you don't want my business, then I'll skip the oysters-with-the-cold-cold-attitude, and get clam chowder elsewhere instead. Hot clam chowder might make me feel a whole lot warmer inside, a far cry from the chill I got from the service at Anchor and Hope.
author: Marie F.

description: Anchor and Hope serves Kettle Potato Chips with Mayo instead of bread and butter for the pre-meal bite. This is genius! I just wanted to sit on my couch and watch Bravo when the server placed that at our table. The menu is seafood heavy and so we ordered the Calamari, Crab Cakes, and Tuna Melt. The Calamari was delicious though I thought could have stayed in the fryer for a little longer. The Crab Cake was the highlight of my meal as they set themselves apart with the pouched egg and bacon bits. Egg yolk over crispy crab and bacon bits is probably what they serve for breakfast in heaven everyday  It was amazing. The Tuna Melt was warm and gooey. The salad that accompanied it tasted quite bland. Overall I had a great time and I would come back again to try out the other offerings on the menu. The service was great and attentive. Anchor and Hope's interior is charming with its warehouse loft feel. It would make a great date place or fancy lunch outing.
author: Charlie L.

description:
Bonus star just for the cute name. I think Anchor Hope as a name would be even better, take out the &. :) 

Cute decor, like the fish on the chasing each other, all moving towards the hooks. I'm sure my fisherman sign. other would have enjoyed that painting. Service was good, although our waitress seemed like a robot. 

Anyhow, on to the food. To be fair, I think my dinner mates enjoyed their dinners more than I did, but I'll be rating just what I sampled. 

Enjoyed my $8 dungeness crab salad. Pretty cheap considering the salad is entirely crab (in a little small bowl). Nicely mixed together with onion, celery, and lemon I think? Just got super salty for some reason towards the bottom. 

Skirt steak- I know, what the heck did I get steak at a seafood place, shoulda known even when they claimed it was great. Darn it! Should have gotten their version of fish&chips. Anyhow, my steak was overcooked and dry, but they made it up with the dijon bordelaise sauce which was surprisingly tasty, but the super salty. The potato sticks/string or whatever they'are were a good subsitute for regular fries. The grilled tomatoes were good too. 

My friend's scallops were tasty, shoulda gotten that perhaps...
author: Caroline L.

description:
WOW! If you come here and don't order the Angels on Horseback, you probably hate America. IT'S THAT DAMN GOOD!

Now you may be thinking, bacon wrapped oysters sound like a heart attack and a half, but fear not my friends, it is AMAZING!

The sea urchin appetizer is delicious as well! It's mixed with creamy potato and lobster chunks. And, if it's not good enough already, it is actually served in the shell of a sea urchin! How bad ass is that?!?

The salmon tartare was great as well as the avocado cream mixed with the salmon bits were a great compliment to the chips it was served with. 

The ahi tuna poke was average, but it was still great paired with the rest of the food. 

The atmosphere is amazing and the interior decor really attributes to the overall aquatic theme of the restaurant. 

Hands down I would recommend this place to anyone! It's also a great date place!
author: Langdon N.

description:
Good fun place.
Food was decent but the service was very slow else it might deserve a half more of a star. Liked the calamari and my cod entree. 
I like the ambiance for a casual date or a business meeting. 
Would return just for that. But for food I would rate its sister restaurant Salt House a little higher.
author: Neil B.

description: I had the fish and chips here for lunch; it was okay  Can't say it's the best I've had but ti was decent.  The worst part about the meal was that it took a long time for the food to come out; we had already been seated for 45 minutes - we had our sodas but not our food.  One of the ladies in our group had to go because she had a meeting at 1 pm; we brought back her lunch for her in a to-go box.  If you have a 1 hour lunch break, I would not recommend coming here.  Service is slow and you may end up having to take your meal back to your desk and eating it there.  I've also come for happy hour and this is another a-ok spot.  Decor is really interesting but with poor service, so-so food, small portions and high prices - I'd have to say  there are better options downtown.
author: Bebe W.

description:
Ok, here we go...review time.  A group of us decided to get reservations for a nice little Saturday dinner in SOMA district of SF.  Wanted to give Anchor & Hope a shot.  

Arrived, our table was going to be ready in about 5 minutes. Hung out at the bar and grabbed some drinks.  I opted for the excellent "Consecration," by Russian River Brewing Co.  It's an American Wild Ale.  If you haven't had it before, be warned, it is unique, but very flavorful. I think it's excellent and jump at the chance to order when I see it avail.  Let it open up and get to about room temperature though.  You will see a major difference in flavor.  

So after about 5 minutes, we sat down at our table.  Pretty quick story from there.  Started with "Angels on Hoseback," smoked bacon wrapped oysters. They are a must.  So good. From there opted for the main entree of Soft Shell Crab Pad Thai.  Also very good.  A few of us then finished things off by splitting Carrot Cake.  It was good, but maybe the weak point.  Not the greatest.

But not to end on a bad note, all in all, had a great time.  Fun atmosphere, nice restaurant layout, good service and solid food.  Will be returning for sure at some point.  Anchor & Hope is recommended!
author: John R.

description:
Loved this place - the decor is fab, the service was great, and the wine was plentiful.

Had the fish n' chips which were so amazingly light and savory but my friend ordered the unfortunately oooooooooversalted salmon pastrami & fried egg dish which we were not fans of (and I don't usually shy away from salty dishes, but this ish was SALTY). So minus one star for that.
author: Carrie H.

description: I thoroughly enjoyed the food here for lunch. I went here for a lunch meeting with a client and loved the trendy warehouse ambience. I ordered the lobster roll, which I order anywhere it's on the menu and was pleased. The lobster roll was served on a brioche bun which was nice but a little too much bread and not enough lobster if you ask me. I'm used to the lobster rolls at Woodhouse Fish Company so I've been a bit spoiled. I will say they make the best homemade chips I've ever had. Super thin, fried and seasoned to perfection. For the price, I wouldn't necessarily go back on my own dime. It's also VERY loud. Of course being an old warehouse, everything echos so this isn't the place for intimate conversations. I found myself smiling and nodding like an idiot hoping to catch just a few words out of each sentence. Come prepared to use your outside voice!
author: Shariyah M.

description: I was underwhelmed by Anchor & Hope, mostly due to the sluggish service and absence of a full bar. The wine selection was good but not as impressive as those at sister restaurants Town Hall and Salt House. The Catalan Mussels were the star of the show, but the Cod and the Rockfish entrees were less special.  Overall the meal was enjoyable but not special enough to bring me back. Next time I'll go to Salt House instead.
author: Ryan B.

description: I have been here a few times for lunch.  I feel like I might like just going here more than I really enjoy the food.   I like the building, I like the high ceilings, and I like the decor.  We have never waited long for a table, and the service is fine.  The food can be a little heavy though.  Also the lobster was almost too chewy to eat on the latest visit.
author: Andrea W.

description:
Like a fisherman out to sea, a wager needs an anchor as big as one's ego to weather all the odds against you and the other,  hope,  the underlying prayer to reel in the bountiful catch.  So when I had the opportunity to wager a bet with my Cowboys against my friend's Eagles I could not resist.  And Boy what  catches those were...the touchdown passes I mean (34-14).
 
The wager was a steak and dinner of the winner's choice- Anchor and Hope was mine since they also served meat as well as seafood (yea I wanted to milk this baby for all it's worth- I mean how could he even think he was going to win on this game).
 
I decided to arrive early, after a bit of downtown shopping and decided to gloat I mean, wait (while I thought of this glowing review)at the bar.   The restaurant had a quaint yet modern interior, alluding to a boat house.  Giant ropes meandered through the ceiling as did various tools and fishing buoys and the only thing missing were the fishermen themselves.  A school of fish drawings drawn above the bar like Russian matryoshka dolls eaten up by the bigger one-- I felt like one of the little fishes in the school ready to eat the biggest one...you know just like Romo winning his first playoff win to silence all his critics (yay!!!- I just had to sneak that one in there).
 
My wait at the bar started with a full tasting of their white wine selection- and I highly recommend them all.
 
Gewurztraminer- Hibou de Nuits, RUssian River Valley, Sonoma Ca. 2007
Floral, Ripe Melons, Delicious apples and hints of strawberries and honeysuckle
 
Sauvignon Blanc- Forefathers, Marlborough, New Zealand 2008
Fresh, vibtrant with a slight Oak finish
 
Viognier Copain tous ensemble Mendocino CA 2008
This one has a sweet honey roundness to it, delicate hints of citrus and kiwi and minerals
 
My friend arrived a little late- I let it slide since I could tell he was still sulking from the lost last night, and upon his confession still had a remaining hangover...(enter my aweeees and "it's ok there's always next year" consolation).  
 
We were seated, I believe, on the best seats of the house where one could see everything in the restaurant and next to the giant floor to ceiling windows so that the passing traffic could get a glimpse of what kind of meal one could be having.
 
We started off with a dozen oysters with a selection from both Pacific (Hood Canal, Beausoleil and Kusshis) and Virginia (Malpeque)type varieties...all were memorable fresh sweet kisses from the ocean :-)
 
I was hoping they had a the halibut but they didn't that evening so I decided on  the Spice Crusted Sea Scallops with Israeli cous cous shaved fennel and madras curry sauce and citrus salt.  The scallops were seared heavily on one side which surprisingly was not overcooked- the caramelized top was a tad too seared I thought but it was still quite delicious.  I did not care much for the madras curry sauce- it overpowered a bit although it was not a heavy serving.  I loved the cous cous- it was cooked al dente.
 
My host had the the Prosciutto wrapped Brook Trout with butternut squash, Brussels sprouts and salted almonds with sage brown butter.  This was a superb dish- I delight in anything wrapped in either bacon or prosciutto-- I will definitely use this next time I bake a fish.  The accompanying sides were as delicious and I don't even like Brussel sprouts, nutty and buttery!  
 
For dessert we shared the Chocolate cake- a triple layer of moist chocolate cake with tiny praline bits and nuts in the icing.  
 
Hmmm wonder what kind of wine will go well from oysters to saucy fish dishes with that added butter?  Why not try a Gamay?  The low tannin and a mellow wine with a little sweetness and spice...Domaine Ruet, Cuvee Vielles Vignes, Brouilly, France 2006.  Parfait!
 
PS-I am waiting on my next wager for Cowboys to go all the way to the Superbowl...any takers? Im thinking 5A5 :-D 
Update: I guess I just saved a buckeroo-- kudos to Favre!
author: Arissa C.

description: Thursday night with friends for a birthday, definitely get a reservation cause it was full. Attentive staff very friendly, knowledgeable on the wines and extensive beer collection and eager to offer a taste before committing. We started with appetizers, big fish platter of clams, oysters, ceviche, prawns, all very yummy. Moved on to calimari perfectly cooked and with a Thai Chile lime sauce that was out of this world. Grilled octopus with chorizo was also equally incredible. Wasn't expecting that. We tried a couple different wines which went perfect with the different foods thanks to the guidance of our waiter. Finally we just couldn't resist the boullabase and fish and chips .  Everything was just perfect and delicious. Oh and for desert a flourless chocolate cake with cherries. Amazing. Can't wait to come back here for one of the more civilized meals I've had in a while, not to mention incredible food. A must
author: Matt A.

description: Me and one of my favorite dolls came here for a girls night! We had a drink at the bar and some calamari. Then we were seated. I had another glass of Wine and ordered the Linguine and 2 of the oysters. Yummmm. Everything was delightful. I have not bad thing to say about the food here. The atmosphere was upscale and made me feel like such and adult [lol]. This place is pricey, but perfect for special occasions or if you just feel like having a classy night.
author: Natalie F.

description:
I've never had a bad meal here. Raw bar, appetizers and main courses, all good and always consistent, whether during lunch or dinner.

And the service from Jessica,  Jane, Anna and Jonathan is always warm and friendly. 

The only drawback is the noise. The acoustics are pretty bad so bring your outside/concert voice.
author: Roger H.

description:
Dropped anchor for lunch.

Different meal. Different menu. It was nice to be back. The space was as awesome as I remembered it. Exposed beams, lights hanging from pipes, waiter with little anchors embroidered into their attire. All very well branded.

Salmon on a torpedo roll made for a terrific sandwich. Perfectly grilled. Thick teriyaki sauce enhanced the flavor. Side of greens.

Waiter was very friendly, made sure all my requests were fulfilled (none of that, some of this) without even a hint of hesitation. 

Quality does come at a price. The generous portion of salmon was $17. Much higher than I'd usually spend at lunch (and cost them the fourth star), but on a warm Friday afternoon with an anticipated week ahead putting me in a good mood, it wasn't that big of a deal.

Pulled up the anchor. Walked back to work in the sunshine feeling fed and happy. Made for one of many, many I love San Francisco moments.
author: Jason B.

description:
Yum yum seafood wrapped in a nautical cozy warehouse. 

$1 Happy Hour oysters from 4:30-6:30 (M-F) are so worth it! They are fresh, delicious and did I mention the price? Don't expect the waitress to promote this special; you must ask! I've been there a few times and they never promote or have it written anywhere...they'll just let you order off the blackboard oysters for 3x the price :I (Minus 1 star) 

*Standout item- clam risotto (wish they increased this dish to an entree because the black risotto was perfect) 

Entrees, apps and wine are on point but I heart Dollar dollar oysterssss!!
author: Charlene A.

description: Great lunch spot for food, ambiance and service.  We had raw oysters, shrimp roll and crab louie.  Everything was great.  Very high ceilings and bright.  Professional service.
author: H. H.

description:
I love coming here for lunch. Food is great and the decor is clean and simple. The place looks clean and open. Love it. 

My co-workers tell me their crab sandwich is pretty bomb. I haven't tried it myself. The first time I went there, I tried their Grilled Mahi and the 2nd time I was there, I ordered the Grilled Brook Trout with Butternut Squash Puree. I'm not a big butternut squash person, but man, was this dish good! 

I recommend making a reservation prior to eating here as they are always packed during lunch time. One time we tried coming here w/o a reso and we were turned down. 

The Eggs says: How come you never take me here?
author: Cindy W.

description:
I loved the meal that I had here. 
Everything looked so good, it was hard to pick what to eat. 
We had a shrimp cocktail, salad, a huge platter of seafood (the loveboat), lobster tails, a coeur a la creme, and an amazing chocolate cake that was out of this world. 

The waitstaff was good, but not great.  Things were a bit slow.  However, our waiter took good care of us, even adding additions to our seafood platter so we could all taste everything.  

We had a great table that was separated from the rest of the dining room so it felt very private. 

I will definitely be back.
author: Katharine A.

description:
Ok, I think this is a 3.5. I liked the atmosphere and the service was awesome. Oysters & lobster roll were really good and loved the wine selection.

Maybe it was just our ordering, but we got a lot of fried apps which made me feel blah afterwards. I also don't get why we were told the earliest reservation on a Tuesday nite was 8:30, but only seemed half full when we got there.
author: Karen S.

description: I would go back to have the sea urchin. By far the best plate they offer. Excellent presentation and flavor. We also ordered the lobster roll and the oysters rolled with bacon but for me we not the best thing.
author: Guillermo M.

description: One of our favorite restaurants near the Financial District.  Great ambiance, great food, and great service.  We usually choose this as our go-to lunch spot with clients, and it's usually our happy hour spot - they have great happy hour food options too.
author: Theresa M.

description:
Beausoleil Oysters:  Fantastic

Sea Urchin and Crab in Shell:  Outstanding

Clam Chowder:  The best in SF.

There is no finer seafood restaurant in the city.
author: Fred X.

description:
Hidden in an alleyway in Downtown, Anchor and Hope offers friendly service, cozy atmosphere, and good food. The spoiler, though, is the time spent on waiting to speak to the waiter and get your food, 'cause everyone in this restaurant is busy here and there. But, I think it's acceptable, unless you are in a hurry.

Wine list was adequate, not overwhelming. The server was helpful and let us have a few samples of different wines before a final decision was made. I was impressed that every sample offered was pulled from a new bottle. They definitely know treating customers right. Beer list was above par with quite a few uncommon selections.

Oysters were nice and fresh, though 4 out of 7 types were run out. Bummer.

Risotto with squid ink was great and it reminded me of my trip to Italy. It was full of flavor and I can't ask for anything more.

Tuna tartar with cucumber nibs had a refreshing taste. Lobster cakes didn't disappoint - soft inside and firm outside so they didn't fall apart when cut apart - and were filled with decent amount of lobster meat. I'd recommend the pan fried trout based on the comparison with my experience at Bouchon in Vegas.

In my opinion, Anchor and Hope presents to be a nice and semi-upscale place for happy hour. My experience there was positive, especially after a hard day of work, it is always enjoyable to have drinks and bites in this warehouse-like decorated restaurant. Mind you, you pay extra for being in downtown.
author: Edmund L.

description: I thought this restaurant was exceptional. The only reason that it's not getting five stars is that the linguine with clams was a little bland (a little more garlic or basil would not hurt) but still very fresh; everything else was fantastic. The PEI mussels moules frites were outrageously good and well recommended by the wait staff, who were attentive, funny and very well informed on the menu. The maitre'd was fantastic, worked throughout the tables rather than simply standing behind the desk, and made several excellent wine suggestions for me. We had a great conversation about the wines he'd suggested and he even gave me the names and distributors of several others he thought I might enjoy, as well as a copy of the wine list for reference. I'll definitely be returning on my next trip to SF and look forward to dining here again!
author: Michaela I.

description:
So hard to choose among the many restaurants near the Embarcadero, but Anchor and Hope was a good choice for us last Saturday night. Made reservations on Open Table and we were seated right away, though I noticed a party of four who also had reservations hold out for a table not near the kitchen. I actually liked my view of the kitchen--you can watch the servers plating and chef-guy wielding the Kitchen Aid. 

Mr. B. and I had enjoyed wine and cheese at the Ferry Building, so were too full to order appetizers--big mistake on our part. Our entrees arrived within 10 minutes of our ordering, right as I was breaking off a piece of the Acme mini baguette. Still, we both very much enjoyethe spice crusted sea scallops and ate every bite ofthe couscous. Delicious!

We managed to stretch dinner to an hour and 15 minutes and in no way felt hurried by the staff. The only slight snafu was when we ordered a piece of the blackout cake to go. We sat for a good 10 minutes, craning our heads in search of the server. Gave up and asked the hostess the location of our cake; turns out they had very efficiently packed it up and it was sitting at the hostess stand. Our server found us and apologize profusely. No harm done...I'd definitely go back, if only for the couscous!
author: Kitty B.

description: Awesome beer selection and awesome food. Probably my favorite restbeeraunt. It's like a fancier Hops & Hominy with more seafood, less southern.
author: Doug H.

description:
I love this place! The decor is super awesome, it feels like you're at an indoor fisherman's wharf but much classier. They're got a rich selection of Beer on tap which is always a plus. Be sure to ask them for a taster to ensure you get the best beer of your choice. I think their beer selection spreads across 2 pages on the menu. Also, the wine list is pretty comprehensive and I've been happy with the drink choices that I've made 
thus far.

As for the food, my favorite is still the battered cod - aka Fish and Chips. The batter is super thin and crispy and the cod inside is fresh and buttery. Probably one of the best fish and chips I've had but again, I never pay $25 for fish and chips so it better be the best one I've had. I've tried the chicken hot pie and the scallop before --- both are decent but wouldn't go back just to order it again.
author: Keara C.

description: Cool, casual spot for lunch in SOMA. The complimentary kettle chips and aioli dip are insanely addicting. I ate a bowl of those before I even got my entree. The menu features a variety of seafood items all of which looked very tasty. I went with the tuna entree which was cooked with a rich, delectable sauce with potatoes and polenta. Cubed tuna was nicely cooked with a rare center. Solid lunch spot for business or a Friday afternoon.
author: Ed L.

description:
The bf and I were looking for a good seafood restaurant to go to in San Francisco and yelp brought us here. I'm really glad we went because this restaurant opened my eyes to a bunch of new things. Yes, I'm mainly talking about the Angels on Horseback. 

First and foremost, let me get the things I didn't like about this place out of the way so I can focus on the good stuff. 

-Parking is horrible. It's really easy to miss this spot and it's located in an alley. Not a good place to walk to alone at night, especially in San Francisco. 

-I got the Warm Sea Urchin, which I was really excited for because I'm a big fan of Uni. It came in the actual shell of a sea urchin which looked pretty cool but the smell was kind of a turn-off. Besides the smell, there was this weird sour/bitter taste here and there. The kind of taste you're hoping not to experience when eating seafood. Overall, this appetizer was a bit of a letdown. 

Ok, now on to the good stuff: 

The decor of this restaurant is really cute and I think the atmosphere and the lighting makes it really intimate if you bring a date here. 

For our appetizers, we also got the cornmeal fried artichokes which has a great crispy crust. They do not skimp on the artichokes, these babies are huge! The sauce that came with it is amazing as well.  Our other appetizer was the Angels on Horseback, aka Bacon-wrapped-oysters. I'm not a big fan of bacon but I mean everyone else loves bacon and who doesn't like oysters? Whoever decided to pair these two together is a genius. So, all you bacon aficionados, this is a MUST. 

Anchor and hope has some pretty amazing twists, and when they pull it off, it is simply out of this world!

As the main course, my bf got the Alaskan Halibut and I got the Sea Scallops. When they brought out our dishes, at first, I was thinking "only 4 pieces!?" I don't know if it was the appetizers before or maybe the bed of couscous under the scallops but I could not finish my scallops. I only ended up eating two! Let me tell you, both of these dishes were to die for! They were melt in your mouth, just like butter-type of goodness. 

Now, I know for a fact I had only eaten 2 scallops and had them box up the rest. The next morning, I was excited to eat my leftovers but there was only 1 scallop! I don't know if my bf secretly ate one and is just denying it or if the waitress stole one but if I were you, be very cautious with your scallops, someone will steal them!
author: Bianca L.

description: I wanted to like this place.  Cool location....cool interior and I was excited to try the food.  The Calamari was fantastic.....but when we got the seafood platter the shrimp tasted old and like cardboard and the clams were just plain bad.  Oysters were great tho.  The server was unfriendly and pretty useless.  Didn't as us how our meal was just wanted to know if we were ready to order more.  We finished our drinks and got the check.
author: Michael S.

description:
I love the very nautical New England-ish atmosphere and there were some cool fish painted on the wall with dripping paint.

The epi baguette served in the paper bag was awesome.

Main course: salmon served with collard greens and black eyed peas. Overall it was pretty good, but nothing memorable

Verdict: overpriced and just ok.
author: Elaine S.

description: Anchor and Hope is one of my favorite restaurants. They have delicious selections that always please the palate. I have been dying to make it there for happy our to enjoy their fabulous oyster selection at a discount. On top of the good food, the  service is excellent; personable, knowledgeable and attentive.
author: Angus M.

description:
GO HERE TO EAT.

What we got:
Angels on Horseback - smoked bacon wrapped oysters, remoulade
Lobster Roll - brioche bun, old bay kettle chips, sea salt

YUM! This place was GREAT! It's on a little side street so it's easy to miss. And it is busy! Make reservations because the lunch crowd definitely fills this place up!

J and I got the top 2 recommended items by Yelpers and by our waitress. The lobster roll comes stuffed with plenty of lobster, enough for two. And of course, who doesn't love brioche. Then take two of my favorite foods, bacon and oysters, and put them together - you can't go wrong. They're so cute looking too :)

Love this place, I am coming back for dinner for sure!
author: Samantha C.

description: we came here on new years eve and the place was packed.  there was such a great vibe.  everyone from the the general manager, manager, hostess, waitress, etc. was incredibly nice and professional.  the service was awesome and the food was divine.  we had the small seafood platter, the steak, the fish + chips, the lobster roll and pasta.  everything was SUPERB.  this restaurant is amazing and i highly recommend. cannot wait to visit again.
author: Samantha B.

description:
Fantastic meal. We just ate at the bar on a sunday evening and everything was perfect. From the angels on horseback, chowder and island creek oysters to the fries with eyes and the oh so crave-able sea urchin with crab and mashed potatoes...yum!  The butter and bread were good as were the house olives with meyer lemon. Great beer selection.  Not cheap, but when most of the restos in SOMA cost about the same - I'd say this is more than a good square meal. 

Town Hall is boring and conservative, Salthouse is obnoxious (don't seem to know how to handle being slammed), but Anchor & Hope floats my boat.

PS: Mayor Willie Brown and Sonya were dining there too!
author: Maïa Cybelle C.

description:
A&H was OK...my friend and I went there to scope the place out for a cocktail reception buy out.  It's very loud in there and industrial looking, exposed beams and existing brick.  

The appetizers were decent.  I really liked the fried calamari with thai chili sauce, the sauce gives the calamari a kick.  The angels on horseback weren't as impressive...I LOVE oysters but the bacon flavor overpowered the oyster flavor, big time.  

The CA swordfish was good, but isn't it unhealthy to eat this stuff because of the mercury?  It was perfectly cooked on a bed of garbanzo beans and chorizo, with a bit of diced red pepper.  I believe it was in a red pepper sauce also.  

The fish and chips were OK.  The fish was pretty fish, wish it was seasoned a bit more though.  I ate this with malt vinegar and a dash of pepper.  The fries on the other hand, were a bit TOO seasoned with salt and rosemary.  

Overall the meal was decent, but nothing fabulous about this place.
author: Wendy S.

description:
An excellent seafood restaurant, slightly off the beaten track and definitely not a place you would just happen upon.


 A pretty good wine menu compliments a small but excellent selection of food. I had some beautiful Skate served with a beautifully light sauce, creamed potato and morrel mushrooms.


 Desert was a bit of a dissapointment, the lemon in the lemon meringue was just a little too strong and overpowered my glass of Moscato.


 Everything was redeemed however by an Illy espresso.


 Certainly value for money at $70 per head.
author: Gorbuck

description:
I loved it.
It was better than Cats.
What can I say? I am a sucker for great food and sassy servers in an industrial restaurant setting.

Best calamari and corn soup I have ever had. Period.
Bam!
author: Shira G.

description:
I went with Rebekah for our monthly girlfriend lunch patrol.  I enjoyed the food but I wasn't blown away.  It may have been because we came at 1:00 PM and perhaps the staff were losing some steam by that point.

We're both ordered the DAT lunch: Bacon wrapped oysters and Ahi tuna melt with baby greens.  Plus two starters, the scallops ceviche and the dungeness crab remoulade.  I enjoyed the ceviche and the crab.  But it felt like a little too much remoulade. . . remoulade with the oysters, the crab, and something remoulade-like with the scallops. Perhaps another form of sauce would be nice to complement to richness of the seafood. . .

 I did enjoy the first two bacon wrapped oysters but the last one was just too big and scary-looking and the bacon wasn't too crispy on it.  Loved the first two but I covered the last one with one of the oyster shells. R.I.P. Mr. Oyster.  I prefer smaller oysters vs. four-bite-oysters.

Lastly, I loved the tuna melt (I am a tuna melt making master myself).   But GF's salad had these very aggressive stems on her watercress but mine was a-okay.

The service started out strong but by the end of the meal, it had dwindled to very little attention.  My GF needed water refills and waited.  The time between our apps and the entree was very long.  Lastly,  I had to wave my credit card to get the bill at the end so we can pay and leave.  

Overall, I would give them a 3.5 stars. .  . it would've been 4 stars if the service hadn't petered out.
author: Freida N.

description:
Date/Time:   Friday - 8:30pm
Occasion:    Dinner get together
Party of:   Three
Ordered:   Angels on horseback appetizer (bacon wrapped oysters), asparagus poached egg salad, squid ink risotto with steamed garlic clams,  New England clam chowder, and grilled hanger steak.
Location:   Cute decor. Warehouse-feel. Very spacious. Trendy.  Hidden along Minna Street between 1st and 2nd.  Park on Mission and cut through.
Total incl gratuity:   ~$117.00

I'm surprised this place didn't score a 4+ rating.  I thought their food was excellent.  The angels on horseback oysters is on the list of 100 things to try in SF before you die.  It was good but I'm not a fan of cooked oysters so to me, it was that great.  The clam chowder was so yummy!  The flavor was excellent and it contained huge chunks of clams.  The risotto was extremely rich so it was hard to eat big portions of it.  The steamed clams were very garlicky so they were really good.  The beef was very flavorful and tender.  I would highly recommend that dish if you're feel extra hungry.  The service was ok..nothing spectacular.  I want to come back for those $1 HH oysters. Yum! Yes it's not cheap but I think it's worth the extra $. A solid 4!
author: Jess C.

description: Service was excellent. A bit slow but for us, at dinner, that was a plus. Food wonderful to amazing. Lots of seafood in the dishes. Specifically lobster roll and fried fish. The chowder was also wonderful. Atmosphere spectacular too.  The only reason it's not 5 stars is that it's very pricey so you get what you paid for, it's no "find". At their price point you expect excellence and we got no more than expected. Everything was great but they didn't blow our doors off on anything.
author: Thomas B.

description:
Lobster roll. So Good!! 
Calamari here is one of my favorite
author: Juan T.

description:
So, I'm a student again, which means that I have no money for lunch. You can often find me at McDonalds every day of the week, trying their different dollar menu items. 

Not this past Tuesday. On a rainy day after a tedious half day of class, I decided to anchor my rolly briefcase/luggage thingy in hopes to actually eat a decent meal.

I went for the Pulled Pork sandwich which came with chips. It was so good. The fat on the pork melted in my mouth and the tangy bbq sauce was fantastic. Their burger (comes with big wedge fries) was juicy and delicious. It came with a juicy slice of tomato and a fresh crisp piece a lettuce.

I admit - I eyed their awesome selection of beers but only had a few sips of my man's Firestone since I had another class after lunch. 
So good. (the beer, not the fact that I had class after lunch).

Our waitress informed me that they have a fantastic happy hour with drink specials and $1 oysters. Yes. I shall skip my daily McDonald lunch and go to their happy hour.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
The most amazing shrimp I have ever eaten.
Wonderful variety of oysters and beers.
The atmosphere is cozy, casual but nice enough to feel like you are splurging a bit.  And that we did ....over 100$ for ea of us!
And two of us got lobster rolls.  32$ for a lobster roll is a bit much but because it was so good I will forget... hate to say it but Wood house has a lobster roll for 17$ and it is the BEST I have ever had.  And I have eaten a lot of east coast lobster rolls.
Our gay sailor waiter was GREAT!  He was so much fun!  Unfortunately the expediters got a little mixed up with our order (forgot the fries and brought a glass of wine instead of a bottle).
All in all this place is awesome and I will be back - when I want to splurge.
author: J J.

description:
I have had from 3 to 5 star meals at Anchor & Hope, so it is difficult for me to find the "number" of stars to give it.  Really my review is probably more 3 1/2, which it currently has (damn you Yelp!  When are you going to get with the 1/2 star action??).

I see a lot of complaints about the service, which I have never experienced.  The servers and wait staff have always been great.  

The seafood is generally excellent.  Pretty much everything you order raw is going to be extremely fresh and tasty.  I really enjoy the salmon tartare app they have that  is cured with apple.  The seafood platter is also nice (though somewhat pricey).  I truly love the lobster roll, it is a 5-star standout on the menu, and I order it frequently.

Straying from the seafood is not recommended.  Whenever we have, we have been disappointed.

The decor is great, as is usual for this team's restaurants.  They also have a great happy hour, and are usually packed at lunch (which keeps this as  one of my regular client lunch destinations).

Overall solid, though somewhat a roll of the dice on how great it  will be.  Could be fantastic one night,  and slightly underwhelming another.  I will continue to go back  however.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Brick walls and wooden barn-like roof in an urban setting.  (Is this place   seismically safe?)  Lots of dim incandescent naked bulb lighting.  

Got there early, plenty of tables.  Got crowded as the night went on.  Started off with the bacon wrapped baked oysters.  Excellent.  Fresh bread came a bit late, so I managed to avoid stuffing myself with bread before dinner.  We had the lobster roll, cole slaw, and chips which was fine.  We had the cod fish and chips come with the Anchor & Hope fries, and it was tasty.  Nice glass of white wine.  Finished off the dinner with the malted vanilla ice cream and German chocolate cake.  

Nice meal.  Interesting place.  Good service.  Tab was over $100!  Whoa!  Can't say that a lobster sandwich and fish and chips with chocolate cake is at $100+ meal.  

Impossible street parking, really expensive ($15-$20) parking lots a block away.
author: Doctor G.

description:
We had a part of five, for lunch, with no reservation. We were lucky to get a table and were seated properly.

We shared an order of calamari, which was fresh and delicious. I was able to taste one of the "Angels on Horseback" (bacon-wrapped oysters), which was okay but not great - guess I'm not much of an oyster fan!

For my meal, I had the ahi tuna sandwich with fontina cheese, served with fresh greens. It was excellent, though I probably could have made something similar at home for far less than $13. I will definitely try my almost-ordered fish tacos next time.

The food was good - not amazing, but good. (I may have been happier had I been able to order a drink, but it was a work lunch and that didn't happen.) The only drawback was the extremely slow wait staff. Our waiter forgot some of our requests, and left us sitting for more than 10 minutes without visiting the table once we were done - I had to flag him down to get the check, and then he never came back to pick it up.

This restaurant could use an improvement in their staffing, but otherwise it was a good experience and I will be back if the occasion presents itself.
author: Karen C.

description:
One of my favorite spots for quiet dinner has become way too popular (i.e. reservation at 8 but you will be seated at 8.45pm) thanks to food network. 

Amazing appetizers with average quality+overpriced main course. Angels on horseback (glorified name for bacon wrapped oysters) is super delicious and sea urchin with crab, lemon cream sauce is addictive. Unfortunately the sea urchin wasn't served in the shell as advertised. Sad face. 

Desserts are forgettable. Two star deduction for failing to provide happy ending.
author: Fred F.

description:
Bacon wrapped scallops and the lobster. Anchor and Holy Moly.

And let's not forget Allagash on tap, way to my heart.

The only downside of our experience was the service. We did have a later reservation, and it seemed they wanted to get out of there... but we had two waitresses throughout - who didn't seem to be communicating and I got my glass of wine after our appetizer. I mean, you can be slow all you want - but don't forget the alch.

The decor is awesome, from the great murals to bringing out your check with a heavy anchor - yes it too heavy to take home with you...
author: Chelsea D.

description: Oysters!  I love the ambiance of this place tucked away in a small alley.  The service is always great and the food is consistently good.
author: bill l.

description:
This place is delicious!!!! My boss has taken us here twice for lunch & I have to say that I am really fortunate that I got to try this place!!! The lobster roll & the angels on horseback (bacon wrapped oysters featured on the Food Network & 7x7 magazine) is TO DIE FOR...  

The service is also really great here & the ambiance is nice, but can get a bit loud during lunch hours.
author: Krystel M.

description:
The stripped down warehouse ambiance is lovely and the lighting over the bar is inspired.  Unfortunately, the food and service don't live up to the potential of the interior.

We went there for dinner with a party of five.  The restaurant was busy but not overly so.  The staff seemed to be completely in the weeds.

Our wine glasses showed up about 20 minutes before the wine.  I'm glad the wine was good because it took forever to get our appetizers. 

Husband and I were going to split a salad.  When it finally showed up - instead of the one salad we'd ordered we got two salads we hadn't ordered.  We decided to eat them anyway since the everything was moving so slow.  They were completely overdressed and the lettuces were soggy.

My flatiron steak had great flavor. Unfortunately, I ordered it medium rare and it arrived extra mega double rare.  The potatoes that came with my steak were tasty but cold.  My table mates didn't seem to be wowed by their choices either.  

For the location and price, I expected better food and service.  Hopefully, Anchor and Hope can get it together, but I don't think I'll be back.
author: Miss Information X.

description:
Delicious.
Seriously - fresh seafood - fresh sourdough - what more could you want?
author: Sarah T.

description:
Not a bad spot. I went for Happy Hour and tried a bite of about everything as I was with a large group. Very tasty all around. Nothing that blew me out of the water but, definitely a place that I would return to without hesitation. 

:)
author: Brian R.

description:
This place had an interesting setting. That said, we went here at the suggestion of a friend who had enjoyed the happy hour and I decided to take my wife there for her birthday dinner.

Bad idea. While the food was alright, the ambiance and definitely the service was horrible. Our waitress was inattentive and seemed rather rude. 

Perhaps happy hour is a better idea. Just get some beer and then get the heck out of there.
author: David H.

description:
I came here with 2 other friends looking for a casual dinner and good seafood. I definitely achieved the former, but not the latter. I really wanted to like Anchor & Hope from the minute I heard about Angels on Horseback and their awesome happy hour. Upon entering through the alleyway that doesn't look like it would house a restaurant until you look a bit closer, we were greeted warmly by the hostess. Oh wait - that didn't happen. Don't get me wrong, it was early and the restaurant was fairly empty so the hostess had no business standing in front greeting guests. The only problem was that she was standing in front, only she wasn't greeting anyone. We had to wait for her to pencil in who knows what before she wanly stared up at us and that's when we said we were early for our reservation, waiting on one more, but wanted to check in. She directed us to the bar that was fairly full for being so early, but we were okay with that. 

From there it took a few more minutes before the bartender acknowledged us and even while laying out our simple order, his eyes darted elsewhere as if to show us that we were boring him already. I shrugged it off as the drinks came quick. Then we decided to ask if we could sit down and wait for our 3rd person at a table, since the restaurant wasn't full. The hostess was warmer this time around and sat us quickly. After that, it was a miracle if we could get anyone's attention to take our order. 

Service - 1 star

Food - 2 stars:
 
Oysters - depending on what variety you get, these were good. 

Angels on Horseback - I expected more. I love oysters, but I wasn't excited about this dish.

Charred Baby Octopus - rubbery and it lived up to its name, tasting charred alright.

Sizzling Garlic Shrimp - good, not great.

Not going back here.
author: Johanna L.

description:
I'm a little torn on the review.. some of the items were VERY good (and would definitely get again), but others were mediocre. Plus, we had a reservation but ended up waiting good 15-20 minutes to get seated (which was slightly annoying). 

I came here on a weeknight with a friend.. this place seriously seems like post-work dinner for folks in financial district. 

Appetizers: 

*bacon wrapped oysters: this was really interesting!! (but in a good way) the downside is, you only get 4 small pieces! 

*buttered dungeness crab: MY FAVORITE! it was so good! it has a little spice to it (because of the peppers), so be warned. It comes with three pieces of bread and bowl of buttered dungeness crab. Generous portions on the crab is a plus! I would DEF. get this one again.

Entree:

* lobster roll: my friend had the lobster roll with the side of salad. I actually liked this one better than my dish! The bun is GINORMOUS, completely-buttered and SOFT! The lobster roll IS good, but I don't know if it's just worth $26. I had a lobster roll at those trucks at golden gate park (Sam's Chowder  House Truck) and I swear it was JUST as good! 

Side note - for those that don't know, Sam's Chowder House is an actual restaurant in Half Moon Bay... but they also have a truck that goes around the bay area! They have GREAT sea food choices! 

* salmon: I had the salmon. I mean, it was good.. but honestly nothing special at all. Pretty typical salmon you would get at any nice restaurant. Probably would not get this again. 

No dessert. Think the damage including tip was a little over $100 for two.
author: Sarah C.

description: Egh, I wouldn't rush back. I had the chop salad and added salmon to it. The salmon was pretty good. The dressing on the salad was not very good. Overall, it was not very enjoyable, and pricey.
author: Olivia P.

description:
Very interesting building with the inside nautical theme being perfect from the signal lights in the rafters to the fish picture painted on the wall of the bar. 

For appetizers we ordered the new england clam chowder and the fried calamari. New england clam chowder had beautifully made house cured bacon and oyster crackers with the consistency being perfect. Fried calamari extremely tender and not to heavy. Next was the Fish and Chips, steak and trout which was well prepared, Fish Chips were average and run of the mill steak.

Anchor and Hope is just a good restaurant to goto for dinner because it's quieter then average, good food and great atmosphere.

                                                                    - LéRat
author: Leo R.

description: My wife and I at at Anchor and Hope on a Friday night.  I really like the decor, but the dishes we had were only so-so.  I started with the mushroom soup (fine) and my wife had the fried calamari.  The calamari was pretty good, but somehow seemed almost too lightly breaded, especially given the pretty spicy sauce.  For dinner I had the seared tuna and my wife had the mahi-mahi.  Again, both were good but I would probably try other things on the menu if I were to go back.
author: Richard M.

description:
Delicious!!! We were able to get in on a busy Friday evening and loved the atmosphere. They have a unique selection of beer and wine but no cocktails. 
I loved the oysters- they were served chilled and were extremely fresh! The lobster appetizer was great but the portion was pretty small. The warm uni was incredible, basically an amazing uni chowder.
The one complaint- the service was terrible! They were extremely impatient with us, made very little eye contact and acted either "put out" or irritated when we asked for service or information.
I definitely recommend checking this place out if you have a little patience and can laugh off the bad attitude we encountered.
author: Marisa S.

description:
I'm updating my review and lowering my rating because I've been disappointed in my ability to find something healthy to eat at this restaurant. You figure for a fish place it would be focused on light, healthy entrees but it's impossible to find a dish that is not super-caloric if you're trying to eat a little better/lighter. The baked salmon is breaded, the grilled trout comes in a brown butter sauce, and even the grilled chicken breast comes soaked in bacon grease.

Now, don't get me wrong, all of these dishes *are* delicious; I'm just disappointed I can't find anything to eat there at lunch that isn't loaded with butter, bacon and salt.

And service seems to have gotten a little slow.

A fine place for what it is; just know when you go you will have to pound water all afternoon afterward, and probably hit the treadmill later. Tasty and delicious -- yes. Healthy and light choices -- not so much.
author: Vince S.

description:
I went to Anchor and Hope about a year ago. So this was based on memory. 

I vividly remembered Angels on horseback - Delicious. Maybe because is bacon wrapped around oysters. You can't go wrong with bacon and oysters :) I remembered the sauce being very delicious!!!!

As for the main course, sadly I don't remember what my friend and I got.
author: Catherine T.

description:
I really liked Anchor and Hope A LOT. a friend reccomended it to me, and once I saw it was the same owners of salt house/townhall I was game!

The design is very open, white clean and crisp. good vibe too. 

I went with my Bff for my Bday. I really enjoyed all the small details. they brought bread that was in a paper bag stamped with "anchor & hope." the butter was sprinkled with sea salt on top, very pretty and tasty. We got clam chowder, steak, and halibut and a yummy brownie dessert  with bing cherries =)

Everything was great, I will definately be going back.
author: maria K.

description: Went here with my team as a good-by lunch for a co worker leaving. The restaurant is tucked away from the main street, but once you walk in the atmosphere is really bright and feels like you're in a sea side town. We had the calamari and the bacon wrapped oysters as apps, both of which were good. I had the salmon BLT, which was really good. I was happy with the portion of salmon. Most of my other team members had the fish (think it was cod that day) and seemed to enjoy it. We eneded up ordering one of each dessert, and they were all really good. The chocolate mousse was by far the best. So tasty! Yum!  :)  I should also mention they have a very decent wine and beer list. Overall, this was a great dining experience and absolutely perfect for our purpose. Would love to go back at some point!
author: Kathy T.

description:
I went to Anchor and Hope about 2 weeks ago for some happy hour drinks and $1 oysters with my co-workers. The service was pretty lousy at first...especially given we were sitting at the bar and the whole place was pretty empty.

We started with some angels on horseback and a 18 oysters. All was good and fine until my 2nd to last oyster, when a live, wriggling WORM slipped out of the oyster just before I ate it!! yes. that's right. a worm.

while it certainly didn't stop us from getting another dozen or so oysters - the waitress wasn't planning on doing anything about the worm situation until my friend called her out. we ended up getting all the oysters comped but you wouldn't think you'd have to ask for something like that after finding a live invertebrate in your food.

good oysters. lackadaisical service
author: Nina B.

description:
