Great place for a fun splurge date night, especially if you like to try new beers; the beer spread is awesome.  Ambiance is really fun, and I love the big fish motif on the wall above the bar.  And shellfish; oh, the shellfish!

It is pricey, but everything is prepared fresh and the cooks know what they're doing.  I've been here about 4 times and every time is wonderful.  Once, I brought someone who I didn't know was a vegan (pretty much everything on the menu has some kind of animal in it).  The waitress and kitchen worked out some menu options and it was handled very courteously and everyone left happy.
author: Emily F.

description:
8/2009

When we walked in the manager brought us all glasses of prosecco because he could tell we "were there to have a good time". 

I loved the atmosphere, very "by the sea". 
My outfit was flawless! 
I had incorrectly ordered, and when I shared that with the server they replaced my entree very graciously. I had a great time here.
author: Kate B.

description:
This review is based on only one visit (business trip)...

The restaurant itself is charming and the hostess was very welcoming.  Our issue was w/ the waiter.  No one came over to greet us for over 10 minutes.  We had to flag him down.  He took our drink order, and then appetizers.  By the time we had finished our appetizers, he still hadn't reappeared to take our dinner order.  We had to flag him down again.   With that said, he seemed perfectly nice, just not very attentive.  Our waiter also got switched after we ordered dinner, b/c our original waiter "went on break."

Now, the food was delicious.  I would def go back for the food.  Maybe we just had an off waiter.  I'd like to believe that b/c the food here is worth going for.
author: martini g.

description:
Disclaimer  - if Yelp doesn't institute a half star system, this may be revised to Five Stars

Anchor & Hope was absolutely wonderful

Something most Yelp reviews haven't really touched:
Anchor & Hope has a beer list that is treated like a Wine list! Comparable to Monk's Kettle, but on a lesser level - beer isn't their shtick, but it is refreshing to see an nice restaurant appreciate good beer and offer an extensive variety.

On to the review...

We went on a weekday night, table of two, for a birthday dinner. And it just so happens that it was SF Beer Week, and Anchor & Hope was offering a four course prix fixe menu that came with beer pairings for each course, well going there I knew we needed to try the oysters so really, I had a five course meal for two, with drinks the whole time in a dining experience that took about an hour an half for less than $200 -- not cheap, but not bad!

We left fat, happy, drunk and definitely coming back.

The staff is a total team there - you can tell, everyone pitches in and it looks like a place that is well run and the people respect each other. Our waitress was stellar.

The atmosphere is awesome. Great lighting, light themed decor, but a place that displays itself upscale yet modest, warranting the attention to the food. 

Oh, the food - it is really really good.

Great presentation, great taste, well timed in between courses

The crab raviolis were my favorite! Absolutely perfect.

Definitely coming back, and I highly recommend this place.
author: Austin P.

description:
I have a penchant for cioppino, and Anchor & Hope's was almost perfect!  All the seafood was excellent.  In fact, the only thing preventing me giving this food 5 stars was the unbelievably strong spice in the broth.  I realize that cioppino broths can really vary (some tend have more kick that others) but when I was reaching for a gulp of water after every fourth bite from a scorched throat, perhaps the chef added a little more spice than intended?!  As such, I ended up not eating that much of the broth and focused on the, once again, delicious seafood.   
 
Thanks to the recommendation by Pinchit...I also gave the oysters at Anchor & Hope a try.  The good part:  they were delicious.  The bad part:  I missed the happy hour, and ended up paying full price! Had the size of the oysters been a bit larger, I would have not minded paying $3.00-$3.50 each.  Either way, the oysters were very, very good and I ended up not using any mignonette sauce.  I will go back for the happy hour special soon!

Though I didn't drink, there was a good selection of wine and an even larger beer selection.  One of the more unique beer lists in SF I've seen.
author: Joel F.

description:
4 Stars for the food! Had Sea Urchin app and it was delicious...table had the clam chowder, scallop app, then lobster roll - wow!, cod and chips....wonderful. Lobster and crab gnocchi...amazing and perfectly cooked/tender.

2 Starts for the service - as previously noted, the place was 1/2 full (Sunday night) and yet it took a long time for everything from drinks to food to check.

3 stars for the price - A little pricey ($25 for 2 pieces of cod and some fries)...Side of cole slaw = $7?!?!

Overall the food was phenomenal with get presentation and flavors...but a 3 for the rest...
author: Joyce J.

description: Very disappointing experience. Very pricey for what you get for a meal. The red trout was tasteless. My beer was served in a wine glass only half full. I left hungry...had to stop at a near by fast food place to get some extra food. Don't waste your time and money.
author: Jeff H.

description:
It wasn't great but it wasn't bad. But with the price of the food, we were expecting so much more.

"Angels on Horseback"
author: Joyce J.

description: You know what depresses me about this place? The fact that it has over 900 reviews! The reason: because its this somewhat small (though actually bigger than it feels) beautiful little restaurant down this super tiny road that barely has any cars, which makes me think that I have found a hidden gem.  I get excited when I find hidden gems.  But less excited when 899 other people have found it too! That being said its still everything I said.  It has a great look and feel... the waitress and the host could not have been friendlier.  They have different types of oysters (my new obsession) though I will be honest, I didn't eat them here because I had gotten oysters already that day!... a great selection of sea food...small but decent wine list...and the reservations were easy peasy.  Its the kind of place I woudln't mind becoming a regular at...hear that anchor and hope...im coming back!
author: Kierstan G.

description:
fun casual spot for fancy-ish seafood.  atmosphere is nautical themed warehouse with ropes hanging from ceiling.

get:
-complimentary bread and butter
-grilled squid had unique caramelized flavor & perfect texture
-grilled trout was fresh and skin nicely salted, yum.
-lobster roll was AMAZING.  loved the buttery roll (not greasy) with generous chunks of refreshing lobster.  accompanying chips were TO DIE FOR.  i wish they would package these for sale.

meh:
-heirloom tomato salad with burrata:  tomatoes a bit too green and burrata not salty enough.  
- plum and blueberry crisp was a bit too sweet

we loved our cakebread sauvignon blanc recommended by our friendly server.  would definitely return for best lobster roll in town.
author: Josie M.

description:
Another fantastic dinner at A&H!!!  We took my brother and sister-in-law, who described the fish and chips as the "best I've ever had!"  Food, service and atmosphere were a solid 4 stars again!

Bad news, though.  They've replaced the chocolate blackout cake with a cherry chocolate brownie.
author: Eddie L.

description:
Two stars because Anchor and Hope continues to suck.  Their food always sounds much, much better than it is and the price tag never matches the food.

Why do I continue to torture myself?
author: David G.

description:
I really love the lobster rolls here, which is what I order pretty much every time I come. BUT, the prices are no joke. Without an expense account, I might think twice about dropping in for a casual lunch or late night dinner.

Keep it in mind for a little splurge.
author: Anna G.

description: Do: Angels on Horseback. Don't: Lobster Bun. Do Drink: Bottle of German Riesling. Don't Drink: Bottle of New Zealand Riesling.
author: Damian D.

description:
I revisited the place for lunch with my coworkers.  This time we ordered the following things:

- Tuna poke: good, refreshing, interesting aioli type sauce that came with it. 

- Shrimp cocktail: is shrimp cocktail.  Good though and fresh.

- Calamari: the Thai chili dipping sauce was good with the calamari.

- Lobster roll: the brioche bun was inside out which was interesting.  It was buttery and good but cut up the roof of my mouth since the fluffy side was exposed and toasted.  

- Port of call: yummy drink.

Our server was a bit inattentive and maybe I'm being hard on this place but I think I'm still in between a two or three star rating for this place.  But since the food was better this time than last, I'll round up!
author: Jessica T.

description:
I came here for dinner on a rainy Friday night. A friend had recommended it to me as I'm a huge seafood fan.

We started with the small seafood platter and the quality of everything was right up there. The first round of beers came and my date and I were both impressed with our selections.

My salmon entree was really good. The almond prep was something different and the sides were great.

It was a little noisy and the tables felt kind of close together. The service was attentive and she was very knowledgable of the crazy beer selection. I've got to back and try something else and some more of their vast beer selection.
author: Valerie S.

description:
Three stars is a bit harsh, but it's definitely not four, so if I could I'd say 3.5. A quick summary: 

-Warm, bustling, bistro like atmosphere. Friendly servers. 

-Neither my friend nor I could really understand what the big deal was with the "angels on horseback". People tend to love things wrapped in bacon so maybe that makes for the rave reviews? It's skipable. 

-I had the fish and chips, though it went by a fancier name and a fancier price tag at $23. The rosemary fries were addicting!  My friend had the rock fish with pork belly which she described as "good, but not memorable". She ended up eating half of my fries;-) 

-The beer menu is extensive and the servers are knowledgeable. Mine asked me to name three beers I liked and brought me a great combo of all three. 

-1 appetizer, 2 entrees, 1 beer, 1 glass of wine, 1 dessert and 1 coffee came to $108 before tip. Seems like a lot for what we got. Maybe the happy hour is the way to go.
author: Mandy G.

description: I enjoyed this place and love the name!  Service was fabulous, food was good.  I ordered the Potato Leek Soup for an appetizer -delish and my client ordered the Clam Chowder - we ate it all (good sign).  For lunch we had the fish and chips and the tuna melt - both were fresh, tasty and very nicely presented.  Not too fancy - just good cooking.  The noise level wasn't as loud as I expected with the warehouse feel and high ceilings - but it did get loud as the lunch hour wore on.  I would definitely return with clients again for a nice, professional yet casual (not pretentious) lunch.
author: Rachael C.

description:
This place has a lot going for it, just a couple of little nit-picky things I would like to see improved.

PROS:  

The Warm Sea Urchin appetizer is TO DIE FOR.  It is filled with mashed potatoes, big chunks of dungeness crab, beurre blanc sauce, and delicate chunks of uni.  I could have eaten this as my entree and been very happy.

The french bread they serve to you is really good.  Crusty on the outside, moist and fluffy on the inside.

The lobster roll was so so good.  The brioche on which the lobster was served was thick, buttery and perfectly toasted, and the lobster was seasoned well.

The presentation of our dinner was spot-on, and they use a lot of color to make the dishes pop.  The Warm Sea Urchin appetizer was served in a sea urchin shell, which I loved.  All of our dishes were beautiful to look at. 

They have a raw bar with a good selection of local and not-so-local oysters.

The BF and I did not drink while dining here as we had just come back from Napa and were a little grossed out at the thought, but I did notice that they had a nice selection of unique wines and beers.  Next time I will try some of them for sure.

The decor was really nice - it was like you were on an old-timey dock in the 30s with nets, unfinished wood plank floors and the lantern-shaped light covers.  Loft ceilings made it feel open and airy.

CONS:

The Alaskan Halibut I had was way oversalted.  I admit, I'm kind of averse to salty foods (some might say that's weird), but I like to taste my food, not salt, and this was too much for me to handle.   So I asked for a second opinion, thinking maybe it was just me.  Nope...even the BF agreed that it was too salty.

The Old Bay Kettle Chips (made in house) that are served with the lobster roll were kind of gross.  Some chips had a light seasoning on them, while others were coated in the stuff.  Yuck.  If the chefs could figure out a way to make the seasoning on these chips evenly distributed, they would be wonderful.

The tables are too close together to have a relaxing dinner.  Next to our table (maybe 2 feet to my left) was a group of Brits that were bitching about how pretentious this or that was, and how the food was so pretentious here.  It was actually really funny, because the pretense just OOZED from these people.  It was too much for me...if the tables had been farther apart, I probably would not have heard them and might have been able to enjoy my food a bit more.


So all in all, I really enjoyed this place, and with a few tweaks here and there, it could be really special.
author: Sarah G.

description:
Was looking forward to this place after some rave reviews I read and after my roommate came home and told me about the angels on horseback. 

The ambiance of the place is amazing! Very comfortable and rustic, just the right amount of open space with a certain New England coziness about it. 

As for the food: Truth be told...  the angels on horseback are overrated (I prefer raw bar). 

The wine list and beer menu are extensive and filled with some good rare finds. 

The scallops with israeli cous cous were the high point of the meal. Great flavor and texture. 

All in all, A&H is alright by me. I may go there occasionally, but it won't be the first place I think of when I think seafood.
author: Douglas L.

description:
Came here after work for happy hour which is 4pm to 6pm.  $1 oysters were fresh and pretty good. Happy hour $4 white or red wine also good for the price... fries were good. tuna stuffed peppers were meh but bacon wrapped oysters were yummy!
Staff was accommodating with a good sense of humor. I arrived earlier than my two friends and the bar was full and the nice hostess was more than happy to seat me at a table to wait for my friends.

I will be back again for happy hour!!
author: Lisa M.

description: Great seafood! I hadn't really found a restaurant in the city that i loveeee for seafood but this one hit the spot. The lobster roll was amazing and the perfect amount of food.
author: Carly G.

description: Full disclosure: I haven't eaten a proper meal at Anchor & Hope. I did, however, try their Happy Hour while in the area, and was a fan! $1 oysters plus some good beer and wine deals. While I'm not the hugest fan of the area, I did think the ambiance was pretty cool. Would definitely go back and give dinner a whirl.
author: Shannon E.

description:
Went on a double date here after drooling over their menu for well over a year.  It did not disappoint.  We got the 7x7 reco Angels on Horseback.  They were good, but not even our favorite part of the meal.

Wine selection is great
Ambiance is great
Fried Artichokes were amazing
Ahi tuna was great but the beans it came with were the star!

dessert was a plesant surprise, we had a seasonal asian plum cobbler. OMG I almost killed my companions for it.  SO GOOD.

Would love to go back here very soon.
author: jessica b.

description:
Great Place. Lovely decor, wonderful food, friendly & attentive staff, prompt service, and cute little extras that make it stand out (like the fishing weight thingee on the bill and the bread in the bags) 

i was trying to eat kinda light the night I went in there so I got there soup-du-jour along with a lobster white grape (i think?) salad. I don't think my meal ended up being "light" but eh why complain about something you can't change. The soup was so good! creamy and delicious. The salad was nice too, not as good as their soup though. Oh I had oysters as an appetizer too! el delicious-o! such nice fresh little briney yet creamy yet cucumberey little delicacies they serve there. 

Also, I was trying to be exotic and ordered their Albarino by the glass. I got it and it was not to my liking. not one bit. But I was gonna be a trooper and just drink water and not complain. But our sweet waiter came over and asked me if I liked my wine, I said "well um uh not so much but its OK" and he insisted on bring me a new glass. He recommended a Willamette Valley Pinot that was delightful. Delightful! And he didn't charge me for my discarded Albarino, which wasn't necessary but appreciated. 

I came with a big ol' group and they took great care of everyone. I thought the prices where fair and everyone seemed to enjoy their food.  Yay for Anchor & Hope!
author: Laura W.

description:
I've been to A&H many times for lunch and it's always good.  I went there recently for the first time in the evening with my sis and for the first time had an experience with an inattentive server at the bar.  We must have sat there for 10 minutes, looking especially hungry, before one of the floor waiters (I think his name is Dustin) came by to help us out.  We loved him!  

Wine selection = great
Beer selection = awesome
Angels on Horseback = good but not one of the top 100 things to eat in SF before I die (sorry 7x7)
Shrimp cocktail = fresh and delicious
Little gems salad = yum (I love when salads have sea salt on them)
Clam chowder = filling - but who doesn't love clam chowder with big chunks of bacon so of course we ate it all

The acme bread and salted butter are ridiculous and hard not to fill up on.  The $$$ is no joke.  I will definitely be back but I do wish they would put the burger on the dinner menu!
author: Monica D.

description:
Came here for lunch on a beautiful sunny SF day.  Had to try the lobster roll since it's one of their specialties.  If you don't like butter, I would advise against this item.  The roll was super soft and fresh and drenched in butter.  The lobster was not soaked in mayo which I especially liked.

I like the exposed brick walls and high ceilings, though it was packed, it wasn't too loud.

Desserts were yummy.
author: Mabelle A.

description: Go for the oysters! Absolutely fantastic! Fresh! Comfortable atmosphere. Great beer selection.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
I am generally swayed by presentation, so I am big-time enamorada with the interior of Anchor & Hope. It's shabby chic of the not nasty faux-french provincial persuasion, but is modern and cool. The goods  just can't compete with the decoration, though. I've been twice and I have to say that I was a little bit disappointed. 

I'm a lobster fiend. A FIEND, I tell ya. Unfortunately the lobster salad that goes into the lobster roll is over-seasoned. Lobster's super delicate and all the lemon, parsley and something else I can't identify they put in there is distracting. The calamari and french fries are ordinary. 

The only thing I had that was outstanding was the tomato and burrata.
author: Eli B.

description:
Happy Hour (HH) Review: 

$1 oysters!! Can't beat the price! I was needlessly skeptical: the oysters were of good quality and presentation was as expected. 

$6 Parmesan fries were ok; not as thin & crispy as my HH friend and I like. 

$4 beer & $5 wine; selection changes 

The ambiance is cool; warehouse-modern. HH is a good time to meet peeps, the bar area really filled up after 5p
author: Stephanie T.

description:
I had to take a couple of weeks before writing this review as I had a horrible experience. We had reserved a table for 5 people. It started being awful from the time we walked in. The table was put in an awkward space right next tot the bar and the door where you could feel the cold draft every time someone walked in. We asked if we could move to another table and the hostess (in a very snobby way) said no, everything is reserved. I will talk about the staff's attitude later.

The food 
HORRIBLE!!! Overpriced cheap food with no taste. My husband ordered a steak, two of us had the lobster roll, we had the grilled sardines for apps and also the scallops. The scallops were undercooked, and looked slimy! The steak was probably the smallest steak I have ever seen, and the fries were stale! How can a restaurant not know how to serve fries properly?? Additionally, they were very skimpy with the chips, they brought chips with WARM SOUR CREAM! They only gave us one set of chips for the five of us! The food is bad, bad, bad and overpriced!

The staff 
Our waitress was very nice and extremely helpful and had an overall great attitude. However, there was a waiter there who had some weird curl thing going on with his hair who was so obnoxious and kept complaining about everyone that he had to serve. The reason we could hear all this was because our table was next to the bar - literally, we were almost on top of the bar. He was loud, obnoxious and only said nasty things about the tables he had. I almost got up and said something to him about being a bit more polite, but I didn't want to ruin the atmosphere (that was left anyway) at our table.

If you want great seafood - you might as well go to Fisherman's Wharf rather than going here. Save yourself the money and go to another amazing restaurant - there are way too many good restaurants in the city to give this one another chance.
author: Julia Z.

description:
We had a lovely time at Anchor and Hope. The staff was extremely pleasant and helpful. The Seafood Plateau was superb as was the sea urchin appetizer and the wild mushroom soup. The Sea Urchin was: mashed potatoes, crab meat, cream, butter and sea urchin served in the urchin shell - amazing.
My boyfriend was not as thrilled with his lobster roll. The lobster was cooked perfectly but he felt the brioche didn't compliment it. My trout was good but not great. 

The dessert was amazing. Gingerbread Pumpkin ice cream sandwich with caramel sauce. The beer selection is out of this world. I know this place has a super lively bar scene during happy hour but we were there late on a Sunday night and it was very quiet and warm. I love the exposed brick.
author: Missy F.

description:
Went here for a business dinner late (8pm) on a Wednesday night. We had reservations at 8 but were seated closer to 9 pm. Ok it's a busy place and we took that as a good sign.

I found the menu to be very interesting. Everything sounded fantastic sea urchin, steak, mussels, tuna. However the food does not live up to expectations. Mind you the food was good but not not great. For example my British friend had the fish & chips ( go figure, he flies 5000 miles and orders food he can get at home) and he gets a smallish serving of fish & chips for $23.  $15 I can see but $23 hello, that's nuts anyone home here?  Anyway I had the braised ribs for $24 served on mashed potatoes and these were god but not great. Overall I'd say the food is good, not great and every dish is overpriced by $5 at least.  

The wine list was the same. Ok but not great with an average price of $46 a bottle.  Heavy on the French wines which are again mediocre.  

Overall I would not go back - the average food is not worth the wait nor is it worth the price.
author: Ken D.

description:
I've been looking forward to coming here for awhile, but I was underwhelmed. Nothing impressed me. Nothing was bad, but nothing was great either, it's just not in the same league as Town Hall or Salt House.
Highlight was the calamari. But the devils on horseback and the lobster roll were just mehh...bland.
author: Rose K.

description:
You just can't give this place less than four stars, because of the outstanding food.  

I understand... the service has stank-attitude 8-miles high, but overall this restaurant still manages to deliver the goods, on multiple levels, on multiple tastings.   The wine and beer selections are thoughtful and wide flung.  The seasoning is superb.  The angels on horseback are a revelation. The wide-open decor allows for large groups to mingle with more intimate diners.  The menu straddles seafood and meat dishes more or less down the middle, with consistent reviews from both sides of the sawhorse.

I'll be back, be treated low, and quietly enjoy the easy wonders of this ktichen.
author: Paul L.

description: Love the seafood chowder (red style), when they had it (hasn't been on the menu recently), and love the seafood in general here. The only problem: this place's prices have really got out of hand. Ambiance is impeccable and I love the warehouse turned chic feel, but you do feel like the food could be better than what you are paying for.
author: Mike G.

description:
I was in San Fran for work and the concierge at my hotel recommended that I try Anchor & Hope.  

I am so glad I did.  I went 2 nights in a row and had the exact same thing both nights!  It was so good, I could've licked my plate clean.

I had the lobster bisque and the halibut.  They were incredible!  Can't wait to go back to SF because I have been craving their food!
author: Sarah B.

description: Great service, and great food. I highly recommend the oyster platter. And the shrimp and clam pasta was delicious as well. Great atmosphere for a fun night out in San Francisco.
author: Angie A.

description:
On our last trip to S.F. my wife and I went to Salt House and we both loved everything we'd ordered.  Having loved Salt House and Town Hall, the next obvious place to try was Salt House.  Unfortunately it didn't quite live up to the hype, unlike its two better previously listed.

When we had arrived, it took roughly 5 minutes to be seated despite at least 3 or 4 empty tables.  The service otherwise was pretty good, though not outstanding.

Our party of three ordered:  Lobster Bisque, BBQ Shrimp Appetizer, Angels on Horseback, Small Shellfish Plateaux, the Sea Urchin, Softshell crab and the Sea Scallop entree.

What I liked:  The Angels on Horseback were delicious.  Pretty moist and flavorful.  Even our friend who hates oysters liked it!  The Sea Urchin was also tasty and chowder-like.  The Sea Scallops were cooked perfectly.

What I didn't like:  The lobster bisque was hyped by the server, but was super salty and not very creamy.  The BBQ shrimp seemed a little overcooked and uninspiring.  The Shellfish Plateaux was mostly good, but not worth $47.  Lastly, the softshell crab was perfectly average.

This place overall isn't bad, it just doesn't seem to be nearly as good value as, say, Salt House.

Pros:
-Some tasty items.
-Great bread.
-Free water!

Cons:
-Slow service.
-Some mundane items on the menu.
-Overpriced.
author: Hans -.

description:
Above average cuisine, albeit rather staid, and by that I mean nothing extraordinary. The rare steak was cooked to perfection, though- a few steps away from mooing, which is just the way I like it. Further, the wine selection was delightful as was the delicious Cote du Rhone. 

The evening would have been amazing had the wait staff not been so inept. Terribly slow, unknowledgable and seemed irritated to simply do their job. The cuisine is worthwhile, but unless you have three hours for dinner I world recommend going elsewhere.
author: Paul M.

description:
Mixed feelings about Anchor & Hope.  Some of the food was great - the sea urchin and lump crab appetizer comes to mind, as do a number of the other appetizers which I didn't order but saw delivered to nearby tables.  On the other hand the entrees lacked finesse; my lobster roll was uninspired (not to mention smaller than a similarly-priced sandwich from Woodhouse), and my date's halibut was fine - but just fine, and that's not saying much for a $24 piece of fish.

Service was super friendly, but I asked for a recommendation on a bottle of dry sake and the selection was decidedly not dry.  I mean, for all I know that was their driest bottle, so this is either a reflection on the restaurant or the server; either way i suppose props are due for having any sake at an American seafood restaurant.

The decor is cute; it doesn't actually feel like New England because it has a certain fancy flair, but I appreciate the effort and the art on the walls is clever and welcome.

Like Lynn S. said over a year ago, Anchor is a restaurant of contrasts.  I wouldn't warn anyone off it, and hell I'd go back if someone else wanted to, but I was definitely left with mixed feelings.
author: Oliver N.

description: It's strange I like this place because I don't eat seafood, at all, but I had a lot of fun. Very cool ambiance, great date place, lots of drinks, and as vegetarian, you can just order a few sides/appetizers and chat happily :)
author: Lana L.

description:
I love the whole look of the place both outside and in. At first glance from the parking lot, it looks like some sort of warehouse and then you step in, what a beautiful space and simple, modern decor inside! I love the painting on the wall of the fish being sought after by a bigger fish who is being chased by yet a bigger fish and so on... very San Fran. (Actually, it reminds me of the the JD Edwards being acquired by PeopleSoft who was acquired by the evil Oracle corporation...but I digress...) 

The food my friends and I had were the lobster roll (a must!) and the quail and clam paella... it was fabulous! We also started off with a few of the appetizers - a dozen oysters, the fish fries (my personal favorite) and a few others that I didn't really care for. 

All in all, we had great food. My only advice is that you do not go there on a warm night (it is rare, but we happen to be there when it was 80+) because it does not have any air conditioning. The fans they brought out did not cool the place, just kept the warm air circulating... no matter, we downed our cold beers fast enough.
author: Jenny D.

description:
I'm actually leaning towards 5 stars on this one. 

Excellent service and a great lunch menu, I have been here three times for lunch lately and they have all been very pleasing!  I love the location on the back alley and the service is always great, we have always been given a seat even without a reservation.  

The oysters on the half shell are great quality and a dream to slip down, if only I could drink at lunch I'd be quaffing a glass of champs or their many yummy bubblies.  Twice I've had the lunch special, which comes with an app, entree and usually a dessert. Both times the meals have been stellar.  I know this is a fish joint but our roasted chicken over salad was DIVINE.  A perfect seasonal nod. 

They serve the usual yummy to die for Acme bread and bring huge bottles of water to your table so you don't have to beg for more. All in all, this place is really becoming my local fav.

Now, all you have to do is make a lunch date with me and you'll see what I mean!
author: Claire C.

description:
Great building and ambiance! Anchor & Hope has a clean, harbor feel to it. You feel as though the fish is being caught right outside. Yet, you're in a clean, sophisticated building. 

Drinks: Water is served in cool jugs and there is a great beer list. The beer sampler gives you a taste of 6 local beers. 

Food: We had lunch here and I tried the lobster roll, tuna burger, and clam chowder. Everything had surprising seasonings, which you couldn't always pinpoint, but loved. The lobster roll was one of the best I've ever had and I love in New England! Great fries! 

Rating: I give this four stars because for what you paid and received, it was what you expected. It wasn't quite 5 stars, maybe if I go back for dinner.
author: kristina C.

description:
I headed here with my hubby for dinner with the intention of getting a lobster roll....BUT when I read the menu I was stricken with a case of EverythingLooksGood-Itis. Plus it was one of those cold summer SF nights....SO, I ended up with the fisherman's stew and it was everything I had hoped for. Huge chunks of fish, mussels, clams, shrimp and garlic, all piled into a a large bowl of steaming, tasty tomato soup. 

Additionally: The Allagash White was a great beer to go with my dinner. 

Next time lobster roll, you will be mine!
author: Julie D.

description:
Went at lunch and found the space to be really light and inviting.  Friendly/good service.  It was hard to pick from all the great-sounding menu choices.  We had the fried clams, lobster roll with housemade chips, crab louie salad.  A dessert of  chocolate cake that was coated with a buttery, crunchy pistachio brittle was delicious!  And they serve that Acme bread that is soo good.

So impressed that these folks have put together three places like Town Hall, Salt House and now Anchor & Hope in the same neighborhood.  We're getting spoiled.
author: Jimmy G.

description:
If you LOVE seafood, then you might like this place. I really LOVE seafood, but I thought this place was just  okay. 

Pros:
-Cute interior (I love the painting of the little fishies and the fish eyeball lights) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iy1KBR5hRNcgCaqiUoBSoA?select=rrgG2GOO26DnK6g_HXNYVw
-Great service
-Good food
-Beer menu is insane!

Cons:
-Overpriced food
-Small portions
-It can get crowded
-When you look outside, theres an awful view of seagulls and dumpsters

I thought service here was great. I dropped my knife on the floor. 1 minute later, someone came by and gave me a new one. I didnt even have to ask! Niiice. Our server was extremely helpful and super nice. 

As for the food, we ordered a bunch of appetizers and shared it. it was good but overpriced.  Not too memorable and didn't blow my mind away.
I really enjoyed their black pepper prawns. It was delicious. But for $10-$12, you only get like 5 pieces of shrimp.
Their calamari was very yummy! Not too chewy. It was perfect and came with a great dipping sauce.  
We also ordered their "fries with eyes" appetizer.  If you like fried smelt, then you might enjoy this. I really liked it! 
Their clams were pretty awesome. I LOVED the sauce! 
We also ordered their heirloom tomato salad. It was good but the portions were very small. 
I also got to sample their lobster entree and their fish and chips. Both were good but I wouldnt waste my money on it.
author: B B.

description:
I can finally cross Anchor & Hope off my list of "must try's."   Here's my breakdown...

Kampachi - drizzled olive oil on top with a side sauce of something that tasted of sesame.  this was really good.

Salmon special - thinly sliced, baked for 2 seconds so that the outside is lightly cooked but the inside raw.  cant place the sauce that was on top, maybe soy based?  nonetheless, this was good as well.  i liked it slightly better than the kampachi.  

Uni - my first time trying uni.  and, well, i wasnt impressed.  not with A&H's version anyway.  a little too strong for my taste and not really fresh.  

Sauteed Prawns - really good and it had a nice kick to it.

 Lobster Remoulaude - mmmm this was probably my favorite of the bunch.  it was like lobster ceviche - lots of flavor and the lobster was like butter.

Herbed Ribbon Fries - nice heaping bowl of crunchy yumm.

I was happy with my experience here.  The decor is rustic and modern with eye-catching art on the wall.  Margaret is like the rockstar of servers.  She was so friendly and awesome.  She took the time to chat for a bit and every question asked, she had a very knowledgeable honest answer.  When i come back, im requesting to be seated in her section.  She's seriously that great.
author: Juv C.

description:
2 1/2 stars.

My meal here made me very sad. I've walked by the restaurant a million times and have drooled at the menu online, confused at its mixed reviews. I love seafood - and everything looked great. I wanted to love you A&H! 

However, the appetizer (an exciting-sounding mix of sea urchin and potato puree served in a beautiful shell) was lukewarm and frankly, not very good. My date ordered a lobster roll, which he accurately described as "uninspired," and I got the halibut which completely lacked pizazz, despite it's jazzy description. It was all just... fine :(

I would/will give it a try for lunch I suppose, as I've heard much better things from friends and coworkers about their daytime menu. Here's (anchor&) hoping!
author: Stephanie P.

description: On my second visit here, I didn't think things could get any better than the first. A&H proved me wrong! First time around, incredible happy hour oysters, top notch micro brews, and friendly bartenders. This time, impeccable Hama Hama oysters with an addictive mignonette and a fresh fresh fresh crab. Flawless. This is THE place to go for fresh seafood! The Cajun popcorn shrimp was delightful as well, and Cooper our bartender even comped them off our bill because they took a little longer than expected. Very cool of him!! We will be back for a full dinner soon as this time was mostly snacks. Impressed.
author: Tanya K.

description:
Bacon-wrapped Oysters? YUM!

Love the restaurant space; big, open, exposed brick walls on a little side street in SoMa

- Angels on Horseback= Bacon-wrapped Oysters. Delish. 
- Shrimp Cocktail: Fresh, succulent shrimps
- Lobster Roll: Tasty, but small portion for $20++

A tad pricey, but a good place for a business lunch. Would love to come back at night when they have the Sea Urchin appetizer. Yay!
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Here's the short and sweet:

Food:  Spans between average to good with very limited choices
Price for average food:  Ridiculous!
Service:  Ours was poor

We found out about this place because it was featured in a Food network channel show. The dish featured sounded delicious and peaked my interest to try. First I will say the sea urchin appetizer was wonderful but I was disappointed with the presentation. It seems they are no longer concerned with that anymore or they only do it only for TV and website advertising. All you are going to get is a white bowl of white gooey stuff. After that we tried the fried oysters which was average and the lobster roll which was a little disappointing. It had super greasy buttery sandwich bread which I felt overpowered what should have been the highlighted ingredient lobster. They should be ashamed of charging what they do for these items. As for the service, it was poor. We showed up 15 min early for our reservation and since we were there for the very first seating of the evening we were quickly taken to our table. Since we were early we were willing to wait for wait service to begin but informed our hostess that we would like to order a drink. She left and never returned and we waited 20 min for our waitress to show up before we were allowed to order anything. We ordered a couple of beers and the items listed above. Their menu selections are very limited and I wasn't interested in any of the entrees so I ordered the oysters as my entree and my husband got the roll. Without us asking, our waitress had the chef plate the one lobster roll on two plates for us to share and when we got the bill they had the audacity to charge us extra for plating half a sandwich. This is after we had already spent $100 there! This place is a poor excuse for fine dining. Don't waste your money. We won't be back.
author: C B.

description:
Really awesome beer selection and oysters are nice and fresh. The wide open space attracts plenty of Fidi clientele, and unfortunately the tables don't turnover for those waiting with reservations.

We tried the uni with crab and lemon beurre blanc, which was very nice, really rich and decadent. The grilled oysters wrapped in bacon were cooked nicely but the bacon actually took it over the top for me. 

I loved the lyonnaise salad with poached egg and crispy veal terrine, my kind of dish. The heirloom tomato salad with burrata was okay, the slices cut a bit too thick for my taste.

Last was the halibut with chorizo. I'm not a big halibut fan but I actually liked this, the fish was nice and moist and all the flavors worked together.

I'd come back during happy hour for their $1 oysters and excellent beer selection.
author: Derrick V.

description: The lobster roll was very good. Buttery roll, lobster was cooked well, very delicious. Also enjoyed a great beer and the complimentary chips!
author: Nathan W.

description:
Don't get me wrong.  I loved the bivalve-centric menu and the simple wine selection.  I just couldn't get over how metallic and stiff the ambiance was.  It just felt cold.  The area is spacious and vast (well in the up direction).  The large warehouse-like space has very high ceilings, however, on the floor - you are elbow to elbow with your neighbor.  The sounds echos and reviberates all over the place.  The ambiance was so distracting and our server was elusive and tending to two larger parties so we felt a little lost.  

I'd give it another go.  I love oysters.
author: Brooke G.

description:
A crustacean-lover's paradise. I went there for another birthday celebration and besides the excellent company, the food was brilliant.

I will say you're on your own for wine. They're good at picking but it's a bit hit or miss if YOU will like what they suggest. But I love they recommend what THEY love.

Go. You'll be happy you did. Try the counter and that will eliminate any chance of inattentive waiters...
author: Raul L.

description: like the Salt House, my friend and i went there for Dine About Town, but unlike that visit over there, we both ended up ordering off of their regular menu. it paid off. i ordered the salmon sandwich, and it was cooked well to my pleasant surprise. the viet-flavored slaw in the sandwich gave it a much-needed crunch and vinegar-flavored tang. the accompanied salad was an afterthought (i'm not much of a salad person) and would loved fries instead. Dine About Town exposes people like myself the opportunity to explore San Francisco restaurants more than i normally would. thanks to this visit to Anchor & Hope, it reminded me that i shouldn't be handcuffed by the Dine About Town menu. perhaps, i should give Salt House another try, and anybody judging the restaurant solely based on that special experience may be not getting what the restaurant has to offer.
author: Mike C.

description: My son and I had a great dinner here.  The arugula salad with peaches and strawberries and pistachios was incredible.  We shared the salmon.  Although it was slightly undercooked for my taste, it was still good.  The wine was wonderful.  The space is beautiful and the service was outstanding.
author: Tamara D.

description:
The food is good but the service is very slow
We go there often and it is common to wait for your food for around 15~20 minutes
author: FOO D.

description:
Good wine and loved our waiter.  Impressive appetizer list so we thought we'd hit them up.  All except for 3 and then we took both appetizers that were today's specials.  Why not?

There were 5 of us and we shared a plethora of apps. to go with a couple bottles of white.  

First off I've got to say that we hit this place up after a day in Napa.  Rough life I know.  It's always a special occasion when our group of old friends unite so we like to live it up.

We love sharing and trying everything we like on the menu... it's a habit, more like a way of life.  Eating and drinking with my friends is my favorite pasttime in the city.

http://www.anchorandhopesf.com/menus/dinner.pdf is a link to their current menu.  Off the appetizer menu, 5 of them were more memorable in some way or another than the rest on the list.  We had a bottle of the Albarino a Spanish White from the Vionta Vineyard in Rias Biaxas region.  It's a perfect Springtime wine and one that goes well when you are eating seafood especially oysters on the half shell.

My favorite was the Sea Urchin Bowl... now I'm guessing the bowl is a prop. as I'm not sure how easy it is to get sea urchin that big on demand.  Probably just wash and reuse right?!?  That's fine.  Presentation is lovely.  I'm definately going to see if I can make recreate this one on my own for shits and giggles, maybe even give it a little twist.

My second most memorable plate was the "Fries with Eyes" which was fried smelt (like fish sticks but whole fish) served with a Remoulade Sauce.

The Warm Asparagus Salad with the poached egg, salt cod and Meyer Lemon Hollandaise was solid except I don't care for huge thick asparagus.  I was thinking less is more for asparagi.  The jinormous strands of asparagus was used to create a fort Lincoln Log style for presentation, great but the thinner ones taste better in my opinion.

The only plate that I was bummed out on was the Seared Sea Scallops that were slightly seasoned with Indian curry and served with preserved lemon-ginger chutney.  The scallops were okay but the sauce (and I think there Israeli cous cous was cooked in this sauce and added to this plate to add dimension) tasted like a cube of chicken boullion.  It was a little off.  

I think the oyster platter that we got before our apps. feast was another show stealer with several different kinds of oysters and a few clams.  Whoo wee.  Delightul and the presentatinon was rustic and lovely.

I truly enjoyed the Anchor & Hope.  I just learned that all wines on their list can be served by the glass, half glass or bottle.  Great idea!!!
author: Shiho F.

description:
We came here with a group of 4 and an 8:45pm reservation.  There was a large party of 20 people who had already long-ago paid, had empty drinks and continued to sit and chat for another 45min after we arrived, which I think was rude of them, since they could obviously see the 20+ people waiting for tables.  This was in no way the restaurants fault, yet the other customers waiting were taking it out the hostess.  When the large party finally left, the tables were cleared and reset in less than 5 min flat and everyone waiting was seated.  I was impressed with their speed and gracious apologies for something that was not their fault.  Their wine list was extensive and their beer list is a reason by itself to check this place out. My friends and I ordered our drinks and took a few extra minutes with the menus, so when we finally ordered, the other 20+ people had just ordered, all at once, causing the kitchen to be slammed.  Instead of avoiding our table, as some waiters might, our waiter, Ryan, came over to explain that the kitchen was a little backed up and asked if he could bring us another appetizer or some chips while we waited.  For apps we got "angels on horseback- amazing, baby octopus crustini-perfect, calamari-excellent, housemade chips.  Everything was wonderful.  
For entrees, my friend ordered the flank steak, but since they were out of flank steak they replaced it at no charge with an excellent perfectly cooked rib-eye.  I got the seafood pasta, which sounds simple but was delightful.  They either make their own pasta or they get it from someone who does.  Another friend ordered the fisherman's platter and was also very pleased with how fresh the food was and how nicely prepared.  
When we were so stuffed we couldn't take another bite, our waiter brought over the dessert menu which we politely declined.  He was so apologetic  for our wait, he told us he would like to bring one for the table to share free of charge.  He brought us the 'caramel bar' (or some simple sounding name like that) but what actually came out was a house made snickers.  We pretty much licked the plate clean and thought we would have to roll ourselves home.  It was just too good to leave behind a single bite.  I strongly recommend saving room for dessert.  
Needless to say we thought the service was excellent and the staff went above and beyond to meet our needs
author: D M.

description: Meh. Had the crab louis salad. Tadich 's is much better - hands down.  Very expense, pretty food, but not worth the price.
author: Stacey O.

description:
Looove this place. Oysters were fresh, bartender was friendly and attentive. This review is ONLY for the happy hour. But $4 Russian River Damnnation and $1 Pearl Point oysters? My goodness.

The salt cod brandade is smoky and delicious.
author: Rich B.

description:
Okay, so after giving them a second chance, it seems as though A&H was back to what I expected of them.

Went here on a Saturday night and was helped at the bar by Chris.

Service was attentive and professional without being intrusive, and he was much more personable that the person that had waited on us previously.

This is what I expect out of this restaurant and it was exactly what I received.
author: Michael M.

description: I remember the decor being pretty cool, the food being above average, but mostly I remember that the heater was broken and we were all freezing inside.
author: Michael H.

description:
LOVE A&H!! I'm not all that surprised because I'm also a big fan of Salt House (less of a fan of Town Hall but whatever).  The raw bar is also stocked with fresh oysters and the lobster roll is delish.  The latter is not really that filling so be sure to order some apps, ESPECIALLY the warm sea urchin shell with dungeness crab and lemon beuree blanc.  I was not an uni fan before this dish came into my life and i'm now a changed woman. 

Minus 1/2 star because there isn't a full bar
Minus another 1/2 star because the service is kind of slow
author: Carol T.

description:
ordered the rockfish and ceviche. they were good, but nothing too spectacular.had the happy hour oysters. wasn't a fan.

complimentary chips were delicious, however.
author: Monica S.

description:
WHEN THE SERVICE IS YOUR MASTER:
-
I am changing my vote to 3 stars and will try Anchor and Hope one more time.  The first try was a difficult experience.  However, I alerted Mgmt to the issues and the response was swift and sincere, leading me to believe the kinks will be removed and this place will be the gem it promises.  

-
author: Jonathan S.

description: Good job. Food was up to Par. Service  great. Ambience great. Will be back.
author: Jorydude r.

description: great atmosphere. I enjoyed my fish and chips, not amazing but definitely really yummy.
author: Sareena N.

description:
Sea Urchin? Fries with Eyes? Not your mama's seafood.

Our out-of-town pal said he wanted seafood. Ok, I'll give you seafood. Not any touristy fried shrimp or a traditional roasted halibut either.

Of course we had to try the 'funny stuff' as mentioned in the reviews. The warm sea urchin with crab and remoulade spread on the bread was amazing just like CC said. Fries with eyes aka fried smelts were yummy BUT we did have a few little fins get stuck going down the gullet.

Had the lobster roll on brioche and while the lobster mix itself was really excellent, the bread just masked the flavors. I ate them separately. Subb'd the ribbon fries for whatever it typically came with, fun.

Excellent wine selection and great service, we had the blackout cake and salted butterscotch creme brulee for dessert. The cake was pretty good but the brulee tasted like spoiled milk. Not a fan. Overall, a solid pick for out of the ordinary seafood lovers with a good ambiance. Loved the decor.
author: Mara T.

description: Short of the fact they serve chips instead of bread, this place lives up to the brand of its sister restaurants. Quieter than Town Hall, with similarly brief menu of almost exclusively fish.
author: Bryce F.

description:
came here with the entire office because our ceo was in town... i had been hearing good things and was curious.

they ordered tons of apps and oysters, all of which were delicious. i especially remember the calamari and sea urchin. i dont think i was thrilled with the sea urchin but hey, gotta try everything once right?

the service was really good, our server was really nice and answered tons of questions and constantly offered to refill glasses of water, wine, bread, whatev.

i ordered a lobster roll but unfortunately had to take it to go and didnt get to enjoy it freshly made. it was a little too salty/oily for my liking, but i'm wondering if that's partially because i waited a little before getting to eat it. the chips that came with it were delicious, but i'm not sure i'll go back to try it again... especially given how many restaurants there are in the same area. oh well!
author: Bethany K.

description: Great beer selection, good oysters and shrimp.  But dang, that was a pretty lame Lobster Roll.  I have no idea why the waitress would recommend such a weak dish.  Order anything else, and you'll probably be happy.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
We came here for dinner after MOMA as it was a short walk away.  Ordered Angels on Horse, which is bacon wrapped oysters, and calamari for appetizers.  They were not bad, but somewhat failed our expectation for the premium prices charged.

The asparagus salad was delicious.  The sauce and poached egg were very good combination in adding different layers of flavor to the vegetable.

The lobster roll was another disappointment.  It was not bad, just did not taste like it is worth the price.

Waiters are very polite and attentive.  We are not sure we would make an effort to come back; probably will if in the neighborhood and want to try raw oysters.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
Lunch: A little slow on the service. Make sure you have at least an hour + to enjoy the wonderful food. Their lobster roll is priceless!

Dinner: Fantastic. Love the sea urchin. The presentation is really cool. The spikes are snipped off, and it's served like a thick soup. The sea urchin is the bowl. Great to share.
author: Jerome F.

description:
4 STARS for Food + Service (-1 star for the high prices) 

Came here for lunch on a Thursday at 12:30. We had reservations, so we were seated promptly. 

FOOD: 
*Lobster Roll ($24): MmMmMm---YUMMY! This was my very first lobster roll and I wasn't disappointed. The brioche bread was perfectly toasted. The lobster pieces were sweet and succulent, although there wasn't much lobster. Light on the mayo which was good. I did NOT like the slaw; it was wilted and had me wondering if it was several days old (yuck!)? As the other reviewers mentioned, for $24, you would think they would at least give you some fries instead of chips. 
*Prie-fix ($21.95): 
-Baby Bib salad with orange: Average salad with vinaigrette and 
orange segments. All ingredients were fresh. 
-BBQ Spareribs: Pretty good. I wasn't expecting anything much since 
this is seafood restaurant. But the ribs were tender and the portion 
was generous. Mash potatoes were also good; creamy and smooth. 
-Chocolate Black-out Cake: HOLY SMOKES! I wasn't expecting 
much....but I was pleasantly surprised. I'm not a sweet tooth and 
don't care much for dessert, but the cake was rich, moist, and 
decedent. It had a ganache-type center which was ooeeey gooeey 
good--not too sweet. That paired with the vanilla ice cream was 
YUMMY! 

SERVICE: EXCELLENT. Our waitress was very friendly, and attentive w/o being overbearing. She checked up on us several times and always made sure everything was ok. We were sharing everything, so they even split the salad on 2 plates for us--how nice. 

AMBIANCE: Not stuffy nor pretentious. A very open space with alot of grays and whites. Can get a little loud when it's busy, so not a great date place if it's super packed. 

Really looking forward on coming back here to try the Uni...MmMmM :)
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I love the outside of this place. I also love the inside of this place. It first caught my eye when I went to a bar on Minna Street. I did a double take on the restaurant and caught myself thinking "What is that place?? I want to go!! So cute inside." So a month later, I made a vday date for drinks with a gf. 

We sat at the bar, ordered some vino, got some a la carte oysters that were $2 each. Had we not ordered that, the regular menu was pricey. I would definitely not have the cash to dine here every day. But maybe some day I will.

Next time, I'll just hit up Waterbar or Bar Crudo to get my $1 oyster fix. A&H should have something similar for the after work HH patrons! It would be so much better!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Went back - another business lunch - and was well more impressed.

My colleagues and I shared oysters which were fresh and delicious.

I then had two appetizers instead of a main:  the clam chowder and the heirloom & burrata salad.  Both were good, solid, and met my expectations of fresh, well prepared food.  Neither were overly seasoned or greasy.

I will definitely return.

The reason for 4 stars instead of 5 is that there is no hard alcohol - only beer and wine.
author: Hanna D.

description:
nice place. I like the piranhas painted on the wall, and the 'eyeball' lights. creepy in an aesthetically pleasing way. 

go for the oysters, they were realy fresh. The cussi were my favourite. 

angels on horseback, yum. 
also had the hailbut, which was great, except it didn't come with enough of the sauce, imho.
ceviche was sorta tasteless tho.

its a nice place to meet friends, throw back some wine or beer. quite enough to chatter, but festive enough to feel welcome.
author: Scarlet S.

description:
Oysters.  Amazing.  Fresh.

Salad.  Incredible.  I will be putting mint in all my salads going forward.

Service.  Pleasant, accomodating, there when you need them to be.

Atmosphere.  Cool without being overdone.

I need to return when I have more time, but I also wanted to point out that we walked in without a reservation and were sat almost immediately.  Just wanted to say thanks for that!
author: Jessica H.

description: Admittedly, this place has a lot of hype to live up to, and that's a difficult position to be in.  However, their "Angels on Horseback" - smoked bacon wrapped oysters - are absolutely decadent.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Really nice service eating at the bar and an interesting menu.  The chef used a bit too much salt, but this seems to be a theme with many of the upscale restaurants in SF these days.  In fairness, the dish I ordered was new to the menu so perhaps they haven't quite worked it out yet.  It was a sole or flounder with rock shrimp and potatoes.  There's bacon in the sauce that it's plated in, so it seemed odd that they added salt elsewhere in the dish.

Overall the food was good.  They have a great by-the-glass wine and beer selection, and the staff are helpful and accommodating.  It's a good experience.

I'll stop in again and check up on whether the over-salting was a one-time thing or part of the chef's style.
author: Adam B.

description:
Ambiance - really nice, exposed brick and rafters, water served in brown bottles, a lot of attention was given to how this place is set up.  
Staff - friendly and attentive
Food - good, but pricey and not incredibly outstanding.  the Lobster Roll is their signature dish and it was a little bland and the cost was $24.  I've had tastier and cheaper lobster rolls, but of course that was on the East Coast.  the oysters on the special were very good and the Bailey's milkshake for dessert was good as well.  
Drinks - the beer list is incredible.  Unfortunately, I had to come back to work.  Their non-alcohol drinks also were creative and the ginger beer was quite good.

Overall I'd have to say the food is a 3 but the rest of the set up is a 4.
author: Nedra D.

description:
Ask yourself, is your time valuable?  If so, Anchor and Hopelessness is not for you.     Do you make over $9?/hour, if so their mind-shattering incompetence is also not for you.

The food is just okay.  The staff has got to be on drugs.  People just don't come this stupid,  or do they?  

So, I'm there for happy hour.  Happy hour, the hour where people have SOMEWHERE else to be, and service should be at least reasonably quick.  I order my SUSHI ROLL at 5pm.  The place is packed with wait staff but not customers at the time.  5:20 = First inquiry.  the waitress said that the chef was "overwhelmed" and my order would be out soon.  My order was out in the next 20 minutes.  5:45, and I finally get my sushi roll.  should  be really good?  NOPE!  And to add insult to injury, the retard of a waitress only deducts the roll, nothing else from the bill!   As if my time was only worth $9/hour.  I wanted a snack before heading home, and could have been home before the friggin snack arrived.  Tasted pretty bad, by the way.

Had I known how incredibly slow the service would be, I would never had gone there.
author: Chris S.

description: Good beer, and super trendy, small simple menu, but may be a bit over rated. The shrimp po boy was perfectly cooked, the remoulade sauce had good flavor and a little, kick, but I felt the serrano ham was a bit chewy and out of place on a shrimp po boy.  The ambiance is cool, the staff is nice, but I found it a bit pricey for what it was.  Not the worst, but there are better places to wet the whistle, and have some grub
author: Nick F.

description:
Wow!  This place really met my expectations.  I came here with some friends since we saw this place in our collective Reader feeds, so it seemed liked a good place to check out.  A Google Reader dinner.

A few of us got there early, and set up at the bar.  They have quite the extensive drink list.  Even their draught collection is quite nice!  I haven't had a few of the beers on tap, so I took advantage of trying them!  All quite nice :D  The La Merle especially, with it's kickass glass.

When everyone arrived, we sat down and got some appetizers.  TBH, I don't think I remember them as particularly remarkable, since I can't remember what we got, but I did get the clam chowder.  Clam chowder is one of my favorite foods in the world, so I was pretty excited.  It wasn't the best clam chowder I ever had, but it certainly was one of the most unique.  Tasted quite different from the baseline clam chowder, and I thought it was pretty damn good.  I'd be happy to eat a couple bowls of this for lunch!

As for the main courses, they were all quite good.  I won't say...blow my mind, but I definitely enjoyed them.  I got the trout, and it was great.  The skin was really perfectly cooked.  I also tried the cod and duck, and they were equally delicious.  I didn't try the scallops since I'm not partial to scallops, but I heard good things.

As far as downsides, I thought the portions were a little small, especially considering how expensive the entrees were.  I get that it's a fancy place, and fancy people like to be skinny, but I was pretty hungry.  I had 3 big beers, appetizers, and an entree, and I was still a bit hungry.  Not famished, but when I realized I dropped $80, I still felt hungry.

Before I forget, I should mention that I thought the service was phenomenal.  The hostess to bar staff to waitress to bus boy.  All nice, helpful, and sometimes funny!  I always appreciate good service.

I think if I come back here, it'd be for happy hour.  I could see really enjoying this place tremendously for happy hour.
author: Robert S.

description:
Great kampachi crudo, sea urchin with beurre blanc, salmon tartare, cocktail sauce, shrimp sambal, tomato & burrata salad, 

beau soleil oysters were average.
author: Marina N.

description:
Been here for the 2nd time last week for lunch with a big group, and the food and the service was superb. On our last visit,  our host- George- was spectacular. Our out of town visitors were pleased with the superb treatment. Aside from the oysters, their  salmon was awesome.  The bar is well stocked and have a good wine selection. Wish though they would have  a dungeness crab on the menu being in SFO.
Regardless would keep on coming back.
author: Gilbert T.

description:
Just happened upon this joint while walking along Minna Street.

The beer selection @ Anchor & Hope is phenomenal!  The La Chouffe is excellent.  Smooth and very creamy.

I tried their new england clam and it's very good.   Paired with a pain epi from Acme Bakery with unsalted butter and a sprinkle of fleur de sel- it's fantastic!
author: Randal P.

description:
after my recent boston trip... i have to say, A&H can kick any boston's @ss in lobster roll.... seriously!! i went all over looking for a lobster roll that's better than anchor and hope... and could not... 

came back here for lunch this week and of course, order the lobster roll... yes... i can't have enough lobster... and i've decided... the lobster roll here deserves 5 stars... yes 5 big red stars!!  

the lobster is cooked perfectly on their roll... i've never gotten a piece of over cooked tough lobster here!  the brioche is buttery crispy.... it's just so good.
author: Kelly H.

description:
I've been here twice now and can't complain about anything!!!! :)

I love that this place is tucked away on Minna in the alley to make you feel like you've discovered a hidden gem.

The lobster poor boy is the BEST!  I lived in Boston for around 7 years and know my way around seafood.  This place knows what they're doing. Fantastic menu!

The vibe feels like a downtown manhattan eaterie as well.  Can't put my finger on it, but it just feels very cosmopolitan but effortless and relaxed at the same time.

The Angels on Horseback first course is sooo good I hvae ordered both times.  The shrimp fritters too -- Oi vey are they but good!

Are you a beer snob?  Is white wine an affront to your masculinity?!?!

...then you have arrived my friend, because the beer list is the most amazing thing about this place imho.  The waitress knows how to pour too. I ordered the Weihenstephaner Kristall Weissbier and watched as she poured about half then rolled the bottle between her palms like nobody's business before pouring off the rest -- what a champ!  

...ahem, naturally, I ordered a second.

Great new addition to the SoMa Fin'l District area.  Love it!
author: Luis O.

description:
I haven't been here for dinner, but it was a great spot to get lobster rolls for lunch.  I heard through the grapevine that they actually are made with Atlantic lobster, and even though they weren't the best lobster rolls I'd ever had, they were extremely decent.  It's not New England, after all.  A fun addition to the neighborhood.

Bonus: My favorite beer, Allagash White, is on tap.  This is the first time I'd seen it on tap outside the Northeast.  That bumps it up to 4 stars from 3.
author: Caroline M.

description:
My Fiance and I came here on an impromptu mid week date night. We didnt have reservations however we were able to be seated right away. 

Waiter was very attentive and friendly. Bread and water were brought to us upon arrival.

A nice glass of wine ( Chenin Blanc from France) for me and a rare find brew from the tap for him (Weihenstephan...worlds oldest brewery Freising Germany...if you are ever in Munchen you need to take train to this place great food and beer).

We ordered a few things from the apps menu and shared:

1. Angels on Horseback...pretty good but bacon a bit overpowering, beware of shells. we had two out of the four that we had bit into shells. I think these should have been cleaned better to prevent that.

2.Warm sea urchin in the shell, dungeness crab, lemon beurre blanc...beautiful presentation and if i had to describe this would be like a sea urchin and crab pot pie. good flavor, sea urchin is fresh. You have to like sea urchin to like this, its a texture thing that some people cant deal with. My fiance not a fan of sea urchin but he ate everything else and made she not to scoop up the urchin and that worked well.

3.Slow cooked oxtail marmalade, oven roasted bone marrow and brioche... great flavor however not much comes on a plate. This is more for one person to enjoy and brag about.

4. Dozen oysters...we got one from the east coast (island creek), two from the west coast. (Kusshi and one that i cant remember for the life of me). The oysters were shucked well and were fresh.

5. Salad, wasnt stellar cant remember what was in it.

Overall i would come back and enjoy their dinner menu.
author: Sandra M.

description: A casual place with good food and an extensive beer selection.  Good service but on the noisy side (which seems to be what's in).
author: Nick C.

description: This is my second time here and it wasn't as good as the first.  This review will be relative to the portions of the food, small.  My biggest pet peeve was the popcorn shrimp.  There were three of us and I think there were six pieces, six pieces!  I thought the waitress dropped some on the floor on the way over.  The calamari was better but the entree I had, sea bass for 32 dollars on a bed of a risotto was good but portion was small again.  I understand fish is expensive so how about more risotto?  Anyway, somewhat disappointing because I had a great time when I went last.  I would go back again but I have to order a lot more food.
author: Pierre L.

description:
4.5, really.

It's one of those places I didn't think was kickass right off the bat, but as the evening went on, it got better and better. The food was really (really) good, and I can see myself coming back time after time. Service was great. But something about the atmosphere bugged me. Nautical themes just kind of weird me out, I guess, after too many (two) trips to the subpar Bubba Gump's. I completely chalk that up to my own hang-ups though, and not to A&H.

It's very SoMa in here, with the cavernous ceilings and repurposed warehouse space - so it's not exactly intimate. Good for a group of six, which we were.

The food was killer, and reheated just fine the next day. The curried shrimp appetizer with rice was a bit too large for an appetizer, but damn was it tasty. My lobster roll entrée (with kettle chips and coleslaw that did NOT taste like mayonnaise) was delicious, and I savored every single one of those buttery little pieces of lobster. Wine and beer selection was good, I liked the bubbly starter as much as the Czechvar beer. I left way stuffed, leftovers in hand.

The damage was about $75 a person, which isn't bad for some nice din.
author: Tara R.

description:
Came here with a few coworkers to try the DAT menu during a workday lunch.  Of course, I didn't end up  getting the DAT menu because the menu items look so much more appetizing.  On a coworker''s and the waiter's recommendation, I ordered the lobster roll which the waiter assured me would be more than filling. 
All I can say is that obviously the waiter has never served a girl from Texas before.  One lobster roll and $33 later, I was still kind of hungry!  Definitely not starving but I would have eaten more if I could afford it!  
Regardless, it was a pretty good lobster roll.  Had little mayonnaise, lots of lobster meat and an extremely buttered roll but not the best I've ever had.  Also, the fries were decent but that was it.  It would have made for sense for those to come with my lobster roll instead of the extra $6 we had to pay.  

Review:  Good to try but not great enough to warrant another trip.
author: Susan L.

description:
I was in San Francisco for a couple days and decided to find a place to have my friends meet me for dinner. One of my friends there asked me what type of restaurant I was looking for (to help me choose a place) and I said: One with brick walls and metal beams that feels like a converted warehouse. You know, pretty much what I imagine a cool restaurant in San Francisco to be like.

At first I was greeted with laughter as my description was not of the detail expected. Nevertheless, he gave me a few options and I picked this one. As it turns out, my criteria worked exceptionally!

This place is very warehouse-modern inside. And, it has excellent food! Modern American/seafood fare. I really love Anchor & Hope - I almost want to go back to San Francisco just for this.
author: Touradj B.

description: Salmon, sweet corn soup and Cesar salad all fantastic.  Fruit crisp excellent.  Service attentive but not intrusive.  Lovely evening.  The calamari was the only disappointment.  Cold, too much breading and a bitter tasting sauce.
author: Pamela M.

description: this place gives me ... Hope. And, great dishes. Love the atmosphere, love the food (great seafood, always), dig the beers. And because its a little off the beaten path, the crowd is always less touristy than your average upscale restaurant near Market and the Embarcadero.
author: Ricki M.

description: Went here on a first date. Chill atmosphere. Seemed a bit empty, but it was a Wednesday night. the service was excellent. My date was like 30 minutes late, and the servers gave me complimentary snacks and drinks. I had Calamari and the NY strip steak. The food was good. I felt the menu was too small / limited however. That's why I ended up ordering steak at a seafood place. A tad on the expensive side. Overall pretty good though.
author: Neal F.

description: Had dinner here, well actually skipped the entree's and worked through the appetizers.  Atmosphere was terrific a huge open space that you would think would make conversation difficult, but not the case at all.  The restaurant and bar area was packed but it was easy to move about to and from the restroom.  Oysters were fresh and delicious, Angels on Horseback are as tasty as every picture, the sauce that accompanies the calamari  is insane!
author: Richard W.

description:
Gorgeous gorgeous space in a rehabbed warehouse..Easy to get to from BART.

Acme baguette with Berkeley Farms butter....the ultimate yum combo.

House made gravlax..makes your eyes roll back in your head...perfection.  I would order this every time I came to this place.

Yum yum yum salads.

Great brews on tap.

Long live Anchor and Hope
author: Bleep S.

description:
I really enjoyed this restaurant with its laid back atmosphere and good food. This is a very solid fish restaurant and the scallop ceviche is excellant and definetly the best I have ever had. I had the lobster tail for my main course which was very tasty however the there wasn't much lobster which I wasn't a fan of. My girlfriend had the Uni soup which she really enjoyed however another one of her friends complained that the Uni was not fresh (I don't know, dont care either, it tasted good to me). Halibut looked slightly overcooked but was nice all the same.

Probably a three and half star restaurant but I loved the music and atmosphere so it bumped it up half a star in my book.
author: Don J.

description:
Anchor & Hope is a really smart, unique space - half white with modern graphic accents, half "old wharf" bleached wood nautical.  I went there for lunch - single girl from out of town here for a conference - on the recommendation ("it's mildy funky") of a local friend.  I seriously needed some funk after a morning of FIFO, CAPEX and EBITDA, so I headed over.

There was a short line upon arrival at 12:40pm on a Friday, but I was able to immediately squeeze in to a single seat at the bar.  Got a menu - and whew, I have to say, I knew SF was expensive but this was way beyond my modest Austinite expectations - $10-$15 for apps and $20-$30 for main courses. I was also surprised by the fact that the seafood offerings weren't that extensive - a good minority of the menu were things like chicken salad and gnocchi.  

After suppressing the fleeting desire to flee with my wallet intact, I decided to stick it out and ordered the salmon gravlax/salad appetizer and the steamed mussel and clams for the meal.  

The salmon was very good - fresh, sliced very thin, with a nice pile of greens on the top and very finely chopped onion. I could have used less dressing, but that's just me.  At $10, this appetizer was actually a good deal given the volume of salmon on the plate.  

But it was the steamed mussels and clams ($17.50) that really made me glad I came.  Perhaps a dozen plump shellfish floating in a fragrant yellow broth chock full of slivers of onions and bell peppers.  A fun extra touch was 4 tiny sausage balls along with - presumably for flavoring.  I ate every bit of that dish, and sopped up all the broth with the chewy fresh bread provided.  Mmmm.

Service was very friendly and accommodating.  The waiter didn't blink when I asked for extra bread to take home with my excess salmon, and he was happy to get me some tin foil for my leftovers rather than the standard big styro box (I hate those styro boxes).  

Truly excellent food, but the bill of $35 for one lunch eater who drank water is a shock to the system.  Yikes.
author: M B.

description:
This review is for weekday lunch... 

We went for DAT. Some ordered the prix fix, some off the menu. The food was pretty good... pricey for what we got... I ordered the ceviche but disappointed because they put some sort of creamy dressing on it. No need for that stuff. Tho - the service was EXCELLENT.

I would go again, I will probably be back for dinner to give it another try!
author: Heidi L.

description:
I went here the other night with my three girlfriends.  We had the mussels and sea urchin as starters. The sea urchin was quite delicious and savory. I'd definitely come back here for it. The mussels were nice, but not memorable. As an entree I had the trout. It was tasty, a little salty, but overall good.

I felt that the restaurant is a bit overpriced. Wines by the glass were somewhat expensive. I had two glasses of wine, and I think out the door was close to $90. I probably won't come back here for dinner.
author: Cindy Y.

description: This place was amazing. The staff was so welcoming and helpful. They have a great wine list and offer great suggestions if you aren't sure what to get. The menu had some many great items it was hard to decide, we even got an order of fries to share at the table because they sounded so good and they were. Next time Im in San Fran, I will be dining here again.
author: Sarah C.

description:
When i was a kid, I always wanted to go to the big fancy restaurant at the end of Oceanside pier.  My parents said "no way, that place sucks".  So with my shit job I had at 17, I took a date there. Disastrous....It was bland, gaudy and overpriced.  Two weeks later I went to the cheap fishhouse with a real Anchor hanging from the ceiling.  Just a quick fish sandwich after surfing.  It was cheap, comfy and yummy.  You're all "where is this review going?" The point is most seafood places are one or the other.  You go to a nice place with a light hearted nautical theme, and the food is always a joke, or it's a cheap dive with greasy but great grub.  This place is the best of both worlds.  This place gets it.  Just cause I'm a grown up with a delicate pallet doesn't mean I don't like theme restaurants.  I just wish this place was in my home town 15 years ago.

Bacon rapped oysters, fuck yea. 5stars

Heirloom salad, yum. 4stars

Raw bar, overpriced perfection 5stars (money is no object with raw food this good)

Sole over bacon succotash, indulgent, hearty and a most creative use of trumpet mushrooms. 5star

Dessert, blackout cake.  Heaven for chocolate lovers.
