Why no five star.....the fucking music.....I HOPE YOU GUYS AT ANCHOR AND HOPE ARE LISTENING.  NO LIVE 105, NO SUBLIME AND NO POP HITS.  get some friggin taste.  Trying to tell my girlfriend about some heavy shit and that crap comes over the P.A..  Sad.

Also the waitperson checked in too much and sounded like she was reading a script (instead of actually knowing the food).

so the food was superduper and the look was cool and the staff was OK and the music was shit
author: gabriel a.

description:
Wonderful Lunch.  Tried the Lobster Bisque which was outstanding.  The Lobster Roll was excellent, but a lot of bread.  Can't wait to go back and try dinner.

We had a big party for a business lunch, and the service was very good.  But needed to get there early to get a table big enough.
author: Alan L.

description:
Atmosphere- very cool & lively. Open high-ceilings warehouse feel with exposed brick & wood joist ceiling. Note: it gets loud! While I appreciate the rustic feel, the designer could have incorporated some soft surfaces, cool drapes or accoustical treatment to absorb some of the sound.

Food/drink: yes, great wine list & wide selection of yummy international beers. Bartenders are extremely nice & knowledgeable of the wines & give you a tiny taste of to decide. Food is good, but still lacks that distinct factor that stands out in your memory. I think the lobster roll was too mayonaise-y. 

Service: I've been there quite a few times & it has varied each time from really good to 'where IS she!!?' They're all nice, but as a fellow Yelper said, it's spotty when they're busy. They need to be more consistent here. Also, not sure if the wait staff does tastings of the daily specials, but a vivid description & honest recommendation is something I really appreciate & look for.

Crank it up a notch, A&H. I'm rooting for you. :-)
author: Jamie R.

description:
I really like Anchor & Hope. Its perfect for a cool friday or Saturday early evening or happy hour if your happy hour starts at 5pm. The space is really nice and a very nice selection of wine.  

The food is a bit overpriced and not everything is worthy of the pricing. Was that a double negative statement?  Well it fits. The calamari is pretty good and the chili sauce makes it better and the salmon or halibut well whatever fish it was it was great but all our other dining eats where ok like the oysters ummm so so but the bread and the service was great and my side of garlic veggies.

Oh yeah the chowder is awesome!

A&H isn't all bad but dine at your own risk
author: Karim R.

description: My first visit was with a colleague. She surprised me with a spontaneous lunch. We both ordered fish taco. It was the best fish taco I ever had! And the side grilled corn was also so good, fresh, sweet, and juicy. 2nd visit with a large group, could not find fish taco on the menu anymore. They change menu frequently. We ordered many dishes, but nothing as memorable as fish taco.
author: Emmy P.

description:
Good food, not great, and somewhat pricey for what it is.  Clam chowder was tasty, if a bit thin.  Heirloom tomato soup was also decent, but not great.  The sea bass was tasty, and the fish and chips was good...lightly battered with good fries, although the second piece of fish was pretty small.

The service, however, is quite another story...some of the worst ever.  Too-long wait to be offered a drink, followed by the always amusing (and tip-reducing) server disappearing act after we ordered our food.  We saw him, so we know he was there...tending to other tables, gabbing with his buddies at the bar.  He never bothered to stop by to ask how everything was or if we needed anything, until at least 10 minutes after we finished our food.  I'm sure he was planning to bring dessert menus but, at that point, all I wanted was to get the check and get out of there.  

We won't return, which is a shame, since the food is actually decent.  There are better and more pleasant places to spend over a hundred bucks on dinner, where I'm happy to tip well for good service.
author: Glenn R.

description:
I suspect this place is a 4, but I just went for apps at the bar.

I had the 1$ oysters which were quite nice (\better than what I get on the east coast) followed by the salt cod which was just ok. Finally I had the bone marrow with ox tail marmalade which I liked very much, but there was so little of it...I loved it but I wanted more.

As for the rest, the abandoned warehouse decor was cool, the bartendress was nice enough, and the beer selection was good (I think)...full disclosure, I'm a beer geek from the east coast, so there were a lot of new beer options to me which may not be that new to a west coaster...at any rate, I was happy.
author: Mike R.

description:
At times one is sure that they are witnessing a religious revival when eating food; as if the pure act of consuming morsels so succulent and magnificent with one's body is an act of divine praise akin to a spiritual quest.
It's pretty cool if you can achieve that feeling for under $50, to boot.

Last week Anchor & Hope was the temple at which I prayed. I pledged my devotion at the alter of a delicious $6 microbrewed wheat beer; a fresh and delicious little gem lettuces salad (an executive chef could put the term "little" and "gem" in front of the word "rubber" and I'd still love it), and scallops and risotto so breathtaking I had to splash water on my face and listen to Terry Gross from NPR for an hour to cool myself down.

There's more: the hostess who was oh-so-attentive was probably the most beautiful woman I have ever seen. It just goes to show you that a little seafood and a black cocktail dress are really all you need to have an excellent night. Throw in an extremely cool restaurant on one of the dingiest streets in North America and we're talking extra special hip.

But seriously, the shanty town down the street from the bus station on the next block couldn't dim my love of Anchor & Hope. I will gladly lower my anchor in these calming waters and assess your bounty as often as I am able. I hope.
author: Ross S.

description: I wouldn't bother coming here....the only thing I liked was the uni and crab dish.
author: Cha C.

description: My partner and I came to SF on business, but came a day early to just walk around and take in some good food. We made a reservation at the A&H which was a short walk from our hotel on the Embarcadero. The place was full of locals which is a good sign in touristy SF. The service was excellent on a busy Saturday. Appetizers were raw oyster (mix them up) also the angels on horseback   were perfectly done. She had the salmon and I stuck with the lobster roll, both fresh.  I will go back on my next visit.
author: Barry M.

description:
I came here with a friend last week and we loved it!  I highly recommend the Sea Urchin appetizer (has crab and I think a lemon butter as well).  For entrees we got the trout and sea bass.  Both were very well composed and flavorful dishes.

Perhaps even more impressive than the food is the drink selection. We had a White Ale flight (one light-bodied, one medium-bodied, and one full-bodied), which I thought was really cool as I like to enjoy variety when I can.  We also had this amazing trappist ale that might be my favorite now.  I believe it was called Koning's Hoeven.  I like to go to a place where I can always try something new, and with this selection, I'll be finding new gems for quite some time to come.

Service was warm and efficient, and I thought there was a strong soul/identity about the place (like how your bread comes as a baguette in a brown bag).

I will be returning!
author: Eric R.

description: Went here for a business lunch. It was ok. Nothing spectacular. A little pricey for just ok food. We went there at 1pm, so it slowed down quite a bit, so I was a little peeved that the server was still so inattentive. Won't take a client here again, but may swing by for raw oysters when I'm in the mood since it's down the block from my apartment.
author: Tiffany K.

description: The beer selection is worth a visit! The Bacon wrapped oysters are also great (i mean - its bacon). The rest is good, but not spectacular...
author: Rasmus P.

description:
either i was disappointed or had really high expectations of anchor and hope considering it made the 100 things to eat in sf list.  we came here for dinner and ended up being one of the few parties left dining.  out of all places to seat us, they decided to seat us at one of the smallest tables next to one of the metal columns coming down from the wall.

now onto the food.  we ordered oysters, angels on horseback, an eggplant appetizer, black cod with crispy pork belly, and the lobster roll.  only one pair of the oysters were good.  the angels on horseback were good but nothing spectacular and something you could get at another place.  the black cod had no taste and needed salt.  the lobster roll was way too salty and we ended up taking the dessert to go.  the almond chocolate cake was dry and not very impressive.  i would definitely go back to salt house before i come back to anchor and hope.
author: Carli F.

description:
I came here a while ago with a group of 8, and the service was excellent.  We split the calamari, which is one of my favorite things to order wherever I go, and their version did not disappoint.  Although I wouldn't consider myself a seafood lover, I'm definitely a fan, and was brave enough to try a bite of the gooey sea urchin, which I had never had before.  Let's just say I was more impressed with the lobster roll.  I like seafood with a crisp sauv blanc, but went for the prosecco on this occasion...you can't go wrong with bubbly IMHO.

The main highlight was the service.  They were very accommodating when we added people to our group and let us linger as long as we wanted.
author: Laura B.

description:
Perfection. Utter perfection.

Ambiance? 5 stars. Service? 5 stars. Food? 5 amazing stars.

Seriously, in pure Yelpian terms, this place goes to 6.

I almost want to say that it's the service that really takes Anchor and Hope over the top. The servers, from the maitre-d' on to the woman who poured our bubbles to our table server, were all genuinely nice people. And oh, so helpful. I usually think anyone who puts up with my crap deserves a good tip. The people here answered my questions and really went the extra few miles.

For example: When I asked for a wine pairing with my crab bisque appetizer, and I said that two recommendations sounded good, the waiter brought out two glasses and let me decide between the two. Bravo!

For entree, I chose the much-heralded paella with half a shell-on crab. Yes, shell-on crab is a lot of work, but if you like getting your hands dirty like I do, it IS worth it. The other meats in this smorgasbord were mussel, sausage, and chicken. I'm eating the leftovers now, next day, and they're just as heavenly.

Anchor and Hope will set your dreams of a debt-free existence back a few paychecks, but it's oh so worth it. Extra points for being fairly easy to get to, as opposed to many seafood locales on the northeast waterfront.

I'm going back, just as soon as I finish paying off this credit card.
author: Jeff H.

description:
This is the third Doug Washington (formerly of Jardineire, but currently of Town Hall and Salt House fame) enterprise to open in a 0.5 mile radius (no joke) within a year. Any self-respecting SF foodie had to taste the hype. With unbridled excitement, I did so within days of its commencement on April 22.

Spartan decor in a converted warehouse I'd kill to live in. A nice Stoic start; duly noted. 

Unfortunately, any further positive note-taking is nonexistent. Fortunately, I had the foresight of self-accessorizing with a bottle of 1990 Chateau Pichon Longueville Comtesse de Lalande. While my foresight saved me from whining about the prosaic wine list at the time, it's not doing much for Anchor & Hope now as I recall having had to request that it be decanted. Did the wait staff not notice the way I was cradling and caressing this bottled poetry? To add to my dismay, the joke glasses were never removed and I was forced to propose a stemware exchange...

The menu was imaginative but unappealing. Granted that this is a bit of an "oyster bar," what is with the shell fish lineup? From lobster, to clam,  to crab, and prawn... I only intended to be branded a bad Jewess for one evening! That means no mussel stew for me, either.

Without sighting a single hama hama on the menu or basking in the ice trough, this soon-to-be-blacklisted Jewess settled for a tasting of the chowder, prawns, lobster roll, and sea bass. With special exception to the chowder, the rest of the Little Mermaid entourage was lousy and utterly forgettable.

My wine was rich and austere, though, and finally opened up after an hour. Its fabulous chocolatey aftertaste saved me from having to select more mediocrity from A&H's unpromising dessert menu. I pat myself on the back for bringing an accessory that not only tasted immaculate but also hastened my escape from the Nemo nightmare.

Notwithstanding my lackluster dining experience, the evening wrapped up charmingly as Mr. Washington himself came out to chat about the wine. Feeling bibulous, I ask him for the anchor-shaped leaded paperweight that accompanied the bill. He claimed he only ordered 30 and they cost $40 each. I told him he would have been better off devoting the funds to lighting the restaurant. Seriously, I added, it needs a few buckets of flair.

Leaving Doug still in shock, I escaped the dimly lit lair, which has now begun to resemble a socialist cafeteria. Magically, I realized that 111 Minna is a trot down the street. Moses doesn't hate me yet.
author: Nobody X.

description:
My friend D and I came in here 10min before closing, HOPEing that getting a bite would be feasible. The staff were beyond kind, we sat at the bar and proceeded to have some of the best seafood I've had in a while.

There is one thing here that is so delectable, I'm dreaming of it days later: The warm sea urchin in the shell. I'd never tried sea urchin...and we hesitated, but our server convinced us (rightly so) that this was the best thing on the menu.

This was followed by the other star hits: Angels on Horseback, and the Lobster Roll. 

I'll be back for sure, the staff was friendly, and the food top notch.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Casual Seafood.  Quality food, decent portions, attentive, very personable service (Roz was great). "Live" acoustics so difficult to hear. Yelpers are right: the bacon-wrapped oysters were great (Angels on Horseback).  Funky decor. Vintage lightbulbs are cool. Also not easy to find (one way alley). Only major complaint was that the Lobster Roll was not classic. Shredded lobster meat in vinegar, etc.
author: Bob B.

description: Came for lunch.  Very nice atmosphere and decor.  Large section of seafood and beer. Entrees were tasty, nicely prepared, and well seasoned.  Everything was a bit on the pricey side and I almost felt neglected by the waitress...  I'd probably go back but just sit at the bar.
author: Matt J.

description:
I am a little biased because Doug Washington is in my personal pantheon of culinary superstars. There were three of us dining, a little early in the evening on a weeknight. 

Service was good, though not what I have come to expect from Anchor and Hope's big-sister Town Hall. The waitstaff just seemed a little greener. I started with the Angels on Horseback (bacon-wrapped oysters), which I quickly regretted. The oysters did not seem especially fresh and the heavy flavors seemed intended more as a way to use leftover oysters than to highlight the bright fresh flavors of the ocean one expects from an oyster. I would stick to the raw selection in the future. 

Bacon wrapped oysters to start, so you know I had to go big on the entree. The Lobster Pot Pie is definitely in my top five favorites of all time. I might even consider changing it to my Last Meal on Yelp. A light yet buttery puff pastry crust encloses the lobster pot pie goodness within. The sauce was delicate and complex and thickened just enough that it napped the lobster and vegetables with moisture and flavor without weighing down the dish. 

If only I could have started it with Town Hall's Fried Green Tomatoes and Tuna Tartare.
author: Joshua R.

description:
When I first arrived in San Francisco, my friend drove me straight to Anchor and Hope from the airport.  What a treat!

We had the small sampler with 6 different kinds of oysters, crawfish, shrimp, clams, and sauces.  I was almost full off the sampler when the Sea Urchin appetizer came out.  My mouth watered.

The appetizer, which was a sea urchin/crab chowder in the urchin shell, was amazing.  Good with the bread they serve in the beginning.  I am not a fan of sea urchin, but this dish can quickly convert you.

For the main course we shared the sole on potatoes and brussell sprouts, which was absolutely delicious.  It had a light flavor but it was still tasty!  We were both full by the end of the meal.

Parking may be a little hard to find, but it definitely is worth it!
author: Lauren S.

description:
There's a hot new player in the yelperhood. Anchor & Hope is the newest restaurant from the team behind Town Hall and Salt House, and quite possibly my favorite of the three. A seafood shack with a modern and industrial feel, you can be assured that the food is just as creative as the decor.

I love the nautical theme and all the fine little details that bring it together. Everything from the names of oyster ports stenciled onto the vintagey light bulbs along the wall to the anchor ball that holds the check down makes the place unique. The super cool piranhas painted on the wall were done by owner Doug Washington's wife.

Service was top notch. The staff was extremely accommodating and our server, Devon, was wonderful. We originally started as a party of two, but when we needed to add another place setting, they were able to make arrangements and move us two tables down to the corner table (the best seat in the house, because you could see everything going on), even though they were a full house.

Everything on the handwritten menu sounded amazing. We started off with the fried Ipswich clams and sea urchin with mashed potatoes and dungeness crab, both very salty and rich. Make sure you spread the creamy sea urchin onto their freshly baked bread - it's delicious. For those of you who aren't a fan of uni, this is a great way to eat it because the texture and flavors are masked. Devon recommended a lovely Chenin Blanc to go with the sea bass that I ordered. I loved the fish and the cumin potatoes, ramps and cider soaked apples that accompanied it. My dining mates had the fried halibut (a bit dry) and potato wedges and the $25 lobster roll with chips and slaw. The sea bass was the table favorite. We ended with the heart of sweet cream with strawberries and lavender tea cookies. It was the way to go after a filling dinner!
author: Connie C.

description:
Anchor & Hope has a few great things going for it:

1/ Service - these restaurant guys (Town Hall, Salt House) really know how to run a place.  
2/ Beer & Wine - affordable, interesting choices.  Belgians go well with seafood!
3/ Atmosphere - upscale casual done well, historic building character and charm

For food, I the appetizers we had kicked the asses of the main courses:
Angels on Horseback - bacon wrapped oysters - decadent and delicious
Clams in Basil Broth - perfect, incredible spicy/savory broth with almond butter...sopped up every last ounce 
Smoked Trout Salad - this was good, and would have been excellent with one more poached egg on top

For our main courses we had the Lobster Pot Pie and the Petrale Sole, which were good, but not great.  The crust on the pot pie was excellent, but the lobster kind of got lost in the sauce (is this a lobster?  a potato?  not sure).  The sole was cooked well but there were a lot of flavors going on in the dish, perhaps one or two too many.

Friendliness and good service go a long way, and next time I would sit at the bar and dig into some clams, a lobster roll, or a selection from the raw bar.  Oh, and that urchin has my name on it - it will be mine.
author: Liz S.

description:
Since my first visit back in mid-May, I've been to Anchor & Hope a few more times for lunch but it was last Thursday that I finally went in for a full dinner. 

Despite the holiday weekend, the place was hopping at 6:30pm, and only got busier as the night progressed. Service was spot on, and it didn't hurt that Doug was in the house, making the rounds.

I went with the Smithwick's Battered Bass (used to be Halibut), and honest to Gawd, it might have been the best version of fish and ships this old yelper has ever had. Complemented with a side order of their fried pearl onions, the meal could only have been made better if we had remembered to order some "Angels on Horseback" for the table.

Always next time, I suppose.
author: Nish N.

description: Went here for lunch and tried the rockfish. Who knew that rockfish could be so good?! It was cooked just right and had the perfect amount of sauce. It was a pricey for lunch, but the presentation and flavors were excellent. Service was also pretty quick considering how crowded the restaurant was too. I'll be back for sure to try more items on the menu.
author: Jenn J.

description:
I had to upgrade you today. Seriously you deserve it, don't be embarrassed be proud. 

This was my third time at A&H and a third time is a charm. You most certainly charmed me today. I sat at the bar and just enjoyed myself. I started with some of those yummy rolls! I want more and more and more but I need room for my main course. I decided to have a Savignon Blanc from Alsace region and with that the tombo tuna melt. Perfection is all I have to say! I enjoyed it so much I chose to have a second glass of this most amazing wine. 

A&H is going to be one of my favorite places. The decor, service and food all have me sold! I am a big fan. Maybe I need to start a fan page on Facebook. Hmmmm!
author: Scott P.

description:
This was going to be a review featuring my bickering, conflicted inner voices (Me, Myself and I) but the dysfunctional trio inside my head is strangely silent on the subject of Anchor & Hope.  Seafood as therapy...I could definitely go for that.

Given that the inner critics are uncommunicative, let's just talk about the visit.

The staff was friendly and professional; from the welcoming gentleman at the host stand to our waiter who gracefully explained the lack of wine list at our table (Anchor & Hope's liquor license was delayed).  

The space is a rehabbed old warehouse with soaring wood ceilings, an open floorplan, nautical touches and a palette of grays and blues that somehow manages to not seem icy.  How did they do that?

The food:
Our shrimp cocktail appetizer was very basic, if beautifully presented.
Our mains were delicious!  I had pan-roasted black sea bass with thinly sliced potatoes and wonderfully lemony wilted greens.  My friend had Guinness-battered halibut with spicy steak fries - quite possibly the most delicious 'fish and chips' dinner I've ever tried.  And perhaps the most expensive...

We didn't stay for dessert, but on our way out we were warmly invited to come back again soon.  

I can't put my finger on the reason why I liked this place so much on the very first try.  It could be that I wanted to taste most of the entrees on the menu.  It could be the touch of elegance combined with whimsy in the decor and execution.  Another reviewer mentioned the word magical and I think that might have some merit - sometimes a restaurant just hits the right notes at the right time.  All I know is I'm very happy to have this place so close, and I will definitely be back to try their food with wine.  And some dessert...

(Update 5/02:  Liquor license issue resolved!)
author: Suzanne B.

description: Food and atmosphere were excellent, but unless it's normal for a party of 4 to wait 20min for drinks to arrive and 1.5hrs for entrees at lunch, the service was terrible.
author: joel m.

description: This restaurant is great. Been there 4-5 times now and it is good every time. The staff is really nice especially Colleen the manager. Recommend the seafood platter, moules frites, and of course the home made potato chips washed down with microbrews. Doesn't get much better.
author: Tony D.

description:
In case you didn't know, Anchor & Hope is a new venture by the folks who own Town Hall and Salt House. Salt House is now one of my after-work standards, so I was really excited when Nish, Stephy and I went to check this place out. The atmo is really great -- it looks like a cozy loft space with tall ceilings, exposed brick, wood beams and a really cool modern art piece on the wall above the bar.

The wine was free flowing and the sea food appetizers were delish! Oysters on the half shell, huge prawns, stuffed clams, fried calamari, bacon wrapped oysters and a creamy clam bisque all came out of the kitchen quickly and were eaten just as fast, let me tell ya. The menu looks amazing! The fries with eyes definitely intrigued me.

I can picture myself coming back frequently for a coveted space at the bar for vino and bites. Besides, what's better than bacon wrapped oysters??? Uh, nada.
author: Nicole G.

description: great seafood and ambiance. Customer service is the best i've seen in any restaurant enviroment.  Staff will make you feel very welcome and will accomodate you in any way they can.  Seafood is excellent, great sea urchint.  i left my credit card there by mistake and the manager personally brought it to my work for me.
author: Jimmy H.

description:
Hummmmm, Overall I will say the food was good! I was let down by the bone marrow appetizer, it was more like a bread crumb and bone. Lets face it, bones are cheap and you could put at least a few of them on a the plate. Our wait staff was never around, never asked how the meal was, had to chase her down to order more drinks cause the food took so long to come out. Not sure if the kitchen was in the weeds or she couldn't handle the tables she had. Would have liked to stay for after dinner drink but she really blew the mood. the only thing she was quick at was dropping the check and picking it up! 
The food is good but not worth the wait or price....
Anchor & Hope, Zuni your not!!!
author: WildBill C.

description:
Yay yay yay, I got to try this place before you did, I'm special, la la la la.

Okay enough of that and I hope you know I'm kidding, but what is no joke is how much this place rocks. I went to the soft opening last night and am still feeling it, thanks red wine and champagne! 

It's a really cool spot and I loved the looks of the place. Super tall, open ceilings, groovy raw beams, nautical ropes, and the coolest black fishy painting on the wall. I understand the owner's wife is responsible for that and props to you, my dear, it looks manufique! 

As for the staff, everyone was super friendly and cool and there are some real cuties working here as well, so come for the eye candy, stay for the food!

Which reminds me, the food! YUM. They were passing little samples around and all were pretty much hits. I tried the crab and artichoke dip on the leedle toasts (deelish), the stuffed clams on the shells (super deelish), the lobster roll (oh yeah!!). Sadly I couldn't try the bacon wrapped oyster, since I am allergic to oysters, but holy hell, if that isn't happiness on a plate I don't know what is. I mean, c'mon, it's got bacon and everything is better with bacon :)

I will definitely be coming back here for dinner soon and you should too, ya know when it's open for all of your "normal" people, hehe. I keeed, I keeed ;)
author: Stephy S.

description:
Solid seafood centric restaurant from the folks behind Town Hall and Salt House. The space is fantastic - huge ceilings with exposed beams and we ended up with the best seat in the house...a two top in the corner so we could check out all the action around us.

Food was solid - our beet salad was a great way to kick off the meal and I really enjoyed my ahi. My friend's salmon may have been a tad bit undercooked but she still enjoyed it. Service was a bit bumpy - our waitress was sweet but also disappeared for long stretches at a time. Also, we ordered a side of cauliflower and it didn't arrive with our food. We told our waitress and she put in another order for us - it didn't arrive until we were just about done with our entrees and had so much red pepper flakes on it that it was pretty much inedible anyhow. She did however take it off the bill since it arrived so late. Dessert was a chocolate cake and it was fine, not all that memorable actually. 

Lots of great choices on the menu that we didn't get to and relatively inexpensive considering the quality and freshness of the seafood will bring me back to Anchor & Hope. Hopefully I'll be able to venture out a bit from my boring old tuna stand bye!
author: phil h.

description:
Been here multiple times  and always had great seafood and wonderful service.

Many good dishes to list here, but the one very fun, creative but somewhat scary side order called the "Fries with Eyes", which I can never forget , were deep fried small to medium size fish with head on.  We ordered it once out of curiosity and it didn't taste as cute as it sounded.  Kinda soggy and limpy. Halloween anyone?

Fries with Eyes aside, I will be back for the rest of the food on the menu.
author: Florence W.

description:
Maybe it's that SOMA-warehouse-chic crossed with cottage-on-the-Cape-with-a-gentle-sea-breeze is my heart's home decor style, but I was happy as the clams looked delicious on the menu to be at Anchor & Hope last Thursday.  

Friendly people (I think I have a--giggle--middle school crush on Doug), happy ambiance (there are fish painted on the wall - BIG fish eating little FISH), and yummy food (memorable dishes included the uni and crab app as well as the lobster roll.)  

You bet your bottom sand dollar, I will be back!
author: Audrey T.

description:
My husband and I have been known to be complete gluttons when it comes to over ordering at restaurants. It's like we lose all concept of the size of our appetites when we start reading a menu. Or we'll be full from a meal we just consumed mere hours ago and think we need another snack when we see a menu. It's bad. 

This gluttonous behavior happened to us when we entered Anchor & Hope. We were taken by the wonderful atmosphere, friendly hostess and big bucket of what looked to be Acme bread at the end of the bar. 

Once we looked at the menu, we were hooked. We were in traditional form and decided to order a variety of items so we could try everything that sounded good. 

Our waitress was nice enough to split our dishes (without us asking) so we each had our own plates of food. 

Here's what we tried. 

Parsnip and dungeness crab bisque - amazingly creamy and just the right amount of crab. It was sinfully rich. 

Basil broth steamed clams - well prepared clams and tasty broth. We used the aforementioned Acme bread to soak up every last drop of the broth. 

Warm sea urchin with potato puree and dungeness crab - this was a standout dish and made the meal for me. The urchin tasted like the sea (in a good way) and was delicate, smooth and went well with the potato and crab combo. At $16.50 it's a splurge, but worth every morsel. 

Lobster roll - huge chunks of lobster, served on brioche and house made potato chips. 

I wanted to order the brussels sprouts, calamari and house made salmon gravlax but somehow restrained myself. In retrospect,  I'm happy about that because I need to save a few menu items to try during our next visit.
author: Lee H.

description:
I was very excited to try this place - heard a lot of good things so I took a couple of co-workers from out of town to try it

Service was the biggest issue overall. We had 3 different servers - and the hostess forgot about us and had us wait at the bar for almost 40 minutes before I had to go up to her to remind her we were still there.  She admitted she forgot about us.  Better than trying to cover it up I guess.

The sea urchin appetizer was excellent, my co-worker said the Clam Chowder was watery, my lobster roll was pretty good although a bit too bready (at least the mayo content was okay), fish and chips were okay, and the whole branzino was really good but the orzo was full of butter.

I'd go back just because I like the environment and proximity to work but if it is just mediocre again, that will be my last visit.
author: Rishi G.

description:
This restaurant is a great alternative with good food and attentive wait staff to more traditional financial district restaurants, and less noisy than their sister restaurants and less expensive than RN74.  HOWEVER...the experience did not start well.

We had a reservation for a party of 2 for 12:30 pm.  Since it was the first time either of us had gone to Anchor & Hope, and didn't know it was so easy to walk to, we arrived a bit earlier at 12:10. (And we wanted to finish lunch early to get back to meetings.)  The restaurant was busy but there were tables opened.  We asked the hostess if we could be seated earlier and she was pretty non-committal and said they have some reservations coming in.  We waited in the small entrance way, along with 2 other parties since the bar seating was filled up.  So I swear she seats 2 ladies who walked in WITHOUT a reservation who came in AFTER US.  In the mean time, there are still 2 tables open (from the time we came in the restaurant).  Then my friend remarks, "I hope she didnt make us stand for 20 minutes and will seat us at that table right by the door that has been open all this time."   So we're still waiting. 

And then at 12:30, the hostess seats us at the rickety table that was open all along, which she wouldn't let us take.

AND, then my friend points out to her, why did you make us wait since that table was open the whole time?  She mumbles some excuse WITHOUT AN APOLOGY OF ANY SORT about the restaurant having to work out the number of tables, blah blah blah.  

So mind you, were were hungry and now even cranky.  And we had been waiting for 20 minutes for a table we had been staring at... Did she want a tip or something to seat us earlier?  

When we sat down, the table was uneven, which they fixed for us.  The menu looked good, but my appetite was already surpassed by my upsetness.   

We ordered the Angels on Horseback - bacon wrapped oysters ($13) which are a MUST HAVE if you try your luck here.  I had the blackened catfish sandwich and my friend had fish and chips ($23).  The food is pretty good, but we were pretty irritated to enjoy the experience.  I have to say, the wait staff was really attentive and nice and made up a little for the hostess.

Your wonderful wait staff cannot continue to make up for the lack of experience and the poor attitude of your inept hostess.  She is on the front line and that is the first experience your customers will have at your restaurant.
author: Betty L.

description:
Anchor & Hope is a really nice restaurant with great (sea)food.  Love the large open space and the fish decor over their exposed brick wall.  They have a bar area where you can drink beer and chit chat with friends too if you're not looking for a full meal.

We ordered the infamous Angels on Horse back appetizer--bacon-wrapped oysters--and tuna tar tar, both delicious and very fresh.  I had a fish entree which was prepared very well too.  

Overall presentation, ambiance, and taste of their food are all great, but don't expect to go home full after just that.  It's also more on the pricey side (but that's the norm for good seafood right?)  A good place to go for business lunch or dinner nonetheless.
author: Ashley S.

description:
This is my second time back and I feel it's safe to say it's worth the fourth star.

The seafood is very fresh and the service is perfect.

Being from a design background I love the space, it's cozy yet definitely remains open and has a soft golden glow throughout.
When I dine here I always sit at the bar. 
I love being a little higher up and having more control over service when I need it . Plus my date and I get to kibbitz with the staff whenever we want and hear about everything that's happening with the place.

The dishes that have stood out have been the Sea Urchin and Ipswich Fried Clam apps and the whole Snapper and Sea Bass entrees.

Desserts are heaven, super chocolate cake.

Will definitely return to this sweet little fish delice on Minna.
Love the mermaid avatar.
author: Katherine N.

description:
It's an upscale Bubba Gump's.

I mean that in a good way.  Delicious and nearly everything on the menu is fresh seafood, but a little heavy on the theming.

All 60+ wines are "coastal" - no inlanders here.  They're all available by the glass too.
author: Gil S.

description:
I walked out of Anchor & Hope and thought  "This is the beginning of a *beautiful* relationship."

Great service, nice room, great menu.  The menu is the size of a legal pad, and 2/3 of the back of it is dedicated to wine.  I'm a self professed wine dummy, but the list was impressive to my untrained eye.  The bottom 1/3 was dedicated to beer.  There are a few on tap, and maybe 20 in bottles.  The selection was pretty darn good.  I'd describe it as heavy on the California micros with a few good Oregon micros on it as well.  

We had oysters and a salad as appetizers and then I did something I never thought I'd ever do in a nice restaurant:  I ordered the lobster roll.  It was excellent.  Seriously, a restaurant where I can order a lobster roll and have a beer or two that is also going to make the wine and champagne crowd happy will go a long way with me.  My first lobster roll was at this place:  http://www.yelp.com/biz/lobster-roll-restaurant-amagansett#hrid:N5lAW8qwnUzT1_IEztuOlw, and the one at Anchor & Hope kicked its ass.  Price difference between this one and the one on the end of Long Island:  about $4.

See you soon, Anchor & Hope.  See you soon.
author: Nelson W.

description:
Anchor and Hope is a cavernous place with an active bar populated by all sorts of happy folk.  The table service is busy as well; my server had tables here there and everywhere about the room.  Consequently she lost me at times but was apologetic and for the most part got the job done with an assist from other members of the staff.

Every component of a salad of little gems, mint, toasted almonds, orange, and parmesan was fresh and the salad was properly dressed; but it didn't come together.  I don't know why; perhaps a professional reviewer could decide whether the problem was the salad, the dressing  or my palate.  Whichever, the salad was just OK to me. 

Angels on horseback, baked oysters wrapped in bacon was a nice appetizer and something different from the run of the mill.  It didn't knock my socks off but it was interesting. 

Prosciutto wrapped trout was superior.   The whole fish had been boned before being cooked and was crisp outside, moist within, and not overwhelmed by the prosciutto.  The brussels sprouts , butternut squash, and almonds that came with the trout were nice enough but  the plate wasn't more than the sum of its components.  This didn't bother me too much as the trout was so well done.  

The place is on the pricey side for what you get.
author: David D.

description:
4 stars for food (tasty) & atmosphere (open & chill), 3 stars for service (sufficient), 1 star for value (price-vs.-what-you-get = outrageous), ergo, 3 stars overall. 

Things we ordered + taste-rating: 
     Raw oysters: 8/10, great assortment of E & W coast, fresh-from-the-sea taste, nice mignonette ($36/dzn - about what you'd expect) 
     Clam chowder: 6/10, good, not great and try-too-hard smokey flavor ($10 for a small bowl - gasp!) 
     Calamari: 8/10, fresh, solid overall ($13 for appetizer plate - total joke!) 
     Fish & chips: 8/10, batter was crispy & light, fish was flaky and perfectly cooked; potato wedges were ok, nothing special but fine ($24 for 3 small pcs fish & 4 teeny wedges - I thought it was a friggin misprint!) 

Add a couple of drinks plus the above 4 items = bill of $148. Are you serious?! Don't get me wrong, I'm in love with food and will be first in line for spendy meals anytime, so long as the crime fits the punishment... but this place is downright insulting. The positive is that the menu is well put together, where you really do have a hard time deciding, choices are very nicely edited; and there's a terrific selection of wines by the glass and multi-page beer selection.
author: Jen H.

description:
I had been wanting to try this place since it opened. Same folks (in some capacity) that did/are doing Town Hall and Salt House (I think)... two of my favorite restaurants in SF (I know).

I feel like if you were to put me on the spot and ask for an amazing seafood joint in SF, I don't know what I'd necessarily say... 

Until now! (omgweee)

Loved this place. Love the location on Minna... the atmosphere was new and fresh. Amazing oysters. Great menu full of all sorts of seafood options. I ended up going with the fancy lobster roll (I can't help it!) which was great but next time I'll definitely try something a little different.

I hate to not go with five stars here but our waitress was inattentive and really ruined a perfect dinner. We ended up having to ask random servers running around for more bread, more drinks, dessert menu, etc.

Anyway. GO EAT HERE.
author: Derek B.

description: Grab a drink during happy hour, good ambiance, friendly employees, for surez!
author: Seth B.

description:
The restaurant is charming and the hostess was very friendly.
Love the lobster roll. But a bit expensive.
author: Rita C.

description: I Love this place. The atmosphere and food is amazing! The service is good, though it can be a little slow. A must try!
author: Kimberly R.

description:
I came here recently for lunch with a colleague from work. It was my second time here for lunch in a year and the experience was pretty consistent on both occasions. The staff were friendly and prompt. The atmosphere is nice, not too noisy but enough talking and reverberation to give it a good vibe. I especially like the decorations around the restaurant. It makes you feel like you're at an upscale lunch spot on the New England coast.

Now, to the food. On different occasions I had the tuna melt and the lobster roll. The tuna melt ($13) is pretty good and the lobster roll is fine but at $24 it's too pricey for what you get. For $24 I'd want to see the roll packed with a few more ounces of lobster meat to feel like it was a fairly priced meal.

Net-net: A good lunch spot but a little pricey.
author: Dylan S.

description:
For all the hype, this place was just ok.  I had the fish and chips - which was just ok.  No better (but definitely not the worst) than any I've had anywhere else.  

The interior or the place, as others have mentioned, is kind of neat with a nautical theme, but it gets very loud.  

As my date observed, the nicest thing to look at in the entire place was the hostess.  His eyes nearly fell out of his head and into his oysters.
author: MoMo D.

description: I'm giving Anchor & Hope 5 stars based solely on the food.  When I heard that the people behind Town Hall/Salt House had opened a new place, Anchor & Hope shot to the top of my to-do list for San Francisco, and I was not disappointed.  Other reviewers have hit upon some valid issues--service is a bit on the slow side, and the prices are pretty high for the concept, but presumably at least the former will be worked out in time.  However, quibbles aside, my meal was incredible--the clam chowder was inventive, fresh, and delicious, and the lobster roll, even though it was nothing like what I grew up with in New England, was out of this world.  It's been three weeks since I visited Anchor & Hope, and I'm still craving another lobster roll, which in this obese writer's mind is the mark of quality.
author: Ty D.

description: We went here for happy hour and really enjoyed the experience. We got the $1 Skookum oysters and their happy hour champagne. Such a good combo! The Skookum oysters were definitely the best I've ever had, they were big, plump, and really yummy. We walked away with a very small bill, and were filled to the brim with oyster goodness. Definitely coming back!
author: Sonya D.

description: The happy hour $1 oysters and $5 dollar wines are awesome! The sea urchin appetizer very good, but a bit expensive $16.50 the lobster roll is bland and came with super salty potato chips and slaw. For $30 they are straight trippin!!!!!!!!
author: Dusty P.

description: Went here recently with some friends, and sat at the bar (didn't want to wait for a table). The three of us ordered 2 entrees and an appetizer, plus beers all around. The food was really good (lobster roll - a little too heavy on the brioche ratio imho, and the cod + pork belly), but as my friend put it: "This place would be good if we had money to burn and didn't care about spending $50 to be only slightly full." Service was friendly and the space had a neat vibe, but it's a little too rich for my blood.
author: christine l.

description:
Before Anchor & Hope was officially opened, we walked past it en route to Salt House for dinner - saw a private party inside and the place was hoppin'!!  We made a mental note ... Must. Try. Out.  Well, I found myself a month out after making that mental note and FINALLY got in for dinner!  Yay...  

Thanks to my brilliant planning, I didn't make resie's so unless my friend and I were willing to wait until 10:45p to eat dinner on a Thursday, we had to tempt our fate with a walk-in.  Must have been our lucky night!!  We walked in and the very friendly and gracious hostess spotted 2 open spots at the cool, zinc countertop/bar and quickly ushered us over.  Perfect.  We were immediately greeted by our waiter.  He was fantastic.  Assertive.  Attentive.  Friendly.  Gave me xtra wine pours.  I likey.

The interior design is quite stark - urban hip - very "Deadliest Catch" - well ... kinda.  You know what I mean, very seaboard fish house.  ;)  The bar even has these eyeball lights that shine down on you while you eat.  Cool.  Kinda freaky.  Even cooler.

The food was YUMM.  We started out with some oysters.  Yumm, I do enjoy oysters!  Reminds me of summer and warm, balmy weather, sippin' adult bevvies dressed in flowy linen ... I digress.  I enjoyed the sea scallop ceviche (a special that night) and a cup of the corn chowder.  Delish!!  My friend had the spicy mussel & monkfish stew.  He raved about the flavors - he was a happy guy.  Guess he was craving some yummy seafood earlier in the day - turns out this spot was the perfect selection!  

I'll definitely be back - was a great spot, cool vibe and delicious food.

Oh wait.  You must order the Heart of Sweet Cream for dessert.  Decadent.  Delicious.  Oh so perfect.
author: Nicole Rynee B.

description:
Well... 3.5 Stars.  
 
Came here for dinner tonight.  The service is great.  Our waitress was super nice.

I got the bacon wrapped oysters.  Its Ok... taste like what you would expect it to taste like.  I also got a side of cole slaw, which was really good, its a little on the tart side which i like.

I thought that overall the food was as expected, nothing really extraordinary.  

however, i really enjoyed our dessert, the chocolate blackout cake.  The frosting has sea salt and pistachio.  it wasnt too sweet and the sea salt make the chocolate frosting really intense.
author: Janet S.

description:
Very cute restaurant tucked away in a bustling SOMA alley.  Glad to see such a different approach in building a classy restaurant straight out of an old warehouse.  Their before pictures straight up looked like a  Public Storage space.  They've kept the rustic touch by keeping an uneven paint job on their front entrance wall.

The vaulted ceilings allow the usual overly noisy buzz to travel up and out.  Ropes dangling over the untreated wooden cross beams and muted industrial lights give patrons a sense that they're dining in the hull of a creaking ship.  

My party of 4 was probably given the best seat in the house.  It's the 4 top hidden in the back corner, so we got a private room feel during our visit.  The openness of the restaurants really helps with the flow of space.  I find it so rare in SF restaurants to be able to walk normally, as opposed to side stepping it to avoid knocking someone's head with my purse.

We started with the Angels on Horseback, an oyster wrapped with bacon and dressed with a creamy tangy sauce.  This dish could not lose... an old flip flop fried with bacon would be delicious!  But texturely it worked well -- soft and crispy are a favorite combo of mine.  

For my main, I had a seared tuna fish dressed with baby greens, creamy tomato sauce, and tempanade.  Overall it was a well-prepared dish.  The sauces carried the flavor of the entire meal, but really could have left out the tempenade.  Overly salty and powerful for the delicate flavors of fish.  Almost made the fish taste sour.  

A strong contender for best seafood in the city.  One of those restaurants that will be on many "must try" list.
author: Chris T.

description: What a nice place. Seafood gastropub. Rachael really made me feel welcome. As I was alone, she grabbed me a seat at the packed bar. Tom provided expert input on beers and the days specials. Started with the Rockfish ceviche which was different than the run of the mill citrus based recipes. Had the Louisiana fish and chips. Light tempura like batter with the best fries I've ever had. I'll be back when I'm in the area!
author: G B.

description:
There is something about when new restaurants who take over older buildings and keep original look and feel of the structure.  Situated in an old warehouse squeezed between the hustle and bustle of downtown, Anchor & Hope is a refreshing mid-day or dinner escape.  

The service was great, but the majority of the pricey dishes didn't follow suit.  

The Good...
If your are into oyster, you'll love the decent variety of oyster especially the east coast ones.  I also really enjoyed the fried ipswich clam appetizer that is paired with an interesting chunky aoli.  

The Bad...
The steamed mussels has a unique presentation with the shaved fried potatoes(fries), but the dish was disappointing with the freshness of the mussels and the questionable fries.  The Trout Salad isn't anything special and it does set you back $15.  Be sure to MISS OUT on the deep fried pearl onions also, its not crispy at all. 


With many new restaurants, the opening is a work in progress and being affiliated with Town Hall and Salt House, you know that the best is still yet to come.  I would gladly come back for a return visit, but later this year!
author: Jason A.

description:
I've been a big fan of Salt House.  It makes my list of best places in SOMA and perhaps even the list for best places to eat on a regular basis after work.  I had the same expectations for Anchor & Hope, considering the same ownership.

Overall, fairly impressed with the place.  I think it's a better place for a larger group than Salt House. The menu is diverse with a variety of fish and other seafood, along with short ribs and a chicken dish.  The trout was excellent and prepared very well and the short ribs were excellent.  They have a nice beer list as well.  I enjoyed the experience but I may not frequent back too often.

I do think if you are in town and looking for some solid seafood you have numerous choices.  Farrallon is expensive but by far the most impressive and a few other places including Bar Crudo and Waterbar have hit the scene.  Anchor & Hope is not among that class, but I still think it's a nice, somewhat casual and fun place to visit for seafood and a nice beer or glass of wine.
author: E L.

description: I have only been here once and I was not impressed. However, if you need a less conservative spot for a business lunch, this restaurant is great for that. The food is OKAY. From what I remember, the tables were pretty close together, the service wasn't the best, and it was on the pricier side for an okay lunch. The only reason I would go back is for the ambiance which is very lively on a weekday.
author: Jenna Q.

description:
I really enjoyed this place. I went with a large party -  9 colleagues - and they were able to keep everything coordinated and coming in a timely fashion.
We ended splitting calamari apps, and I had the scallops over couscous. Very good, but not great. One of my colleagues has the trout wrapped in prosciouto, which he said was excellent.
author: David L.

description:
This restaurant tucked in the end of Minna st. disguises itself very well.  I can see that it tends to surprise people from the inside out.  From the outside it is a deceiving warehouse but from within, it is a very well decor restaurant. I love the decorations especially the Big fish eating little Fish design on the wall.

The Food - We had the specials: Mussels with thin shaved fries, the sauce was so rich, I kept getting more bread to finish it with.  It was very tasty.  We also had a red snapper sashimi with Ponzu sauce.  Delicious, and we topped it off with the Lamb.  The Lamb is very soft and falls right off the bone, but  I think it was a little dull, I wanted some more flavor out of it, even though the texture was very soft and wet.

I was also very impressed with their incredible selection of Beer, so much to choose from I had to tell the bartender to just pick a crisp light ale for me, it was awesome.  

Our wait Keko, was the nicest man on earth, he was very generous with our wine...Thanks!  but also made good recommendations for us.

Overall, this place is right off SOMA, so expect alot of Suits and business folks trying to strike a deal over dinner, but the spacing is good, so everyone is close enough to see, yet too far to touch.  I had a great time, and would come again.
author: J Y.

description:
Eating raw oysters at Anchor and Hope is like taking a deep dive into the Mediterranean. Crisp, refreshing, delightful, what dreams are made of.

We got a bunch of diff apps and the lobster sandwich entree to share and it was perfect. There are so many good seafood creations that it's better to try as many as you can. Sea urchin for example. If I were stranded on a deserted island and had to choose one thing to eat always for the rest of my life it would be their sea urchin app. 

Their clam chowder was straight cream; that was the only thing I had reservations about. Good in moderation, so I would even get that to share (between 3 people at least).

So good though, so good.
author: C P.

description:
Some of my closest friends took me here for my bday today.  It's pretty decadent, heavy food..fried seafood.  Here's what we had..

Appetizers
Warm Sea Urchin - by far the best appetizer.  It's like mashed potatoes with gravy..but with seafood!
Fries with Eels - pretty good, fried eels essentially; the fantastic dipping sauce taste like the oyster dish.
Oysters with bacon wrapped - I'm usually not a fan of oysters, but the bacon made up for it.  

Entrees
Smitchwick's Cod - tastes like their version of fish & chips, but better!
Oven Roasted Sea Bass - I'm a big fan of bass...so I can't help but like the buttery taste.  Kick his assss sea baaasss!!!
Cornmeal crusted slow baked salmon - I like the texture very much.  Crumby outside..can't beat it!
Lobster dish with bread (forget what it's called) - I really liked this dish.  The combination of the lobster & bread is excellent.

Drinks
They have a fairly large selection of imported beer which ranges from Belgium, German to even Russian Beer.  I had some German beer which was very crisp and light.  Which was a perfect combination for the meal since it was so heavy to begin with.


I'm not sure if I'd go here every month or something.  But even though the portions are small, they are heavy dishes so it makes you really full.

The ambiance is a combination of intimate and good for groups.  Saw a lot of of business professionals here dressed up on a Tuesday night.  But yet, if I came in with tennis shoes and jeans I think I'd still be comfortable.
author: Yup S.

description:
I ate here with some friends last Friday night. Heard the food's good but I had to see for myself. 

Must call ahead for reservations. Luckily, my friend Wes did that and we were seated right away. I felt the ambiance needed more charm; sadly, it reminded me of eating on Cannery Row in Monterey for some reason. 

I had settled for the fries with eyes aka fried smelts and the 6 pc. shrimp cocktail since I had a huge lunch earlier that day. Nothing to rave about except trying the bacon wrapped oysters...which I must come back for.  I had two glasses of their pilsner and it complimented my meal. I was sorely disappointed on the 6 pc. shrimp cocktail. The shrimp was overcooked and this is a must-avoid for next time. 

It's tucked right on Minna in between 1st and 2nd streets. I found parking on New Montgomery and skipped over to Minna. 

Service was spotty in the beginning but our server warmed up to us and was a huge help throughout the dinner. I didn't stay for dessert.
author: Mika D.

description: My husband texted me from San Francisco to go on Yelp and say how amazing this restaurant was. He had the fish & chips and said it was outstanding.
author: Andrea W.

description:
I just ate there tonight and the thoughts going through my mind was ...this place ain't cheap.  

We got the seafood platter which was $82, I could eat  82 oysters at Hog Island Oyster at Happy Hour.

I had the lobster roll...the coldness of the meat, and the warmness of the brioche bread was a great contrast, but yet, I feel like there wasn't enough lobster meat as usual.  The chips were a little too salty.  I think I had about three glasses of water tonight.  

Overall ...it was packed with a lot of people...why?  We waited to sit in the bar.  

I thought the manager there was an a*hole, but the bartender was friendly.  

I don't know if I'd ever go there again...especially with the economy like this, the prices were STEEP! At least if the ambiance was amazing, but nothing out of the ordinary.
author: Jenny K.

description: It was good, not amazing. I had the shrimp and grits. Overall the food and service were good. The food took a very long time to come out. Not sure I'd go back.
author: Heidi C.

description:
Anchor and Hope worked for me on all levels :) - 5-stars for sure. 

Loved the overall ambiance and theme, a lofty-nautical interior, with high, airy ceilings - a perfect backdrop to the food and drink! The furnishings and accents (benches, mirrors, signage) all are excellent, thought-out details.

Love that A.H. is versatile and layed back, but still NICE. You're good either dressed up or dressed down. As their website says, "Come in a suit or jeans. Enjoy a 4-course or just champagne and oysters. Eat early or late ..."

Love great beer especially with fabulous, creative seafood. 
Along with our pints of Hefe-Weisse, we had the divine, "Angels on Horseback" and "Fried Calamari with Basil and Thai dipping sauces" appetizers.

I had the tender lamb shank. Bf and another friend had the lobster sandwiches. Everything was prepared well and delicious. 

We left very satisfied :)
author: Kimbalee W.

description: What a fun place! Discovered this restaurant by accident and I'm glad that we stumbled in here. The decorum has a great mix of the old cannery and modern restaurant. Fun for couples and groups!  I had good service tonight.  Serving almost all seafood, I ordered their fish & chips. Good size portions and a great selection of beer and wine here.
author: Patrick W.

description:
Confirmed: dinner is equally fabulous, especially for us seafood lovers.  t

Come early and grab a drink at the bar (warning: beer & wine only).  And don't forget bring a date to share the oysters, they'll love it.
author: Zuzzi E.

description:
Close your eyes and picture yourself in a Maine fisherman's shack. The shack is actually a former auto repair shop, with hawsers looped over steel girders spanning the wide open area dining room ... and you are surrounded by yuppies and aren't even close enough to SF bay to smell it.

Even though the space isn't authentic, the food is really exquisite, well at least the sea urchin is. It's one of the most amazing tastes that I have ever had in my mouth: warm urchin, in mashed potatoes, crab, and plenty of BUTTER served in the urchin's shell. Amazing texture and tastes. I would go back just for that app. I also had oysters, and chowder. Both were good. I suggest you sit at the zinc oyster bar and watch the goings on in the parts of the kitchen you can see.
author: Chris L.

description:
I come here somewhat frequently for business luncheons

Good atmosphere, fun, good seafood.  Oysters, yum!

If you want privacy and a place to discuss business, the restaurant does get loud.  Then I suggest Roy's nearby, tables are farther apart and less rowdy crowd.

Fun place to go with clients without feeling awkward and restrictive.
author: Dindy H.

description: I came here for lunch and was hoping to take advantage of the Dine About Town options, but I was disappointed.  There were no choices for their Dine About Town...only one set menu (salad + etouffee).  I wasn't too interested in that option, so I decided to go with their fish and chips, which was a battered, deep fried cod with rosemary and thyme fries.  It was good.  The fish was light, fresh, and flaky.  There was two generous sized pieces (which was kinda expected for a $24 lunch item).  The fries were yummy.  The rosemary and thyme flavor was subtle but added a unique taste to the fries.  Most of the other people in my party got the lobster roll, which they said was okay.  It came with house made potato chips.  I tried a few and they were good!!  Overall, it wasn't bad, but it wasn't anything spectacular.
author: Melisa C.

description: We went for my husband's birthday dinner, before a night at the theater.  Great choice for him.  Great beer selection, and oysters and bacon (angels on horseback), two of his favorite foods paired together. The angels on horseback are as good as everyone says.  Definitely get them.  Our waitress was absolutely terrific, very knowledgeable about both the food and booze.  We did get caught in a shift change, so that affected our service a bit, but the waiter we had second was also very good.  Casual nautical themed decor.
author: Ruth B.

description: I never thought I would say a dish had too much butter but both dishes did.  Good food but definitely heavy meals that were so laden in butter and other goodies that it took away from the entree.  The pricing was fair, but a little on the expensive but the portions were very hardy and generally a positive dining experience.
author: dennis a.

description:
Forgot to write a review about this place after I ate there a couple of months ago. Probably because the experience was not memorable.

Oysters were good - I especially loved the red spicy sauce they came with. Not your typical cocktail sauce. Definitely the highlight. The lobster roll was crazy thick with mayo which made it really disgusting. I was looking forward to the Old Bay spiced chips because I'll use any excuse to eat Old Bay (seriously, try it on tuna sandwiches) but what came out was more like kettle brand potato chips dusted with a couple shakes of the spice. Bummer

Wasn't expecting much though, not a big fan of Salt House either.
author: Sarah P.

description:
Looks like everyone has raved equally about each dish based on the Yelp reviews, but we went in not doing much homework on what's good and what's worth missing. Passing A&H on the way to Harlot the other night, and it being on my Yelp bookmarks list forever, there was no question we were coming here the first opportunity we had.

Delicious it was! I started with the warm endive and baby beet salad. It  looked like effortless perfection with hidden globs of goat cheese and candied walnuts hidden under a mound of tangled frisée. Larry had the bisque which was creamy and light but full of crab and flavor; prime for bread dipping. The shrimp cocktail was bold with a horseradish sprinkled cocktail sauce and six plump shrimp. When the lobster roll came out I feared the lobster spread on the toasted brioche would taste like mayonnaise, but there was no taste of it at all. The lobster pieces still kept their integrity, texture and taste and went well with the lightly toasted brioche and the side kettle chips, which I literally couldn't stop eating. Larry's cod 'n' chips were delicate and fried to perfection and were clean on the palette. We topped the meal off with a cabernet and blood orange sorbet sprinkled with crushed pistachios on a thin slab of peanut brittle.

Fresh and exciting really just sums up the whole meal and experience here.
author: Chelsea P.

description:
3.5 stars

Pan d'Epi: Wonderful.  However, it came out in a brown paper bag which I thought was wasteful.  

Oysters: Terrific.  My fave were the St. Simon's.  Mignonette could have used more shallots.  Fresh horseradish was a big hit!

Beet Salad with Watercress and Blue Cheese: I liked this a lot.  The sweet and tender beets, peppery watercress were delicious with the sharp and creamy Rogue.

Lobster Roll: From all the reviews, I knew that I HAD to order the lobstah roll.  But did they change the recipe?  It was dressed so much that the sauce made a small pool on my plate.  It overwhelmed the flavor of the lobster.  You might like it but for me, I'll have to ask for it "naked" next time.  I prefer the sweet, briny, tender goodness in it's natural state, with drawn butter.  The bread, however, was toasted and buttered perfectly!  

Service: Definitely could have been better.  See Monica S.'s review.  Seems like they're still working things out since they haven't been open for more than a few months.  Things will probably improve with time:)  

I'll return for champagne, salad and oysters!
author: michelle s.

description:
You must get at A&H:
Calamari w/ Basil Thai Chili Dipping Sauce
Spice crusted ahi w/ greens & salt/vinegar chips


You may want to try at A&H (but it won't be the best you've ever had):
New England Clam Chowder...not bad...not great


You should avoid at A&H:
Burger...yuck...don't get a burger at a seafood place.


All in all....eh...
author: Susan L.

description:
Loved eating at Anchor and Hope!
1. The skylights during the day opened up the restaurant and made me feel like I left the city and posted up by the coast. 
2. Heirloom tomatoes take me hooooooome to my Bulgarian motherland -pretty much the only tomatoes that have enough flavor to resemble what I used to eat when I was young.
3. Fresh oysters, always a plus.
4. Extensive wine list, but awesome beer list too.
5. Butter is important -they have good butter.
6. LOVE the location. Minna is my favorite! 

Could've been better.
1. The bread was great but should've been warm
2. My muscles were a bit too salty
3. The busboys kept trying to take my plate at inappropriate times.
author: Rada I.

description:
I came here for lunch with a small group of 3. 

I am a seafood FREAK, so this place was right up my alley. 

Angels on Horseback - Awesome, Simply Awesome. Bacon & Oysters, what could be better? Did I mention, Bacon?

Had the lobster roll, and it was delicious. Right on par with Sams Chowder house. For the west coast, those are some good lobster rolls. Doesn't compare to the northeast, but lets not be picky about everything :)

They also have an extensive beer menu. Had a few IPA's that I was completely satisfied with. 

Next up, one of their sister restaurants: Town Hall.
author: Christian K.

description:
I've dined here twice a, this second time during the new happy hour. 

Happy hour wines: had the sparkling, white and red and all were very nice for $5. 

$1 oysters: okay for a buck. 

Sea Urchin - decadent, should be tried at least once. 

Tuna Crudo - melon, cucumber, spicy peppers..very fresh and delicious. 

Shrimp with Eggplant: 4 prawns with the heads on over an eggplant, cumin  compote thing. The flavors were complex, I approve. 

Ceviche - it was a fish ceviche, I forget which one, but I've had better at Destino's. 

Angels on Horseback: not a fan at all and actually sent it back. The bacon seemed undercooked, the oyster oozed...I chased my half bite with some bread and that was that.
author: Nikke G.

description:
3.5 Stars (Get your act together and do 1/2 stars Yelp!)

Anchor and Hope was the 3rd stop on DAT Tour 2009 (Winter Edition). Brought to you by the same folks that did Town Hall and Salt House, this place purported to be a seafaring version of the other two places, and having been wowed at Salt House, I had high expectations for this place. I don't know who does the architecture for all the Town Hall restaurants, but they really get it spot on with the motifs. This place had high slanted ceilings with exposed beams and maritime themed decorations all over. Extra points for innovative design.

I started with the Tai Snapper Ceviche. I'm not quite sure what the sauce was, but it was slightly acidic and very light, not overly limey as most places that attempt ceviche tend to do. The Tai was sliced well and fresh, I really loved the texture of the finely diced red bell peppers and chives. Great starter to the meal for me. My companion OrangeJenn, ordered the Baby Bib Lettuce with Cara Cara Orange Salad off the DAT menu. Sounds simple enough, but someone in the back got a little too zealous with the salt as the bite I tried I could taste a several grains of coarse salt. OrangeJenn also complained about it being overseasoned.

For our entrees, she got the Spice Blackened Mahi Mahi, Shaved Fennel and Arugula Salad, Rosemary Pesto. The Mahi Mahi was cooked correctly, coming out juicy and tender, but the fish just lacked flavor. The Rosemary Pesto was too understated even when you lathered it on the fish. My Lobster Roll on Toasted Brioche on the other hand was a whole other story. The Brioche was toasted perfectly and matched well with the generous portions of lobster in creamy sauce peppered with diced celery. There's nothing more I hate when people overdo the creamy sauce, but this one was light. The accompanying Cole Slaw was a little tart, but still good and the Old Style Kettle Chips made a good pairing with the meal. I relished each bite of this delectable sandwich. We also split (read she ate one and I ate the rest) a plate of Steamed Mussels with Herb Ribboned Fries and Creme Fraiche which was also very well done. The mussels were larger than what's normally used in a preparation like this, which I enjoyed. I hate picking through a plate of quarter sized mussels. The Herb Ribbom fries added a contrasting texture to the dish and were just fun to munch on. 

For dessert, I had the Meyer Lemon Souffle with Huckleberry and Thyme Sauce. When I see a souffle on a menu, I have very distinct preconceptions of what should be. The words light and and airy come to mind. The words curdy and custardy do not. On top of the failed texture, the flavor was way too tart and sour, even for a Meyer Lemon. The Huckleberry Thyme sauce did nothing to tame this flavor. The DAT meal came with Chocolate Blackout Cake topped with Sea Salt Pistachio Brittle. This dessert reminded me of my last girlfriend, dark, salty, and leaves a bitter taste in your mouth. The cake was very dense, almost fudge-like. I thought there was too much dark chocolate or not enough sugar and damn it, I know fleur de sel goes well with dark chocolate, but I wish chefs would stop putting salt on desserts. Really, I think they should have named this place Salt House instead of the other place.

I really wanted to like this place given my experience at Salt House, but there was just too much inconsistency here. Measured solely on what I ordered, I would say the only miss was the Souffle, but factoring in OrangeJenn's plates, that really brought the experience down for me. Anchors Away to flavor with no Hope of recovery.
author: Tony V.

description:
Went here with D and some of her friends.  I hadn't even heard of this place before arriving, so I was goin in totally blind.  What a find!  A sea food place that understands that sea food comprises more than just salomon and halibut!

Group of 6 seated hairly quickly without reservations!  (It was about 8:30 on a Friday night).  We were all starving, so we destroyed the bread, but still had room for our meal.  Wide variety of sea food options, including Sea Urchin.  I couldn't do the sea urchin (bad flashbacks to a sea urchin "experience" at a japanese place), but one in our party did order it.  I had the trout.  All agreed their meals were well prepared and tasty.  The atmosphere strikes the right balance between casual and formal.  Good date place.  4 stars.  If you can handle the price tag, this is a great place!
author: Richard F.

description: I usually come here for Wednesday Happy Hours $1 oyster before class with my husband or classmates. I love their oysters and beer during happy hours and at five thirty we start to order dinner, I usually don't care much about their entrees after having more than a dozen oysters, fries and beer. I always order their sea urchin with dungeness crab bisque. Love this bique
author: T B.

description:
Wow! I haven't enjoyed a restaurant like Anchor & Hope in a while! Although I was slightly annoyed that our table was half an hour late, the great vibe of this place made it up. I love the ambiance.. it's casual, upbeat, loud and happening. 

I started with the Angel backs and they were SO good!! Fresh oysters wrapped in pan fried bacon. YUM!!! I highly recommend this appetizer. My friend had the Sechwan prawns and they were good too, but the Angel backs were definitely the highlight.

For my entree, I had the spicy mussels with monk fish, chirizo and potato stew. The seafood was delicious and the broth made it even better. The broth was spicy with a hint of curry, it was perfect for dipping my crisp bread in. The chirizo was prepared as meatballs. Very unique and delicious. It was a nice balance of "surf and turf". I had a bit of my friend's sea bass and that was delicious too.

For dessert, we ordered the crisp, but I was VERY disappointed when our waitress came back and told us they were out.

Anyway, overall, I HIGHLY recommend dining at Anchor & Hope. I'm even thinking of going back with the BF this weekend to more Angel backs!!!
author: Denise L.

description:
Doug has done it again... what an amazing place!  If you're big into old-world brick and timber architecture, you'll love this place.  They've retrofitted what was for a long time a parking garage into a serious culinary hot spot with a touch of nautical flair (old buoy lanterns and a cool wall painting by the owner's wife -- same artist who did the Don Quixote in Salt House.)  Even the menus are cool -- printed daily with distressed ink, cool typeface and handwritten details of each dish.

The food was of fantastic quality, and again -- I'm more of a presentation guy.  The spines-on urchin was awesome, as were the scallops.  I recommend being a little adventurous and going for the "fries with eyes," because -- really -- can anything deep fried not taste good?

The service was also solid -- very attentive with a little edge.  Our server was witty and joked with the table, and the GM dropped by to say hi too.  

Well played, A&H.  Well played.
author: Josh M.

description:
Have been here a few times and I had to bring my four star review back to three. Suddenly in this economy, $24 for a lunch roll (even if it has lobster) seems very excessive.  

The clam chowder here is still delish and full of rich clammy flavor.  The broccoli rab was overly salty.  The chips that came with the lobster roll were too salty as well. Food is still decent, but I don't think you get a good value here for what you're paying.
author: Sid D.

description:
Not bad!  The appetizers were all amazing - especially the sea urchin appetizer.  The presentation alone on that dish was worth it.  The clam chowder also got points for unique presentation, and from what I hear, was quite tasty.

All in all, a solid meal.  Any concerns about it being too noisy were unfounded.  It's a lively place, but not over-the-top loud.
author: james s.

description:
What a great seafood place and especially in a place tucked away so hopefully the secret wont get out to too many ppl...Doug from TownHall did a wonderful job and the food is excellent.  I really enjoyed their baked clams and their scallops.  Everything is soooo fresh and tasty!  The fish n chips were quite good but I wished the batter on the halibut was a bit more crispy...like the ones you can have in Alaska. ..this one was a bit soggy...oh and if you like vinegar with your fish n chips you must ask them for it...they have it in the kitchen but don't offer it on the dish.  Our server Kimo was really kewl and friendly! Took great care of us!!

The sea urchin baked with crab was quite good too but wish it didn't have so much mashed potato on the bottom! The flavor was good and not to pungent of the sea urchin!  Even if you don't like sea urchin you should try it!

Anchors away and Hope to see you soon!
author: Mee-stique K.

description: Ate here in December with some great family and friends. The seafood platter is fabulous and a must have. The wine list compliments the menu nicely and really, everything was enjoyable. Leave the kids home and substitute an extra credit card in place of them, you'll need it.
author: Mark M.

description: We had dinner here last fall, and this tried the signature warm sea urchin in the shell.  The presentation was as really pretty -- and the dish basically was like a seafood chowder, with fresh sea urchin.  While it was good (a solid 4 stars), the dish that really wowed me was the Zarzuela - the Spanish bouillabaisse.  The dish was just insanely good -- they even had pan-fried piece of fish that was large enough as a meal itself on top.  I absolutely love it.  I looked at the dinner menu again just now and don't see the fish listed, so not sure if they've changed the dish.  I sure hope not b/c I will one day be back and again savor the Zarzuela.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Great space, perfect to come on a date.  

Lobster rolls!  It wasn't as good as the ones I had in Maine, but definitely delicious.  Kind of a lobster salad, if you will.  Served with chips and a delightful cole slaw.  We had hamachi as a starter- melts in your mouth.

Huge beer list, which is a plus.  Our waitress was very nice, but verrry slow.
author: Sarah F.

description:
I really wanted to like this place more than I did. The decor is fresh and open, but that couldn't overcome the high prices and service, which wasn't great but.... it wasn't great. There, I said it.

It seems like this place has all the elements of a great, upscale seafood restaurant... The look.... The menu... The food itself.... But somehow Anchor & Hope just can't make it all come together.

I had the Crab Louie, by the way. Others at my table has the Lobster Roll, the Shrimp Louie, and the whitefish. Good good all around. Again, I wish I liked it more.
author: Cleo B.

description:
Thanks to Thrillist and Yelp, I found this place and was lucky enough to try it last night.
