Earlier in the day, I received a vm from A&H notifying me that they hadn't received their liquor license yet so they could reschedule our reservation or chill/serve our wine at no charge. Kudos to the girl who had to make those difficult calls--I appreciated the notice. We brought our own wine from the corner store and it was just fine. 

Our waiter even recommended foods to go with the red wine that we brought (I know we were having seafood but that's what I wanted). We had three different types of oysters: two East coast (because they are a little richer and go better with red) and one West. All delicious.

Next was asparagus salad and the salmon/mixed greens/fried oyster appetizer. Very crisp and refreshing. The salmon was super fresh (nice to not have raw smoked salmon for once) and the mixed greens really complimented everything--nice contrast with a crispy fried oyster. My bf pointed out that I don't usually like inconsistent textures but I liked this!

Entrees consisted of the seafood stew (monkfish, mussels and chorizo meatballs in a rich broth) and the halibut fish & chips. The stew was accompanied by some nicely toasted focaccia that dipped just fine. I LOVED the crunchy-on-the-outside-but-soft-on-the-inside-chips. The tartar sauce was more of an aioli and I dipped those fries in there, too. Of course the fish was tender and flaky and cooked just right--batter stayed on but wasn't too thick.

Since I was feeling greedy, I had the chocolate pudding cake all to myself--nice and moist and great texture on the outside (pistachios?). The bf had the strawberry-rhubarb cobbler with home-made graham cracker topping a la mode. I had to admit it was good although I don't care for rhubarb.

Oh and I almost forgot to talk about the place itself--cool, clean, decor. Service was fine and they just need to fine-tune by bringing the correct silverware with the food (mini-spoon with oyster sauce, spoon and bowl for discarded shells with stew).
author: Kat H.

description:
I keep ignoring my rule: don't go to a restaurant within the first 2 months of its opening.   I went in June, so I think I'm due to revisit soon...

This place has serious potential.  I LOVE the decor and it's in such a great location, but our service was not great and the food was only decent.  Hate to say it, but I did not dig the sea urchin!  Sorry guys,  it didn't do it for me...

I'll try again soon with the hopes of raising the star count.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
Good new place.  They had just received their liquor license the night we went but they still didn't charge a corkage fee which was cool.  I think now they do bottle for bottle where if you buy one of theirs, they will uncork one of yours for free.

I had the seafood stew with monkfish, chorizo, and shellfish - not a huge portion so not particularly filling, but the broth itself was delicious and made it worth ordering.  Friends got the sea bass which came with a very understanded but tasty sauce and was great as well.  We had some local oysters as an appetizer that were great.

It is a large, open space and a little loud because it is new and popular, but fun.  Good place to take a group.
author: Brian F.

description:
Decent food, but probably not enough to bring me back.  

Being seated 30 minutes after our reservation never is a good way to kick things off.  In their defense, the host did offer us sparkling wine.  But it was pink.  And not very tasty.  

The open space of the restauarant is definitely cool.  We were sat at a cool round table tucked in the back.  It made us feel like we had our own private dining room.  

Food was just mediocre.  The oysters with bacon were tasty, but I was underwhelmed by the entrees served at our table.
author: Pamela D.

description:
After several failed attempts to snag coveted dinner reservations here, my friends and I decided to try Anchor & Hope for lunch during the work week.  I immediately loved the feel of the restaurant with its casual look, spacious dining area, high ceilings and lots of natural light through skylights and glass windows.  It was a great place to relax and catch up with friends over a great meal.  

I was impressed with their approach to seafood.  They bring in fresh fish everyday and change their menu based on what fish and ingredients they bring in for the day.  We tried the lobster roll, crab louie salad, and the steamed mussels.  The seafood was fresh and very well-prepared.  And we were definitely guilty of polishing off the homemade potato chips!

What made the experience for me was the excellent service.  Our server was friendly and knowledgeable about the menu.  She was also very respectful of our time and checked with us to see if we needed to finish lunch and get back to the office by a certain time.  We wanted to split the two lobster rolls amongst the four of us, she had them cut in half and brought out as individual entrees with plenty of homemade potato chips.  Plus her description of their sea urchin on the dinner menu finalized my decision to come back as soon as possible for dinner!
author: Kimberly J.

description: Came here on a Monday night and they were busy which is always a good sign.  The food was excellent and the server made some great suggestions when we asked.  We started with the ceviche which was very tasty; then I had the halibut and my friend had the steak and both were cooked and tasted excellent.  We ended with some gingerbread dessert that was to die for! The only think I didn't like was that the tables were so close together you can hear everyones conversation around you.  It isn't a cozy restaurant and while the service was very good its not great. Also don't come here before you go out at night because they have an open kitchen and you will smell like food when you leave.
author: Allison C.

description:
Currently my favorite restaurant in the city.
Every meal I've had here has been perfect and if I could eat here nightly I would.
The staff is great and I've never had to wait very long to be sat or get a drink at the bar.
I've been lucky enough to have Fiona as a server the last 2 times I went and she's been awesome from start to finish.
Their beer selection is vast to say the least and definitely worth the visit alone. Abita purple haze is still haunting the memory of my taste buds. 
I am obsessed with the Sea Urchin appetizer and the bussers have to yank it out of my hands long after it's been finished because I just don't want to see it go.
I try a new entree every time I visit and I have never been disappointed! 
They've got a loyal fan in me...Oh, but can you please put some Riesling back on the wine list?!
author: Hope D.

description:
3.5 for the sea urchin and experience, but 4 for the belief that the food experience might be better on a second go round. I saw a few dishes pass by that my eyes took a liking to. 

As for the sea urchin, I wouldn't be so fast to put it on the list of best things I've ever eaten, but I still enjoyed it. It was rich, heavy, and creamy. At least a good start as my first ever. The crab shell..... I am attuned to the perils of unexpected crab shell in mouth, so I wasn't that fazed. I would expect future dishes to be completely edible and shell-free though. 

The scene: Definitely a 30s and 40s crowd. The airy ceilings and exposed beams made the space seem huge. I loved the flower bouquet light fixture. Another memory creator was how stifling hot it was throughout dinner. Probably a freak incident since San Francisco was actually hot in the evening (for once). The one fan outside did not help the situation at all. Lastly, I think the service could be more attentive. It was okay and friendly, but could improve.
author: Faye P.

description:
Try the heirloom tomato salad...it's to DIE FOR!

Anchor and Hope is a definite find for seafood.  Their attention to detail is impeccable and leaves a lasting impression.  It's nice to see the manager of the night mingling with diners and even putting his own charm into serving them.  The food was cooked to perfection and definitely left me wanting more.  

Yes Anchor and Hope, you will be a rotating establishment in my adventures to come here in SF!
author: Shane P.

description:
For me, this restaurant JUST made 4 stars.  It's good, but not amazing.  One thing that you might want to keep in mind -- this is the kind of place that the appetizer is better than the entrees...that's my feeling.  But don't get me wrong...thats only cause the appetizers were really REALLY good.  Here's a few that I had:

Appetizers:
"Fries with Eyes" -- smelts and remoulade sauce.  
Simply, just battered little fish with dipping sauce.  As simple as it is...it is actually pretty good.  The fish are not dried out but still juicy and moist.  The batter just thck enough to get the crispiness and battered taste.  Very good balance

"Warm Sear Urchin In The Shell" -- with mashed potatoes and dungeness crab
This is a very good appetizer.  I'd say this serves about three per order...tapas portion.  I normally don't like sea urchin any other way than sashimi style, but this time...hands down..good job.  There's also a creamy sauce that they mix in with the sea urchin, crab, and mashed portatoes...almost like a chowder sauce.  Oh, and the sea urchin is still raw..thank god.  Made very nicely.

"Angels On Horseback" -- smoked bacon wrapped oysters
Bacon wrapped...only in the states!  Haha.  This dish is not bad.  I mean, what can possibly go wrong with bacon wrapped anything right?!  If you like the bacon wrapped hot dogs they sell on the streets after clubbing, then you'll certainly like this.  Oysters are very nice and fresh and juicy,

Entrees:
For the entrees, I had a oven baked fish with leeks...I forgot what the fish is called...something that I don't see everyday.  But just like the waitress said, it is a fish that is very similar to the taste and look of salmon.  It was cooked very nicely...very fresh and juicy...and yet just the right about of rawness in the middle and cookedness on the outside.  Good dish.

My other friends had the Lobster Roll.  I had a small bite.  It was pretty good...but I needed a bigger bite to comment on it. Haha.  The chips that came with it is homemade and fresh though.  So that's always a plus.

That's it for the food.  A few side notes:
-Great service
-Nice atmosphere and deisgn.  Minimalistic and clean.

Anyways, that's it from me.  Now go check it out if you are into seafood!
author: Jonathan C.

description:
I was very pleasantly surprised.  

1) Ambiance is vibrant and hip and the decor is modern with a great school of fish mural behind the bar.  Tables in the dinning room are a little too crammed together for me though.

2) Apps were outstanding.  Ordered the Sichuan pepper prawns, which had excellent spice & flavor, and also the chowder which was among one of the best Ive had in a long time!

3) Wine list was reasonably priced and offered a wide variety of selections (ordered the Foxen Chennin Blanc $40...clean).

4) One of the misses for me was the decision to put potato wedges with the Smithwick's battered halibut.  It just seemed like a little too much heaviness for a fish dish (maybe a cole slaw or something light would have balanced it out).  Also had the Rib eye which was cooked to temp and had nice flavor and came with a great, spicy Dijon Bordelaise on the side.  

5) The other big miss was the service.  Although we did come in a little later (9:45 on Friday night) the staff was a little scattered and unorganized.  We sat at the bar and had about 3 different server/bartenders.  Maybe they all work together and don't  have assigned sections, but the service just didn't flow very well.  

**Overall, I would make another return any day of the week.  Ambiance and food were on the mark and I'm sure the service will follow suit.  Make reservations.
author: Steve M.

description: Arrived here about 10:30pm on a Saturday night after attending Harlot across the street. We sat at the bar and had 4  superlative fish appetizers. Popcorn shrimp, shrimp cocktail, calamari and the hands down favorite the sea urchin dungeness crab, that dish was orgasmic! I love creativity and the bread delivered in a brown bag was a wonderful quirk, and tasty. The service was good but did not make great as our man although very pleasant and informative, towards the end of our visit prioritized chatting with other staff over serving us. Still, overall we are talking brilliant !
author: Lorna S.

description: Seafood seafood! I was in seafood heaven. My roommates and I made reservations for Friday night...good food, great company.  I recommend the seafood sampler platter as an appetizer. It came with a variety of oysters, prawns, crab legs, and crayfish. The stuffed clams were also pretty damn good.  I got the halibut as an entree which was delicious but I definitely wished I got the scallops after trying my roommate's. Fiona, our server was very friendly and attentive. The wine selection was good but I was disappointed they didn't serve any cocktails. I was kind of in the mood for a martini when we were waiting at the bar for our table.  I've been to both Salt House and Town Hall and I definitely love Anchor & Hope just as much.
author: Debbie C.

description:
Let's be honest- great food is essential, but it's great service that really makes you want to go back.  This place seems to have everything else going for it with the exception of the service. I have to admit I was starving upon coming here, so I was banking on getting some bread when we arrived. However, the night just started off strangely. Our hostess immediately greeted us and within about 5 minutes had our water served. About ten minutes later our drink order was taken, but then our server was nowhere to be found almost 15 minutes later when it came to taking our food order. By the time we almost finished our first glass of wine, the bread arrived at our table?

The most bizarre part of this whole experience was that our server only communicated with me- and never once acknowledged my date. All of the questions were directed to me...strange no?  Something about the whole experience from several of the staff members was just off and perhaps insincere.

Now to the food: 
appetizer: fried calamari- amazing
entrees: thai snapper with potatoes and green onions- perfectly cooked- tender and complex flavors
lobster roll- never had one before, but the bun was perfectly toasted and the lobster was really tender
dessert: chocolate cake- similar to flour-less version, somewhat similar in taste to a german chocolate cake

Decor:

Loved the rustic, fisherman theme with the dock lamps, ropes hanging from the rafters, the large circular lamps that remind you of fish eyes, and the large art wall with the black painted fish

Overall- get the service together and this could quite possibly have been a 4-5 star rating, but it goes to show you how essential it is to feel welcomed and attended to by a good wait-staff
author: NaNa M.

description:
Went here on a Tuesday night. What a cute atmosphere! It is another one of those "hidden in an alley" San Francisco restaurants with an industrial, exposed brick-feeling interior. The even lighting and floor plan made the restaurant feel really open and even, not small and intimate.

I really enjoyed the sea urchin...my only wish (and yes picky, picky me) was that there was more sea urchin in the dish to enjoy. The seafood stew also had really tasty broth that was both delicious and homey/comforting. The cobbler was exceptionally good. It almost had a floral taste, and there was a nice contrast between the hot juice in the cobbler and the ice cream it came with. I wish there had been a little most "crust" but that's being picky, picky again.

Verdict: yum. Want to take a trip to Portland to try the owners' new Irving Street restaurant!

P.S. Yelp...on your "wheelchair accessible" survey, I think that all commercial buildings are required to be accessible to wheelchairs per ADA codes...
author: Elise G.

description:
I had dinner at Anchor & Hope for the first time recently, and although the atmosphere was great I was totally disappointed in the food.  Because I grew up on the New England coast, I was excited to find a lobster roll on the menu.  The $25 entree involved an oversized roll with a meager amount of overdressed (very wet) lobster consisting of only tiny chopped pieces -- no larger chunks at all -- along with a side of cole slaw that was so soupy it was inedible, and a pile of ordinary potato chips.  It was simply the worst lobster roll I have ever eaten anywhere, and therefore extremely overpriced given the poor quality.

My friends' meals were better than mine, but not exceptional in any way.  The service was only average.  I was expecting more from the owners of Salt House and Town Hall, both of which I love, but this was a real step down.  Their web site lists the chef as "Boston raised" which makes her attempt at a lobster roll even less acceptable.  Her version is a total failure.  If you are looking for an authentic New England lobster roll, head to Yankee Pier in Larkspur instead!
author: Susan F.

description:
I have nothing but good things to say about Anchor and Hope.

Service - exceptional. On all fronts. i waited for 15 minutes at the bar. They corked the bottle I brought (am actively attempting to consume more of the wine I buy). Bar service was fantastic... really friendly... everyone! They let me taste one of the wines I had never heard of and in lieu shared some of mine.  Table service was equally as friendly. Our sommelier was extremely knowledgeable and provided some information about the 2 bottles that I had brought. 

Food - flavors were immense. Oyster selection provided for a lovely variety of west coast flavors and quality was outstanding. i don't think fresh is a descriptor that gives the oysters justice. It were as if you were to have shucked the thing right after you got back into your boat. yummy yum yum. 

Lobster roll: I ordered this based on sheer accolades. And let me just say that everything everyone has said is true. I think that's about all I have to say about that.

Ambiance: Perfect date spot. Lighting is well balanced, love the nautical feel. Love the walls. I want to take chalk and draw on it for some reason.

I will be back. It's not as expensive as I had "expected" for this caliber of San Francisco fare, but my wallet is still licking its war wounds.
author: Annie T.

description:
Don't be fooled by the location.  I recommend this restaurant highly.  Thank you Jonathan and Chris for your company.  Everytime I eat there, the managers always have a wine recommendation for me and a little time to chat.  Extensive wine list!  Superb oyster bar and great entres.  The entres are nicely balance, not too heavy but filling.

The embience is noisy and social.  Fun!  Great for large groups.  I recommend making a reservation unless you don't mind eating at the bar.  Service is fast and professional.
author: Arturo S.

description:
The Nutshell: Interesting place, food was good, but prices were kinda high. 

I've been meaning to try the place for sometime, finally got out last night. 

First thing I asked walking in the door was, "got fresh crab?" -because the season just kicked off. Their reply was, "yes we do" only to discover later that there was no crab on the menu, or for special order. Hmm.

From there, app was very good (the sea urchin) and the mains were nice (the sole, and the lobster pot pie). And with two beers, our total was $90.

Seemed a little fishy there in the price, but that's that.

I plan to go back for lunch sometime next week... stay tuned.
author: Joe R.

description:
Food = 3 stars.  I need to preface this review with the fact that I'm allergic to crustaceans, which isn't usually a big problem... there are usually plenty of items that a non-crustacean eater would try.  I'm sure the crab paella or the seafood stew were totally awesome.  I was drooling when I saw it on the menu... but my damn allergies kept me from them.  

I ordered the petrale sole last night... it was ok.  I didn't think it was bad, but it wasn't spectacular either.  It was just ok.  For appetizers, we ordered the beet salad and basil clams.  Basil clams were pretty good, especially the sauce it came with.  Clams were fresh and didn't have that nasty "sat in the freezer" taste.  If I were to go to this restaurant again, I'd order the clams again.  

For dessert, we ordered the eggnog la creme and the sorbet.  Again, it wasn't bad, but wasn't anything to rave about.  

Add one star for ambiance and service (our table stayed there for three hours).
Total = 4 stars.
author: Olivia L.

description:
I will start with the bottom line: dinner was not worth the amount paid--and hopefully "yet" will be attached.

I am not sure what is going on but once again, I sat at a bar and watched people walk in after me and get served a drink. I sat there for 10-15 minutes, and finally the manager came over and asked me if I had been asked if I would like a drink. I said no, and he brought over a drink menu and comped me an expensive glass of bubbly. Nice save.

My friend joined me at the bar and our server was great. I ordered the sea urchin appetizer which was as good as everyone has said--it was small though, so sharing would be difficult if you are a piggy like me. My friend had the corn chowder and the clams were a bit chewy. 

For entrees, I had the Mussels, Monkfish and Chorizo stew and it was really good. My friend had the lobster roll and it was underwhelmed--but what is a east coaster doing ordering a lobster roll in California? She said the bread wasn't squishy enough--too toasted. 

We ordered a bottle of white wine from New Zealand which was nice and around $40.

Anyhoo, when the bill came it was around $50 a person just for food, and neither one of us really thought what we had eaten was worth the amount on the bill. I will try them again in a few months to see if the quality of food matches the price because right now it does not.
author: Deborah S.

description: Great food, drinks and service! The salt and pepper calamari was great and the lobster roll was amazing. My wife had a really nice Rosé and I had a dark beer that was brewed with fresh oysters! A nice surprise was after we finished our meal we saw a friend who we didn't know works there (that used to work at another restaurant that we frequent) and she bought us dessert, a wonderful rhubarb cobbler.
author: James B.

description:
The good: the interior is very nicely done, the wait staff is very nice and helpful, the beer battered halibut(its insanely good!), the chocolate cake dessert, the white wine

Needs improvement: the sea bass was so so, kind of didnt work; the lobster, just couldnt figure out what they were trying to do; we had two other desserts but i forget what they were as i was kind of tipsy but they had fruit in them

Good news: the place is only a few weeks old as of this writing so i wont rush to judgment and will gladly go back for another try
author: Not M.

description:
Nice space and friendly hostess
Fried clams - luke warm
Watermelon/heirloom tomato salad was delicious
Lobster roll was too cream-mayonnaisey, the slaw was sopping
Good wine selection
Service was attentive
The experience averages out to good overall, but I'm not running back for the food.

They only get one star because of how they handled an error on the bill. We spent a couple of hundred $ and I got double-charged. Mistakes happen. I'm fine with that, but the gen-mgr didn't return my call for 2 days; when he did, he was nice, but not once an apology and told me I should wait and see. I had to call the bank & take care of it myself. 

C'mon folks, when you're in the service industry, remember, "thank you" and "I'm sorry" goes a hell of a long way.
author: Bibi B.

description:
I've been here twice, once for lunch and once for dinner. Both times I was very disappointed with the service. It took almost 15 minutes for someone to even come by with menus during lunch, and another 15 to order our drinks. The waitresses rarely stopped by to check on us throughout both meals. For the amount of money one will pay to eat here, you'd think service would be spot-on. 

The only item on their menu I think is worth mentioning is their lobster roll. 

The interior is way too staged. I felt like we could have been eating at Fisherman's Warf. Or Disneyland.
author: F H.

description:
Love the name, love the decor, love the written menu, love the location. But man, even on a business lunch budget ($75/two people), this place was pushing it in terms of cost.

Why the mussels and fries are not on the appetizer menu is a bit perplexing, but whatever. We ordered them off the entrees and at it as a starter. Portion was small considering it was intended to be an entree, and I wish they had either served the mussels in a shallower dish so the sauce could mingle with the mussels, or fill the bucket thing a little more with sauce. To me, the whole reason you get 'moule frites' is for the sauce--both on the mussels and for dipping fries into. Regardless, it was tasty.

The lunch entrees are composed of $15+ sandwiches and $25 entrees. We had the lobster roll - very tasty, if not a bit greasy. Coleslaw was flavoriless, and chips were so so. I would have rather eaten a larger sandwich for the price. We also ordered the salmon with basmati rice -- again, pretty good, but salmon and rice for twenty-something bucks? Eh.

For the price and the reputation, I was expecting something a little more creative and varied. I wouldn't go here on my own. But for another $75 lunch? Why not. Sure beats eating at Umbria every other day.
author: Sabine S.

description:
I love finding a new restaurant and being able to give it five stars, and after a few visits, I'm thrilled to report that Anchor & Hope definitely deserves all five.  Located in a former auto mechanics bay (and somewhat hard to find, off the beaten path on Minna between Mission & Howard at 2nd street), this new restaurant delivered on all points.  They've been open a relatively short time and seem to have ironed out any of the wrinkles that were initially present and to be expected in a brand new establishment. 

Service -- extremely friendly, accommodating, helpful, and attentive.  The hostess and waitstaff dazzled.  

Beer/Wine -- extensive selection of bottled beers, served perfectly.  Very well thought-out wine list, not too lengthy but hitting on all cylinders.  

Food -- excellent.  Three of us shared two appetizers, the exotic beet salad (so delicious, and perfectly balanced), and the Ipswich fried clams, which were delicate, crispy, and so flavorful.  Note that these are not the rubbery strips so typical of many restaurants, but are tiny, Ipswich clams, lightly battered, and then fried crisp and served with a nice house-made tartar sauce.  

The entrees were great too, and I commend the restaurant on its portion control -- it was "just right."  I am so tired of restaurants that feel like they have to overwhelm us with volume, and conversely with places where the food is so very special they can allocate only precious tiny tastings for big prices.  I had the halibut, served with crispy potatoes (they were nice and held the rosemary on the potatoes for me -- I recommend asking them to do it -- rosemary overpowers the fresh pure flavor of the potatoes otherwise.)  My friends had the scallops, which were perfectly cooked and seasoned, and the bass, grilled and served with peaches.  

On another visit, this time at lunch, I ordered the crab salad.  After being assured that it included no onions, I was not happy when with my first bite of the crab, I discovered finely minced onions.  However, the waitress swiftly whisked it away and replaced it with the shrimp salad.   A minor glitch, but something that restaurants need to be aware of -- many patrons have sensitivities to certain foods and it's not just that we don't "like" it -- it almost puts us in the emergency room. 

I must mention the desserts, which earn a couple of stars.  We three shared two desserts:  the rich, moist chocolate espresso cake, which was truly spectacular, every bite so succulent and rich; and the fresh peach & cherry crisp, served with house-made vanilla ice cream, which married somewhat tart peaches, very sweet cherries, and a buttery topping with the creamy smooth vanilla goodness.  I would be hard pressed to determine which was my favorite -- both were excellent.  (Realizing I've used "excellent" and "perfect" way too many times already, I do feel compelled to add that they serve excellent coffee, in oversized cups.  It's perfect!)

Ambiance -- like all but a few restaurants, yes it's noisy and at times we had to repeat ourselves to be heard.  But this didn't diminish our enjoyment of the restaurant, with its subtle nautical theme.  It's not kitschy like something you'd find at Fisherman's Wharf, but more like the types of lobster places that dot New England.  Note that this is more like the favorite place the locals frequent, and they usually keep it to themselves while sending the tourists to the paste-like clam chowder house tourist traps that most New England towns are packed with. 

Prices -- are about what you'd expect in FiDi, and given the quality and service, well earned.  I highly recommend trying Anchor & Hope, especially if you're burned out on all the other restaurants in the area.      I've visited the sister restaurants Town Hall and Salt Box numerous times, and have to say this one is my new favorite of the three.  Reservations were easy, via OpenTable.  I've learned, however, that if you're trying to book for a specific time and OT shows it unavailable, to call the restaurant directly -- they often have availabilities that don't show up online. 

Color me happy!
author: Bevy M.

description:
Well I just had lunch here today and it was really fantastic.  Staff was prompt and on top of things and the tuna melt i had had perfectly crisp bread to compliment the tombo tuna which wasn't overpowering in any way.  The crab bisque as a starter was delish too.  I loved how it was poured into the bowl and we also had some lobster and oysters.  I am not an oyster afficianado but I like kumamotos and also tried the kummi(?) which was tasty!

For desert we had a melange of the offerings since it was a wedding party including chocolate cake of some type that was rich and filling, as well as a couple sorbets.  All in all a great outing and I'd love to come back in a less formal setting to try Anchor and Hope again.
author: Gene X.

description: I've had several good meals at Anchor & Hope. Ironically, I'm inclined to have the Fish & Chips every time I go! Really, excellent Fish & Chips. Very good service,  attentive and pleasant servers, nice crowds and good vibe to this place. I recommend it highly.
author: Andrew P.

description: Food was good and atmosphere is clean. I'm giving it 3 stars because they seated us  about 15 mins past our reservation time and our seafood platter had some seafood that still had rocks or pieces of shell in it.
author: H C.

description: BF and I decided last minute to eat out for dinner and swung by Anchor and Hope.  The hostess was so nice and the place just gives off a not trying too hard hip casual vibe.  Definitely like having the large beer selection and everything on the menu sounds tasty.  We ended up with the smelt fries, the uni app, the chowder, bacon oysters and grilled shrimp.  Not a miss in the bunch but my favorites were the oysters and the uni.  The service was great and we just walked away completely happy with dinner...well we actually walked away with a loaf of bread...don't ask.
author: Jen C.

description:
We had a lovely experience at Anchor & Hope. The hostess accomodated a last minute addition to our party, and also purposely placed us in a more intimate, enclosed area. This allowed us to conduct our business dinner and still enjoy the lively yet not overly loud atmosphere. 

Food: Try the "Angels on Horseback"  -delicious bacon wrapped oysters! We also had the "fries with eyes", which were fried smelts with a dipping sauce. Fried = tasty. For my entree I had the Smithwick's battered cod with rosemary potato wedges. I couldn't have had a less healthy selection, but I had seen it online and wanted to try it. I'm sure glad I did because the fish was battered so it had a delicate yet sturdy coating with a tangy tartar sauce. The taters were perfection. It's not my fault fried stuff tastes good! A couple people in my group had the boulliabase, which they also enjoyed. Our group ordered dessert, and the stout cake with maple gingersnap ice cream was delicious, and so was the apple pie with hazelnut ice cream!

 Service:I wish I had gotten our servers name because she was so on top of it without being overbearing. We were dragging our asses and she never pressured us. She was also quite knowledgeable about the wine and beer list, which are both quite extensive. Awesome wine-by-the-glass selection.

The space looks fantastic at night time, and it's lively without being too loud. We had a good time, even if it was a business dinner. Best part about that though was that I didn't have to pay, and we got to order all kinds of appetizers, desserts, and wine without worrying about the pricetag! If I had to pay, maybe my review wouldn't have been so enthusiastic, but I still feel the prices were right on for the quality and freshness of the food and the high level of service.

I will definitely be back!
author: Audrey K.

description: Nice decor.  The waitress was friendly, but the service was a bit slow on a Sunday night.  We ordered the sea urchin, lobster roll, and spice crusted sea scallops.   The sea urchin was not bad, but it was overpowered by other components in the dish. The lobster roll was bland, and the chips were way too salty.  The spice crusted sea scallops were undercooked.  The kitchen recreated the dish, and it was all good the second time.
author: Roger W.

description:
More like Anchor & Nope!

My work took me here for my birthday and I was really looking forward to enjoying some tasty crab on the company dime.  We had a reservation and were sat promptly.  That's pretty much were the fun ended.  

Once we got around to ordering, which was about 25 minutes after sitting down, you have time to enjoy the decor since you'll wait equally as long for your food to come out.  

Our table had the tuna melt, crab Louis, shrimp Louis and the burger - all equally good.  NOT out of this world, man I NEED to eat here again, but good.  I wasn't opening up the snack drawer when I got back to my desk.

The waiter was just plain bad. Totally on his own schedule and didn't both catering to the lunch crowd that needs to get out by 1.  We were at his restaurant and were going to be served as he saw fit.  Points majorly off for that. 

I will not be dining at the Anchor anymore.
author: Joe U.

description:
Came in on a Monday night.  Place was still quite bustling.  We were immediately seated for our reservation, (though 15 minutes early).  We made our reservation through Opentable.  Decor was decent.

She had a couple glasses of wine and I had a couple from their beer selections.  The beer list is really good!  Some great Belgian imports!

Appetizers:  Bacon wrapped fried oysters, (Angels on Horseback), Schezuan Prawns.
Entrees:  Artic Char, Lobster Roll.

Of the above, the Lobster Roll was amazing.  I could have had 2.  I'm not even a lobster fan, but this thing was....WOW!

Service was perfect.
author: shawn p.

description: Outstanding service, great food, and an extremely responsive and customer focused management...General Manager Colleen Booth is just fantastic (thank you Colleen for the wonderful dining experience).   I am definitely a fan!
author: Kara B.

description:
I love Town Hall, however- Anchor and Hope was VERY disapointing.  I had high hopes...but the food was not good.  

appetizers:
The shrimp cocktail that we started with was what you expect- nothing special. And the calamari was overbreaded and didn't stand out.

Main Course:

I had the sea bass and the dish was very salty, I like salt- but it was over salted, coupled with the chorizo very overpowering for this delicate fish.  It was not good....

Dessert:

I don't even remember what we had- I just remember that I didn't want more than 2 bites...!

Sorry- love town hall and salt house....but will not be begging to dine here anytime soon...
author: Christina S.

description: My criticism of Anchor & Hope is the same that I have for the sister restaurants, Town Hall and Salt House. They're all okay, but not spectacular--not a destination restaurant but probably better than your average neighborhood restaurant. I had the Fisherman's stew, which was on the skimpier side, although the broth was really delicious (spicy, and not too tomato-ey).  My partner had the lobster roll, which he thought was good, but nothing to write home about.  Dessert was a good strawberry shortcake--again, everything was okay, not spectacular, and I would probably be more enthusiastic if I'd liked the service.  But our server seemed to be in a rush--we'd barely been seated when she came to take our orders.  And after we ordered (no starters), the food came about 5 minutes later.  I kid you not. We did order dessert, but I felt like the server kept checking in on us, which gave the meal a very rushed feel (not the mood we were going for, since we were meeting friends whom we hadn't seen in a year). Even weirder, when we left, the place was far from packed, so I'm not sure why she seemed in such a hurry to see us out.
author: Christine H.

description:
I liked the location of this place - kind of tucked away down an alley away from the business of Market & MIssion Streets.  The restaurant has a very open industrial feeling - brick and exposed beams, etc.  Really cute with interesting piranha mural behind the bar.

Joined a few friends for a drink and appetizers during happy hour.  Two of our friends arrived slightly before us and ordered a few things to start because happy hour was ending soon. We got there just at the cut off for happy hour but our waitress was kind enough to let us order a few more things.  The waitress was very nice but not the most attentive.  Luckily we were there more to chat and didn't mind much at all.  There were a few other servers that stopped by and were happy to help as well.

The $1 Oysters were a great deal and were delicious. I don't eat raw oysters very often but these tasted very fresh. The garlic parmesan fries are a must - delicious.  Also tried the Salted Cod Brandade which I didn't like or dislike. Just not really my kind of dish.  The Clam Chowder was good but I hear there are better chowder places to go in the city

I would go back but probably not for dinner as their entrees are on the pricier side.  You can probably find better bang for your buck elsewhere for dinner.  All in all, it was good for what we came for......Happy hour drinks and appetizers.
author: Stephani B.

description:
I was surprised and sad that they replaced the fresh baked bread with chips. My shrimp roll was too salty and overloaded with aioli spread. Would have preferred the shrimp roll bioche more on the naked side. The brioche was overbaked and dry.

My lunch date had the lobster roll which I tried. It's overrated and overpriced for what you get.
author: Lisa W.

description: Nice cool SOMA late night spot.  Good staff.  Decent food.  Not all that different from Salt House but with a seafood focus.
author: Laurence H.

description:
This is the restaurant featured in one of the "The Best Thing I Ever Ate" episodes with its famous sea urchin dish.

The restaurant has a unique ambiance, giving it a "sea-village" look and feel -- perhaps an attempt to emphasize its style of cuisine.

Nothing on the menu besides the sea urchin captured my attention, but that's not a problem, since I was solely there for the uni.  I ordered two -- one for appetizer, and one for entree :)

While the staff is polite and friendly, all of our waiter/waitresses were neglectful to some degree.  For example, they forgot to serve one of our beverages.  As well, one "helpful" waitress insisted on taking my used spoon (after I was done with my appetizer) despite my refusal to surrender, yet she forgot to give me a new one with my entree (another sea urchin).

On to the food, the sea urchin was indeed a great exhibition of originality and creativity.  However, there were a few problems with the dish.  The beurre blanc was overpowering the taste of crab and sea urchin.  As well, there were pieces of feature bones and shells inside the dish.  I jokingly said to my friends, "Gordon Ramsay would not approve of this dish".

All-in-all, it was an excellent meal that did not live up to its hype.  I am torn between a three and a four.  However, the service and the pieces of bones really vitiated my overall dining experience.
author: Bill T.

description:
Though I can't fairly rate the food since I didn't eat dinner here, I will say this: 

Good service, yummy oysters and good drinks. 

But what makes it 4 stars for me is the city vibe and ambiance of the place. Modern, industrial but with these detailed sea/ocean/nautical touches that show the owners are paying attention to detail and it's going to come through in the food. 

Plus coming from the same people behind Salt House and Town Hall, I'm betting the food is great!
author: Denise B.

description:
It's rare that I am willing to return to a restaurant several times in one month, but I could to to Anchor and Hope again and again and again.  And I have. 

Anchor and Hope is by far the best seafood restaurant I have been to in the city because it has the seafood trifecta: fantastic food / great atmosphere / reasonable prices.  Nestled on Minna, it would be easy to totally miss A&H if you didn't know what you're looking for.  But inside the restaurant is a combination of polished cement floors, raw wood planks, glass and black chalk boards.  It has the same modern/stylish yet comfortable atmosphere as sister restaurant Salt House.  

The food is outstanding.  My favorites so far are the scallop ceviche and the monkfish & chorizo stew.  All the other options we've tried were great, including the lobster, oysters and fish & chips.  They have a great wine list that is reasonably priced; a recent dinner for 4 which included appetizers, mains, a bottle of NZ sav blanc plus a round of tawny port came to $65pp including tip.  

Highly recommended - make reservations and give yourself plenty of time to enjoy yourself.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
I finally tried this place and had a wonderful meal.  Highlights include:

Acme bread:  Delicious and fresh, and served with a little pot of delicious fresh butter with nice sea salt on top.  

Scallop appetizer:  too small to share among more than a couple people, but absolutely fantastic.  The scallops were so fresh and perfectly cooked that they were sweet.  

OLD BAY KETTLE CHIPS:  Yum.  These were a side for an entree that I did not want, but I HAD to have the chips.  I asked, A&H served.  They are made from scratch at the restaurant, and are fantastic.  I tried to explain to my table about how Utz makes an old bay potato chip, and how I go out of my way to get them when I am in the mid-atlantic.  No one really listens to me, but everyone loved the A&H old bay chips.

Calamari with Thai chili sauce:  not the best calamari I've had, but it seemed freshly breaded and fried.  I'm always partial to marinara or aioli with calamari, though.

Halibut on a bed of onion puree:  The onions and onion puree were a really tasty accompaniment to the halibut, which was perfectly cooked.  

Stop here.  Go find a nice cafe if you want dessert, or just enjoy the illy coffee and skip the sweets.  Salted butterscotch creme brulee with chocolate cookies sounded SO good, but it almost cost this place a star in my review.  Really, really not good.  The assorted sorbets - nothing special.  Save your $8.50.
author: Amy D.

description:
Sitting quietly in the Minna alley, this "fish house" retains the old warehouse air of exposed bricks and high ceilings, while serving up really creative seafood with an impressive list of beers.

I must admit, I was a little skeptical about this place since I didn't particularly like Salt House when it made its debut (owned by the same people).  Now all skepticism out of the window for A&H!!  

We started off with a dozen oysters and a bottle of Sauvignon Blanc.  While I wasn't sure if the wine was truly worth $70 (would've gone with beers but wine seemed to be a more reasonable choice for a dinner party of two), the oysters were all very good.  The Kumamotos were sweet as always, and the Kushis were larger in size and creamier in taste.  

Moving onto our appetizers: We had the beet salad and the warm sea urchin in the shell.  The beet salad, as expected, was refreshing and light.  The warm sea urchin was probably the richest seafood appetizer I have ever had...  It was made with crab and mashed potatoes and cream...  It was like eating foie gras from the sea.  Every spoonful was heart attack delicious and just as I thought I was getting overwhelmed, I went for another bite.  The shell was scraped clean when it was taken away from our table. 

Which made sharing an entree a smart idea.  

We got the grilled petrale sole with Brussels sprouts, which was ideal following the sea urchin experience.  It was light and airy, the perfect kind of white fish to calm your palate before dessert.

We wrapped up the meal with cups of espresso and a apple pie topped with hazelnut gelato.  Heavenly.  

I highly recommend this place.  Instinct tells me that wine is on the expensive side, so BYOW may be a better option, or just enjoy their fantastic selection of beers, as I will soon, on my next visit.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
it's a beer/wine only bar.  Memo to A&H:  Run, don't walk, to the Liquor Control Board, and get the liquor license.  Shellfish without hard alcohol is like sex without orgasm - I enjoy it, but it's not what it could be.

Still, Bon Apetit magazine said Anchor & Hope was a tremendous shellfish place, and they didn't lie.  No frills, raw shellfish platter was tremendous.  Great oysters, fresh shrimp, not too big, not too small.  Good fish stew, and the wife's steamed clams were spectacular.  

Chairs are brushed aluminum and COLD - don't go bare-legged with your skirt.  (They are, though, surprisingly comfortable over the course of a full meal.)  The place filled up and was packed by 8, without being noisy or crowded.  Waitress was friendly and cheery, and the shellfish platter she put together for us was great.  So overall, a nice seafood experience.
author: John H.

description:
I stopped in at Anchor & Hope after work last week looking for a bite to eat and a glass of wine after a long day.  I had long anticipated coming in, their storefront is attractive and I'd heard good things.

The hostess seemed disappointed that I wanted a table for one, and that I indicated I was just looking for apps and a glass or two.  She seated me at a two-top along the side wall, where the tables were so close together it was nearly calamitous to try to squeeze through to get to the far seat.

My waitress was less than attentive, and I had to wait nearly 20 minutes for her to finally decide to take my drink order, and even then she rushed away so fast I couldn't also give her my order for food.

I ended up ordering two apps, a cured salmon salad and the oxtail marmalade and beef marrow plate.  The food took a long time, although the restaurant was pretty empty except for a load of people enjoying oysters at the bar.  While I waited, they brought a good portion of cold bread and salted butter.

The beef came up before the salad, unfortunately, but once it arrived, the food was good.  The marrow was pretty raw, but the oxtail marmalade was amazing.  The salad was well-dressed and the salmon was generous.

In all, I wish I'd been there with a larger group, or somehow been able to earn more of the server's attention - I actually really wanted something from their "raw board," but she was pretty impatient with me and I didn't feel like hassling her into a discussion on what was on offer.

I'd go back again, but only as part of a larger party.
author: Laura M.

description: This a great place... Atmosphere, service, food. It's all good. My wife and I had the fish and chips... Some of the best around. Especially good was the shrimp cocktail and clam chowder... Not your everyday chowder either. We ate at Anchor and Hope after a full day in the art galleries. Couldn't plan a better place to close a great Valentines Day. Highly recommend.. Will visit again
author: JP G.

description:
I don't go out for nicer work lunches often and my colleague suggested Anchor & Hope.  I was not sure what to expect although I'll admit that I am partial to the ocean so that was a good start.

Food: we ordered calamari to start.  It was ok although the dipping sauce was great.  Luckily, the main courses shined.  I ordered the blackened catfish sandwich and my colleague ordered the salmon sandwich.  Both arrived with huge sides of tasty salad.  My sandwich was great in that it was on fresh, whole wheat sourdough (I think) grilled bread and the blackening was not so much that it was overdone.  My only problem - eating it all with my hands as it started to fall apart a bit.  No biggie - that is what a knife and fork are for.  My colleague completely and utterly cleaned his plate, which I take to be a good sign.  

Ambiance: perfect for lunch.  Light, airy, and not too loud but tables were far enough apart that you would not hear the conversation at the table next to you.  I also happened to love the way they changed up this small warehouse.  

Service: perfectly timed and run.  Zero complaints.  No one rushed us or brought out our sandwiches before we were done with our calamari.  

Definitely my new favorite lunch spot for nicer lunches.
author: Adam S.

description:
Had a very solid and fun experience at Anchor & Hope last week.

The service was at the same time playful and mature. Nice work there.

We shared the Sea Urchin, a lobster claw appetizer (I'm embarrassed to note that I forgot the name) and the evening's special, lasagna-like dish with ricotta layered between a folded noodle. The dish featured more slices of truffle than I've ever eaten before!

We also had a tasty, but otherwise not memorable dessert.

Anchor & Hope fills a nice seafood restaurant niche that clearly needed to be filled in San Francisco. That is, it's not super casual or super high-end and it's also not a tourist trap. I'd definitely return to explore the menu a bit more and to order that Sea Urchin again!
author: Brad L.

description:
Had dinner here with friends on the night of the election to celebrate. Though the day itself was spectacular, and the company was great, I can't say great things about Anchor and Hope.

We are fans of Town Hall and Salt House, so we had high "hopes" of another great experience.

Service was friendly, but slow and often unattentive.  (we had to ask to order another bottle of wine after ordering champagne - couldn't they tell we were happy lushes ready to drink??? - items took a long time coming from the kitchen, etc...)

Food was unremarkable at best.  We had the tuscan white bean soup, warm endive salad, and paella.  Soup and sald were ok but nothing to write home about,  and the paella was greasy.

Dessert was the highlight of the meal - sticky toffee pudding.  It was great and I would love to have it again, but not if I have to sit through another very average dinner at Anchor and Hope to get to it.  There are just too many other places in the City I would rather try or go back to.

My recommendation? Pass.  I'm bummed to say it, but it's true.

p.s.
One other bummer....though it seems like a perfect spot for cocktails, they only offer beer and wine.
author: K. B.

description: We sat at the bar and enjoyed ourselves. The zuckerman asparagus app is excellent. Definitely try!
author: Lauren B.

description:
Angels on horseback was amazing - I wish we hadn't decided to share just one dish.  Also enjoyed the lobster roll.  The first few bites didn't quite convince me, but it got better with subsequent bites.  It still can't compare to the lobster roll at the Old Port Lobster Shack, though (I still dream about the bread there).  Thumbs up to the fish & chips as well - the fish was amazingly tender.  I didn't enjoy the scallop ceviche as much as it was pretty small and not flavorful enough for me.

Great ambiance - Love the high ceilings, rafters, and exposed red rick.
author: Melinda C.

description:
My favorite SF restaurant of 2009!!!!

My husband took me there for a Valentine's Day dinner and it was just superb! The seafood was fresh and delicious (although they ran out of sea urchin before we could try any....WHAT? and I still give them 5 stars? YUP coz by the end of the dinner I would forgive anything), the food was so flavorful, the menu well thought through including the dessert options. The raw bar was fun, and the wine list was excellent. 

The service, considering it was a super busy night, was impressively attentive, polite and elegant.

The decor is very clean and classy, with funky fish painted on the walls that make the place unique and hip.

I could eat there over and over and over and over again!!!!!!
author: Natasha k.

description:
I went here about 9 months ago. I remember we ordered a couple of appertizers and all were exceptionally delicious. The sea urchin was phenomenally prepared. Appertizers portion were very small, leaving me wanting more. We had a party of about 5, thus our we each get almost to nothing for each appertizers. The entrees were not as outstanding as the appertizers. My entree at least was mediocre. I remember one of us had this seafood entree, similar to cioppino, and it was huge. It looked delicious! Good service ang good food. The environment felt, "steely"-neatly organized and bare w/ metal decors. Felt like I was dining in the back of a seafood warehouse. 

I'll come back here, when I get a better job with better pay!
author: MT D.

description:
Anchor & Hope fits perfectly into the SoMa neighborhood; modern colors and a loft-like layout make you feel like you are in a very trendy bedroom for a dinner party.   This is primarily a seafood restaurant and these guys know what they're doing! Mercury never tasted this good ;)

I take it their menu changes periodically, maybe daily, so I won't go into recommendations.  However, I will recommend getting a table along the wall for the romantic factor.  The white wall you would be facing from sitting at the bar is a little harsh for the gentle aesthetic's eye.

I'm looking forward to returning and trying their other succulent fish creations!
author: Aristocles P.

description: You know you have had a  disappointment when the most memorable part of the meal was the potato chips.  This restaurant lacked it all from the cold ambience to the lousy table service.  I had the lobster brioche.   It should have been labeled bread with a light topping of lobster pieces.  And, at $40 per person who could ask for less.
author: Barry Z.

description: For the price of the food, you would expect much better service at this place.  Dinner took 4 hours here and I felt like our table was neglected. We had to flag down our waitress if we needed anything (water, ordering our food, the check, etc)..  The appetizers were okay, but not worth the price.  As for the entrees, I didn't think it was anything great.  It took an hour and a half for my main dish to come out after we finished our appetizers! ...And then another half an hour for the dessert to come out after we finished our food. I wouldn't recommend this place unless you have your entire day or night to waste. If the service wasn't one of the worst I've experienced, I would give this place 2.5 stars at best.
author: Emily S.

description:
3.5 rounded up.

4.5 stars for service: the host offered us free sparkling wine for having to wait for our table.  I give restaurants HUGE points for this.  Throughout our meal, our server was attentive, etc. 

4 stars for atmosphere -- really nice, open space.  My one complaint is that the bar area was really more of a dining area (set with plates and silverware), not really a place to just grab a drink.

3 stars for food -- I enjoyed the bacon-wrapped oysters (how can you go wrong with that?), the sea urchin appetizer (very rich) and the fried cipollini onions, but the mussells with chorizo stew was pretty average.  The rest of the table really liked their entrees though.

Solid place -- will likely be back again.
author: Mitzi C.

description:
Roasted stuffed lobster. 

Half of a whole lobster with the tail in tact and roasted in butter, claw fully in its shell with sweet meat inside, and the main part of the lobster scooped out, mixed with breadcrumbs, butter and some other delicious items, stuffed back into the shell and roasted. It's freaking fabulous.

We also had each of the Pacific Coast oysters, all fresh and delicious with their special spicy cocktail sauce and horseradish concoction, and the fried calamari which came with a perfect tangy dipping sauce that offset the fried batter (the way malt vinegar offsets fish and chips). 

The decor is beautiful - exposed ceiling loft with beautiful lighting, both industrial and cozy, and thoroughly modern. The check comes under a heavy ball anchor - a cute touch.

Tres bon! I will be back soon.
author: Deb I.

description: This is one my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  I usually like quiet comfortable restaurants but the experience at Anchor & Hope is very enjoyable.  The seafood is always fresh; the lobster roll is my absolute favorite!
author: David C.

description: I wish I could review the food, but I never got past the RUDE person who answered the phone, put me on hold for several minutes and then hang up on me.  I actually even called back, and got put on hold again for a LONG time before I gave up.  Work on your manners.
author: wendy t.

description: Wow. Awesome beer selection, even more awesome food. Really great atmosphere.
author: Ron K.

description: This is the first oyster bar I'd ever been to and it was a good introduction.  We ended up ordering 2 varieties of oysters at the bar - they were served over ice with lemon and a tangy sauce meant to be drizzled over the top.  They have a ton of beers on tap which is appreciated (next time I come, I want to try the tasting flight - a number of samples for 18 dollars).  Good oysters and beer, prices can be a little steep though.  Luckily, I had my banker friend there to expense all our food.  So thanks Citibank for the delicious oysters ;)
author: Taylor J.

description:
A friend and I ended up here tonight after agreeing to meet near the W and then finding ourselves completely out of ideas for where to eat. As this was only the second night of their opening, and they lacked a liquor license, we were able to "bring our own" drinks gratis, so ten glasses of wine later, shared between the two of us, my friend and I were rather pleased.

We both had the halibut and then shared the rich chocolate cake with pudding for dessert; all of which was delicious. He had an Americano, and I had a green tea that was, supposedly, especially made for A&H.  Again, rather good. 

Overall, the service was impeccable, the menu was interesting, and the decor was intriguing. We ended up sitting at the communal table given how busy the restaurant was and enjoyed our selves thoroughly; only occasionally stopping to chat with our neighbors.

Admittedly, I didn't love that our server said something to the effect of "and, of course, I'll be bringing an Americano with the dessert", which sounded as if it, too, would be complementary, though it showed up on bill.  Given the free wine we imbibed, though, this was a negligible irritation.
author: D L.

description:
Went with a friend and adored it!

The service is amazing, even when busy. They sat us pretty late and didn't seem to mind. Knowledgeable servers who were able to pair our wine with scrumptious entrees. 

Great loft style building. Gigantic fish painted on the wall, great seating/lighting/design. Big moorings hanging from the ceiling.  It was back in an alley way. Really cool, NYC type atmosphere. Really wasn't familiar with this neighborhood of San Fran. 

Now for the food: we got an ahi dish and a tilapia dish. But from what they say the menu is always changing. How exciting! It was all so delicious can't wait to go back.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Went last night with a friend from outta town. We split a wondeful bottle of Chardonnay and a whole bunch of apps: Warm Sea Urchin in Shell, Fries with Eyes, Pepper Prawns, Smoked Trout Salad, Angels on Horseback, Clams in a spicy Thai broth, & Ribbon Fries. Everything was good with a few items being great. 

The Angels on Horseback, or bacon-wrapped oysters were crispy bacon on the outside, with nicely not too cooked oysters inside. The oyster was like a creamy, gooey burst of the sea... The Fries with Eyes were an well fried, not greasy and a great rendition of whole fried smeldts served with a tasty remoulade sauce... The Sea Urchin was interesting and tasty. Pieces of uni mixed in with crab meat and mashed potatoes... The clams were perfectly cooked and the broth was bread-sopping goodness. Flavored with some Kaffir and Lemongrass me thinks and some Fresno chilies... The Ribbon Fries, are really more like chips, but a great side nonetheless... The Prawns weren't bad, but didn't blow me away... And the trout salad was tasty, but really coulda used a bit more trout. But the poached egg on top was a really nice touch.
author: Brian J.

description:
Came here on Friday without ressies for 5 girls.  They were very accomodating and called us in 45 minutes when something was available.  So we just went to John Collins for a drink in the meantime. We had the chowder, gravlax, salmon entree, bouillabaisse, lobster roll, shrimp cocktail, oysters wrapped in bacon and their signature uni.  No real standouts except for the last 2 dishes.  everything else was nothing special and all seemed to have the same tabasco hot sauce kick.  All in all, it was pretty reasonable at $50 for seafood and wine...

Atmosphere is nice and I loved the artwork with the big fish chomping on the lil fish - adorable...
author: Amina B.

description:
I'd probably give this place 4 stars if it was a bit more reasonable price wise. Thought the atmosphere was cool - that rustic/modern/shipyard thing going on. 

We started with the Miyagi oysters, which were good as always (but not quite as good as the Kumamotos) and a few brinier ones from the northwest which were ok. Next up we split the "fries with eyes" which I could have passed on but my boy dug since they prepared them the same way as his favorite tapa in Spain, aka fried bocarones. My favorite dish of the eve we tried was the salmon carapacho salad which was light, refreshing but  flavorful salad. We also shared the fish and chips which were tasty, not greasy and the chips had a nice rosemary flavor. 

Overall good service, food, but again, I'd save a return visit  for a dinner-on-the-corporate-card type event.
author: Kelly R.

description:
The first time I put a bacon-wrapped oyster in my mouth I think I heard angels singing and a small harp playing in the background...the first words out of my mouth..."Mmmm...oh yea..." get your minds of the gutter ;-)

In my book anything wrapped in bacon is going to be good, but to take something already so decadent and delicious on its own and to add bacon is really a treat.

As to the rest of the meal, I would say good, but not great. While the uni dish is great conceptually and actually quite good, the added cream and crab elements do take away from the "ocean essence" of the uni, which is the reason to eat uni in the first place. Uni is truly best left unadulterated. The lobster roll was on par with those I've had while living out east, as were the scallops which really are hard to mess up.

Next trip here will be for happy hour (solid beer list) and appetizers only.
author: David H.

description: Like most things on a mass published list, great disappointment and pure hype lurk around the corner.  However, I was really surprised by A&H.  I was charmed by both the food and the nautical-themed interior.  7x7, you totally did good with this one.  I actually completely agree!  A piece of bacon wrapped oyster heaven. Further, my life is also now complete after tasting the sea urchin and whipped potato dish.  Mmm.
author: Wendy L.

description: We went in a rather large group, and got to try a good dozen dishes. All were exceptionally good. The decor is fun and funky. Coupled with an Alonzo King show at the Yerba Buena center, the evening was quite delightful.
author: Sramana M.

description:
Loved this place! We had our rehearsal dinner at Town Hall a few years ago, so we were already fans of the owners. Salt House had left us wanting more, so A&H was a really happy surprise.

We waited a long time for our table, but the staff was incredible accommodating - sending comped appetizers and a couple drinks our way. So were happy to get a nice cozy table in the back.

The tuna entree was one of the best preparations i've ever had. the lobster roll was tasty (but not as good as yankee pier in marin!). 

the crowd was a nice, eclectic mix of biz, arts and fashion mavens. A fun night out.
author: layla k.

description:
I had very high hopes for this place.  The food is pretty good but the service was HORRIBLE.  Do not go one minute early and think you can have a drink at the bar because the bar is actually just for dinner.

The bartender was so unbelievably rude when he informed me that I could not actually sit at the bar but that I could stand at the end of the bar and he could serve me there.  Yeah, the end of the bar was the service station.  You can only imagine the bobbing and weaving we had to do to avoid having wine dumped all over us by the service staff who were pissed that we were there.  It was ridiculous.

And our waiter was pretty much MIA the whole night.  By the time we asked of the check we were pretty sure that he had gone home for the evening.  Apparently he was just six or seven blocks away judging by the amount of time it took him to get to us.

The food overall was pretty good.  The Ipswich clams were good but not as good as they are in Ipswich and the entrees and dessert were good too.  However, until they clean up their act on the service and attitude I am not going back.
author: Jenn K.

description:
We went here for my birthday dinner and I loved it alot. We had:

Bottle of Prosecco
Oysters - 5 stars (very very fresh, one of the best i've had)
Sea Urchin - 5 stars (delicious and different)
Petrole Sole - 5 stars (seasoned well, very fresh)
Lobster roll - 3.5 stars (it was ok, but nothing too exciting)
Chocolate cake with salted pistacio toffee - 5 stars (delicious, moist cake and the salted pistacio toffee was very unique)

The interior was very creative. It was interesting. Staff was quick and attentive. I will definitely go back again.
author: Cat B.

description:
Brought a friend here visiting from out-of-town cuz he loves seafood.

Trendy decor -- not too fancy but not shabby by any means.  Nice but casual.

Had their vegetarian dish, and wow, it was so unique!  I almost never get the main vegetarian entree cuz it's usually a bunch of veggies covered in butter for a price equivalent to a piece of gourmet meat, but this one was definitely worth it!  I can't remember exactly what it was called, but it was these crispy dough-type strands tossed with veggies and a green puree -- soooooooooooooooooo good!  not too greasy either.

My friend had their oysters -- very fresh.  And he had their halibut, I believe -- said it was quite tasty.

Bill was rather pricey, but overall very good.
author: Latef X.

description:
We were fortunate enough to visit Anchor & Hope on opening night.  I was mildly concerned that they would not have hit their stride, but other than a few opening night jitters, they exceeded our expectations.  

The decor was New England fish house / Industrial chic, but was comfortable for a two hour dinner.  The wait staff was exceptional in knowledge of the offerings, as well as the perfectly timed arrival of refills on wine, water and bread.  We did lose our waiter for a moment, but others were quick to cover his absence.  

We tended toward a compliment of appetizers which included the "Fries with Eyes" (just had to try them because of the name - but wouldn't do it again.  Curiosity killed the cat, and now we know why.)  We also had the Salmon Gravlax which was very good, and the Warm Sea Urchin which was amazing.  Most have probably never tried sea urchin, but don't be afraid - it's really good.  We also had the Sea Scallops with raisins which was also very good.  Temperature of the food was perfect and presentation was simple but elegant.

All in all, I'd give Anchor and Hope a two thumbs up for it's inaugural night.  I'd recommend it for a casual and enjoyable night with no pretense.
author: Nicole D.

description: The squash, bacon wrapped oysters and steak was all very tasty.  The bar staff is very professional.  Great spot and intend to go back again and again.
author: Dom P.

description:
We sat at the counter (or was that a bar? I'm not sure) for late night champagne and oysters and it was PERFECT. Except for, I guess, discovering that we both hate oysters..but we went for the experience so it was totally worth it. 

I'm holding out on the 5th star because I only ate one oyster (an angel on horseback, specifically -- I thought it would be an easy way to dip my toe in the pool of oyster eating...but FYI, wrapping oysters in bacon and deep frying them doesn't make them taste any less awful), but the service and the ambiance = 4 stars.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Before I write my review I'd like to point out that my wife and I have both been to Anchor & Hope in the past, have returned multiple times and have recommended other people to this restaurant. However, we recently had a HORRIBLE experience that is makes us question the quality of this restaurant and its employees.

We visited Anchor & Hope on Saturday, August 18th to complete a day of activities celebrating my wife's baby shower. We had a number of out-of-town guests and thought it would be nice to finish off the evening at Anchor and Hope since my wife and I have both had wonderful experiences at the restaurant. Our server for the evening was Ryan (if you ever get him, request for another server). To make a long story short the service was so bad because, plain and simple, we were ignored. When we sat down, our waiter Ryan promptly came over to take our drink order. When the drinks came, we asked that we needed a few more minutes to look at the menu. That was probably the last time that Ryan voluntarily came over to our table. 

Our meals came extremely late -- Grant it the restaurant was busy because it was a Saturday so it's understandable that things may lag. However, I don't think it should take 30 - 40 minutes. We even had to call Ryan over once again to ask him what was going on with our order. This is a good time to note that in the 30 - 40 minute wait, Ryan did not come over to our table one to ask if our drinks needed to be refilled or to apologize for the delay.

Rude service -- Again, we've received some very bad service in the past but this past  experience with Anchor & Hope was by far the worst dining experience that we've ever had. After dinner, we called the general manager to let her know how poor the service was. She was very helpful to try and smooth things over by offering to comp our drinks and dessert. However by this time, all we wanted to do was pay the check and leave. After the general manager delivered the check, we reviewed the bill and placed the bill with credit card and cash at the corner of the table for Ryan to pick up and close the table. Ryan walked by us a number of times  without picking up the check. One of our guests actually stood up and tried to hand him the bill with cash and credit card but Ryan blatantly turned around and ignored her. I then had to go back to the general manager to at the bar to close out the check.

I spoke with a couple of the managers a few days later. They said that disciplinary action will be taken and that I am suppose to receive a follow up email. It's been a few days now and I have not heard back from them. I sincerely hope that this issue isn't swept under the rug.

It is important to note that Ryan did not once come back to our table to apologize for any of the above mentioned. We have received some bad service in the past but  the experience with Ryan at Anchor & Hope takes the cake for the worst service ever and it really makes us question about ever returning to what was once one of our favorite restaurants.
author: Arvi R.

description: great place for fresh and high quality seafood, before i came here i did not have the most adventurous palet, now i am head over heels in love with seafood, would come back for sure!
author: Mike P.

description:
We went to A&H after a very disappointing hour at RN74, and it saved our evening. I really, really like the food at this place. Between the two of us, we had 6 apps for our dinner, and LOVED all of em. The service within the restaurant is a little inconsistent - a couple of the staff are fabulous while others seemed a little challenged/confused, though everyone was very friendly. Love the wine and beer list - extensive and unique. 
There were some babies screaming when we were there, which is a bit of a drag - it is casual and big enough that kids could easily factor into the mix at times, fyi. Fabulous food and drink though - MUCH better than SaltHouse.
author: Ellen H.

description: I had a great experience at this restaurant - service, food, atmosphere and wine. They have a HUGE selection of oysters which were all fabulous (one drawback, they don't have a full bar...a martini would have been perfect with the oysters).  That said, the wine list is great, many excellent choices at a variety of prices. We finished off a bottle of wine we enjoyed and tried to order a second bottle and they were out of it, the manager of the restaurant came by and made a recommendation for another wine that was even better.  The heirloom beet salad with hazelnuts was so good as were the other starters we tried and shared. I had the blackened sea bass and it was perfectly prepared. Very cool atmosphere - It is located in a renovated warehouse with exposed brick walls, high ceilings and modern decor that give it a loft-y feel.  Look forward to my next visit to try more items on the menu.
author: Vicki A.

description:
Food was just ok. I ordered 4 appetisers  and only 1 was yummy (Celery-Apple soup with truffles) The others were so-so
Service should be better for a $$$ place. They took 15 mins to get our drinks.

Great selection of Beer, except I don't care for beer.
author: Insi L.

description:
I saw this place on "Best Things I Ever Ate". When they featured their Warm Sea Urchin and Dungeness Crab and knew that I had to come here someday to try out their food. I took my girlfriend here for dinner at the end of Oct for our anniversary. The food was really good and exceeded my expectations. We got a few appetizers because we wanted to try a little bit of everything. The Aki Poke here rocks.. their sauce on the side just won me over. I forgot what was in it but the only word that comes to mind is "volcano sauce".. not sure why. it was a nice creamy, spicy orange/pink sauce that just made the tuna taste soo much better! The "Angels on horseback" was great. I've never really tried oysters with bacon so that was a new taste. Surprisingly enough.. oysters taste pretty damm good with bacon! The warm sea urchin & dungeness crab was milky, warm and very tasty. When the Food Network said "filled with envy" they weren't lying. I wanted more! 

For our entrées I had the grilled rib eye with the yukon potatoes cooked in duck fat.. it was YUMMIE! I ate the steak the way it was. I didn't need any tpye of BBQ sauce or anything. The potatoes threw me off. I was expecting one big potato but it was 3 smaller potatoes that were super flavorful and crispy on the outside and mushy on the inside. I loved it.
My girlfriend got the small sea food platter.. it looked real good and she enjoyed it. Each of the oysters that were on the dish were all different. she said each had a different flavor and she loved it. The prawns that came with it were HUGE. It took 2 or 3 bites each prawn. 

Well worth the money and what a great experience!
author: Johnny T.

description: Took a client here for lunch in April.  Good food and competent service.
author: Daryl G.

description: This restaurant is one of the better seafood places around. Dollar per oyster during happy hour is always a good deal. The chowder is delicious, big chunks of fresh clam floating in creamy goodness. The warm uni and crab is divine. The lobster roll is also pretty good, it is served cold with slaw and chips. The service here is lacking though. The server was MIA for a good 10-15 minutes after we sat down. We weren't checked on nor was our water refilled. Suffice to say that we felt we were forgotten at times. Other than that I think the seafood done here is pretty good.
author: Stanley C.

description:
Even though I live in New England, I tried the beer (Smithwicks!) battered cod. It was awesome. As were the oysters. And the Waitress.
And the bread. Yes. It's pricey! Sheesh, but these places can be fun, especially on off nights, like during 4th of July weekend when we had a blast there eating and drinking fun beers--the Allagash, from New England!, was great on tap.
author: mickey l.

description:
It's pretty pricey, but so worth it.  The fish is fresh and unpretentiously prepared.   The wine list is great, as are all the oysters!!  They usually offer 6 kinds -- 3 from the east coast and 3 from the west coast -- so it's a great chance to taste and compare.  My favorite thing is to order one of each!  

The atmosphere is fun and relaxed, with its wide open space and super friendly staff.  I've been there on dates for two as well as with large groups, and it's been fun every time.  I definitely recommend this San Francisco gem.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Impressed with the seafood quality and great service on each of my visits.   Casual and classy with in a great old building.
author: Jeff A.

description: Not sure what all the fuss is about.  Portions were smallish, the seafood platter at $55 was a big disappointment, although the oysters were nice and fresh.  It's MUCH MUCH too noisy, and the service was rather perfunctory.  I got the feeling of a corporate restaurant, instead of something special calling San Francisco home.  Banana cream pie was not pie at all - so sad.  Just a banana creme pudding.  Meh is right.  Wouldn't go back in a hurry unless someone else was paying!
author: R.B. W.

description:
We had a great dinner here last night.  Consensus from the group is that Town Hall is still their best effort but this one comes in a pretty close second.... obviously very different, but you know what I mean.
