Great service (love the aprons), fun atmosphere, good wine (try the gewertz) and we all enjoyed our food.  Sampled a bite of the sea urchin app-- do it my way and get someone else to order it so you don't have to commit but get to taste!  Crab salad was really good and the monkfish stew was just good.  I left happy and would go back again soon, so 4 stars!
author: Mara H.

description:
A friend told me that this was one of the new best restaurants in town and that she want to try it.  So, we went.  The staff was really great.  The waitress was the one I want every time I go out.  She was just amazing and made it a great experience.
They bring bread in a brown bag and just drop it on your table, which was very weird.   The Heirloom Tomato and yellow watermelon appetizer was very good.  I ordered the sole, which was nice but I found it a bit too fatty because of the sauce.  The seats were super uncomfortable.  Sitting on a bench for hours was not fun.
author: Ayelet B.

description:
Lively energy. Unbelievable beer list.

Very solid food. A bit pricey but you knew that before you walked in didn't you?

Catfish sandwich with the fried tomato is my favorite item. I go for lunch and sit at the bar.
author: Gary G.

description:
I had heard good things about this place and its so close to me, I don't know why it took me so long to check it out!

It was a quiet Sunday night when we were there and not sure if that was part of the reason why I felt a sort of lack of atmosphere about the place.
The space is cool, and it really has a nice rustic feel to it, like a great fish restaurant you'd see in Seattle, but the ultra high ceilings gave the place a drafty feeling, sort of lacking in warmth.
I couldn't quite put my finger on it, but I think I was just expecting something more cozy and intimate and the minute we sat down I felt like I was at a chain restaurant.

I would have really liked to try the oysters, but we decided to dive into apps and entres.
I asked our waiter about the sliced Kampachi...and he said they were very good.

When they came, we tried and we were a bit unimpressed.

For entres, I ordered the Lobster roll which was very fresh and very good....just a lot of bread.  I must say the coleslaw on the side really hit the spot.

He ordered the Ahi and that was delicious as well.

I am certain there are very good apps and I"m curious to try the oysters.  I was just a little unimpressed at my first experience there.

It may have been partly because I was so hungry and the entres seriously took forever!  (I guess they kill the fish right before its served!)

I would definitely try this place again, but am not in a huge rush.
author: Ahnee M.

description:
I feel a little bit sheepish giving this place only three stars after I had a great night there, but I'll explain in a minute.  Let's start with the good stuff.    The clam chowder is straight up buttery and creamy and super delicious.  The beet salad was wonderful, and the lobster roll was yummy.  

That said, I really thought the menu did not have enough variety on it, so unless they plan on changing it up frequently, I would get bored if I came here again.  Also, the prices seemed a little bit steep for what we got.  I mean, I have no problem dropping some serious coin to eat, but I would be more forgiving if the prices were a shave lower.
author: Julie B.

description:
I've been twice and think it's just getting better.  The first time we went it had been open only 3 weeks.  Service was fine and the food was good, although they screwed up our bill a little.  I ordered one of the white wines and the waiter suggested I try it first so poured me a small sample.  He was right...it wasn't what I had expected so I switched to something else.  Had the Lobster Roll which was good, but not as good as the price indicated.  Friend had the monk fish and chorizo stew which was spicy and tasty!

Second time we had a larger group and we all had terrific meals.  I can't recall anyone having anything that was sub-par.  I can't recall exactly what everyone had, but clearly remembering everyone walking out satisfied.  I will return for meal #3.
author: Todd S.

description:
Great location and feel from the folks that have brought us Salt House & Town Hall!  It's a nice addition to the resturant "empire" they are building.  It's been unusually warm for the past week, so their building for lunch can get quite hot.

Their chowder soup is quite tasty...not too heavy, and the addition of sweet corn is a nice treat.  Presentation was also a surprise with the corn & clams arranged nicely in the empty bowl, and the broth poured over tableside.  Nice touch.

The lobster roll is apparently their most requested so I had to try.  The lobster was quite plentyful, but overall nothing to get too excited about...I'll probably order something else next time.

Great place for lunch, would be interested to see what their dinner crowd is like...
author: Vince B.

description:
We were recommended to this place by the Hilton concierge. We arrived and the only table available was right by the door. To their credit, they seated us and then allowed us to move when another table was available.

The bread was good. We ordered, and shortly thereafter were told that they were out of steak (at 7:30PM on a Saturday night). The entree menu is very limited. We tried the "little gem salad", not little, but with a strange dressing and the clam chowder-very thin, a few potatoes, and a strong bacon flavor. We tried the lobster roll (tasty, but lots of bread), the peppercrusted ahi (average), the fish and chips and swordfish with curried cous cous (bad). The fish and chips was the highlight (think chips). The dessert menu was uninspired.

The wait was polite and attentive, but the food came out very slowly.

Overall 1 star.
author: Stan S.

description:
A friend and I stopped into Anchor & Hope for lunch on a Friday afternoon, and I must say that they have a great lunch menu. There are options for everyone including some seafood and some non-seafood (burgers, salads) options. 

I opted for a burger and it was actually very well made for a restaurant that obviously specializes in seafood. My friend ordered the mussels which arrived in a gigantic heap (and were the largest mussels I've ever seen) and were accompanied by really nice looking super thin fries. The portions were generous, and I guess that's a good thing considering that this place is kind of pricey for what it is, but it was not bad at all.

The decor was very lovely, somewhat nautical-themed, and the space was really bright and cheerful during the day - I am sure it would be super cozy at night. The waiter that served us was a bit sassy for my taste, but service was good and fast. 

Overall, a good place to grab a nice sit down lunch and I think it's a big plus that they have a variety of options, even during weekdays.
author: Justin S.

description:
Two words: Dee-LICIOUS. Just kidding... That's actually three words.

Anyway, the food was fabulous and the service just as good. I showed up with 2 people at 6:30 on a Wednesday night and it was packed, but they made every effort to squeeze us into a table. The crab bisque was deadly good and the chocolate cake was positively sinful. I feel like I should go to confession -- and I'm not Catholic. I also had the lobster pot pie which was yum yummy, but not worth the $32 price tag, simply because there wasn't much food on my plate.

I gave it 4 instead of 5 stars for two reasons:

1. A little over-priced in my opinion -- but that's only because I'm cheap.

2. The acoustics in this place are HORRIFIC. It was so loud that I started getting a headache toward the end of the night. And I could hear the entire conversation of the people 2 tables away, but couldn't hear a word my date was saying. Go figure.
author: Kerra H.

description:
Felt my lunch was really overpriced for what it was - fish and chips for $22.50. It was two pieces of fried cod (standard) and normal french fries. For that much money at least spice up the fries a bit with something and provide three pieces of fish.  The beers were expensive too, but at least they delivered.

Ambience and service was good, but I won't be going back anytime soon to overpay for a lackluster meal.
author: Matt H.

description:
Always looking for the next great meal I happened upon Hope & Anchor over on Minna street...hardly in the main line...and had an early dinner with a buddy and his girlfriend. I hadn't done any research and was only expecting a good meal. I'd seen some press leading up to the opening but it dropped off my radar until early this week.

Arriving I found an nice open space and given the decor was given notice that this was seafood and they seemed serious about it. A chalkboard near the door listed the oysters and shellfish for the day. My friends were already seated and we got down to the business of menus. The very first item on the menu was teh Anchor & Hope Chowder with white corn and little neck clams. My bar for chowder is Hog Island's Clam Chowder. This particular variant was rather sweet with just a few clams. In short, all chowder, few clams. Nice taste but all broth. Ahh...too bad.

Entrees were next. I'd ordered the bass. My friends went with the Lobster roll and the special of the day - soft shell crabs. My bass was fine...flaky and cooked well but little taste. The comments from the other side of the table were to the effect that rather than serving east coast fish the chefs should stay local. I'd agree. It was all "fine" but nothing near inspired.

The chocolate cake for dessert was lovely and the wines-by-the-glass selection was pretty good. All in all an OK night but there are too many great places for me to want to come back here any time soon.

3 stars.
author: Gary C.

description: THE most delicious trout I have ever tasted in my life!!  The service was excellent.  Our service was on top of everything and made excellent suggestions to us based upon our tastes we described.  I am burning with anticipation to go back and sample some oysters!
author: Misstoo B.

description:
I had high expectations.  

The space is stunning and the nautical theme is well executed.

The service was the most disappointing thing about the meal.  It wasn't that it wasn't friendly, it was that  they weren't attentive.  The restaurant was slow when we first got seated, but all of the waiters and busboys were so busy with their tasks that no one filled our water glasses and we had to hail someone down.  We also had to hail down our waitress to take our order and wait a fair amount of time for our wine and the food came out slowly as well.

The food was good--the lobster roll was very good--great slaw and chips to boot--but nothing that was earth-shattering.  The crab and parsnip bisque was a bit too much like a gallon of light cream.  

I'd expect more....too bad.
author: Caren H.

description: Food Network's Best Thing I Ever Ate featured Angels On Horseback, so that's what locked me in.  The ambience was great, high ceilings, cool decor nice bar area.  The bacon wrapped oysters were not the best I ever ate but pretty damn good.  The sea urchin and asparagus salad were interesting as well.  If you're a seafood person who likes interesting dishes, then go here.
author: Karen A.

description:
Meh....that is about the extent of it.  It wasnt what I expected from a food perspective.  It was what I expected of the decor- except louder.  I would imagine it would be a decent place for a large, loud group.  

The website says East Coast style...not sure exactly where on the East Coast but it isnt New England style (which was what I expected).  The lobster roll was very frou frou...the chowder was a very thin broth.  I started with the stuffed clams, which tasted fresh but was a very dull dish.  My boyfriend had the chowder, again broth was very thin and the flavor was meh...not bad.  I had the mussel and monkfish spicy stew..which was good and spicy but could have used more broth and a bigger bowl...it was hard to get to the different ingredients in the tiny bowl.   My guy had the sea bass and said it was very tasty but the portion size was for a mouse (his words).  The bread was yummy..I think they make it themselves and the desserts were nothing special so I was not even tempted.  The service was attentive and good.

And this may just be me, but an 8:30 sat night reservation at a restaurant where you will be spending at least $150 for 2; I dont expect  a baby to sitting on the patrons lap next to me fussing and crying for most of our dinner.  

Overall, I dont think I would go back...unless with said large and loud group.
author: M B.

description: If you love seafood, this is a good place to go.  The sea urchin soup was phenomenal and the oysters were great.  The lobster roll was everything I dreamt it would be and the truffle fries are awesome!!!
author: Norm P.

description: Absolutely loved this restaurant! A great find since its literally around the corner for us. We ordered the chowder which was delicious and then we ordered the idaho trout with creamed corn & my husband ordered the lobster roll. My  husband didnt completely love the lobster roll but i think it was more due to the fact that he thought it would be hot rather than cold. The trout was incredibly delicious. The pairing of the flavors were exceptional...the only downside was that the first mouthfull was full of bones. I think the chefs got a bit lazy on my fillet as the couple next to us ordered the trout and didnt have one bone. The waitress and Maitre D quickly came to check on me & comp'd the meal. All in all the food was delicious, the service prompt and attentive and we will definitely be back!
author: Nicole E.

description: I went here on the recommendation from a friend and was quite pleased. The selection of seafood was fresh and expertly prepared. The beer list is awesome, and the wine list was nice too. We had the small platter of fresh shellfish with oysters, clams, shrimp, and lobster & crab to start. The waitress said we could customize it to our taste if we wished but we stuck w/ the standard offering and were happy.The scallops small plate was the best dish of the night. The salmon main was also very good. I met a friend who I hadn't seen in months and the waitstaff was very good about letting us catch up. The price is typical of SF seafood. Check it out- recommended.
author: Becky E.

description:
Love seafood but didn't love this place. Went on the company card so costs weren't and issue, but flavors left something to be desired.

Had oysters to start which were great, but c'mon lets face it, how can you screw those up if their fresh. We ordered a bunch of appetizers to share and they all ranged from just OK to downright bad:

Bacon wrapped oysters: Terribly fishy. I love bacon and I love oysters, but the combo didnt work.

Octopus: Sauce they were in must have burned as they sauteed because they had a terrible burnt flavor

Dungeness Crab salad: Pretty straight forward. Crab was fresh but portion was small.

Chowder: Meh.

The best part of the place is the ambiance - What a great space. Service was also good but in the end the food has to be there. Couldnt believe how crowded it was!
author: Big P.

description:
We had a horrible experience here last night on 3/21/12. We were there with a client He had barely finished his first glass of wine, when he decided to look at the wine list and order a 2nd bottle. It was at this time that he noticed that the wine menu had a derogatory term on it. He immediately asked to see the manager to point out the term and request that in the near future it should be changed by the owner because it could be construed as offensive. When the manager on duty, who was very very young, came to our table she thought the ordeal was funny.  She just kept smirking and made lite of what he was saying, which of course angered our client because she did not take his request seriously.  All she had to do was to tell him, thank you for pointing this out and I will let the owner know.  But instead she continued to disrespect him in front of the entire table.  She then refused to serve us wine and then walked away. I would be very very careful about bringing clients to this restaurant since they don't understand the concept of the customer is always right.  Since we still hadn't received our meal, and our client was incensed, we thought it best to leave and find another restaurant to eat dinner at.   

We did walk down the street to Umbria. The owner of this restaurant was delightful and very service oriented. My client walked away feeling satisfied with both the meal, the wine and the service.
author: Kyra I.

description:
Very good stuff. Great open space covering a much needed territory down in this area - good seafood.  We went opening day for lunch and my group of 5 were all very satisfied.

First off the place has got a great casual harbor theme but with a nice upscale flair to it.  Hard balance to execute but done very well.

Food was very good.  Shrimp Cocktail had a nice portion of firm,sweet shrimp.  Amazingly clean taste and texture. 

My mussels were presented beautifully with a nice broth.  Everyone at the table seemed happy with their choices.  Nice little touches like bread being put on the table in a paper bag.  Desserts were solid.

I will be back!
author: Stephen L.

description: Have usuallly sat at the bar which is a good place to share a few things.  Serice at the bar has been very good.  Very broad beer selection.  Menu is a little limited and food is not outstanding but it is definitey above average.  Have enjoyed halibut etc.  Ambiance is excellent as they have a very interesting building, ala restored warehouse.  Location is a bit challenged for a late dinner.
author: Glenn S.

description:
Had dinner here saturday night for a table of 8-- they seated us promptly and gave us a great table. We ordered a bunch of dishes (Angels on Horseback, sea urchin, calamari, and a few others).  I ordered the sole as my entree- and it was incredible-- the lemond rind and almonds combined with the tender sole was a beatiful medley of tastes and textures.  Standout dessert was the caramel bread pudding, so good. 

This was definitely an expensive meal for a big group dinner, but the ambiance and food was spot on for a big night out.  Location is perfect for a dinner before heading over to Harlot.
author: Sonia S.

description:
happy hour review - 
bitchy hostess, but lovely waitstaff. 
friday - 5 o clock. we were scared the place would be packed but it really wasn't. place was empty except for the bar.

we asked the hostess if happy hour was only at the bar and she said it was. it was three of us girls and there were only two seats spaced apart so we stood there just kinda waiting. a waitress came by and told us we could ask the hostess for a table for hh. THANKS FOR GIVING US THAT OPTION, HOSTESS! -.- we ask her, and she says that she needs to check. ummmm.... hello..... THE PLACE IS EMPTY! what do you mean check? while she went to "check" we looked at the tables and reservation list. nothing there. wtf?

she came back to say that we could but we would have to be out by 6:30. fine. whatever. 

2 dozen dollar pearl point oysters, with lemon, vinegar? and marinara + horseradish. + smoked trout deviled eggs, fries, and neptune fries. 

the neptune fries were a complete disappointment. it seemed, on the menu, that they would be clams with chorizo and cheese. instead, it was 5 clams on top of their regular french fries, with chorizo cheese sauce. -.- it was more like a seafood poutine. 

anyways, oysters were fresh, and tasted of the ocean. very good. french fries were nice, except the aioli was too thick for my taste. it really just tasted like garlic mayo. most places make it thinner so you don't feel as guilty even though you know exactly what it is. deviled eggs tasted of breakfast - smoked fish + eggs. how could you go wrong? 

also got the ace pear cider for 5 bucks. not too shabby and tasted really nice. 

3 ppl for 60 bucks (including 2 drinks and excluding tax). a pretty great way to spend a friday night after a boring week at work. :)
author: Melissa C.

description:
Went here last night with some co-workers to put drinks on the Reuters guy's tab. The beer selection was awsome with all sorts of gnarly named beers. they only carry beer and wine so if you are looking for a cocktail i would suggest changing your mind and trying out a bunch of 9% alch beers you've never heard of instead. 

Reuters also got us every single appetizer on the menu (X2). pretty much everything was interesting and tasty in its own way from the platter of oysters to the mashed potato and urchin combo, put in an actual urchin shell (watch your eyes!) 

it was a lively place and we were all pretty toasted after a bunch of drinks. good place if you like beer, wine, and seafood. bad if your looking for cocktails and land animals to eat.
author: brian m.

description:
I think the tipper on this one was the price.

I came here with my uncle and his friend.  They start you off with a baguette that's pretty good: crispy on the outside, and really soft on the inside.

We started with clam chowder, some fried calamari, and a dozen raw oysters.  The appetizers were far better than the main course and dessert.  I didn't try the clam chowder-- but the fried calamari was good.  I think they have some lemon zest in the batter which gives it a fresh taste, and it comes with a sweet and spicy sauce that I think is balsamic vinegar, grilled onions and hot peppers.  The raw oysters on their own were good, and they came with a house seafood sauce that's not as tart as the usual stuff, as well as black peppercorn in oil.

They do put together some interesting combinations of flavors, but I didn't like them that much.  My uncle had scallops on couscous-- you get three large scallops, and they pour a buttery curry sauce overtop.  Tastes new, but not that great.  I had a brook trout with a light mustard sauce on some beans, and I didn't like that combination.  The beans weren't soaked for too long so they still had that grainy taste, and the brook trout wasn't anything special.  So it's not terrible, but I think it would taste better if it could be made more moist.

Dessert was this chocolate mousse thing with peanut butter cookies.  Not that tasty.  The peanut butter cookies were all right, but they're just peanut butter cookies-- they made them there but I think out-of-the-box ones taste about the same.  And either the mousse or the caramel sauce had something strange going on there... some metallic taste.

I think dinner came out to $170 or so for the three of us.
author: Kenneth L.

description:
Anchor & Hope was pretty awesome, I gotta say. Took the girlfriend here for her birthday a few weeks back, and it definitely was memorable. We had a 10pm reservation on a Friday and the place had already reached it's peak it seemed, but it was still about half full and there was a noticeable hustle & bustle.

The ambience here is incredible---almost like being in a house on a dock or something.  It's a wonderfully huge & airy space, so I can imagine it being great for groups.  

The food is top notch. We got a variety of oysters and they all were unbelievably fresh & mouthwatering. Some distinct undercurrent of flavors that made each kind pretty distinct. The sea urchin appetizer was FANTASTIC, not to mention that it was presented in a badass way (sea urchin, fresh crab, and mashed potatoes served up in a spicy sea urchin shell). The fresh crab claw was fun too (although wow... had to default to the GF to crack it open after my part went flying across the floor and under the table next to us). Oh and dessert fiends, the butterscotch dessert was damn good too.

The bacon wrapped oysters (aka Angels On Horseback), however, were disappointing. That was the dish that was raved about recently on the 7x7 100 Things To Eat In SF Before You Die list so based on some of the other things on there I was familiar with, I had very high expectations for this one. The bacon was flavorful enough, but the cooked oyster had an extreme flavor that overpowered everything too quickly. Good idea, but I think they should go back to the drawing board to get the flavor right. Also, the raw Kampachi appetizer was just good, but not exceptional.

It is worth noting that the service was EXCEPTIONAL. Our waitress not only knew everything about every kind of oyster on the menu, and when I asked her to describe each of the three Rieslings on the wine menu so I could order the sweetest one like my girl likes it, the bottle we chose showed she nailed her description right on the head. Also--the manager apparently thought the restaurant was taking too long to get us going on our food (we didn't notice anything out of the ordinary though), so he came over and told us he would be comping the entire oyster assortment. In fact, we were just ordering a few initially, so he really hooked it up big time. Fucking awesome and it really felt great to be taken care of like this from two people at the same restaurant.

Excited to try some of the entrees on the next go around, and oh yes, there definitely will be another go around. Definitely add Anchor & Hope to your list of SF restaurants to get down with.
author: George C.

description:
If I am offered one more heirloom tomato salad, I just might scream!!!

Not that I have any issues with Regular Tomato's juicier, chubbier, uglier cousin, but by the end of Heirloom Tommy season, I'm ready for some different vegetarian options when I go out to eat.

This being said, I still opted for A&H's heirloom salad with melon and pepper vinaigrette -- I'm certainly not going to be the non-fish eater complaining about the lack of veg. options at a seafood restaurant.  The salad was absolutely amazing, paired with a delicious pilsner that seemed to keep refilling itself.

The service was impeccable: friendly, prompt, knowledgeable.  Our waitress was just chatty and sassy enough while giving us some alone time to be romantic (aka stuff our faces and pound our beers, as we were running late for a myopenbar event).

A&H, you have helped Heirloom Tomatoes recapture my fickle, vegetable loving heart.
author: Abby M.

description:
Disappointed because of all the buzz around the opening of this new restaurant, but I might go back after a few months. They have to work out a few glitches. 

The oysters were good (we had 6 pieces). The seared sea scallops were OK, not great ($24). My friend had the Portuguese clam style stew which had a few mussels, several were closed leaving him with only 2 opened mussels, not a good value for $21. The broth, however, was delicious. 

The French fries were utterly revolting: thick, mushy, soaked in oil, tasteless. I took one bite, called the waitress and sent them back to the kitchen. The dinner went downhill from there.

For dessert we had the strawberry rhubarb crumble which was average. I can make a better version of this at home. 

Total bill $70 (without wine because they did not have a liquor license yet). 

The crowd: older, boring. I expected a younger, hipper crowd. 

Music: ghastly and unbearable -- Johnny Cash, bluegrass. They should get a good DJ or put on some cool tunes.  

Decor: "ocean" theme meets industrial chic meets Gulliver's Island + tiki bar. Ridiculous.
author: Esme V.

description:
Had dinner here with a girlfriend on a Saturday night for some apps and drinks at the bar.

The drink menu:  Fantasic artisan beers.  

Atmosphere:  great high ceilings, nice vibe.

Food:  Oysters -- were just OK and not much to rave about.  I'd stick with oysters at Wayfare Tavern, Swan Oyster Depot or even Hog Island.  

Fries-- FANTASTIC and delightfully seasoned to perfection!  If I do go back to the restaurant, it's for a beer and fries.

Gravlax Sald - The presentation looked beautiful and the horseradish creme fraiche on top of the salad was good.    However the overall salad was just mediocore and I'd skip it next time.

Tuna Poke special --- SKIP this dish..  Tuna was a bit grainy for my taste, a bit too chunky and the wonton chips were wilting.

Salmon Tartare -- If you like avacados, then this dish is for you.  

Fried Artichokes -- Great app there mainly due to the spicy mayo sauce.

Conclusion:  Great place for beers and fries.  The service was good and the bartender was very helpful in selecting beers that fit the food.  First impression wasn't so great but I'll try it again because I like the atmosphere.
author: VIOLA L.

description:
OMG!  great.  food, service, atmo was all perfect......  def a real's winn'r.

:)

P
author: Pammy S.

description: the ambiance was very nice. it was packed on a monday night with people waiting for tables. bar was buzzing and had a pretty good selection. the clam chowder was good but too thin for my liking. my lobster roll was good but i prefer the one at old port lobster shack in redwood city.
author: Loan H.

description:
We liked the atmosphere and decor -- you feel like being on an old wooden boat. The service was also good and attentive. 

There were a couple of dishes that really didn't work for us though: 
- The squid dish was very salty and tasted like whatever was burned  the grill before it. 
- Blackened hamachi was served with such a spicy sauce that it completely killed any taste that the fish had. Not a good combo.

The place had good vibe to it and was full with people, so perhaps there are other dishes worth trying in there, but we'll opt for other places in the future.
author: Y Z.

description:
EXCELLENT SERVICE!!! From the hostess to the waitress to the floater guy.... they were all genuinely nice!

DECOR & STUFF: I thought that their decor was very "anchor and hope-ish"  I loved the paintings of the fishies over the bar. I couldn't get over the "purse hook" that you could request for your table. It's the best idea ever!

BEER: pages of selection

SHIRLEY TEMPLE:  it was $4, but so delicious!

ANGELS on HORSEBACK (bacon wrapped oysters):  My bf thought that it was very tasty. presentation was great, and pretty much everyone around us ordered this appetizer.

DUCK:  Unfortunately I am not a seafood person, so I had to go with the duck. It was very disappointing to me- It seemed overcooked and dry to me. There was also a red sauce that I couldn't eat. The sausages, carrots and garlic beans were delicious though, so I just ate around the duck. haha

BATTERED COD & WEDGES: It was pretty yummy, but pricey for some upscale fish n chips

BUTTERSCOTCH CREME BRULEE: Delicious!!!! One of the best creme brulees I have ever tasted!

PRICE:  A bit on the high end, but I was blessed with a giftcard, so no complaints. Overall the 2 of us spent a lil over $100 after gratuity

SUCKY PART:  they have pictures of yummy scallops on their website, but it's "seasonal" and was not available that night.
author: sophia l.

description:
A somewhat tough reservation to get, this place still has a buzz about it because it opened only a few months ago.

The same guys who brought you Salt House and Town Hall are responsible for Anchor and Hope and they seem to have a winning recipe for all three places: good food, casual and fun atmosphere, and eardrum-splitting noise levels.

The restaurant occupies a nice space, it's airy and the decor is fun.  Feels like I just went fishing but didn't do any work.

Seafood is king here and you won't be disappointed by their menu.
Fresh oyster selection, you can taste the sea.
Terrific sea urchin in the shell appetizer.
Decadent lobster roll, loved the home-made potato chips.
Get the fresh fish of the day, you won't go wrong.

Service is friendly and attentive.
Best of all, my ears weren't ringing when we left the restaurant!
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
Service= fantastic! very friendly and informative

Food=Angels on Horseback did not make my as happy as I had wished they would after reading everyone rave reviews.  I loved the heirloom tomato salad and the the sea urchin in the shell... very tasty.

Atmoshere= open airy at bit noisey....but overall I loved the design.

Homo factor= We were the only dyke customers in the restaurant but  felt very welcome.

Price=Average

Hostess=Both hostesses were very friendly.

Bathroom= clean
author: Annmarie K.

description: one of those fancier places where the seafood is "dressed up" thus the flavor itself masked by all the other added flavors, albeit the guaranteed good stuff like butter and bacon.  so angels on horseback (bacon wrapped oysters) well the oysters are lost in the bacon.  for the lobster roll, it was very buttery (good soft bread with ok amount of lobster) but I actually ended up preferring the shrimp po boy which had large pieces of breaded shrimp and the remoulade was good with a mild kick.
author: Rob C.

description:
Yum!  Simple perfection!  The whole experience was great - our server was chill but attentive, the ambiance was sophisticated but relaxed, the beer list was stocked and there were few, if any, poor wine selections.  Oh, and the food was delicious.  We ordered:

Smoked bacon wrapped oysters w/ remoulade sauce (my date was not an oyster fan): FANTASTIC.  The oysters melted in your mouth and were complimented by the fabulous remoulade sauce.  Great baby step for someone who finds oysters' texture to be unnerving.

Halibut w/ fresh veggies: date's dinner, the halibut was complimented by a very delicious (and generous) sauce and the snow peas, asparagus, etc. were arguably the most perfectly cooked veggies I've ever had.  

I had the trout on special, but it's been about two weeks and I can't remember all the details, just that it was GOOD.

Panna cotta with raspberries was divine.  Panna cotta was creamy and mild, and the raspberry liqueur they poured over it at serving was full-flavored and sweet.

I loved this place.  Perfect date night without being awkwardly romantic.  Would recommend to anyone (including strangers, obviously)
author: Ashley C.

description: I had the most amazing black pepper seared ahi here and oddly, I don't care for fish much but since that's there thing. The sauce was flavorful but didn't overpower, which is probably why I don't eat much fish. Okay so it was the best fish I ever had and the dessert was sooo yummy but I forget what it was
author: First L.

description: I've always had great experiences here, dined about 5 times total and never had anything bad. The building is great, ambiance is nice, service is great, food is wonderful. I particularly love the fish and chips, and have a hard time ordering anything else cos it's so delish.
author: crystala t.

description: Very mediocre.  The lobster roll was terrible but liked the homemade chips.
author: John K.

description: Angel on Horseback is delicious.  The uni dish is also creamy and terrific.
author: Jim J.

description: This place is pretty good for lunch.  And some of the best fish and chips i've had in a while.  We also had the fried pickles, which were peculiarly good.  The french fries are chippy and thin.  I may go for an after work dinner again, but not a place i'm absolutely dying to go back to.
author: Ronjini M.

description: 2.5 stars... Anchor and Hope was fine. Overpriced for what you got - even taking SF into consideration. Service was good. Wine and beer was good though not inexpensive. The ambiance is cool. Nice decor. My husband in jeans was probably the only man in the whole restaurant not wearing a suit. I guess that's because it's downtown and we went on a Thursday night. I like the Old Bay chips to start. Husband had the King Salmon which at $30+ should be excellent and I would say it was very good; salmon was a touch more done than I like. I had the Linguine and Clams ($24). Clams were small but tender. But the sauce was disappointing. Very similar to the red sauce I make at home. Nothing special at all in fact the menu said garlic as the first (other) ingredient and I didn't taste any. Also not served with anything notable like a nice triangle of bread, etc. Dessert was $8 for the red velvet sundae which was a rip off. Dry pieces of red velvet cake over vanilla ice cream with icicles plus caramel and pecans. I do not recommend though I think if I made it myself with homemade cake it would be yummy. Anchor and Hope was fine but for the price it isn't likely that I will be returning.
author: Jennifer R.

description: I had such high hopes. The best thing about the restaurant was the service. An hour and half into being seated, our server brought us a complimentary app because we still had no entrees. The food came and it was just ok... I was ready for love but that was not the case. Next.
author: Mei B.

description: Love this place for a glass of vino and some oysters with a side of fries. I've come here several times for their Happy Hour from 5pm - 7pm which entitles you to a selection of $5 glasses of wine, $1 oysters of the day as well as a few other treats. We got there right before 6pm and sat at the bar but shortly thereafter, patrons filed in by the dozen. If you're looking for a quick bite and a sip, I'd get there on the early-side. Also, while sweet, the staff seems to lag a bit. We had to wait quite a bit for someone to take and serve our order, as well as eventually bring the check. But for $1 beautiful and fresh oysters, I can handle it.
author: Chantelle D.

description:
Came here for the Angels on Horseback (bacon wrapped oysters). They were perfect. The oysters were creamy, the bacon was crispy, the roumelade was perfect, even the crunch of the arugula is perfect. I will definitely be back. My lunch mates had the lobster roll and the burger; I had the catfish sandwich. The sandwiches are filling and then you have the seasoned fries or chips that accompany the dish. I was so full from the sandwich that I took my chips back to the office for a snack. The coleslaw had a perfect spice to it, my only complaint was it was a little watery and had too much sauce on it. The Lobster roll looked delicious, but was a bit heavy on the dressing for me. I was happy I got the catfish sandwich. 
Our waitress was a little off that day, she dropped a drink or two at another diner's table (oops, glad it wasn't near me). 
I am definitely coming back here.
author: Michelle M.

description: Came here for a friend's b-day dinner about a month ago. We basically got a mixture of appetizers and entrees to share. The goodness: strawberry arugula salad, bacon wrapped oysters, warm sea urchin, cornmeal fried artichokes, Alaskan hailbut, fish and chips, and the spice crusted sea scallops. I have to say everything was good. I mean seafood is my thing so I have no complaints.
author: Jeanne L.

description: Food was pretty good but service was really terrible. Bad pacing and just slow with no acknowledgment.  Not sure if that is a regular thing here but you're paying enough money that service shouldn't be an issue.
author: Nick G.

description:
So, I've walked by this place numerous times while running between Harlot and One Eleven as well as passing by it while going to Zebulon, John Collins and Prana/Temple. So, as you can see, it's situated in a nice spot. It's near Osha too. But, I have to say, while it was good, it was just alright. We took our coworker to celebrate his birthday and we shared the calamari, which was definitely the standout. The batter was crispy and the dipping sauce was wonderfully spicy.  The bacon wrapped oysters were eh, just ok. They were good, but I guess it tasted a little too oystery for me. I have had raw and baked before, but for some reason, they were very flagrant.

The bread, which came in its own bag, was delicious, btw...

I had the glamorized fish and chips (cod and potato wedges). I think I had too much fried food and although I was starving when I got there, I was completely full after two bites of my fish. The batter was sorta thicker than it was described, but the fish was good. Potato wedges were good, but when you aren't that hungry, things just don't taste as good as they do when you are starving.  My friends had the salmon and tuna, which they completely finished, so I know their dishes were good.
author: Natalie S.

description:
My controller took my boss and I here for our shared birthdays. Two of us started with the arugula, baby beet and goat cheese salad. I thought it was very yummy and wouldn't hesitate to order again. My boss started with the parsnip/dungeoness crab bisque, which i had as my main course. They also both ordered the salmon. One order it cooked medium and the other medium well. The medium came somewhere between seared and rare, and when sent back to be cooked again, took another 20 minutes to be served (meanwhile tables around us were being served their salmon. when the salmon finally came back it was about 1/3 the size (not sure if it was the same or a new piece) of the original piece. 

If it wasn't for the hiccup the service was great. The atmosphere cool. If taken by a vendor I'd go again, but wouldn't rush back on my own.
author: Betsey T.

description: Amazing!  Delicious fish- way better than being at a typical restaurant by the water (think Fisherman's Warf).  Dishes are modern and inventive, not fried and gross.  Great beer selection.  Apps, main, dessert, and drinks all top notch.  Plus, the server was knowledgeable and actually had an opinion.  Definitely would go back.
author: Lacey G.

description: This place is my husband's "place to go to" in the City.  Not sure if it is because of the beer selection, the food or more than likely both.  He tries to come here at least once a month which considering we live in the South Bay says a lot.  Last Friday was my first time eating here and it won't be my last.  I had the lobster roll and other than the bread it reminded me of something I would have ordered at the Fish Market in Old Town Alexandria.  My husband had the soft shell crab sandwich and he devoured it.  My only regret about this lunch was that I wasn't hungry enough to have tried the lobster and smoked tomato soup as an appetizer.  Hopefully it will be on the menu next time I am there.
author: Debbie M.

description:
I went here a couple weeks ago and had an amazing meal AGAIN. The manager came over to our table and talked to us about our wine (we brought our own) and was extremely nice. We had Margaret as our server...she's awesome, ask for her if you can.
LOVED the calamari...still have dreams about it. Perfectly done, not oily at all! Also had oysters, of course, the miyagis were delicious as well as the malpeques. Their food is so fresh and tasty, I highly recommend it!!
author: Shelley M.

description:
Really like the space and decor, provides some nice character and charm to the joint. In my opinion, the food was fine, not exceptional, and certainly not bad, and even a solid step up from mediocre. I'm always looking out for the strict veggie and vegan crowd (though I am not myself), but truth is, people often go to dinner in groups, there is often at least one person who doesn't eat meat or seafood, or cheese, or anything that casts a shadow, so hey, I'm looking out for you.

There is an option for you folks, it is likely stir fried veggies, and based on the description from the server, not very inspiring. Anyway, our group all eats seafood, so we went that way. I was happy with, but not happy enough to rave about it - the meal was solidly good, and I would not hesitate to eat here again, but I won't go out of my way. One thing I can say, it is a far cry better than any of the seafood joints you would find along the pier.

We did manage to find a very good CA wine, and I am not a big fan of CA wines. And quite honestly the wine list is pretty darn good, if a little over priced for many of the selections.

What really killed it for me was the service - just a little lackluster all around. We were there early, there were only a few tables seated, and the entire service staff just seemed to be waking up from an afternoon nap or a good puff. It was just attentive enough to avoid really downgrading the tip, but not interesting and caring enough to make the experience 'zing' - and it would have only taken just the smallest amount of additional care, and we would be looking at a 4, 4.5 star situation.

I'll certainly give it another try, and hopefully bring this up to 4 stars (maybe more). I will say the food was certainly of high quality, even where I was impressed with the particular combination of flavors, they do get high quality, fresh seafood, so I feel it is worth another chance or two.
author: Ben K.

description:
I'm pretty sure I was the youngest one dining in here the Saturday night that I went - most of the crowd appeared to be in their mid-30's or older. Which was totally fine, I can SO act like a grown-up in these situations.

I loved the Blue Point oysters and clam appetizers, but steer clear of the bone-in sole dish. The sauteed spinach it came with was WAY salty.
author: Jen O.

description:
If you like seafood you'll love it here!!

The food was really good. I had the lobster roll with homemade chips which were light surprisingly. They have a raw oyster bar which was really good!  But the thing that made my experience there great was the waiter we had! He was on point with suggestions from the wine, beer, and meals! He even let us taste some beverages before we fully committed. Now that's service. 

I am definitely coming back!
author: Jazmine S.

description: Have eaten here 3 times already, and the place is amazing! The tuna tartare is amazing -- my hubby doesn't even like tartare and he loved this one. Of course, oysters are great as is any other dish I've tried. Probably most remarkable is that they have such an extensive beer list -- and even a beer sommelier! Highly recommend!
author: Maria O.

description: Not a bad dinner. The Idaho Trout was decent, but the garlic shrimp appetizer might get me to go back. Outstanding service and nice ambiance were pluses too.
author: Ari L.

description:
I have to say I feel pretty much the same about Anchor & Hope as I do about its sister restaurant, Salt House: It was decent, I had a nice time, but I won't go out of my way to go back. From a design perspective, the place is as charming as all get-out... You really feel you're in an old-style warehouse (largely because you are), and the open-air space creates a nice environment. The staff were also competent and friendly, even going so far as to let me try a couple wines before deciding on a bottle.

Again, as with Salt House, it was the food that made things fall flat. I mean, everything was decent, but nothing was really great. The gravalax starter I had was flavorful, but had a slightly off taste. I had the seared tuna as an entree, and the sauce was overpowered with too much vinegar. My friend's fried halibut was good, but I had to really scratch my head at what was basically a $25 order of fish and chips. 

So while I would certainly be willing to give A&H another shot, it will probably be at someone else's suggestion.
author: Aaron L.

description:
SEA URCHIN!!!

You must try the sea urchin.  I loved it.  It's almost like a seafood chowder.  

I can always have more oysters but how to review something they didn't actually cook?

The lobster sandwich was tasty but disappointing for $25.00.  I don't think I could have been satiated by that alone.

Dr Loosen Riesling on the wine list made me very happy.  It's my favorite riesling. 

Service is great but the atmosphere cold.  Art on the wall behind the bar is interested.  The rating should be 3.5 stars.  3 seems a bit harsh, 4 is just too high.  I think the prices are steep for what you get.  I don't  mean portions although they are small.  I pay for good food!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
This is a great addition to downtown's restaurants - I really like it.  

We had a great server, and although the wine list is overwhelming (seriously, there is such a thing as too many choices), she made some good recommendations.  The oysters are fresh and delicious, and they serve these little fried potato noshy things that are terrific.

The room is gorgeous - open, airy, (love the skylights!), and the concrete floor keeps a cool air to the place, though it makes for an environment that's a bit noisy.

Be aware if you use the men's restroom - it shares a wall with the kitchen, so if there are loud thuds and bangs, it's just the kitchen staff doing what they need to do.  But it scared the hell out of me the first time I visited.

All in all, a place I need to return to when I've got some dough to spend on a really, really nice dinner.  The menu looks incredible.
author: Evan G.

description: Honestly the food is about a 3.5, but you are paying for a 4.5 and the snooty servers are providing 2.0 service. That kind of disconnect adds up to a 2.0 experience.
author: Curt S.

description:
My Sales Manager took me out after Q3.  She originally eyed the lobster roll and I asked about the crab louie.  In the end I ordered the lobster roll which was tons of lobster meat on a brioche bun.  It came with chips that had Old Bay seasoning on them.  She got the crab louie which looked good.  

The atmosphere of this restaurant is nice!  A bustling lunch crowd but they get you in and out really quick.  I would be interested in checking this place out for dinner...
author: Christopher W.

description: Tried this place with a group of friends, including one who highly recommended this place, and I wasn't all that impressed. The food was decent, but overpriced.
author: J K.

description: Since I see the potential in this place I am giving it 3 stars. After you get through a sketchy part of SF where we were told by the parking attendant to get our car by 12AM or it would be broken in to, you reach Anchor and Hope. The ambiance is old time industrial/rustic and we loved it! However the excitement stopped there. The food is so-so-eh. The calamari is standard, nothing special, the crab app was good, the arugula salad was really good, the osso bucco could have had more flavor (good though), the scallops were ok (the accompaniments were better than the actual scallops) one even made me think twice about swallowing it (tasted a little sketch). Dessert, sorbet ok, German chocolate cake bad, cherry and pear crisp good. It seemed like everything we ordered was just good or a complete bomb. Don't plan on going back ever. Maybe a good place for drinks though : ).
author: Kate N.

description: Overall this was a good place. Angels on horseback wad pretty good, king salmon was ok, but the sauce and veggies with I were really good. Also had a nice belgian beer. I'd go back.
author: Evaristo R.

description:
I went here for a work lunch and was very impressed. When we arrived our reservations were lost, however we had no problem sitting at the community table. Wasn't able to try much but the oysters and the Shrimp Curry dish were both amazing. The portion size was just right, which tends to not be the case. 

The only complaint I had was that it was a pretty cold day and the front door was open so it was very chilly in the restaurant, luckily I had a jacket. I really liked the minimalist layout and openess of the restaurant. 

Can't wait to come back and try dinner :)
author: Sarah W.

description:
Have been to Anchor & Hope twice, once for happy hour, once for lunch.  Sadly, at lunch the hostess dramatically underestimated our wait time for a table of 4, so the 1st 45 minutes I spent at Anchor & Hope were painful (she said it would be 15, and never apologized).  The restaurant needs better ventilation, as you smell smoke from the kitchen at the front door and walk out smelling like food.  The smoke smell issue was a problem both times I visited.

Other than those two major issues, my food was fantastic and I was less grumpy after wine. And I like the look of the restaurant.  In fact, if the smoke was resolved I might go again, but food-cooking-smoke-smell and bad hostesses are a major issue, so can't go again unless things improve.
author: Sara S.

description:
YUMMY! I am on a quest to try many of San Francisco's culinary delights. Consider it part of my quest to become reacquainted with my home town. My visit to this restaurant was unplanned and the result of a work event. We had a small group of 6 and unbeknownst to me, one of my dining partners was a personal friend of the owners. Both owners stopped by our table and shared stories of their passion for food (particularly BBQ, who woulda thought?) It was evident why they own and run 3 restaurants. 

The service was ok, not sure how much it was influenced by the owners stopping by. Love the way, they present the fresh bread. You're able to tear off a piece without spreading germs to your table mates. 

Prior to dinner, I ordered the scallop seviche. Being a seviche lover, I thought..."how could I go wrong?" Unfortunately, this dish was not for me. The scallops overpowered the remainder of the dish and tasted decidedly fishy. For dinner, I ordered the trout with rice and snap peas and was NOT disappointed. The maple/carmel (??) glaze was amazing and the blend of seasonings with the trout was delectable. The herbed ribbon fries were wonderfully lite and hard to stop eating. 

Portion sizes were perfect and the ambiance welcoming. Heads up....we were there on a Monday night around 6pm. By 8pm the sound of voices was deafening and you had to yell for the person across from you to at least catch every other word. 

With all that said, I would go back again. I am a seafood lover and am curious to try other items on the menu.
author: Island G.

description:
Let's go with 3.5

I'm vegan, so I only had really one option on the menu - the "Daily Vegetarian Special" - which honestly, kind of sucked. It was just a plate of haricot vert and roasted tomatoes. SERIOUSLY. for $18.  I called the waiter over and said "um... I'm going to be starving again in 10 minutes. Can I get a sidecar of starch here?" so he brought me some roasted potatoes and all was well.

So you're probably saying...WTF... why aren't you giving this a 1?

So here's why
1. service. Our waiter was  PHE-NOM-E-NAL
2. WINE - great lovely little wine list...
3. The other people LOVED their food

The lobster roll apparently is divine - two folks at my table had that
Another one of us doesn't eat fish so she had the rib eye and said it was excellent.
Lastly, the urchin appetizer was apparently out of this world.

I enjoyed the room, its lovely. I think the mural above the bar is totally cute. 

basically the service was the key.
OH and the fact that we got this darling corner table just to the left of the entrance. Cozy.
author: Gina P.

description:
Anchor & Hope was the chosen spot for my sister's annual (i.e. expensive) birthday dinner. 

I like the location - I'm a sucker for an old warehouse in an alley. Easy parking (for now), although you have to pay for it, unlike the old days (what was that Caribbean place with the old 727 fuselage that used to be under the freeway ramp there?)

I really like the space too - big open room with lots of zinc and rough beams. Busy but not overwhelmingly loud. Lots of good-looking people. I like the big fish mural and the funky eyeball lights. Off to a good start. 

We had some oysters and a glass of "sparkling wine" at the bar while we waited for our table. Nice selection of oysters; we had a combination of 3 different west coast varieties. My sis liked the Point Reyes - creamy and soft - my favorites were the Totten Inlet - salty and meaty. Apparently Totten Inlet is in Puget Sound.. The Tasmanian sparkler lured us because it sounded unusual, but it was green apple, sweet, and sort of flat tasting even though very fizzy. Not their fault, we chose it. Service at the bar was OK, although we did sit there for a couple of minutes initially before anyone acknowledged us, which is a bit awkward and would have been better avoided. 

We sat down - nice corner table and had a look at the menu. Lots of good-looking stuff!  A guy who I would guess was maybe the head waiter (?) came over and welcomed us, and we ordered a bottle of Morgan chardonnay, fried clams and maple smoked trout salad to start, and mussel and monkfish stew and black bass with peaches and ramps for mains. 

Timing was great - wine came quickly, then starters just a few minutes later. Fried clams were *excellent*. I grew up eating fried clams on the beach in Maine as a little kid and I'd come back just for a basket of these things. The trout salad was nice, with bitter arugula and radicchio to contrast with the soft fish and little cubes of potato. There was supposed to be an anchovy dressing, but I don't remember tasting that. 

Nice break before the entrees arrived - just long enough but not too long. My stew was pretty good, but I have to say the main ingredients - mussels and monkfish - didn't make the dish. The mussels were tiny, and monkfish is a bit strange... Luckily there was plenty of nice spicy chorizo and that flavored the broth well. I would have liked slightly larger mussels, different fish, and for the fish to have taken the flavor of the broth more. 

My sister's entree looked beautiful - big pieces of sea bass with tiny early peaches and a bunch of sauteed ramps. Taste was good but not amazing. I case you haven't gathered yet, I like bright food with big, fresh, spicy flavors, so sometimes I find that lacking when someone else would a quieter dish. Sis liked the fish. 

We split a shortbread biscuit with lots of berries and a little champagne cream - very nice finish and my kind of dessert. 

Did I mention expensive?? Oysters at $3 ea. is more than a bit steep. Even so, I really like the room, and I'd come back for more modest meal - beet salad and fried clams, fried clams, fried clams, for sure.
author: Bowen D.

description:
I think I'm still full from last night's dinner here!  I was highly surprised by how much I liked their food, but then I should've expected it since these people also did Salt House and Town Hall.

The best surprise of the night was hands down the warm sea urchin appetizer.  Yummmmmmmmm!!!  
If you are at all a sea urchin person--you must get this.  
If the sight of sea urchin makes you gag, the taste of this appetizer may get you to change your mind!  

The oysters were very fresh and my sea bass was perfectly paired with yummy peaches!
author: Miranda S.

description:
Service:  A+.  All plates arrived at same time (4 of us)--which, I know should be standard, but let's be honest--so many restaurants fail on this simple point.

Decor:  Just my cup of tea.  As others have said--it's very SoMa, with exposed beams, etc.  But its rustic touches (lanterns, awesome signage/entrance) were unique.

Food:  hit and miss . . . read on for what to get and what to avoid

Must eat this:  Angels on Horseback--smoked bacon-wrapped oysters.  Plump, fried oysters wrapped in quality bacon, served with a fabulous sauce.  4 oysters--perfect for 2 greedy people or 4 who are sharing other apps.  My 1 oyster was 2 amazing mouthfuls.  Brilliant.

Don't eat this:  Smithwick's Battered Halibut--I've had better fish 'n' chips at many places.  The chips are actually rosemary potato wedges, but they're just not exciting.  It didn't help that my fish was overdone.  (But the chef sent a couple of desserts to make up for it.  Oh, but I'm still writing about the unimpressive dish.  Is that a Yelp-a-no-no?  Hey--gotta be true to the food!)

The Heart of Sweet Cream was interesting and nice.  The chocolate cake, which I don't see on the menu online, was really heavy.

Pretty good:  Cold Smoked Trout salad and the Sea Urchin--which reminded me of fancy clam chowder (lobster!).

Definitely go, but just choose wisely!
author: Em P.

description:
I went to A&H one night on a date. Within the first 8 minutes we were seated, walked through the specials and offered wine samples. My date and I shared the scallop ceviche, I ordered the crab remoulade, and the guy ordered seabass. 

The food, including the dessert, was pretty good, as was the wine. The service was efficient yet unobtrusive. The restaurant was bustling around 9:30, which I think is sensational for a Wednesday night in San Francisco. My first experience at A&H was pretty good; I'm surely going back!
author: Matin N.

description:
Conveniently located around several bars and clubs, this is a great spot to coat your tummy with a good bite before trashing out on one too many vodka tonics.

I didn't really dig the fish and chips too much but did like:

- the fresh raw oysters on a half shell.....can't really go wrong on these since little preparation is needed
- "angles on horseback"......bacon wrapped with fried oysters
- heirloom tomatoes with yellow watermelon and watercress salad
- "warm sea urchin in shell"....with mashed potatoes and dungeness crab
- A&H lobster roll......served between a tasty brioche like bread
author: Katie K.

description:
Great restaurant with great food!  I had experienced Salt House before this place and thought the food here was much better.  The unagi with tomatoes and shrimp was awesome! Wished they had more unagi in the dish though. =(  Ordered raw oysters which was 'melt in your mouth' delicious!  Then there was the appetizer clams and some entree with a variety of seafood in it that had great spicy sauce.  Definately loved eating their bread with their sauce soaked into it.  

I'm not a big seafood fan but this place was great.  I have to admit I was quite buzzed as I arrived to this restaurant so there may be a slight possibility I overrated the food.  =P  Although it's pretty pricey, I would definately come back here again. Very convenient place for bar hopping after dinner considering there's so many bars around.  =)
author: sidney c.

description: Great food and great ambiance. Best lobster roll of my life.
author: Nate M.

description: Came here for a Business lunch...I think these are the only people that can afford to eat here at lunch...unless you really want to pay $23 for a sandwich.  The food was excellent, thoughtfuly prepared. Angels on Horseback were delightful, Lobster roll was the best I have ever had and the service was excellent...but after paying over $100.00 for lunch I was quick to go back and expense it.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Welcome to the purveyor of the best sandwich I have ever eaten.  

I just moved to SF a month and a half ago and am trying to eat up a storm.  I came here for lunch the other day since I work right around the corner, and I'd skimmed the menu quickly beforehand but nothing stood out to me.  When we were seated (at a table next to the bar, which the hostess confirmed was ok with us first), the "pork belly BLT" screamed ORDER ME -- so I obliged.  And I'm so happy that I did.

B=Pork belly - succulent and crispy, eye-rollingly savory
L=Arugula - my favorite green 
T=Fried green tomatoes. yup.

It came with house-made chips which were good but -- the sandwich stole the show.  My colleague got the grilled mahi-mahi sandwich, and the fish was tender and juicy (kind of hard to eat given how thick the filet was), but really tasty just the same.
author: Kasia F.

description: Went here for the first time the other week and loved it.  Everything we ordered was great -- the appetizer platter shared with the table, and I had the salmon entree which was delicious.  We were all a little surprised when the "cod" dish came, which was actually just fish and chips, it was good but not expected.  I love the atmosphere, the huge open space, converted warehouse feel, and great beer and wine list too.  Will definitely be going back soon.
author: Joanna S.

description:
Walked in on a Friday night at 7:30pm without a reservation for a party of three. We got seated right away. There appeared to be ample seating for walkins, as other tables were empty too. I'm not sure if that's the result of the economy or just a fluke. The oysters and ceviche were memorable, but the calamari was not. The bouillabaisse was solid, but nothing to write home about. And the lobster from lobster roll was delicious, though the roll was drenched in too much butter. 

The decor is nice with the brick walls and high ceilings, reminiscent of Salt House. Overall, it was solid for seafood and a pleasant dining experience.
author: tessie n.

description: Four stars because I didn't personally try and of the food (had already eaten and was visiting for a friend's birthday), but can speak to the wine/beer list and definitely a lot of good choices, albeit a bit pricey. Then again, good wine is worth it.
author: Allison F.

description:
Two words: food poisoning.  

Ask yourself: is it really worth the risk?
author: Shamir C.

description:
Anchor & Hope on Minna recently featured Festina Peche on draft, and I decided to pair it with the restaurant's delicious fish tacos: two small corn tortillas topped with crispy lightly fried fish and a spicy salsa. Anchor & Hope served the Festina Peche in a wine glass, but I think Dogfish Head's effervescent Berliner Weiss is a better match with the tacos than a still white wine or even champagne. The tart Festina Peche resonated with the salsa and was like an extra squeeze of lemon on the delicate fish. 
Anchor & Hope, which opened in 2008, is the third restaurant by brothers Mitchell and Steven Rosenthal and their partner, Doug Washington, following Town Hall (2003) and Salt House (2006). Anchor & Hope is a popular destination for downtown office workers during lunch and dinner, and for its excellent happy hour specials, like a chef's selection of oysters for $1 each, fish tacos and shrimp fritters, as well as beer and wine specials.
Despite the stainless steel that gives the restaurant an urban ambience, the bright room has a lot of warmth, which was enhanced by Tom McDermott playing New Orleans style on the piano that Anchor & Hope brought in for the occasion. McDermott was recently featured on HBO's post-Katrina series Treme.
Enjoying the fish tacos with the fresh Festina Peche while listening to McDermott play Professor Longhair on the piano was like taking a mini vacation from bustling downtown San Francisco. I for one hope the piano, and music in general, becomes a regular fixture at this downtown oasis.
author: chuck l.

description:
To celebrate a special occasion, my date and I decided to feast ourselves on some seafood. I have friends who are huge fans of this place and I myself love seafood, so seemed like a natural choice. 

This is a solid restaurant. Everything was tasty and the wait staff were attentive and friendly. 

I got the lobster roll. I've never had one before, so I didn't realize it came as a sandwich. The lobster was good. The brioche was a bit dry, but still good. The date got scallops and oysters and kept making 'O' faces while consuming his meal. Thus I can safely assume they were good. 

What I didn't like about Anchor & Hope was a lack of ambiance. It's very loud and there isn't a separation between the waiting area, the bar, and the tables. Our table was sort of near the door, so I kept looking up at hungry partrons waiting for their turn to eat. This made the anxious. Also the loudness of the music, the bar-goers, and the frenzied wait staff made it hard to relax and carry on a conversation. 

Maybe this place is better for a group dinner, but I don't think I'll be coming back here on an intimate date.
author: A K.

description:
Seafood lovers must check this place out! Fresh and tasty preparations. 

I had the oysters to start and my BF had the gem salad. Delightful!

For our main course, BF had their take on fish and chips. Excellent! The Guinness beer batter was crispy and tasty - not a health-conscious item, but a great treat.  

I got two small plates: scallop ceviche and crab salad. The crab salad was not a greens with crab, but a deviled-like crab salad. Very generous serving for $8, flavorful and very fresh crab. The scallop ceviche was a bit  disappointing - again very fresh, but it was a bit bland for me. I added fresh squeezed lemon, salt and pepper - it added the zing it needed. If it weren't for this dish - I'd likely give them 5 stars. 

The wharf inspired decor was very open and inviting. And is in sync with the menu.

I'll definitely be going back!
author: Kimberly N.

description:
We went on the april 26th, when there was no liquor license and the place was working out some kinks, so I cut it some slack.  
The appetizers were great.  The chowder presentation is interesting, some may say pretentious, but I thought it made it taste better.  The sea urchin app was really interesting.  
The decor is like Scoma's in the 21st century.  Well done, casual, clean.  The old Emeco Navy chairs are so comfortable yet sleek.  The tables and woodwork have this grey stain to them which, when under the skylights made the space look totally different than most restaurants.  Almost like you are up at Tomales Bay bbq'ing your own oysters in Hog island's picnic area...  Sans the salt water scents.  And I love the graphic of the ocean food chain above the bar.
The 'onion rings' were scene stealers,.  My butterfish was great, the portion huge!  The fried halibut was light and crisp.  The mains were very good, not memorable but solid all around.
The minuses to our experience were all easily attributed to growing pains, the server couldnt remember all the specials and some parts of dishes, but always came back quickly with info.  My brother's hangar steak (first mistake at a place call ANCHOR and hope) was not cooked medium.  Floor manager quickly insisted they re-do it, 10 minutes later a new steak was still well done, but they were very apologetic and took it off the bill.  First class service.
Even overcooked, it was still tasty and juicy in my opinion.  I think its a good sign when the overcooked steak still tastes great at a Seafood restaurant.
author: Christian W.

description:
Not impressed!

As a huge fan of seafood I had such high hopes for this place. Work in the neighborhood, around the corner so have seen this place turn into the welcoming dining room with a  clean and simple decor, loved the look and layout with a variety tables. The small touches are very evident by the hand-written menu, and very attentive staff. Though quality is a 4 1/2 star, originality is hugely lacking. Nothing seemed to stand out on the menu, was more excited about the bread on the table then the dishes we ordered.   

Every dish is presented beautifully, yet kept asking where is the rest. For the prices being charged i would expected much more, would have rather spent a bit more at Roy's down the block. Located in the midst of many great restaurants this place does fill the void of simple seafood lunch spot, yet felt like we left paying for dinner. I understand it is not Lee's, Zebulon, Flames, or Harvest n Rowe but just left a bit disappointed and was still craving something more.
author: Danny B.

description:
- Halibut was AMAZING
- Lobster rolls were also great
- Fried pearl onions & also the salmon/potato cakes were AMAZING
- They had snapper last night: disappointing - don't waste your money
- Great wines
- Great staff
- Good interior, lighting, and also parking nearby
author: Olivia S.

description:
LOVE this place!  It is much more spacious than Salt House or Town Hall, and maybe even a tad less noisy.  Considering how new it is, I was surprised they could accomodate our group of 6 (which swelled to 9 as a nearby happy hour ended and friends trickled over) on a Wednesday at 7:30.  They were super gracious about our unexpected guests, and all the staff seemed friendly and knowledgable.

We sampled nearly everything on the menu, and I loved everything except the fries with eyes (too fishy), and the desserts, which were a total letdown after the incredible appetizers and entrees.  I thought the salad portions could be a bit larger, but protein portions were quite generous, and it was an all-around delightful meal.

I particularly recommend the lobster, beet salad, artic char, and guinea hen.
author: nicole l.

description:
Tried Anchor & Hope today for lunch with 2 friends.  We liked the open airy design of the restaurant.  Even though it was pretty full, it was easy to converse and hear each other so they've done something right to keep noise from being overbearing.  The bread was good and arrived within seconds of when we sat down along with water.

Our waitress took our orders quickly and the food arrived within about 10 minutes.  Nice when you have to get back to work.

I had the Crab Louie.  It was described as coming with haricot vert, nicoise olives & butter lettuce in contrast to the Shrimp Louie I didn't get, which had the same description other than Arugula lettuce (vs butter).  The Louie arrives and here's what I got.  A small stack of Arugula dressed with a light vinaigrette, maybe 6 haricot vert and 2 teensy smashed pieces of a single nicoise olive.  One piece of butter lettuce with about a cup of crab sitting on it.  Next to that was a small container of a nice spicy thousand island-type dressing.  Oh, there was also one cherry tomato cut in half and a quail egg cut in half.  It was all ok but no way was the portion worth EIGHTEEN DOLLARS.

One companion is vegan and had the only vegetarian choice on the menu.  Chef's Delight was the name and it was a selection of roasted vegetables that were nicely prepared, but again, not a very large portion.  The other friend had the lamb burger which came with a stack of the shaved fries.  Burger was a tad well done but otherwise flavorful.

The waitress was polite but a bit off her prime.  She forgot our drink order until she came to check on how our food was and then remembered she'd never brought them.  She was polite and apologetic and dashed off to get them fast when she realized the error.

All this came to $65 without the tip.  We didn't have dessert, no alcohol, no appetizers.  

I'm a fan of Salt House & Town Hall, but A&H loses my vote.  Too much money for mediocre & small portions.
author: Lxs S.

description:
I'm a fan of Anchor & Hope. I'm pretty much a fan of anywhere that serves lobster rolls, but theirs is exceptional. I have been there twice, and the food has yet to disappoint.

On our last visit, the service was not so great, but the somalier did ask to try our wine because he suspected it was corked, and gave us a new bottle. None of us tasted any difference, but I guess he has a fancier palette. Whatever.  

One warning - if the price of an item says A/Q, ask how much it is. Three of us ordered the lobster, which was AMAZING, but it was $51!! Sometimes it's nice to just enjoy and not ask, but that is pretty steep compared to the rest of the menu. Oh well, glad it was delish!
author: Jamie C.

description: I had one of the most amazing dishes of my life at this restaurant!!! Was visiting San Francisco with a few girlfriends.  We were wondering where to eat our first night, somewhere that was walking distance from our hotel (the Palace).  We ended up choosing Anchor & Hope.  Ordered the lobster, crab and potato gnocchi dish.  The one word to describe it is DIVINE.  The sauce was so good, wanted to lick the plate!  They had a great beer selection, and great ambiance.  The prices were also very reasonable.  I would definately go back, the only con to this place is that its not in LA where I live.
author: Tamar O.

description:
I was a big fan prior to last night.....now I'm a cautious fan.  We enjoyed the setting, pacing, and ambiance as usual, but the food seemed to be a bit of a letdown.

Two signature apps, Fries w/Eyes and Angels on Horseback, were not as tasty as in previous visits.  the Fries were barely crunchy and the bacon around the Angels (oysters) was so thick, it deterred from the delicateness of the oyster texture.   However, the Scallops were cooked perfectly on top of a Curried Israeli Couscous.

For an entree, my Fisherman's Stew was meh.  The mussels had an "not so fresh" taste, so I only ate a few of those.  Worrisome as this is a Seafood Restaurant, right?  The tomato broth base really didn't have much flavor....overall I was hoping for better.  Hubby had the Clam Paella with Quail.  The Paella rice was tasty, definitely non traditional, but it had nice pieces of asparagus in it.  The Quail was undercooked.

The restaurant doesn't seem to be lacking for customers as every seat was occupied at 8pm on a Monday night.  Maybe the kitchen had an off night for us, but they can certainly do better.  And for that, three stars instead of two.
author: D V.

description:
Went on my B-Day from a short trip to SF. Food was just o.k. Halibut must have had 3 or 4 different styles of peas and shoots, but no starch. Pancetta vinaigrette was almost non existent. Clams on the half shell where tiny at $1.50 each. Girlfriend had lobster roll, fresh tasting and good bread. Donuts at the end where doughy, but good (never met a donut I did not like).

 A couple of things stood out, only beer and wine, no booze (should have done my homework better). The server kept saying after she had taken each order "Oh, that's my favorite". What the whole menu? Asked for them to call us a cab, 20 minutes later, after we paid, she returned, and said " I dont know what is with your taxi, you are probably better off going out and hailing one". I called a taxi company on my phone and they where there in 4 minutes.
author: Andrew B.

description: I have been wanting to try to place since it opened and finally made it. The food was ok and nothing special. Had Manila clams and it was a little fishy. The tuna melt was ok but then again if you pay $15 I'd say there's better tuna melts elsewhere. The mussels were actually pretty good and I'm not even a big fan of it.  Doubt I would be back.
author: Mary L.

description: great place... great staff & service, Sea urchin soup was amazing. Great seafood platter
author: Alan B.

description:
Eh. 

I read about Anchor & Hope in a food magazine at some point, and urged a friend to add it to our "try these" list. It took us several months to get around to eating there, and it kinda wasn't worth the wait, or the place on our list.

To start, I had the clam chowder with bacon. We headed over straight after work and were therefore unfashionably early, which is the only reason I can think of that the soup chowder was watery, its potatoes too crisp. That battered cob was fine, but indistinguishable from other fish and chips I've had at far less acclaimed spots. The brook trout tasted exactly like salmon, but wasn't cooked like it -- it was too dry, all the flavor seemingly cooked out.

Anchor & Hope deserves stars for its comprehensive beer selection and charming, casual atmosphere. (My dining companion announced that he would happily gut the restaurant and live in it.) Sadly, the food was pretty average.
author: Katie T.

description: Hm....the service here is not so great. Greeted by someone who liked to power trip at the front door, she blatantly said, "we're super busy tonight, as she sharpened her pencil" It was only 5:35pm and the tables were 90% empty. The guy who sat us down was like "we're really going to need this table at 6:45" which was fine because we were only going to be here for happy hour. But man! what a greeting. The oysters were really fresh so I cant complain. And the beer sampler wasnt bad. Parmasan fries were a little soggy and the fried oysters were so so. I hope I just came on a wierd night, where the staff was in transition because the quality of food is pretty good.
author: Angela J.
