description: I just love the inside decor of the place, but the food continues to be a bit too flavorful for me. To start, I ordered the little gem/fresh mint salad (good), but the short ribs and sides that came with it were too heavy/flavorful/salty. The highlight of my latest meal here were the desserts: stout gingerbread/apple/butternut squash compote and chocolate blackout cake.
author: Chihee K.

description: Was here a couple weeks ago and it definitely lived up to its rep. Came for the Angels on Horseback per 7x7 and was not disappointed. The setting with low lighting made our table in the middle of the room still feel private. Service was great, with no wait due to our reservation.
author: Jenny X.

description: Recently had lunch here with a couple of people. Interesting fishing (as opposed to nautical) theme. Great place for a "casual business lunch", as tables are big enough for note pads. Lobster roll was a little expensive, but tasty.
author: Michael B.

description: The sea urchin and the bacon covered oysters are still amazing. Love their beer selection. The service was great. We were stuffed by the time our main courses came thanks to the bread, oysters and apps but still one of my favorites in SOMA for seafood.
author: shadi m.

description: Just what the doctor ordered for a cold, rainy week night! We had a wonderful experience at Anchor & Hope.  The building was an open warehouse with bar along a wall and open seating across the floor.  It was a bit raucous but up beat on the floor; so not the place for a quiet romantic seafood dinner.  However the service and food was great.  We asked our server to surprise us with an appetizer of his choice along with the "angels on horseback".  We were delighted with buttered dungeness crab... mmm... it was buttery bliss!  The angels on horseback were awesome also.  We finished off the experience with the lobster roll and scallops which were good but not great.  The appetizers were the best part of our meal, but we will return to try more of their entrees. It's nice to find another restaurant downtown to take friends to!
author: Brad K.

description:
My guess is that Anchor & Hope improves after it's been open for a few more weeks. Right now, it's clearly not ready...for instance, they don't have a liquor license so we had to go around the corner to buy some beer for the dinner. I don't mind that so much but I question why they got themselves into all the local newsletters (Thrillist, UrbanDaddy, etc.) touting their excellent beer selection without noting that it wasn't going to be available when they opened!

Angels on Horseback -- oysters wrapped in bacon with light seasoning. These were amazing. The best dish I had by far. Bacon is hard to beat and it was just crispy enough to really contrast with the texture of the oyster instead.

Chowder -- Had an interesting kick that was unusual and separated it from your corner store chowder.

Lobster Roll -- This was bad. First of all, lobster rolls are supposed to come stuffed with lobster. There were two on my plate and two on my girlfriend's and none of them had even close to enough. The bread -- which was grilled with butter but crumbled too quickly -- overwhelmed the bland lobster salad to the point where it wasn't edible. Perhaps I have high standards, coming from the Northeast, but this was a very weak effort.
*This dish was slightly redeemed by the delicious, light potato chips served with the rolls.
author: Nick L.

description:
Only 3 weeks into business and all systems seem good to go for a successful restaurant.
food-really good, may have been a bit over salted
service-good, a little overzealous with refilling the water
customer service-great, both waitstaff and one of the managers were super attentive
return visit- most definitely, better of the three, Town Hall and Salt House
in all of the above.
author: Ms J K.

description:
Alright friends pay attention!  The best way to go about this place since its new is to go tapas style.  5 of us ordered 4 appetizers and 3 entrees to split. 

Appetizers:

Bacon wrapped oysters (good, but not amazing)
Stuffed Clams (amazing)
Sea Urchin (a must, see everyone else's reviews)
Beet Salad (the pine nuts popped with in my mouth with every bite)

Entrees:

Chef's Veggie Delite (roasted tomatoes were out of this world)
Sea Bass (melted in mouth)
Lobster Roll (another must, see other's reviews)

We had a lot of fun here, and I will definitely back.  No disappointments, on par with Salt House and Town Hall
author: Lindsay T.

description:
Two words: SCALLOP CEVICHE!  That alone will keep me coming back for more. I'm not sure if they have it all the time though, it was on the chalkboard menu the night we went.

The oysters, both the fresh ones and the deep fried, were delightful, as was the lobster roll. The sea urchin was so-so. Great presentation with the shell, but I tasted more of the mashed potatoes than anything else. Nice wine list, friendly waitstaff.  Great, open loft-like space - they need AC in there though. Granted, we went during that crazy heat wave, a rarity in SF. But really, an oscillating fan blowing in your face every few seconds while you're eating can get kind of annoying.

Overall, I enjoyed my experience here and still can't stop thinking about that scallop ceviche.
author: Amy H.

description:
This is probably more like a 3.5 stars - but I just couldn't round up to 4. 

The service was good - not amazing. The food didn't blow me away, but did meet my (very high) expectations. I loved the ambiance. 

With so many places in the city I still want to try, I can't see myself coming back. But, if a friend plans a dinner there, I wouldn't boycott it.
author: Amanda S.

description:
This place is ok...the starters were good.  We had the Angels on Horseback, Heirloom Baby Beet salad, Asparagus salad and scallop ceviche.  The ceviche was good.  Not excellent.  

For my main course I had the Spicy Mussel and Monk stew.  Disappointing.  I was warned that it could be spicy.  The saffron was strong but other than that it lacked a bit more oomph.  There were 2 pieces of chorizo and although the broth was tasty I expected it to be a bit thicker.  The dish as a whole didn't seem to come together very well.

I will say that the staff and service was wonderful as well as the wine selection.  The venue is very cool.

Overall the food is good.  But just good.  Maybe our party ordered the wrong stuff but we did try many different plates (including 2 of the 3 desserts) and were not wowed by any.
author: Olivia H.

description:
Laid back after work dinners with amazing food. I like the old auto-body shop interior with no fuss furnishings. The staff were warm, helpful and offered great recommendations. I had the Sea urchin with dungeness crab and mashed potatoes served in the urchin shell. Presentation was fun and the taste was great. The consistency was  little more soupy than I expected, but it was delicious...
I also had some calamari with thai chili dipping sauce, and the house made salmon gravlax, which on the potato cake was also fantastic.
A little on the pricey side ($150 for three people?) but damn tasty.
author: Patrice S.

description:
I think this is a solid place to go with your family or a relative that's visiting SF or maybe a biz lunch.  It's a nice open space, really stellar service, and the food was tasty.  Anchor and Hope doesn't exude a lot of uniqueness in any shape or form, but it delivers a good experience with good food.

In my humble opinion.
author: Antichris E.

description:
I went again for dinner during the week and really enjoyed it.

FIRST THINGS FIRST: This time I ordered the schrimp cocktail.  Yum!  6 large schrimp beautifully presented on a bed of ice.  My companion ordered an Asian-inspired sauteed shrimp dish which was accompanied by a small dish of rice.

Of course we shared the tasty sea urchin.  Just as good.

THE NITTY GRITTY: I ordered the sole on a bed of brussel sprouts.  The dish was outstanding - however, it was very very salty.  But it was so wonderful, I tried really hard to overlook it.  It was a nice-sized portion too.

My companion ordered the ribs...yum yum yum.  A little spicy sauce and very meaty.

LIQUID GRAPES: Lovely lovely wine list.  Something for everyone and again the beer list is 3 pages long!

The main thing is that everyone there is NICE!  It's amazing how a pleasant and nice staff can influence a dinner/vibe of a restaurant.

Overall, a very unique restaurant where I actually will go back again despite the plethora of other choices I have.
author: Jackie M.

description: Went here for a Valentine's Day dinner with my girlfriend and we had a great time. The menu was good, enough to choose from depending on your seafood preference. The beer menu was giant and was very extensive. Prices were high but that's what I expect when dinning downtown. For appetizer we got the bacon wrapped clams and they were okay. After we got our clams we got the surprise of getting homemade kettle chips with a salt and vinegar aioli sauce to dip. Very tasty, I could have eaten that all night. For my main I had the Ca Sea Bass which was perfect. No problems at all with that dish. My girlfriend got the cioppino soup and she loved it. The only thing she want more of was the bread, so that she could soak up every drop of the soup. Got the bill and it was expensive, but hey its seafood downtown. I just wish there was a view for the price I was paying for. The view is the alley way it's located in, not so great.
author: Zachery H.

description: This is my favorite place of 2009.  The environment is really edgy and classy without being stuffy.  The food is incredible but I think it depends on what you order.  My party didd well, fresh grilled fish and vegetables.  I did see other tables with shocking looking plates of fried 'fish and chips' looking things...but i didn't taste it so ignore that part.
author: Duanne G.

description: Cool steely interior with food to match: bland, boring, disaffecting.
author: Nicole L.

description: The overall experience was good - we were seated quickly, the service was good, the interior was nice (very open but something on the floor helped keep the noise down). The beer list was almost a daunting length in varieties (they don't serve hard alcohol). But for the type of food, the prices were a bit much compared to other places with similar selection and quality. I'd go back for the beer (even though that was a bit pricey as well) just for the selection.
author: James S.

description: I love this place! I've been here 3 times and each time I'm impressed. It's on the expensive side but is worth it IMO. The first few times I ordered scallops, which were amazing, and though small, just enough. Last weekend the scallops weren't on the menu so I tried the gnocci and lobster with "lobster foam". I've been craving it ever since.. the gnocci was nothing like I've had before, it must've been homemade. Very soft. There were chunks of lobster that tasted very fresh. The foam is just a creamy sauce. My dish was clean by the end. We ordered the beer sampler which is 6 different types of beer in mini glasses from different countries, which was fun and only $13. Would definitely recommend this to seafood lovers.
author: Ashley B.

description: Seafood focused....and the food is done very well - innovative twist on linguine with clams...though mussels and frites were not anything special.  The decor is quirky nautical and really makes the space.  Be aware they only serve beer and wine.
author: Anne M.

description:
Town Hall and Salt House are two of my favorite places to eat in the city when I'm out with the girls. I was hoping Anchor & Hope would be the same since its so close to wear I work. The ambiance is definitely what you'd expect - casual and sophisitcated at the same time, warm and comfortable and not too loud. 

The service was great. And here's a story to prove it: I ordered the wine for our table and then got through the tasting alright (I'm a lady and like the man at the table to do this kind of thing for me. Sorry Gloria Steinem.). The server poured our glasses and then set the bottle to my right. Because I'm a klutz., a very big klutz, I decided to move the bottle before I had a chance to spill it - and while I was moving the bottle, I spilt it all over myself. So embarrasing. But the staff descended upon me like a NASCAR team and in 10 seconds flat it was like it never happened. Kudos to them for being so efficient about everything.

Now for the food - very salty and wasn't as good as I was expecting. I had the lobster roll. I love lobster and this just didn't love up to Woodhouse Fish Company in the Castro. We also shared some seasonal cake dessert which was ok. Not sure if we were there on an off night?
author: Kimberly H.

description: We were here on Sunday evening after my husband expressed a wish for seafood - it was a little pricey for what you get but overall a hit.  He ordered the asparagus soup as a starter, which he said was incredible.  I and our other two friends ordered clam chowder which was the perfect thing for a windy cool night.  I loved the bread that came to the table, super-crusty and delicious with real butter.  I ordered the fish and chips - the portion was huge and a little greasier than expected, but the fish was breaded beautifully and the fries had a lovely thyme seasoning.  My husband ordered the seafood stew which he loved.  Our friends had the lobster roll which looked amazing and the halibut, which was a fairly modest portion compared to my fish and chips, but looked tasty.  The service was reasonably attentive and when the waitress forgot my soda and I asked about it, she brought it over and indicated that she wouldn't charge us for it, which was not necessary but I thought it was a very nice gesture that a less upscale place wouldn't have made.  We would visit again next time we're in SF.
author: Jocelyn R.

description:
As far as I remember, the food is good, not a lot of choice thow.
And I like the deco
author: armelle p.

description: Meh exactly. Second visit. Food is fine but too expensive for what it is and not all that imaginative. The seafood all has pedigree but what I've tasted there was drowned in kind of dully flavored oily sauces. Great beer and wine but SERIOUSLY ovepriced. Way too noisy. Service was erratic; nobody but busboys for about 15 minutes and then eventually server came and was fine if busy. Not many healthy options at all. I get the desire to create the New England seafood joint experience but not sure this is it.
author: Darien W.

description:
Because I love Town Hall, I was excited to try this new seafood venture from the same restaurateurs. We had a reservation on a Sunday night and were seated immediately at a wonderful table at the front next to the Window. The space is really impressive and pleasant. There are high ceilings, its bright and there is quite a bit of room in between tables. Its not like Town Hall where you can't hear your dinner guest speaking over the loud noise in a tightly packed room. 

Unfortunately, our food was just pretty good. I can't complain about anything specific, but, it was just a bit forgettable. I had their special for the evening which was a soft shell crab dish ($25) and my husband had the sea bass. Both of us enjoyed the meal, but, I probably wouldn't rush back. We also had a watercress salad with beets and hazelnuts ($11) and bread pudding w/ white peaches for dessert. Everything was just a little over average. 

They had a nice beer selection though. We had Hoegarden which they had on tap, but, they also had a list of Belgians including Delirium, St. Bernard's and Duval. 

It was pretty neat that you could order individual oysters and crab legs. I had one oyster ($3) and my husband had  one crab leg ($6). Its pretty neat to be able to just get a taste of something and not commit to a big dinner.
author: Joan L.

description:
I arrived a bit early for our dinner reservation, so I took a seat at the bar and learned a bit about chardonnay from the bar tender.  He was knowledgeable and helpful and let me try some different wines before I made a commitment.  Plus, the fishies on the wall are way cool.

This space really is lovely and open and airy - it has a warehousey vibe that plays well to the nautical theme.

As for the food, I was very pleased with my mussel and monkfish stew.  The chorizo was a nice touch.  I also enjoyed the basil clams, but the bacon-wrapped mussels were only okay.  My dining companion's stuffed and roasted lobster was pretty amazing though.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Just lunched at Anchor & Hope and overall, I left quite satisfied.  

The clam chowder was rich and buttery, chock full of sweet corn, certainly one of the best yuppified versions of clam chowder I've experienced.  My main entree of a lobster roll was fine too.

The restaurant itself is just a tad Fisherman's Wharfish - the nautical theme might be a touch overdone to make one feel like this is a local SOMA hangout and not a restaurant that caters to the tourist crowd, but that aside, my overall experience was nice.

Great service too!
author: Rafael R.

description:
I just found my favorite fish & chips in the city! they are perfectly light and super crispy, but very flavorful and delicious. i substituted the ribbon fries for the potato wedges which was great idea. i LOVE fries, and the ribbon fries are like ribbons of potatoes that are perfectly seasoned and crunchy like potato chips.

you can also get lump crab or lobster meat by the 1/4 lb. which we ordered as an appetizer. i like the decor and it's a fun place to go with a group or with kids. To me, it was like an upscale Lobster Shack (in North Beach). Very fresh seafood, good service and nice atmosphere.

I would recommend this place for people who love seafood and raw bars.
author: Pumakat K.

description:
I wish I wrote this the evening I dined there with a friend, because I would be able to give a better description, but I was impressed!
They have a nice, although not too extensive wine list and when I arrived first, I enjoyed a nice glass of vino.  I did make reservations, but if you get there early enough - 6-ish, you should have no problems getting seated.  I intend to try them out next for a later seating and report back.
The ambiance is hip warehouse meets fine dining with the fish processing angle thrown in.  Our service was very good, without trying to rush us (which I read in other Yelp reviews).  I recall the meals were delicious with appropriate portions and presentation and being an East-Coaster, I did appreciate that the menu kinda reflected that area.
author: Rich N.

description:
I wasn't expecting the food to be THIS good.  I'd read about it in 7x7 and decided to give it a try.  The ambiance is great- it's an old auto body shop, and we sat at a communal table - how Euro. Our server was awesome and the food blew me away.   

Check it.
author: Jason I.

description:
Scallop Ceviche appetizer was awesome,as well as the salt and pepper prawns. Funny multi lingual server was nice to look at and mildly entertaining.

  Main courses, Fish and chips and tuna not all they raved to be but not awful either.  The tuna was overcooked for sure and my bf was convinced the fish chips could've been crisper.

Lobster rolls......I could do without eating again. 

Overall the atmosphere was super busy, even with a reservation on my birthday we waited at the bar for almost half an hour. They have no hard liquor so dont think youll be enjoying a burbon with your crab cakes. The decor is simple shipyard inspired and looks pretty basic. 
Prices are a bit much and its already overrun with yuppies.

Over all I didn't have a really special experience here, or a really bad one. It was just another restaurant with mood lighting.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Just get the Lobster Roll!

So, I have yet to visit this restaurant, but I Iove the lobster roll. The lobster was fresh, the roll was perfect. So many times, the lobster is great, and the bread is crap; well, not in this case. My special person in life brought it to me and it made me so happy.

My friends have been and they love the place. I really want to go and based on the food that I have, I would suggest it. To those that don't like the lobster roll and think it is too expensive, they clearly do not understand the cost of food in San Francisco.

If you don't trust my suggestion, just get the lobster roll to go and you will see what I mean, and then you will have had the same experience as me. I can't give it a five until I have been, but it can get four stars for food.
author: Christopher W.

description: Went here tonight for my Mom's birthday and left feeling minimal excitement to go back.  When we arrived, we were told the heaters were broken and they sat us by the kitchen stating it would be a warmer location but it did not seem to be as the night went on.  The chairs were ice cold when we sat down and I had to keep putting my coat back on to keep warm.  The food was nothing to run home about and the service was mediocre. Felt overall that the menu was very overpriced and all the hype about the lobster rolls were disappointing. Espresso after dinner arrived late and luke warm as well as cold bread to start the dinner off.  The Angels on horseback were good as well as the calamari for the price compared to the main dishes. Probably would not go back due to overpriced dishes and so so service.  Ambiance is fun, and they do offer valet.
author: Jamie L.

description: I had high hopes for Anchor and Hope but it was kind of a letdown. The service was really slow and the food was just ok. I had the seared ahi tuna and it was really tough, not great flavor either. Not a very extensive menu. Probably wouldn't go back anytime soon.
author: Louise S.

description: Ok food. Not great. Service was not great but pleasant. Decor is good. Lighting is way too bright.
author: Sir M.

description: We really enjoyed our night here. The food was delicious, it's a beautiful space, and the wait staff was very nice. My husband asked for a change to his dish, and our waiter was completely helpful - went back to the chef to see if it was okay, and it was. Excellent beer list and nice wine list, too. Just very comfortable atmosphere, and was just what we were looking for our date night.
author: Jess H.

description: I went to Anchor and Hope for a simple and early evening of wine (Albarino) and Smörgsbord of delightfully fresh oysters and enjoyed the super fresh cod Brandade.  The space is what you want a south Financial District restaurant in the South of Market demarcation.  I remember this space years ago as a lunch restaurant but it's use as a seafood restaurant is what it should be--the FinDi needed a reasonably priced seafood restaurant.  The ambiance is comfortable and casual.  The service was very attentive.  A good experience.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: I went here for a friend's birthday and ended up paying $65. I never had oysters and was excited to try them, but was not a fan (so maybe my review is a bit biased...). I had a salmon salad which was pretty good, but nothing phenomenal, and quite pricey. The "Angels on Horseback" were VERY good and I would definitely suggest trying them. They are nothing I would ever crave, though, and they were expensive.
author: Steven M.

description:
The black and white piranha fish that adorn the walls are a nice touch. Even better if it gets you coverage in San Francisco's 7x7 magazine or some other sort of hipster publication. 

The ceviche was fresh and the seared tuna with mustard dijon sauce was tasty. The causal upscale atmosphere gave the dinner a nice ambiance. Perhaps the most notable portion of the evening was our waitress who was knowledgeable about the wine list, served us with impeccable service and was willing to chat jovially about the poem tattooed on her arm and her plans for tattoos to come.

A nice evening completed by a nice menu, waitstaff and blood sucking piranha decor.
author: Jenny T.

description:
I'd really like to give Anchor & Hope more stars. The food was great, but the service was so incredibly slow and inattentive.   Our server lacked any kind of charisma, let alone interest in being there.

Our wine glasses were brought out but we had to wait another 20 mins for the actual wine to arrive.  It took 40 mins to get our appetizers, dinner followed quite awhile after that.  In between courses our plates were never picked up, we had to put them on the table next to us.

So many reviews for bad service you think the management would correct this.  

We did enjoy the food, but unfortunately won't go back unless we hear the service has improved.
author: BH ..

description:
For a girls night out, we all visited Anchor & Hope to start the night out.

We had a couple of really nice bottles of wine and the food was pretty good.  Seafood was fresh and we were all happy with our apps & meals.

I especially enjoyed the service there!  We were there for a couple to few hours and never once felt rushed.  We never poured our own wine or water and our napkins were folded every time we left the table.

It has been a long time since I felt the money I spent at a reataurant was worth the meal and experience.  I'm glad I found Anchor & Hope and looking forward to my next experience there!
author: Janey K.

description: Anchor & Hope is a restaurant in the Soma district of San Francisco.  I wasn't happy with the service.  The food was very good.  Even though we came at lunchtime and it was somewhat busy ,we didn't need  a reservation.  All the tables are very close together and it's noisy so it's difficult to have a conversation.  I was listening to the men next to me.  My mother had Sashimi and an Ahi Poke. I had the Lobster salad on a grilled Brioche which I would  recommend. The kitchen was slow and it took awhile to get our food.  If your going to a museum or are in the neighborhood it's a place with good food for lunch.
author: Nicki B.

description:
I keep hoping that some of the newer nicer SF restaurants might get it right, but alas another $125 for food that is total crap.

The atmosphere is great the service is good, with a great beer & wine selection, but the sea food is terrible. We ordered appetizers of clam chowder way over seasoned & mostly milk, crab which was totally bland. The entrees of the grilled trout was mediocre & poorly presented, but the pepper corn ahi was not even edible.

If you like oysters shoot a few at the bar with a good beer, otherwise skip it.
author: Bill K.

description: We walked here on a busy Saturday night after our hotel's concierge recommended it and made a reservation (they were technically booked full but they would hold two seats at the bar). In a renovated warehouse next to a huge construction pit we found a wonderful dinner in a great space. The staff were courteous and friendly (and heavily tattooed!) and every dish we tried was absolutely super. We also had a great view of the kitchen staff at work, which is always fun to watch. We had "angels on horseback" (oysters wrapped in bacon), a dish of scallops and stuff (I forget what) in truffle mousse, and a delicious halibut served with toast and a great tomato sauce (yummy garlicky). The deserts were also a real treat: strawberry shortcake and a berry and rhubarb crisp. Drinks were also great (a nice IPA and pear cider). The noise level was very reasonable, our conversation was never drowned out.
author: Guido v.

description: Good Seafood Place!  Great oysters, and the salmon dish was great.  The dessert was AMAZING!  chocolate blackout cake with peanut brittle topping....awesome!!!  Some things are hit or miss (salads shrimp ceviche) but a good place all around. Great service very friendly.
author: Rebecca W.

description:
3.5 stars - it was a "good" experience.

I came here with a few friends since this restaurant was on the 2010 Big eat SF - 100 Things to Eat+Drink Before You Die list.

Though we didn't make reservations, we still were able to get seated - which was very nice.

The beer was good, the food was good, and the service was good. 

I'm still wondering why the Angels on Horseback is on the Must-Eat list though.  The beer was better.
author: Daphne L.

description:
I've now been to Town Hall, Salt House and Anchor & Hope. I like how they all seem unpretentious and relatively affordable by SF standards. I went here for the first time with a group for lunch and had high expectations. We started with fried clams and they were among the best I ever had. 

I ordered the Lobster Roll, being from the northeast and wanting a taste of home. Unfortunately, they tried to do too much with what is a very basic thing to make. The sauce overpowered the taste of the Lobster and in an attempt to make it high end, they defeated the purpose of why people love them. North Beach Lobster Shack is a better place for Lobster Rolls. 

The waiter forgot our side dishes so we never got to try them. We got the chocolate cake and strawberry crisp for dessert (comped becuase they forgot our sides) and they were very good. Service was slow and forgetful, but we loved the atmosphere.
author: Jason M.

description:
Things started off  a little shaky, the wine prices are quite high and the pours of questionable size, certainly  not generous.  Things picked up with appetizers, the oysters were incomparable, and the special scallop ceviche terrific.  But then thing took a nose dive on the main courses.  The softshell crab was tough and the lobster roll tasteless.  

Overall I liked the atmosphere and service.  But my biggest complaint is the prices are no where near justified by the quality of the food of the food.  This place is very expensive for what it is.   Better food and better prices are available in the neighborhood and in fact from the same proprietors at Salt House and Town Hall.
author: Robert G.

description:
Ok, so I know some of you ran into a lot of the problems and kinks this place has yet to work out, and we didn't have a full dinner but  from our experience: I have to give it five stars.

I went there for my birthday, wanted something snacky and lowkey with diverse beer selection and that's exactly what I got!

I was pleasantly surprised to see my beer of choice was carried at both Town Hall AND Anchor and Hope: La Fin Du Monde. YAY!

The one thing I KNEW I had to try, ever since I glanced the menu online, were the Angels on Horseback! A delicious concept of friend oysters wrapped in thick crispy bacon. Strangely enough, and yummy as it was, this was our least favorite of three appetizers and a side we tried out.

The sea urchin in the shell dish, a somewhat soup-esque dish with mashed potato and Dungeness crab made me orgasm a little.
Just a mini O, here and there, mind you. But, YOWIE!
I could have eaten a trough of it. Plain and simple.

The sea urchin dish tied with my other favorite of the evening:
The Fried Ipswich Clams.

This appetizer made up for me the fact that this seafood based restaurant had NO FRIED CALAMARI!  Seriously, it SHOULD have a star missing for the lack of calamari goodness, but I regress...

The fried clams were divine, the tartar sauce was classic and complimented them well. I could almost close my eyes and pretend there were tentacles.

The service was pretty good, Host was great, Server was a little too attentive at the beginning and a little too much less-so when we wanted to get out of there and celebrate my birthday elsewhere.

Overall though, if conditions are ideal: Anchor and Hope is a GREAT restuarant for getting together for some drinks and apps. + less costly than some of the other local restaurants of a similar caliber.

I will try a full dinner sometime soon, but my over all point is:

With app.s like that? Who needs it!
author: TheJane N.

description:
NO, NEVER GO THERE. THEY WANT YOUR MONEY NOT YOUR SATISFACTION. EVER WHEN THEY POISON YOU! Also VERY poor value.
I have been to Anchor and Hope 4 or 5 times. I am allergic to shell fish. This night I had a horrible reaction to the shell fish lace fish and chips. They did not call 911 but presented me a bill. I had a choice of paying or going into shock. When I went back for a refund the answer was NO.
author: mike w.

description: Funky location, but awesome interior. Noisy, so dont try to have a meeting here. The food was great but expensive. The sandwiches are really spicy, they add peppers to them so be careful. The lobster roll was delicious as were the angels on horseback.
author: Kim J.

description: One of my favorite places to go to San Francisco for happy hour. They have a pretty decent wine list, which they change pretty often. Good wine and beer selection for happy hour and amazing oysters and fries. They have a great selection of oyster's from west and east coast. I have also had dinner a couple of times, but I prefer the appetizers at happy hour. Love the warehouse, kind of weird location with the alley, but nice decorations.
author: Erin S.

description: Had dinner here last night with a couple of out of town guests.  The building itself is very nicely done, so great atmosphere - it was also hopping with people very late into the evening, so you would think it was a happening spot - also casual, so you didn't feel out of place in jeans and a sweater.  Our server was very nice and wasn't on top of us all night, but checked in enough that he also wasn't a distraction.  The food - Both the guests had the salad (without avacado) and they said it was pretty salty.  I had the clam chowder and it was also salty, so mabye a note to the chef - lay off the salt a bit - if I want salt I'll add it.  For entree I had the Halibut, it was grilled nicely and served on a balsamic reduction and garlic mashed potatoes - very tasty.  One of the guests had the gnocchi, which the portion was on the small side for the price.  Decent selection of tap beers - I had the Russian River Brewing Company draft - nice pairing with the meal - just a hint of something sweet in the blend.  We shared the pumpkin/gingerbread dessert item - that was really quite good with a mix of cake and ice cream - enough for two.  Might give them a chance again, but lots of other places to explore in the city, so it'll likely be on the back burner.
author: Steve A.

description:
Great service, good beer selection, and the antique light bulb collection is unparalleled!

It's clear that attention to detail is top priority.

Highly recommended.
author: jamie f.

description: Had the red snapper and the presentation was nice. it was good. The warm uni with lobster was quite delicious. Oysters, clam & shrimp was fresh.
author: Kat T.

description:
This place gets 5 stars for ONE reason, the Lobster Roll. We're in San Francisco, so we're not exactly on the right coast to be bragging about our lobster, so it's impressive to be able to find a place here that does Lobster Rolls proud, and Anchor and Hope definitely does it well!

I'm not a big fan of oysters, so if you're looking for a review of their selection keep looking, but I'm big on a delicious lobster roll, and A&H does it right. They have them for lunch for a couple bucks less, and for dinner as well, and both times you get their freshly made potato chips and sea salt.

Several others have commented on the price, but keep in mind you're getting a large amount of lobster, and it's not cheap these days, so put that into perspective.. for the money it's a nicely done restaurant and the price is fair for what you get.
author: Andrew B.

description:
This place is incredible.  Came last night with my parents.  Although I don't eat much seafood, the sole was incredible, and the salmon was perfect.  The chicken, well, the chicken restored my faith in chicken.  It was perfectly cooked, insanely juicy, in a delicious sauce.  I think it was the most delicious chicken I have ever eaten. 

The service was good and professional.  Our server knew the menu really well and dealt gracefully with my parents' banter/demands.  

And the beer list! It goes from light to dark, which was really helpful, and they had a lot of my favorites on there. 

The space was beautiful, I loved the anchor that came with our check.  Can't say enough great things about this place.
author: Cat F.

description:
Anchor and Hope is just another decent, overpriced  seafood theme restaurant. Went last night and left feeling disappointed

Service was decent though our waitress never smiled once throughout our dinner; told her we had had enough bread, yet she returned two more times to offer us more bread

Food was ok; had the Battered Cod which is nothing more than Fish and Chips; nothing really good or bad to say about it yet for the price, I expected more.  My wife had the oven roasted bass and she said there was absolutely no taste to the bass; the rest of the dish was ok

Just ok is the theme
author: Kevin H.

description:
Very nice experience here. Brought the a group of family and friends here on a Saturday night. Started with a drink at the bar and were brought to our table in a very timely manner - good selection of beers and wines  - but no real bar so no cocktails. Had an attentive waitress who had good suggestions. The food began to come and didn't stop for a while. We ordered a few of each oyster (compliments of dad who loves oysters). Then a few rounds of the asparagus salad. This was one of my favorite dishes of the night which is odd because i rarely enjoy asparagus and am only so-so on eggs and this had both of them. A fried egg topped the perfectly heated asparagus along with a light sauce and cheese. It was a wonderful blend of veggie flavor with creamy saucey goodness. The fresh bread as yummy and I always love when a restaurant has salt to drizzle on the butttered bread, they had this so that made me smile. We also ordered the angels on horseback to check off a list item. Again, they managed to make me like something I normally don't like! I am an avid non-bacon eater. I mean, if i even taste or smell the hint of bacon it turns me off of my meal. But because of my obsession I decided I'd have to suck it up and give it a taste at least. Well, I was pleasantly surprised, they were actually good. I stuck to my one bit - but the fact that it didn't make me scrunch up my face and wish I hadn't even had the bite is huge. So for all you normal people that love bacon, you'll love this, a lot, everyone else at the table did.  
For our main course we had the following:
Lobster roll - good but don't get this for dinner, it's a downer. But for lunch awesome. 
Steak - Great, perfectly cooked, juicy and flavorful
Halibut - delicious and fresh
Scallops and couscous - very good

I would recommend this place to anyone looking for some yummy yummy seafood. Atmosphere is really good too. We'll definitely be back.
author: Audrey V.

description:
I tried out Anchor & Hope last night for a company dinner. 

Here is what I loved: service, lobster roll, wine list, décor. 

Here is what I hated: rowdy happy hour folk, volume. 

Overall loved everything about the restaurant and only hated the noisy intoxicated people surrounding our table. A&H: no hard feelings about almost losing my voice trying to have a conversation. I love your food too much to hold it against you. I would definitely go back.
author: Rosie M.

description:
Went here to lunch with mama-san visting from the motherland... She was jonezing for some lobster so I suggested a lobster roll ..she'z never had one.. kind of suprising since she lived in the NYC for 20+ years..but NYC\Strong Island is not quite NE..anywayz.. i digress..

I read about this place in a paper somewhere so decided to check it out...

Food - pretty good ...we had the chowdah, the roll, and the crab claws...  

the chowdah was pretty rich....with the bread, mui excellente... 

the roll was really good... the potato chips and slaw were a hit!!... 

the crab claws were alright.. alot of work.. I dunno what I was thinking...

Price - it aint cheaps ..peeps... hmmm 9 bucks for a bowl of soup and 20 bones for a roll.. 4 samoleans for a claw...what do you expect? its frkn hip .. :)

Ambiance - pretty cool, nice decor.. enjoyed the space,  busy.. without noise being too much of an issue....

The beer was cold....Scrimshaw..oh yeah..tastee.. 

the staff and cooks were friendly... we sat at the bar and could say all the prep going on... those heirloom tomatoes lookd hecka good mang...

my only gripe.. took a while for me to order drinks.. I mean I was sitting for a good 5 minutes mang.. and I was sitting at the BAR...the roll came dead last so I was wondering if they forgot about it... but hey, was a day off and I was chillin' with my mom.. gotta keep it cool..:)

it's only been open about 3.5 months.so.. I guess we can forgive'em...

but you figure, for the prices we're paying the service could be on it... the folks were friendly but kinda spaced out mang..could just be the lunch crunch...anywayz..

a solid 3.5... 

I would definitely come here again...on a payday!! :)  .. BAR GOLF candidate baby!! ...oystahs (angels on horseback) and beer..oh yeah..
author: Roony P.

description:
I had dinner at Anchor and Hope with my cousin who was visiting from Philadelphia.

The dinner was outstanding, especially the snapper - rich in flavors and astonishingly moist.

But don't overlook the energetic bar scene and be sure to let the bartender make a recommendation for you.  He steered us in the right direction with some outstanding microbrews that we wouldn't have found otherwise.

Finally, service is top notch, from the adorable brunette hostess who continues to smile warmly and genuinely, even when the pace picks up to the management who is quick to step in and resolve any issue that would prevent an otherwise unforgettable experience.

Highly recommended, all around.
author: John G.

description:
Went here with some people from work on a wednesday night.

Service- they quickly move away the extra setting for our extra seat and the waiter was over quickly.  The water was poured and then a bottle was left on the table- which i very much appreciated.  The waiter gave an overview of his favorites for everything. Overall good service. 

Food-we ordered an assortment of starters- fries with eyes),  Angels on Horseback, scallop ceviche (I liked this), the sea urchin, crab, mashed potato mix- the best app in my book- and heirloom tomato salad.  The bread was served in a brown bag- kind of weird, but tasted good/fresh and had salted butter on the table.  

On to the mains- i had the curry sole- which was good- the other two mains my table tried were enjoy- i'm blanking on what one of them was, but the other was a tuna.  The selection was pretty good- there were several other fish dishes I was deciding between- so that is always a good thing.

Dessert- this may have been a half disappointment- there were only two choice- luckily for them both of them were very enjoyable- chocolate cake with chocolate pudding filling was good- but the heart of sweet cream was really good- i hope the next time i come they have expanded this selection...

Drinks: I had a glass of sonoma sauvignon blanc- it was good.  They had a nice selection of wines- almost all came by the glass which was a nice surprise.  They also have a pretty good beer selection.  I didn't see any cocktails.

Vegetarian selection- i only remember the heirloom tomato salad-which i had and would say is average- and the 'chefs special'- which you will have to look at other reviews for because with all the fish on the menu i will not be trying it. I guess you shouldn't be expecting veggies at a fish place- but this is sf so i thought i'd comment and I'm find myself looking for veggie/vegan reviews when i have veggies coming out with me.

Ambiance- the chairs are oddly light and seem like they have been spray painted their silver color.  The boat/fishing theme is there classed up a little, but didn't feel as fancy as salt house or town hall.  Try to get a table along the wall or the five seater in the alcover if you don't want some traffic around you.  The noise level was relatively low for sf.  The bathrooms were nothing special either- i always love to be surprise with a nice bathroom like umami- i'll have to keep looking.

Even though none of the parts were amazing the overall experience was really nice and I will likely come back if i need a work dinner location that is close to the office.
author: Maria F.

description:
I love going to Anchor & Hope because the food is consistently good, the team pays attention to the diners, and they have great wine recommendations (try the Demetria).  And, because they are in my neighborhood, I tend to eat here at least twice a week.

Foodwise - the fish and chips is delicious because it so light and perfectly crispy.  The chowder is divine because it's not a brick of cream in your stomach and the corn kernels are sweet crisp nuggets.  The oysters are delicious and the servers are great at describing the flavors and making suggestions.  The salmon gravlax is very well done, it's rich tasting but not overpoweringly fishy.  The fish stew is tasty but I would have preferred it to be spicier.  The sea urchin appetizer is worth a taste because it's a fun way to present it and keep the briny taste of the sea urchin to a minimum.  

Desserts - the sweet cream heart is refreshing and light, the chocolate cake has an amazing top layer of salt, chocolate, and nuts and the meyer lemon tart is tangy without being bitter.

Ambiance - there's a lot of energy and chatter in the room but it is not overwhelming.  The crowd is varied in terms of suits to jeans and a variety of ages.  

The team - this staff is fabulous!!!  The servers are knowledgeable and easy going.  Chad is a riot!!  Brady does a great job making things happen.

An update from last night's dinner on 8/19:  The trout salad is perfect in it's salty goodness.  The lardons add just enough salt to make your tongue tingle with pleasure.  The egg was perfectly poached and oozed beautifully across the salad. The trout comes across with a true fish flavor and the greens offer a refreshing texture to the dish.  Mmmmm.
author: Serena L.

description:
The last time I was at Anchor and Hope it was a great experience.  Lively atmosphere, good food, great service.
But we went there again last night for a birthday dinner. The service was painfully slow (a half hour after our plates removed was the pre-requested birthday dessert delivered) and the food ordinary, at best.  I know they can do better given their pedigree. There are just too many fantastic restaurants in the city to tolerate mediocrity.
author: Layne G.

description: The restaurant is stylish and cozy.  But we went on the hottest day in the summer - no air-con inside! I was sweating and falling asleep halfway through my meal...
author: Lisa L.

description:
This was my second time eating here and the food is great.   The nautical  ambiance makes you think that you are in an Oyster bar in the Hamptons, but with more of a city feel.

Service is friendly and the wine selection is fairly extensive.  I had steamed clams in a garlic basil broth for appetizer.  For the entree, I had a seafood paella.  It wasn't served traditionally Spanish style but still delicious.  I could have done without the half steamed dungeness  crab on top of the plate. (It got a little messy) The chorizo and mussels were enough.  

Would recommend this place for anyone looking for a good oyster bar/seafood restaurant downtown.
author: Arthur L.

description: 4 stars for food take away 1 for the waitress.  She should spend less time talking to her friends (she SAT a few tables away talking to her friends, we see you!!) lol.  We waited to order drinks, order dessert, and yes waited finally for the check.  Eh, whatcha gonna do.
author: Todd C.

description:
Had a great time here.  The food was excellent.  Had the oyster-wrapped bacon, fried artichokes, lobster roll, and brownies with cherry ice cream.  All were very delicious.  I really love the ambiance of the restaurant.

I've been several times.
I think overall, it's a great experience.
I had the mussels a few months ago, and it was great.  When we went again about a month later, it was still good, but not as great as the time before - thus the 4 star rating.
author: Leslie L.

description: After recommendation from San Francisco Magazine, I went yesterday. Interesting location in a converted warehouse. The Tuna melt sandwich was excellent, definitely not from the can. However, price tag: $13.00
author: D T.

description:
My friend and I went to a late lunch at Anchor & Hope during the middle of the work week.  

We had reservations so when we arrived we were promptly seated.  But overall I would say the service was slightly slow throughout the rest of the meal.  It was a late lunch and not in the middle of the lunch rush hour, so I was a little surprised by it.

Bread comes in a paper bag, which some people don't enjoy, but I thought it was a fun little twist.  I had the lobster roll, which was really good and prepared well.  The lobster was moist and not overcooked, and the dressing was well seasoned.  

The prices are a little high compared to other great seafood restaurants in the city, but if you have the extra dollars I would still say to go and try it out.
author: Cathy A.

description:
So this place was pretty crowded when we went here for dinner on Friday at 8:30. The space is LOUD. Brick walls and an space make for lots of bouncing sound. But it gives the restaurant a certain energy at the same time.

I didn't have any oysters from the raw bar, (I'm apparently spoiled and had some at home before going to dinner), but I noted they had Kumamotos, Miyagis, Kusshis, Beau Soleils, Malpaques, and Island Creeks. I'm an aficionado, but I was trying to save room for the...

Angels on Horseback (a.k.a. Bacon-wrapped oysters):
What can I say? Wrapping food in bacon is cheating. It automatically wins +1000 points. Especially when aforesaid bacon is wrapped around one of my other favorite foods (goodness, could you imagine bacon-wrapped foie gras? I would die. I bet someone has done it. If you know where to get this, let me know!!). So how were they? In all honesty, I don't know if they lived up to the hype. Perhaps it's because I'm more of a fan of raw oysters. And I also probably had built them up in my head, so really, maybe it's my fault. However, I will say, I admired the textural contrast between the soft, delicate oyster and the crisp bacon (well, the parts that were crisp, anyway). And these things looked like a pain to make. I asked our server what varietal the oysters were and she said that they are made with Blue Points. I noted that the shells looked more like Miyagi's, and she said that they do use a variety of shells, but that the oysters were always Blue Points. Interesting. But believable. Blue points are generally less expensive too, I think. I thought the remoulade was a bit flat, but adding a squeeze of lemon really brightened the flavor.

Honey Mustard Trout: Wow. What an interesting combination of flavors! Admittedly, on my first bite, I was a bit overwhelmed by the mustard (I apparently am terrible at reading and retaining--the mustard was totally unexpected). However, the flavors really melded well together upon further....mastication. And the trout was cooked perfectly, with a bit of dill weed and lemon peel in the center cavity, which infused every bite with a subtle flavor. Very impressive. However, I was not as impressed with the bed o' pinto beans. The flavor was okay (as in, it didn't do it for me, but I also was not revolted by it) and improved slightly when combined with the watercress (I thought the watercress should have been wilted a bit, but then realized they are relying on the fish's heat to wilt it--with mixed results), but it's really hard to get the texture of beans "just right," as there's a thin line between that and mushy. I also think "just right" can be pretty subjective; I think these were just too underdone for my taste.

Petrale Sole: Again, a really interesting combination of flavors. The sole was fine, but the smokiness of the tomatoes really penetrated the fish and added a lot of complexity. I will say, some tasted like roasted red peppers, which was too overpowering. Those potatoes though! I can't say that I've had smoky potatoes, but these were fascinating (in a really good way)! Very enjoyable.

I was pretty impressed by the beer list (lots of bottles, but on the pricier side).

Service was a mixed bag. It took ages for our server to take our drink order (in fact, I was ready to order my entree by this time, and that NEVER happens). During dinner, the service was good...and then tapered off again.

One thing that I noted: They serve bread in a paper bag. I personally think this is just trying too hard. It's kinda tacky, actually (think, "this is how I buy it in the supermarket!"). And it's a waste of a bag.

Overall, I admire the creativity of the dishes. I'd come here again if someone else was interested, but might not go out of my way otherwise.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Mmmm...uni appetizer is so yummy.  That's all I wanted that day.  It has uni, crab, potato, and creamy goodness inside the actually uni shell.  It was paired with an order of fries that came with a savory aioli and a cold glass of happy hour beer and I was a happy girl.  LOVE the decor (little fish chasing big fish trying to eat smaller fish)  and casual vibe of the place.  Bartender was really cool and gave me a sample of a couple beers since I couldn't decide what I wanted.  Can't wait to have a full meal there!
author: Nina L.

description: Been here twice. First for lunch and then for dinner. Lunch was decent. The atmosphere was chill and the service was reasonable for how crowded it gets during lunch. I came back for dinner because of the $1 oysters and happy hour specials. I heard raves about the happy hour menu but really you can choose from one type of wine and one featured beer. It was four of us, and after a few $1 oysters, three rounds of drinks and some fries - total bill $130. Little steep for happy hour.
author: johanna a.

description:
well, three of us went out for dinner.. 
we had local beer and oyster bar for appetizer and had cod, scallop, and lobster roll.  I would give 4 stars to scallop and lobster roll and appreciate their local draft beer list.  but.. the service was horrible. delayed.. not at all attentive. server changed without a notice. and delayed. . unfortunately, felt like we were not welcomed there. my friends were huge fans of the restaurant but after all this.. the food tastes bitter. 
I hope my experience today was a personal thing because I've seen many new restaurants built up unnecessary attitude over the time.
author: soson j.

description:
The good: the clam chowder is really good and our waitress was nice and fast.
The bad: Absolutely the worst softshell crab I have ever had.  Its the first dish I have ever sent back.  Most of the other food is mediocre.  They were 20 minutes late seating us and the hostess was a bit rude.  When I asked the bartender for a suggestion for a beer, he suggested a canned beer....I was suprised it wasn't Meister Brau or Old Milwaukee.  I bought my date a glass of wine, the bartender took my $20 bill and did not give me change.  I had to ask him to give me change 10 minutes later...in the 15 years I've been going to bars this is the first time I have ever had a bartender do that.  If you are looking for good seafood, I would highly suggest going somewhere else...most of the dishes are fried and have a high French influence...which for me ruins seafood.
author: Jimmy S.

description: What I love about this place is it really brings home the New England vibe. The seafood is of excellent quality, probably one of the best in San Francisco. The Angels on Horseback appetizer is quite the mouthwatering experience. It's the only place on the west coast that does Lobster rolls right. Their beer selection is outstanding, a plethora of micro brews from all over the world.  Service is great as well.
author: Marco M.

description:
You definitely pay for what you get here. 

Yes, a bit pricey, but well worth it. It's not too difficult to pay $20 a plate during lunch in the financial district these days. 

The GF and I went there the other day to check it out.
No reservations, no problem; they sat us right away.

We started off with the BBQ shrimp. They had a nice char to them and were very simple. They tasted just like they should.

I got the lamb burger. You know, the kind that melts in your mouth. It came on a ciabatta roll of some sort with carmelized onions, bacon and bleu cheese. The only bummer was the fries. They were sliced so thin that they were hard to eat. And I wanted to eat them all they were so good. 

She got the tuna melt, which came with a very simple salad. The tuna was great, on a roll and was cooked like a panini. All the flavors were there and no ingredients overwhelmed the others. 

The portions are great, the menu diverse and the staff friendly. Our bill came to $45, but was worth every penny. 

I'm very much looking forward to round 2.
author: B B.

description: Just finished my third dinner at Anchor and Hope and it has officially become one of my favorite restaurants in SF.  The oysters are awesome as are the entrees.  I've had the lobster roll twice and it is freaking' amazing.  You should also get an order of fries for the table because they rock.  They have an ample wine and beer list...actually it's a huge beer list...and the corkage fee is $20.  I'll definitely be back many more times.
author: Bryan B.

description:
After sitting us by the main entrance with the glass door opening every 5 minutes, we requested to be seated at a table in the main dining area.  The hostess honored our request and made the table ready within 10 minutes which we most appreciated.
Most dishes were delicious, especially the fish and chip where the batter was light and the fish (cod?) was equally tender.  Sea urchin with crab meat in mashed potato had a stunning effect when presented. Fried calamari was also well executed, tender, crispy and light.  Our guests also like the lightly fried smelt with herb.  Overall, A&H did a wonderful job at lightly fried/tempura items.  Weakness came with our two entrees, the signature lobster roll was too salty and lobster meat over-cooked.   The flank steak, still pink inside, was bland, salty and tasteless.  They should stick with what they do best.
Scene was energetic, especially for late night snack.  Not exactly an alternative for NOPA or Salt House but I will go back once in a while.
author: Foodie C.

description: Solidly executed, if not super-interesting, food. We had the "angels on horseback", the fried artichokes, Monterey sardines, and spiced scallops.  The spiced scallops were incredible - a nuanced, well-prepared dish.  The sardines were really good, and the others were tasty.  Like the atmosphere and vibe.  Would love to go back and sit at the bar for oysters and beer.
author: Leah S.

description: The space is really cool, and the food was amazing.  Our server Kimo recommended the sea urchin which I was nervous to try, but it was so good.  The Angels on Horses was dreamy and the asparagus salad was perfectly balanced.  The somalier was very knowledgeable and recommended some amazing wines.  We had a great meal and we'll be back for lunch.
author: Greg G.

description:
Chi-Chi SF take on an East Coast fish house. 

Food is way overpriced but good, that is if you ever get it. I've been here twice & each time the service was horrendous. 

We waited a LONG LONG time for someone to take our order, then waited and waited and waited for our food to show up. We barely saw our server, and she had a major attitude the few times she did appear. We tried getting other servers' attention, but they were all doing that I'm going-pretend-I-don't-see-you super fast walk by. For the prices they're charging, I expect much better service than that.
author: Lisa M.

description: A great sea food restaurant all around. Top quality raw bar, excellent entrees, great beer and wine selections. Ideal for date night.
author: Mark L.

description:
Our hostess was extremely nice!

Tried the clam appetizer and they were delicious. 

I couldn't help but order the lobster roll. It was good and looked small, but I couldn't finish the chips (a little on the salty side) or the cole slaw, so the sizes are deceiving.
author: Retired B.

description: Its the the best fresh seafood in San Francisco!! The beers are great too! When i work late I am there for supper! There is always good fresh fish on the menu. I like to do 4 o'clock dash there for some of their chowder! yum! I work round the corner so I am a regular!
author: Andrew S.

description: Everything was really good, but the portions were small.   The lobster roll was lobster salad tucked into really fat bread.  The sea urchin was good, but very little urchin mixed with chowder over mashed potatoes - with all that, it was still a small serving.  Also, there was not a full bar.  In a place like that, i would have liked to see some unusual cocktails.  I am not a big beer and wine fan.  In summary, we had a nice night, but I doubt we will go back.
author: Cathy F.

description:
I came here because I saw the warm sea urchin dish from Best Thing I've Ever Ate. The uni was delicious. I also ordered the halibut, which was worth the price for the amount you get.

I gave it 4 stars because the uni dish was not too good when I went back the second time. There was less crab and only one piece of uni. The sauce was also too watery.

We ordered a side of french fries, which were awesome! I would go back again hoping that the uni dish next time will be better.
author: Denise L.

description: Fresh oysters, refreshing little gem +mint salad. Angels and horseback were good, but not great. Uni was great--rich, but great.
author: Ali A.

description: Not very impressed with the warm uni -- I was sooo looking forward to that.  Presentation was nice.  Everything came in very small portions and was overpriced except for the $1 happy hour oyster special which was so-so quality.  I liked the lobster roll the best, but again, tiny 2 bite portion.  The baked clams and calamari was just ok.
author: Sophie K.

description:
Yes. Overall; and perhaps (yes, I'm employing a semicolon here) my high marks are a smidge bias. (I did have exceptional company and service.) And did we really eat from the bowl of a sea urchin?? Again Yes. Whatever, take it as you will or won't. The atmosphere is a bit stark and too white-cool but the ropes above are whimsical enough to imagine climbing out from anything too unbearable. Loved, loved our Kimo service! Top notch. Thank you.
If you don't do oysters, like the "OC" gal next to us, somebody else more bold might ask "why bother?" F*ing fantastic--except for the lil too creamy, BIG local bay ones... I forget their "T" beginning name??
Scrumptious effort. Just go! duh.
Didn't even think of dessert, a usual must hear at least for me. hmmpf.
author: Deb D.

description: This restaurant has a great ambiance. The West Coast Oysters were nice followed by a pretty good ceviche. The fish and chips was pretty good, and the linguine with manilla clams was utterly fabulous - the sauce was a fantastic blend of flavors that paired perfectly with the delicate clams and linguine. Fabulous. Order it!
author: Nick P.

description: Showed up with 10 people on a Monday night at 9:20pm. They should have hugged every one of us considering the day of the week, time and size of our party.  Appetizers arrived promptly.  Main courses arrived over one hour after we finished our appetizers. Our server didn't say a word about the delay (before or after they arrived), and there couldn't have been more than 15 customers in the entire place, so they couldn't have been jammed. Props to the bartenders, when we could not locate our server and asked one of the them about our main courses, he followed up, updated us and apologized.  Ten people = automatic gratuity = server complacence.  Food was decent (third time here, it's not spectactular, but is at least decent), but will probably think twice before eating here again.
author: Boss H.

description: I've come here a few times for happy hour. $1 oysters and a glass of tripel always end in good times. In my last visit we decided to try an item from the full menu. We ordered the "signature dish", warm sea urchin with dungenous crab and lemon. I've never had sea urchin before but I was definitely up for the challenge. I made the mistake of gathering a huge spoonful and stuffing it in my mouth. The taste was different, still not sure how I feel about it to this day. I think I'm willing to try it three or four more times to fully understand it, and I'm sure it would help trying it prepared differently in the future. But aside from the sea urchin, the crab was amazing. It was drenched in a chowder of lemony butter and potato puree. Every bite melted in my mouth and it was so full of flavor. There was a fresh herb, possibly dill, that gave the dish a really great organic aftertaste. I tried to incorporate sea urchin to each bite once I built up the courage, and together it was amazingly delicious.
author: MaryAnn C.

description: Ive heard lots of good things about Anchor & Hope.  I wasnt too impressed, maybe cause I followed it by dining at Boulevard the night before.  The decor is awesome, really trendy and clean.  I had the lobster sandwich which was definitely above average.  Its probably the only thing on the menu I wanted to try.  Its a heavy meal so if you plan on going out afterwards... you might feel the effects of a heavy food coma.  The prices were a little high, as it was about the same as Boulevard but not as good.  The waitstaff also... I dont know it was questionable.  They were pretty rushy about everything and didnt let me enjoy my meal.  The dessert choices looked great but I was wayyyy too full!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
It's a rich man's seafood-themed pub with an identity crisis - it has one foot in "rustic pub" land and the other in "high-priced hangout with upscale food and wine" territory.  Their pride and joy appears to be their beer selection, which is impressive, but they seem awfully eager to cater also to the wine crowd as well.  They offer lobster roll and a fancified fish & chips alongside "cornmeal crusted slow baked loch duart salmon" served with "heirloom beets" and a "red wind reduction" and "spice crusted sea scallops with Israeli cous cous ..."  They serve bread in a brown bag, but their butter softened in a white ceramic container and topped with sea salt.  They claim to be a fish house, but they have almost as many meat entrees, which from the looks of the short ribs at the next table, would have been a better choice than our fish entrees.  It feels like it should be a casual place, but most people were dressed quite nicely (men in suits, ladies in dresses, skirts, slacks).

We were not so thrilled with the food.  Apart from the recommended Angels on Horseback, which I hated (apparently not even bacon can make me a lover of cooked oyster), nothing was particularly bad.  For the prices they charge, however, things should be at least a noncommittal "good," and they weren't even that.  The clam chowder wasn't simmered long enough for all of the ingredients to meld, which was fine, but not good.  The salmon tasted fine, the beets on that plate were fine, but again, none of it affirmatively good.  The battered cod was the only dish that I actually enjoyed, but it still would not make my top three.

Even the decor is a bit disjointed.  The bar is appealing in a clean, sophisticated way, as are the tuna fish patter along the wall behind the bar and the light fixtures throughout the restaurant, in a whimsical sense.  But then you have the exposed brick and unfinished ceiling beams with thick, rough rope draped around it.  I get that it's all with an eye toward a deep sea/nautical theme.  It just seems a little undecided.

Given my lukewarm impression of the whole experience, this would have been a 2-star review, except that the restaurant was packed with well-dressed familes and co-workers that seemed to appreciate and enjoy the place in all its schizo-glory, starting with beer and apps (salad, or maybe clams over squid ink risotto (sounds better than it tastes), or a tray of oysters), and moving on to wine and entrees. It was bustling, others seemed happy with their meals, and by the time we were leaving, there was a bit of a wait.  It got me thinking maybe we just did this all wrong - ordered the wrong food, had the wrong expectations.  I probably won't be back to confirm either way, but it seemed enough to tack a star back on.

Pros:  Beer, including beer flights; nice atmosphere and crowd; friendly waitstaff; substantial and aesthetically pleasing bar area

Cons:  Mediocre food on average (not very high highlights and some very bad lowlights); uncomfortable chairs
author: Alice C.

description: Fantastic beer selection, very good food.  Nice spot in SOMA for happy hour, clientele leans towards the "greyhairs."
author: B R.

description:
My husband have been to Town Hall and Salt Hoise, so our expectations do Anchor and Hope were high! The other two being phenomenal!  We walked in, the ambiance seemed lovely, open, loud, great! Loved the Devore and the details (ropes from e ceiling, writing in the light bulbs, etc.  Alas, that's where the wow ended. 
We had to wait forever for the waiter (I don't want to name names, but i do remember who hi was) to come and take our drink order. Then, finally when he came to take our drink order we were ready to place our food ordr, but he left to place our drink order and took forever coming back to take our food and didn't even have our drinks ready! We ordered the octopus appetizer. He did warn about e smokey flavor, but it was WAAAY too smokey. Overwhelmingly smokey. They for our main dishes my husband ordered the lobster roll which we both liked a lot, the challah was great, and I ordered the soft shell crab/prosciutto sandwich. We waiting awhile for our main dish and when it came I looked at the side and it was something breaded. I lifted up the bread on top and it was breaded fried shrimp, rather than soft shell crab. Our waiter was nowhere to be found, so I asked another waitress, talking to her customers two tables away if the sandwich was supposed to have soft shell crab and not shrimp. She said yes, but that they had run out if the crab. Out waiter never told me that. I would have ordered something else had I known that. Finally, our waiter came over and I told him that I got shrimp. He said that e kitchen told him that they had one sandwich left and he was sorry. Offered tomhave them make something else, but we had waited SOOO long already, I didn't have time to wait for my mnext meal. Needless to say it was SUPER spacey, flavorless and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.  I had e most sour flavor in my mouth at this point and it turned even worse when he LEFT THE ITEM on our bill! I coldn't believe it! How dare he make us pay FULL PRICE for his or the kitchen's mistake. Needless to say, his tip was super slighted. 

Sorry, we will not be going back as the customer service and food just did not meet up to SF standards. There are far more restaurants to go to that are better and make their customers feel welcome.
author: Jessica K.

description:
As an update, we have been back to anchor and hope twice as a treat. We have tried most of their main entries and they are always delicious.

We have found that we very much enjoy eating at the bar rather than the tables. The bar has a lovely atmosphere and the bar tenders are terrific. you can get a full menu at the bar.
author: Fog N.

description:
My 3 friends ate there on the the 26th of Feb., ordered some oysters from Washington State, and got food poisoning all weekend.  

Yuck!
author: Eebee H.

description:
came in last night on a whim while in the soma/fidi district.couple friends were yearning for some of Town Halls fried chicken but i convinced them all we should check out the third sister restaurant(second being salt house)found 3 spots at the bar and started diving into there extensive beer selection.the place seemed to have a very cool vibe,not crazy busy,just right.Very cool decour and east coast fish house feel to it.we decided to start with some calamari ,tuna poke,and some fresh oyesters(the bacon wrapped oyesters seemed directed towards people that dont really like oyesters to begin with,anyways...)every thing was great,calamari nice and light,killer dipping sauce,poke was freaking awesome,and oyesters were well...FRESH.now im not the biggest beer drinker but the bartender(sabastion?)was compelled to find me the right beer.I wasnt expecting him to take the time to find a beer that i enjoyed with lil tasters,especially since we werent the only patrons at the bar.not only did he find me and my friends beers that we loved (russian river concecration)he seemed genuily excited in pleasin our taste buds and chatting about our evenings. We ended up sharing some entrees,scallops were good,scallops them selves seemed a little burnt but the cous cous was stellar.the real winner was the salmon(bartenders recommendation)perfectly cooked with ever so tasty mushrooms.
All in all i really enjoyed myself,as well as my friends did.food was great,service was great and personable,cant ask for a whole lot more.

oooh and they have dollar oyesters all week long from 430-6 happy hour!!!

will definitely return
author: Betty T.

description:
After anxiously awaiting my first dining experience at the much hyped Anchor and Hope, I left disappointed.  The ambiance is nice, yes.  I can tell they put a lot of effort into the design.  And, the location is great, too...half a block away from my place of work.  But, other than that...the menu is mediocre and the best thing I had was the bread and butter.  And make note: its a beer and wine only bar...poo. 

We ordered the angels on horseback (fried, bacon wrapped oysters), the fries with eyes, the warm sea urchin in the shell, the black sea bass and the lobster roll.  Out of all these, I'd say the sea urchin was the only thing that I "mmm'ed" about.  Everything else was disappointing.  And, I feel like the only reason I liked the sea urchin was because it was mostly buttery mashed potatoes. The fries with eyes are not as scary as they sound...but I'd pick a fried fish filet over those any day.

Our entrees were the most disappointing.  I had never had a lobster roll before, and if this lobster roll is representative of what a lobster roll should taste like, then I would say that lobster rolls are completely over-rated.  Anchor and Hope's lobster roll was bland, unexciting and I felt like the lobster was undercooked.  The lobster meat was too soft and somewhat slimy.  And, it was basically just lobster, mayonnaise and some parsley.  Very under seasoned.  And, it was difficult to eat by hand...just skip taking a bite out of it and use your utensils to avoid a huge mess.  The sea bass was equally unexciting. The best thing about it were the stewed peaches...other than that there were no exciting flavors...very bland and forgettable.

There are two other issues that need to be addressed.  The first, and most important, is the seating issue we had.  The place was nearly empty, on a Sunday night.  We were seated at a table along the wall on the right, where there were about 10 tables lined up, none of which were occupied.  About 15 minutes after we were seated, the hostess seats another couple at the table immediately next to us-instead of choosing one of the other 15 open tables.  Why would you seat the table next to us (I'm talking 1 foot away), when you have SO MANY other open tables available?  It was cramped, and we felt like we were basically having dinner with this other couple, listening to each other's conversation with no privacy.  It  ruined the ambiance of our meal.  Terrible seating choice by the hostess- it really impacted my experience. Taking away 1 star for that blunder.  Second issue: watch out for the splinters on the bench seating along the wall.  We were picking out splinters from our clothes and/or skin for an hour after sitting on the bench seating.  And ladies: if you're wearing tights, ask to be seated in a chair to avoid ruining your stockings.

All in all:  'aint nothin' to write home about.  For seafood, Cafe Maritime has toads got this place beat.
author: Genevieve M.

description: This is another one of those fancy-looking establishments that has based its profit model on providing an elegant setting where FiDi denizens may conduct business, and good value comes in a distant second as a priority. The bacon-wrapped oysters were delicious, but the calamari was clearly one of those perfunctory items that restaurants throw on menus because they're expected to. For lunch, I had the crab louis, which was expensive and tiny. A mountain of salad next to a handful of crab meat (a child's handful, at that), is not a real entree. At least it tasted good.
author: Angela X.

description:
randomly crashed a dinner here at anchor & hope at the last minute, and i'm glad i did! had no idea what to expect since i hadn't heard of the place prior, but was delighted at the menu. clam and corn chowder, sea urchin with mashed potatoes and crab, clam strips (!), lobster roll, an oyster bar and a veggie option called "chef's delight," nice! so i tried a little bit of the appetizers already on the table upon my arrival: sea urchin (rich, creamy and flavorful) and clam strips (meaty but a bit salty). then narrowed my entree choices to the chef's delight or the lobster roll, and the lobster roll won out. and good thing too because i'd highly recommend it. it was kinda massive especially with the side of kettle chips but i powered through and inhaled it. the other entrees were ok, if not a tad too salty.

service was very accomodating. and i dug the design elements including the hand-written menus, the etched light bulbs, the fish eye/egg lamps and lofty space. watch out for splinters on the bench seating though, ouchie!
author: spiff e.

description: Dined there twice. Even on a Friday nite at 930pm the place was packed, but we were able to get a table without waiting. Oyster selection is outstanding; the Malpeque is one of my favs. Waitstaff is excellent and very attentive.
author: Antoine C.

description:
the open, raw and airy feel reminded me of a nyc loft.  simple and unpretentious, the decor was reflective of the owner.

a dear friend of mine took me out for an early bday lunch.  people get so hung up about getting older, i just like any excuse to eat with friends.

like the space, the menu was simple but intriguing.  
1. the chowder was a must.  i rarely eat bread so that i don't fill up but i had to sop every bit of the soup.  licking the bowl was tempting but not too elegant.
2. the asparagus salad was ok.
3. the fried pearl onions were tasty.
4. the sardines sandwich was well balanced
though i might try the salmon next time.
5. oysters are always a sure thing
6. the thai snapper ceviche is a must!
7. the salmon has a kicky sauce
8. the tuna is just deelish

we chatted and sipped pressed americano and cappucino in oversized cups.  
dessert was a berry crumble.  again simple and homey.
