the cheese plate was a medley of three cheeses that changes.
  
the service was friendly and very attentive.  

overall, it was simply....fab.
author: Anh V.

description: We finally checked out Anchor and Hope last night. I'd heard mixed feedback from friends so had put it off for quite a while although I'd been interested in trying it since before they'd even opened. Anyway, we decided to try a bunch of things and share. We had the uni, fried calimari, burrata salad, kampachi crudo, shrimp ceviche, and roasted prawns. The uni was super rich and I felt the sauce overpowered the uni. The roasted prawns were my favorite bite of the night, eaten whole, shell and all, delicious. The bread was fantastic, Acme of course. Really enjoyed the cinnamon sugar doughnuts with berry jam and mascarpone and the moscato wine, nice way to end the evening.
author: Sarah R.

description: One of the best dining experiences in SF! they were courteous, generous and didn't try to turn our table. it was like being in france! loved it...every bite
author: Michelle S.

description: We went here for the first time recently. It was a party of six on a slow Monday night, so we weren't sure what to expect. Fortunately, we were spoiled! Several of us got their version of a Maine lobster roll which was amazing and served on a thick, squarish, toasted bun with homemade chips and Barbara's slaw on the side. My wife even enjoyed the chef's veg dish (which, at many meat or fish houses, can amount to a lame afterthought of soggy veggies). The drink list was great and the desserts were delicious - especially the lemon meringue "pie" in a jar! Almost an hour after the kitchen closed and the place had entirely cleared out, the staff patiently served us without 'tude until the bitter end - even hailing a cab for one of our out-of-towners! Love this place!
author: Dan B.

description:
When someone is taking me to a free dinner, it automatically puts me in a great mood. Anchor and Hope kept that mood going with their great service, food and ambiance though.
Scott, Danny, Natalie and I dined here last weekend after our event at the Ferry Building concluded. We snagged a reservation pretty quickly just prior to getting there and were lucky enough to find parking right in front on the street. Our waitress was incredibly knowledgeable and personable from the start. We went with 1/2 dozen Malbec and a 1/2 dozen of another kind of oyster I've forgotten, the bay shrimp ceviche and the Angels on Horseback (aka bacon wrapped oysters) for our starters. The oysters were fabulously fresh and the Angels on Horseback were pretty great too. The ceviche was just okay for me but I'm not a fan of shrimp ceviche.
For the main course I went with the Petrale Sole and I was skeptical of it's curry sauce in the menu description but fell in love at first bite. Simply delicious and a whole new take on a favorite fish of mine. Natalie had the mussels and Scott the ahi tuna while Danny joined me on the sole side of things. I think we had the best main entrees. It was all accompanied by about a bottle and a half of a great white wine whose name escapes me. Dessert found us sharing the apple pie with hazelnut ice cream and the cheese plate. Loved the cheese plate but honestly the apple pie wasn't that remarkable and we only got it because Danny was amused at the "warm apple pie" description by our waitress and how it reminded him of that scene in "American Pie". 
Yeah, he's kind of an ass like that.
author: Jill D.

description:
Let me set up the situation. I came on a Saturday night with my sister and and her husband. We were eating on the later end (around 9) and went in without a reservation. The hostess offered us bar seating but then said she had a table leaving and just had to re-set the table. Somehow, resetting the table took about 20 minutes. The decor/ambiance is definitely cute - minimalist/nautical. The bartender was friendly and walked us through the beer selection while we waited. 

Once seated, I found our waitress to be on the aloof side, never coming by to see if we needed anything after we were served. Don't get me wrong, I don't need someone asking me how everything is every 10 minutes, but its helpful for a waiter to stroll by, catch someone's eye from the table and give them the opportunity to call him/her over if they need something. Between our appetizers and entrees, the wait was inordinately long.

Now about the food. 

I agree with a previous reviewer that the bread arriving in a bag evoked an expectation of just-out-of-the-oven-hot. It was not. I would suggest that the restaurant then do away with the wasteful bags and serve the bread in some other re-usable vessel that is appropriate to the decor. The bread itself was only ok. 

Our group had 2 of the soups to start: clam chowder and what I think was a special soup with ramp. The ramp soup was very good, but the clam chowder flavor was overpowered by the bacon. Being a bacon fan, this is not such a bad thing, but when you are in the mood for the flavors of a good clam chowder, this soup does not deliver.

For entrees, we had 2 orders of the scallops with Israeli couscous, the chorizo and mussel stew, and a side of the broccoli raab. The scallops were delicious and the brccoli raab perfectly cooked. The stew was good as well, but had a questionable consistency to the chorizo meatballs. We asked the waitress if the meatballs were thoroughly cooked and she took the whole dish back to the kitchen to ask. Upon her return, she was suddenly the expert on the preparation and meat quality of chorizo. She said that the texture of the meat and its ability to retain moisture was why the meatballs were still seemingly raw and assured us that they were fully cooked. After dinner, I told her that our family uses chorizo regularly and that is the first time I had heard of the reasoning she gave us, but we let it go. 

For dessert, we tried the Bailey's milkshake and the chocolate cake. Both very good although the milkshake was more original. The oatmeal cookies that came with the milkshake seemed like an afterthought.

Now for my favorite part: the cost vs. product quality. I understand that ambiance is very important in a dining experience, but I think restaurants in the city lean too heavily on that when it comes to pricing. Just because there are clean lines to the furniture, whacky light fixtures, and the building used to be a garage/firehouse/what-have-you, it doesn't mean that the food price qualifies for a major bump up. Food quality and service are what should be the main factor. The service here left much to be desired. It is the food quality that helps give my rating a solid 3. There's something about the menu options that bothers me but I haven't been able to zero in on it. As I said, just a solid 3 stars. It's definitely on the over-priced side.
author: Maria Y.

description:
I'm a fan of the food and style boasted by the Salt House and Town Hall, so I was eager to try Anchor & Hope and was  not disappointed. We were a late-dining party of five, and aside from feeling somewhat rushed through the meal, everything was pretty great. 

The restaurant itself boasts a charming vibe of sea shanty crab shack meets industrial chic. It was spacious, inviting, there was a cool mural of big fish eating little fish, a nice looking bar, frosted light bulbs with the names of oysters etched in them. The food was a similar combination of tried and true and latest and greatest. The smoked trout salad with quail egg, frisee, and bacon was a delish take on the classic lardon salad. The mussel stew with chorizo and kale was amazing. I'm still sad I couldn't finish it. It was so much food! Their version of fish and chips with halibut and rosemary potato wedges was wonderfully light and crispy. And the Arctic char with leeks was a beautiful, delectable dish. 

Definitely recommended. Just don't go late or you'll feel the staff trying to get you out the door.
author: Sage R.

description: Recently I found Anchor and Hope purely by chance. I am very happy that I did as it was a fabulous place to dine with a very trendy atmosphere.  The California King salmon sitting on a bed of corn, black eyed peas, rock shrimp salsa verde was incredible.  The service was excellent as well. A few days later, I joined some business associates here to try it again. It was just as great the second time.  If you're downtown San Francisco, definitely give this one a try!
author: Philip T.

description: Had heard so many good things and after a wonderful experience at  the Salt House I was really looking forward to finally dining at Anchor & Hope.  Service was slow and uninspired, they didn't have either of wines we wanted to order.   We tried two of the entrees and several of the appetizers. Nothing stood out. Perhaps my expectations were to high, very disappointing experience all the way around.
author: Debra M.

description:
3.5 - but showing 4 as it is a fairly new restaurant.

we went for lunch and arrived early, which we learned was a good thing. we were able to beat the rush. impressive for a fairly new restaraunt that is hidden in the alley..

appetizers: had a variety of a dozen oysters. the west coasts seem to be better. i liked the point reyes one. 

entrees: sardine sandwich, seemed a little small, its an open face sandwich with a good bit of veggies on it; lobster roll, looked pretty filling, co-worker said it was good; steamed mussels, a good sized pot of mussels in a white wine broth with their ribbon fries stacked on top; 
nothing on the menu was really jumping at me, but the clam chowder looked interesting, it was a sweet corn and clam chowder. pretty good, sweet and not too heavy. i also had a side of cole slaw, which was pretty fresh, but i didn't like the bitter ingredient that was in it.

dessert:
blackout cake. choco cake with choco pudding and pistachio curnch topping. it was moist. delicious. the pistachio added a nice crunch.

i would love to come back in a few months to see how the restaurant has progressed. we suspect that it could turn into a good hh place.
author: cat k.

description:
I wanted this place to be great. Our appetizers were excellent but entree didn't stand up. Sea urchin was rich and very good, Angels on Horseback - bacon wrapped oysters also very good as well as the Calamari. Dinner was so so, Lobster roll was good nothing that would make me want ti again, the bass was mediocre at best.
Maybe for happy hour our appetizers it would be worth going again.
author: Marie C.

description: One of the best kept secrets in the city. Hidden on Minna is a great place for happy hour. Chef's selection of Oysters for a buck. The fish is fresh and the service friendly. Unlike it's sister restaurants. This place is a jewel!!!!!
author: earle s.

description: Didn't understand the appeal.  Food was just ok. The only thing great about ths place is that is it so close to Harlot so you don't have to go too far to get a bite to eat, after drinking all night! And it's next to a parking lot, in case you are from the East Bay and can'y parallel park (like me).
author: Lily S.

description: I'm so glad everyone had a nice experience at Anchor & Hope.  Four of us went there the first week it was open...and yes, we're all friends of Doug...that said, the food was so vile that our entire meal was comped.  The manager even called Doug and asked him to get to the restaurant pronto because it was a bad night.  Doug offered to have us come back in a couple of week, on him, but I wouldn't take him up on it.  I feel this place will not improve.  Nothing tasted good...no salt, no herbs or spices.  Everything was beyond bland and everything tasted basically the same.  The lobster roll had the same ingredients or lack thereof as the special lobster salad.  They won't be seeing me again.
author: anne l.

description: A sister restaurant to Town Hall and Salt House, this is perhaps the most casual of the triumvirate in terms of ambiance. In terms of quality and style of food, the fare here isn't quite up to par with its sister restaurants. That being said, it is still good seafood, and the friendly waitstaff adds to the pleasantness of the dining experience. If half stars were available, this would be a 3.5, but I will round up to be kind.
author: Sandy Y.

description: I thought I had eaten all types of french fries known to mankind...until I got to Anchor & Hope where I discovered ribbon fries.  It looks like the end of the ribbon when its gift wrapped by someone who can gift wrap.
author: Wakako U.

description: We went there for a mid-week dinner.  The brightest part of our evening was Adam, who served our table and was attentive without being overbearing.  Other than that, it was a horrible experience.  The complimentary potato chips were greasy and cold and not crispy at all.  I ordered the fish and chips and my guest ordered one glass of wine and the steak.  The steak portion was extremely small for the price ($29).  3/4 of the plate was covered by cheap bibb lettuce and a very weak vinaigarette dressing and some very greasy onion rings.  The fish and chips ($24) looked appetizng, but the coating was not crispy at all and the meager amount of fries included with the dish were not enough to keep the grease from forming on the bottom of the plate.  The bill came to $ 72 and we both left hungry and very dissatisfied.  With all the other wonderful dining options in SF, you should do yourself a favor and avoid this place.
author: Kevin R.

description:
I have now been here 3 times (thus qualifying for me to review as restaurant - I'll never review anywhere until been there 3 times) in the past 4 weeks and despite a couple of hiccups, I really really like this new addition to the Washington-Rosenthal trifecta of downtown restaurants. I've hit it for a night with the girls, and two business dinners.  The ambiance is perfect for both, since the food, although casually presented, is very, very good and attention to detail is very cool -- and the laid back vibe of the place fits many bills.  The first two times I went I thought the service was bumpy, but it improved from second to third so dramatically I think they are kind of figuring it out.  The wine list is just killer - love that almost everything is done by the glass - and unusual and the staff seems knowledgeable about it all. The ambiance is great too, although keep in mind that it is a high-ceilinged loft, so it is LOUD until quite late, but the airy feel and the decor is just right for the food's presentation.
I love, love, loved the sea urchin appetizer - you need to try it to understand it but it is fantastic as was the "Angels on Horseback".  I also liked everything from the raw bar to the trout salad and the other salads we shared.  The lobster roll is magical. I thought the special seabass I had was fantastic, but another entree, the monkfish and mussel stew was really not good at all- a step below mediocre and oddly stood out from everything else there that was great - it was flavorless and dull where it should have been rich tomato-y and spicy;  a discordant misstep in an otherwise good menu.  Anyway, desserts were terrific too.

Go if you want a non-stuffy, not quiet place for dinner or want a late night alternative to a bar where you can snack and share and indulge in seriously great wine (and beer list is excellent too).  Doug Washington has prowled the place each night I was there and his attention to customer service is just phenomenal - the kind of restaurant proprietor you wish there were a thousand of when paying your hard earned money for a meal....
author: Kirsten M.

description:
The selfish part of me is reluctant to add to the positive buzz over Anchor & Hope because I think there's a real risk that this young restaurant will become unbearably popular. I think, though, the secret may already be out.

The about page on the site [http://anchorandhopesf.com/about.html] does a good job of succinctly evoking an accurate image of the restaurant's character, both in ambiance and cuisine. What's not captured in that description is that the menu, which includes familiar items like oysters on the half shell, stuffed clams, and lobster rolls, offers some more gastro-provocative fare than what the conventional mind might readily imagine, such as the warm sea urchin appetizer served in its spiny shell and the decadent lobster-stuffed-with-lobster entree with a horseradish bearnaise.

The sea urchin appetizer, which even tantalized the shellfish-allergic at my table, seems poised to become a signature must-try item, and the Portuguese clam-style stew featuring octopus, chorizo, and monkfish in a spicy broth was exceptional, although I will say that I had to wait for the stew to drop about ten degrees in temperature before its flavors registered in full. I tried a bite of the stuffed guinea hen breast, and it, too, was pretty amazing.

From soup to nuts, the service was top-notch. The host was exceedingly nice -- perhaps he was the general manager? -- seating us promptly but also checking in on us throughout our meal and attending to us in conjunction with our server, who was uncommonly attentive, engaged, and knowledgeable in her own right.
author: Eugene P.

description: It is mean to judge kids in comparison to their brothers and sisters, but that is what's going to happen here.  Out of Town Hall, Salt House and how A&H, I have to say this youngest child is my least favorite.  That said, cool space, good food, but maybe too similar to SH.  I think I would choose a return visit to the other two before this one, but I would gladly come back here too.
author: e w.

description:
My first (but not last) review of a San Francisco establishment!  On a recent business trip to San Francisco, I asked a San Francisco business associate for his favorite restaurant and he named Town Hall and Anchor & Hope. He was pretty unwavering on these choices, so I thought I would check it out.  A colleague and I went to Town Hall first and looked at the menu.  The menu and atmosphere were fantastic, but my colleague was in the mood for seafood, so we took a short walk to their sister restaurant Anchor & Hope.

The restaurant itself is in an incredible setting: a historic garage that was converted into the restaurant with exposed brick and wood beams and the decor was incredible as well, elegant in a casual way.

Now let me start off by saying that I am a vegetarian, but I am still also a foodie and primarily go to non-veggie restaurants because I love the  different cooking styles of really great chefs.  That being said, I couldn't make up my mind between the Tarragon Marinated Baby Beet Salad w/ Aged Parmesan, Watercress and Salted Pistachios and the Little Gem and Cucumber Salad w/ Buttermilk Dressing and Chopped Dill.  So, I ordered them both :)  They were both incredible: extreme fresh ingredients, beautiful seasoning and the dressings were incredible (the beet salad had an amazing dressing with horseradish in it).  My colleague ordered 2 appetizers as well: starting with a mixed plate of oysters and a dish called I believe Angels on Horseback? (oysters wrapped in bacon).  My colleague is from New England and is well versed in seafood and the only silence I got from him was while he was devouring these dishes.  After of course the silence was broken by his raving about not having had oysters that good in like forever.

Now for the main course!!  We came to this restaurant because my colleague wanted seafood, but after seeing another table's meal, he ordered their Hanger Steak.  Again, he raved about the quality of the beef, the seasoning and that it was cooked to perfection.  As for me, when the server discovered that I was vegetarian, she offered me a vegetarian dish that was not on the menu, but sounded delectable.  However, I had already set my heart on some of the side dishes.  So I ordered the sauteed Brussels Sprouts, the Broccoli Raab and an order of Fries.  I was in heaven.  Like everything else, everything was extreme fresh, not overcooked and seasoned brilliantly!!  I was truly a happy camper.

We finished the meal by splitting the Chocolate BlackOut Cake w/ Salted Almond Walnut Brittle.  It was packed full of flavor without being overly sweet and just hit the spot.

I will also mention that the wine list is great. And as for the staff, everyone from the maitre d' to the server were extremely friendly, accommodating and attentive!!!  All in all, we had a wonderful experience.

Not only will I return (next time I want to try their vegetarian offering), but I am dying to try their sister restaurants Salt House and Town Hall.  I actually will be in SF again in 1 week and already plan on dining at Town Hall!!!  Hats off to the owners and chef!!!
author: Mdivani M.

description:
Went there for a birthday dinner with friends last night.  Had a good time.  Food was excellent.  I ordered the kampachi appetizer and the scallops for my entre.  our table also ordered a shell fish platter with oysters, shrimp, and some lobster and clams.  very tasty stuff.  

I also ordered the IPA tasting, which includes three 6 ounce pours of 3 different IPAs.  None blew me away...they should add Hop Devil to the trio and lose the Racer 5.

I also had a glass of syrah, which was quite delicious.

Nice atmosphere, fun design, overall good value and experience.
author: Anthony S.

description: I really enjoyed this place.  Food, service and atmosphere - all were fantastic.  We started w/ the crab salad and the bacon wrapped oysters.  No complaints there (who complains about bacon and a bowl of delicious crab anyway??).  Then on to the scallops and roasted lobster which we also shared.  The sharing was perfect because both dishes were slightly rich so I wonder if I had one of those dishes to myself it would almost be too much of a good thing?  Finished off with their chocolate dessert - eh.  I'm thinking that dessert isn't their strong point.  Our waiter was a cool dude - knew just when to show up and pour my wine (never let me go empty!) and see if we needed anything.  Looking forward to going back and having the lobster roll.  Yay for a place that specializes in crab and lobster!
author: Piper B.

description: They say the apple doesn't fall far from the tree.. I beg to differ. Town Hall, being the big sister for A&H, sets an expectation level that A&H has yet to achieve. Service was good, and the food was just average to me. I had the lobster roll which was good, but their slaw was just plain weird. When people prefer the slaw from KFC over yours.. there's a problem. I'm not knocking the place.. by all means give them a try.. just don't expect too much.
author: Alan N.

description: I love the ambiance of the restaurant and the service is great but I went here on an office lunch a few months ago and, have to say, i wasn't impressed by the food. My Crab Louis was uninspired, pithy and the flavors of the unique substitutions did not marry as well as the original ingredients are known to. Maybe dinner would be more enchanting. I'd be willing to try again. The side of brussel sprouts and the aioli sauce with the fries were very tasty, however.
author: rachel b.

description: I took a client here for lunch today and it was a great place to have Halibut.  I my opinion it was cooked perfectly and dressed with supporting flavors that didn't overwhelm the fish.  The service was a little slow, it may have been because we ate there during the lunch time rush.  They have an extensive wine and beer list that I'm looking forward to sampling here soon. If I could I'd give it 3.5 stars. Perhaps after the next visit my opinion will change, for now I recommend you go try it at least once.
author: Aco A.

description: Very expensive for what you get. Our server Keith was very nice but the food lacked substance overall. The host was also very polite and allowed my party to be sat even though not all attendees were present. Even still I wouldn't go again nor recommend. Food was not bad but not good for the cost.
author: Cynthia M.

description: Eating seafood here was best of the best. Had few drinks at the bar and then started to order the food or the seafood, oyster and the lobster were yummie, i even try for the first time sea urchin was was made right but not my type of food, i will not eat this dish in the future but it was not the kitchen mistake it was not in my food sectors. we also had the asparagus salad which was interesting dish. The name of the place is funny and the location in a warehouse made the dinner interesting and nice!
author: James A.

description: Wow. This was surprisingly bad. No wait, awful. The Crab Louis was virtually tasteless...the salad on the other hand was unbearably salty.  The Lobster Rolls had a stingy amount of lobster and the chips seemed to be coated with a massive amount of salt (I think they forgot to include the potatoes).  The Sambal Roasted Prawns were, eh, a decent try.  The only exciting thing was the beer menu...and I couldn't partake since we declared it a dry lunch. Rats.
author: Amelia C.

description: Alright, I came here on a Monday night with my lady for a quick appetizer and a drink.  I requested that we sit at the bar and we were seated very quickly.  We then ordered a bubbly and a riesling.  Fabulous!  We also order 4 oysters.  At $3 an oyster, they were a bit expensive, but tasted excellent!  They came with all the right fixin's too!  For a $33, 30 minute stop-by, it was an expensive time, but yet cool....  The environment is beautiful inside and white.
author: Limzer L.

description:
How can i forget Anchor and Hope.  you are hopeless on my to-try list.  I would give you negative star if i can.  Thanks for making my birthday so special and memorable!  
Memory take me back a year ago, It' was my birthday, and my husband had a surprise party for me that night.  He made reservation for 4 at 7:30pm, but we had two more friends showed up around 7pm.  So, we stopped by and told them to add 2 more people to the party.  we were told we would get our table about 8pm. i had couple drinks with everyone in a bar near by, and around 8pm, we went back to Anchor & Hope.  We were insured to wait for 15 mins, so we ordered some champange at the counter.  30 mins passed by, no one come by and let us know what's going on, 45 mins passed by, all we got was "sorry, there is nothing we can do" with a cold poker face. After a hour, i thought i got enough insult and disappointment for the night, my birthday night!
from then on, i would never go back to Anchor and Hope.  i would never send any lunch or dinner business to that place, as well as their sister restaurant - Salt House.  There are more than enough good restaurants for me in the city.  For you - keep up your rude attitude, you will go out of business someday......soon!
author: Sophia L.

description: sometimes not so easy to find just off snd street on Mina fish house...nice spot open warehousy chic yet it has just enough old school kitcsh  like lobster traps and other fish restaurant of yore swag to remind you what you are here for... seafood!... first time was here for casual dinner and ate much of the menu second visit was lunch... they do a full house turn at noon and you can see why... the food here is fresh and good. the fried oyster sandwhich was yummy, the salmon pastrami was good- a tad dry and way too many pickles on the open face sammy combined with the side of pickeled veggies made for an acidic luch and as always the angels on horseback stole the show... yummy ... this is a very consistent house with very good food and very open floor plan and cute staff... happy hour is the next stop over here for me~!
author: Ricote F.

description: On the higher-priced end, but really tasty seafood options. The calamari was just ok (a little bit too fried for my liking), but the dipping sauce -- a Thai chili sweet/spicy sauce -- absolutely made the dish. And then there's the lobster sandwich on brioche roll which was really just to die for. We split everything and having just half of that sandwich was plenty -- so light, creamy and delicious.
author: Hilary M.

description: darn it! I just realized they have sea urchin here. Ive been here a couple times and i guess i totally missed it. I indulged in my first love - OYSTERS!!! I loove the selection and could have eaten five dozens if my tummy allowed it.  I honestly dont remember what main courses I ordered because all i could remember was the oysters.  The place is a nautical type theme and i digged the design. Definitely going back and making sure i remember to order sea urchin and remember what i actually eat for the main course.
author: Bren L.

description: Nice atmosphere, friendly service, food was just awesome, and I am talkling specifically about flounder. as for desserts- just 3 on choice, and the server's recommendation- peanutbutter something- was ok... but overall, nice experience!
author: Alex F.

description:
a good friend was in town, i now work in menlo park.... and am not keeping up with all the new great restaurants in the city.

so, i found this restaurant and we decided to try it out!
it was a great decision! i got there on-time, but tried to circle around to find street parking for 20 minutes. i ended up parking in the lot right next to the restaurant. 

we started with housemade salmon gravlax with fried oysters - the oysters were delicious... the salmon & salad we a great compliment. the seafood was extremely fresh.

we also had a wonderful glass of wine, it was something from spain that was reccomended. 
my friend had the sea bass with potatoes and vegetables and i enjoyed the steak with green beans and fried potatoes (like fresh potato chips).

for dessert we tried the chocolate pudding cake, which was cold and wasn't what i expected... i had a huge cup of coffee (which was pretty good coffee). and we sat and caught up... and weren't rushed out... it was great!

my friend is originally from the bay area, moved to san diego about 5 years ago. and during our meal, all she could say is that this is a san francisco restaurant. i think deep down inside, she misses the sf culture & nite life!! =P maybe she'll decide to come up on business trips more often!
author: kiko v.

description: This place is good if you're looking for something classy, good service, and an overall nice ambiance.  But it was pretty pricey and the food was mediocre at best with very small portions.  The salmon appetizer was basically just a fried egg on top of VERY salty slices of salmon on top of mashed potato for $15.  I felt like I could have made it better.  Everything looked a lot nicer than it tasted.  I would not go here again.
author: Andrea S.

description: Went for lunch.  The place was packed and really loud but our experience was great!  We got a cozy table in the back so we could sort of hear ourselves think.  Great ambiance, nice artwork on the walls...and the unpretentious menu was heavenly.  I had a hard time choosing what to eat and ended up with the crab louis which was excellent.  Others had the lobster roll which looked amazing except it had huge chunks of celery in it (which I don't like) and the shrimp louis which also looked fab.  Would definitely go back again for lunch or even dinner!
author: Cyn B.

description: Amazing meal! The space is impressive right when you walk in; this would be a great place to take guests or friends. We didn't have the world's best waitress but the food made up for it in my mind. Like others have said, the warm sea urchin appetizer is a must, as is the salted chocolate cake to finish it off. An impressive beer and wine list, and some wonderful entrees. I definitely enjoyed my meal here.
author: Jon N.

description:
i needed a place to take my grandparents to dinner (or rather, let them take me while they were in town), and my mom had mentioned that she saw a&h on a "10 best seafood restaurants in the u.s." list in one of her mom magazines. great, i thought, this will be perfect - i haven't been and my grandparents like seafood (whereas some of my contemporaries do not and might have been a harder sell).

we went early on a monday night, MLK day to be exact, so the spacious dining room was nearly empty to start. that didn't bother me save that if the large group in the front hadn't been there, it might have felt like we were dining alone. 

moving on - i had two appetizers for my meal - a soup and a thai prawn dish. both were good, but nothing to land the meal on any top 10 lists. and my grandparents like their meals as well, but my grandpa pointed out that for a san francisco restaurant, a disturbing number of the dishes featured seafood from far and wide - the atlantic coast, new zealand, etc. i live in the "city by the bay" - i want local fishies.

overall it was a good, but not great, meal - i guess i had high expectations. i will definitely be going back, if only to try the angels on horseback. i will eat anything wrapped in bacon.
author: Sara C.

description:
I was underwhelmed with Anchor and Hope.  I thought it would be a better seafood experience.

Anyways, I love the old renovated warehouse that the restaurant resides in. Kinda cool.  We went on a weekday and when we arrived the bar was full, but the dining area had plenty of seating. The hostess made us wait a long time (15-20 min) because she was expecting a large party to come.  That's cools but she never came back to check on us. And that large party never came.  We ending up grabbing two spots at the bar.

They only serve beer and wine so I had a Belgium beer and I order the Lobster roll. My girl order a fish dish(I forget the type of fish) which came wrapped in the paper that it was cooked in.  The lobster roll was decent, no real complaints there.  My gf's fish dish was really bland though.  The fish was cook perfectly and had a great aroma, but it totally lacked flavor.  It was a shame because it smelled so good.  She didn't finish it, so I had some and agreed it was bland as hell.

Even though its a cool place, one time is enough for me. I probably won't be going back.
author: Terrel R.

description: It's just not that good. Totally disappointing.  And horrribly painfully slow service.  For over ~$25/entree, I expect at least a little bit of WOW or at least good service.  Neither found here.  Great space though.
author: Melanie C.

description: This place is yum, yum, yum!  Pricey, yes, but wow, the food leaves you wanting to come back for more.  The paella was unforgettable!
author: Sylvia F.

description: Sea urchin, trout and snapper on the lighter side.  Comparable to Ame in style -- but somehow not quite as successful.  Open space, good for large parties (we had 7, sat at a bench-style table, brought our own wine, so this was a stress test of sorts).  Not as intimate as Salt House or as boisterous and large as Town Hall.  Nice crew.
author: ed y.

description: cool vibe, great appetizers, good entrees.  probably would be 3.5 stars but their draft beer list bumps them up to 4.  only complaint was thought my main course curry sauce was too salty.  Solid spot for beer and food.
author: Raj D.

description: The $25.00 valet parking fee is a warning to all that A&H isn't inexpensive.  If fact for what you get it is too expensive.  While the service was good and the food well prepared the lobster roll (the reason we went) was a pale imitation of what we get in New England.  The small amount of lobster finely chopped with to much filler and over seasoned.  The soup and dessert were 4 stars.  Why serve a very average potato chip before and with the lunch service?  Not planning a return.
author: Tom M.

description:
It smells so good as you walk up to the restaurant, but that smell doesn't carry over to the actual eating experience. I've been there several times for lunch and tend to always get the same thing, the tuna melt or the lobster roll.  I find the bread a bit too buttery for me ( I'm the type of person who never dips my lobster in the butter, so it could just be that old, puritanical New England thing) and the fish is good, but lacking a bit of seasoning, i also find myself pining for celery for some reason.. 
However, the service is good and people are friendly. It's somewhat loud.... you have to shout across the table, so not really good for trying to get business done or romancing...
I will have to try out dinner one of these days though...
author: judith m.

description: Nice room decent food...not going to blow you away though
author: Chris H.

description:
stopped in for some appetizers and looks pretty promising. still a few rough edges but i'm sure i'll bump it up a star or two in the next month.
the thing that gets me is that i didn't absolutely LOVE anything I had. everything was good but not as impressive as town hall or the salt house. for example, i had the fries with eyes (too much batter on the smelt), the maple smoked trout (good, but the potatoes that came with it were disappointing) and the chowder (a little too sweet for me). Also, no liquor license as of last night so call before you come in to make sure you're ready if you have to byob.
author: Rowena M.

description:
anchor and hope.  i had high hopes for this place but it sure was anchored.  

service -- fast in that they do bring out the food pretty quickly but aside from that they were unattentive and slow.  made reservations for 3 and were waiting for the 3rd.  while we were waiting for our friend we were not visited once by our waitress.  we finally managed to flag her down to let her know that we'll be ordering first but we must have been unattended to for at least 20 minutes because my friend arrived nearly 30 min late.  

bad food - angels on horseback were such a disappointment.  they're deep fried with bacon wrapped around.  how can you go wrong with deep fried?  and bacon!?  our order tasted like it was sitting around for awhile and the oysters tasted below grade.  not even deep frying could save those.  same goes for the smelt fries.   the battered halibut entree came with 3 good sized chunks but they were meh.  i've had better tasting fish and chips.

good food - the warm sea urchin in the shell was really delicious.  i can't recall the name of the other entree we ordered but it had leeks and the fish was either a snapper or a tuna.  whatever it was it was yummerific.  

if it weren't for these two dishes i'd give it one star and i rarely give one star.
author: Cindy N.

description:
came here for dinner tonight and i really enjoyed it.  the service was friendly and the food was good.  it was nice to see they had the allagash white on their beer menu.  i went to the brewery a couple years ago when i was in maine and that was my favorite, a perfect beer to have seafood with.

tried the portuguese seafood stew, the sea urchin with mashed potatoes which was fantastic, the pork belly was good...not perfect, but was still delicious.  my gf had their salmon and that was also tasty, it was light and had a mediterranean touch to it.   for dessert, i ended with a half dozen oysters -- cleanly shucked and pristinely fresh.  

our food was just a tad bit slow in coming out and i'm not sure how i feel about the bread being in a bag, but over all the space was nice and spacious and i can definitely see myself coming back to try more things on their dinner menu.
author: ML ..

description: Maybe I'm just a sucker for ocean/fishing themed restaurants but this place was amazing!  The staff was overly nice and pay us lots of attention, the food was great. I had the asparagus salad, the lobster salad and the lobster roll.  I loved the asparagus salad, and I think the lobster salad contains an entire lobster. All protein skinny girls... super yummy. My friend got the urchin and the presentation was incredible. We finished with the cherry Crme brle which was fantastic.  The crowd seems friendly and unpretentious, everyone seemed like they were excited they'd found this new gem. The restaurant is running surprisingly smoothly for only being open a short time. It's still BYO so don't forget the wine!
author: All About Town ..

description:
former warehouse space
stylish, minimal, like food
bacon wrapped oysters!
author: yutai l.

description: I first ate here a few years ago and the fish & chips were one of the best I had EVER had, just delicious & cooked perfectly. I returned a couple of years ago and the fish was abit soggy but still okay. A couple of weeks ago I was really craving fish & chips so my partner and I went for lunch. Well the price has gone up, $22.50 for fish & chips and only 2 pieces compared to the 3 pieces they used to give you. For that price the fish & chips should be perfect. The fries were great but the fish disappointing, soggy, watery and too much batter and not enough fish. My partner had one beer and I had an iced tea. The tab for 2 of us was around $58, seriously ??
author: V A.

description: Great seafood selection. Be sure to get some oysters and a brew. Decor could use some warming.
author: benjamin c.

description:
very friendly hostess and server.  my sis and i were there for a special treat - she got a bonus and we were there to celebrate!

we had two appetizers - tuna and prawns. loved the prawns, they had a fun kick.  i ordered the halibut - it was superb!  sis got the lobster tail and was also pleased.  

we did donuts and the special for dessert - i was so full when i left it was ridic. 

overall, it was a fun night.  service was a wee bit slow  (as in, by the time i actually got my dessert i was wishing i hadnt) and i noticed that for the table next to us it was far worse.  they left upset, visibly.  i like to know my fellow diners are having a good time as well, you know?
author: Kristin K.

description:
A fan, but at what cost?

Went in for my "I am so not gay" but super totally gay friends birthday.  Top it off with a couple of his friends and we were a veritable scene.  I note that the 7:30p dinner crowd was markedly suit-ed, as it is the financial and Soma districts watering hole for those who don't beat the commute.  The crowd wasn't that enthralling, nor was it much of a scene.  I like to people watch, but at least it wasn't stifling.  I am sure we were the most garish people in there.  Waiting for the rest of our party we saddled up to the bar and ordered a bottle of VERY good, VERY reasonable champagne (of which I am escaping and actually *know*... server said it was best on the menu and last bottle so I was proud of it enough to let it get me inebriated enough to... totally.. forget... what it was).  We had the rest of the party arrive and got to our table, but not until after we see two separate tables have customers go belly up on the light, aluminium chairs that were on the slick service floors.  

By the end of the night, patient reader, THREE total chairs had hit the ground... and it wasn't until my female compatriot deferred to the other chair flippers that we realized it wasn't due to inebriants greasing the balance of the consumer... but rather the floor and chair connection being poor, at best.

However, this really was our only complaint.  The food was amazing.  The Snapper was full head on delicious, my fish and chips (of which I am a dorky connoisseur)  were some of the best I have ever had in my entire life.  The batter was superb.  The fish perfect.  The service was awesome, and the cute blue eyed bartender graciously flirted with my man lover friend.

In the end, after two more bottles of wine, 5 entrees, and some dessert... the bill came out to a bit more than a "casual night out with a couple friends".  Actually... doing the math now of picking up two meals, plus the birthday boy.... it really was fair, but I ended up dropping much more than I am normally comfy with and walked away consumed by the cost.

In retrospect, that is my fault, not there facility's.  It is right on the back side of where I dj, so I could imagine myself catching a quick app or drink before my gig.  I will give it another visit and see how I feel, but until then... I think this is a great new space that will have some good times in front of it!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: I went there for a celebration lunch! The service was great, I had the clam chowder and beet salad - loved it! The only thing is that is was pricey - but that is SF norm for resturants....
author: Kristine H.

description: On the whole, this is a welcome addition to the neighborhood.  The space is interesting and welcoming.  During lunch, the place was not quiet, but also not too noisy to have a conversation.  The food is good, if not exceptional.  The prices reflect their Town Hall pedigree, which is to say on the high end.
author: Gene G.

description: My wife and I stumbled in here on a Wed night after a movie at the Metreon.  The tables were full so we sat at the bar.  They have a great beer selection, especially Belgian varieties.  The scallops are ridiculous -- everyone must try them!  The halibut was also good but similar to preparations I'd seen at other restaurants.  I'd give the place four stars but our service was a bit slow.
author: Kumar D.

description:
well, anchor and hope is just fine. the decor is fun, as others have noted- they really take their nautical theme to heart. (you will be presented with a real life anchor weight on top of your bill at the end of the meal, for example). and they have hooks under the bar for purses and jackets - a thoughtful touch which should be required everywhere, imho. 

decor gimmicks aside, i found the food to be good, but not over the top. i had the lobster roll (hello, is there any other item TO have?) it seems to me that a lobster roll on a brioche bun is almost foolproof- and i did enjoy it. but i didn't think longingly about it afterwards, or about the fried calamari we all shared as a starter. and that's what i want in a great restaurant- food that makes me sit up and take notice.
author: oona m.

description:
Overall, a fabulous little establishment. Spacious, lofty, modern but warm enough. The very same delicious bread served at some of the nice little places around the city (including Salt House and Town Hall, natch). 

Extensive wine menu. Sadly, I can't really attest to the quality of any of their selections - it was a non-drinking work-related lunch.

Fresh oyster selection on the chalkboard. Is the new oyster standard?

Apps were standard - roasted beat salad was really quite spectacular - the sunflower seeds really made it stand out.

I went expecting to try find a fish dish and break my vegetarian diet but alas, there's a vegetarian menu item, simply described as chef's delight. I'm fairly certain that loosely translates to a fresh tortellini in some sort of brown butter or cream sauce with French beans, carrots (the fancy kind with the little green tops still on), and mushrooms (unidentifiable because I don't really like mushrooms). When butternut squash is out of season, the tortellini is ricotta, tomato, and basil in a heavy, buttery, flavorful cream sauce. Too often restaurants let cream take center stage in a sauce like this. It was really refreshing to enjoy a cream sauce with some spices, caramely onions, and mmm mmm goodness. Needless to say, I was not forced to choose a fish option. In fact, none of the non-veggie options were even the least bit tempting. Fellow diners enjoyed the Tombo tuna melt and the Reuben sandwiches. 

No room for dessert but perhaps if I make an encore appearance.
author: Angela N.

description: I like it in Anchor & Hope; it is casual, but the food and service are much better than casual dining. The oysters are fresh and delicious, and seared tuna was great. The "fish & chips" were good but I don't think it's worth ordering such standard fare at a restaurant this good. Oh, and the bread and butter were really good. Big props to the servers, really excellent service. They should have a better Champagne selection to go with the oysters.
author: Anton C.

description:
I can't comment on food, but can comment on service...or lack of service.
We made reservations for four ppl, but at last minuted needed to change it to six ppl.  They told us that they could not accomodate us at that time, but offered a new reservation two hrs later.  When we returned two hrs later, they said to wait at the bar. Forty minutes later we were still not seated.  We left.
author: Anna H.

description:
I had dinner with a friend at Anchor and Hope tonight.  I had not been in a couple of years, and although it was good, it was not nearly as good as I remembered.  I was put off a little bit when we arrived.  I was eating with a friend of mine who works at a nearby hotel and sends lots of his guests to Anchor and Hope.  He had made the reservation, and when we arrived the manager was at the front desk.  We gave our name for the reservation and the manager was kind of rude and looked down the list and said he did not see the name, he kept repeating the name over and over and sort of mumbled no reservation.  At that point the hostess came over and she recognized my friend, and she was super friendly and sweet.  We were seated and ordered.  They have a great beer selection.  Our waiter was very friendly, but the service was off a bit .  For instance they brought our first course before the drinks(but they were all so nice it did not detract from the meal).
We started with oysters which were very good, then we had a shrimp ceviche which was excellent.  We also had an octopus with ham hocks and frisee.  The octopus was a little soft and not that flavorful, and the portion of seafood was very small.
For main courses we had Monk Fish in a curry sauce that was pretty good, but it was overly salty, but tasty.  We also had the salmon which was very well prepared.
The place has a fun vibe to it, and although it is expensive, it is totally unpretentious.  I think I was most bothered that the manager never even came over and said hello to my friend after being rude to us.  If I was rude to someone who was consistently sending customers to my business I would make sure to have at least come over and checked on his dinner.  I felt bad for my friend because I could see the incident embarassed him, but its not a big deal since every other place I have been with him they treat him like royalty.
author: Trevor S.

description:
Just came back from lunch there.  It is in an old wharehouse, which would give it a nice atmosphere if they had remembered to install heat before they opened it as a restaurant.  Additionally, the chairs have metal seats which made matters all that much worse.   I was so looking forward to the lobster roll, but who the hell wants to eat a cold sandwich when you're already shivering?.  I had the trout which I suppose was pretty good, but I could not enjoy it with the temperataure being what it was.  

Perhaps it would be a better place in the summer.  Wait staff was very good but I agree with the other poster who said it's not up to Salt House or Town Hall standards.  I just could not get past the cold.....
author: Sue C.

description:
I took some colleagues there and we were quickly seated at a lovely out-of-the-way table so we could talk. The natural daylight from the old skylights combined with the old wall materials and exposed structure created a delightfully different effect, very pleasant for lunch and not too noisy. The waiter doted on us; I prefer a bit too much service to too little. I had the special roasted char in a leek broth. It was great. The bread was wonderful. Another person had the mussels and a 3rd had the lamb burger. They were pleased with their dishes, especially the shaved potato fries. 

Our office is moving to that neighborhood so I will be going back there. My colleagues were impressed that I led them down a little alley to a great looking space with great seafood.
author: Susan O.

description: I went here and had the most pretentious bowl of clam chowder ever! It's overpriced just for the sake of being overpriced.  The portions were small and the food quality was sub par. They also stuck the party I was with in the back in an enclosed area that shuts you out of the open floor of the restaurant. I'm calling bullshit on Anchor and Hope.
author: Cameron E.

description:
I LOVE this place!  I've been here for lunch and dinner... several times.  They never let me down!  The staff is always knowledgeable and friendly.  The food is always very fresh and the atmosphere is fun (albeit a little loud at times).  

You can't miss the warm sea urchin!  That alone will bring me back over and over!
author: Courtney C.

description: I'm a seafood lover so I love any seafood place. I think I would have given this place 4 stars but I was disappointed by my entree.  I eagerly ordered the red curry mussels (2 of my favorite things!) but it was a huge disappointment. First of all, it was wayyyy too salty.  Secondly, it had so much pungent lemongrass in it that it took away from the red curry flavor. Also, the curry wasn't quite curry-like...it was more of a broth, which would be ok if they described it better on the menu.  So yes, I was very disappointed but the other dishes were quite good.  Oysters were fresh and the grilled sardines were excellent with the pureed white bean sauce.  Yum! I will definitely go back but will avoid the mussels.
author: jen h.

description:
I went to A&H for my birthday dinner. The food and the ambiance were great. I think the concept is really great. The service, however, was awful. Our server was clearly overwhelmed, and the restaurant wasn't that busy while we were there. We felt abandoned and waited a long time for each course. The real topper was that we waited so long after finishing our entrees to get her attention. When she finally came to our table, she asked if there was anything else we wanted. How about a dessert menu? It was my birthday, after all, and I wanted dessert. My husband said maybe we should skip it. Nope. I wanted dessert. So we waited a while for her to take our order, then waited 15 minutes to get a piece of cake which really just needed to be sliced and plated. The manager actually served the cake, and that's when I told him how disappointed we were with the service. He seemed aghast, but did listen. I was surprised when the bill came and he didn't comp the dessert. Most restaurants would have done at least that.

I doubt I'll go back. If I want that fish-shack ambience and menu, I'll go to Barbara's Fish Trap in Half Moon Bay. And it's a lot cheaper.
author: Michele H.

description: Highly anticipated dinner proved to by a HUGE disappointment.  I'm a big fan of Town Hall and Salt House but this is sadly different.  Waited a long time for service and food.  The oysters are very good (hard to mess with mother nature) but everything else should be avoided.  Even the beverage suggestions by our waitress were off, at least she was nice.  Better change fast or this restaurant is toast.
author: Charles G.

description: Over a year of dining at A&H and I feel comfortable with five stars.  Love the fresh food.  Service is usually just right and great beer selection.  Prices can be a tad on the high side, a shrimp po'boy would be great on the menu and it is unbearably hot on the rare summer days.  All those constructive points don't dent the five stars. Solid all the way around.
author: D S.

description:
my overall experience at anchor and hope as not good.  where do i start.  i had a 7:30pm reservation on Wednesday night.  showed up on time and ended up waiting over 30 minutes for a table.  when we were seated, it was this awkwardly configured table that would had four people sitting in a U formation, with two of the people at opposite ends of the table so far apart that there was no way verbal communication was possible.  in case you didn't know, this place is LOUD.  anyway, we weren't pleased with the sitting arrangement but decided to wait there until another table became available.  this took another 15 minutes.  

on to the food.  i had the clam chowder which was good enough, it had some good kick due to the use of bits of peppers and bacon.  then i had the battered cod entree, which in the end was an overpriced fish and chips dish, don't know what i was thinking by ordering it.  it was nothing special.  

the only thing really worth a darn here is the beer selection.   if you like lagers try the Session lager, it's from Mt. Hood, OR.  they also have a nice hef from germany.  

in the end, our drinks were comped and they gave us a free calamari appetizer to apologize for the wait.  that bumps them up to three stars instead of the two i would have given otherwise.  still not going back anytime soon.
author: Scott K.

description: Ate here AGAIN, and loved it. Just keeps getting better and better.  Full  menu is served at the bar.  This is a real treat...oysters were so good we ordered a second dozen.  The fresh bread is amazing...and then of course the menu.  Sea bass was FANTASTIC.   I plan to go here until I have tried everything on the menu.
author: Angela N.

description:
was going to stay home and cook, but decided to go out for dinner instead, and i'm glad we did! anchor and hope was a great choice and i only wish we were hungrier, so many things looked good. 

we really wanted to try the lobster roll, but our server convinced us to get the stew. it wasn't bad, and the broth was delicious as i dipped my bread in it, but i'm still really curious about that lobster roll!

we started with the fries with eyes (fried smelt), which i was excited about, and although the flavor was good they weren't as crispy as we'd hoped, actually, they were kinda soft and soggy...we also got the uni with mashed potatoes and dungeness crab. i wasn't sure how i was going to like it, since i'm not a big lover of uni, but it basically tasted like super rich mashed potatoes, not a bad thing! the only thing that kinda disappointed is that they weren't serving it in the uni shell that night for some reason, it just came in a large coffee mug type thing. finally we also got the bacon wrapped oysters. who doesn't like bacon wrapped anything?! 

i really liked the open air feel of the restaurant, it's a casual laid back place, serving really nice food. the service was great. chad, our server, is very personable and informative. he picked some great wines for me that night, and now i'm on the hunt for one of them! and he definitely doesn't rush you to put in your whole order all at once. we started with apps, and then he came by to see how we were doing and if we wanted to order entrees. we really were just able to relax and enjoy the dinner, ahhh, what a great way to end the work week.
author: Angela W.

description:
as tho to prove that it's related to the salt house...

one star: got my work to pay
one star: got my work to pay

minuses: hello? can someone take our order, bring our food, or at least stop standing on the food prep station in their shoes? ...and two hour lunch? for overpriced salads and sammiches?

plus: good conversation with a four-year-old.
author: eliza w.

description: This place looked great- big space with quirky art. I loved the fried pickles and the fish and chips. The service was attentive and polite....  the waiter kept touching me on the shoulder. Hmmmm, now I really can't wait to go back.
author: B S.

description: I tried to ignore the pompous crowd. Twas a challenge.  Just had a beer here.  It was $7 and wasn't too big.  I also tried an oyster.  Not an oyster fan; I wouldn't say it tasted 'great' as some would say.  The nautical ambiance and decor is clever.  Service was good, too.  Would I go out of my way to try this place out for a full meal? Probably not.
author: Scott G.

description: OK - really?!  Bacon wrapped oysters?  Need I say more?
author: Catherine B.

description: The design of the place is really great, but the food is really not.  The best dishes we had were oysters on the half shell and a beet salad.  It's hard to mess up good raw oysters, and the beet salad, though tasty, was not worth $11.  The entrees were a let down.  My monkfish stew was a mess of muddy flavors.  My husband's scallops were nice, but the block of braised pork belly that came with them was actually just one solid piece of fat.  I know pork belly is fatty, but there wasn't even the thinnest sliver of meat in it.  It was basically a piece of fat-back.  I really like the space, and it's close to my house, so I hope they revamp the menu.
author: Michelle A.

description:
I had really high hopes for A&H after reading about its opening and subsequent reviews.  They were able to accommodate my very last minute reservation and from start to finish, the host and wait staff were all very...friendly.  I hate to be mean to our dear waiter, who was all smiles and very sincere, but he messed up our appetizer order by bringing out the wrong dish, then proceeded to tell us he was going to bring us the right dish, and then told us they ran out of that dish.  I don't know if that's even really his fault.  When he was describing the specials, he seemed a little lost and unsure of himself.  But, I am fully giving one star for this waiter, b/c like I said, all mistakes are forgiven when the waiter is uber friendly, which he was.

But, NOTHING can excuse the fact that my entree smelled like a seriously bad case of B.O.  At one point I actually held my nose and tried to eat it that way, but still could not stomach it.  I ordered the spicy mussels and monk fish stew.  Good size portion, but did I even come close to finishing it?  No.  The mussels were cooked perfectly, the monk fish was overdone and rubbery, and it just plain smelled awful.  

One additional star for the iced tea they served which was fabulous.  

But...iced tea is not enough to bring me back here.
author: Grace C.

description: Walking down Minna I was wondering what I had gotten myself into, but the diversion was worth it.  What a charming interior (the waitress said it had been an artists studio for years) with loads of natural light flowing in from the skylights.  The food was simply prepared and delicious and the pace of service was just right.  I asked for my whole fish to be filleted and the waitress did that for me table side.  I'm already plotting my next visit.
author: Raj-Ann R.

description: Anchor and Hope tries to have it both ways, moving toward the genuine  while still grasping for a bit of outré. The result is a restaurant that's caught between caution and abandonment. And that's probably not a place where a seafood lover wants to be, especially given the prices.
author: Jacob S.

description: I love everything about this restaurant; excellent food / wine, phenomenal service, cool, unique decor, and awesome location.  I was on a date; I must admit that this is not the place for anyone that is on a tight budget.
author: Myra M.

description: I loved this place!  I went here for dinner on a Wednesday night, and even that night it was packed. We were a bit early for our reservation, but they sat us early.  We started with the calamari and oysters which were both delicious!  I had the Tai Snapper, but tried my dinner companions lobster roll and trout, all of which were really delicious!  It is a bit pricey, but c'mon anywhere you eat out in the city is going to be pricey! Overall this place is worth going to.
author: Holly K.

description: i love the fact that they take lunch reservations but im not sure i like the food or the service. i heard really great things about this place before coming so when my bosses came to town i took them here for lunch, there was 6 of us. i was a bit disappointed, i paid more than 20bucks for a lobster sandwich and potato chips(?).. the sandwich was ok, but who the heck eats a $20 lobster sandwich with potato chips!? i would have rather have had a green salad.. there didn't seem to be very many patrons in the restaurant either but our server seemed very impatient and a little annoyed. the worst part was in the end it was very awkward, the servers watched us exit but from my experience every other restaurant ive visited servers normally say "thanks for coming in" no one did that here.. they all just watched us leave, it was very awkward. even though i tipped them $40bucks on a $160 lunch tab. over all it was ok but i dont think i would return.
author: V I P.

description: Went for lunch and had the lobster roll which was OK. Sam's Chowder house in Half Moon Bay has a better lobster roll. Service was really good.
author: Jesse M.

description:
This place was wonderful!  I came with a crowd of 8 people ( w/reservations) and was seated immediately. They didn't  make us wait to set up the table or anything. Our server was really polite and patient as we had so many people. 
I tried most things on the menu but my favorites were the sea urchin, the ceviche and lobster roll!  The sea urchin looked amazing, as it came in its shell and I loved how the uni was blended with some lobster. The lobster roll did not have a lot of mayonnaise, and the meat was very succulent. 
For dessert the we ordered the chocolate cake and the goat cheese cheese cake. Chocolate cake was moist but VERY rich. I actually enjoyed the goat cheese cheese cake, as it was not as heavy as cheese cake made of cow's milk. 
It's definately not a place to come if you are dieting because you would want to eat everything!
author: Benny S.

description: Great setting!  Awesome waiter!  Wine list that intrigues.  Fresh, delicate and delicious food.  A restaurant worthy of multiple visits.
author: Steven K.

description: delicious! we ordered lobster rolls and grilled fish. great atmosphere, good service. good beer.
author: Christine V.

description: Bad news.  If you're a white 30-something, don't care or know about food, and are desiring a very homogeneous scene, you've found your place.  Otherwise: if you order oysters, prepare to eat a lot of knob, because they're not properly shucked.  If you like chowder, prepare to eat some herb twigs, because they're not taken out.  And if you like grilled fish, prepare for it to be overcooked.   It's that kind of restaurant.   A big disappointment if, like me, you've enjoyed Salt Houae.
author: Guy h.

description: Not enough for way too much. Will have to return though, as they have a dish on the 7x7 list of 100 things to try before you die. Damn blast the world of competitive eating.
author: Miranda J.

description:
i am happy to say that i loved my experience at anchor and hope!  the food and wine were great, and the service was spot-on.  i loved the atmosphere, very open and inviting.  
we started with the salmon gravlax appetizer and the fried pearl onions.  i was a little skeptical about the onions but they were delicious.  i do think they could have come with a sauce though.  the salmon was great - i loved the combination of the greens, salmon, potato cake, and sauce... so tasty all together in 1 bite!  
for my entree i had the tuna which was very fresh and perfectly cooked.  the veggies were very summery.  my friend had the bass, which is their version of fish and chips.  i tried some and i think next time that is definitely what i would get!  i loved it!  
we didnt have dessert becuase we were too full, but thats all the more reason to go back again.
author: Carolyn B.

description: I went during lunch, there is decent menu selection. Of course I went with the bass special which was quite good. My friend had the Crab Roll which she said was very good. For dessert I had the best item of the whole meal a strawberry rhubarb hot curb cake. This was by far one of the best dessert I have had in a long time. The crust was made and cooked to perfection. It came out a the right temperature and was topped with a nice scoop of vanilla ice cream. The main was good but I will come back just for dessert next time. The food and wine is a little overpriced in my mind and the space is OK. If you are on someone else dime a good spot for lunch otherwise hit some where else with your hard earned cash
author: Prescott R.

description: Overpriced, overhyped, stiff atmosphere. The "legendary" sea urchin was disappointing and did not live up to the hype. Also ordered the shrimp ceviche appetizer, which was a joke -- I've made better ceviches in less than five minutes. Had the scallops as an entree, which lacked inspiration (and flavor).
author: Rich L.

description:
this one is tough...i've actually eaten here twice over the past few weeks.  i would say the appetizers are very nice.  the calamari...excellent.  has this nice hot/sweet sauce that comes with it.  i had this smoked trout salad which was also very nice....had this poached egg on top, and bacon...that's right, bacon...you can't really go wrong with the bacon!

main courses, not so much.  i had the battered halibut...it was actually pretty decent, but a little salty....and trust me, i'm not on a low-salt diet.  the fries were okay.  the next time i had the lobster pot pie.  it had no flavor.  i had to keep on adding salt, and that is just WRONG!  not sure if they did this by design, so that we could get the full flavor of the 2 or 3 small pieces of lobster in there, but come on.  not that i'm a cheap-ass, but for $32, i'm thinking that i should have gotten a warm, happy feeling eating it, and that didn't happen....

i got this chocolate cake both times...it was goooood!  they really enforce the portion control for those slices though....i felt like i was at a wedding or something...did anyone get that reference?  oh well....

the vibe is pretty cool in there...service is nice....if i ever go back, i'd stick with the apps for the most part...
author: Miss P.

description: Dinner at anchor & hope was a blast. Food was delicious -- esp the Sea Urchin. I was prepared by my friend that it would be fabulous -- but I didn't really believe it until i had it. It's chunks of sea urchin with crab and cream and potatoes and other goodness. it's warm and yummy. If you go, you must have this dish. The rest of the food we got was great - light seafoods and salads with flavor. I loved the eyeball lights along the side wall by the bar. Makes for a gregarious fun hip atmosphere. I'd highly recommend A & H.
author: Natala M.

description: Based on other yelp reviews,. I was wasn't expecting a great dining experience.  I was not disappointed.I like Salt House but this restaurant is fair at best. First of all it is way too noisy to carry on conversations. The food is creative,I had the Lobster pot pie,but pricey. The chairs are not comfortable.The tables are too close.the service was spotty. It all adds up to  just OK  for my yelp review.
author: Barry G.

description: food was good, but service sucks. The waitress rarely check on us. When the bill came, it was well over 15 minutes before I had to walk up to the counter for them to take our payments. For the price we had to pay, I'd rather take my business elsewhere with better service.
author: w m.

description: Friendly waitstaff.  Good food.  Spiced up the shrimp cocktail with tabasco in the cocktail sauce.  Ceviche was good.  Yellowtail tuna, while a smaller portion than I would've liked, was good.  Chocolate espresso cake was good.
author: Atif Q.

description: It's a gorgeous space with nice atmosphere.  The menu is totally oriented toward seafood, and everything was good.  They go for a rustic-y feel, with bread served in a brown bag (um, okay), but they're also serving you a whole sea urchin with tons of crab and mashed potatoes inside.  Yum!  My main course was really good, some scallops and pork belly with cabbage and favas on the side.  My friend got the seared tuna which was definitely out of the ordinary.  The wine list is interesting and really filled with great options.  Check it out before the reviews in the paper come out , making tables harder to come by.
author: Leo C.

description: We had an excellent experience...the decor was unique and fitting, our server was great including the dessert presenter, the overall service was top notch (they were on top of it), the food was excellent (oysters, salmon gravlax, red snapper, tuna, and some cheese heart) and my boyfriend loved the fact that there was a variety of domestic beers that are hard to find.  We will def. go back...
author: Lisa D.

description:
At the moment they get 3 stars. Upon my next visit I will update this review to see if they lost or gained any stars. It *may* have been my fault for not enjoying my meal :(

  I was excited to dine at Anchor and Hope. I have recently fallen in love with seafood and I like Town Hall and The Salt House so I figured I was in for a good meal. That was until I discovered they were out of my first choice for my entree. After the waitress informed me of the shortage I decided on a Louie Salad which I did not enjoy. The salad came deconstructed which drives me nuts and (this is totally my fault for not realizing this) the dressing was 1000 island which I don't enjoy. I was doomed from the start. That being said, the shrimp while unseasoned, were fresh, tender, and downright yummy. I can't really give them less than 3 stars because I made a bad choice and from a technical aspect they lived up to their end of the bargain. I did have one of my coworkers muscles which had a great sauce that complimented the seafood flavor nicely. When I return I may just try a plate of muscles for myself. Finally, the fried pickles are awesome. I would give them 5 stars on their own! They come out super hot so be careful, but the are delicious...
author: chelsea b.

description: I had high hopes for this place but ultimately, it didn't pop for me.  We started off with a dozen oysters, which were were nice and briny.  Then we had the fries with eyes, which ended up being only a few small sized smelts which were a bit greasy.   We then shared a fish stew, filling but kind of bland.  The restaurant sure is a nice space though.  Too bad.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
I really liked the unconventional location and decor of Anchor and Hope. I went with a group of four friends and we all dug the look of the restaurant. A&H took the place of an old auto mechanic shop and is on a side street off of Second Street. From the outside it looks like something out of a Jim Burton movie, slightly creepy and intriguing with a hint of potential for fun. 
The hostess is a real cutie but I wasn't particularly happy with where she seated us. We have a reservation and yet we ended up at a table literally right next to the door. Fortunately the weather was mild the opening and closing of the door didn't bother us. What was weird was the acoustics in the restaurant. Not only is it really loud (the ceilings are really high) but it seemed like no matter how loudly we spoke it was hard to hear. I compared it to talking into a pillow. Apparently, if you sit against a wall you can hear better.
I'm not a big seafood fan but I figured I'd try something new. If you like oysters, this is the place for you. They've got a nice selection of west coast and east coast oysters, they had six types of oysters. The menu changes everyday so the variety will likely change. The love boat and tug boat oyster appetizers are basically samplers with various seafood salad sides; they sounded good but what you were actually going to get was kind of confusing. We ended up getting the urchin, angels on horseback and bacon appetizers. The urchin was the best followed by the angels and horseback. I ordered the cod entree which was essentially fish and chips. It was good, not oily but the chips were slightly under cooked. I would suggest getting something more exotic. 
For dessert we got the chocolate cake. It was very good albeit slightly small. 
Overall, it was a decent seafood meal in a unique setting. I'd go back for the oysters or lunch.
author: Richard S.

description: I always make the mistake of getting too excited to check out certain new spots only to be disappointed in the end.  That is exactly what happened here.  The food was good, actually the lobster roll was great but the service just killed it for me.  It wasn't busy.  I'd say about half the tables were seated and our waiter was nowhere to be found the whole time.  I had to flag him down to order or first round of drinks, dinner AND the second round.  I was entertaining a guest from out of town and we both left after paying $60 each feeling robbed.  Don't know if I'll be running back anytime soon.  If I do, it will be for the lobster roll and I will sit at the bar.
author: elizabeth s.

description:
cool atmosphere/ambiance.  good beer.  started with oysters.  at over $3 each they are so freakin' small that 1/2 dozen didn't satisfy me and I couldn't afford a dozen.  Lobster roll ok, i think we like it better with a bit of mayo/aioli instead of just butter.  Seafood gumbo was also just ok, would have liked to have been able to discern the shellfish a bit more.

Beer was good, service was friendly.
author: Numbers Y.

description: I had been excited to try this place, as I love Town Hall and Salt House, but I love seafood even more.  They did a great job with the space, very unique and nautical, but stylish at the same time.  Waited nearly an hour for our table, even though we had a reservation.  However, the staff was very good about keeping us updated (apparently they had some lingering parties of 4 post-check).  They made up for it well with a lovely little table in our own semi-private room, and promptly brought us complimentary apps and drinks.  Food was excellent, although I was a little disappointed by some mis-information from our server about the oysters.  Lobster roll and the calamari were highlights.  Miyagi oysters were divine.  Kusshi's were bigger than normal :(  Would have given them 3.5 if possible.  Oyster info and late seating cost them the 4th star for now.
author: S B.

description: I am still in shock that this place is owned by the same guy who owns the oh-so-fabulous Salt House and Town Hall restaurants. The service was so-so (except for the super attentive bus boys, who I give 5 stars) The menu limited and not enticing, and food just plain bad. Except for the oysters, which let's face it, they just cracked open. Not a lot of skill required there. There is only beer and wine available, and while they have an extensive selection, I like vodka with my oysters. My date had tried the place back when it first opened, and had a similarly bad experience, but had hoped it was just a matter of working out the kinks. No such luck. Do yourself a favor and go to Salt House instead.
author: Jillian W.

description: I like this place, but it's definitely pricey for what it is, that's what knocked off half a star.  The other half star got lost for parking.  There are some parking garages around, but they're city prices, and if I'm only going to be at a restaurant for a couple of hours I don't see why I should pay $20 for parking.  Great service and food, the waiters know they're wine.  Would recommend getting a table of apps and going family style, you'll get to try so much and it's better on the pocket.  Raw bar could do with some improvement.
author: Kym P.

description:
4.5 stars for the decor. I got the concept and it was well executed. A well-heeled modern take on a casual seafood shack. The only problem is that the food and prices don't really follow through on that premise. I wanted to like it I really did, but I should have known when we got there for happy hour and it was dead.
