Note to Managers: PUT ON SOME HAPPY HOUR SPECIALS! You might think - "We're too nice a place for something trashy like that. We did Salt House and Town Hall!" But hey Bacar has them and they manage to fill up with people who are there for Happy Hour and Dinner Service. I just find it a shame that this could have been a really great place to go to for a casual but well executed seafood shack in the FiDi. This week we go to the place next door which was jumping by the time we left the still empty Anchor & Hope.

2.5 stars for the food. Had Angels on Horseback - meh I think I'm a fresh oyster gal. My companions had the scallop ceviche and an order of the crab claws. Again meh - too much scallop (what? how is that possible?) Ok, maybe it's more accurate to say, not enough everything else. The bits of jalapeno were nice, but other than that the flavors just weren't there. I like to really taste the lime, vinegar, onion etc. instead I just tasted the scallop. The crab claw was ridiculous for $4 a piece, they each had about a tablespoon worth of meat to them. Ironically I have to echo other yelpers in saying the free bread and salty butter were highlights of the time we were there. The olives were also good. The only thing that managed to get an ooo out of us was the dessert (!) The unassuming chocolate cake was really tasty. Simple flavors that popped off the plate. The frosting had a saltiness that was tasty playing off the not too overwhelmingly chocolatey chocolate cake.

5 stars for service. The staff really tried to be welcoming and friendly and we could only sheepishly smile at each other when she would ask how things were, to which we would do our best to say "great", but we both knew that it was not so much.

Maybe this place just needs to rethink who it is. Call me when they decide to simplify the menu and I can go there and have a decent happy hour .
author: Sherrie D.

description:
love the high ceilings and exposed ducting that are so indicative of trendy SoMa these days. waitstaff was extremely attentive and friendly - at one point i dropped my knife and before my bite was swallowed, i had a new knife in hand :) 

we had raw west coast oysters plus the bacon wrapped angels on horseback that i had read so much about. both were tasty and for me not such a huge raw oyster fan, the bacon definitely helped counter that fishy taste i just can't quite handle. 

he had the mussel and monkfish stew which was spicy and delicious! i dipped most of my bread in the broth and we even took some home with us for leftovers. i had the halibut and rosemary potatoes which i was disappointed to find was really just glorified fish and chips. wish i would have ordered something else - although there was no crab entree on the menu i was sad to find. 

dessert was delicious - yogurt and creme heart topped with cherry and raspberry compote...mmmmm 

definitely would go back and try some other things on the menu. worth the experience!
author: jaja w.

description: The sea urchin was fantastic! Apart from the urchin I thought the menu was a bit boring. The quality of the food was very good across the board. The server was knowledgeable and attentive without being in your face. While it's not on my top ten list, I would certainly go back.
author: Amber B.

description:
a lot of new joints have popped up in the year since i've been outta the SF scene....thanks to my good friends for introducing me to this one.

def get a reso

as for the food:
sea urchin and ipswich clams
get them
author: Dpb T.

description: Yawn.  Bleh.  The lobster roll is smothered in mayo, yet still has no flavor.  The only decent aspect of it was the buttery acme roll.   All in all, not very impressive.
author: Deanna K.

description: Noshed here this past Thursday, some would say the dining set up lacks intimacy, but we had a great conversation with the people next to us! Fantastic wine list, great service from the wait staff.  Thoroughly enjoyed the curry prawn app, my duck confit cassoulet was to die for, and the chocolate cake with pistachios was a little slice of heaven.  Tablemates enjoyed the fisherman's stew and the roast lamb with risotto.  Would definitely dine here again!!
author: Kate N.

description: Two of us went to Anchor & Hope for dinner the other night (week night). We had a full dinner with 2 apps, 2 entrées and 1 dessert + drinks. The food was either good or  great, nothing mediocre. We really enjoyed the drink selection - both wine and beer. The server was very nice in allowing tastes of beer to find a selection that would work well for me which was nice. The fish that we had was cooked perfectly and delicious. Although on the pricey side, it was worth it for a special occasion for us.
author: Eric W.

description: Visiting for New Years Eve, My boyfriend and I decided to try Anchor & Hope which as suggested by his sister who is from SF. The location feels like it's a secret spot since it's off the main street, behind a pub. I love the simple painted sign & lamps that make you feel like you're right at the dock. As we entered I noticed the open layout with lots of cool decor. It was casual, but you wouldn't look dumb if you were over dressed either. We checked in early & sat at the bar for a drink. My BF tried the beer sampler which is well priced at $8. I choose a light Pear cider since my stomach was empty. We ordered the following dishes: APPS: CHARRED BABY OCTOPUS & HALF DOZEN OYSTERS. ENTREES: ROCK COD/CRISPY PORK BELLY & SCALLOPS. DESSERTS: MINT TEA, BLUEBERRY TART & CHOCOLATE CAKE... sorry not exact dessert names. Our favs were the octopus, rock cod & crispy pork belly. The oysters were sweet & fresh. The staff was helpful in making selections. Overall a good, but not great experience. Would probably go back to try other dishes like the whole fried tilapia fish or the angels on horseback.
author: Rochelle P.

description: we caught the end of happy hour on fri night.  since they have $1 oysters for HH, we made sure we ordered 4 dozen (for 4 of us!) right before 6:30.  we also got the salt cod brandade and fries.  the oysters were good, but the brandade was a bit bland, considering it was made w/ salted cod.  there are a lot of beers on tap, and for HH, you can get 2 beers for $4 each.  not a bad deal if you can make it here in time by 630!
author: Helen T.

description: Tasty lobster roll, good wine, great service, and a very airy, professional interior for an SF restaurant. Enjoyable!
author: John M.

description:
eh. 

Pros: friendly hostess, food came out quickly, cool atmosphere

Cons: service a little off, food just average tasting.

We got our appetizer before we even had a chance to order wine. The lobster roll was good, but it was kinda small.  I wouldn't make a special effort to come here again.
author: Shing H C.

description: I ate at Anchor & Hope on Tuesday and let me say....WOW. I went with my gf and we split the arctic char and the red snapper. Both were superb. I have worked in restaurants before, and I have been convinced that new restaurants suffer from the usual beginners growing pains, usually related to the service and new cooks; in this case, whomever is working the hot line deserves serious Kudos. Bravo, Anchor & Hope.
author: Jeff G.

description: Great bisque.  That was the extent of the praise I have for Anchor & Hope.  We went On a Saturday night in early December.  It was cold and the aluminum chairs did not help.  They were going to seat us at a table right next to the door... I mean right in front of it... This table should not even be there... it was just an odd placement right as you enter.  We waited at the bar for a table away from the door.  They do have a great beer selection.  The rest of our food was adequate... though too rich, especially for fish.
author: Francis B.

description:
Disappointing! I went in with very high hopes as the restaurant came highly recommended. I'm not even going to complain about our table not being ready when we showed up. We waited at the bar and were seated. Not bad...Sitting around, no one comes by...Finally our waitress shows up and looks like she'd rather be yanking her fingernails out than working. "ready to order" yes, just like that - not, do you have questions, how are you. My friend asked if she could tell us about the menu and she goes "well there is really not much to say"... Kid you not! Anyhow, she recommended some things lack luster, we ordered 2 appetizers and asked she come back for our main course. She walk away, never asks if we want anything to drink. Anyway, another waitress brought over the app, just one... we ate it. No one comes by to check in, ask if we want any wine. "Happy" walks by and avoids any eye contact. I had to actually waive her down and ask for an order of wine. Mind you this girl is pretty much MIA the whole night. She came back with the wine and took for our main order. We're sitting around and our main course comes. No second app!!! So we ask the other waitstaff who brought us our food where our appetizer is. They had no idea, and we just asked them to cancel. Mind you Waitress of the Year doesn't bother to come by and apologize for screwing up, or simply acknowledge us. Just being a raging bitch all around. 

Anyway, the food was ok. The Angels were not bad. I had the salmon and it was pretty bland with a sorta decent sauce and a blob of pure. I've made better at home. My friend said her paella was pretty good. The fish and chips were alright as well, but nothing to throw $26 at. "Happy"  came back and got our desert order. Again, decent but nothing to get excited about. Check came or should I say - she threw it at our table, no apology for screwing up. An anchor came with the check and I was tempted to chuck it at her head. Honesty we're not high maintenance. So long as someone acts like a human being, we're happy. And we were being nice to her the whole night despite her shitty attitude and service. But that was just a crappy experience. Not going back and wouldn't recommend it to my friends. Oh and prices are a little out of control too.
author: T I.

description: fantastic!  with a capital FANTASTIC.  I went here with a friend of mine.  I loved the feel of the place.  The ropes and the exposed wood gave it a dock feel.  The seafood we had was fresh and quite spectacular- this what they are great at. The fisherman's stew is tasty- my mouth is watering just thinking about.  The wine pairings that were recommended really enhaced the entire expierence.  The staff was very friendly and attentive.  Going back for sure.
author: Erin S.

description: A big disappointment.  Since I was here for a work lunch I went ahead and ordered the lobster roll after reading all the reviews.  I was so unimpressed - there was nothing special about it - especially for $25.  The bread was good, toasted but greasy.  The lobster tasted fresh enough and there seemed to be plenty of it (the photos on yelp were accurate) but the overall flavor combination was lacking.  The chips were good, but my co-worker's substituted fried looked much better.  The waiter took forever to take our orders, and not all the food arrived at the same time - a little awkward when you're politely waiting for everyone to be served before you start eating.  However, the servers were great at refilling the water glasses.  The ambiance was fun, an urban take on the nautical theme.  The location was odd, off a side street by itself.  I'm not planning on going back unless someone else is paying and I'd get the burger which looked really great.
author: Erin L.

description: Fabulous food and service.  I had the best seafood dinner hear a few nights ago.  You must try the sea urchin and the king salmon.  I can't wait to go back!
author: Yolanda N.

description: This place is owned by the same team as Town Hall and Salt House and the only reason I gave this place three stars versus four is because I didn't feel it was as great as Town Hall-- but I do like it and would recommend it. I think the only other thing that prevented me giving it four stars was the price. Although the food was good and it was good quality it seemed a tad overpriced. For appetizers you can't go wrong with the raw bar, but the sea urchin appetizer was fantastic as well. For entrees the fish and chips were good and the lobster roll was nice. Dessert were ok. Service was attentive and knowledgable.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Early Sunday dinner with friends, we were the first guests to arrive at the restaurant at 5.30pm. Greeted by a somewhat vacant hostess and shown to our table. I really like the interior decoration, contemporary feel with a nice used edge. Love the big fish eat little fish mural above the bar. Ok, so to the food and drink. To start we shared the artichoke crusted with cornmeal and shrimp fritters, well presented and very fresh, but bland (for me), that's because I didn't like the dipping sauces they came with. Main course, the cod and herbed fries were absolutely outstanding, Tuna was great and the trout delicious. Now to the beverages. This place has an incredible collection of ever changing world class beers that is hard to match in San Francisco, expensive, why of course yes, $20+ for a bottle? You bet sir! But hey, it's a beers drinkers heaven make no mistake, couple that with the solid food and it makes for a great dinning experience. Did I mention the service? Well it was OK, not great, just OK. Our waiter decided that after 45 mins of floor time it was time for his break, in the middle of our meal. Another waitress took over, but only because we asked for service.
author: Kevin S.

description: My husband and I went here with our, let's just say "antsy" toddler. We were reluctant to dine at this establishment because it is on the nicer side and we hate to interrupt other people while they are out and trying to enjoy a nice meal. We were brought here after reading about the warmed Uni appetizer. It did not disappoint and neither did the other dishes we had. The Uni dish even inspired us to re-name our new dog.Their are few places I give 5 stars, but A&H gets it not only for their great food, but for their EXTREMELY courteous and friendly staff. Our waiter was completely understanding of our need to speed things along. He was very quick to exchange our empty beer/wine glasses (it was happy hour). Our son is frequently throwing things down on the ground and every staff member that walked by was happy to pick anything up and hand it back to him. They also get bonus points for having a mermaid logo. I look forward to dining here again and maybe next time we can get a sitter and stay a little longer. =)
author: O Ommmm O.

description:
I'm not much of a seafood fan but when I heard that the crew behind Salt House and Townhall were opening up another place, I decided to check it out.  The space of the restaurant made me feel like I was in a small intimate clam-bake back east. Decor was simple but still very fresh...candles lit every where with white roses as their standard flower centerpiece...i didn't feel like i was in SOMA of San Francisco...had a good East Coast feeling to it.
Since A & H didn't have their liquor license just yet, we were told that we could bring our own wine and wouldn't be charged a corkage fee...SWEET.  Our waiter was extremely cute, friendly & attentive but not overbearing. In fact, the whole staff was attentive and great. We were recommended the seafood platter and we dove right in...for 42 dollars, I thought that might have been a little bit much BUT this is San Francisco so I wasn't surprised. I didn't count, but it came with a lot of oysters that for two people we were having a hard time finishing it...and this NEVER happens, as I happen to love oysters. There were cocktail shrimps (really fish and plump) and stow crab claws, which I was a little disappointed because they weren't fresh...I am guessing they aren't fresh because Stowe crabs are mainly harvest in Virginia, so i am assuming that they were shipped, plus they had that texture where something was frozen and just thawed feel. But I liked it overall...
Entree: I got the spicy mussel and monk fish stew and it was good...It's comes with little toasted bread on the side so that you can dip into the rich, tomato/bell peppery broth. I liked it and would ordered it again. My date got the scallops...I've had better...I wasn't impressed and would not recommend it....especially if you are picky about scallops. 
On to desserts...if you come here...you have to get dessert. I thought it was actually better than our entrees...hahahaha...
I got the rhubarb strawberry cobbler with homemade graham cracker topping and a scoop of their Tahitian vanilla ice cream...SIMPLY DIVINE & my date got the brandied cherries creme brulee...yum...
JUST yum...it was heaven. 
Overall...I would recommend Anchor and Hope...the atmosphere, starters, desserts and wait staff make it worth coming back for.
author: Mary B.

description: Such a cute name!!! A shame that the feel didn't match.  I felt like I had to act proper in the place.  Mind you, if that's what you're into - then I would give it five stars.  But when you feel like you would be offending the staff by not having a brooch on your lapel, I'll call not it... however, willing to give it another chance - I'm not quite definitive on my opinion yet...
author: Yve T.

description:
Loved the interior of the restaurant. Aside from that, all I have to say is lobster roll time! Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm.

Also, a coworker got the steak sandwich, and they are generous with the steak, if you catch my drift.

Looking forward to going back for dinner.
author: Kaveh A.

description:
Took my CEO and a business partner here for lunch.  Called in for a reservation and was placed on hold 3 times in a row for a long time.  Probably spent 25 minutes holding when we were only 10 minutes away.  Seems the hostess was MIA and whoever was answering the phone didn't have the training to book tables.

Ambiance was fine - a little loud due to the brick warehouse but still comfortable.  It took a while to get a server to come over - I noticed she was also playing hostess and busing tables so they may have been understaffed.

We ordered some wine and oysters followed by fish and chips.  30 minutes later as the wine was running dry - still no sign of the oysters.  Figured that was because we ordered the ones from Oregon and they had gone to farm them fresh.  Waitress tells us they are on the way (without checking with anyone).  They did bring bread in a little paper bag - I think the idea was supposed to be clever but we found it cheap.  Ran out of butter pretty quickly and they didn't notice - had to ask and the refill took 10 minutes.

40 minutes into the meal - oysters arrive - yea!  We slurp those up instantly then there is another 20 minute wait for the main dishes.  Fish and chips were just OK but for the price I felt pretty ripped off.  They tasted a bit watery and we had to ask a few times for more sauce.  At this point the crowd had dissipated and the whole staff was congratulating themselves on another lunch service finished, while we were still waiting for condiments.

We ended up late getting back for our 2 pm meeting even though we should have had ample time.  We would like to be fans of the Town Hall and Salt House crowd but for serial restaurateurs they just really don't have a solid game.  Plus that whole screw-you attitude.  Probably won't be back.
author: Sara L.

description: Their Sea Urchin appetizer was the best thing that I had there.  The food is good and the service is also very good, the wait staff was very attentive.  I had the char, which was good but not great.  My friend enjoyed her snapper though. She ate everything sans the bones, tail and eyeballs.
author: Lorraine Y.

description:
Maybe it should be called "Hope and a Prayer"!

Okay, so I would probably give this place more like 4 stars based on the food alone, but combined with the clumsy service and lack of  atmosphere I wouldn't recommend it. I had dinner here last night with three friends and we all felt that it was a major disappointment.

First of all, the dining room atmosphere is ill-conceived and poorly executed. It is a nice size room with exposed rafters and skylights which could be good. But as soon as you walk in you notice the awkward scattering of mismatched tables, some with linens, some without, and some placed just feet from the door. The seating also seems as much of an afterthought made up of uncomfortable aluminum chairs and wooden benches. They are apparently going for a "fish shack" atmosphere, but if you're not paying "fish shack" prices than you would expect a little more . They are obviously going for something here, but it just looks cheap and thrown together. They have used incredibly flimsy looking metal factory lighting and they threw up a few old fishing lanterns above the seating. It looks like they've set up for a theme party and forgot to put the rest of it up, or forgot to take it all down. The mural behind the bar is graphic and modern but completely incongruous to the rest of the decor. Also the open service station is poorly placed outside the bathrooms which also seems strange and serves to cut off flow. 

The service was also pretty appalling. For a place that charges $12 for a salad, you'd imagine the service would be pretty great. However, this is not the case. The service was slow and not particularly friendly.  It seems our server had to leave after asking every question. He asked if we wanted water, then left for 10 minutes, then came back and we ordered drinks, then left for 10 minutes, then we ordered some oysters, another 10 minutes, the oysters came and we still did not have our drinks, then he came back and we finally got to order our main dishes, our salads came fairly promptly, but it seems like our entrees took forever. When they did arrive, my partner asked for more sauce, which never came, and at one point I was asked by a server to hand him a plate that was apparently out of his reach. Now, normally I am happy to help out, but when a meal is over $300 for four people, it is unacceptable. 

Now the food is the one bright spot here. I have to say they have some very inventive and delicious dishes. They have a good selection of oysters and they were fresh and creamy, however the platter came with two sauces and no way to spoon them on. I ordered the smoked trout salad that blew me away, it was very good, although no fresh cracked pepper was offered to anyone at my table. This was followed by the Monkfish, Mussel, and Saffron Chorizo stew, again it was excellent, although it was so hot when it came to the table I think it was still boiling. My partner ordered their version of fish and chips which he said were outstanding. But do beware of the iced tea, which tasted, believe it or not, like liquid smoke had been added, very odd. 

It seems like this place is going through growing pains. But with so many amazing restaurants in the Bay Area they need to figure it out. The kitchen seems to have it together, but the front of the house needs a lot of work. The decor is either not enough or too much of a theme and not high-end enough for the food and it's prices. The service needs to be streamlined and polished. There seems to be a lot of servers rushing around looking busy, but not being very efficient. I will try to come back here in a few months to do a follow up, although I don't think I will have any luck persuading my friends to come back with me.
author: Andrew D.

description: I had lunch and dinner here last week and I'm impressed.  Their fresh seafood bar includes a great shrimp cocktail and a good variety of oysters.  The space is really cool, very large and light.  It's tucked away on Minna right at 2nd.
author: Christine E.

description: Great food and wine. Scallops were delicious. Wait staff was friendly and helpful. Fun atmosphere!  Would go back on another visit to San Francisco.
author: Michelle C.

description: We came for dinner with a group of 6. It was really loud and very difficult to exchange conversation. The restaurant is more like a shellfish bar with a lot of tables. A couple of us don't eat shellfish, so I can't attest to the crab and oysters etc. Also, the chef seemed determined to X-out the non-shellfish options by adding non-Kosher ingredients to the fish dishes, such as pork belly, catfish, and ribs. So, it was very frustrating trying to order. But the fish we had, Idaho trout and almond crusted Shetland salmon, was very good. Just be prepared for a limited fish menu. For some reason we had an exceptional wait (over an hour) for our entreés. The menu had asparagus as a side on many of the dishes, but by the time we were served we got broccolini, so it's possible they ran out and had to send someone to Safeway for another vegetable. There is a huge and astonishing beer menu.
author: Eileen A.

description: Recommended from a good friend, we headed over to Anchor & Hope for a V.D. celebration. V.D. as in cupid, People. I had the Angel's on Horseback and the cod main dish done cajun style. LaDuke had the soup and then the salmon main dish. We had a good bottle of wine they suggested. We loved the service and open space. The food was very yummy. Good and quality ingredients. This is the place to go for seafood. We will be back. I'd give it 3.5 if I could.
author: Seymour S.

description: Well, just went there for lunch, didn't pay so I wasn't shy about ordering. Went with a whole bunch of fellow workers and they raved about the lobster roll. It looked hefty. As for the tuna melt, there 2 thumbs up delicious and on thumb down taste like subway. The raves the angels on horseback got made us order several orders. Ho-hum actually. The rule that everything tastes good when fried holds true and the oyster was nice and creamy inside but it was a bit "hard" on the outside, not crunchy, if you know what I mean. I had the crab salad which was just okay. I've been known to sacrifice a live crab for my personal delectation and so my familiarity and my standards are high, so I would venture a guess that the crab was cooked the day before, and possibly not alive/fresh when it was cooked at that. I love raw oysters and the eastern oysters were delicious, briny and tasted of the ocean in all her glory. The local oysters tasted off, fishy and full of iodine. Stick with the east coast ones. The fish tacos were a disappointment, not tasty or crunchy using what looked and tasted like store bought tacos wrapping around bland poorly fried pieces of non descript fish. Contrast that with the excellent fried chips. The dusting of seasoning was haphazard which made for an uneven experience should you just eat one but well I couldn't just eat one, or two, or three so if I ever came back (doubtful) I'd make sure they were on the table right in front of me. Service from the manager was great, she was attentive and efficient. The waitstaff was another story. They didn't know who ordered what, they took my water glass and I had to ask for another one since they never came back with another. They poured for one side of the table and ignored the other. One person waited 5 minutes before we told them that we were missing an order. Very unprofessional, almost amateurish. For the money we didn't have to pay, I would say go elsewhere where someone who does pay will get what he or she paid for. If you know what I mean.
author: bongo c.

description: Great food, try the Angels on horseback, and the sea urchin soup!
author: jack j.

description:
Seeing all the great reviews on here and the sibling restaurants that Anchor & Hope have I thought it was going to be way better than it was.  
The place is amazing, loved the decor (the 1.5 stars) but the food and drinks where mediocre. 
We did not have a reservation so we were at the bar, no biggy, so we ordered some apps to check it out and see if we would wait out the wait for a table. We order oysters and smelts. The oysters where good (.5 stars) but the smelts.....not so good. For the amount that we paid and getting sand in our mouths because of the lack of cleaning of these little fishes was not good. The cava that I had was pretty boring and tasteless. I being a foodie and my sis and friend that had worked at Kokkari...me were not impressed and decided to go home to Kokkari and have some real abundant clean smelts.
I might try it again if someone really wants to go but not recommending it to anyone. 
Sorry A&H as I really wanted to try the sea urchin dish and oysters wrapped in bacon.  Maybe one of these days.
author: Jacqueline A.

description:
I wish there was a 3 1/2 star option. That's what I'd give it.

My one visit told me:

the food is pretty good. I had sizuan (sp?) prawns, and we had those fried clam things for appetizers. Both very good.

But they didn't have the bacon wrapped things for lunch (at what point in the day can you not have bacon, really?) and I heard the crab roll was just pretty good/okay, not spectacular.

I think they're still working out the tweaks of their service since it's fairly new. they forgot to bring us our sides, but then comped us dessert and the chocolate cake thing was really good.

interesting environment.

I think the reason why the score drags down a little is because this place kind of sets a certain level of expectation, and I don't think it really got up to that level during my visit. I felt like it was stuck between wanting to be real straight up sea food joint without a lot of bs, and wanting to be the new hot hip trendy place to go.
author: Karen J.

description:
A very good but not great experience.

There were aspects of greatness:  the ahi tuna with grean pea hummus and the warm sea urchin were outstanding dishes.

There was the nice surprise of perfectly fried oysters on top of the gravlox.

Then there was a scallop ceviche that tasted a bit like raw scallops that had been marinated in thousand island dressing--not a happy combination in any way.

Then there were oysters that were just tastless and a waste of time and money to eat.

Finally a dessert that made it clear that this is a place to forget dessert. 

The staff were all quite pleasant and did a nice job.

So, I would happily go back and order the tuna entree, and might even order two of those dishes all for myself next time.  I would order the urchin again, but I would stay away from everything else.
author: Richard P.

description:
Went for lunch today. beautiful vibe - love the way the sunlight shines through the ceiling. Very cool interior. The wait staff was great. Very attentive but not too much. Water is bottled and kept on the table which is great. They even brought a second bottle. Bread comes in a bag which is cute. I had the lobster roll which was yummy. I didn't eat the roll part since I had a piece of the bread but it looked great. Came with their own kettle chips - really good, light and crispy. My friend had crab louis salad which she ate very slowly and very completely. She is a critic - and ate the whole thing and loved it. She didn't offer me a bite so I know it must have been killer. We were too full for dessert. Because of the cement floors and steel structure - tall ceilings - there is a noise issue. So sit close, talk low and hear what I say.  I love Town Hall and Salt House so what can I say? I'm in love with these guys. They get it right every time. 

For lunch: go early and book reservations. I can't wait to go back for drinks and pupu's. I'll report back soon.
author: Good J.

description: I came here for dinner and had a great time.  It's a good choice if you want very good seafood with a hint of goof-ball atmosphere.  If I return, it will likely be for lunch.
author: eli c.

description:
Yum-diddy-yum-yummy! Who knew you could open up three restaurants in the same 1 block radius and give them each such a distinct and worth-while reason for being!!? We found ourselves without a reservation on Saturday and threw caution to the wind - we went early and crashed the bar. And it was the best seat in the house! Highly recommend sitting at the deeper section of the long bar. You get a nice view of the kitchen and can watch all of the food come out while you decide what to order. You also get a server instead of the person behind the bar, who can sometimes be distracted by drink orders. 
And speaking of servers, we had a great one! Be on the look out for the girl with the wavy short hair and slightly tinted glasses. She rocks! 
The food was fantastic. I highly recommend the smoked trout & frissee salad and the bouillabaisse.  Plus they serve every wine on their menu by the glass - a very nice and unique feature. We'll be back.
author: Heather G.

description: Good meal great service cool place to go with a group!
author: David G.

description: Maybe they had a bad night but we won't be back. We had a reservation for 8:45 Saturday night. It was kind of a special occasion for us so I was looking forward to a nice night out with my husband. First impressions were good. It's a really cool looking space. We had to wait a little longer for our table - fine, we can deal with that. The beer was pretty good - sorry, I can't remember what we ordered. It took a while for the waiter to come around and take our order. Um, ok. The place was busy but emptying out quickly. Finally ordered - oysters, apps and entrees. The oysters took about 20 minutes to come out. The apps didn't arrive for another almost 40 minutes. The restaurant is half empty by now. We're looking around. No one has any food on their table. Hmmm. Apologies from the waiter. Still no food. Finally, we threaten to leave if or food wasn't there in five minutes. Apps show up. 15 more minutes. Still no entrees. Still no one in the restaurant has food. We're leaving in 5 minutes if entrees don't arrive. We ask to see the manager who offers an excuse of "Sorry, the kitchen is really slammed." We look around - don't buy the excuse. Only half the tables are filled. Anyway, the food arrives. I had the halibut - supposedly a signature dish. The fish is cold and the veggies underneath piping hot. Not too tasty. On the other hand the soft shell crab I had for an app was great. Maybe this place was good in the past but I see a quick demise for Anchor and Hope.
author: Bobbi C.

description: I wanted to love it, I really did.  Ambiance?  Awesome.  Service? A-ok but nothing to write home about.  Food?  In one word, "Meh."  Started out with the Angels on Horseback which I've heard so much about, and I was unimpressed.  Oysters were overly tough and fishy, and that's coming from an oyster lover.  Clam chowder, however, was amazing.  Great place to try, but make sure you're ready to shell out (pun intended) some cash.  Glad I went, but probably won't be back.
author: Lauren M.

description: I give this place 4 stars because the staff at this place is some of the best I've ever experienced.  Me and a group of friends found ourselves wondering SOMA on a Friday night without a plan - meaning, every place we ventured into was packed.  We happened to see this quaint place up on of the small alleyways off 2nd and were practically treated like movie stars on the red carpet.  Not only were we ushered in like VIPs, we were all seated immediately!  We did not eat as we were looking for a nice place to visit and have a drink.  The beer menu was exceptional and the staff was extremely helpful in providing samples of those we were a bit hesitant about ordering.  We WILL be going back for a full meal at this place!  Check it out!
author: Wen Z.

description: I had dinner here this past weekend and was very, very impressed. The space is beautiful. Had the garlic shrimp appetizer, the salmon entree, and the carrot cake dessert. All three were fantastic. And our waiter was freakin' adorable! Will definitely be going back. OH - INCREDIBLE beer selection, too.
author: Robert M.

description: I have had dinner at Anchor & Hope three times in the 7 months I have lived in San Francisco. Is it "high end"? No. Does it have a full bar? No. Is it amazing seafood in a comfortable and casual setting? Yes. This place changed my opinion of Oysters. For the price, I think it offers by far the most bang for your buck if you want good seafood.
author: Jonah B.

description: I like coming here for lunch.  The place has great energy and the food is consistently good.  I always leave this place happy.  So far I've tried the lobster roll (yum - wish it was bigger), lobster bisque (i am a lobster fan), salmon, and tuna melt.  My favorite is the complimentary bread and butter :)
author: M L.

description: The food is great, waiters are very friendly and know the menu very well ... The atmosphere is very relaxing... Great place to have a nice dinner !
author: Aleks D.

description: This place is a must to try. Here are some reviews on their greatest plates! http://www.lipglossculture.com/2011/food-pop-anchor-and-hope-soma-district-san-francisco-review/
author: Katie G.

description:
Excellent all-around.  The fish warehouse ambience, complete with several nautical touches, is fabulous.  The fish and shellfish are fresh and delicious.

It's all about the details here: little stitched anchors on the waiter's aprons, bacon-wrapped oysters ("angels on horseback") over a bed of seaweed, an extensive BEER menu, hand-stamped paper bags to serve the acme baguettes in . . . . I could go on and on.  

Not to mention the service was top notch, with wonderful recommendations and attentive staff.  This is a great SOMA spot.

Thanks for making my valentine's day even more special, Anchor & Hope!
author: Matthew A.

description: The food is excellent - our fish entrees were impeccably prepared.  We had the tai snapper and the trout en papillote.  They were both extraordinarily good.   We started with some oysters, which were actually a touch disppointing (Zuni Cafe has a better selection and seem fresher, not to mention their superior mignonette).  The red curry shrimp appetizier was very good as well.  We loved the ambiance - just a very, very cool space which was not overdone; the service was excellent.  The wine list was extensive, as was the beer selection.  THE ONLY NEGATIVE WAS THE PRICE - $25-30 FOR A PLATE OF FISH???  DON'T THEY KNOW WE'RE IN A RECESSION?  We will likely go back, drawn by the genius and execution of their simple fish dishes, but won't be regulars at these prices.  4 Stars food, 1 Star due to price.
author: C.M. L.

description:
honestly im not a seafood person
but my bf wanted me to give it a try soo i did
and i was far from dissapointed

the bf and i ordered way more than 2 people can possibly eat so we took a lot home but it was fun to try everything

 first we had some type of mashed potatoes with cod mixed in, sounds funky but it was delish

we then had an expensive but amazing little salad with cheese tomatoes and some sort of vinegrette i think it may have been the arugala salad or little gem i cant recall

we then had the ahi tuna poke im not a sushi fan but dipped in the sauce they make it was yummmmmy

then we had some fancy fries and tried a few of the happy hour oysters which were bomb
he had a few of the happy hour beers which we discovered when we got the check werent the happy hour beers haha make sure you get the right ones

we had the sea urchin in its shell next and it looked so weird! but tasted suprisingly good, a little weird for my taste but my bf loves seafood so he liked it a lot

then for the entres we got the seared ahi which was tasty and a steak that was grilled to perfection

to finish it off with desert i had the bluebottle milkshake best milkshake ive ever had



the service was great the server was very attentive and knowledgeable

the menu has changed since i went there last because they have a new chef but i am sure that the food is still great

this is the only seafood restaurant i will ever eat at and i am sure i will go there again. im not just saying this because i know several people that work there, i really did enjoy the whole experience

the prices are high but so is everywhere else in the city. 
this place is hidden in an alleyway which is unfortunate because it makes it harder to stumble upon unless you yelp a lot

i would suggest a change of location but im not sure they would listen =p

they get suuuuuuuper busy on the weekend so i would suggest a reservation!
author: breeanna h.

description: Went here for a girl's night out and had the best time.  I'm from the east coast and just went ga-ga for the decor and then ga-ga again for the yummy oysters.  We tried everything on the menu and passed plates like crazy and it was one of the best dinners I've ever had.  Go there!
author: Amy D.

description:
Who doesn't want to try a new place, right?  I went to Anchor and Hope and was not disappointed.  Although I did enjoy the sea urchin appetizer, I thought that it was a little overwhelmed by the potatoes.  

My entree had great flavors, textures and was the perfect size.  I definitely recommend the sea bass with ramps.  My friend had the lobster and was very pleased with it.  

My only problem with the dinner was my server's wine knowledge.  Working at a similar type restaurant, I expect a knowledgeable recommendation and instead was given a glass of wine so dry that I couldn't drink it.  Yuck.  

Despite the wine incident, the rest of the meal was great and I was very satisfied.  I'll be back Anchor and Hope!
author: blythewood m.

description:
Ate there last night.  Food was pretty good, not outstanding.  We had a pretty good amount of wine, but still were surprised by the final bill total.  Seemed pretty expensive for this type of restaurant, as it's really a casual place.  Fish and chips are the best, the tuna was pretty good too.  Nice selection of oysters as well... 

All in all, I probably won't go out of my way to go back, maybe down the road.
author: Brad G.

description: Had great service on a girls' night out here.  It's got nice, clean chic ambiance, freshey fresh fish and a great wine list.  The bread was warm and lovely.
author: Mission D.

description: lobster roll was quite good and fried pickles were interesting.  overall, a decent restaurant for work lunches but i would go to other seafood restaurants if you're craving a great seafood meal.
author: Helen T.

description: The sea urchin and crab appetizer was good. So was the tuna special but the entrees are WAAYYYY over-priced. The oysters were also over-priced starting at $3 a piece. This is kind of ridiculous when you can get them elsewhere at $1.75 and $3 on the high end. It must be the ambience you are paying for. Although I have to say our waitress was surprisingly snooty given that the bill for 2 people was pushing $200.
author: Chris D.

description:
we went to salt house and they were fully booked so the hostess recommended us to go to a&h because there was no wait. since this restaurant is literally in an alleyway, you wouldnt have noticed it unless you knew you were going there. inside a not so nice brick building, the interior decoration is surprisingly very nice. the clientele of the restaurant were all business people during lunch on a weekday. the food is definitely pricey for lunch, so hopefully your boss is paying, as it was for me :) 

i ordered the spice seared ahi tuna. i was hesitant about this because i hate cooked ahi tuna. however the waitress said it wasn't cooked too much and i requested that it be cooked even less. but when the dish actually came out, the server (different from the waitress) gave my coworker, who ordered the same thing, my request... he didnt notice but i definitely noticed that his ahi tuna was not as cooked as mine. he loved it but i was a bit peeved that they didnt give me the correct one, since the dish is $23. simple mistake but one ding for service. however there was someone always coming by to pour your water if you like that kind of thing. the others ordered sandwiches and they were quite satisfied with it as well. overall its a great place but i wont be coming too often since their menu is a bit pricey... their happy hour menu does look more affordable and good though! might come back for that..
author: Jen S.

description:
Great set-up, beautifully done, and good food.  

A heads up:  they don't have their liquor license yet, so it's BYO w/ no corkage fees.  

We were seated promptly for dinner, hostess super friendly and bubbly.  Our server was very knowledgeable, albeit a bit too detail oriented at times.  Service was super fast, possibly a bit too fast... our entrees came before one of our apps so we kindly asked that if they hadn't started on the second app, that we'd just cancel it and certainly do dessert instead. 

Portions are a bit on the smaller side so order up.  Roasted stuffed lobster was half a small lobster.  Halibut was on the small side too.  Lobster was tasty, halibut a bit oversalted.  Good selection of oysters, but the rest of their raw bar that's listed on their menu online is not quite up and running yet.  Love that they do fresh grated horseradish with their oysters!

Realistically, they are not quite fully set up in general, our server pointed out.  Only 3 desserts to choose from so far:  Strawberry Rhubarb Crumble, Brandied Cherries Creme Brulee, and Chocolate Pound Cake.  

Lunch service starts today!   Ambiance - 5 stars, Service 3.5 stars, Food 3.5 stars.  It's a pretty spacious set-up so probably would be good for groups.  It was a tad bit warm in there though even though they had the doors wide open.
author: Haxter G.

description: I'd give it 4 stars for the space and 2 stars for the food which averages out to 3 stars total.  They did a great job with the space and it is a wonderful after work location for FiDi workers - great energy, great people watching.  The food was nothing special though.  We had the fries with eyes and stuffed clams appetizers both of which were fine but certainly nothing special.  We then had the halibut and lobster roll.  Again, nothing to write home about.  They only have a handful of desserts.  We had the chocolate blackout cake and the mixed berry shortcake - both of which were exceptional.  I'd definitely go back for cocktails and dessert, but would have dinner elsewhere.
author: Tom S.

description:
We went on a Sunday night for the first time and enjoyed it.  The space is alot airier than Salt House, which we prefer (I do not like bumping elbows with the person at the table next to me).

We started off with some Oysters.  Then I had the chowder and my husband got the fried clams.  Both the appetizers were okay - not fabulous, but okay.  The chowder was more thin and soupy.  Clams were fine, but had more fry than clams (but perhaps, it's unfair to compare them to the clams we get in MA).  We both ordered the char - quite yummy, with cooked fennel and crispy skin.  The char will bring us back to try other things.
author: C K.

description:
The food was nothing special. Good food but not what I was expecting from the people who brought us Town Hall. Great beer selection but the wine list was unimpressive.

I would go back for lunch but it's expensive, generic seafood.
author: Jen J.

description: Sea urchin. It's not exactly a "go-to" item on which one pounces when perusing a menu.  That being said, Anchor & Hope made a believer out of me.  My famously fabulous friend and I endeavored to try the sea urchin one rainy night on a bit of a dare.  The bartender who was friendly but unobtrusive gave this urchin and crab appetizer so hearty an endorsement that we simply had to order it.  And it was fabulous. The sea urchin's soft, velvety texture was, well, a bit sensual--and definitely delectable.  The dozen oysters we ordered were a mixure of east and west coast lovelies, and my dining companion and I both concurred that it was all about the west coast, baby.  Those oysters were far superior in taste and texture.  As far as entrees go . . . both the scallops and the ahi tuna were fabulous, and the red wine was absolutely fine.  The acoustics aren't the greatest, so be prepared for a it to be a bit noisy.  We sat at the bar to be closer and better able to enjoy and comprehend each other's words before their syllables were lost in the past.  Be forewarned.  Anchor & Hope does not have a full bar--just beer, ale, and wine, but who cares? This out-of-the-way restaurant, housed in an historic building is definitely worth setting down anchor for a moment in time, and I hope you do.
author: Shadi G.

description: Great atmosphere. It's off on the side roads and it feels like you're going the wrong way. Then all of a sudden this small restaurant with a cool look and a huge glass front appears. The food is really good and it's always a good sign when the beer menu is about 4x the length of the food menu. They focus  on Belgian beers and they have a great drought selection as well as bottles. I wasn't too hungry so I had a great salad - persimmon salad - and an interesting (if ugly), tasty appetizer as my entree: the sea urchin and dungeness crab. It was served in the urchin. Cool but ugly...
author: Duke S.

description:
Anchor & Hope is a great fish house. Probably one of the best in the city. The food is Inventive and flavorful. Ambience, despite the somewhat staged feel, is casual and welcoming. Service is attentive. The third restaurant from the people that brought you Town Hall, to me, scores as number two.

For an in-depth photographic review, read more at 
http://www.nosaladasameal.com/2008/05/anchor-hope-san-francisco.html
author: Haas H.

description: I love this restaurant and no, it's not just because I leased it to the Tenant on behalf of the Owner, but the atmosphere really is nice there.   It's a rustic feel and great seafood too ....
author: Jay S.

description:
Upon my first visit to this place i was totally divided, so I had to go back for a second time before reviewing. Alas... I am still totally divided! There are things that I love and things that I hate. 
The decor is super cool, a little over done but very well executed. Details like an ancient classroom desk as the host stand and a wrought iron community table with giant wedges securing its position summon emotions and memories warm and inviting. You feel as if you are in Nantucket steps from the ocean and a Kennedy. The blinking buoy above the bathrooms however??? Are you kidding me? Apparently not.
TO THE FOOD
The food gets a mere "meh" from myself and my guests. The first time we were a party of 6 so we had plenty to share and taste. The "fries with eyes" and the seafood stew were the only things worth remembering. The black bass was good but nothing special; the lobster roll was good but nothing special; the fried clams were good but nothing special. Do you sense a theme here? The second time around it was one other person and I solamente. We were lucky enough to order the sea urchin with dungenous crab and potato served in its shell. In fact this dish bumped the review up to 3 stars from 2; its that good. The foie special however... BORING. There was little chunks of tuna (I think) on the plate with this marmalade stuff that I kept mistaking for the the foie and toward the end of the dish I was just pissed. I want my foie to shine and represent itself in all its evil glory.
This place is worth checking out but temper your expectations. Like its sisters Town Hall and Salt House, Anchor and Hope has great things and terribly wrong things. I'd even just sit at the counter with the bulbous breastastic lanterns hung from above, you're more than likely to check your expectations that way.
author: Ishmael C.

description:
Great service - maybe a little too good.  the busboys are so eager to work, that they scooped up our plates before we were finished....slow down dudes.

The apps were all tasty - the fried clams were seasoned well, the oysters were fresh, and the ceviche was unique, fresh and good flavors. 
We tried the fish & chips - fantastic fish, the chips were a little soggy and over seasoned. Overall, a solid dish. The lobster roll was typical east coast style, not too much mayo. The salmon was a bit overcooked and the biggest let down for the night. 

I would go back and suggest that if you go, you use the recommendations from yelp - they served us well!!
author: Ore d.

description:
so much potential but definitely not fantastic.

Food:  fish and chips that everyone raves about was average, although i like the fries with thyme
sole, mine was late in arriving cause the chef burnt it(?) so then i think it came out right after but i felt like it was a bit under cooked?  either way it didnt feel right . I had a tasting of most of the menu since we had a large party but everything mediocre.

service:  we got our food very very late .  waited over an hour!  (maybe it was because we had a large party- but thats still no excuse)
author: chris y.

description: I showed up to Anchor and Hope mistaking my reservation for the wrong day.  The restaurant was super busy but i was excited to try it so really disappointed when i realized my mistake.  They could not have been nicer - we had a short wait during which time the manager brought us through some great wine tastings and then got us seated rather quickly.  The atmosphere is fantastic - a great combo of rustic seafood shack with nice dining experience. The food was excellent - great fresh shellfish (oyster bar is great and love the clams! - and there is a ton of variety for mains.  I will put this on my staple go to list!
author: Kate E.

description: I have gone to this place twice. I have been amazed at their oyster selection both times. Also, the staff is super relaxed and knowledgeable. The service was outstanding. The second time I went, my waitress informed me that the chef had just changed. The first time I ordered the tuna which was good, and the second time I got the halibut which was delicious. I really enjoyed how light and fresh it tasted and how it was presented on the plate. Also, the salad with the mint is really good.  The mint adds a little extra zing and the dressing is great as well. Props to the new chef, Peter.
author: Kate R.

description:
interior is cool....but super loud.

tried the bacon wrapped oysters and they were pretty good...but totally overpriced...$13 for 4 cooked oysters.

tried 2 entrees...both average and overpriced.  lobster roll was below average.....Waterbar's is infinitely better.  the chips that came with the lobster were way tooooo salty (and i love salt).

also tried seared ahi......the fish was gross but the beans/sausage/sauce was good.

definitely disappointing....Salt (right around the corner) is much much better.
author: Jay M.

description: I liked the high ceilings and industrial space, and the heirloom tomato salad was good.  The lobster roll was only fine.  I'm from Maine.  It had the right kind of bun, meaning kind of like a hot dog bun, except that all that crust stuff is shaved off on the proper lobster roll/tuna-salad-at-Friendly's bun.   But the lobster to bread ration was not sufficient.  Not enough lobster meat.   It made me a bit sad.  I was really looking forward to this lobster roll.  I was working way too hard at work (it was a couple of weeks ago), and feeling homesick, not really for Maine, but more for my friends and family (because I'd been working so hard I hadn't seen them), and this was a rare lunch out.   So it was a disappointment.  But I'm picky, and this is a limited review.  Also, the quality was really good and the dressing was right.  It  just needed more lobster to be truly authentic.  As I said, I'm picky, the salad was great, the atmosphere was too, and I'm sure that one Mainer's review of a roll isn't enough.  But there you have it.  It was the entire reason I came here.
author: Laurel B.

description: Ambiance was a four. Food was a five. Sampled some appetizers and we were thoroughly impressed. Bacon-wrapped oysters were incredible, even for two people who don't necessarily like bacon. Would definitely come here again, and for sure bring a date.
author: ross f.

description: I had a business lunch at Anchor & Hope a couple of weeks ago and loved it. I had the fish tacos that were fantastic. The staff was extremely helpful and friendly. I will definitely be going back in the near future!
author: Bridget H.

description: we had the angels on horseback, fresh uni, lobster rolls polished off with draft beers - a grand slam in my book. keep it up a&h
author: Curt W.

description: a nice casual lunch stop after visiting sfmoma. the restaurant has wonderful decor and friendly staff. i really enjoy my fish taco as well as generous collection of beer and wine.
author: Connie H.

description: If you are like me than quality beer and french fries are one of my primary food groups.  Anchor and hope has an amazing local beer selection and wonderful (and really salty) sweet potato fries.  I just discovered this place a few months back and am definitely a fan.
author: Miss A.

description: I enjoyed Anchor & Hope.  The decor was creative with a lot of character, from the fish painted on the wall behind the bar to the wooden bench that looks like it belongs in a park.  Even the bill came out with a tool for deep sea fishing.  The waitstaff was attentive, though my waitress yesterday seemed a bit scripted and robotic.  My friend and I tried all of the oysters and the bacon wrapped oyster appetizer, which was tasty with a satisfying combination of crunchy and soft.  I ordered the lobster roll entree, consisting of marinated pieces of lobster in a bread roll, with homemade kettle potato chips and cold slaw.  I ate the lobster without the roll and it was flavorful with a kick.  The chips were thin and crispy with just enough salt and pepper, while the cold slaw was refreshing.  My friend had the sea bass, which from a taste was good.  Then we had the multi layered chocolate cake that had expresso spreads between its layers and pieces of caramel brittle to top it off.  The cake was very moist and rich, so the brittle added a nice diversity of texture, making it more delicious.  A minor complaint was that our sauvignon blanc was too chilled causing its flavors and aromas to be absent.  However, overall I had a pleasant dining experience at Anchor & Hope.
author: Linda P.

description: We had the lobster roll and clam chowder.  The clam chowder was very bland, tasted like sweet milk with some white corn and 2 clams.  I wanted to take it home so i could add some other stuff like small diced potatoes or dill biscuits, but they did not have any take out cups.  The lobster roll was also very bland.  It had no taste.  The roll was very crisp and hard.  I could not it it like a roll and had to open it up and use a fork and knife.  The lobster had no taste, needed some thing to jazz it up.  I think the lobster roll and chowder are better at Woodhouse in the Castro.  At $22.00 a roll, I expected better tasting food.  Probably wont go back.
author: Helen m.

description: I sat at the bar on a Saturday night to order dinner. I had half a dozen west coast oysters, the warm sea urchin, and prawns. Each appetizer being a single serving per average person; all three was sufficient enough for a person (with a bigger appetite) like me. With a roll of crusty bread and all the dishes previously mentioned in my belly i was rather content but as always i need to look at the dessert menu. Decided to have the goat cheese cake. Light and creamy, not too sweet with a sprinkle of cookie crumble on top, figs and a hint of basil in the mix. So yummy with my cappuccino. Bill came to $78 with tip. No alcohol.  I would definitely go back again when I'm there.
author: Miss E.

description: I wasn't all that impressed with Anchor & Hope. The beer list was pretty awesome, ambiance was nice, but when it came to the food.. I expected better. The warm appetizers we ordered, including the sea urchin, all came out cool, as if they had been sitting out too long? Ordered sea bass with chorizo bouillabaisse and I thought the chorizo overpowered the fish. Maybe I need to give it another try and order something else. Experience: ok. Not great.
author: H K.

description: We went as a group of 8 for lunch.  The service was fine, and the food was ok, but nothing about the experience makes me want to go back.  I would say, based on the beer list, that this would be a better place to go after work for drinks & appetizers than for a full meal.
author: Mark L.

description:
This place is in a great space and has a lot of potential, but in the cut throat realm of SF dining, they had better get the food / drink service and customer service down. There are too may great alternatives to select from in this city to return to a place that makes a dozen blunders a night (including, but not limited to, late seating despite our reservation, very late service once we're at the table, and a table seated after us was attended to us prior to us, two wrong food orders served, one wrong wine, food that we were still eating snatched away from the table, etc.). Furthermore, they didn't record our Opentable points despite the fact that the reservation was confirmed by the restaurant and by Opentable. When I called Anchor & Hope to ask about this, I was met with a diffident, jerk of a man who said he really couldn't help me (no explanation of who could) and that I needed to take it up with Open Table . He then "checked" and said there was no record of me having been in the reservation system! This despite the fact that THEY called ME to confirm the reservation. And despite the fact that I can show him the Opentable reservation (still in their system, at least someone keeps things in the system!) and our credit card statement that we paid for dinner.

 Sorry, but the food's not exceptional (or even memorable) enough to reward such pathetic customer service, and there are plenty of other places vying for my disposable income.
author: Ruth M.

description: you know that show "the best thing i ever ate" on food network?  well, they featured this appetizer from anchor & hope - warm sea urchin dungeness crab with lemon beurre blanc sauce and i HAD to try it!  it was to die for when i finally took the first bite, and i couldn't stop myself from enjoying every bite of the scrumptious smooth tasting of warm sea urchin and dungeness crab!  i could eat 3 of them and would be very satisfied, but i also had to try their lobster roll, and it was so yummy too, but nothing beats the best appetizer i ever ate!  just get me 3 of those appetizer and i am in heaven!  the restaurant is situated in an alley kinda had a nyc feel to it!
author: Teresa C.

description:
the 3 stars is based on my experience so it may not be indicative of your experience.  maybe it's a day-eating place.  one yelper mentioned the nice sky-lights which would be a benefit had i went during the day.  maybe i'll try lunch there and it'll be great.  

i've worked in this area for about 7 years now and parked within 50 yards of this place for about 5 years - although, of course, it was not open the entire time.  so i'm one of the hold-outs that just didn't see the need to try the place out earlier.  it's something about the glass front where you can see everybody inside and the metal uncomfortable looking chairs and the not-too-comfy tables that make the place somewhat less of an intimate environment.  it seemed from the outside to be like having dinner in someone's bathroom.  bright lights, hard surfaces, lots of glass.  not so sure about that.  finally stopped in for a quick appetizer and drink and it was okay.  the lobster roll was very blue collar but i think that's on purpose.  i think she actually mentioned: "ketchup" and "mayo" when describing the sauce used in the lobster roll.  but again, i think that's the whole deal.  potato chips, cole slaw (both very good) and the lobster roll with more blue collar ingrediants.  anyway.

i suppose it was a classy touch that when you order a glass of wine, they bring the whole bottle out to you and give you a taste and chat a little bit about the wine before they ask you to fully commit to the glass.  that combined with the fact that they will pour almost every bottle on their list as a glass is nice.  we didn't have a lot to eat so i can't comment on most of the menu, just the lobster roll, wine and decor.  staff seemed helpful although my friend said the waitress was giving her the evil eye.  i thought they were gonna cat-fight for a second.  that would have made it a 5 star review for sure.
author: dan h.

description: I went here with a group of friends to try this new place.  We started out with a few apps that I enjoyed.  The Oysters were fresh and some of the apps were very tasty.  We even ordered a nice bottle of wine in which the Sommelier recommended which was excellent, the Bruc Cellars 2006 Grenache.  The problem started with the main dish.  I ordered the Lobster and when I tasted it, it had an "ammonia" type of odor and flavor to it.  I hate complaining but I mentioned it and they took it back right away and brought me another one.  Unfortunately, the new one had the same odor and flavor.  They were *extremely* nice and apologized and brought me an order of the stone crabs which were very mediocre.  I had amazing stone crabs from Florida many times and these were bland and the meat was a little chewy.  So, I think they are really trying here, but there's definitely something amiss in the kitchen that they need to square out before I can give them some more stars or come back again.  I really want to because they really did try and were nice about it and the space is pretty neat.
author: Mitch A.

description: We had a terrific dinner here last night.  We were a party of six and the staff generously went out of their way to make sure we were seated.  The food was spectacular.  We started with the gravlax salad and fried calamari for the table.  The dressing on the salad was wonderful.  The calamari was fried perfectly.  We each tried different dishes and were passing around bites, as everything was perfectly cooked and wonderfully flavorful.  The only thing missing was a martini.  I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Sarah J.

description:
never again.

the atmosphere is awful.... a cross between a cafeteria, fish shack, and a warehouse. the seating is so unorganized... tables crammed in the middle and then tables literally right at the front door!  it's so loud in there you have to scream to your dinner mates.  

service was awful. waiters very unorganized and not really friendly.  you ask about the specials and they respond "read the chalkboard"-- mind you, you need binoculars to see the chalkboard because it's WAY back in the corner near the entrance....you ask for drinks, water, etc... and then you never get it. you ask for condiments, you never get them.  your utensils are always taken away by the bus boys and then you never get replacements, so you are always having to ask for replacements. the bus boys also make you hand your plates to them when you're done... now remember, this place charges outrageous prices-- so you'd expect some good service. not the case. 

food was ok. way too overpriced. you might as well have been at pier 39. 

never again.
author: brian t.

description: You have to make a reservation even if no one is in the restaurant. Last night we asked for a table but were directed to the bar even though half of the restaurant was empty. Their food is mediocre, but definitely not worth the price tag. Most importantly, my husband had their lobster roll last night and we had to go to the emergency room this morning because of food poisoning. It used to be one of our favorite restaurants and somewhere we would take visitors when they came in town. Not anymore!! One star.
author: K L.

description: We discovered Anchor & Hope while walking around SOMA one evening. As soon as I saw the decor, I knew we had to stay for dinner. Inside, the place was packed on a Weds, and the hostess nicely informed us that she had two seats at their bar, which we promptly accepted. After careful consideration, we decided on some drinks, the most expensive sparkling rose on the menu, and a sweet white for the bf. It took a bit for us to be greeted by our bartendress/server but she was very gracious to offer us a few tastes of champagne to aid us in our decision. The food was pretty amazing,we began with the acorn soup(love the seasonal menu) and then moved on to the calamari(loved the chili peanut sauce) and then shared the paella(bonus for no seafood in it!) and I had the lobster remoulade , the special of the night, which I loved!! It consisted of huge chunks of  lobster and fresh herbs! Overall, good service, great ambiance, and great food! Will be back with family members who love seafood!
author: mia l.

description: I've dined here for dinner (appetizers and entrees) twice, and the food has been good, but not great.  I have found the ingredients used to be fresh and the food prepared properly (not over- or under-done), but the flavor combinations aren't particularly inventive and some ingredients in a dish or flavor combinations don't quite work.  Service has been great both times.  Would give 3.5 stars if that were an option.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Appalling service! We have never been treated so rudely!  From the passive- agressive hostess to the overtly hostile waiter, our entire group agreed that this was by far the WORST service that any of us have ever encountered. I can't comment on the food because the service was bad enough to get up and walk out, but the menu was boring and the location was very scary to walk to. AWFUL experience!
author: jill f.

description: Good to excellent food. Really nice wait staff. They have a great "Express Lunch" deal that includes a drink (choice of one of their coolers, a glass of wine or something non-alcoholic), clam chowder, entree and dessert for $24! Tasty fish & chips. Also enjoyed the trout on sauteed brussel sprouts with bacon. Will definitely go back, esp. for the lunch deal.
author: Dedicated E.

description: what started as the most expensive, but best tasting/looking fish and chips i've ever had later turned to the ickiest belly ache ever. you gotta love over priced food poisoning. great beer selection. i prefer their other place saltbox hands down.
author: casey c.

description: I went here because I saw this place featured on the Food Networks "The Best Thing I've Ever Ate". Aida said the warm sea urchin was the best thing she ever ate. It was in a lemon cream broth with lots of crab which I really liked. I didn't care for the actual sea urchin in the dish, not the restaurant's fault, just didn't like the texture. But I loved the lemon broth, lots of crab and mashed potatoes on the bottom of the shell. My only peeve about the dish, almost every bite of crab I ate, had reminents of shell in it. After every single bite of crab, I had to spit out shell and put it on my bread dish. At the end of the meal, I saw a lot of shell. It was a bit disappointing. Withouth all the shell, I would have given this place 5 stars, but it was just such an elementary mistake..
author: Stefanie G.

description: I'm a big fan of Town Hall and Salt House so I was super excited when they opened a new restaurant specializing in seafood. I was really excited to try Anchor & Hope for the first time. First off the ambiance of the restaurant is great. I've never actually been to a fish house in Maine or New England but it had that kind of feel with the high ceilings and driftwoodesque tables. Really cool place for like a family dinner or second or third date. We started with the "fries with eyes" which was really tasty, little fried fish with remoulade. Be prepared to eat the entire fish though, eyes and head and all. Delish! I had the lobster roll for my entree and while it was good I don't know if I agree with the $25 price tag. It was definitely filling but man I kind of wanted more bang for my buck. Well I wasn't paying but you know what I mean. It's basically a sandwich and chips and yeah I know it's lobster but really? You get like three ounces for $25 bucks (how much do chips and roll cost? like 2 cents?) So yeah, it was tasty but expect to shell out the bucks here for that good ol' ambiance and trendy factor. I did really enjoy my meal though. Also we were able to walk in without a reservation on a Thursday night. We did get seated at the communal table but I thought that made it more fun.
author: Cathy T.

description: yum!  this place was very good and had great servers that made the experience even more enjoyable.  my girlfriend and i shared the warm uni appetizer and it was so good.  for my entree i had the lobster roll with was good but i was eyeing all the dishes around me.
author: Gina T.

description: Fantastic ceviche and oysters!  Good fish-friendly beer (and wine) selections.
author: Julie D.

description: the place has a great atmosphere. loved the independant micro brews on the menu. the food was amazing (could of been a little bigger portion sizes) but my wife and i loved this place. amazing desert too.
author: randy s.

description: Finally dragged my husband here after a long sailing day in Sausalito.  We had early reservations (6:30pm) on a Sunday night, but were late, and called ahead to let them know.  No problem, the place was still in daylight, 1/2 full and friendly vibe when we walked in past 7pm.  Had a great table, in the corner, at 90 degrees of each other, looking out into the restaurant.  The service tried to be attentive, with different staff taking orders, delivering orders, refills etc.  I appreciated the waitress really knowing the wine list, and offering to put 1/2 my glass of white wine chilled while I fnished the first portion.  A first for me!  Loved the"angels on wings" - I had these at Xmas time and raved about them then.  Even hubby tried them.  We both chose one of the specials, which was a "CLT" -Soft Shell Crab, with other incredible ingredients,and a mixt salad on the side.  The service did deteriote slightly through the meal, however my husband did not notice, and they served his cappucino with a single candle for his birthday - very nice touch. Also the first round of drinks was not on the cheque, and we appreciated that.  This is a special, casual place that I would reserve for my friends that appreciate good food, casual but fun atmosphere.  Most of the clientele are in their late 30's and more......  Enjoy.
author: Nancy N.

description: Wow, where to start. We had a group reservation for 8:30 for a friend's birthday and we got there early to make sure we could check-in. Over an hour later and without apology we were seated and then left alone. There didn't seem to be any interest in taking our order and it wasn't until after two hours from arriving at the restaurant that we received our appetizers. Other parties that had arrived after our were seated first and served first. I did not see any effort made to try to accommodate our group or any urgency to provide service. The simple task of refilling water was even neglected. By the end of dinner service the only thing I wanted to do was be able to leave. It seems the only thing they do fast is take your money. I would not recommend this venue if you want attentive service. As for the food, it was generally good (though I believe overpriced). Some of the appetizers were over seasoned with lemon but other than that the food was good. Overall though, the experience left a bad taste in my mouth and I will not be returning there for dinner again.
author: Josh B.

description: Pretty disappointing. The service was not impressive.  I believe we had an 8 pm reservation ... and we sat down at 9:30.  They gave us a few complimentary appetizers which were pretty decent but did not really help our hunger pains.  When we finally sat down, I thought the food was pretty good but not worth trying again given our long wait.  Too bad - it seems like a good concept and the space is nice.
author: Caroline B.

description: Trendy decor in a warehouse - a typical SF restaurant. Alot of seafood dishes... we tried the shrimp cocktail, lobster, and the halibut fish & chips. Shrimp was as expected, nothing special. The lobster was awesome. And the fish and chips were decent with really good rosemary seasons fried potato wedges. Everything was overpriced as expected as well. But I would go back to try a few other dishes. Service was excellent.
author: Michelle R.

description: loved it.  the lobster roll and IPA on tap was FAN freakin tastic and would go back there for it in a heartbeat.  i had gotten there too late for lunch, but they were so kind and opened up the kitchen to make me the lobster roll, which i had heard great things about and was not dissapointed.  big chunks, delic bread, YUM!
author: sara l.

description: i've only been here once, but so far, so good!  we had a drink at the bar before getting dinner, and thoroughly enjoyed both.  it defintely reminds me more of salt house than town hall, but with an emphasis on seafood - the open space is fun and social, the wine selection nicely matches the menu, and everything we ate & drank was delicious.  i love the location as well - definitely a great addition to the neighborhood!
author: Erin C.

description: Nice airy room with lots of two tops and a few very large tables.  The welcome was pleasant the server was nice but frustrated with the kitchen.  I liked her honesty.  My asparagus and poached egg salad was excellent and the trout en papillot was delicious and a nice light entree.  The french baguet also came in a bag and was good.  Extensive wine by the glass menu.  If the kitchen was quicker and the service more attentive I would have given it three stars.  Unfortunately, there are plenty of better alternatives.
author: david a.

description: Great for lunch but stick to Town Hall for dinner.  Seriously, this was glass half full/half empty experience all the way around.  Everything there had an upside and a down side.  Let me explain:  The East Coast fish house theme decor is cool but the metal chairs are cold and uncomfortable.  The staff was fantastic but a little too attentive. if you know what I mean.  The guy behind the bar was great - he let me sample 3 wines before selecting my glass.  The server was fantastic (thin woman with short hair).  She definately found her calling.  The down side was that the busser came over every 3 minutes to try and take plates.  Seriously, he came over more than 5 times and my co-worker had to grab her plate!  The food was good but definately more suited for lunch.  I had the halibut that is served as fish and chips.  It was good but not spectacular.  My co-worker had the lobster roll and it was just okay.  I should have tried the black bass.  We did experiment with an interesting appetizer though.  We tried the sea urchin and the presentation was very cool.  They simply hollowed out a large purple sea urchin and mixed the meat with some potatoes and a sauce.  Somewhat tasty and interesting but I wouldn't order it again.  We skipped desert since nothing sounded good.  Again, check it out for lunch but stick to Town Hall or Salt House for dinner.
author: Kris N.

description: very nice.  service was spot on, food was super good (the stuffed lobster was ace, sea urchin, fries with eyes, bacon wrapped fried oysters were bursting with flavor) atmosphere was really good, the waiters had a great sense of humor too.  will go back for sure.
author: Alfredo I.
